column2: Rigorous tests of the manmade metal plutonium, used in atomic and hydrogen bombs, were described last week by the General Electric Company, which operates the billion-dollar plutonium-producing plant at Hanford, Wash., for the Atomic Energy Commission.

ONE of the pleasant things about the new and growing interest in the literature of modern Greece is the lively literacy of the texts that subserve it -- to which we should add, and gratefully, the sensitivity and competence of such interpreters as Lawrence Durrell.

It is astonishing how much of current news has to do with what used to be called "The Dark Continent." The Congo has been in the news for many months, Algeria for half a dozen years, South Africa ever since the turn of the century. Ruanda-Urundi is newer in the news, but it is important because what happens there may be the reflection of what happens in the Congo or in South Africa.

THE dust-jacket of "The Annals of Logan" describes Robert Graham's work as "a lyric commentary on our world of big business"; a more conventional description would be, "a novel in verse." This book "about corporation men," complete with Table of Organization, tells in a series of monologues the story of how one ineffectual man is reduced to a state of insanity by the sudden realization that his boss despises him.

IN the Nineteen Thirties Bernard Shaw published four volumes of selections from his musical criticism. The present volume, edited by Dan H. Laurence, is a cross-section of what Shaw left uncollected. It contains some of Shaw's earliest articles, some of them unsigned and spans a period from 1876 to 1950.

PARIS, March 18 -- France embarked this week on a course that seemed destined to end French sovereignty over the last remaining bit of her once great African empire. Agreement by President de Gaulle's Government and the provisional government of the Algerian Moslem rebels to begin negotiations, probably before the end of March, to end nearly six-and-a-half years of rebellion can have only two possible outcomes.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., March 18 -- Seemingly isolated although State Highway 150 with its tourist traffic runs within a stone's throw, the ninety-acre Sanja Cota Indian Reservation at Santa Ynez is gradually taking on the luxuries of civilization so close at hand.

BOOTLEGGING and political skulduggery are the topics of this Southern novel. It is all right to call it a Southern novel, despite its being a Yankee-eye view of the Deep South, because David Halberstam writes with comprehension if not with love. Bloodless murder, cruelty enjoyed and sex for sale are minor sauces in this by no means unpalatable stew.

DETROIT, March 18 -- The first position papers on the 1961 automobile negotiations have been issued, leaving little doubt that the usual battle over sizable economic gains will be injected into this summer's contract talks.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI) -- The Automotive Safety Foundation urged today development of a "driving simulator" as a major contribution to highway safety.

THE Galapagos Islands have a special significance in biology -- and in the history of ideas -- because it was there, in 1835, that Charles Darwin first consciously started to speculate about the origin of species. Why were almost all the animals and plants of the islands so very different from kinds found on the mainland?

Permit me to express a few remarks concerning the constitutional controversy which has evolved with regard to Federal aid to nonpublic schools. It is of course a fact of constitutional development that the Supreme Court of the United States has never directly passed upon this important constitutional issue.
HACKENSACK, N.J., March 18 -- Voters in twelve of Bergen County's seventy-three school districts said "no" twice to school budgets last month.
Cutting an impressive swath in the Intercollegiate Fencing Association championships, New York University yesterday took three-weapon honors and tied for the saber team crown.
PHILADELPHIA, March 18 -- Plans are under way here for the establishment of one of the most complete cancer research centers in the United States.
PINKHAM NOTCH, N.H., March 18 -- Gordon Eaton, Middlebury College's schussing sophomore, put on another fine performance today and captured the men's national giant slalom crown with surprising ease.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 (AP) -- Bob Goalby carded a four-under-par 67 today for a 196 total and a one-stroke lead at the end of three rounds of the St. Petersburg open golf tournament.
CARLINVILLE, Ill., March 16 -- "How're the sows doing?" asked Orlando G. Leach after the new tenant had jumped down from the tractor to greet him.

THE New York Stock Exchange is one of the half-dozen most popular free tourist attractions in the city, particularly in these days of heavy trading. Last year, with 450,000 visitors, it broke a record set in 1959.

Substantial disarmament could help speed up the rate of economic growth in both Communist and non-Communist countries, some of the world's leading economists agreed earlier this month at an international conference on the economics of disarmament.
CASA GRANDE, Ariz., March 18 -- Westward flows the course of baseball empires and with it has come a training-camp boom for Arizona.
A Western diplomat who visited Communist China not long ago has estimated that recent production difficulties set back the economic-development program by at least five years.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 18 -- A Speedy band of St. Joseph's Hawks flew around Wake Forest's highest peak -- Len Chappell -- tonight and won the Eastern regional play-offs of the National Collegiate basketball championship.
A ferryboat bound for Manhattan from Staten Island was the setting for the hold-up Friday night of three passengers, who were threatened with being thrown overboard if they resisted.
HONG KONG, March 14 -- Communist China is going all out to make a spectacular success of the world table tennis championships beginning in Peiping next month.

BONN, Germany, March 18 -- The last test of strength between Chancellor Adenauer's Christian Democrats and the opposition Socialists prior to this fall's general elections will take place tomorrow when 15,000,000 voters in two West German states elect local governments.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 18 -- Contested elections are scheduled in six of the ten Suffolk County villages that will select officials next Tuesday.

POPLAR BLUFF, Mo., March 18 (UPI) -- Douglas W. Thompson, desperado who surrendered yesterday on the advice of an elderly farm woman, was charged today with the murder of a motorist who gave him a ride.

A WEEKLY "appraisal of the printed press" will be initiated April 23 by the Columbia Broadcasting System's television station here. To be written and presented by Charles Collingwood, the program will be televised on Sundays from 3:45 to 4 P.M. under the title "WCBS-TV Views the Press."

OPERA singing is primarily exhibitionistic singing, with the accent on pure voice. A lieder singer can accomplish miracles with brains and style, and many international careers have been made on the concert stage by singers with little voice.

CAIRO, March 18 -- Plans to present a touring American Theatre Guild Company in Cairo next month have been dropped because United Arab Republic authorities objected to the fact that the troupe had included a visit to Israel on its itinerary.
Patrons and friends of the Museum of the City of New York are planning to attend the performance of the Moiseyev Dance Company at the Metropolitan Opera House the evening of April 26.
Lord Balfour of Inchrye is a man who advocates discontent.
WARSAW, March 18 -- Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski and Wladyslaw Gomulka entered into open conflict-tonight over the relationship of the Roman Catholic Church and the state in Poland.
One of the world's few experts in marine seismic refraction and reflection investigations was killed Friday in an explosion aboard the Columbia University research ship Vema in the Pacific off Chile.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 18 -- Antoine Gizenga, political heir to the late Patrice Lumumba, rejected today the establishment of a confederation of Congolese provinces.
RICHLAND, Wash., March 18 (AP) -- A seven-and-a-half-month labor dispute at the Hanford Atomic Works was settled early today.
MEXICO CITY, March 18 -- One of the oldest and knottiest problems of Mexico, the invasion of private property, has arisen to plague the Government again this week.
Broklyn Tech captured the Public Schools Athletic League team swimming title last night at New York University's Quigley Pool in the Bronx. Four meet records were set.

WAILUKU, Island of Maui, Hawaii -- The park system of this island state is scheduled to undergo a change of organization next summer. At present, Hawaii National Park is the joint designation for two big tracts, one here on the island of Maui and the other on the island of Hawaii, which is south of Maui.

PHILADELPHIA -- Variety and innovation marked the national photographic trade show here last week. More than 10,000 persons registered for the five-day event, which was held under the sponsorship of the Master Photo Dealers and Finishers Association.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, March 16 -- Moise Tshombe, the fast-rising political star in the Congo, has one major liability that so far has overshadowed his qualities: He is regarded internationally as a "Belgian puppet."

MINEOLA, L.I., March 18 -- Nassau County Executive A. Holly Patterson met here today with ranking members of the local Republican party, apparently in an effort to head off open warfare in the party ranks.

With your pictures of covered bridges ("Bridges to the Past," March 5) you quoted a couple of lines of eloquent poetry. I wonder if the whole poem is available; I am sure many readers would enjoy seeing it.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Kennedy Administration has developed specific ideas on foreign aid "burden-sharing" that it will propose to the development assistance group conference in London March 27 to 29.
SAN JUAN, P.R., March 18 -- One of the nation's largest maritime unions has made clear its determination to win wider Government attention to the problems of the merchant marine.

VIENTIANE, Laos, March 18 -- The pro-Communist Pathet Lao movement, its eleven-day-old offensive still rolling, has artillery within twenty-two miles of the royal capital of Luang Prabang, an informed military source said today.

ATLANTA, March 18 -- While thumbing through their mail this week, thousands of Atlantans found a postcard inviting them to draft a local civic leader as a mayoralty candidate. The invitation was signed by one of the South's leading bankers, a group that traditionally shuns open involvement in politics.
A total of $128,000,000 was raised by Jewish federations, welfare funds and community councils last year to meet local, national and overseas Jewish needs.

THE main issue that appears whenever a new Bible translation is published was well phrased by Lafcadio Hearn. No stranger to the shocking statement, he ventured the "not altogether true" but "partly true" opinion that "it is only since Englishmen ceased to believe in the Bible that they began to discover how beautiful it was."
DETROIT, March 18 (UPI) -- James Bolatto and Marion Hetelle of Marseilles, Ill., bowled a 1,246 today for fourth place in regular-division doubles of the American Bowling Congress tournament.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- Senator Alan Bible asked the Treasury Department today to re-examine what he termed a policy of selling too much silver at prices below the world market.

MIAMI, March 18 (AP) -- The first yacht race from Miami to Montego Bay, Jamaica, got under way today in beautiful weather and a spanking 15-to-18-knot breeze that sent the ten craft skimming swiftly out of the harbor.
GOROKA, New Guinea, March 18 -- The natives of the Territory of Papua and New Guinea took their first feeble step toward self-rule today.
NEW HAVEN, March 18 -- The population explosion and the threat of nuclear warfare were major topics at a two-day symposium on world medicine that ended today at the Yale University Medical School.
Subtle end-of-game play by Mikhail Tal of Latvia enabled the world chess champion to win the second game of the title match with Mikhail Botvinnik of Leningrad in forty-five moves yesterday.

DURING the spring holidays just ahead, teenagers by the hundreds of thousands will begin putting out feelers for summer jobs. They will be wise to start early because this year the general economic recession and the increased teen-age population combine to make their prospects far from bright.
Pickets marched in front of four legitimate theatres here yesterday.
The Flight Engineers' International Association suffered a setback last week in its attempt to set aside a scheduled election among flight crews on United Air Lines.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 18 -- Ed I. McKinley Jr., a segregationist who served briefly as president of the Little Rock School Board, has been appointed acting postmaster here.

PAY-AS-YOU-SEE television, which for years has been a subject of unlimited verbiage and very little practical result, showed its true potential last week with an absolutely brilliant presentation of Gian Carlo Menotti's opera, "The Consul."
Despite the college basketball investigation, bookmakers continued to accept bets from their clients on yesterday's National Invitation Tournament games at Madison Square Garden.

FOR THIS WEEK: Spring's arrival this week spurs gardeners to go outside and start work, but until the weather settles and snow melts everywhere, patience is the rule. . . . Continue pruning shrubs, trees and fruits. . . . Browned leaves on every greens indicate drying from winds and winter sun; spring growth will replace battered foliage. . . .
The need for greater flexibility in United States foreign trade policies was presented in exceptional detail last week in a staff report issued by the Senate Commerce Committee.

Just as war cannot be left entirely to the generals, neither can humor be left to the professional humorists. This is the conclusion reached by a group of interested citizens who are worried about the state of humor in this country.
G. Mermen Williams, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, arrived yesterday from a month's tour of sixteen African countries.
NEW DELHI, India, March 13 -- Continuing problems in the treatment of religious minorities are evident in both India and Pakistan.

The marketplace for which Joseph Wharton sought to promote "competence and morality" when he founded a school of business at the University of Pennsylvania in 1881 plays a much more pervasive role in America today.

CHICAGO, March 19 (AP) -- Old crop soybean futures mustered some fairly substantial gains on the Board of Trade last week but other contracts and the grains finished lower under rather persistent selling pressure.
THE Japanese housewife, eagerly cheered on by inventive Japanese electric appliance manufacturers, is racing happily toward the don't-do-it-yourself age.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- The Graham Foundation for Advanced Studies in the Fine Arts announced today the award of nine fellowships for advanced studies in the fine arts. The one-year grants are for $5,000 to $7,500.

ALBANY, March 19 -- Another last-minute rush is in the making as this year's regular legislative session heads for adjournment this week. All indications are that in the remaining days the Legislature will approve nearly as many bills as it has approved since the present session began on Jan. 4.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Kennedy faces a test in Congress this week as the House takes up his minimum wage bill.

I have read with profound sorrow both the "high road" defense of the House Committee on Un-American Activities in the recent Supreme Court majority opinions in the Wilkinson and Braden cases and Representative Walter's "low road" assault upon Representative James Roosevelt for opposing appropriations for its investigations.
Something tells me that whatever the missile age and the astronauts might be up to, John Doe and Richard Roe are going to remain earth-bound till the end of their natural days.
Extensive amusements offering "wholesome fun" will be part of the World's Fair, Robert Moses said yesterday.

PARIS, March 19 -- Premier Michel Debre hinted tonight that France might insist on partitioning Algeria into French and independent areas if the population of the territory voted to break all French ties.

Trafalgar Hospital, a 136-bed, voluntary general hospital at 161 East Ninetieth Street, will be the beneficiary of a cocktail dance Sunday in the Carnegie International Center, 345 East Forty-sixth Street.
I have just read your editorial of March 15 entitled "The Kennedy Plan."

Secretary of State Rusk's five-hour conference with Soviet Foreign Minister Gromyko last Saturday afternoon was a vivid expression of the new spirit and tactics the Kennedy Administration is putting into our policy toward Russia. Before last Saturday's meeting there had been Ambassador Thompson's long visit with Premier Khrushchev in Novosibirsk and Adlai Stevenson's repeated contacts with Mr. Gromyko here at the United Nations.
The leader of the African independence movement in Angola deplored here yesterday the "extreme violence" of the Africans against Portuguese settlers in the north Angloan province of Sao Salvador.

Organized labor charged yesterday that administration of the State Workmen's Compensation Law was tending to make its protections meaningless. A court fight was announced against the board chairman of the Workmen's Compensation Law.

DETROIT, March 19 (UPI) -- Jean Beliveau and Claude Provost scored goals tonight as the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 2 -- 0, and captured their fourth straight National Hockey League championship.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI) -- In another action today, the commission entered a consent order under which the Aluminum Company of America and its subsidiaries are to stop using "false and misleading" demonstrations to sell "new super strength Alcoa wrap."

BONN, Germany, March 19 -- George W. Ball, United States Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, arrived today and started informal talks with West German Government officials aimed at coordinating Western aid to less-developed nations.
A newly-formed steamship company, the Overseas Carriers Corporation, has bought two vessels from the Luckenbach Steamship Company fleet for $1,600,000.

THE distinctive tone and quality of frequency-modulation radio was illustrated in an unusual program for an unusual cause yesterday. For twelve hours -- from noon to midnight -- station WBAI-FM displayed a special sampling of its wares to raise additional public funds for its operating costs.

GULFPORT, Miss., Mar. 19 (AP) -- Buster Cupit, the 1960 victor, fought a driving wind and heavy rain today and won the abbreviated $5,000 Gulf Coast invitation golf tournament. Play was halted at the 54-hole point of the scheduled 72-hole event.

PINKHAM NOTCH, N.H., March 19 -- The men's national Alpine skiing championships ended in two protests and a series of disqualifications today as Canada and the United States shared top special-slalom honors on Wildcat Mountain.

Dick Gregory, the 28-year-old Negro night-club performer who is making his local debut at the Blue Angel, is the only member of his race thus far to join with and hold his own in the ranks of the bright, young, intellectually oriented, wittily topical, stand-up comics.

Ten pivotal anal controversial Presidential decisions in American history are discussed in "Decisions of Destiny," a new book by Richard L. Tobin. The decisions show how the nature of the Presidency has molded and been molded by its incumbents.

The current expressions of concern over the marked switch in the past six months in Democratic concern for adequate staffing of the Federal bench are well-founded in principle, although unsupported by historical tradition. Throughout our history one of the important spoils of the party in power has been the appointing of Federal judges.
The American Civil Liberties Union made public yesterday a statement by 250 American college and university professors urging the abolition of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

JERUSALEM, March 19 -- The coordinator of an Israeli archaeological expedition in the Judaean desert described today some of the rich new finds from the period of the Jewish rebellion against the Romans in A.D. 132-135.

David Lloyd, whose contributions to the musical life of New York have been as numerous as they have been splendid, has usually appeared here with orchestra or in opera. On Saturday night at Judson Hall the tenor gave a recital instead.
GENEVA, March 19 -- The Swiss stock markets ended last week with a flourish that compensated for the earlier sag because of profit-taking.

The Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken urged yesterday that the Christian principles of "loving one's enemies and nonresistance to evil" replace "cynicism and retaliation" in this country's dealings with the Soviet Union.

LOS ANGELES, March 19 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Lakers moved into the Western Division finals by crushing the Detroit Pistons, 137 -- 120, in the fifth game of their National Basketball Association play-off series today.
The Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association held its twenty-eighth anniversary dinner last night at the Manhattan Hotel, honoring stars and coaches of the sport.
TUNIS, March 19 -- The problem at the head of a list of issues that might disrupt the French-Algerian peace negotiations is the Saharan question, according to best informed North African quarters.
HAVANA, March 19 -- Public schools in Cuba will close April 15 to let students serve in a 100,000-member "army of education" ordered by Premier Fidel Castro to eradicate illiteracy.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- Four manufacturers of pain-relief preparations were accused today of making false advertising claims about the speed with which their products work.
Eastern Air Lines has asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for permission to try a reduced-fare airline shuttle service between New York and Washington and New York and Boston.

WARSAW, March 19 -- Stefan Cardinal Wyszinski, head of the Roman Catholic Church in Poland, is girding for another trial of nerves, determination and faith in a struggle with his nation's Communist regime.
THE first week-end of the New York City Ballet's season at the City Center restored four works to the repertory. With one exception they were all familiarly cast.
The final concert of the seventh season of the Brooklyn Philharmonia took place at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Saturday night and featured an excellent performance of the Verdi Requiem.

Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin told 300 American Jewish leaders here yesterday that it would be a great mistake to try to forget the crimes of the Nazis, but that there was no danger of a Nazi revival.
The earnings of hired farm laborers last year were the lowest of any segment of the nation's economy, the National Sharecroppers Fund, Inc., said yesterday.

LUANDA, Angola, March 19 -- Portuguese Army forces were reported today to be moving into position to seal off the rebel-troubled Congo district of northern Angola and prepare for a large-scale mopping-up operation.
The field of insurgent Democrats seeking to end Carmine G. De Sapio's rule as Tammany leader in Greenwich Village has been narrowed to two.

"Gallows Humor," formerly called "Galgenhumor," has undergone a sudden change of sponsorship. The Jack Richardson play will be put on by Richard Barr and Clinton Wilder rather than Norman Twain and Helen Kamber.
Mayor Wagner entered Memorial Hospital yesterday for surgery to remove a tumor beneath his right ear.
Stereotypers on daily newspapers in the metropolitan area voted unanimously yesterday to ask their international union to sanction a strike vote against the papers.
Opposition to moves against licensing chiropractors in New York State was announced yesterday by the Chiropractic Association of New York, Inc.
WARSAW, March 19 -- Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, apparently ready for a showdown struggle, hurled defiance today at Poland's Communist "Caesars."
THAT pearls come out of oyster shells is well known, but it took a vivacious young French woman to produce a whole collection of jewelry from a seashell.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 19 -- The use of rivers as commercial transport routes has increased in the last ten years at twice the average rate for all other forms of transportation, a Princeton University conference has reported.
NEW DELHI, India, March 19 -- Former Premier Souvanna Phouma of Laos declared today that he was "completely pleased" by an apparent shift in United States policy toward his war-torn country.

CAIRO, March 19 -- More than three millennia ago a splendid, boastful civilization flourished along the upper stretches of the loud-sounding Nile as it roared through cataracts in the area where the Sudan today joins Egypt. This was the ancient land of Kush, or Nubia, a Vice Royalty of the powerful Pharaohs.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 19 -- Roger Reiman, a 24-year-old mechanic from Kewanee, Ill., won the American Motorcycle Association's 200-mile national experts championship race today.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- A widely acclaimed "champion suggester" among Army, Navy and Air Force civilian employes throughout the world is Elmer P. Riddick Sr., a photolithographer at the Norfolk Naval Shipyard, Portsmouth, Va.

An influential United States Government adviser on Soviet affairs charges that Soviet envoys in the West are spreading false rumors about Premier Khrushchev's position in the Kremlin power structure as a means of extorting important concessions from Western nations.
The city school system continues to be plagued by a simultaneous feast and famine of pupils, the Board of Education reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Kennedy Administration hopes that Moscow will heed what Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko was told yesterday by Secretary of State Dean Rusk in their long talk on the crisis in Laos.

MOSCOW, March 19 -- Pravda's correspondent in New York charged today that he and his Soviet colleagues in the United States had been subjected to humiliations, police surveillance, searches of their homes and general discrimination.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- A Congressional committee criticized today the construction of a multi-million-dollar camp that suits neither the United States, which put up the money nor the branches of the Pakistan Army that use it.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 19 -- Interior Minister Cyrille Adoula and three other members of the central Government flow today to Luluabourg, provincial capital of Kasai, following reports of severe unrest there.
PITTSBURGH, March 19 -- Jewish women's leader criticized tonight American Jewish spokesmen who "impulsively rush into print whenever an unexpected Israeli development occurs."
The First National City Bank of New York has leased 25,000 square feet of space in the Pan Am Building, which is being constructed at 200 Park Avenue, adjoining Grand Central Terminal.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Manufacturers of durable goods booked more new orders, and sold more, in February than in January, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Even in booming Australia it is possible for the American investor to lose his shirt. Most everyone knows the Australian success stories: how, for example, General Motors-Holden's rose from nothing to a giant, practically overnight, and began turning huge profits.

The report of the National Sharecroppers Fund on the condition of farm labor in 1960 shows a growing public awareness of its problems, especially those of the migrant workers, and some amelioration of their lot, but with wages, working conditions and Government protection shockingly substandard.

Camilla Williams gave a program last night at Town Hall that was her first recital here in three years. As is customary with the soprano, everything was sung with sympathy, much was charming and some songs were lovely.
One of the big marketing battles of the decade ahead appears to lie in the area of the electric typewriter.
German and American music made up the substance of Marian Parry Thompson's debut program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. It was a handsome program, well sung.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy said today the Justice Department was investigating alleged price-fixing of meat, milk, drugs and other products.
The program played by the New York Philharmonic in Carnegie Hall Saturday night had one work in common with the orchestra's other regular weekend concerts.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 19 -- There's a big international resurgence of interest in that grim segment of history known as the Third Reich, and William L. Shirer this week-end suddenly found himself embroiled in the echo as he was in the original enactment.
Some underprivileged children will have vacations at summer camps as the result of the second annual Shower of Violets Supper Dance in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on April 7.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- After a bothersome prelude, the nation's money supply in this recession has expanded as much as, if not more than, in the other three since World War II.
MIAMI, March 19 -- The New York Yankees turned from players to playing fields today in a press conference before their exhibition game with the Baltimore Orioles.
Two big private bus companies in Manhattan and the Bronx have asked the city for permission to increase their present transfer charge of 3 cents to a nickel.

LONDON, March 19 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies of Australia said today that he had wanted to keep South Africa in the British Commonwealth. He added that he believed her racial separation policy -- apartheid -- would not work.
ROME, March 19 (AP) -- Italy had a balance of payments credit of $521,600,000 in 1960 although her trade deficit more than doubled.

BONN, Germany, March 19 (AP) -- Chancellor Adenauer's Christian Democrats scored impressive gains over the Socialists today in municipal elections in the key West German states of Lower Saxony and North Rhine-Westphalia.

In a plea for Federal aid to parochial schools, a Roman Catholic spokesman said yesterday that members of his faith had always been considered "first-class" citizens on the battlefield and should be so regarded in the school issue.

AUSTIN, Tex., March 19 -- Two weeks before the Texas special Senatorial election, it looks as if liberalism, especially as represented by the Kennedy Administration's legislative program, is in for a defeat.

American Machine Foundry Company, net earnings in 1960 rose 21 per cent to a record of $24,104,000, equal to $3.06 a common share, from $19,888,000, or $2.55 a share, in 1959, Morehead Patterson, chairman, told stockholders in the annual report released today.

Harness-racing fans are not doing handsprings over the opening night feature -- a thin $6,000 pace -- but they are expected to be on hand by the thousands tonight for the reopening of Yonkers Raceway.
A preview of some of the material in a proposed Broadway musical, "Kicks Co.," will be televised March 28 on "The Dave Garroway Today Show" over the National Broadcasting Company network.
SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 19 -- Two Long Island rookies may pull up the Boston Red Sox.

BOSTON, March 19 (UPI) -- Frank Ramsey and Bob Cousy paced the Boston Celtics to a 128-115 victory over the Syracuse Nationals today in the opening game of the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division championship playoffs.
More persons will be questioned today at the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan about the college basketball scandal.
OPERATIONAL analysis, the "application of analytical and scientific methods" to the solution of military problems, is now exercising a major influence upon military decisions.

New Delhi is trying to get rid of its beggars. According to recent reports, a new law making alms-collecting illegal has caused 6,700 beggars to flee the city already. If experience in India and elsewhere means anything, those who have fled (if they really have) will be sure to flee back.

ROME, March 19 -- The first shipment of Italian-produced oil from Iran arrived today giving the influential chief of the state fuel trust an opportunity to magnify his formula of assistance to underdeveloped areas.

Net income of Pullman, Inc., in 1960 declined to $12,065,501, or $2.63 a share, from $13,542, 752, or $2.93 a share, in 1959, the company reported yesterday. Revenues rose to $425,167,735 from $406,870,010.

PROVIDENCE, March 19 -- Ch. Zamitz' Jumpin' Jack, owned by Waseeka Kennels of Ashland, Mass., and handled by Robert Forsyth, took best-of-show and best American-bred honors in the forty-fifth Providence County Kennel Club fixture at the Cranston Street Armory today.
Prof. Owen Lattimore, authority on the history, culture and politics of Central Asia, has received a visa to spend the summer in the Mongolian People's Republic.

LONDON, March 19 -- "They all end up with the shakes." This was the comment of a banker in the City of London the other day on a special breed of men who have just been through an unusually hectic two weeks -- the foreign exchange dealers.

BRUSSELS, March 19 -- The Theatre Guild American Repertory Company won applause and critical superlatives here before leaving today for the Netherlands. They will play Amsterdam, Rotterdam and The Hague on the next three nights.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 19 -- An empty tiger cage in the Central Park Zoo brought sorrow today to Rajeshwar Dayal, the Indian diplomat who is Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's personal representative in the Congo.

PHILADELPHIA, March 19 -- The Ukrainian Nationals defeated Baltimore Pompei, 4-0, in a National Challenge Cup match sponsored by the United States Soccer Football Association at Huston Field today. At half-time, the victors had a 2-0 lead.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- An effort to place the varied and scattered problems of mass transportation into new perspective as part of the national problem of metropolitan growth is gaining strength in Congress.
Five new films are scheduled to arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follows:
LONDON, March 19 -- Despite South Africa's unsettling decision to leave the Commonwealth, the stock market continued to gain last week.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- The railroad industry -- for the third time in three years -- started a major push today for Governmental action to help ailing carriers regain some degree of national well being.
PITTSBURGH, March 19 -- Steel officials say the recovery is continuing. However, they admit they are puzzled by the lagging pace of the order rise.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $82,244,961,909. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:
The modernization of eight commuter railroads in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut region through low-interest Federal loans and broad tax aid was recommended yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 19 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has extended the term of Rajeshwar Dayal, his controversial special representative in the Congo. Mr. Dayal's dismissal had been demanded repeatedly by Joseph Kasavubu, President of the Congo.
The National Association of Manufacturers announced yesterday a program to create more jobs. Major planks are tax reform and "curbing of abuses of union power."

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., March 19 (AP) -- Dr. Eugene Carson Blake charged today that the John Birch Society and others were waging "campaigns of falsehoods" against the Presbyterian Church and the National Council of Churches.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 -- Two years after the St. Louis Cardinals had gloated over the acquisition of Lindy McDaniel at what seemed to be a bargain bonus price of $50,000, they were further delighted when he was joined on the pitching staff by his kid brother, Von, also an apparent bargain at $50,000.

This marks the fortieth year that the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, 251 Park Avenue South, New York 10, has served the people of New York City. In its first year, 1921, the federation was a group of twenty-two childcare agencies. Today it is a network of 224 health and welfare agencies which operate 412 distinct programs.

RABAT, Morocco, March 19 -- The Jews of Morocco called today for greater authority in the direction of their own affairs at the first Jewish congress since Morocco achieved independence five years ago.
A program designed to raise the professional level of the American theatre has been announced by the Ford Foundation.
New York City's first comprehensive street-system map was filed 150 years ago Wednesday.

Just before he became President Kennedy's top tax collector, Mortimer Caplin prepared an article discussing recent legislation that was designed to put different kinds of businesses on a relatively equal tax footing.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 (UPI) -- Bob Goalby set a record of eight consecutive birdies for a 65 today and won the St. Petersburg open golf tournament by three strokes.

The New York State Senate will, we hope, have a higher sense of public responsibility than that shown by the Assembly last week when the latter approved a thoroughly deplorable constitutional amendment to permit the leasing of public lands in the forest preserve for private benefit.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., March 19 (AP) -- Chuck Kocsis of Royal Oak, Mich., and Armand Cerami of New York posted their second straight six-under-par 66 today and won the men's international four-ball amateur golf title with a 72-hole total of 266.

James Felt, chairman of the City Planning Commission, said yesterday that the commission would "in general" stand by its recent disapproval of construction of municipal parking garages in midtown Manhattan.

CEDARHURST, L.I., March 19 -- G. Diehl Mateer Jr. and John Hentz of the Merion Cricket Club in Philadelphia defeated Lorne Main and David Pemberton-Smith of Montreal, 15-9, 9-15, 15-12, 15-8, in the final of the twenty-sixth United States squash racquets doubles championship at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Protestant Episcopal Church urged its members in every state today to work for abolition of the death penalty on the ground that it violates Christian teaching, brutalizes society and fails to deter crime.

MANILA, March 19 (UPI) -- Gabriel (Flash) Elorde of the Philippines retained the world junior lightweight title tonight by scoring a unanimous decision over Joey Lopes of Sacramento, Calif., in a fifteen-round bout.

On Thirty-sixth Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, where a neighborhood works in an atmosphere of demolition and decay, a Presbyterian church that started almost from scratch last August now conducts services in four languages, and runs athletic programs for 150 teen-agers.

BERLIN, March 19 -- East Germany announced today that it would scrap its entire aircraft industry because of "grave economic problems" facing the country. A shortage of raw materials and labor as well as general industrial dislocation has also forced the Communist regime to cut sharply the production goals for 1961.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Shutting off the leaks in this capital is about as futile as dampening a Senator in full cry along the campaign trail.

ALBANY, March 19 -- The 1961 Legislature is scheduled to adjourn this week, but it faces one of the heaviest closing work loads of recent years. Present plans call for the legislators to wind up their regular session sometime Friday evening, but debate until Saturday afternoon or evening is not at all unlikely.

LOME, Togo, Monday March 20 (Reuters) -- Togo, the smallest independen nation in Africa, made public today the draft of a proposed Constitution that would give the country a government patterned generally after that of the United States.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The State Department has under study charges by Soviet correspondents concerning humiliations and harassments.
William F. Laporte, president of American Home Products Corporation, commented:
"The general public just seemed to be buying all over the lot."
CAIRO, March 19 -- Three hundred African nationalist leaders will arrive in Cairo this week intent on pushing measures to isolate South Africa politically and economically.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., March 19 -- James Bostwick of Westbury, L.I., won the Tuxedo Gold Racquet racquets tournament and the Tuxedo Gold Racquet court tennis tournament today at the Tuxedo Racquets and Tennis Club.

LoisAnn Oakes, mezzosoprano, made her New York debut in Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon accompanied by Sergius Kagen. A graduate of both Yale and the Juilliard School of Music, Miss Oakes teaches at Ohio State University.

The foreign exchange market returned to a more normal state during the past week following the confusion that existed in previous sessions. British pound sterling showed a steadier undertone while the Canadian dollar and some European rates turned easier. Business transacted was moderate.

PHILADELPHIA., March 19 -- Dottie O'Neil of Norwich, Conn., regained the women's Middle Atlantic badminton championship today by defeating McGregor Stewart, the defender from Baltimore, 3 -- 11, 11 -- 6, 11 -- 7, at the Wissahickon Badminton Club.

The Citizens Budget Commission made public yesterday the twelfth edition of its "Pocket Summary of City Finances." The folder, measuring 3 by 5 inches, shows that "the cost of everything is going up, and the limit is nowhere in sight."
The Maritime Administration, housekeeper for a dwindling fleet of war-built Victory and Liberty vessels now in reserve status, is about to sell surplus ship equipment valued at $29,000,000.

TO parents who have been inclined to relax on Saturday mornings and to place their children under the trusteeship of television, it can be reported that Shari Lewis is an admirable electronic governess.

GENEVA, March 19 -- The United States and British delegations are preparing for Tuesday's resumption of negotiations here for a nuclear test ban with the realization that the Soviet Union, after two and a half years, is losing interest in an agreement isolated from general disarmament.
DENVER, March 19 -- The contest for the national open pair championship entered its two final sessions today in the American Contract Bridge League's spring national tournament here.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 19 -- Gene Parchinski's free throw with one second remaining enabled Bishop Loughlin to defeat St. Peter's of Staten Island, 51 -- 50, in the final of the fourth annual Iona College Catholic High School invitation basketball tournament today.
An interior branch of the New York sidewalk engineers has been meeting daily for the last eight weeks to appraise the construction of new moving stairways in the Port Authority Bus Terminal.
Come next week, the State of Ohio will still be the thirty-fifth largest in area in the country, seventeenth to be admitted to the Union and fifth in salt production.
The National Hockey League season ended on a lively note for the New York Rangers last night at Madison Square Garden.
BUENOS AIRES, March 19 -- President Arturo Frondizi's Radical Intransigent party won a sweeping victory in municipal elections in Santa Fe Province today.
Sylvia Zaremba, pianist, played a recital in Judson Hall last night just twenty years and four days after having made her Town Hall debut at the age of 10.
BOSTON, March 19 (UPI) -- The Boston Bruins closed their worst National Hockey League season tonight with a 4-3 triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 19 -- The wealthier nations should lend $2,000,000,000 a year to the poorer ones for public works and services during the Nineteen Sixties, Paul G. Hoffman said today.

The Barnacles, a group of Government and business executives in the transportation world, has chosen Francis J. Barry, president of Circle Lines-Sightseeing Yachts, Inc., as the "Waterfront Man of the Year" 1960.

The Rev. Vincent McCorry, an associate editor of America, the weekly Jesuit publication, deplored yesterday the criminal element in large-scale college athletics and briefly indicated his support of Federal aid to private education.
The season for spreading the wealth will start today when some 40,000 speculators are expected to make their way to Aqueduct for the opening of the thoroughbred racing campaign here.
MOTHERS who feel trapped by their family responsibilities and long for a career might consider the reasons that some career-minded people have chosen child rearing as their life work.
MIAMI, March 19 -- Whatever it is the Yankees are trying to prove, they are doing a thorough job of it.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 -- For the first time, the combined use of surgery and drugs in certain cancer cases has virtually achieved the status of the preferred treatment, specialists reported here.

American Electric Power Company and subsidiaries reported over the week-end a gain of 6.7 per cent in net income for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28. The report placed net income at $53,831,000, equal to $2.46 a share, against $50,447,000, or $2.38 a share on fewer shares, a year earlier.
Fuller Smith Ross, Inc., has named William E. Holden a senior vice president and manager of the New York office. He also has been appointed a director of the agency.

Eleven Rome Prize Fellowships were announced yesterday by Michael Rapuano, president of the American Academy in Rome. They are for one year beginning Oct. 1 and include $3,000, free residence and use of a studio at the academy.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that he would propose a $57,300,000 increase in pay for 160,500 city employes.
Wagner's "Parsifal" will be given its traditional Good Friday matinee by the Metropolitan Opera on March 31.
A new program to prepare specialists to deal with the political, social and economic problems of Africa will be offered at Columbia University next fall.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Mrs. William B. Long's Pembroke Welsh Corgi, Ch. Willets Red Jacket, of Carlisle, Mass., became best in show of the National Capital Kennel Club dog show tonight, proving anew how uncertain are the fortunes of dog competition.

THE untabulated cost of an unassuming dinner check is all too often an unappetizing environment, even though the food may be fine. As for service, this is frequently of the catch-as-catch-can variety, while intimacy of surroundings loses appeal when shared with a total stranger at a virtually overlapping, although supposedly separate, table.
A new program to prepare specialists to deal with the political, social and economic problems of Africa will be offered at Columbia University next fall.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Mrs. William B. Long's Pembroke Welsh Corgi, Ch. Willets Red Jacket, of Carlisle, Mass., became best in show of the National Capital Kennel Club dog show tonight, proving anew how uncertain are the fortunes of dog competition.

THE untabulated cost of an unassuming dinner check is all too often an unappetizing environment, even though the food may be fine. As for service, this is frequently of the catch-as-catch-can variety, while intimacy of surroundings loses appeal when shared with a total stranger at a virtually overlapping, although supposedly separate, table.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- An increase of $16,000,000,000 to $20,000,000,000 in installment credit outstanding the next ten to twelve years was predicted today by Edward J. Frey, chairman of the American Bankers Association's installment credit committee.
Steel production increased slightly last week from the level of the preceding week, but still showed no sign of the major upturn forecast by some industry officials.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- A solution to a controversy about racial segregation in Charleston, S.C., will be sought tomorrow at a closed session of the executive committee of the National Civil War Centennial Commission.
SEOUL, Korea, March 19 -- South Korea, the poorer half of one of the poorest countries in the world, is trying to exist as a nation with too many people and too few resources.

The recommendation of the Port of New York Authority that a World Trade Center be constructed on a sixteen-acre site along the East River, adjoining the downtown financial district, at a cost of $355 million, should be discarded. The plan is highly speculative and its failure would result in a severe blow to the prestige of lower Manhattan.
A crucial test of Soviet intentions will begin today when the three major atomic powers resume their conference in Geneva on a treaty to ban further nuclear weapons tests.
JUNEAU, Alaska, March 20 (AP) -- Two young climbers were rescued today from a fifty-foot-deep crevasse on near-by Mendenhall Glacier, where they were trapped overnight.

A small fire in the understructure of a BMT Brighton line express train caused the power to be shut off for thirty minutes on the southbound express track between Prospect Park and Coney Island in Brooklyn during the evening rush hour yesterday.
Mrs. John F. Kennedy and her sister arrived by plane at La Guardia Airport yesterday afternoon for a four-or five-day visit.

NEWARK, March 20 -- The New Jersey Air Pollution Control Commission showed twenty-five experts today the results of its efforts to lift the pall of smoke that for years has characterized the state's northern meadowlands.
TRENTON, March 20 -- The Port of New York Authority agreed today to involve itself financially in commuter rail projects after having operated for forty years without doing so.
PARIS, March 19 -- The junk fair and the ham fair, two thriving descendants of the Middle Ages in Paris, returned yesterday for their traditional one week runs.

Eastern Lime Corporation, Kutztown, Pa., announced that it plans to diversify further in the building materials field by purchasing Lehigh Building Block Company, Allentown, Pa., maker of concrete building blocks.

FOR women in a quandary as to whether it should be a straight skirt or a pleated one this spring, Peck Peck has come up with a solution. For $50 it has a wool tweed suit with one of each. The short jacket in orange and beige plaid is bound around the notched collar and the pocket flaps with solid orange.
Maine potato futures fell to new lows for the lives of the contracts yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange in the fifth most active trading session of the year.

LUIGI CHERUBINI was born in 1760, and thus his bicentennial took place last year, a fact largely ignored by New York musical organizations. Thomas Scherman and the Little Orchestra Society helped make amends last night in their final concert of the season.

The Municipal Art Society reported yesterday that it hoped to be allowed to present a court brief against the plan to build a cafe in Central Park at the corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

The appointment of Dr. Robert Wayne Houston as laboratory director of the Industrial Reactor Laboratories at Plainsboro, N.J., was announced yesterday by Columbia University. He is a Professor of Chemical Engineering at Columbia.

We moderns may read with a sense of amusement that three wise men a century and a half ago this week thought it "improbable that for centuries to come the grounds north of Harlem Flat will be covered with houses." The men in question were eminent and in their day respected: Gouverneur Morris, Simeon De Witt and John Rutherfurd.

A joint program leading to the Master of Arts degree in philosophy will be offered by three of the municipal colleges starting in the fall, Gustave G. Rosenberg, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, announced last night.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 20 -- It was, said Ralph Houk, the manager, to Del Webb, the co-owner, only a question of time before the Yankees straightened out.
Can a new day be dawning in the rough rock-'em and sock-'em field of proprietary drug advertising?

The National Association of Investment Companies reported yesterday that net assets of United States mutual funds reached almost $19,000,000,000 in February, despite a decline in sales from those of a month ago, and from the February, 1959, level.

The Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the twelve months ended On Fen. 28. However, the latest operating revenues trailed the level for the twelve months ended on Jan 31.
WASINGTON, March 20 -Assistant Secretary of State G. Mennen Williams said today that he had recommended more aid to Africa.
PARIS, March 20 -- Last week in the most solemn moment wrestling had known, the White Angel stood solemnly in a ring here and solemnly removed his mask.
WASHINGTON, March 201 (AP) -- President Kennedy told building-construction trade unions today he will never be satisfied that the nation is enjoying prosperity when so many are unemployed.
New Rochelle's Board of Education asked the United States Court of Appeals yesterday to stay Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman's order for a desegregation plan to be submitted to him by April 14.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 20 -- Maj. Gen. Joseph D. Mobutu declared today that United Nations troops would "never" be allowed to return to Matadi and Banana. He warned that "blood would flow" if the international force attempted to reoccupy the two strategic ports against the will of the Congolese Government and Army.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 20 -- The United States delegation offered a comforting hand here today to Soviet correspondents who feel they are not wanted.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI) -- The Senate Internal Security Subcommittee is answering queries about the controversial John Birch Society, a semi-secret anti-Communist organization, by describing it as apparently "a patriotic organization,'' it was learned today.

The John Deere Credit Company filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday covering a proposed offering to the public of $25,000,000 of debentures due in 1981. Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., is manager of an underwriting syndicate that would offer the debentures to the public.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI) -- Pierre Salinger, White House press secretary, accused the Eisenhower Administration today of manipulating the news during the 1960 Presidential campaign.

A system of awarding construction contracts by which the low bidder is eliminated and the work given to the contractor who most nearly strikes the average price has been advocated by the head of a large contracting concern.

PITTSBURGH, March 20 -- The National Council of Jewish Women, a sixty-eight-year-old educational service organization, asserted today that any Government aid to private schools "would undermine the very foundation of public education in the United States."

JERUSALEM, March 20 -- Israel was condemned today by the Israel-Jordan Mixed Armistice Commission for bringing tanks and heavy artillery into Jerusalem in violation of the General Armistice Agreement.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20 -- Ever since Dick Stuart and Bob Skinner of the Pirates were trapped into a home run-hitting contest with Stan Musial and Ken Boyer of the Cardinals, the cheerful Musial has been giving Stuart the needle. In that contest, Boyer belted the first five pitches into the seats and the Red Bird pair defeated the Pirate twosome, 14 homers to 1.
The purchase of Duell, Sloan Pearce, Inc., New York publisher, by the Meredith Publishing Company of Des Moines, was announced yesterday. The purchase price was not disclosed.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- President Kennedy asked Congress today for almost $500,000,000 of added appropriations. The biggest requests, for farm price supports and certain other agricultural programs, would have no effect on the level of Government spending.

Twenty-four local government agencies subsidized by the Housing and Home Finance Agency are planning to sell temporary loan notes aggregating $46,619,090 to finance urban redevelopment projects. Bids will be received on March 28.

DENVER, March 20 -- The national tournament of the American Contract Bridge League, which has been in progress here since March 11, ended today with a roundrobin contest among three teams to decide the winner in the Vanderbilt Cup event for the national open team championship.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The vote of this Government in the United Nations Security Council last week for the Afro-Asian resolution concerning Angola is being generally accepted as a reversal of fundamental past policy. It had many aspects of this.

GERMAN wines of the 1959 vintage, rated as "outstanding" and "perhaps the best year since 1921" by one merchant here, have just begun to arrive in quantity. These are white wines that, well chilled, will provide a refreshing zest to spring and summer meals.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 20 -- More than forty scholars, scientists, diplomats and writers will participate this week in an international conference on the implications for educators in the world's "new directions."
MADRID, March 20 (Reuters) -- A Foreign Ministry spokesman denied today Moroccan news reports that Spanish forces seized four Italian oil technicians in the Sahara last week.
DETROIT, March 20 -- L.A. Iacocca, Ford Motor Company vice president, predicted today that the automobile market would blossom out in the next thirty to sixty days.
A program to permit the Transit Authority to issue $200,000,000 in twenty-five-year bonds to buy 1,800 subway cars was announced yesterday at City Hall.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 20 -- The Soviet Union is expected to press tomorrow its demand for the liquidation of the United Nations Congo program within thirty days.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., March 20 -- Proposals to aid deficit-ridden commuter railroads in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut area were denounced sharply today by officials of the-American Automobile Association.

YONKERS, March 20 -- Whether the quadruped runs, trots or paces matters little to the horseplayer, who remains a horseplayer as long as the money holds out. So it was hardly surprising that quite a few guys and dolls who had spent the afternoon at Aqueduct wended their way to Yonkers Raceway for the opening of the local harness racing season tonight.

The Chase Manhattan Bank has filed an application for a branch at 365 South Oyster Bay Road, Plainview, L.I. and for a public accommodation office at 1724 Hancock Street, Ridgewood, Queens, adjacent to its office at 918 Seneca Avenue.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20 -- Something that stimulates production of one of the body's master chemicals and also appears capable of bolstering the strength of an animal's natural defense mechanisms against disease was described here today.

INTEREST in the life of Oscar Wilde is high. Only last June two British-made films about Wilde were put on local movie screens. Last week Micheal MacLiammoir brought his one-man reading of Wilde's plays, letters and poems, "The Importance of Being Oscar," to the Lyceum Theatre. Last night Thomas Del Vecchio's "Feast of Panthers" opened at the East 74th Street Theatre.

ALBANY, March 20 -- Legislation authorizing New York City to invest $12,000,000 in the Lincoln Center for the performing Arts was submitted to the Legislature tonight with the blessing of Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner.

JERSEY CITY, March 20 -- Mayor Charles S. Witkowski angrily walked out of a City Commission meeting today, but the other commission members ignored the protest and promptly voted a lower tax rate for Jersey City for 1961.
HENRY HULL'S performance as an unwanted old man is the principal attraction in "The Wooden Dish," being shown on "The Play of the Week" over Channel 13.
Man's story will add a new dimension at the American Museum of Natural History with the opening today of a permanent Hall of the Biology of Man.
CHICAGO, March 20 (AP) -- Selling pressure continued without letup in the grain futures trade today and prices extended their general downward trend another cent or more on nearly all contracts.

LUANDA, Angola, March 20 -- Sweeping constitutional changes are reported being prepared for Angola and Mozambique, the two large Portuguese African possessions. Angola, which has been shaken repeatedly by African violence in the last six weeks, and Mozambique, which is quiet, are to receive economic, fiscal and administrative autonomy, it was reported today.
City school officials are considering advancing the opening date of the 1961-62 school year.
Sales and earnings of the Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation rose to new highs in 1960 for the eleventh consecutive year, Paul L. Davies, chairman, disclosed in the annual report yesterday.
Trans World Airlines, Inc. has elected a new president, filling a post which has been vacant eight months.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 20 -- Three successive eighth-place finishes haven't squelched hope in the camp of the Fightin' Phillies.
Stocks rose yesterday for the fourth successive day. Motors, oils, nonferrous metals and food processors did well. Other groups, even when higher, showed considerable unevenness.

LONDON, March 20 -- Prices of industrial and oil shares continued to advance strongly in the stock market here today, taking the Financial Times industrial shares index to within 2.2 points of its record. At 340.7, the index was 1.7 points up on say.
FOR a change of mood, take the 25-cent guided tour through the Capitol.

Three generations of Israelis are presented in "Pioneers of Israel," a collection of reminiscences that World Publishing Company will issue April 17 The author is Shmuel Dayan, one of Israel's pioneers, a member of the Israeli Parliament and author of five books in Hebrew.

JOHNSON CITY, N.Y., March 20 (UPI) -- Endicott Johnson Corporation, at present in the red, hopes to have a profit in the second half of 1961, Frank A. Johnson, president, said at the annual meeting today.
A tour will be made of five private art collections in this city on April 18 for the benefit of the Spence School Alumnae Scholarship Fund.

SALISBURY, So. Rhodesia, March 20 -- The American Independent Oil Company (Aminoil) is to build an oil refinery in the Central African Federation, it was announced today. Frank Owen, Minister of Commerce and Industry, has said the refinery will form the nucleus of a new $50,000,000 in dustry, the largest project in the Federation's history except for Northern Rhodesia's copper mines.
ALBANY, March 20 -- The Legislature today approved New York's first measure to bar racial and religious discrimination in private real estate transactions.

There will be some changes in the New York Central Railroad's top-level plans and policies if the Murchison family of Dallas, Tex., succeeds in its drive to obtain control of the Central's parent, the Alleghany Corporation.
ONE busy morning just before Christmas a woman stepped up to the ribbon counter in Bloomingdale's and proceeded to order yards and yards of three-inch embroidered ribbon that cost $6 a yard.

BONN, Germany, March 20 -- Leaders of the Christian Democratic Union rejoiced today over their party's good showing in municipal elections yesterday involving nearly a quarter of the West German population.
If New York's unnamed baseball entry in the National League is still homeless by the start of the 1960 season, it may play its opening games at Roosevelt Stadium in Jersey City.
What memorable remarks were made yesterday at the Basketball Writers Association weekly luncheon at Leone's? None.

I must take exception to misstatements of fact made in the letter published in The Times of March 11, written by Aaron Hardy Ulm, dealing with legislation pending in Albany to license chiropractors in this state.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The Kennedy Administration has resolved to face all the risks of a test of wills with the Soviet Union rather than let Laos fall under Communist control.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The witnesses, including the president of the United States Conference of Mayors, told a Senate subcommittee today the breakdown of commuter rail and urban bus services was strangling cities from coast to coast.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on a contention that Government officers should be barred from copy-righting as private property their public speeches on official matters.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 20 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk ranged over Administration attitudes on the "cold war," the United Nations and disarmament in a speech at the University of California today.
WHITE PLAINS, March 20 -- An investigation of the Air National Guard's plan to use C-119 Flying Boxcars at the Westchester County Airport was ordered today by the county's Board of Supervisors.
LONDON, March 20 -- Sir Roy Welensky left London tonight confident he had won a measure of British support for slower African political advancement in Northern Rhodesia.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today that three officers had been charged with dereliction of duty in the collapse of a radar island off the New Jersey coast two months ago.
The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange was 3,854,206 shares on March 15, an increase of 15,442 shares from the 3,838,764 shares reported on Feb. 15.
CLEVELAND, Ohio., March 20 (UPI) -- America's railroads today said the industry was "in jeopardy to the detriment of the national interest" and came out with a "Magna Carta for transportation."

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 20 -- Dr. Tomas Enrique Carrillo Batalla has resigned as Minister of Finance, the Government announced today. His resignation, submitted two weeks ago, will become effective Thursday.

The United States has had a Federal minimum wage law since 1938; but even today only a little more than a third of the American labor force is protected by it. In the twenty-three years since the law has been on the books, there has been virtually no upward revision of its coverage; and even the monetary floor (originally 25 cents an hour; now $1) has not been raised in over five years.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to look into a legal snarl stemming from Venezuela's attempt extradite former President Marcos Perez Jimenez for prosecution there.

GENEVA, March 20 -- The Western proposals to be submitted at the resumption of the nuclear test-ban conference tomorrow are, in a sense, a now-or-never effort to get what President Kennedy has described as "the first international arms-control agreement in the nuclear age."
A benign tumor was removed yesterday morning from the right side of Mayor Wagner's neck.

A local group of citizens interested in providing New York with an educational television station has submitted a new and increased bid of $5,500,000 to purchase station WNTA-TV (Channel 13). The group's initial offer of $4,000,000 had been declined last month by National Telefilm Associates, owner of the station.

A former high police official testified yesterday that Max Schuster, the father of the late Arnold Schuster, had refused a police bodyguard for his son sixteen days before Arnold was murdered near his Brooklyn home.

The season changed its name yesterday to spring, but winter's gloom and discomfort were still in style here with a warning from the Weather Bureau that there would be freezing temperatures today and maybe rain mixed with sleet or snow.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 20 -- Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd declared today that South Africa's withdrawal from the British Commonwealth was "not a defeat but a victory." Dr. Verwoerd received a highly emotional welcome from a crowd estimated at 25,000 to 50,000 at Jan Smuts Airport when he arrived from London.
Texaco, Inc., announced yesterday the award of a contract for the building of five 25,300-deadweight-ton tankers to the Bethlehem Steel Company for its yard at Sparrows Point, Md.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI) -- The Treasury, in a move aimed at better Soviet-American relations, ended a ban on the importation of Soviet canned crabmeat today.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Government and industry spokesmen heartily supported "in principle" today a proposed measure to legalize dual-rate contracts for ocean shipping. However, strong objections were voiced to details of the draft bill.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. March 20 -- Belgium declared today that her policy in Ruanda-Urundi involved "the fullest and most frank cooperation" with the United Nations.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 20 -- A vehement denunciation of Cuba's leaders as "megalomaniac puppets" of communism was addressed to General Assembly delegates today by Guatemala. "Every statement" by the leaders is "an outright lie," the Guatemalian Ambassador said.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Army officials made clear today, with some bitterness, their disapproval of a Pentagon directive assigning most space research responsibility to the Air Force.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- One of the architects of the New Frontier's economic policies predicted today that industry would be forced into a shorter work week unless there was a significant reduction in unemployment.
Five nonpaying passengers disembarked from the liner Independence yesterday after a voyage that began Feb. 25.

BUENOS AIRES, March 20 -- President Arturo Frondizi's Radical Intransigent party was elated today over a surprisingly complete victory yesterday in municipal elections in the key province of Santa Fe.
Electronic equipment for transmitting electrocardiograms by telephone was demonstrated yesterday at the opening of the 1961 international convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its decision of Jan. 23 upholding censorship of motion pictures before their public showing.
ASIDE from use on gay towels, pattern is not always easy to achieve in bathrooms. Many have no windows, and, because wallpaper tends to peel in a damp room, the walls are often left bare.
The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation said yesterday it had developed a commercially practical way of making aluminum from common clay.
The Cities Service Company reported yesterday that its net income last year declined to $41,320,000, or $3.85 a common share, from $42,434,000, or $3.95 a share, in 1959.

Leaders of the Medical Society of the County of New York yesterday backed the State Health Commissioner's opposition to Albany bills to sense chiropractors in the state. They called chiropractic "a cult and a quackery."
Jose Gonzales, a Puerto Rican middleweight, made his 1961 boxing debut at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. It was a winning one.
Three directors and a major shareholder of Goldfield Consolidated Mines Company are seeking an injunction against the company, the four other directors and the treasurer, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Senate hearings on the Federal school aid bill ended today with three Protestant church groups opposing Roman Catholic efforts to bring private and parochial schools under the program.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Treasury bill rates moved in opposite directions on today's sale of the regular weekly issues. The discount rate on the three-month day bills -- ninety-two days in this case because of the Decoration Day Holiday -- dropped for the third consecutive week.

The head of the house had an unnerving experience the other day. Hearing the cook return from the supermarket, he strolled to the kitchen. It is his habit to help unpack the groceries, his sole aim being to relieve her of the physical strain of lifting heavy sardine tins from the table to the shelf.
ALBANY, March 20 -- Legislators agreed today to increase the pay of legislators by $2,500 a year starting in 1963.
OTTAWA, March 20 (AP) -- Traffic on the St. Lawrence Seaway has been substantially less than predicted and a result may be an outery in the United States for higher tolls.
PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -A strike of 750 unskilled workers halted production today at Cuneo Eastern Press, Inc.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. March 20 -- Thirty-nine Asian and African countries asked tonight for an immediate General Assembly debate on the situation in the Portuguese territory of Angola.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court rejected today an appeal by Mrs. Vi Murphy, a news reporter of Colorado Springs, Colo., who received a thirty-day contempt sentence for refusing to disclose a confidential news source.

THE multitudinous admirers of Ingrid Bergman were put to a rather stringent loyalty test last night. The gracious actress appeared on Channel 2 in a drama entitled "Twenty-four Hours in a Woman's Life" and, all in all, it was one terribly long day.
At 1:20 P.M. yesterday at Aqueduct, George Seuffert's band gave out with "Happy Days Are Here Again," to the accompaniment of applause from the music lovers huddled around the band.

Marcel Pigou sat in a six-foot square closet off Eighth Avenue yesterday, thinking past next Saturday night when he will fight at Madison Square Garden. He was speaking softly of d'argent, the stuff of which his dreams are made.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 20 -- Now is the time when the Hollywood elite move lock, stock and golf bag to the desert.
Two business men and a robber fought with heavy sheet metal shears yesterday over a $724 payroll. The thug won momentarily, but was caught several minutes later by a patrolman as he tried to escape.
John E. Hand, real estate agent and Democratic political figure, appeared in two courts yesterday on housing matters and resigned as a member of a local school board.
Eight diaper services in the metropolitan area were charged yesterday with conspiring to fix prices and destroy competition, at a cost to customers of "more than $1,000,000 annually."
ALBANY, March 20 -- A sharp split among top Republicans is delaying the introduction of the Rockefeller administration's bill to continue residential rent controls in the state two more years.

FORT PIERCE, Fla., March 20 (AP) -- A state undercover agent, credited with solving the 1955 Chillingworth murder mystery, testified today that Joseph A. Peel Jr. had asked him to kill Floyd Holzapfel and silence him about the killings.
WARSAW, March 20 -- The Roman Catholic Bishops of Poland are preparing an episcopal letter that will be the Church's next move in a mounting struggle with the Communist regime.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Louisiana's various efforts to block the desegregation of schools in New Orleans were held unconstitutional by the Supreme Court today.
CHICAGO, March 20 -- A Federal judge ruled today that Igor Y. Melekh, a Russian employed by the United Nations secretariat, must stand trial here on charges of conspiracy to commit espionage.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 20 -- The General Assembly's Political Committee was expected to begin work tomorrow by deferring a debate on disarmament and taking up a United States plan for African development.
A detective of the District Attorney's squad was found critically wounded outside the Criminal Courts Building early today.

The fourteenth annual card party and tea through which funds are raised for scholarships at the Cornell University-New York Hospital School of Nursing has been arranged for the afternoon of April 12. The event will take place in the hospital's nurses residence at 1320 York Avenue.
Robert M. Morgenthau was understood yesterday to be getting top consideration for appointment as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

LONDON, March 20 -- Lawyers for Gordon A. Lonsdale and Helen and Peter Kroger, who are being tried for conspiring to violate Britain's Official Secrets Act, announced today that the three would not take the stand or call witnesses in their defense.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fell 3 to 12 points (15 to 60 cents a bale) yesterday. The near May showed the greatest loss.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The United States will offer concessions on some controversial issues but stand fast on the key issue of inspection when talks are resumed in Geneva tomorrow on a prohibition of tests of nuclear weapons.

An attack on the New York Port Authority and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority for assertedly not meeting the city's transportation problems was made last night by William Reid, former chairman of the New York City Board of Transportation.

Olympia Lanes in Brooklyn, the first New York bowling establishment to have duckpins set by machine, opened last Tuesday at the corner of New Utrecht Avenue and Fifty-second Street. The reaction to the small-pin small-ball game was enthusiastic.

The General Electric Company struck back yesterday at one of its persistent critics. The target was James B. Carey, president of the International Union of Electrical Workers, AFL-CIO, and trustee of the union's pension fund, which holds some G.E. stock.

The Treasury's move to further the Eisenhower Administration's advance refunding of public debt has momentarily relegated to the market background the Federal Reserve System's commitment to the Kennedy Administration to lower long-term interest rates.
CHICAGO, March 20 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Mayor Wagner is expected to submit a request to the Board of Estimate this week for an appropriation for his new Charter revision commission. He was reported prepared to ask for an immediate special session of the board if necessary.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The Kennedy Administration will propose a Youth Conservation Corps of male teen-agers to work on conservation projects across the nation.
BONN, Germany, March 20 -- Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin said on his return from the United States today that he was much impressed by the "stock-taking process" currently under way there.
Virginia Snow and Elizabeth Raynor, between their chores for David Merrick as assistant and executive secretary, will produce a pair of modern Scandinavian one-actors this spring Off Broadway.
ALBANY, March 20 -- Republican legislative leaders reached tentative agreement today on a $29,000,000 increase over last last year in state aid to local school districts.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- An American Basketball League club owner reported today that teams in the new pro circuit would get 3 points instead of the usual 2 for sinking long shots.

Savings in the nation's savings and loan associations rose by $530,000,000 in February to $63,226,090,000 according to the United States Savings and Loan League. The increase was 30 per cent greater than that registered in February, 1960.
AKRON, Ohio, March 20 (UPI) -- A $500,000 libel suit filed by Edward Lamb against J.P. Seiberling, president of Seiberling Rubber Company, was dismissed today in Summit County Common Pleas Court.
MILAN, Italy, March 20 -- A national congress of the Left-Wing Socialist party endorsed today the independent policy of its leader, Pietro Nenni, by a small margin.

A former lawyer awaiting trial on charges of throwing lye in the face of a woman friend startled Bronx County Court yesterday with the dramatic declaration that he was making a "citizen's arrest" of the prosecutor, the arresting police officer and the judge himself.
Record sales but lower earnings were reported yesterday by the J.C. Penney Company, department store chain, for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31.
