Edward N. Costikyan, leader of the Eighth Assembly District South, expressed doubt last night that Carmine G. Dell Sapio could be deposed as New York County Democratic leader "within the next month or two."
The third game of the world championship chess match in Moscow between Mikhail Tal of Lativia and Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia was adjourned yesterday after forty-two moves.

Whenever there is an election in a Latin-American country these days one fears the worst. Now and then there is a pleasant surprise and the results are favorable to candidates and parties who are in the democratic, pro-Western and if not pro-Yankee, at least neutral line.

In Poland, one of the world's bastions of en garde and touche, Mike Dasaro has apparently replaced Douglas Fairbanks Jr. as America's best known fencer. The difference is that Dasaro sometimes loses -- and he never fences anyone while backing down a flight of castle stairs.

VIENTIANE, Laos, March 20 (AP) -- As rebel forces pressed toward Vientiane on two fronts, a Government official proposed today that the pro-Communist Pathet Lao movement set up its own states under a national union.

THERE has been a quiet revolution going on in maternity clothes the last few years. The ink is hardly dry on the latest fashion news before the impact makes itself felt in this specialized field of design.
The investigation by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office into the bribery of college basketball players continued yesterday with the questioning of more persons.
Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg has taken executive action to abolish the sweatshop conditions under which girls are forced to practice piano more than an hour a day.

It appears that the new Federal Administration has recognized that unless the present outflow of gold can be reversed, many economic and political decisions may come to be heavily influenced by their effect on the trade and payments position.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 20 (AP) -- Circuit Judge Walter B. Jones denied today a request that he waive the $1,000,000 bonds that four Negro ministers must post to appeal a libel judgment against them.
LONDON, March 18 -- Britain is about to back a new plan for expanded operations by the International Monetary Fund to help the world over its periodic monetary crises.

STEWART, Fla., March 20 -- The celebrated Bert Pruitt ruled after mature deliberation today that fishing hereabouts would be even better from here on out than it had been for a month, which is considerable.

ARTHUR HOBSON DEAN, head of the United States delegation to the conference on a prohibition of tests of nuclear weapons reopening in Geneva today, is a hard bargainer who conceals a tough streak behind a cherubic exterior.

In government as in private employ an underpaid worker is no bargain. The public properly demands abstention from use of the strike weapon by its civil service employes. In return the employe has a right to expect just treatment, voluntarily tendered.
The thoroughbred returned to New York yesterday, with the opening of Aqueduct's spring meeting.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to examine a Virginia law that the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has contended might destroy it in that state.

TUNIS, March 20 -- Finance Minister Ahmed Francis of the Algerian rebel nationalist Provisional Government is expected to head the rebel negotiating team at the coming peace talks with the French because of the illness of Vice Premier Belkacem Krim.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- An unusual dispute broke out on the bench of the Supreme Court today.

MEXICO CITY, March 20 -- The posibility of a temporary international agreement for the production and price stabilization of world lead and zinc was raised today. The occasion was the opening of the third re-union of an international study group on the two commodities here this morning.
DETROIT, March 20 (AP) -Auto production last week hit its lowest point of the year and with eleven of sixteen Ford assembly plants idle this week only modest improvement is in prospect.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 20 -- Manuel Bisbe y Alberni, Cuba's permanent representative here, collapsed and died today in a lounge outside the General Assembly hall. The 55-year-old diplomat had been critically ill in recent months and is thought to have suffered a heart attack.
If Loomis J. Grossman has purchased the property at 328 to 336 East Seventy-fifth Street, adjoining the southwest corner of First Avenue, for improvement with an apartment building.

LONDON, March 21 (AP) -- Henry Cooper, the British and the Empire heavyweight champion, stopped Joe Erskine in five rounds tonight and lifted his chances for a crack at the world champion, Floyd Patterson.

MONTREAL, March 21 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens scored four third-period goals to break up a tense struggle and rout the Chicago Black Hawks, 6 -- 2, tonight in the opening game of the best-of-seven semi-final National Hockey League Stanley Cup play-offs.
A number of upsets marked the elections yesterday in eighty-five villages in four suburban counties.

In the first of two appearances for the benefit of the Sino-American Amity Fund, Tung Kwong-Kwong gave a piano recital in Carnegie Recital Hall last night. She will be joined by her husband, Ma Si-Hon, violinist, and brother,Yuan Tung, 'cellist, for the second program, on April 27.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday that net income and consolidated sales and revenues had risen to new highs in 1960.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The House Judiciary Committee approved today a bill to create seventy Federal judgeships.

An element of "calculated risk" may weigh considerably in decisions that will determine the nature of increased export credit facilities recommended by President Kennedy. The President proposed expansion of these facilities in his message to Congress on measures to correct the large deficit in the nation's foreign payments transactions.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI) -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Democrat of Manhattan, brought the power of the purse to bear today in his battle with Representative Carroll Kearns Republican of Pennsylvania, for a two-room office suite.
ALBANY, March 21 -- The Rockefeller administration submitted to the Legislature late today a bill that would continue rent controls for two more years.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 21 -- The United Nations is facing a problem on the first issue to test its new independent line on colonial questions since the Angola debate in the Security Council.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- President Kennedy is now up against a hard dilemma: Whether to intervene militarily in Laos, as President Truman did in Korea, or to risk the communization of at least part of that kingdom, as President Eisenhower did in French Indochina.

The two major Cuban groups seeking to overthrow Premier Fidel Castro have reached an agreement and have chosen Dr. Jose Miro Cardona to head a provisional government. The pact involves leaders both in and outside Cuba.

Does the Kennedy Administration's right hand know what its left hand is doing? Have our current Attorney General and Secretary of Agriculture bothered to check recently on the consistency or lack thereof in their actions and proposals? A negative answer to both questions is suggested by the obvious schizophrenia shown by some aspects of recent Administration policy.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 21 -- Premier Joseph Ileo appealed to the United Nations today to recognize that the situation in the Congo had changed and that the Congolese were able to solve their own problems.
A total of 856 persons were injured in traffic accidents in the city last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This figure is ten more than in the same period a year ago.

MEXICO CITY, March 21 -- Jose Pardo Llada, one of Cuba's top radio and television commentators and an adviser in public relations to Premier Fidel Castro, will announce tomorrow his defection from the Cuban regime, sources here said tonight.
Bracha Eden and Alexander Tamir gave a two-piano recital of substance and skill last night in Carnegie Hall.

STUART, Fla., March 21 -- A fish ranch on which big bass would graze over pastures flooded seasonally by plan may be the next thing in the commercial sports-fishing cards in Florida, where anything goes provided it is odd enough.

ANOTHER chapter in the disheartening story of drama on network television drew "a close last night. The Du Pont Show of the Month," which once experienced some of the medium's glorious hours, gave its last performance over Channel 2 and brought a four-year run to a close.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- President Kennedy said today it was "quite possible" that the nation could enjoy an economic recovery this summer and still have an unemployment rate of 6 or 7 per cent.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- R. Sargent Shriver was approved by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today to head President Kennedy's newly created Peace Corps.
FORT PIERCE, Fla., March 21 (UPI) -- A prosecution witness said today that Joseph A. Peel Jr. had been ready to sacrifice his own brother in an assassination plot to evade arrest for murder.

A Hawaiian company, M. McInerny, Ltd., of Honolulu, has won a top place for the first time in the annual Brand Name Retailer of the Year awards. The McInerny concern, which won a certificate of distinction in 1959, was named specialty store winner.
Three Harlem School Districts of the New York school system have hired Carnegie Hall to present performances of American opera and ballet for their students.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- Hal B. Hayes, a builder, said today that Government pressure and fussy officers' wives forced him to stop work on $55,000,000 worth of military housing last year.
Will American military units be fighting in Laos next week or next month?
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 21 -- The United Nations Conciliation Commission reported today that the Congo was "on the verge of catastrophe." It recommended urgent measures to save the situation.

The shortage of nurses became critical in Rhode Island hospitals during a polio epdidemic last summer. Hospitals and state officials appealed to the Red Cross, which recruited registered nurses from as far away as West Virginia.

Events tonight: "Parsifal," Metropolitan Opera, 7:15; Orchestra of America, Richard Korn, conductor, Vida Chenoweth, marimba player, Roman Totenberg, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Robert Gerle, violinist, and Albert Fuller, harpischordist, Town Hall, 8:30; Richard Norris, pianist, Judson Hall 8:30.

The Elliot Manufacturing Corporation, manufacturer of electrical fittings, has purchased a building that was erected to its specifications on the west side of Ninety-eighth Street at the corner of Fiftieth Avenue, Corona, Queens. N. Giacomino, the builder, was the seller.

I want to take this opportunity to congratulate Dr. Leona Baungartner for being aware that the health professions are not communicating what they know about control and prevention of certain diseases to the public. She refers to diet, smoking and exercise habit for the prevention of heart disease and cancer.
CHICAGO, March 21 -- L.L. Colbert, chairman and president of the Chrysler Corporation, predicted today rapid improvement in the auto industry by the early part of the second quarter.
A casting call likely to tax the resources of Actors Equity has just been issued from the offices of Allen-Hodgdon, Inc., an independent film producing company in midtown Manhattan.
The Public Service Commission authorized the New York Central Railroad yesterday to raise commuter and other fares in the metropolitan area by 10 per cent, effective April 1.

CHICAGO, March 21 (AP) -- Futures prices for grains and soybeans worked into a firm range today, as speculative dealers evened up their positions in the March delivery and shifted operations to later contracts.
ALBANY, March 2 -- Governor Rockefeller's bill to establish a central fingerprint file of youths taken before the courts was consigned to the legislative graveyard today.

PITTSBURGH, March 21 -- Obsolete methods and inadequate resources in public-school guidance and vocational training programs pose a "serious danger" to the nation's economic growth, according to a report today by the National Council of Jewish Women.

Classic examples of murder, mystery, fear, fantasy and intrigue have been tied together by Charles Bennett in an adaptation called "Once Upon a Midnight." Julian Olney and his wife, Dorothy, will present the offering here early next year after a tour, commencing on the West Coast in August.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Despite White House intervention, the National Civil War Centennial Commission refused today to make any changes in plans to hold its annual meeting at Charleston, S.C.
A managing agent began serving a 140-day jail term imposed in Housing Court yesterday after he was unable to pay the alternative sentence, $700 in fines.

Brooklyn's $90,000,000 pier redevelopment program passed the halfway mark yesterday.
Four Chinese, who describe themselves as United States citizens, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on perjury charges.
PARIS, March 21 -- On the first full day of spring Paris opened a major art exhibition at the Musee Carnavalet, a sixteenth-century mansion now dedicated to the history of the city.
Two members of the Cabinet may have to resolve a musical crisis that has arisen because Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg has "chartered" a union of teen-age piano pupils.

Walter Gropius, the architect, was awarded an honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters by Columbia University last night.
DACCA, Pakistan, March 21, (AP) -- A tornado that struck four East Pakistan districts Sunday killed 180 persons, officials reported tonight.
Bowling, one of America's fastest-growing sports, is going underground.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., March 21 -- The American Automobile Association charged today that the major political parties were treating motorists as "second-rate citizens."

IN the last two decades Americans have been blamed for corrupting the rest of the world with a variety of exports, from carbonated drinks to rock 'n' roll. Any day now, men of other cultures who appreciate the well-padded feminine form may start castigating the United States for setting loose the fad of skinniness.

Fifteen hundred truck drivers and pushboys in New York's huge women's garment industry went on strike without warning yesterday. The immediate effect of the surprise walkout was to bottle up the flow of cut dresses, suits, skirts, coats and sportswear from jobbers to contractors for finishing.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- President Kennedy conferred with Democratic Congressional leaders today on the budget message he plans to submit Friday.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Senator Barry Goldwater called today for loans to private and parochial schools as part of any legislation providing Federal aid for public schools. However, the Arizona Republican, a leading spokesman for economic conservatism, repeated his opposition to the use of Federal funds for elementary and secondary education in testifying before a House subcommittee.
THINGS were fairly hectic at the City Center last night, for Mrs. John F. Kennedy, accompanied by Adlai E. Stevenson and a party of guests, attended the performance of the New York City Ballet.

MONTREAL, March 21 (AP) -- The National Hockey League's final statistics for the season made it official today -- Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion of the Montreal Canadiens won the scoring championship and his team-mate, Jean Beliveau, was runner-up.
Residents of west Greenwich Village bombarded Borough President Edward R. Dudley for two and a half hours yesterday with reasons why their area should not be designated for urban renewal.

Preliminary plans have been drawn for a world-wide scientific effort to be known as the International Year of the Quiet Sun, or I.Q.S. Y.
The acquisition of the assets of the Carpenter Paper Company by the Champion Paper and Fibre Company was approved by stockholders of both companies at separate meetings yesterday.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 21 -- South Vietnam, regarded here as the key of Southeast-Asian defense against Communist aggression, has become a testing ground for new United States Army guerrilla tactics designed for fighting in tropical jungles.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- The American Bar Association announced today the appointment of an eleven-member committee of lawyers, judges and law teachers to help find temporary employment for Cuban lawyers and judges in exile.

An important step toward developing an artificial heart to be implanted in the chests of heart-disease patients has been accomplished, it was reported here yesterday at the International Convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers at the Coliseum.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., March 21 -- Seton Hall University announced today that it had entered into an agreement to purchase 180 acres in Saddle River to expand the school.
Old rubber still has plenty of bounce. And it is being re-claimed by new processes for a great variety of uses.

LOS ANGELES, March 21 (UPI) -- Douglas W. Johnson, a self-employed janitor who found $240,000 after it was dropped from a Brink's, Inc., armored car, turned down a steady job with the company today but accepted $10,000 in cash.

CAIRO, March 21 -- The imminence of Algerian peace talks has produced certain changes of attitude in this city which aspires to paramount leadership among the Arab capitals. These changes might be listed accordingly: growing respect for General de Gaulle; realization that President Bourguiba, for long discounted and assailed, is a man to be reckoned with; and an initial feeling of satisfaction that the cause of North African nationalism again seems about to triumph.
The State of Massachusetts borrowed $62,547,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance highway, sewerage, water supply and other public improvements.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Secretary of the Navy told Congress today that Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara had assured him that the Navy would not lose the space programs in which it was interested.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 21 -- Demonstrations in the streets marked the return of Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd to the South African Parliament today. Eleven persons were arrested.
John F. English, Nassau County Democratic leader, announced his support yesterday for Peter J. Crotty for Democratic state chairman.
The election of Edward L. Steiniger and Albert Green as directors of the Kennecott Copper Corporation was announced yesterday by Charles R. Cox, president.
ALBANY, March 21 -- The Senate approved a bill today to discourage persons from coming to New York State to get on public relief rolls.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- The income of the Government's two Social Security trust funds will be sufficient into the long-range future to cover all outlays for benefits, according to the trustees' twenty-first annual report to Congress.
Two municipal electrical inspectors were arrested yesterday on a charge that they tried to get $100 a day from Twentieth Century-Fox to overlook any electrical violations on a movie location here.
The Treasury's advance refunding of securities due in 1962 and 1963 into 3 3/8 and 3 5/8 bonds due in 1966 and 1967, respectively, was the major interest of the bond market yesterday.

MANY of the fine food shops in this city now offer jars of cockles, currently being imported from Wales. Grocers, however, are not expected to advertise these wares in the words of sweet Molly Malone's song, for the cockles very definitely are not "alive, alive-o."
ALBANY, March 21 -- When a worried lobbyist asks a State Senator to step into the fireplace here, he is proposing nothing more perilous than a quick conference. In fact, he steps right in after him.
TRENTON, March 21 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that grand jury presentments must not be used to rebuke individuals in the absence of conclusive proof of wrongdoing.

HONG KONG, which has been getting intensive attention on television this season, was the subject of a one-hour program, starring David Brinkley, over Channel 4 last night. He had been preceded to the Crown Colony by such eminent sociologists as Jack Parr and William Holden.
SAVANNAH, Ga., March 21 (UPI) -- All 914 students of a Savannah Negro high school stayed away from classes today to protest against the dismissal of a principal.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- A rocking chair in President Kennedy's office is one of his most treasured possessions, and has been for more than five years.

A second retired police official testified yesterday that Max Schuster had refused police protection for himself, his tailor shop or his home after the Schuster family received threatening letters and telephone calls.
ALBANY, March 21 -- Republican legislators today summarily pigeonholed the New York City Transit Authority's request for power to issue bonds to buy new subway cars.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, said today there had been "nothing personal" in Senator Harry F. Byrd's cancellation of hearings on five Administration appointments after his defeat on a major bill last week on the Senate floor.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fell 2 to 16 points (10 to 80 cents a bale) yesterday. This continued the broad decline of Monday.
PARIS, March 21 -- The conflict between Yonkers Raceway and Roosevelt Raceway over the New York appearances of Masina, the best French trotter of the season, apparently was settled last night.

LINDEN, Ala., March 21 (UPI) -- A plot of land partly owned by the Rev. Ralph D. Abernathy of Montgomery was sold at auction here yesterday to help satisfy a $500,000 libel judgment against the Negro integration leader.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- Republican Congressional leaders refused at a State Department briefing today to give any advance commitments of support for President Kennedy's long-range foreign aid program.

One quite faithful indicator of the railroad outlook is the number of new freight cars on order. The American Railway Car Institute has reported that the backlog of cars on order in the railroad's own shops totaled 13,760 and that the orders in the hands of car building companies amounted to 4,669, or a total of 18,429 on March 1.
