WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Kennedy Administration has decided on immediate steps to raise the military effectiveness of the Laotian Army in its fight against Communist-directed rebel forces.

The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad, which is seeking to become part of an expanded Pennsylvania Railroad system, tried yesterday to delay temporarily plans of the Pennsylvania to acquire all the stock of the Lehigh Valley, which it already controls.

LONDON, March 21 -- Gordon Arnold Lonsdale, who has identified himself as a Canadian business man, declared in court today that he was responsible for filling a suburban London bungalow with espionage equipment.
Brazil's new policy of economic austerity will result in higher air fares and reduced airline schedules within the country, Ruben M. Berta, president of Varig Airlines of Brazil, said here yesterday.

SYRACUSE, March 21 (AP) -- Dolph Schayes sparked a big second half tonight as the Syracuse Nationals beat the Boston Celtics, 115 -- 98, and evened the National Basketball Assocaition Eastern Division play-offs at one game apiece.
LONDON, March 21 (AP) -- The Soviet Union today withdrew Epigraff II, the best of its three horses, from next Saturday's Grand National Steeplechase.
The Civil Aeronautics Board has widened its investigation of overbooking by airlines to include the sale of lounge seats.
TRENTON, March 21 -- Charles R. Erdman of Princeton said here today that he would retire as Republican State Chairman April 25.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- The House voted today to continue for twenty-one months economic sanctions against Cuba and the Dominican Republic in the form of reduced sugar purchases.

Philip Vetter Jr., a youth who received leniency and medical assistance from a General Sessions Court judge four years ago, was in trouble again yesterday. He was arraigned on charges of assault and robbery, violation of the weapons law and statutory rape.

Dayton, on the strength of a basket with three seconds left, and Providence, with a team effort in the last ten minutes of play, gained the semi-finals of the National Invitation Tournament last night.
LONDON, March 21 -- Industrial shares were buoyant on the stock market here today, helped by some cheerful company statements and yesterday's strength on Wall Street.
GREENWICH, Conn., March 21 -- Serious inaccuracies were charged today to the United States Census Bureau by the chairman of the Connecticut Travel Council.

RABAT, Morocco, March 21 -- King Hassan II of Morocco turned over tonight to diplomatic representatives of the United States, Spain, France and Britain the eleven oil technicians kidnapped ten days ago in the Spanish Sahara, which Morocco claims.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- In an exchange of notes here, Brazil established diplomatic relations today with the three Communist countries of Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria.

IN the off-Broadway reincarnation of "Ladies Night in a Turkish Bath," the Cyrus Wood adaptation of the 1920 bedroom farce by Avery Hopwood and Charlton Andrews, the corn is as high as an elephant's eye.

POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 21 (UPI) -- The New York Yankees' B squad walloped the Washington Senators, 9 -- 2, today in a game called at the end of seven innings because of rain and wet grounds. The muscular Yankee farmhands slapped sixteen hits, illcluding two homers.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission disclosed today it had found inadequate safety procedures at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, L.I., and had halted the operation of two reactors and two critical assemblies there last Tuesday.
LUANDA, Angola, March 21 -- Portuguese officials said today that several thousand armed Angolan African rebels, in bands of fifty to 200, were still moving at large in northern Angola near the Congo.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI) -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today legislation to split $60,000,000 among 660,000 former G.I.'s of the Korean war period who held on to their service life insurance.
Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg was voted "the outstanding labor personality of the year" yesterday by a panel of New York newspaper men.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 21 -- The littlest Angel of all, Albie Pearson, may become one of the biggest assets for the new Los Angeles baseball team in the American League.

Northern Illinois Gas Company yesterday reported gains in operating revenues and net income for twelve months ended on Jan. 31. At the same time the utility announced an increase in its quarterly dividend rate to 35 cents a share from the 30 cents paid previously.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Kennedy Administration has taken a first step toward establishing high-policy direction over the national space program by choosing an executive secretary for the long-dormant National Aeronautics and Space Council.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 21 -- "West Side Story" completed a five-week tour of Israel last night. The Broadway company is sailing to France tomorrow for a month's performances in Paris.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 21 (AP) -- Gov. Edmund G. Brown refused today to bar a controversial speaker from the University of California campus.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 21 -- Official discussion of disarmament was deferred here today in the hope that the United States and the Soviet Union will make further progress on the issue in private negotiation.
A guest star at the New York City Ballet last night never left her seat. But a spokesman for the company exclaimed ecstatically, "She has made our season."
Less than twenty-four hours after a successful operation for a neck tumor, Mayor Wagner stopped worrying about himself yesterday and started worrying about the city.

THE youngest team in twenty years won the Vandrbilt Cup Championship early yesterday in Denver. Arthur Robinson of Philadelphia, who is in his twenties, is the youngest on the team. The others -- Robert Jordan, another Philadelphian; Eric Murray of Toronto and Charles Coon of Boston -- are in their early to middle thirties.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Senator Prescott Bush suggested today that the revitalization of mass transportation systems in metropolitan areas might be speeded if some railroads were put into bankruptcy.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 21 -- The Bucharest radio announced today a major reorganization of the Rumanian governmental structure.
Nadia Boulanger will be the first woman to conduct a full program of the New York Philharmonic.

Judge Gregory F. Noonan reserved decision yesterday in United States District Court on a motion to remand to State Supreme Court a stockholder's suit against Investors Mutual, Inc., and Investors Diversified Services, Inc., of Minneapolis.

ERICH MARIA REMARQUE, an American citizen who now lives in Porto Ronco, Switzerland, has been one of the most famous and successful of German novelists since the publication of "All Quiet on the Western Front" in 1929.
The cockpit of the average private airplane is something like an inefficient kitchen, according to Najeeb E. Halaby, head of the Federal Aviation Agency.

GHEORGHE GHEORGHIU-DEJ, the prudent and ruthless politician who has remained in power in Rumania through all the twists and turns of recent years in the Communist party, has been affirmed as the nation's leader.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- The Soviet Union raised questions about an RB-47 flight over waters near its northern border on Jan. 30, ten days after President Kennedy took office, the State Department reported today.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 21 -- From a strictly baseball standpoint the Phillies offer so little to talk about that they can very well finish last in the conversational league, too. But the deep thinkers on the ball club provide the best group of golfers to be found on any major league team.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that both exports and imports of steel mill products declined in January.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., March 21 (AP) -- A B-52 bomber made its first landing today with a fully fueled X-15 rocket plane attached to its wing -- an operation termed potentially hazardous.
The greatest danger to the Unit States is not from enemies with or subversive communism within, is the danger of bureaucratic control of our way of living.
Yesterday was Bach's birthday, and Sylvia Marlowe, as she did a year ago, celebrated it by presenting a concert of his harpsichord concertos at Town Hall. This program had a clever twist, too.
The Board of Education is considering trying out a prefabricated school that could be dismantled, moved and reassembled.
Reduction of tax costs for American industry was urged yesterday as a counter balance to low labor costs abroad.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 21 Just about everything connected with the Detroit Tigers is new. The American League baseball entry has a new owner, a new general manager, a new field manager, new coaches, at least four new regulars and even a new name for its twenty-three-year-old home park, now called Tiger Stadium.

The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company has announced a new low-cost program to help parents of college students spread the cost of a four-year college education over periods up to ten years. The program is available in amounts up to $15,000 to parents who live or work in the bank's service area.
HACKENSACK, N.J., -- March 21 -- Three men and the company one of them heads were indicted here today on charges of conspiring to defraud the Borough of Lodi.
Arrangements are being made for two benefits for the Vocational Advisory Service, an agency founded in 1921 to help young people.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- The Senate passed today a bill to authorize $51,000,000 in Federal grants to the states to help them set up television stations for school broadcasts. The vote was 67 to 13.

The Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company reduced the interest rate on $70,000,000 of debenture debt from 5 1/2 per cent to 4 3/8 per cent through a market refunding operation yesterday. In a competitive sale, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company affiliate placed its new debenture issue with an underwriting group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., which bid 101.131 for thirty-seven-year debentures bearing 4 3/8 per cent interest.
IN an hour best described as heimish, a term the cognoscenti will immediately equate with homey and unaffected, Channel 13 took on overtones of Second Avenue last night.
VIENTIANE, Laos, March 21 (AP) -- The Royal Laotian Government, facing what it calls a crucial week of decision, announced today it would renew peace talks with former Premier Souvanna Phouma.
The verdant texture of sponsor cash, rustling crisply at the three networks, marked the first full day of spring in the television industry.

The Living Theatre, a modest but daring and imaginative company, has an invitation from the French to appear in the annual international theatre festival his summer in Paris. But it may not be able to go, and this would be a pity.

LONDON, March 21 -- Anthony Wedgwood Benn is undeniably and irrevocably the second Viscount Starts-gate and can no longer be a Labor member in the House of Commons, a Parliamentary committee reported today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 21 -- A bitter speech today by Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Foreign Minister, was denounced by the United States as being in "the worst and most destructive traditions of the cold war."

Archaeological discoveries throughout the world from 1945 to 1959 are described by Edward Bacon in "Digging for History," which John Day will issue May 5. The author is known for his association with the archaelogical features of The Illustrated London News.
HAVANA, March 21 -- An American and four Cubans were captured last night when they attempted to land near Cabanas Bay o nthe north coast of Pinar del Rio Province.
YONKERS, March 21 -- There was not a dull moment just before, during and immediately after the first event at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

ST. LOUIS, March 21 (UPI) -- Elgin Baylor scored 44 points and led the Los Angeles Lakers to a 122-118 upset over the St. Louis Hawks tonight in the first game of the National Basketball Association's final Western Division play-off series.

The Italian Left-Wing Socialist party, under Pietro Nenni, has had its national congress in Milan and ended up where it started. Signor Nenni won a small majority for his policy of autonomy from the Communists but, if anything, he has lost a little ground.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- A compromise emergency feed grain bill backed by the Kennedy Administration was passed today by the House and sent to the Senate. The roll-call vote was 231 -- 185, with most of the opposition coming from Republicans.
The city will defend in court today its cancellation of its contract with the Broadway Maintenance Corporation to take care of nearly 52,000 parking meters.
Railroads and the Dow Theory dominated activity on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Aggregate market value of the carriers rose 2 1/2 per cent.

The National Dairy Products Corporation set new peaks last year in earnings, dollar and unit sales, dividends and working capital, according to the 1960 annual report of E.E. Stewart, chairman, and J. Huber Wetenhall, president, released today.

FREEPORT, L.I., March 21 -- A little pond next to the high school here has created something of a mystery. It did not freeze all winter. This has been boon to the Canada geese, swans and ducks that paddle around. It also has given bird-watchers something new to watch, and to figure out.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 21 -- Struggling on a rain-soaked field, the Yankees skidded to their ninth defeat in eleven games today when they bowed to Joe Gordon's Kansas City Athletics, 4 to 2. Rain, which had delayed the start of the game for an hour, put a final halt to the encounter after six and a half innings.

DETROIT, March 21 (UPI) -- The top booster division team, Hall's Recreation of Detroit, was disqualified and Rich Volling of St. Louis captured the classic singles lead at the American Bowling Congress today.
I grew up in Albany and I heartily agree with your editorial of March 4 in which you state that the Executive Mansion is too ugly and too poorly situated to be restored after the recent fire.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- President Kennedy's proposal to cut from $500 to $100 the amount of duty-free goods that American tourists can bring home from abroad will be considered again tomorrow in a closed meeting of the House Ways and Means Committee.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 21 -- Either in their numbers or in defects of structure, consistent evidence of abnormality is being found in the chromosomes of human leukemic blood cells, according to a report here today.

SEBRING, Fla., March 21 -- The Porsche and Ferrari teams, first of the factory representatives to arrive on the scene of the Sebring twelve-hour world championship sports car race set for this Saturday, were out for preliminary practice on the 5.2-mile course today.

ALBANY, March 21 (AP) -- A bill that would have eased libel or slander damages against newspapers or radio and television stations after retraction of the offending material was killed in the Assembly today.

GENEVA, March 21 -- The Soviet Union put the future of the conference on a treaty banning nuclear tests in serious doubt today. In a lengthy speech reopening the conference after a three-and-a-half-month recess, Semyon K. Tsarapkin, the Soviet delegate, went a long way toward confirming the Western powers' worst fears that the Russians had lost interest in working out a mutually acceptable treaty.

A combined Oxford-Cambridge lacrosse squad arrived yesterday for a close view of how the game is played by college teams in the United States. During a tour regarded as the most ambitious of its kind ever attempted by a group of English university players, the visitors will participate in seven contests.

Wool futures prices climbed in active trading yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Light trade buying touched off heavy commission house purchasing. There was chart buying of the deferred months. Trade selling supplied the contracts. The market closed at or near the highs of the day.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 21 -- Brazil, whose "independent" foreign policy ,already has shaken up her relations with the United States, appears to be preparing a jolt for another old Brazilian ally, Portugal.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Representative Francis E. Walter called today for resumption of the program of intercepting mail from Communist countries.

The Universal Match Corporation announced yesterday that it was negotiating to buy Reflectone Electronics, Inc., of Stamford, Conn. The transaction, if it should go through, would be made through an exchange of stock.
ALBANY, March 21 -- The Rockefeller administration's bill to restrict billboards along interstate highways has been tightly bottled up in committee with only a few days of the 1961 session left.

PARIS, March 21 -- The United States has decided to propose to Western Europe and Japan that each industrialized country provide annual aid to underdeveloped countries amounting to 1 per cent of its gross national product.
A proposal that Mayor Wagner appoint a Goals Commission to devise a long-range plan for the kind of place New York City should be was made public yesterday.
A special award was made yesterday by the Art Directors Club of New York to Helmut Krone, art director of Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc., for his work on the Volkswagen campaign.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 21 -- The Yankees today confirmed that they would switch their spring training camp from St. Petersburg to Fort Lauderdale in 1962.
Kenneth Thornhill's Brave Pilot took some of the chill out of the air for the favorite-players in the crowd of 24,386 at Aqueduct yesterday when she won the $10,000 feature.
LONDON, March 21 -- The Government rejected today a proposal to create a National Theatre.

LAST week Paris fashions for spring 1961 became widely available to New York women. From the Grand Concourse to Fifth Avenue to Thirty-fourth Street to Queens Boulevard, women could look at, try on and buy "line for line copies," "authentic adaptations," "direct translations" or "import impressions'' of the newest creations of Balenciaga, Dior, Chanel, Nina Ricci and other topflight designers.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- Swift Co., major packer of meats and other foods, was accused by the Federal Trade Commission today of offering "costly, unfair inducements'' to persuade, retailers to handle its ice cream and other frozen products.
Long Island University announced the 1960 winners of George Polk Memorial Awards in journalism yesterday.

Realizing the difficulties he was facing in attempting to prolong the third game of the world championship chess series in Moscow with Mikhail Botvinnik, Mikhail Tal of Latvia, the titleholder, resigned without resuming play, according to a report received yesterday through Tass, the official Soviet press agency.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- President Kennedy got a new name today, A-chi-ya-la-to-pa.
Paperboard production eased in the week ended last Saturday to 320,783 tons from 323,093 the week before, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. A year ago the figure was 320,721.
Mechanical failures, a death and an injury led to delays and confusion on the city's subways yesterday.
OXFORD, England, March 21 (AP) -- A sports car tore down the runway of a deserted airfield at nearly 100 miles an hour with a blind man at the wheel. Sitting unperturbed by his side was his wife.

MOSCOW, March 21 -- Premier Khrushchev reiterated today his long-standing proposition that the Soviet Union would agree to accept "any control" if the West accepted the Kremlin's disarmament proposals.
A report yesterday that Leo Durocher would be named manager of New York's new baseball entry in the National League was quickly dismissed by club officials.
OXFORD, England, March 21 (AP) -- A sports car tore down the runway of a deserted airfield at nearly 100 miles an hour with a blind man at the wheel. Sitting unperturbed by his side was his wife.

MOSCOW, March 21 -- Premier Khrushchev reiterated today his long-standing proposition that the Soviet Union would agree to accept "any control" if the West accepted the Kremlin's disarmament proposals.
A report yesterday that Leo Durocher would be named manager of New York's new baseball entry in the National League was quickly dismissed by club officials.

The fourth game of the world chess championship match between Mikhail Tal of Latvia and Mikhail Botvinnik, the challenger, at the Variety Theatre in Moscow, was adjourned after forty-one moves yesterday according to a report received through Tass, the official Soviet press agency.
Growth hormone extracted from human pituitary glands has quadrupled the development rate of those known as pituitary dwarfs.
In the world of professional prize fighting, those who have business at the Eighth Avenue Gymnasium seldom are seen at Voisin, a French restaurant on Park Avenue.
The Otis Elevator Company achieved record earnings of $24,313,245, or $2.95 a share, in 1960, L.A. Petersen, president, reported yesterday. Net income in 1959 was $24,011,732, or $2.91 a share.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -A regional planning expert told a Senate subcommittee today that the chronic ills of commuter rail service in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut metropolitan region could be cured only by a tri-state agency with Federal help.

The Chinese Nationalist Government is to be commended for finally acting to take out Chinese Nationalist military personnel and other refugees from Communist China who have long been a troublesome factor in areas of Burma, Laos and Thailand bordering on Yunnan. Nationalist planes are now regularly lifting loads of refugees from northern Thailand to Taiwan.
Mayor Wagner has ordered a permanent police detail to be assigned to Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan to hunt wrong-doing in city agencies.
PARIS, March 22 -- The French Government decided today to expose France's industry to an increase in foreign competition on the home market by reducing tariffs.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday he would begin presenting evidence on the college basketball scandal to a grand jury on April 4.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Legislation that would bring more than 1,200 inland water carriers under Government regulation was endorsed today by J.W. Hershey in behalf of the Inland Waterways Common Carriers Association.
Michael H. Prendergast said yesterday he had no intention of resigning as Democratic state chairman at a meeting of the party's new state executive committee this afternoon in the Biltmore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Administration's school-aid bill has been drafted in such a way that amendents providing for loans to private and parochial schools cannot be added on the House floor, parliamentary experts said today.
MANHASSET, L.I., March 22 -- A Nassau County policeman was shot and killed today by three masked men shortly after they had robbed a supermarket manager of $3,000.
ALBANY, March 22 -- The State Senate approved a highly controversial bill today expanding the jurisdiction of the bi-state Waterfront Commission over labor activities on the New York waterfront.
LONDON, March 22 -- Profit taking forced most industrial share prices lower in the stock market here today. Nevertheless, there was still considerable selective demand.

The time for investors to avail themselves of the Treasury's offer to exchange up to $8,000,000,000 of Government securities due in 1962 and 1963 into higher-yielding bonds due in 1966 and 1967 ended yesterday with a late demand of broad scope developing for the new 3 3/8s of 1966 and the exchange partner, the 2 1/2s of 1963.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 8 points up to 5 points off yesterday. There was near-month covering at the close.
LONDON, March 22 -- All five defendants in Britain's latest espionage case were found guilty today.
A portrait of Galileo by Feliks Topolski, will appear in the first advertisement of a new campaign for the Eterna Watch Company.

BANGKOK, Thailand, March 22 -- Military commanders of the United States and its seven Allies in the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization met here today to decide on advice to their governments concerning Communist penetration into Laos, South Vietnam and other Asian nations.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Vice President Johnson today appointed the ten members of the United States Commission on the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 -- There is statistical evidence that smokers using cigarettes relatively low in tar and in nicotine suffer less from chronic coughs than do smokers of those with higher tar and nicotine content, Dr. E. Cuyler Hammond of the American Cancer Society said here today.

ALBANY, March 22 -- A bill that would require all motorists to furnish proof of adequate eyesight as a condition for renewal of a driver's license was approved by the Senate today despite some opposition from upstate Republicans.
LOS ANGELES, March 22 -- The third murder trial of DR. Bernard Finch and Carol Tregoff, who are accused killing the surgeon's wife, to the jury late today. Deliberations will begin tomorrow.
CHICAGO, March 22 (AP) -- A university professor peered into the future today and said he saw a mostly rosy outlook for the American economy during the rest of the Nineteen Sixties.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -Congress completed action on the Kennedy Administration's first farm bill today. Immediately afterward, the President signed the measure and proclaimed it "a very important step toward learning to live with our agricultural abundance."

EDWARD R. MURROW is off to a dismaying start as director of the United States Information Agency. His action in trying to induce the British Broadcasting Corporation to cancel a television program showing an unfavorable aspect of American life is as indefensible as it is futile.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 22 -- The General Assembly postponed a resumption of the Congo debate today because no delegate was ready to speak. The Assembly is not expected to take up the Congo question again before Friday.
A New York author who wrote his first television drama to enter an international script writing competition was informed yesterday that he had won the first prize of $5,000.

BRADENTON, March 22 -- For the third time this spring one could say today, "As Mickey Mantle goes, so go the Yankees." On this sunny afternoon Mickey had to go to tremendous lengths before the Yankees were able to flatten Chuck Dressen's Braves for keeps, 14 to 11.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These rates do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -President Kennedy signed today the act of Congress he had urged restoring the five-star rank of General of the Army to former President Dwight D. Eisenhower.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 22 (AP) -- J. Philip Murphy, vice president of Yuba Consolidated Industries, Inc., was elected president last night, after the board of directors accepted the resignation of John L. McGara, who had been president and chairman the last four years.

ALBANY, March 22 -- State bills to add fifteen justices the New York City Municipal Court this year appeared tonight to be headed for immediate legislative approval. Under bipartisan agreements, nine Democrats and six Republicans would receive the nominations of both parties for the new places if Governor Rockefeller signs the bills.
A New York Daily News reporter testified yesterday that Arnold Schuster had expressed fear of bodily harm the day after he told the police where to capture Willie Sutton, the fugutive bank robber.
The nation's reserves of crude oil declined last year while those of natural gas and natural gas liquids rose to new highs.
Julian A. Silverman Associates, realty Operators, have bought four buildings from the Holden Holding Corporation in a package deal negotiated by Schimmer, Kerner Feder, brokers.
The Commonweal, a Roman Catholic weekly published by laymen, yesterday said the Kennedy Administration's aid-to-education bill "should be supported."

PITTSBURGH, March 22 -- The National Council of Jewish Women called today for Federal legislation to provide medical insurance for the aged under Social Security. The council said that longer life spans and lower retirement ages were creating a "new class of Americans -- the medically indigent."
Mayor Wagner's proposal to redevelop fourteen blocks in Greenwich Village has been obscured by the indefiniteness of the plan itself and the intensity of the opposition it has engendered.
QUITO, Ecuador, March 22 -Political unrest is spreading in Ecuador, a prime South American target of Communists and Castro agitators and organizers.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 22 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Beau Prince, with Eddie Arcaro contributing a masterly ride, defeated Crozier by a nose today in the $15,000-added Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park.
ALBANY, March 22 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today that the burned-out Executive Mansion would be rebuilt rather than replaced.

Railroad issues moved up in a nondescript stock market yesterday. Once again low-price shares dominated trading on the New York Stock Exchange, for eleven of the fifteen most active issues closed below $25 a share and of these nine were up.
Three couples were arraigned yesterday following charges that they had stolen $150,000 in valuables from fashionable homes from Florida to Massachusetts during the last few months.

A heated exchange between opposing counsel marked yesterday's closing session of Public Service Commission hearings on the Long Island Rail Road's application for permission to provide rail-bus service in Suffolk County.

LONDON, March 22 -- Britain is dispatching a note to the Soviet Union asking for immediate reactivation of the International Control Commission on Laos to halt fighting in the nation and to end the flow of United States and Soviet arms.

PARIS, March 22 -- Jacques Chaban-Delmas, Speaker of the French National Assembly and a recent visitor to Washington, predicted today a meeting between President de Gaulle and President Kennedy "before the summer."
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 22 -- The Congo is facing a desperate economic problem and financial bankruptcy.

Circulation figures for the last half of 1960 in the highly competitive magazine field show over-all newsstand sales up two-tenths of 1 per cent, subscription sales up 3.3 per cent and total sales up 2.3 per cent from the levels of the last six months of 1959.

Othmar Schneider, the ski teacher at Stowe, Vt., is leaving for California today to appear in a pro race. He isn't perturbed by reports that Marc Hodler, the president of the Federation Internationale de Ski, is against racing for pay.

Events today: "Don Carlo," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic preview concert, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, William Masselos, pianist, 8:30; Peter Dickinson, pianist, and Dinos Constantindes, violinist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Harold Russell, national commander of American Veterans of World War II and Korea (AMVETS), said today that, while he opposed all measures pending in Congress to increase veterans' pensions, he did not oppose all pending bills affecting veterans.

ST. LOUIS, March 22 (UPI) -- A third-quarter assist from the bench carried the St. Louis Hawks to a 121-106 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers tonight. The triumph evened The National Basketball Association's final Western Division play-off series at 1-1.

Time will tell which was the "blunder" -- the position taken in your editorial of March 18 castigating Charles Silver, president of the New York City Board of Education, or Mr. Silver's position in his testimony before a House committee.

"PASSPORT TO CHINA" should inspire few moviegoers to apply for one. Appropriately, this British-made melodrama, starring Richard Basehart, opened yesterday in neighborhood theatres in second place on a double bill.
CRISTOBAL, C.Z., March 22 -- After almost running down their unlighted twenty-foot launch in darkness, the fruit ship Yaque rescued last night four Dutch nationals who were adrift almost three weeks.
New York will have its first city-wide demonstration of Girl Scout know-how in a "Daisy Days" festival on May 6 and 7 in each of the five boroughs.
LONDON, March 22 (AP) -- John's Court won the Lincolnshire Handicap at odds of 25 -- 1 today and Britain's top bookies gave a huge sigh of relief.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- President Kennedy twice today termed Dwight D. Eisenhower a great President.
A French airline stewardess was accused yesterday of attempting to smuggle four and a half pounds of pure heroin into the United States from Paris.

THE annual Intercollegiate Bridge Tournament, in which 170 college teams of sixteen or more players each competed, ended earlier this month, but the winners will not be announced this week as scheduled.
While hundreds were having lunch yesterday at Luchow's restaurant, 110 East Fourteenth Street, two gunmen, bound and gagged two women employes and seized a $9,000 payroll.

GENEVA, March 22 -- The West started today on a detailed explanation of its proposals for a treaty banning nuclear tests. It was a time-marking operation and everyone around the conference table knew it.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 22 (UPI) -- A former Pentagon employe, Arthur Rogers Roddey, was sentenced today to eight years in prison for stealing a secret defense document.

TORONTO, March 22 (UPI) -- George Armstrong broke up a Stanley Cup semi-final game tonight after 4 minutes 51 seconds of the second overtime period and carried the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 3-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.
The strike of 1,500 truck drivers and pushboys in the women's garment industry -- New York's largest -- was settled last night.
Mayor Wagner continued to improve yesterday in his convalescense from a neck tumor operation on Monday.

LONDON, March 22 -- Kenneth Adam, controller of television programs for the British Broadcasting Corporation, said last night that the B.B.C. had bought "Harvest of Shame" in good faith, as it had bought other programs from America, such as recent ones on the U-2 flight and the color question.

Roy Wilkins, executive secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, assailed yesterday a statement issued by the National Civil War Centennial Commission in a dispute over hotel accommodations in Charleston, S.C. Mr. Wilkins said the statement was something less than honest.
The State of Rhode Island borrowed $10,900,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance highways, schools, beach developments and other public improvements.
PHILADELPHIA, March 22 -- The Most Rev. John Joseph Krol was installed today as tenth head of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Philadelphia.
PHILADELPHIA, March 22 -- The four-day strike of 750 unskilled workers at the Cuneo Eastern Press, Inc., ended today.

Plans for construction this summer of a new hydroelectric plant to cost about $44,000,000 were announced to stockholders of the Shawinigan Water and Power Company at their annual meeting in Montreal yesterday by J.A. Fuller, president.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 22 -- If a boat leaks, plugging the hole with a stopper from another part of the boat isn't recommended. But Charlie Dressen, the not-too-ancient mariner who pilots the Milwaukee Braves, has been desperate enough to do something along those lines.
MARYSVILLE, Calif., March 22 (UPI) -- A four-engine Super Constellation crashed into the swampy Butte Sink area near here today, killing all six men aboard.

Residential sales of electricity by the American Electric Power Company, by 1975 should approach 1960 sales to all consumers, including industrial users, Philip Sporn, president, predicted in the 1960 annual report released yesterday.
United States petroleum refiners cut processing operations last week as gasoline inventories neared the record high set a year ago.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had completed arrangements with three insurance companies for a $10,000,000 "excess bond" designed to protect investors against losses through fraud.
The city's elementary school system apparently is losing ground academically compared with schools elsewhere in the nation, a Board of Education report indicated yesterday.
Many travel-minded New Yorkers are likely to be in Europe in the late spring. Therefore, a benefit on the Continent would appear to have a likely potential.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -Following is the text of President Kennedy's message to Congress on foreign aid:
MEXICO CITY, March 22 -Jose Pardo Llada, a leading radio and television spokesman for the Cuban regime, declared today that he had broken with Premier Fidel Castro.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges said today that the United States must attract more tourists and do "a much better job of making them welcome."

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, March 22 (AP) -- Picket lines were established in front of the Halifax Shipyards, Ltd., today as 1,200 Halifax and Dartmouth shipyard workers went on strike to support wage demands.

FORT PIERCE, Fla., March 22 (UPI) -- A private detective with a bloodhound named Holmes tried to cast doubt today on the prosecution's story that Circuit Judge and Mrs. C. E. Chillingworth had been murdered at sea.
SHIRLEY BOOTH gave a warm and attractive performance as a housekeeper facing the loss of her job in a taped "United States Steel Hour" production on Channel 2 last night.
Cuba is being "infiltrated daily" by men and supplies to help forces within the island to oust the regime of Premier Fidel Castro, according to former Premier Manuel Antonio de Varona.

Volume on the New York Stock Exchange has been mow i ing at a brisk pace. Yesterday, __fr example, 5,840,000 shares !changed hands. The total, hoNlever, does not include rights -.s [those special deals to stocki holders offering them the ]chance to buy a company's [:shares at a special price.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Edward R. Murrow, director of the United States Information Agency, tried and failed to persuade British officials not to show a controversial television documentary on the plight of migrant labor in this country.

A Providence, R.I., savings bank has made the first investment of private capital in Federal Housing Administration home mortgages in Alaska. Daniel E. Stoddard, president of the People's Savings Bank, said that his bank had purchased $1,000,000 in loans made to finance the construction of fifty homes in Juneau.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Scientists in several nations, among them the United States and the Soviet Union, already have done things to control the weather through "cloud physics." But this Government, which is spending billions annually to reshape the conditions of outer space so that mankind may traverse it for the purposes of peace and war, devoted only $36 millions in 1959 for meteorological research in inner space by all the Federal departments and agencies.
The Rockefeller Administration's rent-control bill was assailed by both landlord and tenant groups here yesterday as a politically inspired proposal that favored the other side.

In the course of discussing Australian dogs in general, David J.K. Roche of North Adelaide mentioned that while the importation of German shepherds was forbidden by law, the breed probably ranked second only to English cocker spaniels on the island continent.

Five favorites scored at Aqueduct yesterday, causing many of the 22,485 customers to consider themselves most astute. The victories virtually transformed a damp, cold day into a balmy spring afternoon.

WARSAW, March 22 -- Polish civil authorities were reported today to have decided to shrug off for the time being the bitter attacks of Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski against the Government's Church policy.

Electric power production fell in the week ended last Saturday to 14,295,000,000 kilowatt-hours from 14,353,000,000 kilowatt-hours the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the comparable 1960 period the figure was 14,219,000,000 kilowatt-hours.

The rule or ruin policy of Premier Khrushchev toward the United Nations is now being extended to the disarmament and test-ban negotiations with one no longer disguised objective. This is to impose Soviet domination on all international machinery, whether it be the United Nations, or a disarmament or test control commission, or an international police force, or, failing that, to paralyze such agencies by a veto.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee accused the Kennedy Administration today of trying to impede newsmen "in their efforts to keep the public fully informed about Government activities."

A merger of Actors Equity and the American Guild of Musical Artists is in the discussion state. Ralph Bellamy, president of Equity, which has a membership of 12,000, has let it be known that an amalgamation is "imminent."
BALTIMORE, March 22 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted eight milk companies today on charges of fixing prices and rigging bids on milk sold to Baltimore city and county schools.

An investor has bought the five-story walk-up apartment building at 35-20 Ninety-fourth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, from Mrs. M. Toffler. The buyer, a client of Herbert Frutkin, lawyer, paid cash over mortgages of $72,000 in a deal negotiated by the William K. Langfan Company, broker.
BUENOS AIRES, March 22 -- Lieut. Gen. Carlos Toranzo Montero, Commander in Chief of the Argentine Army and long at odds with President Arturo Frondizi, was reported to have resigned today.
DETROIT, March 22 (UPI) -- Morrie Oppenheim moved into third place in the classic singles with a 660 today at the American Bowling Congress.

Dayton, the only seeded team remaining in the National Invitation Tournament, will meet St. Louis in the first semi-final game of the annual basketball event tonight at Madison Square Garden. Providence and Holy Cross are slated to meet in the second game.

YONKERS, March 22 -- Down-flashes, or "hot horses" as the punters say, did well at Yonkers Raceway tonight. Two lightly regarded pacers developed into "good things" in the first two races and the result was a $127.10 daily double.

During the past two or three week-ends, in this latitude, there have been those who worked diligently in their yards, raking leaves and sometimes burning them to the discomfiture of leeward neighbors, or carting them off to compost heaps (as books on gardening say they should).
Atlantic City Electric Company sold $10,000,000 of first mortgage bonds at a competitive sale yesterday at an interest cost of 4.41 per cent.

MRS. ALFRED L. WOLF scorns the idea that ballooning is dangerous. But she was recently involved in an incident to chill the blood of the earthbound. She Was 4,200 feet above the earth with four other passengers in the basket of her balloon when an emergency panel opened.

More than 125 women crowded into a male stronghold -- the Harvard Club -- to hear talks about investments yesterday. Guests of honor were two women who probably control more money than most men -- Elizabeth Rudel Smith, Treasurer of the United States, and Hilda G. Schwartz, Treasurer of the City of New York.
ITHACA, N.Y., March 22 -Prof. Walter F. Willcox took Walter F. Willcox Day in stride here today.
CHICAGO, March 22 (AP) -- Old crop soybeans futures prices leaped well ahead today on a couple of bullish factors and closed at $3 a bushel or more with gains of about 9 cents.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 22 -- South Africa's Suppression of Communism Act was used today to restrict the activities of a leading anti-Communist and critic of Prime Minister Verwoerd.

INSTEAD of a stethoscope Henry Brandon uses a tape recorder. Armed with it he has been asking all kinds of leading Americans all kinds of leading questions. His findings are presented in a stimulating book of conversation pieces called "As We Are.''*

The Orchestra of America, formed and conducted by Richard Korn, completed its second season last night with a Carnegie Hall concert devoted to music by four living Americans. They were Philip James, William Schuman, Paul Creston and Randall Thompson.
Commercial paper dealers cut by one-eighth percentage point yesterday the rates to investors on these unsecured short-term obligations of business concerns which they sell in the open market.

LOS ANGELES, March 22 -- The United States must provide the dynamic leadership the world so badly needs and in doing so must keep first in mind the nations of the Western Hemisphere, Premier Pedro Beltran of Peru said today at Charter Day exercises at University of California, Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 15:
ALBANY, March 22 -- Action was taken by the Rockefeller administration today to enable New York State to take speedy advantage of the Federal extension of unemployment insurance benefits.
NEW DELHI, India, March 13 -- A New York team learned here this week that it could not beat the Indians at their best sport, but that it could win their hearts.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Western powers will present a new peace plan on Laos to the Soviet Union tomorrow. It is viewed here as probably the final test of Moscow's willingness to work out a peaceful settlement of the Laotian struggle.
LONDON, March 22 -- The intensity of the strife rending the Labor party was demonstrated today when a right-wing member of Parliament quit the party and a left-wing M.P. was suspended by it.

American Broadcasting-Paramount Pictures, Inc. realized a 31 per cent increase in earnings last year on a 16 per cent gain in gross income, Leonard H. Goldenson, president, disclosed in the annual report issued for publication today.

THE New York City Ballet came forward last night with the novelty of its season at the City Center -- a ballet called "Electronics," built on an electronic score composed by Remi Gassmann and created physically by him and Oskar Sala in the latter's laboratory in West Germany.

The Pennsylvania Railroad, the nation's largest, operated at a net loss of $9,031,977 in the first two months this year. It was one of the worst showings for the period in the carrier's 114-year history.

The appointment of Rear Admiral Norman J. Drustrup of the Navy's Civil Engineer Corps, as director of the Atlantic division of the Bureau of Yards and Docks and Area Public Works Officer was announced yesterday.

LONDON, March 22 -- For five days last week and three days this week, a calm, quiet-voiced, self-effacing man has looked down on one of the most intriguing spy trials Britain has witnessed since World War II.

Robert Paxton, who resigned as president of the General Electric Company at the end of February because of ill health, on Feb. 14 purchased 4,723 shares of G.E. stock, increasing his holdings to 28,450 shares.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The State Department said to day that Cuban refugee groups would violate United States sovereignty and international law if they established a provisional government in the United States without United States consent.

Richard Norris, a young pianist from the West Coast made his New York debut last night in Judson Hall. A longtime student of Egon Petri, he played with the San Francisco Symphony in a summer concert and has given several recitals in his section of the country.

TAMPA, Fla., March 22 -- For years, the Reds have had almost everything except pitching to make them a pennant threat. It would be exaggerating to say that they have everything else this season, but, in a low voice, Manager Fred Hutchinson does suggest that the Cincinnati pitching will be better than it has been for some time.

BONN, Germany, March 22 -- George W. Ball, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, indicated today that he had found the West German Government agreeable to a United States suggestion that industrial nations spend 1 per cent of their gross national product annually for foreign aid.

Rumors that lower synthetic rubber prices are in the offing and poor consumer demand depressed natural rubber futures yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Trade and hedge selling touched off light stop-loss orders.
Stockholders of the ABC Vending Corporation will be asked to approve a two-for-one stock split at the annual meeting on May 3, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin Sherman, chairman.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 22 -A sixteen-acre site along Hempstead Harbor that abounds in minerals, fossils and marine life will be acquired by Nassau County for development as a park.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- After 161 years, the District of Columbia's voteless citizens are expected to get next week the right to vote in Presidential elections.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -Each President since Franklin D. Roosevelt has felt constrained to perform an act of faith in the field of Soviet-American relations.
Foreign maritime opposition to the "Ship and Travel American" campaign of United States ship operators was termed unrealistic here yesterday by a shipping executive.

Bills in the State Legislature to create new judgeships -- thirty-eight were recommended by the Judicial Conference -- have been hamstrung in their passage by a complicated tangle of partisan political maneuvers. Party leaders, both in and out of the Legislature, don't want such measures passed unless they can agree beforehand as to what the party allegiance of the judges to be named will be -- even some advance agreement as to the candidates themselves.

LONDON, March 22 -- Prime Minister Macmillan denounced South Africa's racial policy in the strongest terms tonight. He described it as "abhorrent to the ideals with which mankind is struggling in this century."

On March 25 and 26 a Conference of Western Europe for Amnesty for Spanish Prisoners and Political Exiles is to take place in Paris. It is with the utmost regret that the Spaniards who sign this letter must record not only their inability to support such an assembly but their protest against some aspects of it.

The United States Census Bureau said yesterday that it had not intended to offend the State of Connecticut and that its final, official report on the 1960 census had included all the information the state desired.
American jazz followers are experiencing an event rare in this country although it is the customary lot of their European counterparts: a visit by an internationally famous American jazz musician.

The Ford Motor Company Fund announced a grant of $250,000 to the Institute of International Education yesterday. It will be used to bring fifty outstanding scholars from non-Communist areas to the United States for graduate study.
SOME of the complaints women have been voicing about the design of bedrooms and beds in recent conferences on housing were echoed yesterday by a group of professionals.
An outline of specific programs to refurbish Times Square and the theatre district was submitted to Mayor Wagner's office yesterday.
Sixteen acres of land at the southwest corner of Waverly Avenue and Sunrise Highway at Patchogue, L.I., have been selected as the site for a new shopping center to be known as Sunrise Plaza.
LEOPOLDVILLE, March 22 -- Supplies for the United Nations have started to arrive in Matadi despite the absence of United Nations forces in the port city.

The Statte Commission Against Discrimination warned cab drivers and operators of taxi fleets yesterday that "stern measures" would be taken against anyone found guilty of turning away Negro passengers.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 22 -- Foreign oil companies and local petroleum distributors are quietly fighting an order by Brazil's Government that "windfall" income resulting from an increase of 75 per cent in gasoline prices be turned over to Petroleo Brasileiro, S.A. (Petrobras), the state oil company.
CHICAGO, March 22 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 22 -- Ed Wynn is back at his old tomfoolery.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Congress cleared the way today for the payment of additional unemployment compensation to workers whose state benefits have run out. The first checks should be available in early April for those who qualify.

The Board of Estimate informally approved yesterday the contracts and the financing program for a 55,000-seat baseball stadium in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens. The action was taken at an executive session and the board is scheduled to give its formal approval at an open meeting today.

CLEVELAND, March 22 (AP) -- Controlling ownership in the Cleveland Browns of the National Football League went to two New York men today in a $4,000,000 deal. Coach Paul Brown received a new eight-year contract and a free hand to operate the team in the same winning way he has since 1946.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 22 -- The United States and the Soviet Union have decided to resume disarmament negotiations in Geneva, probably in August, but they have not yet agreed on who shall join them around the table.
The city has modified its regulations limiting the operation of huge construction cranes and other equipment on the streets.

The Red Cross doesn't have to read statistical charts to know that the nation is on the move. In just four years the amount of blood exchanged through the national reciprocity system hap gone up 50 per cent.

The city Traffic Department did not provide enough spare parking meters and this was partly responsible for delays in service by the Broadway Maintenance Corporation, the company has charged in one of its suits against the city.

After practicing such nonsense for more than a decade, the United States Post Office has finally been ordered to stop seizing printed matter addressed to American recipients from Communist-controlled countries. Since the McCarran-McCarthy days of 1950 the department -- at first surreptitiously and later openly -- has been holding up such mail as it deemed propagandistic and (only in recent years) delivering it upon specific request of the addressee.

MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, B.W.I., March 22 -- Escapade, which had appeared almost certain to make a runaway of the Miami-Montego Bay yacht race, ran into unexpected head winds while rounding the southeast corner of Cuba this morning.
TRENTON, March 22 -- Four children died this morning in a fire that burned out the trailer home of their parents in nearby Hamilton Township.

LUANDA, Angola, March 22 -- Four hundred Portuguese shouted and booed for nearly two hours today in front of the United States Consulate here. The demonstration was in protest against United States criticism in the United Nations of Portugal's colonial rule.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- R. Sargent Shriver was confirmed without dissent by the Senate today as director of the Peace Corps.
Confidence that the United States could achieve a new growth of export trade was voiced yesterday by Rowland Burnstan, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for International Affairs.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Simon H. Rifkind of New York, a former Federal judge, was sworn in today as the new chairman of the President's fifteen-member panel considering the controversy over work rules in the railroad industry.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk has ordered officials not to tell Congressional investigators anything about alleged scandals in the foreign aid program. They are being investigated by the Executive branch.

ALBANY, March 22 -- The Assembly passed and sent to the Senate today a bill that would permit bank holding companies to obtain 100 per cent ownership of subsidiary banks without setting up intermediate "phantom" banks.

The American Ballet Theatre will have a spring season of two weeks at the Broadway Theatre beginning April 24. This will be its first appearances in New York since its tour last season of Europe, which included the first visit of any American ballet company to the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- President Kennedy's supporters in the House of Representatives apparently were preparing today for a major concession in the battle for an increase in the minimum wage.

BELLEVILLE, Ont., March 22 (UPI) -- A 10-year-old kidnap victim was found tied to a tree and dead of exposure near here today twenty-four hours after the boy's Scoutmaster had committed suicide after having been questioned by the police.

In your leading editorial of March 18 you rightly praised the action of Ambassador Stevenson in supporting a debate about Angola in the Security Council and in voting for the resolution which followed even though our British, French, Turkish and Chinese allies, not to speak of Portugal, took a different view.

"A Calabash of Diamond," by Margaret Lane, will be published by Duell, Sloan and Pearce next Thursday. It is an account of a safari made by the author, her husband, the Earl of Huntingdon, and his nephew into the wild African territory between southern Rhodesia and Mozambique.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 22 -- Bergen County moved today to help improve the state's economy by taking steps sooner than expected to issue $1,615,000 of improvement bonds. Almost $1,000,000 will go into road work.
MADRID, March 22 (Reuters) -- Eleven oil prospectors captured in the Spanish Sahara eleven days ago arrived today in the Canary Islands after their release by the Moroccan Government last night.

It is astounding to find the president of the Board of Education of New York City testifying in favor of aid to parochial schools on the specious argument that the city would be unable to take care of the several hundred thousand children now in such schools.

FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., March 22 (AP) -- Sidney B. Wood 3d, 22-year-old Yale tennis star and son of a former international tennis player, died here early today of injuries suffered in an automobile accident Saturday.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The number of dilapidated housing units occupied by households whose heads were nonwhites dropped from 1,273,000 in 1950 to 886,000 in 1960, the United States Census Bureau reported today.

The National Association of Securities Dealers expelled twenty-three of its member concerns last year for violations of its Rules of Fair Practice and also revoked the registrations of thirty-six representatives of member concerns.
Grading operations began yesterday on thirty-five acres in Kissena Corridor Park where the enlarged, improved Queens Botanical Gardens are to be situated.

ALBANY, March 22 -- Legislation upholding Mayor Wagner's authority to prohibit driving in New York City during emergencies was passed unanimously in the Assembly today and sent to Governor Rockefeller.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- President Kennedy called today for a "fresh approach" to foreign aid. It would shift the emphasis from mutual security to a collective free world effort to help the under-developed nations attain greater economic growth and stability.

The Cuban exiles have at last agreed on the equivalent of a unified Provisional Government. This was an obvious, preliminary step that had to be taken before there could be any hopes of concerting a drive to overthrow the Castro regime.

NEW ORLEANS, March 22 (AP) -- Ron Weber took the lead in the first qualifying round of the fifty-ninth Western amateur golf tournament today. He shot a three-under-par 35, 33 -- 68 at the New Orleans Country Club course.

THE first "Parsifal" of the season was presented last night at the Metropolitan Opera, and among its several points of interest was the presence of Karl Boehm, who had never previously directed the opera in New York.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 23 -- Salary increases are planned for Nassau County's 8,000 employes.

Although Laos could become a major East-West battleground, the vast majority of the nation's 3,000,000 people have never heard of the "cold war." Ninety per cent of them are illiterate farmers who grow rice and cotton and produce the country's main export, opium.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The New York Times reported incorrectly this morning that Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman would have the authority to sell grain at less than the Federal price support under terms of the new feed-grains bill signed by President Kennedy last night.

Administrative and legislative leaders in New Jersey yesterday indicated overwhelming opposition to the package bill that would authorize the Port of New York Authority to acquire the bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad and build a $335,000,000 world trade center in lower Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Following are the main points of President Kennedy's news conference today:
Negotiations are in progress for Bob Newhart to star in a comedy variety series next season over the National Broadcasting Company television network.
WHITE PLAINS, March 23 -- The organization of the Vigilance Committee to Preserve and Expand Westchester County Parks was announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Space agency said today that within a few days it would attempt to shoot a payload far above the earth to measure the intensity of magnetic fields and solar winds in interplanetary space.
The General Dynamics Corporation reported yesterday that it had a net loss of $27,055,851 last year, in contrast to a profit of $31,056,069, or $3.12 a share, in 1959.
HOUSTON, Tex., March 23 (AP) -- A credit expert said today teenagers would limit future family ability to purchase a new automobile, refrigerator or television set.
GENEVA, March 23 -- The West appealed to the Soviet Union today to join in a program that would utilize peaceful nuclear explosions for the "benefit of all mankind."
A three-week visit to this country has persuaded four Soviet professional women that the Soviet standard of living will overtake the American "in not so many years," they said yesterday.

Peter Dickinson, pianist, and Dinos Constantinides, violinist, played a program of five sonatas and one sonatina in Carnegie Hall last night. The sonatas were by Corelli, Handel, Brahms, Copland and Mr. Dickinson. The smaller work was by Mikis Theodorakis, who -- like the violinist -- was born in Greece.
Twenty-two families were ordered out of a seven-story apartment building in the East Bronx yesterday. The Building Department said it was in "imminent danger of collapse."
LENINGRAD, March 23 -- Leningrad residents acclaimed tonight the premiere of a Soviet ballet in modern tempo, "The Legend of Love." It was danced by the Mariinsky Ballet Company.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 23 -- The textile industry still expects to obtain quotas on textile imports, which long have been hampering it in building volume.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 23 -- Conciliation efforts between the Congo's Central Government and the rival regime of Antoine Gizenga will get under way officially in Stanleyville Saturday.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- President Kennedy suggested tonight that the United States should pour more books into the battle for men's minds in uncommitted nations.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 23 -- Financial authorities moved here today to put tighter strings on the purse that Secretary General Dag Hmmarskjold can use to meet sudden threats to world peace.

BANGKOK, Thailand, March 23 -- Strategic considerations raised by the turmoil in Laos have focused on the broad Mekong River as the line the United States and its allies would have to defend to prevent a Communist advance southward from the Laotian salient.
American Export Lines, which is usually more concerned with promoting travel aboard its three passenger liners, is putting an accent on de luxe freighter travel.
YONKERS, March 23 -- Spring was nowhere in sight, but business went on as usual at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

In a recent editorial on "Unwise Boycotts" you quote the Administration as having spoken out vigorously against this procedure. You fail to quote Secretary of Commerce Hodges' statement in The Daily News Record of March 1 that "mills need Government aid to survive."

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The United States is rushing military support to the Government of Laos and was reported to be placing its latest types of military equipment at strategic depots for possible action by the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization.
Mrs. John F. Kennedy returned to Washington yesterday after three days of shopping in New York with a load of spring fashions that could have been marked "Top Secret."
A national mental health program designed to change drastically the public care of mentally ill persons will be presented to Congress today. It includes a proposal to use Federal funds for treatment.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 23 -- War booty believed to have been captured from Roman legions by Jewish rebels eighteen centuries ago was found today in a cave west of the Dead Sea.

MONTREAL, March 23 (UPI) -- Eddie Litzenberger's goal with less than three minutes to play gave the Chicago Black Hawks a 4-3 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight. The Hawks' triumph evened the four-of-seven Stanley Cup semi-final hockey series at one victory apiece.

Pepis-Cola United Bottlers, Inc., largest independent bottler of Pepsi-Cola, is seeking an injunction to restrain the Estate of James W. Carkner from selling 282,380 shares, and Mrs. Grace Carkner from selling 9,900 shares of Pepsi-Cola General, Inc., without giving Pepsi-Cola United first refusal.
CORVALLIS, Ore., March 23 (AP) -- Oklahoma State scored three first-round victories today in the National Collegiate wrestling championships.

ALBANY, Friday, March 24 -- The Rockefeller administration's measure to extend rent controls for two years was approved by the Assembly this morning by a 130-13 vote. All the negative votes were cast by upstate Republicans.

ALBANY, March 23 -- The State Senate approved unanimously today a bill revising the corporation franchise tax, which will provide $16,300,000 in tax relief for some manufacturers but increase the burden on other taxpayers, mainly real estate corporations, by $14,800,000.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23 (AP) -- Neil Johnston resigned today as the coach of the Philadelphia Warriors of the National Basketball Association. He said it was best for all concerned, but he didn't say why.
ALBANY, March 23 -- The Assembly gave final legislative approval late tonight to a measure to discourage persons from coming into the state to get on public welfare rolls.
LONDON, March 23 -- The House of Lords, with one excep tion, stood united today behind the British Government's firm position against South Africa's racial policy.

ANOTHER sparkling book by Bernard Shaw. Although he died in 1950, it is difficult to realize that his disappearance is permanent. For new collections of his letters and random pieces keep turning up in the bookstalls and giving fresh insights into his genius.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) -- Charles B. (Bud) Wilkinson, head football coach at the University of Oklahoma, was named by President Kennedy today as a special consultant on youth fitness. He will serve without pay.

KANSAS CITY, March 23 (AP) -- Ohio State's unbeaten Buckeyes resume defense of their National Collegiate basketball championship tomorrow night when they meet St. Joseph's of Pennsylvania in a semi-final game.
CREATIVITY, particularly in children, is becoming more and more a subject of deep interest to parents, educators and child-care specialists.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 23 -- A site known as Edgemoor, just outside Oak Ridge, Tenn., has been chosen for a $125,000,000 Tennessee Valley Authority steam plant.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 4 to 18 points yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
OMAHA, March 23 -- Secretary Freeman said today that the Administration's new feed-grain program could become "a very significant turning point away from the long build-up in farm surpluses."
Automotive accessory manufacturers are girding for a windfall of new business.
A heliport that will make it possible to fly to the heart of Manhattan will be built atop the fifty-nine-story Pan American World Airways building going up behind Grand Central Terminal.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- There are signs of improvement in the national economy, President Kennedy declared tonight. But he said it was too soon to make a precise judgment on whether the recovery would be strong enough.

In his letter published March 9, Walter Millis discusses the issue "Whether we do or do not prepare ourselves to fight a conventional war for Germany and Western Europe" and observes that: "If we do not, we are handcuffed to our super-giant weaponry and will be unable to fight any war except for ends on which we may justifiably stake the survival of civilization.
Around dawn today in a spot in the Atlantic Ocean south of Argentia, Nfld., the Coast Guard will drop a shipment of blood plasma for an injured Norwegian seaman.
Heraldic shields representing major cities in Italy adorned the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night for the Italian Centennial Ball.

WHEN Harold and Barbara Rhodes went to France in the summer of 1948 they had four whole months to spend. Their plans were vague, but they knew that for several weeks they would be paying guests at the Chateau Beaumesnil in Touraine not far from Blois. It sounded like such fun! They both loved France and being in France and the very idea of France.

SEBRING, Fla., March 23 (UPI) -- Count Wolfgang von Trips of Germany set an unofficial lap record in a rear-engine Ferrari today in a practice run for Saturday's twelve-hour endurance race for sports cars.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Treasury announced today that it would borrow $1,600,000,000 in cash next week and that it might borrow another $200,000,000 in succeeding weeks.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- The methods used to determine the various ratings ascribed to television programs are studded with errors, a group of statistical experts reported to Congress today.
The New York Central Railroad had a net loss of $7,953,381 in February and its deficit for the first two months of this year was $13,230,299, the carrier reported yesterday.
LONDON, March 23 -- A new arts center on the south bank of the Thames, combining the Royal Festival Hall with a smaller concert hall and an art gallery, will be built within three years.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Following are excerpts from a report made today by The Joint Commission on Mental Illness and Health for a national mental health program:

THE two little plays from the French that arrived at the Royal Playhouse last night are written with delicate sensitivity, but they are so fragile that they almost evaporate before they have fun their course.
Tax borrowing by businesses at New York City banks was significantly higher this March than a year ago, figures published yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed.
STUART, Fla., March 23 -- Art Flick of Westkill, N.Y., a Catskill fly fisherman before he stopped using baby talk, is the author of the immortal couplet, dazzling in its simple clarity:
THIS deal caused trouble to every pain that held the North-South cards in a recent bridge tournament played in New York.
Labor peace returned to New York's garment center yesterday after a two-day strike by 1,500 truck drivers and pushboys.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 23 -- Brazil will not act alone ahead of the United Nations on recognition of Communist China, a high official source said today.

Production of lumber totaled 216,811,000 board feet last week, the highest level this year, compared with 200,435,000 board feet the week before, according to reports from regional associations. A year ago the figure was 250,517,000 board feet.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, complained bitterly before a Congressional committee today of the "leaking" or unauthorized disclosure of classified documents involving national security.
CHICAGO, March 23 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The City Savings Bank of Brooklyn became yesterday the first savings bank in New York City to join the Federal Home Loan Bank System. Its application for membership in the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York was confirmed by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
Stocks made a rather general retreat yesterday but in most cases the declines were small and in many cases accompanied by lower volume.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- President Kennedy's reputation for keeping himself omnivorously and accurately informed on the details of government suffered a minor setback today. For the first time in eight news conferences as President he had to be prompted.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) -- Republican leaders in Congress asserted today that the Administration's bill on depressed areas would bring only "bitter disillusionment" to the jobless in regions, it is designed to help.

CAPE CANAVERAL, March 23 (UPI) -- The U.S.S. Theodore Roosevelt made its debut as the nation's fourth Polaris-firing nuclear submarine today by launching three missiles within six hours. But two of the missiles failed in flight.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- The House approved today an $800,000,000 military construction bill covering work at 358 installations.
Officials of seven major cities met here during yesterday's snow and rain to discuss the prospects and problems of removing snow.

Providence College, via a stirring 90-83 overtime basketball victory over Holy Cross, and St. Louis University, by virtue of a 67-60 triumph over Dayton, advanced last night to tomorrow afternoon's final of the twenty-fourth annual National Invitation Tournament.
Romare Bearden, an abstract painter, lost a round with the city yesterday in which his studio was the prize.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 23 -- Adlai E. Stevenson called on the African states today to take the initiative in drawing up an ambitious new program for development of their continent.
ALBANY, March 23 -- The Court of Appeals upheld a conviction of murder in the first degree today but in doing so set a new rule of procedure for future criminal trials.
Unless the Legislature authorizes the Transit Authority to issue $200,000,000 in bonds to buy 1,800 subway cars, New York faces an acute transit crisis, Charles L. Patterson warned yesterday.
The City Council, after a sharp debate, asked yesterday that Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan be given the authority to grant immunity from prosecution to witnesses in inquiries.
The Hospital Council of Greater New York declared yesterday that it was "deeply concerned" over the city's new plans to expand Bellevue Hospital.
A special agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified yesterday that the late Arnold Schuster had declared on two occasions that he did not feel he needed police protection.
MOSCOW, March 23 -- The Soviet Union abolished today its prior censorship on outgoing news dispatches.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- The House Ways and Means Committee tentatively approved today legislation allowing the President to cut the duty-free allowance that United States tourists are granted on goods purchased abroad.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased $3,000,000 to $52,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirement declined $71,000,000 to $562,000,000.

A TURN-OF-THE CENTURY insurance scandal that drove games Hazen Hyde into thirty-five years of self-imposed exile in Paris might well be credited with the superb collection of decorative arts that goes on view today at the Cooper Union Museum.

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, yesterday disclosed seven bargaining issues over which, he said, the union's 40,000 unlicensed seamen are prepared to strike June 15, when their current three-year contract expires.
SEATTLE, March 23 (AP) -- American and collegiate records were set today in the first two events of the National Collegiate swimming championships.
Plaquemines Parish, La., borrowed $4,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance levee improvements.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- James M. Symes, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, said today his company was seeking outright control of the Lehigh Valley Railroad at this time solely to prevent the Lehigh from going into bankruptcy.
ALBANY, March 23 -- A sharp political break has developed between Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo, the Republican leader of the Senate, and Frank Kenna, Republican leader of Queens.

The Broadway opening of "A Far Country," the Henry Denker drama co-starring Kim Stanley, Steven Hill and Sam Wanamaker, has been delayed until April 4. It was to have arrived here at the Music Box next Tuesday.
BROWNS MILLS, N.J., March 23 (AP) -- Joyce Okun, 13 years old, of Flushing, Queens, has undergone an operation for a double heart defect unusual in medical history.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23 -- It may be that Ralph Houk is trying to inspire Paul Richards and his Orioles with a feeling of misplaced confidence.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 23 -- Press agents are sometimes thought of as parasitic fauna, cadging publicity for enterprises of dubious significance. But occasionally they do some good.
The New York Rangers yesterday dismissed Alf Pike as coach and reassigned him to assist in the National Hockey League team's player-development program.

LONG BEACH, L.I., March 23 -- The first public hearing on a forty-year $18,000,000 master plan for orderly growth was held here tonight by the City Planning Board. About 1,000 residents attended the meeting.
NEW DELHI, India, March 23 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru was described today as "impressed with the position President Kennedy has taken on a number of questions of world importance.
MIAMI BEACH, March 23 (AP) -- Jay Hebert carded a 31, 35 -- 66 today and took a one-stroke lead in the first round of the $25,000 Sunshine open golf tournament.

Events today: "Turandot," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, William Masselos, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; Alberto Lysy, violinist, Town Hall, 5:45; San Remo Festival Singers, Luciano Maraviglia, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Vienna Choir Boys, Town Hall, 8:40; Yfrah Neaman, violinist, and Artur Balsam, pianist, Rogers Auditorium, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 8:30.

LONDON, March 23 -- Britain called on the Soviet Union today to join her in appealing to both sides for an immediate cease-fire in Laos to end the threat to world peace. The request was made in Moscow in an aide-memoire handed to Nikolai P. Firyubin, a Deputy Soviet Foreign Minister, by Sir Frank Roberts, British Ambassador.
