Eight floors of the new Central Courthouse were formally opened yesterday on behalf of the Municipal Court, one of the two courts that will occupy the twelve-story building at 111 Centre Street. The other is the City Court, which will take over the top four floors, starting April 10.

Martha Graham and her dance company will open an engagement at the Fifty-fourth Street Theatre on April 16 and will run through April 30, with performances omitted on Tuesday, April 18, and Monday, April 24.

The Waterbury (Conn.) National Bank (assets $28,000,000) announced yesterday what may be an unparalelled form of diversification in the banking industry. Banks have added a multitude of cradle-to-the-grave financial services for customers, but the bank in Waterbury (an industrial city with a population of 110,000), says it is the first to offer computer services.
MIAMI, March 23 (AP) -- Ingemar Johansson appeared at the Federal Building today to tell the United States Internal Revenue Service about his finances.

Not everyone trained to sing opera can walk into a role at the Met or even the Baltimore Civic Opera Company, but, in increasing numbers, opera singers are walking into jobs in New York's restaurants and cabarets.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Saturday, March 18 were 9 per cent above the level of a year earlier.

The possibility of acquiring one of New York City's seven television channels for nonprofit cultural and educational TV is now so near realization that this time it simply must not fail. Although the point is often overlooked, the air-waves do belong to the public; and when the public interest is so clearly at stake as it is in the present instance, commercial considerations ought to take a distinctly secondary place.
CHICAGO, March 23 (AP) -- Profit selling in the final few minutes chopped away most of the earlier good gains in the grains futures market today and left prices barely steady to firm.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Major rail and truck interests appealed to Congress today for protection from what they called cut throat competition threatening ruin of their industries.

THE weather may seem to contradict the calendar's insistence that spring is here. Nevertheless, one spring vegetable has turned out in abundance this week. Asparagus is currently so plentiful that it is the "special" in a number of supermarkets.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) -- A dispute erupted today between the A.F.L.-C.I.O. craft unions and industrial unions over proposed legislation to remove restrictions on some forms of picketing.
A handful of percussion players must have been pretty tired after last night's concert in Caspary Auditorium of the Rockefeller Institute.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- President Kennedy called today for passage of a minimum wage bill "as close as possible" to the one introduced for his Administration by the House Education and Labor Committee.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Two young heroes received medals today for outstanding bravery. They were decorated by President Kennedy in a White House ceremony.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 23 -- A Soviet spokesman said today that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko would return to Moscow in time to attend a meeting there Tuesday of Warsaw Pact foreign ministers.
Advertisers, in one way or another always are inviting the public to compare their product with that of their competitor. But do they really mean it?

LONDON, March 23 -- Prices declined on a wide front in the stock market here today in sharply reduced turnover. The heavy fall in demand for industrial shares prompted speculators to take their profits. Their sales depressed prices even further.

BOSTON, March 23 (UPI) -- The Boston Celtics defeated the Syracuse Nationals, 133 -- 110, tonight in the National Basketball Association Eastern Division final play-offs. The Celtics lead, 2 games to 1.

David W. Frankel, realty investor and builder, announced yesterday he had leased the blockfront on the west side of First Avenue between Sixty-third and Sixty-fourth Streets for improvement with a large apartment building.

HOUSTON, Tex., March 23 (UPI) -- An executive of the Chase Manhattan Bank said today prospects were excellent for a vigorous recovery, which would carry the national economy to a level of "full prosperity" in 1962.

LONDON, March 23 -- The Government published today the text of a bill authorizing it to give the Cunard Line financial aid up to a maximum of 18,000,000 ($50,400,000) toward the cost of a replacement for the 81,237-ton Queen Mary.

A plan to send 150 young Americans to teach in the secondary schools of East Africa has aroused unanimous and genuine enthusiasm from people there, according to Prof. R. Freeman Butts, director of International Studies at Teachers College, Columbia University.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- John M. Bailey, the Democratic national chairman, has publicly affirmed for the first time the Kennedy Administration's desire for new party leadership in New York State.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Dissatisfaction was expressed by President Kennedy today with the decision of the National Civil War Centennial Commission to go ahead with plans to hold its annual meeting under racially segregated conditions in Charleston, S.C., next month.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy invoked an almost forgotten law today to open an inquiry into business compliance with antitrust decrees.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) -- The Census Bureau said today that the proportion of young persons in the United States population increased in the Nineteen Fifties.
Patronesses have been announced for "A Parade of Flowers," a luncheon and fashion show, to be held in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom on April 11 for the benefit of the Auxiliary of St. Luke's Hospital.
THE tight knot of Western correspondents at a Yugoslav party in Moscow three years ago opened just enough to admit the short but intense man no one knew. "Polish, probably," someone whispered.

"The Stakes of Power, 1845-1877," an interpretation of the Civil War era, has been written by Roy F. Nichols, dean of the Graduate School at the University of Pennsylvania. Mr. Nichols deals with the contest for political and economic control of the Government between the Northerners and the Southerners before the war and with the adjustments after the conflict.

An enlightened approach to highway safety is evident in a bill submitted to the Legislature by Senator Speno of Nassau County. Like the Florida system on which it is based, it would mandate the issuance of warning summonses by policemen to motorists for defective or inoperative headlights, rear or license plate lights, windshield wipers or horns.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, VA. THE gastronomic gulf between hush puppies and caviar seems vast indeed. But there is a store in this historic Southern town that bridges the abyss neatly. Known as the Seven Day Shopping Center, it displays an elaboration of global delicacies to stun and delight the senses.

LONDON, March 23 -- Prime Minister Macmillan said today that there was no reason to believe that the secret material taken from the Portland naval base included more than a limited sector of British naval weapons.
An application for eviction certificates against sixty-one families in six adjacent East Side buildings has been denied, State Rent Administrator Robert E. Herman announced yesterday.
The snow, sleet and hail stopped just in time to allow the horses in the feature race at Aqueduct to perform the more or less swift completion of their appointed rounds.

For many years I have been a reader of your newspaper and I have always admired its veracity, accurate information and objectivity. Because of this I have been surprised at your editorial of March 7 about "The Chilean Elections."

Two insurgents seeking to displace Carmine G. De Sapio as Democratic district leader in the Greenwich Village area agreed last night that it would be "disastrous for the reform movement to have Mayor Wagner standing for renomination unopposed in the primary."
DETROIT, March 23 (AP) -- Automobile production is expected to rise 23.4 per cent this week from last but will still remain well below the 1960 level, Automotive News said today.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- President Kennedy told the people of the United States tonight of the dangers in the Laotian situation and warned the Communist world that "no one should doubt our resolution" to preserve an independent, neutral Laos.

A hard look at the present foster-care program for children is warranted by findings of a study of serious emotional disturbances among 140 foster care children getting psychiatric treatment, a psychiatrist said here yesterday.

Justice Irving H. Saypol in Supreme Court, New York County, put off yesterday until after April 10 resolution of the question of whether he would issue any injunctions under his recent decision invalidating last year's state Omnibus Banking Law.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) -- President Kennedy's nomination of Stanley S. Surrey to be the Treasury Department's tax specialist ran into trouble today in the Senate Finance Committee.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Republican and Democratic Senate leaders tonight applauded President Kennedy's efforts to seek a peaceful settlement of the explosive situation in Laos.
TORONTO, March 23 (Canadian Press) -- Trans-Canada Pipe Lines Ltd. had a net loss in 1960 of $2,911,148, compared with a loss of $8,410,511 in 1959, the company's annual report says.
An unidentified United States agency has asked that questions about activities in the Miami area by Cubans seeking the overthrow of Premier Fidel Castro be barred in a trial under way here.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) -- The Kennedy Administration is considering asking Congress to eliminate big tax advantages available to American movie stars who make their films abroad.
The retirement of Henry M. Hogan, vice president and general counsel for the General Motors Corporation, was announced yesterday.
The New York Stock Exchange sent out an "emergency call" to its members yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Edward R. Murrow, director of the United States Information Agency, took full responsibility today for his effort to persuade British officials to cancel a controversial television documentary on the plight of migrant labor in this country.
A scientist from the Cornell University School of Medicine has found a compound that appears to have promise as a cheap, safe oral contraceptive for men.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 23 -- The happiest man in Cleveland last April was Rocky Colavito, the curly-haired idol of the lakefront bobby-sox set. He had won his contract battle with his boss and severest critic, Frank Lane. He had had two slambang seasons in a row with forty-one and forty-two homers. He had just moved into a new house that was ideally located, twenty minutes from the ball park and twenty minutes from the airport.

The tense situation in Laos firmed the prices of many commodities yesterday on the New York futures markets. Items reacting to the war scare were rubber, copper, cottonseed oil, cocoa and world sugar.

Alabama Power Company sold bonds and preferred stock in the public market yesterday, accepting bids on the two securities issues that set a 4.912 per cent interest cost to the utility on the stock and 4.442 per cent on the bonds.

The Cucci Corporation, custom tailor and haberdasher, has leased a store, mezzanine and basement in the Savoy Hilton Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street. The company, which was established in 1790, has several stores in Italy.
Twenty-three major ship casualties cost the American Hull Insurance Syndicate about $5,750,000 in claims last fiscal year, Clifford G. Cornwell, chairman of the group, reported yesterday.
A jewelry salesman who had obtained refuge in Mexico for eight years was returned here last night under a Presidential extradition warrant.

Increased community planning of social services in the Jewish health and welfare field were highlights of last year's activities of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, the federation reported yesterday.

Mayor Wagner, convalescing at Memorial Hospital after surgery on Monday to remove a tumor near his ear, was described yesterday by his wife and son, Robert Jr., as "very cheerful" and "very anxious to go home."

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Laos crisis is bad, but not all bad. It is a flash of lightning on an ugly truth. The situation was worse before the flash because Laos was slipping away in the dark. Now at least we can see a little of what is happening and President Kennedy is beginning to tell the country what it should have been told some days and even weeks ago.
Bernard M. Baruch has given $60,000 to the Park Department to provide a sitting area in a congested section of the Lower East Side.

THE concentration of art galleries along Madison Avenue, from Sixtieth to Eightieth Street, is not so thick as it once was along Fifty-seventh Street, but almost every week along that mile some new establishment opens its doors to offer fresh temptations to collectors and/or investors.

Ten major housing and urban renewal projects that will provide 2,578 apartments at a total cost of $51,383,513 were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The largest of the group is an $18,279,000 middle-income development of 960 apartments to be built with state aid. It will straddle the new expressway across upper Manhattan that will be one of the approaches to the George Washington Bridge.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 23 -- Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd attacked Britain's policy in Africa today and declared it would lead to the expulsion of white men from the continent.

WARSAW, March 25 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka got Poland's election campaign under way the other day at a party rally staged in the big Congress Hall of the towering Palace of Culture, Stalin's gift to the Warsaw skyline.
MOSCOW, March 24 -- Premier Khrushchev returned to Moscow today to prepare for a summit meeting of the Warsaw Pact powers opening here next Tuesday.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- A Federal judge, bowing to a direct request from Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, agreed today to dismiss espionage charges against a Russian United Nations employe, provided that he goes home.
Five Chicago physicians have reported starting life all over again for a 2 1/2-year-old boy who had, in effect, died too long.

Mikhail Botvinnik of Moscow, the challenger, was a pawn ahead when the fifth game of the world chess championship match with Mikhail Tal of Latvia was adjourned yesterday, according to Tass, the official Soviet news agency.

A motion-picture theatre, the first to be constructed on the lower East Side in twenty-five years, is planned at Seward Park Houses, a Title I development sponsored by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.
AINTREE, England, March 24 (AP) -- Aintree's race track, where the Grand National Steeplechase will be held tomorrow, claimed the life of a racer today.
ALBANY, March 24 -- Less than twenty-four hours before the Legislature's scheduled adjournment, a drive to add thirty-seven new judges to New York City courts began making headway tonight.
Commercial production of refined nickel at the most modern and second largest nickel operation in the world is scheduled to get under way tomorrow at Thompson, in the Canadian province of Manitoba.
President Kennedy's stand on Communist advances in Laos was endorsed here yesterday by Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Kennedy has made a personal appeal to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru for India's support in winning a peaceful settlement in Laos.

NO matter what new things turn up in the shops for Easter, year after year the egg reigns supreme. Those too busy to dye and decorate their own, might take a look at the handsome floral Easter eggs at Warle, 1177 Lexington Avenue.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn and Vice President Johnson have completed their appointments to the United States Commission on the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

Lucine Amara made her first appearance as Liu, William Wildermann his first as Timur and Gabor Carelli his first as Pong in the performance of Puccini's "Turandot" given by the Metropolitan Opera last night. Birgit Nilsson sang the title role, Franco Corelli was Calaf and Alessio De Paolis the Emperor. Leopold Stokowski conducted.

A 56-year-old certified public accountant was convicted yesterday in Federal Court of giving a $25,000 bribe to an Internal Revenue agent to reduce a client's income tax deficit by $2,425,000 -- from $2,500,000 to $75,000.

Protestant and Jewish leaders are complaining privately over what they consider an "unseemly delay" by the Port of New York Authority in approving final plans for their new chapels at New York International Airport.

Stock prices jogged a little lower yesterday as the market awaited some solution of the international crisis. Turnover fell away. The market narrowed to relatively few stocks. But prices, for the most part, gave little.
SEATTLE, March 24 (AP) -- Four records were set tonight in the National Collegiate swimming championships.

A brisk demand for intermediate-term securities of the United States Government was the highlight of the bond market yesterday.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., March 24 -- The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway has had "peace" feelers recently from the New York Central Railroad, which has been vigorously opposing the C.'s efforts to acquire control of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, as a first step toward merger.
The Commissioner of Social Security said yesterday that aid to Cuban refugees in Florida was being provided at a rate in the best traditions of the United States as a "humanitarian sanctuary."

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 24 -- The Government of Premier Joseph Ileo gave the impression today that it was moving toward agreement with the United Nations on the crucial issue of the future of the Congolese Army.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara has ordered the preparation of a "draft memorandum" revising basic national security policies relating to nuclear weapons.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 24 (AP) -- Barbara Ferries of Aspen, Colo., took first place in the first run of the women's slalom of the Harriman Cup ski races today. The second run was postponed because of soft snow.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk recommended dismissal of spy charges against a Soviet employe of the United Nations in an effort to promote better relations with Moscow.

AMERICAN families today are being wooed with ever-increasing ardor by the nation's merchants and lenders. The success of this play-now, pay-later courtship can be gauged by the fact that never before in this country's history have so many owed so much and for so many different things.
JOHNSON CITY, Tenn., March 24 (AP) -- Mrs. B. Carroll Reece announced herself tonight as a candidate to succeed her late husband in the House of Representatives.

ALBANY, March 24 -- The Assembly approved and sent to the Senate today the Rockefeller program providing for $8,600,000 in aid to railroads.
A pint-sized basketball team from Puerto Rico arrived yesterday in fringed straw hats for a nine-day tour of the city and received a welcome from West Side families with whom they will stay.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Kennedy Administration warned George Preston Marshall today that a new football stadium in the District of Columbia might not be available for the Washington Redskins if he practiced discrimination. Mr. Marshall owns the Redskins.
President Kennedy's Peace Corps plans to send its first volunteers overseas by Christmas, R. Sargent Shriver, the director, said yesterday.

SEBRING, Fla., March 24 -- Charles Kolb of Silver Spring, Md., last year's national champion, won the 104-mile Formula Junior race today. This was the feature event of the day given over to preliminaries to tomorrow's world championship twelve-hour endurance race for sports cars.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- President Kennedy announced today a shift in the United States high command in Korea along with a series of other changes in assignments for key generals.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI) -- The House Appropriations Committee voted more funds today for the Treasury and Post Office Department.
Teachers and students at the High School of Music and Art moved allegro molto yesterday to get ready for the school's twenty-fifth anniversary concert and art exhibition.

A group of teachers, irked by Mayor Wagner's delay in proposing raises for teachers, picketed their school yesterday morning before classes began.

Mrs. Agnes E. Meyer, author and lecturer, charged yesterday that the Roman Catholic hierarchy was attempting to sabotage Federal aid to public schools although "at least half our Catholic children go to public schools."
PHILADELPHIA, March 24 -- The famed art collection of the Barnes Foundation at nearby Merion was opened to the general public today for the second time in thirty-eight years.

This is a day for remembrance, appreciation and a resolve to do better -- the fiftieth anniversary of the Triangle factory fire on Washington Place that, because of inadequate fire prevention and protection, took no less than 146 garment workers lives.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 24 -- New York University's realigned fencing team set the pace in the National Collegiate championships today.
Canada's ailing industry got a shot in the arm yesterday, but the patient's reaction may be as delayed as the shot.
The appointment of George H. Hearn, a 32-year-old member of the New York City Council, to a legal post in the Civil Aeronautics Board, was announced yesterday.
Two men were sentenced yesterday in Queens County Court to die in the electric chair the week of May 1.

Tremont Temple in the Bronx will observe what its congregants are hailing as its "triple-five" anniversary today.

Randolph Phillips has resigned his $20,000-a-year post as a consultant to Alleghany Corporation effective on March 31, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Phillips will not stand for re-election next month as a director of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., an investment complex. Alleghany, a holding company, controls Investors Diversified and the New York Central Railroad.

The owner of a Harlem tenement in which two small children suffocated in a smoky fire last Christmas Eve was indicted yesterday on three charges of manslaughter.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 24 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower today supported President Kennedy's firm warning against Communist intervention in the Laos crisis. General Eisenhower, in his first public statement on foreign affairs since leaving office, added that he believed his successor had made it clear that the United States "is not going to be pushed around." He also noted that "the President is dedicated to peace" as his Administration had been.

THE modern homemaker, young or old, rich or poor, is pretty much convinced that the place to shop for food is mainly in the supermarket and that the way to shop for food is in weekly or twice-weekly expeditions.

The building containing fifty-one apartments at 757-59 High Street, Newark, has been sold by Philip and Belle Weinberg through J.I. Kislak, Inc., broker. R. W. Limited, the buyer, is a syndicate of investors who were represented by Robert Inland, lawyer.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The United States Consumer Price Index rose a trifle last month, to equal the record level it reached in December, the Labor Department reported today.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 24 -- There is a cycle of events in spring training which, if any manager thinks he can alter, "he's gonna develop corns on his head," as Al Lopez says.

The United States Court of Appeals yesterday extended from April 14 to May 3 the deadline for the New Rochelle Board of Education to file a desegregation plan with Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman.

A one-story taxpayer containing ten stores at the northeast corner of Station Road and 192d Street, Flushing, Queens, has been sold by Lawrence M. Lyons. It was bought by investing clients of George Mutterperl, lawyer, in a deal negotiated by George Michelson of the Kraham Realty Company, Kew Gardens brokers.
With its well-established reputation for films of unusual content, Louis de Rochemont Associates has opened a promotional campaign for what could be its most provocative film.
The Hewlett-Packard Company and the Sanborn Company are considering a merger, the companies announced yesterday.
Savings in the nation's 515 mutual savings banks rose by $136,000,000 in February. This compared with gains of $170,000,000 the month before and $50,000,000 in February, 1960.
CHICAGO, March 24 (AP) -- The grain futures market stalled almost on dead center today after a short-lived tendency toward firmness in initial transactions.
Andy Fitch, a National Collegiate champion in 1959, scored two quick pins as the second annual Eastern Amateur Athletic Union wrestling championships opened last night at the New York Athletic Club.

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, March 21 -- An Angolan national leader took issue here today with the contention by Portuguese authorities that the recent disturbances in Angola were the work of organizers coming from the Congolese side of the border.
LONDON, March 24 -- The roisterous Dutch landed at Chatham again today, and the Royal Navy's Nore Command pulled down the Union Jack.
BOWIE, Md., March 24 (AP) -- With Tudor Way out of the race, tomorrow's $118,450 John B. Campbell Handicap shapes up as a scramble among fifteen horses for the $78,992 first prize.

PARIS, March 24 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, leader of the neutralist forces in Laos, gave his public support tonight to a Western proposal for a ceasefire in that embattled country followed by a fourteen-nation conference to settle the crisis there.
Children with school phobias have been treated and returned to school, some within two weeks, with the aid of tranquilizing drugs, a Texas psychiatrist reported here yesterday.
BONN, Germany, March 24 -- West Germany has agreed to repay immediately the equivalent of $189,000,000 it owes to Britain for post-war aid, it was announced here today.
The State of Tennessee is planning to sell $15,000,000 of serial bonds in May.

A garden apartment house for fifty-four families at 150 Secatogue Avenue, Farmingdale, L.I., has been sold by Morris Rosenberg. It was bought by an investing client of Norman Katz of Ossip Associates, Inc., Forest Hills brokers.
Nonfiction television will browse in science, current events, travel, horse racing and effective organizational togetherness within the next few weeks.

MIAMI, Fla., March 24 (AP) -- Joseph J. DiMare 52 years old, shipping company owner, was shot to death tonight and his wife pistol-whipped into unconsciousness by two gunmen who forced their way into Mr. DiMare's car.

Horse players who have been out of touch may be excused if they assume that the New York thoroughbred season is starting today. The feature race at Aqueduct is the Paumonok, the $25,000 added handicap that will be contested for the fifty-second time since it was inaugurated in 1906.
DETROIT, March 24 (UPI) -- An upturn in both-production and sales indicates the auto industry's slump has "bottomed out," Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
A cherry chest of drawers of eighteenth-century Connecticut origin was sold here yesterday to the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Mich., for $13,000.

BUENOS AIRES, March 24 -- Thirty-five or so ranking army officers met for about two hours here today with the War Secretary, Brig. Gen. Rosendo M. Fraga. Indications afterward were that General Fraga succeeded in maintaining the army's support, as a whole, for the regime of President Arturo Frondizi.
Edward P. Morgan, the commentator, and stations in Pittsburgh and New Haven received the 1960 Alfred I. du Pont Awards in radio and television last night in Washington.
The Vienna Choir Boys, familiar visitors to these shores, gave one of their typical programs last night at Town Hall.
Efforts among scheduled trans-Atlantic airlines to arrange a new meeting on cargo rates and head off a possible rate war after April 9 entered a new phase yesterday.
"I DON'T say no to you because I dislike you," the adult told the screaming child who had taken a toy away from a playmate. "I say no because I love you and want to help you."

"On the next day much people that were come to the feast, when they heard that Jesus was coming to Jerusalem, took branches of palm trees, and went forth to meet Him, and cried, Hosanna: Blessed is the King of Israel that cometh in the name of the Lord."

The Broadway calendar of stage events for next week has been reduced by half. With one attraction ("A Far Country") already delayed a week, from Tuesday to April 4, a second ("Impulse") has decided not to come into New York at all.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 24 -- "Action" on the problem of imports was promised to the beleaguered textile industry today by Luther H. Hodges, Secretary of Commerce.

NEW ORLEANS, March 24 (AP) -- Ron Weber cut three strokes from par with a 68 on the 6,505-yard New Orleans Country Club course today and won the medal in the fifty-ninth western amateur golf tournament.
Two statements in The Times of March 11 point up well the basis for the conflict of opinion over whether the House Committee on Un-American Activities should be abolished.
Paul G. Hoffman, managing director of the United Nations Special Fund, called on affluent governments yesterday to increase their financial help to newly emerging countries by almost 50 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices remained unchanged at 119.8 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Kennedy Administration suffered its first major legislative reversal today. Its compromise version of a bill to increase and expand the minimum wage was beaten by one vote, 186 to 185, in the House of Representatives.

TRENTON, March 24 -- The Public Utility Commission today gave the Pennsylvania-Reading Seashore Line the right to discontinue forty-three passenger runs between South Jersey points and Philadelphia and New York.

The Greek merchant marine's foreign exchange earnings last year exceeded those of the country's most important export product -- tobacco, according to a report issued by the Greek Ministry of Mercantile Marine.

KANSAS CITY, March 24 -- Ohio State and Cincinnati, whose gymnasiums are about 100 miles apart, will meet here tomorrow night for the National Collegiate basketball championship. Never in the previous twenty-two years of this competition had the title game matched two teams from the same state.
A hold-up man who apparently specialized in robbing Spotless Cleaning Stores was sentenced yesterday to fifteen to twenty years in prison.

The St. Louis University and Providence College basketball teams, both of which were unseeded, will bring the twenty-fourth National Invitation Tournament to a close this afternoon when they meet in Madison Square Garden.
CORVALLIS, Ore., March 24 (AP) -- Oklahoma State tonight qualified five men for the finals as it neared its twenty-second National Collegiate wrestling championship.

CAIRO, March 17 -- If President Kennedy's scheme to promote tourism in America and help our trade balance succeeds, we may soon expect a flood of foreign tourists pouring through the gates of the Port of New York.

HEMINGWAY said of foreigners in Africa: "A continent ages quickly once we have come." He probably wasn't thinking of the Phoenicians from Tyre at Carthage in the ninth century B.C. More likely he had in mind the post-Elizabethan explorers and conquerors. Or the Stanley-Livingstone set.

YONKERS, March 24 -- King's Meadow, owned by Adrien and Gerard Miron of Canada, scored a three-quarter-length victory over Vineddy tonight in the $6,000 Elmsford Pace before 24,387 at Yonkers Raceway. The time for the mile was 2:07 4/5.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Following are President Kennedy's estimates of spending for the fiscal year that starts July 1, outlining in general terms increases and decreases in various departments, as submitted with his budget message today:

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- The Export-Import Bank announced today a "significant departure" in credit and other policies in the hope of increasing United States sales abroad. The changes include abandonment of this country's historic refusal of financial aid for foreign government-owned oil companies.

Prices of many commodities on New York exchanges continued to show a firm tone yesterday, reflecting the tense situation in Laos. Rubber and cocoa had the best gains of the day. Lead and wool also rose, while copper, sugar, cottonseed oil and coffee were mixed.

If it is possible to achieve a peaceful settlement in Laos, the statement made on Thursday by President Kennedy, together with new proposals to Russia put forward by Britain, provides a reasonable basis for such a settlement.
NEW DELHI, India, March 24 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today he had received a "helpful message" from President Kennedy on Laos.

Marcel Pigou, a French middleweight whose astrologer has told him his dreams of fame and fortune are certain to be achieved, will face the realistic fists of Florentino Fernandez tonight at Madison Square Garden.
BOSTON, March 24 -- Preliminary tests here indicate that tooth decay may be communicable.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- A Spanish inventor was awarded an American patent this week for a device that permits humane bullfighting. Wearing a protective board strapped across its shoulders, the animal is expected to come through a simulated bullfight without a scratch.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points up to 6 off yesterday.

LONDON, March 24 (AP) -- The Moscow radio said tonight that Edward R. Murrow, director of the United States Information Agency, "evidently found it necessary to take steps to prevent the truth about the situation of United States farm workers being known in other countries."

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Two-thirds of the nation's 150 major industrial areas now have "substantial unemployment." This was announced by the Labor Department today shortly after President Kennedy had signed his Administration's first major antirecession bill.
VIENTIANE, Laos, March 24 (AP) -- "We should be proud of ourselves," one American said. "We have taught them how to kill each other. Pretty soon they'll do it as well as civilized nations do."
STERN Victorian bridge players used to tell their partners, "Ten thousand men are walking the streets of London with empty pockets -- because they wouldn't lead trumps."
ALBANY, March 24 -- Edgar W. Couper, who won a Regents scholarship as a Binghamton High School student forty-five years ago, was elected chancellor of the Board of Regents today.
A youthful vice president of the Ford Motor Company came into town yesterday with a wide grin instead of the expected frown and, waving a sheaf of reports, said, "This all adds up to a boom."
A shake-up of supervisory officials of the Bureau of Gas and Electricity was announced yesterday by Armand D'Angelo, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

DETROIT, March 24 -- Sales of new cars continued to rise in mid-March. Purchases of new autos for the ten-day period from March 11 to 20 came to 134,592 units, equivalent to 16,824 cars for each of the eight selling days, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.

HONG KONG, Saturday, March 25 (AP) -- Robert E. McCann of Altadena, Calif., a United States business man imprisoned in Communist China, is near death with cancer, officials of the United States Consulate here reported today. He is 59 years old.
THE new chancellor of the State Board of Regents, Edgar William Couper, is a lank upstater who worked his way through college (Hamilton '20) and departed with his Phi Beta Kappa key.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Edward R. Murrow, director of the United States Information Agency, conceded today that it had been "foolish and futile" to try to persuade the British Broadcasting Corporation to cancel the showing of a controversial television documentary on the condition of migratory farm workers in this country.
The H.L. Green Company reported yesterday that it had net income of $51,014, or 4 cents a share, last year, after a special charge of $811,179, or 56 cents a share.

CHICAGO, March 24 (UPI) Factory sales of home laundry appliances during February were 7 per cent below the January level and 23 per cent less than in February, 1960, according to the American Home Laundry Manufacturers' Association.

Two months have passed since an editorial appeared in The Times entitled "The Mayor's Eighth Year." In those two months the Mayor has made courageous appointments: Eleanor Guggenheimer to the Planning Commission, a person devoted to city betterment and held in universal high regard; Dr. Ray Trussell as Commissioner of Hospitals, an outstanding hospital administrator in the United States, and the highly qualified Police Commissioner Michael Murphy.

A 43-year-old house painter, described by his lawyer as a member of the "smallest bootleg syndicate in the world," pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court to operating a ten-gallon still in his apartment.

Friends and followers of Jack Benny have opened the sale of tickets for the concert arranged in his honor the evening of April 3 at Carnegie Hall. Proceeds of the tribute to the music-loving comedian will go to the support of Carnegie Hall and for the development of new cultural programs there.
LONDON, March 24 -- A bill that would permit a peer to renounce his peerage for the rest of his life was placed before Parliament today.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Kennedy submitted a budget message today that indicated a $2,200,000,000 deficit this year and a larger deficit next year.
ALBANY, March 24 -- The Senate overwhelmingly defeated today a constitutional amendment that would have permitted a private ski development company to lease forest preserve land in the Catskills.

A TOUCH of spring madness seems to have gripped a television station in Baltimore. Under the guise of registering a "first" in "public service," the outlet induced nine of twelve jurors to appear before the studio cameras and re-enact their deliberations that resulted in the conviction of a man for murder and kidnapping.
Nineteen critiques of Ernest Hemingway's works have been brought together by Carlos Baker in "Hemingway and His Critics" which Hill Wang will issue next Tuesday in hardcover and paperback editions.

DETROIT, March 24 (AP) -- A Federal court ruled today that Detroit lawyer Sol A. Dann had been soliciting proxies in violation of regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission in his battle with the Chrysler Corporation.
Two mobile melting pots will be added to New York City's snow removal fleet next winter.
A Coast Guard airplane dropped blood plasma yesterday morning to the deck of the cutter Owasco about 200 miles south of Argentia, Nfld.
Two appointments have been made by the Juilliard School of Music to strengthen its administrative section.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., March 24 -- Hollywood's film writers tonight honored their selections of the best work in their profession last year.

BEN WEBER is an American composer who belongs to no school as such. He writes modern music that sounds conservative (as modern music goes these days), and he writes twelve-tone music that sounds tonal.

ALBANY, Calif., March 24 (AP) -- Johnny Longden, who has won more races than any other jockey in history, scored the 5,500th victory of his long career today. He did it aboard Spring Victory, a filly that had never won before.
A Manhattan company that was formed to aid in sending gift packages to Poland was accused by the state yesterday of illegally engaging in immigration and adoption proceedings.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Railroad labor unions appealed to the White House and Congress today to block further rail mergers until something is done about unemployment.

PERFECTLY reasonable regrets over the lamentable decline of purely technical skill on the part of modern painters will be sustained by the work of Nicolai Fechin (1885-1955) at the Hammer Galleries, 51 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Kennedy Administration has decided to build the world's largest atomic power plant by converting a plutonium-producing reactor at Hanford, Wash., to generate 700,000 kilowatts of electricity.
A large iceberg may have caused the break in a trans-Atlantic cable off Nova Scotia on Thursday, according to cable engineers here. The iceberg was seen in the area yesterday.

Alberto Lysy, a fine young violinist from Buenos Aires, arrived in New York yesterday via Curtis Institute, the Queen Elisabeth Competition in Brussels (where he took a prize), instruction with Yehudi Menuhin and tours through several continents.
MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 24 -- With her spinnaker billowing in strengthening northeast breezes, Escapade was nearing the finish line of the Miami-Montego Bay yacht race at nightfall today.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Douglas Dillon, Secretary of the Treasury, announced today that the Kennedy Administration's first effort at advance refunding was a "gratifying success" and attracted more than $6,000,000,000 of subscriptions.

PARIS, March 24 -- The United States made clear its view today that the defense effort and the standard of living of each advanced country should be taken into account in assessing fair shares of the burden of aiding the underdeveloped countries.

DETROIT, March 24 (AP) -- The United Auto Workers announced today that the General Motors Corporation had agreed to extend supplemental unemployment benefits for a maximum of thirteen additional weeks, the same period that the Federal Government has decided to extend unemployment compensation.
BANGKOK, Thailand, March 24 -- The top military advisers to the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization agreed today on a blueprint for the defense of Laos.
GREENWICH, Conn., March 24 -- Former Representative Albert P. Morano said today he would challenge Senator Prescott Bush for the Republican nomination for Senator in 1962.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Agriculture Department officials asked Congress today for authority to sell an extra $2,000,000,000 worth of surplus farm commodities to foreign countries stricken by poor crop year.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- A man was killed and thirty-eight persons injured, many critically, when an explosion shattered a cafe on the near North Side tonight. The dead man was not immediately identified.

Last night at the New School, David Tudor gave a routine piano recital. Routine for him, that is, not for anyone else. He was striking the keyboard with palms, fists and forearms. He was inside the piano rubbing the strings or sprinkling around what looked like sand.
A newspaper here in town has taken President Kennedy to task for the words he chose to use in a message to Congress in which he painted a dark picture of school children's health.
Plans for construction of a major shipyard and drydock in Mazatlan, on the west coast of Mexico, were announced here yesterday.

Four railroads have broken a united front of 128 railroads that are seeking to make coast-wise steamship operators an "extinct species" of American industry, practitioners before the Interstate Commerce Commission said yesterday.

BORN on the eve of the Civil War, even earlier the first battleground of pro-Slavery and Free-State adherents, an arena of the fiery Abolitionist John Brown, Kansas this year is celebrating a century of statehood.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 25 -- The police were searching today for a 40-year-old artist who, they believed, removed his 5-year-old daughter from Stamford Hospital where she had been a patient for a year with severe burns.

SINCE World War II opportunities for research have increased enormously. Many physicians, already inclined to research during medical school, make the transition from graduation to laboratory with barely a pause for clinical training.

Eric Bentley's lecture at Columbia University, as reported in The Times recently, in which he attacked university theatres for their amateurism and their devotion to Broadway rehash deserves some commendation. In altogether too many places, university theatre has displaced the professional theatre with something even less attractive than the worst sort of "little" theatre, and has done so with factitious pride at having brought "drama" to the community.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 25 -- Last Wednesday the semi-official Congolese news agency ran what may well have been the longest story in its history -- a word-for-word translation of Adlai Stevenson's speech urging fellow delegates to the United Nations to "stop pulling up the roots of this fragile [Congolese] plant every few days to see if it is growing."
PARDAILHAN, France, March 20 (Reuters) -- In the abandoned hamlet of Pardailhan, in south-central France, eighty-nine Christian townsmen from Paris have founded an Israeli-style kibbutz.

Patrons have been announced for the evening performance by the Moiseyev Dance Company at the Metropolitan Opera House on April 22, which will benefit the Children's Asthma Research Institute and Hospital in Denver.
The growth of The Associated Press to record proportions abroad and expansion of its services in this country were reported last week by Frank J. Starzel, general manager.

The Rev. Malcolm Boyd, one of the most controversial priests in the Protestant Episcopal Church, declared here last week that the Christian church in the United States would be dead in two generations unless it "came down to earth."
WASHINGTON, March 25--The National Civil War Centennial Commission capitulated to President Kennedy today and agreed to avoid segregated hotels at Charleston, S.C.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, asked the American Civil Liberties Union today whether it thought persons subject to Communist party discipline should be permitted to teach in United States schools and colleges.
President Kennedy warned the world last week that the crisis in Laos, a sleepy Buddhist kingdom sometimes described as "a land for the fabled lotos-eaters," could lead to war.

WATCHING "Big Fish, Little Fish" the other night, one was enchanted by the impeccable acting. Even by the standards of Broadway, which makes a fetish of type casting, it is rare to find a company of actors so right in their roles and so accomplished at communicating every nuance of meaning in them.

ATHENS, March 20--The United States Government will contribute $50,000 toward the cost of building a new private American high school in Athens. An agreement making this grant available to American Community Schools of Athens, Inc., was signed in Athens two weeks ago.

EL SEGUNDO, Calif., March 25 -- Tomorrow's super-rockets and space ventures are being formulated today by a "corporation," housed in sleek modernistic buildings near Los Angeles International Airport.
BUENOS AIRES, March 25 -- Secretary of War Rosendo M. Fraga is seeking to assure the country that the army dispute that led to the sudden resignation of the Commander in Chief this week is ended.

IN "Abandoned," A.L. Todd pays tribute to the men of one of the most ill-fated expeditions ever to venture into the Arctic. After being neglected for years, the tragic story of Adolphus Greely's expedition to the Arctic in 1881-84 has formed the theme of two books in recent months -- Theodore Powell's "The Long Rescue," published last summer, and now, "Abandoned."

KANSAS CITY, March 25 -- The National Association of Basketball Coaches, meeting in conjunction with the annual National Collegiate tournament, offered its full support today to agencies investigating betting scandals in the sport.
PHILADELPHIA, March 25 (AP) -- The president of the American Association of School Administrators said today that massive Federal aid was needed to provide quality education in public schools.
In the often-criticized and turbulent world of tennis, the loud, clear voice of at least one defender usually rises above the din to cry, "Stop! You may go no further."

STUART, Fla., March 25. -- The State of Maine put up a savage fight today for the Atlantic salmon, repulsing with fearful violence all attacks launched by the partisans of snook. An impartial umpire had to call the battle an inconclusive draw, with Maine left in possession of the field by pure chance.

PARIS, March 25 -- A miniature guillotine was operating here this afternoon at one of the places where 168 years ago a real one kept falling during the Reign of Terror. Today's victims were dummies about eighteen inches tall.

The Kennedy Administration was at grips this week-end with a crisis in Laos and with a long-term policy of foreign aid and mutual assistance laid down at the Presidential press conference on Thursday.
CARBONDALE, Ill., March 25 (UPI) -- A birthday-card purchase turned a usually quiet railroad ride into a harrowing experience for Mary Lou Fowler.

WASHINGTON. March 25 -- Two months after President Eisenhower's farewell address of Jan. 17, Washington has all but forgotten his parting shot at "unwarranted influence" by a "military-industrial complex."

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. -- The National Park Service has promised substantial help to the St. Augustine Historical Restoration and Preservation Commission in restoring the Spanish section of this historic city, which will celebrate its 400th anniversary in 1965.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, March 25 -- The Alaska Legislature meeting in Juneau has approved the establishment of an $18,000,000 state ferry system that it hopes will swell tourism to the forty-ninth state.

New highs in assets, sales and surplus to policyholders were achieved by the Kemper Insurance Group last year, according to W.H. Heineke, senior vice president of the companies and manager of the eight-state Eastern branch office in Summit, N.J.

THE reader who gets beyond the jaundiced cover and bathetic title of this book will be amply rewarded. Robert Rosenbaum, its compiler, has had the interesting idea of letting six notable Victorians recount the central episodes of their lives largely in their own words, and he has carried out his scheme with real skill.

THE jackdaw is a bird we do not have on this side of the Atlantic. It belongs to the family that contains the jays and crows and is a common sight in the English countryside and towns. People who know little else about this bird have heard or read of its propensity for stealing shiny thimbles or buttons or any other small household object it can carry off.

The long awaited report of the Joint Commission on Mental Illness and Health, a five-year study authorized by Congress in 1955 and carried out at a cost of more than $1,500,000, was made public last week.
Lower domestic air trip insurance rates, put into effect at Washington National Airport and at Houston International Airport recently, may soon be extended to other airports in this country.
ST. LOUIS, March 25 (AP) -- Missouri's representatives on the Republican National Committee proposed tonight that the committee name a woman as chairman.

ROME, March 25 -- Three physicians who performed an autopsy on a Danish Olympic cyclist, Knud Enenark Jensen, said in their final report today that the athlete had died from a heat stroke and not from a drug.

THE first opera composed west of the Mississippi was "The American Volunteer'' by Felix Vinatieri, General Custer's bandmaster. The first act of that work was given on March 4 under the direction of Latien Weed, head of the music department at Yankton College here.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 25 -- Sir Roy Welensky declared today that he was convinced there was "a new appreciation in Britain of what we are trying to do in Africa." First-hand information about accommodations is hard to come by, roads are a question mark and recent events have conditioned one into regarding any sort of an African venture as being dangerous.

GILGO BEACH, L.I., March 25 -- The body of John M. Beckmann, former Commissioner of the Nassau County Police Department, was found today in the marshlands of South Oyster Bay. The Nassau police said the cause of death could not be immediately determined.

FOR most Americans, the Comedie Francaise evokes an image of high comedy impeccably acted in Louis XIV settings and enveloped in a flow of amiable wit and eloquence. Indeed as heirs of the House of Moliere, this is the company's official face.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 25 -- The elegant structure that was once the country home of the late August Belmont is to be replaced by new garden apartment houses and a swimming pool. The sale of the property for $500,000 to Country Estate Associates was announced here today.
