TAMPA, Fla., March 25 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds, behind the three-hit pitching of Ken Hunt, a rookie, and Marshall Bridges, downed the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4 -- 2, today.
Dave Abramson of the Knickerbocker Swim Club established a Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union senior record for the 220-yard free-style last night at the New York Athletic Club.

The presence of a professional acting troupe at Pnnceton m well worth Mr. Taubman's notice. Like most New Yorkers who write about the theatre, however, he seems considerably out of touch with the status of the university theatre.

SEOUL, Korea, March 19 -- After taking a careful and somewhat' dismayed new look at its massive program of aid to South Korea, the United States is planning some important economic and psychological reforms.
Five days after his inaugural President Kennedy announced that Russia had released the two RB-47 fliers. The news spurred hopes that a new era of erased tension in the cold war might be at hand.

Wall Street houses that emphasize the "confidence index" and customers who hang upon their words have been having an embarrassing time thus far in 1961. Their favorite indicator has been telling the wrong story.
WASHINGTON, March 25--The Peace Corps will start sending out Monday 200,000 questionnaires to prospective volunteers, the corps announced today.
A controversial measure that would drastically overhaul Federal policy on steamship conferences received searching analysis last week before a committee of the House of Representatives.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 25 -- New York University's three-man team won all four titles today in the National Collegiate fencing champions.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 25 -- An international convention on narcotics was adopted here today, ending a ten-year effort to combine existing agreements. The convention must be ratified by forty governments to become a treaty.

RASPBERRIES are comparatively easy to grow. They tolerate considerable variation in growing conditions. Insect and disease control, so vital to success with most fruits, can be substantially neglected and gardeners can still harvest a berry crop.
American eighteenth-century cabinetry and decorative objects from the estate of the late Reginald M. Lewis of Easton, Md., brought $418,745 in a two-day auction that ended here yesterday.

SEATTLE, March 25 -- Michigan won the National Collegiate swimming and diving championship tonight in a meet that saw records broken in thirteen events. Murray Rose, the Australian Olympic star swimming for Southern California, shattered three records -- in the 1,500-meter, 220-yard and 440-yard free-style events.

In contrast to the heat of the debate surrounding it, educational television (ETV) has had only a modest impact during its first decade. Although the Federal Communications Commission has allocated 264 television channels for educational purposes, so far only fifty-four have been used.

THE review by Reinhold Niebuhr of Karl Jasper's "The Future of Mankind" indicates that Niebuhr underestimates the seriousness of the problem of the nuclear weapons. He says "In this reviewer's opinion, he [Jasper] probably overstates the peril when he declares that for the first time in history modern science has put weapons into our hands that 'make it possible for mankind to be wiped out by men.'

AS producer of "One-Eyed Jacks," the controversial motion picture marking Marlon Brando's debut as a director (he also stars), the questions I hear most often deal with the three cryptic years that will have elapsed between the first announcement of the project and the world premiere in New York.
QUINCY, Mass., March 25 -- Two heavy cranes were needed recently to lift a forty-seven-ton stern section into place for welding to the largest merchant ship ever built.
BOSTON, March 25 -- The Boston Symphony Orchestra will extend its season to fifty weeks beginning next fall. This will mean 221 concerts.

For her piano program in Town Hall late yesterday afternoon, Lucy Brown brought in her own arrangement of Schumann's Studies for Pedal-Piano, three pieces by Beethoven, Bach's Toccata in D and Schostakovich's Piano Quintet.

GROUNDCOVERS can help solve the home gardener's problem of how to carpet areas where grass will not grow -- the small space between the step, walk and house or on steep slopes. Plants from several classifications may be used: annuals, herbaceous perennials and woody perennials.

A bill that would delay the installation of sprinkler systems in old factories was attacked yesterday at a ceremony marking the fiftieth anniversary of the Triangle Shirtwaist fire. About 500 men and women stood in a chill wind at Washington Place and Greene Street for the memorial ceremony.

DARIEN, Conn., March 25 -- { Miss Theodora Linton Foster,{ daughter of Mrs. Linton Haight {Foster of Noroton and the late Mr. Foster, was married here this afternoon to Daniel Brook{ Bartlett, son of Mr. and Mrs.[ Francis Wayland Bartlett Jr. of[ Kansas City, Mo.

Winter doldrums put a damper on business activity last month as measured by checkbook spending in the district. Bank debits rose only 2 per cent from the 1960 level. For the first two months of the year the cumulative increase was 7 per cent.

A BUILDING long shut tight against invasion by the public has been transformed, dramatically, into a magnet for art lovers. It is a building housing one of the world's great collection of art -- valued by those who assess art in terms of money at about $100,O00,000 -- and each Friday and Saturday some 200 eager visitors are journeying to the quietly elegant suburb of Merion, just outside Philadelphia, to behold it.

A group of college students simulating a meeting of the United Nations General Assembly refused to permit one of their number who was "representing" Czechoslovakia to take part in a discussion of Laos.

A series of theatre parties in April and May is being arranged by the New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy to raise funds for its Student Ticket Program and Board of Standards and Planning for the Living Theatre.

" THE STONE ARBOR," Roger Angell's first book, is a collection of short stories all of which have appeared over the past fifteen years in The New Yorker. The quality of these stories -- physically and spiritually -- is very New Yorker-ish: neat prose and bland images, lighthearted attempts at delineating some of the psychic fears around town, pseudo-Proustian reminiscence and an astonishing capacity for skimming the surface of deeply felt experiences.
Steinert High School of Trenton defeated Eastern District of Brooklyn, 59 -- 36, in a televised basketball game yesterday in the New York University gymnasium.

SYRACUSE, March 25 -- The poised and powerful Boston Celtics trounced Syracuse, 120 -- 107, today for their third victory against one defeat in the Eastern Division play-off finals of the National Basketball Association.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Administration's determination to organize the human and material resources of the free world against the mounting industrial power and economic aggression of the Communist bloc was dramatized by separate White House developments this week.

ONCE upon a time a 22-year-old Boy encountered a Girl. She had a shiny nose and pink eyes from skiing, so he proposed to her, and they were married. Immediately. From that time on, everything Tish and Gil Stanton set out to do became equally urgent and eccentric.
Memphis business men converted an abandoned bank vault into a private club with dining room and lounge.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- The secretary of the Illinois commission, Dr. Clyde Walton, said today "I feel certain we will attend" if the meeting is held at the naval station.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Job of Secretary of Defense never seemed more awesome than today with military crises brewing, Soviet relations taking a delicate turn, and the services already battling over the new military budget that is about to be unveiled.
Real estate interests have been working to clinch a tax victory that has been tantalizing them since last September.

Borough President John T. Clancy of Queens called on the city yesterday to create a "land bank" of vacant property near New York International Airport to prevent the construction of more homes in the flight paths of airplanes.
Those sharp-eyed fellows who run novices through the driver's license tests were behind the wheel themselves last week -- being scrutinized by other sharp-eyed men.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 25 -- Gen. Cemal Gursel, Turkish chief of state, said at a news conference today that Turkish political parties would be allowed to proceed with their regional organization and to hold indoor meetings after April 1.
An art exhibition called "Profile in Courage" at an East Side gallery gives brightly colored proof that a man can paint landscapes by holding the brush in his teeth.
WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 25 -- An enraged elephant trampled his trainer during a matinee performance of the Wirth Circus in the Island Garden Arena here today.

I sympathize with the man in the cartoon who thought lady writers came only in three names. Hone of my friends will bother reading Elizabeth Taylor Caldwell any more, although I do still have a sneaking admiration for Rachel Carson McCullers, whose real name, I understand, is George Eliot.
WELLESLEY, Mass., March 25 -- Miss Margaret Clapp, president of Wellesley College, said today that better methods were needed for selecting candidates for higher education.

THUBTEN JIGME NORBU is the eldest brother of the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual and temporal leader of Tibet. The Westerner might expect Mr. Norbu's autobiography, "Tibet Is My Country," to be a saga of the mysterious, the exotic, the unfathomable, of yaks and incense and wailing silver trumpets and buttered tea.

ROOSEVELT, Ariz. -- Roosevelt Dam, the nation's first Federal reclamation project, brought water, fertile lands, people, industry and wealth to central Arizona. It also opened up what was one of the most unspoiled recreational areas in the West.

SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia, March 10 -- The sun sank behind the mountains encircling this city and swallows raced the night to their nests. The dusk left only the minarets of Sarajevo's sixty-seven mosques pointing like giant forefingers to the darkening sky.
NICE, France -- The French Riviera is undoubtedly one of the most fabled vacationlands of all time, and thus it comes as a bit of a shock to learn that tourism on the Cote d'Azur is declining.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 25 -- The United States, aiming for a spot 120,000 miles deep in space, hurled a satellite into a precarious "Yo-yo," or wide-swinging, orbit around the earth today to chart safe paths for space travel.

EARLY spring usually is "moving time" for plants in home gardens. Plants will suffer very little shock if set out on an overcast day, moist and windless, with a promise of rain by evening. If the seed flats are kept safely in a coldframe or on a cool glassed porch, the gardener can wait a week or more for perfect weather conditions.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI) -- Senator John A. Carroll, Democrat of Colorado, advised President Kennedy today that a Senate judiciary subcommittee that investigated ethics in Government would oppose appointment of a White House overseer of Federal regulatory agencies.
MOSCOW, March 25 (Reuters) -- The major shake-up of Soviet agricultural leadership was still under way today.
Since the controversy about Thomas Wolfe and Scott Fitzgerald's bottle of gin has been exhausted as far as literary values are concerned perhaps a mathematical analysis is indicated.

THIS historical romance is a notable addition to the lengthening shelf of novels with "down-under" settings. True, it is feminine, in point of view and in a good deal of its substance. True, it is a story of husband-hunting and the triumph of love in a marriage of ambition.
WORCESTER, Mass. -- For week-end drivers, it is only a short trip back to the Middle Ages via Worcester and the John Woodman Higgins Museum, the home of a hundred and one knights in shining armor.
TRENTON, March 25 -- The first joint appearance of the seven candidates for the Republican and Democratic nominations for Governor is scheduled this week.

PARIS, March 25 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, former Premier of Laos, was quoted here today as having said that the Kennedy Administration's policy on Laos was "fundamentally different" from that of the Eisenhower Administration.

Respecting that letter from Jane Grant, in your March 12 issue, concerning the difficulty experienced by some of the ladies in getting a turn at propounding questions to the President in his press conferences, I, a lame old gent who enjoys these periodical exchanges, have noticed their dilemma.
Efforts by the Kennedy Administration to change the United States from complacent storekeeper to eager salesman in its role in international trade and business are beginning to take shape.

A privately sponsored "peace corps" that grew from a successful jazz and tennis tour of Latin America is scheduled to arrive in Colombia this summer armed with building blocks rather than trombones and racquets.

AMERICA has never had a poet laureate and probably never will. The spirit of American poetry does not leap lightly and obediently to the occasion, but rather runs its course deep and quiet below the surface of everyday events. As Robert Frost put it, "A poem cannot be worried into being."

The private schools, exercising their traditional "freedom to experiment" have collected a representative group of pilot programs in a documentary volume, "New Approaches to Education," published today.
Many specialists believe that unless radical steps are taken there will soon be near chaos in world-wide communications because of shrinking sun spots.

EPHROS, GERSHON: Excerpts from "Cantorial Anthology," Piano Variations, Piano Suite, Introduction, Andante and Fugue for String Quartet; various cantors and choirs, Lucy Brown, pianist, Kohon String Quartet (Tikvah T 70). The seventieth birthday of Mr. Ephros, Polish-born American compiler of the five-volume "Cantorial Anthology," is observed with this disk.

ON Tuesday, the day after his eighty-second birthday, the Museum of Modern Art will open its retrospective of Edward Steichen, who has often been called the greatest photographer in the world and is the museum's director of photography. The selection of over 200 prints (he spent three months culling 30,000 negatives and prints) spans sixty-five years.

SOVIET education is a political weapon, a means of serving the purposes of the Communist state and world ideology, and since the chief target of Soviet politics is the United States, it is pertinent to know what sort of American image is drawn for Soviet youth.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Labor stoppages on the nation top priority missile base program have diminished, but problems still remain.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 25 -- A new theory of international trade based on new world conditions is essential, Senator John O. Pastore, Democrat of Rhode Island, asserted today.
YONKERS, March 25 -- freezing weather will never stop those who wish to bet their money on horses. Tonight at Yonkers Raceway, 28,343 well-prepared fans turned out to wager $1,860,766.

Congratulations dn your publication of James Baldwin's stirring article on-the current Negro mood. Mr. Baldwin's for putting down the truth in his celebt-ab ringing essay style prompts me to remark that I too was profoundly offended by the effort to link' the Lamumba demonstrations at-the United Nations with Mecca or Moscow inspiration
MANILA, March 25 (UPI) -- Archie Moore, of San Diego, outpointed Buddy Turman of Tyler, Tex., in a ten-round heavyweight bout tonight.

Premier Khrushchev and President Kennedy, after two months of probing to determine each other's intentions, have now embarked upon their first test of strength. The Laotian crisis is only one of a number that may be expected in 1961, and the United States and the other members of the North Atlantic Alliance will need stout nerves for the trials ahead.
WASHINGTON, March 25--The Government announced today higher interest rates and a ten-year extension in the maturity of the savings bonds held by 10,000,000 Americans since the Nineteen Forties.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- President Kennedy appealed tonight to the Kenosha, Wis., Housing Authority to make "every possible effort" to provide shelter for forty families threatened with eviction from public housing.

MR. WIZARD lit three cigarettes and started them smoking. They were not in his mouth but had been set in three holes leading to a tube that traveled the smoke further to a glass-fronted box occupied by a small wooden model of an automobile.

A new airborne television system to help guide a telescope floating in the stratosphere is nearing completion at the R.C.A. laboratories at Princeton, N.J. The balloon project, conceived by Prof. Martin Schwarzschild of the Princeton Astronomy Department, aims at viewing the heavens with a 36-inch telescope suspended from a balloon fifteen miles above the earth.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 25 -- Ch. Glen Hill Dreamers Nobleman, a 4 1/2-year-old sable dog belonging to Mrs. J. Richard Shryock and William Lex Jr. of Haverford, Pa., became the best-of-bread winner tonight in the Collie Club of Long Island show.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 25 (AP) -- Brae Burn Farm's General Arthur, close to the pace all the way, took the lead at the quarter pole and won the $41,895 Donn Handicap at Gulfstream Park today by three lengths.

The United States has urged the Soviet Union to stop airlifting war materials to the rebels in Laos. If the Russians refuse to heed this plea the United States will have no recourse other than to step up military aid to the Government, and so an arms race in Southeast-Asia will be on, with no one in a position to say where it will end.
DEN PASAR, Bali, Indonesia, March 11 -- A year ago, people on Bali, a splash of loveliness off Java, were saying bitterly that the only way to get a piece of white cloth was to die.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 25 (AP) -- John M. Bailey, the Democratic national chairman, said tonight that strong and well-organized interests were cooperating with an obstructionist Republican leadership in Congress to block President Kennedy's program.
SEBRING, Fla., March 25 -- Phil Hill of Santa Monica, Calif., and Olivier Gendebien of Belgium won the twelve-hour world championship sports-car race tonight.
As the income tax deadline approaches -- this year on April 17 -- millions of Americans once again grumble as they prepare and file their returns.
MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 25 -- After three agonizing days of drifting in calm Caribbean air, the yawl Escapade today became the first yacht to finish in the race from Miami to this port.
The death sentences imposed on two Puerto Rican youths here have been denounced as a "miscarriage of justice" by a committee that includes Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.
KANSAS CITY, March 25 -- At exactly 11:39 o'clock tonight, the basketball empire of Ohio State crumbled on the hardwood of the Municipal Auditorium. Another king, Cincinnati, emerged.

ROBERT L. JOSEPH says the news isn't that he has written another play, "Isle of Children," nor is the news so much that Lester Osterman has decided to produce it next season in association with Shirley Bernstein (sister of Leonard).

THIS is the best translation of "Faust" that I have read. Printed, on the right hand page, parallel with the German text on the left, it passes a simple test. One can turn from the German to the English, without too much of a jolt.

THE DANCE MAGAZINE has just selected the winners of its sixth annual awards, and the general point on which all three of them center is international exchange. The winners are, in alphabetical order, Merce Cunningham, Igor Moiseyev and Maria Tallchief.

THE Bible has been in process of translation almost since it began to be written down -- certainly before the full text, as we know it, existed. Today, translations, in whole or in part, total 1,151 at latest count. The story of the translations, past and present, is a fascinating one, as two scholars -- one British, one American -- reveal in recently published books.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- President Kennedy flew to Florida tonight for a hastily arranged meeting tomorrow with Prime Minister Macmillan on the crisis in Laos.

INTRAMURAL strife, a euphemism for backstage bickering and brawling, is a commonplace in the theatre, thanks to the neuroses of its inmates and the tooth-and-claw tactics they employ to maintain a queasy professional status variously achieved through self-denial, industry and witchcraft.
NORWALK, Conn., March 25 -- Otto Kaplan, a virtuoso with power tools, is facing a big moment. On Monday, the machine he dreamed of and finally made will begin the production of violin strings.

AN Adams revival is in full swing. John Adams, John Quincy Adams and Charles Francis Adams are finally coming to take their rightful place in the American story. It is ironical that the Adams clan, surely the most unpopular family in American history -- indeed, a family that by its coldness and aloofness scorned popularity -- should now be one of the most attractive and exciting subjects a biographer could choose.

A CARTOON in the Secretariat News, sprightly house organ of the United Nations' international civil service, has struck a chord of the times. It has no caption. It pictures a row of the U.N.'s simultaneous interpreters in their booths, translating into English, French and other basic U.N. languages the words of a speaker on the General Assembly podium.

Marching along through the annals of the literature of all nations is that old cliche of a character, the prostitute with the unsullied, decent, sentimental heart of gold. Throughout the years, she has remained chaste in spirit, selling herself by night and longing for respectability by day.

GENEVA, March 25 -- At 2:58 P.M. last Tuesday, Semyon K. Tsarapkin of the Soviet Union walked into Conference Room VIII at the United Nations' European headquarters here and shook hands with the Americans and Britons.

THIS sequel to "While Mrs. Coverlet Was Away" is as delightful as its predecessor, which is saying a good deal. Mrs. Coverlet, of course, is the invaluable housekeeper for the three motherless Persever children, whose father spends a lot of time in New Zealand.

WASHINGTON, March 25--President Kennedy, Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara and Budget Director David E. Bell met at the White House this afternoon to put finishing touches on major revisions in the military budget drawn up by the Eisenhower Administration.

HAVANA, March 25--Cuba today is a military fortress bristling with weapons under the command of Premier Fidel Castro, who is attempting to put down rising opposition to his regime with the firing squad.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sunday, March 26 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk arrived here early today from the United States to attend from the conference of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization, opening tomorrow.
Investigative and public-service reporting are the subjects of a two-week seminar being held by the American Press Institute at Columbia University.

BUILT to hang on the wall so that it takes up no floor space, here is a compact wall desk which is suitable for use in a child's room, kitchen or family room. The drop-lid front folds down to form a solid writing surface, while the inside has room for pencils, stationery and other writing (or drawing) materials.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. March 24 -- A gentle, smiling man with tribal scars on his face has spent a week here and in Washington inquiring whether the United States will provide aid to his desperately poor country.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 25 -- V.K. Krishna Menon, India's Defense Minister, conferred today with Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold three hours after arriving in New York to attend the General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI) -- Behind the Forest Service's recent proposal for a ten-to-fifteen-year $25.6-million plan to improve hunting and fishing in national forests is the fact that these woodlands are far below their capacity to sustain fish and wild life.
Time appears to have run out on one of the last remaining monuments to "Boss" Tweed, the portly politician who ruled Tammany Hall with open palms in the Eighteen Sixties.

CAIRO, March 16 -- For more than eighty years, Haj Mohammed Marzouk has been a gifted artisan privileged to embroider gold letters from the Koran on the great black plush covers destined for the Kaaba, Islam's most sacred shrine at Mecca.
BOSTON, March 25 -- A mosaic pavement nearly 2,000 years old is to be reconstructed at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum this summer on a concrete slab reinforced by steel.

The brief strike of truckmen in New York's vast garment center set resident buying offices busily rearranging shipping schedules last week. The buying agents for thousands of retail stores across the country indicated that the walkout had snarled deliveries of post-Easter goods, but left Easter finery, most of which is already on store racks, virtually untouched.

HONG KONG, March 17 -- The reinstated free market in Communist China, for commodities not purchased directly by the state, is developing into a black market in many areas desperately short of consumer goods.
Profound cultural differences between groups of Vietnamese and American children were disclosed in a study here yesterday.

The nation's gold stock inched upward again last week. It was only the second rise for a week since mid-1959. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported the gain at $5,000,000. A week before it rose $11,000,000. The latest increase raised the nation's gold supply to $17,389,000,000. It was a welcome change of trend, although still at a slow rate.

JANUARY 6, 1781. -- Be prepared, my dear Eliot, for a shock, and attend to an event which must sensibly affect every honest heart. The accumulated distresses of the army have at length produced most dreadful effects.
SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 25 (AP) -- The $100,000 invested by the Boston Red Sox to lure Carl Michael Yastrzemski from Notre Dame should start paying dividends this year.

Providence College, down by 7 points with ten minutes to go, stormed to a 62-59 victory over favored St. Louis University yesterday and won the twenty-fourth annual National Invitation Basketball Tournament.

WHILE American forces were storming Nazi Germany during World War II a fictional soldier who called himself Cpl. Tom Jones of Green Bay, Wis., began a series of propaganda broadcasts to the people of the Reich.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 22 -- Rumania's Communist officials are drawing up a new national Constitution that is expected to proclaim the country a "Socialist" republic.

METUCHEN, N.J. -- A recent correspondent of the Travel Section [Joseph F. Hannan: "It Isn't So What They Say About Camping," issue of March 12] found tent camping expensive and tiring because he was in-experienced and unequipped.
Two eminent authorities from widely disparate disciplines have proposed practically identical plans for approaching world disarmament.

ALBANY, March 25 -- Senators Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo and Joseph Zaretzki of Manhattan tonight defended a proposed $2,500-a-year increase in legislators' pay against editorial and other criticism.

LET us start with the Baron, an odd chap, mocking life's grim lunacies with his own grim grotesqueness, an "immaculate clown" in his tight checked trousers, derby and white spats. At the crest of melodrama, however, he does something quite uncharacteristic: his pistol shot saves a pair of lovers from their assassin.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., March 25 (AP) -- The boxer who does knee-bends in his corner, the pitcher and catcher who warm up in the bullpen and the football player who sprints behind the bench are not grandstanding -- they are avoiding possible injury.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 22 -- Africa's Lake Kariba, a link between Northern and Southern Rhodesia, may one day become a swamp, clogged with floating weed, and eventually dry up.

PEOPLE who are interested in growing plants are chiefly concerned with the end product. Many gardeners are of the opinion that fertilizing, watering, controlling diseases and insects and other cultural practices are the answer to obtaining good flowers and vegetables.

THE venturesome band that Gil Evans led for several weeks last fall at the Jazz Gallery makes its recording debut on Out of the Cool (Impulse 4-A; stereo S-4). This is also one of the first disks to come from A.B.C.-Paramount's new jazz subsidiary, Impulse Records.
The report that an atomic clock has been developed for the Air Force so accurate that its maximum error would not exceed one second in 1,271 years signals a new triumph of technology over time.
The May 5 performance by the Moiseyev Dance Company at the Metropolitan Opera House will benefit the Scholarship Fund of the New Lincoln School.
About 100 well-dressed men, women and children, residents of Le Havre Apartments in Whitestone, Queens, picketed the thirty-two-building project yesterday in a dispute with the management.

THE drive against alcoholism in France is no longer a great joke. Frenchmen are beginning to realize that liver (delicious when it comes from an Alsatian goose and is flavored with a Perigord truffle) can be quite unpleasant (when it happens to be your own and was damaged by too much Pernod).
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The State Department announced today that a United States military transport with eight men aboard had been missing for two days in Laos.
DETROIT, March 25 -- Voters in Michigan's April 3 election will decide whether a convention will be held to rewrite the state Constitution.

DR. JANET TRAVELL, personal physician to the President, is now serenely settled into her new practice at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. "At last everybody seems to have forgotten that I'm supposed to be so remarkable because I'm a woman," she says.

EDWARD STEICHEN'S work as a photographer and in diverse other artistic mediums since 1895 will be displayed in a retrospective exhibition starting Wednesday at the Museum of Modern Art. It will continue to May 21.

A gala Greek Easter dinner dance will be given on April 10 aboard the liner Queen Frederica at Pier 97, North River at Fifty Seventh Street. The fete will benefit the Scholarship Fund of Athens College.

During the last ten years the nation has been on an aspirin binge. Consumption of the pain-easing pills has increased four times as fast as the population growth. Last week, however, the Federal Trade Commission gave aspirin makers reason to start sampling their own product. The F.T.C. accused four leading manufacturers of making false advertising claims about the speed with which their products took effect.

THAT time of year is officially here -- the season of the first robin, crocus and greening leaves on rosebushes. Gardeners who have been inside all winter are eager to start and plants are waiting to grow. Skies bright blue, with a dash of sunshine for glow, and warm crumbly earth signal spring.

Commercial construction in the Chicago area announced during January totaled $14,950,000, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. The value of the projects was more than double that of the December report when $7,063,000 was announced.
" You don't have to be a millionaire to visit the United States and Canada."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 25 -- Coexistence in the United Nations, as in the world at large, is not a goal, but a fact. Annihilation of the adversary is unthinkable; resignation from the organization is almost as difficult as resignation from the planet There is no choice.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., March 24 -- Working on the premise that respect for paintings and respect for politics are not necessarily mutually exclusive, local officials here have now gone in for art appreciation.
Recent pronouncements by members of President Kennedy's Administration seem to imply that a new tax policy is under consideration, one that would reduce the tax rate in upper income brackets.
Antique firearms, edged weapons and armor will be auctioned Thursday in a sale that also includes Renaissance furniture, Gothic sculptures, Old Master drawings and icons.
Department store sales in the nation in the week ended March 18 rose 9 per cent above the 1960 level, the Federal Reserve Board has reported.
OLDSMAR, Fla., March 4 (AP) -- First Banker lived up his name today and returned a handsome dividend to backer in the $14,690 Florida Breeder Futurity, the closing-date feature at Sunshine Park.
WITHIN the next few weeks New Yorkers will have a chance to hear three little-known Handel oratorios. On April 10 the Cantata Singers, under Thomas Dunn, are giving "Belshazzar" at Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, MARCH 25 -- The Soviet Union this week lifted prior censorship on outgoing news dispatches from non-Communist correspondents working in Moscow. A key element in the announcement was contained in the second paragraph of most of the news accounts reporting this event.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25 -- The San Francisco Giants gave up early on Ernie Broglio, a strong, young right-handed pitcher. So they traded him to the St. Louis Cardinals and the Cards almost made the same mistake. The Redbirds looked on his 7-and-12 won-lost record in 1959 with such distaste that Bing Devine, the general manager, came frighteningly close last spring to shipping him to the Chicago Cubs for Moe Drabowsky.
The medical board of Harlem Hospital yesterday approved unanimously a proposal that it affiliate with Columbia University.
Michael H. Prendergast defied the Kennedy Administration yesterday, telling the Democratic national chairman that under no condition would he resign as state leader.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -The Federal budget a painfully precise document that never works out that way. It is nonetheless the most comprehensive presentation of a President's position on matters that involve money, and almost everything does.

ALBANY, Calif., March 25 (AP) -- Alberta Ranches' Four and Twenty, the winter-book favorite for the Kentucky Derby, beat only one horse in a field of six today in the $10,850 San Francisco Handicap at Golden Gate Fields. Sea Orbit won the mile feature.

AGUASCALIENTES, Mexico-- This city, the capital of the state of the same name, is many miles removed from the great tourist haunts of Mexico City, Acapulco and Taxco. For that reason it has much to offer travelers who want to see a side of Mexican life that has not been noticeably affected by outside influences.
THE SEASON for strolling along the boardwalks that dot the New Jersey coast opens officially next Sunday, when Easter promenaders by the thousands will turn out in their new spring finery.

HANOVER, N.H., March 25 -- The W.K. Kellogg Foundation of Battle Creek, Mich., has granted the Dartmouth Medical School $500,000 to build a teaching auditorium next to its new medical science building.
ATLANTA, March 25 (AP) -- Glen (Fireball) Roberts of Daytona Beach, Fla., was first in a stock-car race of champions at Atlanta International Raceway today.
DE LAND, Fla. -- According to legend, Ponce de Leon, the Spanish explorer, discovered the springs north of here nearly 450 years ago, when he was searching for the mythical Fountain of Youth.
NEW DELHI, India, March 25 -- The revival in New Delhi of the International Control Commission for Laos appeared imminent today.

THE highly popular and shoddy program entitled "The Untouchables" would seem an odd choice for a minor cause celebre in television. But recent events involving the gangster series are eminently disturbing, not because the fate of that particular program is a matter of any moment but because its producer, Desi Arnaz, and the American Broadcasting Company have chosen unwise methods of allaying criticism.

IF the cartoon by W.R. Anderson ("I know it seems trivial, Ed. But I just can't think of a female author who doesn't have three names") reflects Mr. Anderson's own belief, I wonder.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Kennedy Administration looked to the Senate today to repair much of the damage done by the House yesterday to its minimum wage program.

The boat-building empire started by Christopher Columbus Smith in 1906 and now known as Chris-Craft has acquired a new branch. For the first time, a plant has been added on the West Coast to this Eastern empire.
BERGEN, N.Y., March 25 (AP) -- Two New York Central freight trains collided tonight as one pulled into a siding near here, hurtling thirteen cars over a mainline track.

If at some future date a detailed history of advertising is written, a chapter may be included entitled "Rosser Reeves, His Book and the Image of Advertising."

Newbold Morris, the Commissioner of Parks, announced yesterday that six municipal golf courses would be open for play starting at 6 A.M. next Saturday. The courses are Van Cortlandt, Pelham and Split Rock in the Bronx, Kissena and Forest Park in Queens and La-Tourette in Richmond.
" In the fall of 1892, I was requested by a friendly colleague to examine a young lady who had been suffering from pains in her legs for over two years so that she walked badly."

THERE are those who will rightly tell you that, while some movies even now look as if they were made up in the course of their production, in the old days many of them were. Back when the screen was silent, many directors would start a picture with no more than a rough idea, then cook up the story and the business as they went along.
MEXICO CITY, March 22 -- A political storm appears to be brewing here around former President Lazaro Cardenas. The incumbent President Adolfo Lopez Mateos, appears to be directly in the storm's path.

KERBY MAXWELL and the neighborhood crew of "The Lemonade Trick" are back in a new and equally funny set of adventures. Allergic to writing thank-you notes -- and what boy is not -- Kerby varies that post-birthday ordeal by penning diatribes to his two enemies and an over-heated note to the Governor.

FIRST published in 1956, awarded a Pulitzer Prize, and a best-seller for ninety-five weeks, President Kennedy's study of courage and politics is now presented in a special edition for young people. It has not been rewritten but abridged and reset in large, readable type with a letter to young readers from the President.
CAIRO, March 25 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser told an assembly of African nationalists tonight that they must remain on the alert against "imperialism" in Africa.
PITTSBURGH, March 25 -- The once-mighty Republican Organization here is today in most embarrassing position of being without a candidate for Mayor.
TORONTO, March 25 (UPI) -- The Detroit Red Wings squared their Stanley Cup semi-final series with the Toronto Maple Leafs at one game apiece tonight by scoring a 4-2 victory.
Passover, the week-long Jewish festival celebrating the liberation of the Israelites from Egyptian bondage more than 3,000 years ago, will begin next Friday at sundown.

BELG RADE, Yugoslavia March 11 -- The Yugoslavs estimate there are about 5,000,000 persons of Yugoslav origin and their children living in foreign lands. Their ties with the old country are an important source of vital foreign exchange for the regime of President Tito.

The price of cultured pearls has soared during the last year, with some grades registering advances of as much as 60 per cent, according to the Cultured Pearl Association of America, Inc. The group attributes the sharp rise to the 1959 typhoon in Japan, which disturbed the oyster beds and increased European demand.
FORT PIERCE, Fla., March 25 (UPI) -- Cross-examination of Joseph A. Peel Jr., on trial for his life as the accused mastermind of the Chillingworth murders in 1955, ended abruptly today.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., March 25 (AP) -- Two American records were set today in the Indiana Amateur Athletic Union swimming meet by Indiana University swimmers. They were barred from the National Collegiate meet because of a penalty for the school's overzealous football recruiting.
THE National Broadcasting Company plans a daring step next fall. It will televise a police show without crime. This is even more daring than a newspaper drama in which no one yells, "Stop the press!"
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 25 -- A diplomat experienced in the problems of the Congo has made a plea for recognition of the "silent, dedicated work of a gallant band of people."

Independent student responsibility and an interrelated course program are two main features of a prize-winning proposal for a new college of liberal arts outlined in the current issue of the Williams Alumni Review.

FLOWERING or Japanese quince add a striking burst of color to the early spring garden. The cup-shaped blossoms, generally single, range in color from white through pink, rose, salmon and orange to crimson and blood red.

Thousands of products -- ranging from television sets to missile components -- eventually may be much smaller, more reliable and cheaper as a result of molecular electronics. This latest development in micro-miniaturization is just emerging from the laboratory into the market place.

FASTNACHTS on Shrove Tuesday, hot cross buns on Good Friday, bright-dyed eggs on Easter morning -- not many children realize when they eat these vernal goodies that they are perpetuating traditions handed down for hundreds of years.

ALBANY, March 25 -- The Legislature today approved Governor Rockefeller's package bill authorizing the Port of New York Authority to take over the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad and construct a $355,000 world trade center in lower Manhattan.
NEWARK, N.J., March 25 -- The Newark Museum announced plans today for its fourth triennial exhibition of "Work by New Jersey Artists," scheduled to open on May 5 and run through June 11.

I appreciated the excellent article on "Cheap Fares In Cargo Planes" by Paul J.C. Friedlander last Sunday very, very much. And, I would like to thank you for the good work you are doing in attempting to bring trans-Atlantic air fares down to fairer, more reasonable levels.

The season's fifth and final performance of Richard Strauss' "Elektra," given at the Metropolitan Opera yesterday afternoon, had one cast member who had not sung in it previously with the company. She was Leonie Rysanek, who appeared as Chrysothemis.
New York, New Jersey and Connecticut should consider at once a comprehensive study of land and transportation, James Felt, Chairman of the City Planing Commission, declared yesterday.
The prevention of family breakdowns will be the focus of social welfare services by the Community Service Society in the Nineteen Sixties, the agency said in its 112th annual report yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, March 25 (AP) -- The international executive board of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union suspended the union's two top officials today on charges stemming from a shortage of union treasury funds.

VIENNA, March 25 -- The powers wielded by the United States Congress and Britain's House of Commons have stimulated a movement in the hobbled Austrian Parliament to curb the executive and the quasi-sovereign bureaucracy that originated in the days when Austria was governed by the Habsburgs as an absolute monarchy.

LONDON, March 25 -- For the first time in five years the Conservative Members of Parliament are skeptically reassessing Prime Minister Macmillan, his Cabinet and the policies produced by "Tory radicalism."

A WIRY young man with rumpled hair, a jaunty walk, a placid manner and a Lancashire accent under control may not yet be the biggest star in British drama, but he has enough confidence in his future to be able to tell a noisy London audience to shut up and enough public esteem to get away with it.

LUCKNOW, India, March 17 -- "I am a murderer," the farmer said. "I am sentenced to life. But they have given me land and tools to grow wheat and sugar cane. They are teaching me to read and write. Soon maybe I will teach others."
MIAMI BEACH, March 25 (AP) -- Julius Boros, Gary Player and Gay Brewer Jr. were in a three-way tie for the lead at 204 after three rounds of the 72-hole Sunshine open golf tournament today.
Old-timers at the New Democratic Club have turned to playacting to present a primer in practical politicking for the education and edification of newcomers to precinct politics.
SUMMIT, N.J., March 25 -- A 16-year-old girl was dead here today because she had dashed back into a burning house to try to retrieve $35 set aside for new Easter clothes.
THE broadleaved evergreens are conspicuously ornamental all year long. Some of the newer ones may be difficult to find in nurseries until they are more widely available.

AINTREE, England, March 25 -- Nicolaus Silver, a 28-to-1 shot, broke a long-standing hoodoo on gray horses by winning the Grand National today by five length. Merryman II, last year's winner, was second.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 15 -- Harry F. Oppenheimer, head of a vast gold, diamond and copper mining empire in Central and South Africa, said today that South Africa's withdrawal from the British Commonwealth was "a grave, unmitigated misfortune economically, politically and militarily."

MEN have fled their wives and families (before and after Gauguin) to discover for themselves if they were true artists or Sunday painters. In David Stone's THE TIRED SPY (Putnam's, $3.95), 44-year-old Paul Porlock's motives seem quite similar as he packs his tubes and easel, abandons his tedious job in London, his nagging, unfaithful wife and his dreadful daughter, and sets out for Florence.
NEW house this spring -- no lawn -- what to do? This is one of the most perplexing horticultural problems a new home owner has to face. For most persons there is really no perfect, economical answer.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Postmaster General J. Edward Day is rounding out his second month in office with a series of changes in department policies.
NEW ORLEANS, March 25 (AP) -- Glen Fowler, a former professional from Oklahoma City, upset Deane Beman of Bethesda, Md., in twenty-three holes today at the Western amateur golf tournaments.
JERUSALEM, March 25 -- With elections looming, Israel faces the uncomfortable prospect that a renewed debate over the Lavon affair will coincide with the Eichmann trial.

WRITTEN at the end of the Elizabethan age, when our language was in a ferment of magnificence, the King James Version of the Bible mingled grandeur and loveliness and joined beauty to splendor. It helped to shape the English-speaking peoples at the very time they were shaping the world.

Spring arrived officially last week, bringing customers in quantity and in a buying mood. They have six more days in which to do their shopping for the Easter parade, and they thronged apparel departments in stores throughout the country.
CORVALLIS, Ore., March 25 (AP) -- Oklahoma State won the National Collegiate wrestling championship today for the twenty-second time.

The Sun Oil Company has budgeted for 1961 a total of $131,000,000 for expansion, modernization and the drilling of wells to develop new reserves of oil and gas, according to the company's pamphlet report for 1960. This would be 17 per cent more than the $106,000,000 spent in 1960.

PITTSBURGH, March 25 (UPI) -- Americans for Democratic Action called today for restoration of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer's Government security clearance to help the nation recover from a "bad hangover of McCarthyism."

THE home owner who has never had a vegetable garden will be agreeably surprised by how many dividends can be had from even a small one. In addition to fresh, succulent vegetables the gardener will have invigorating outdoor exercise, a profitable hobby and the good glow that comes with honest agricultural dirt on the hands and shoes.

GROWING a few dwarf fruit trees on the home property can be a rewarding hobby. Apple and pear trees are most generally planted because they are available on dwarfing roots. Peaches, nectarines and plums also can be grown successfully, either as standard-sized trees or dwarf types, although it is not possible to obtain all varieties on dwarf roots.
John C. Quilty has been appointed general manager of Shell Oil Company's personnel and industrial relations department. He had been manager of the department.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 25 -- A dissident Liberal who is constitutionally barred from running for President next year and a former dictator who is legally forbidden to be in politics are emerging as Colombia's most active men in a potentially explosive political situation.
BONN, Germany -- "Fine boss, the car is okay, your plant looks bearable and if there's a marriageable daughter in the house we can talk about an apprenticeship contract."

DENVER, March 25 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Pipers rallied in the second half tonight to defeat the Denver Truckers, 107 -- 96, in the final of the Amateur Athletic Union national tournament It was the Pipers' first A.A.U. title.
LOS ANGELES, March 25 -- The John Birch Society received Sharp scrutiny and criticism this week in California.

IN "Each Day's Proud Battle," Josephine Winn has avoided those flaws common to many first novelists -- too little story and too few characters. This heavily plotted book has enough characters to populate the state of Alaska.

LOS ANGELES, March 25 (UPI) -- Bob Pettit led the St. Louis Hawks to a 118-117 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers tonight. The victory tied their National Basketball Association Western Division final play-off series at two games apiece.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI) -- The New York Congressional delegation asked President Kennedy today for "an independent, impartial study" of the threatened closing of the Rome (N.Y.) Air Materiel Area (Roama) before any decision was made.
PARIS, March 25 -- Last summer Gastone Nencini, a 30-year old Italian pro, won the Tour de France, the world's longest, most grueling, most important bike race.

THERE are, as Morton N. Cohen points out, two markedly different types of novelist, the teller of a tale and the analyst of character. Of course in the greatest writings of fiction the two purposes are blended, but there are some who remain, and may very successfully remain, in the one category to which they are suited by their capacities and attached by their affections.

PARIS, March 25 -- The Western world has gone through an unusual experience this month. Something approaching disaster threatened and then was averted without more than two or three out of every hundred Americans and Europeans even knowing there was trouble.
LIMA, Peru, March 25 (Reuters) -- Work has started on construction of three new satellite towns designed to accommodate a population of more than 500,000 within a short distance of the capital.

ALBANY, March 25 -- A partisan battle resulted tonight in the killing of bills to add thirty-seven city judgeships and to provide city funds for the Lincoln Center for the Per forming Arts. The Democrats wanted the judgeship bills approved as a condition for supporting a $12,000,000 city investment in Lincoln Center.

LAKE WALES, Fla. -- This small city in south-central Florida, noted for its up-to-date tourist accommodations, will take on the air of a frontier town during the Polk County Centennial this year. Although the county is 100 years old, Lake Wales itself has been in existence only half that time -- fifty years ago there was virtually nothing here but a turpentine still.
WARSAW, March 19 -- Polish statisticians have come up with good news for Government planners trying to provide for fast-growing population and build a modern industrial society, too.
MESSINA, Sicily, March 25 (UPI) -- On Dec. 28, 1908, the earth shuddered and 75,000 people died in this Sicilian city.
ESSEN, Germany, March 25 (AP) -- Alfried Krupp said today that his vast steel and coal empire's total sales climbed 16 per cent to 5,064,000,000 Deutsche marks ($1,266,000,000) in 1960.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 25 -- Belgium will choose national and provincial Legislatures tomorrow in an election brought on a year ahead of schedule by discontent over events the Congo.

DETROIT, March 25 (AP) -- Saying that "we believe Ford's small-small car will soon be rolling along America's streets," the United Automobile Workers has renewed its request for a top-level meeting with the company on its planning.

Frank Rice scored four goals and led Huntington to an 8-6 polo victory aver New Haven last night at the Squadron A Armory. The victory sent the Long Island team to the final of the Eastern Division of the national twelve-goal tournament.

The Outboard Marine Corporation, the parent company of Evinrude and Johnson outboard motors and other products, has developed a new inboard-outboard engine. It will be manufactured at Waukegan, Ill., the main home of the Johnson motors.

Consideration of short-range and long-range problems will occupy the attention of paper wholesalers at the annual meeting of the National Paper Trade Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel this week.

MORE gardeners grow petunias than any other annual. This is true for many reasons -- the wide range of colors in the new hybrids, the masses of bloom on each plant and the length of the flowering season.

THE potential economic and political importance of the current campaign to encourage travel to the United States is widely recognized. GUY Pene du Bois (1884-1958) was the painter-laureate of the nineteen-twenties. WITH the year's first national tournament over -- it ended last Monday at Denver -- the bridge spotlight moves to the 1961 tournament for the world championship, which will be played in Buenos Aires late in April.

Seasonally adjusted man hours worked in the Federal Reserve district dropped one-half of 1 per cent between January and February. The February level was 5.4 per cent below that of February, 1960, and 7.8 per cent below the 1960 peak month in May.

Pied d'Or of the Calumet Farm made up all the ground to win the $25,800 Paumonok handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Trailing his six rivals as they entered the stretch of the six-furlong race, Pied d'Or came on gamely under the urging of John Rotz to lead the favored Winonly across the finish line by a half length.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 25 (AP) -- A 16-year-old school girl pilot was shepherded to a safe landing today by an airliner. When her plane reached the ground it had less than a gallon of gasoline.

NOVEMBER 18, 1776. -- As for our army, God help it! -- for at present it is in a disagreeable state; the militia gone and going home, the time of enlistment for our regular troops expiring, and little or nothing done toward raising new ones.
FORT LEE, N.J. March 25 -- The Palisades Amusement Park, which annually attracts 3,500,000 to 4,000,000 sun seekers between Easter Saturday and mid-September, will open here next Saturday.

UNITED STATES visitors to eastern Canada last summer were able to take advantage of a new duty-free shopping center at Hill Island, between the main spans of the Thousand Islands Bridge near Alexandria Bay, N.Y. Now construction of a second center has begun at Niagara Falls, Ont.

Although the weather late in the month has not been especially cooperative, retailers will chalk up a sizable gain in their March sales compared with those of a year earlier. In the first three weeks of the month department stores registered a gain of 13 per cent.

SEOUL, Korea, March 19 -- Every day in the week Seoul newspapers print the going prices in a trading operation that has become part of the Korean scene and the Korean economy. It is an important and specialized operation and just about as legal as running off counterfeit money in the cellar.

When Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Futterman leased it, they cleared the floor, restoring the open, airy charm that was the hallmark of such rooms fifty years ago.

The retail store sales jump on the basis of an early Easter and abundant consumer buying power continued last week. SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 25 -- Teen-agers all but took over from Olympic veterans today in the men's and women's slalom runs of the Harriman Cup ski races.

Thousands of churchgoers over the city will observe Palm Sunday this morning, the opening of Holy Week.

DUBLIN, March 18 -- A spirit of optimism and confidence unparalleled in recent years has pervaded the Republic of Ireland.
JERSEY CITY, March 25 -- With only one day left for the filing of petitions for the municipal election here next May, it appeared today that the Mayoral race would be a four-way contest.

WASHINGTOH, March 24 -- No issue was closer to the heart of John F. Kennedy, when he was the junior Senator from Massachusetts, than the increase he sought in the Federal minimum wage. In his campaign for the Presidency last fall, he made no pledge more consistently and fervently than his promise to increase the minimum wage to $1.25 and to include millions of workers in its provisions.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 25 -- The rival Congolese regimes of Leopoldville and Stanleyville sought today to strengthen their respective positions in anticipation of conciliation talks.

WARSAW, March 25 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka's careful balancing of the right and left wings of Poland's Communist party is mirrored in the single list of candidates standing for Parliament in next month's general elections.
