WASHINGTON, March 25 -- When the U.S.S. Shark, the Navy's newest and fastest nuclear attack submarine, was diving this week off Norfolk, Va., an argument broke out among the enlisted men in the crew's mess room over what would happen to the reactor if the submarine turned over.

SAN REMO, Italy -- A bit of neighborly cooperation between France and Italy is expected to ease within another year some of the worst traffic bottlenecks on the Riviera. Work is now in progress on an alternate route between the Italian Riviera and the Cote d'Azur.

MIAMI BEACH -- Organized labor has established a new beachhead here in its campaign to provide more social security under the union label. It has opened the first non-profit resort hotel for retired trade unionists, and the early settlers report: "Everything's beautiful. It's God's country."
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., March 25 -- Once again the Wyoming Valley, center of a depressed anthracite area of northeastern Pennsylvania, is tugging at its own bootstraps.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., -- For the first time in its eleven-year history, the Missile Test Center at Cape Canaveral will be open to the public on Armed Forces Day week-end, May 20 and 21. Maj. Gen. Leighton I. Davis, commandant, has issued the invitation with the approval of the Defense Department and the Air Force.
William J. Quinn has been elected a director of REA Express, the new corporate title for the Railway Express Agency. He is president of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad.

" FATHER of the Monitor" is probably the only accomplishment most young people would ascribe to John Ericsson (1803-89). The Swedish-American inventor, however, had an impressive list of credits to his name long before, and after, that ironcled engagement at Hampton Roads, Va. A steam-operated pump for fire engines, caloric and solar engines, the Princeton -- the first metal-hulled, screw-propelled warship, launched eighteen years before the Monitor -- are among those credits.

It's moving day, or soon will be, for New York's billion-dollar banks. Two moves are under way and another is scheduled to begin on May 1. Within two years, all but one of these eight largest banks in the city expect to be in new locations.

ALBANY, March 25 -- The Legislature closed out the 1961 session tonight in an unusually calm and deliberative way. Much of the major legislation had been cleared before the final day, and the proceedings showed it.
KAMPALA, Uganda, March 25 (Reuters) -- The Democratic party seemed certain today of winning this British East African protectorate's first general election, held yesterday.
MADRID -- Spain is the fastest-growing tourist area in Europe, according to Spanish statistics; and, after tourism, statistics seem to be the fastest-growing industry in Spain.

LOS ANGELES, March 25 -- The recent proposal by Bonanza Air Lines to reduce round-trip fares on its jet-prop service from here to Las Vegas has drawn protests from United Air Lines and Trans World Airlines. It is proposed to cut the fare from $42.40 to $26.

MOSCOW, March 25 -- The Soviet Union announced today that it had launched another five-ton space vehicle into orbit around the earth with a dog aboard and had successfully returned it to earth upon command.

Claims for state unemployment compensation declined further to 50,474 in the week ended March 11. This represented the lowest level in five weeks. The net reduction in the last three weeks, which was 2,500, was of moderate seasonal volume, contrasting favorably with the sharp rise of 6,000 in the like weeks of the 1958 recession, but falling short of the 3,300 drop in 1959.
The New York Athletic Club retained its Eastern Amateur Athletic Union wrestling championship with ease last night.

THE employes came out to the conference room looking a little green. A ham-fisted man built with the squat sturdiness of a fireplug followed them into the corridor. He was chuckling as he stopped to pose for photographers.

LISBON, Portugal, March 25 (AP) -- The Lusitania News Agency said today that Portuguese authorities had captured fourteen members of a revolutionary group planning to set up an independent government in Angola.
LIMA, Peru, March 26 -- Gen. Manuel A. Odria, former President of Peru, arrived in Lima today after a five-year absence.
ALGIERS, March 26 (AP) -- Moslem and Right-Wing terrorists struck throughout Algeria over the week-end. At least five persons were killed and thirty wounded in the violence.

Churchgoers over the world reverently observed Palm Sunday yesterday, the beginning of the holiest week in the Christian year. Millions of worshipers in vast cathedrals and crossroads churches paid solemn tribute to their Messiah, whose palm-strewn triumphal entry into Jerusalem began the drama that culminated in His death on the Cross and His Resurrection.
Federal Housing Administrator Robert C. Weaver announced yesterday plans to unify the policies of three Government agencies dealing with housing for the aged.
TEANECK, N.J., March 26 -- World records, rare in any sport, almost never occur in dog shows, but one was set tonight.

Another book about President John F. Kennedy and his Administration has been announced for publication. It will be "Let Us Begin: John F. Kennedy's First Hundred Days," by Mark Sherwin of The New York Post and Charles L. Markmann of The Daily News, which St. Martin's Press will issue in late August.
ALBANY, March 26 -- Before adjourning last night, the Legislature voted more than $3,000,000 for thirty-eight joint committees to study everything from excessive drinking to school financing.

LONDON, March 26 -- President Kennedy said in an interview telecast today that the United States and Britain will not have any difficulties in a missile race with the Soviet Union if it were not for the law that neither democracy will ever strike first.
ALBANY, March 26 -- Governor Rockefeller flew to Puerto Rico today for a week's vacation, leaving his desk piled high with the accomplishments and burdens of the 1961 legislative session.
DETROIT, March 26 (UPI) -- Gordie Howe and Val Fonteyne scored third-period goals tonight as the Detroit Red Wings beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 -- 0.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 26 (AP) -- The police turned fire hoses on a rioting crowd of about 3,500 vacationing college students tonight.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $78,731,666,909. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:

President Kennedy's quick visit to confer with Prime Minister Macmillan at Key West yesterday was another example of the energy and decisiveness with which he has acted during recent weeks to cope with the Laos crisis.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Monday, March 27 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk declared today that the nations of the free world were obligated to help the peoples of Southeast Asia resist Communist aggression.
LONDON, March 26 -- Before the crisis over Laos came to its head, the stock market experienced another upward move and last Tuesday came within half an index point of touching the historic high.

Union stereotypers on the city's daily newspapers yesterday unanimously ratified a new two-year contract that contains the same basic $7 weekly package increase accepted by other craft unions on the papers.
Cambridge University Press and Oxford University Press, publishers of the two-week-old New English Bible (New Testament), announced plans yesterday to print nearly 1,000,000 more copies.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 26 (AP) -- Louise Suggs of Sea Island, Ga., withstood a rally by Mickey Wright today for a two-stroke victory in the $7,500 Bradenton women's open golf tournament. Miss Suggs scored 293 in the 72-hole tourney.
Five farmers from the Blue Ridge Mountains brought a ripe harvest of traditional music to the city Saturday night.
Foreign exchange market was active during the past week. The trend was generally lower with the British pound sterling, Canadian dollar and other currencies showing losses.

"IS there a Vera?" This question, which has been asked frequently in the table linen, scarf and blouse departments of department stores, was answered in the affirmative the other morning as Vera Neumann offered visitors a mid-morning cup of coffee in her 1810 studio at Ossining.
Cardinal Spellman presided yesterday morning at the ceremonial Blessing of the Palms in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

MAD RIVER GLEN, Vt., March 26 -- John Clough of Middlebury College led a field of 110 skiers today in the New England Kandahar. His time over the mile-and-quarter giant-slalom course with fifty-two gates was 2 minutes 24 seconds.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Supreme Court threw new light last week on an old doctrine -- the rule that confessions extracted from criminal defendants by police coercion may not be used in evidence against them.

A GOOD cook who really knows her onions always has that vegetable on hand. Few recipes except those for dessert do not call for the use of onion as a seasoning. Right now onions can be employed with a lavish hand, for the supply is exceptionally good.
Mayor Wagner charged yesterday that at least six city programs had been unjustifiably rejected by the Republican-dominated Legislature. He called for a special session to reconsider the measures.
Non-agricultural employment in the Middle Atlantic region dropped by 385,900 in January to a total of 11,473,000, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, March 26 -- Steel producers are still waiting for their recovery to move up to the next stage.
ATLANTA, March 26 -- Bob Burdick, a 23-year-old driver from Omaha, won the second annual 500-mile late-model stock car race today on Atlanta's International Speedway.
The Citizens Housing and Planning Council announced yesterday it would support Mayor Wagner's proposal for a survey of fourteen blocks in west Greenwich Village for possible urban renewal.
MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, B.W.I., March 26 -- Escapade, one of the great names in international yachting, today became the winner of the 807-mile Miami-to-Montego-Bay race.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 26 (UPI) -- Barbara Ferries of Aspen, Colo., and Bud Werner of the University of Colorado won first-place honors today in the Harriman Cup women's and men's downhill skiing competition on Baldy Mountain.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- Justice Department officials said today that new damage suits were planned against electrical concerns that engaged in price-fixing on Government contracts.

The aluminum industry's serious overcapacity problem is unlikely to change in the near future, Nathanael V. Davis, President of Aluminium, Limited, noted in the company's annual report released yesterday.
South Africa walked out, Cuba warned of the danger of invasion, the Soviet Union congratulated Cuba and the United States was ruled out of order at a mock United Nations session here yesterday.

The New York Legislature made its usual bad impression in the feverish last-week rush to adjourn, but the 1961 session's record of accomplishment is reasonably satisfactory. There were some serious disappointments, of course.
THE musical sophistication that the Colby College Concert Choir has shown in previous programs presented in this city was apparent again in its concert in Carnegie Recital Hall Saturday night.

There will soon be presented to the City Planning Commission and to the Board of Estimate for approval the final plan for the West Side Urban Renewal Project, covering a twenty-square-block area from Eighty-seventh through Ninety-seventh Street from Central Park West to the east side of Amsterdam Avenue.

Roma Pryma made her New York debut yesterday afternoon at Town Hall in a program of "Dances and Characters of the Ukraine." It consisted, however, not of traditional dances but of Miss Pryma's own compositions staling with Ukrainian legend and lore.
A PRE-EASTER drama of deep reverence and great power was presented on television last night in "Give Us Barabbas!," by Henry Denker.

Chief Justice Earl Warren said yesterday the United States had to achieve "new high levels of excellence" in every field of human endeavor to win the competition for the minds of the world's uncommitted peoples.

The bid of a group of public-spirited citizens to purchase television station WNTA-TV for a noncommercial educational video outlet enjoys the strong moral support of Newton N. Minow, new chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 26 -- The cycle of seasons that governs the lives of farmers has come round again to seed-potato-cutting time for Long Island's 650 potato farmers -- but with a difference that gets bigger every year.

ALBANY, March 26 -- The judgeship imbroglio that enlivened the closing hours of this year's legislative session could have important political repercussions for both Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 26 -- On a back street just south of Hollywood, the movies' first cowboy, Broncho Billy Anderson, is quietly riding out the string in a wheelchair.

MADRID, March 26 (Reuters) -- Representative of Spanish workers and employers have presented to Generalissimo Francisco Franco a plan for the national economic development of Spain during the next fifteen years.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday he would propose $21,000,000 in salary increases and additional take-home pay for the city's school and college teachers in his 1961-62 expense budget.

Worsteds will again be the most popular suit fabrics for boys and students next fall, according to a survey released over the week-end by the Boys' Apparel Buyers Association and the Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A.
The Right Reverend Horace W.B. Donegan, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New York, was the celebrant yesterday at the Palm Sunday service in the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.
CHICAGO, March 25 -- A group of Chicago businessmen will leave on May 5 on a trade mission flight sponsored by the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry to Central and South America.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy, after a week-end in the Virginia hunt country leaves tomorrow with her two children for a vacation in Palm Beach, Fla.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- A general said today that Soviet combat troops' supply of modern tanks, helicopters and other new weapons might exceed those of the United States Army by four or five times.

The Rochester Telephone Corporation is issuing rights to its common stockholders to subscribe at $24.25 a share for 273,437 additional common shares at the rate of one share for each five held of record on March 24. The offering will expire on April 10.
PHILADELPHIA, March 24 (UPI) -- W. S. Heil, vice president and controller of Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company, Bethlehem, Pa., has resigned effective on March 27, the company announced today.

Four eighteenth-century works and one from the twentieth century made up the substance of Saturday night's Music Forgotten and Remembered concert directed by Frederic Waldman at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum.

CHICAGO, March 26 (AP) -- Soybean futures posted some of their best advances in a month last week, but the grains, without any sustaining influences, drifted along without showing any significant trend.

Once again United Cerebral Palsy is appealing to the New York community. Thousands of volunteers are ringing doorbells in the eleventh annual Citizens' Parade for Cerebral Palsy throughout Brooklyn, the Bronx and Manhattan to seek contributions from their friends.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 26 -- Nearly 200 demonstrators, carrying signs calling for worldwide disarmament, walked through the main streets here today on the second leg of a nine-day march to the United Nations Plaza in New York.

Senator Jacob K. Javits called on the United States yesterday to help correct an "arms imbalance" confronting Israel because of the Soviet Union's "huge shipments of modern arms" to the United Arab Republic and Iraq.

MUSSORGSKY'S "Boris Godunov," one of the most compelling, though episodic, of all operatic works, was brought to the television screen yesterday afternoon by the resourceful and still pioneering N.B.C. Opera Company.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg announced today that he would ask Congress to upgrade the head of the Women's Bureau to the rank of Assistant Secretary of Labor.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- President Kennedy may receive from Premier Khrushchev tomorrow the answer to whether the Western powers will have to intervene militarily in Laos.

MOSCOW, March 26 -- Moscow's Minister of Merchant Marine has sailed to hand over to the feudal ruler of Yemen, Imam Ahmad, the facilities of a new Soviet-built port at the city of Hodeida on the Red Sea. The port has been named Ahmadi in honor of the Imam.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will start work this week on a bill to expand one of this country's most successful postwar programs for the creation of international understanding and good will.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 20 -- Rumania's Communist rulers have steered clear of the more spectacular farm collectivization methods of some of their Soviet-bloc neighbors. But slowly the Rumanians have widened the socialized area of their nation's agriculture.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 26 -- The General Assembly's Budgetary Committee will take up this week the most acute financial problem the United Nations has ever faced -- that of raising the $120,000,000 needed to maintain the United Nations force in the Congo in 1961.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- As a spur to business recovery the Administration is considering a cut in interest rates on small business loans channeled through local development companies in depressed areas.

IT is common knowledge that the use of make-up is ages old but how many cosmetic concerns can trace their beginnings to the fourteenth century? One that can is Jon Pierre, which opens its new salon today at Lord Taylor.
Six new films are scheduled to arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:
The University of Cincinnati, which couldn't win the National Collegiate basketball championship with the great Oscar Robertson, has won it without him.
FIVE first performances of the season were to be found on the week-end programs by the New York City Ballet at the City Center.
To survive defeat is a real achievement, but to survive victories "is even harder," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman warned yesterday.

An office and warehouse building and twenty-three acres of land in Newark, Ohio, have been purchased by Jack Resnick, a New York realty investor. The Brener Lewis Company of New York was the broker. The property was sold for a reported price of $1,385,000.

The Socialist Labor party's annual state convention protested efforts to end the equal-time rule for speeches on radio and television during campaigns. Congress temporarily suspended the provision last year for Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates.

DINAH SHORE'S career as a popular singer has been distinguished by intuitive naturalness and quiet charm. Last night these qualities stood her in good stead as she successfully performed in her first full-length dramatic role on television.
Mikhail Tal of Latvia and Mikhail Botvinnik of Moscow played at their best in the fifth game of their twenty-five-game series for the world chess championship.

BUENOS AIRES, March 26 -- Lieut. Gen. Carlos Toranzo Montero, who resigned last week as commander in chief of the army, asserted in a letter made public today the army's right to demand reforms by the Government.
PARIS, March 26 -- Italy was taken to court last week in a new venture in international law.
NEW DELHI, India, March 26 -- Plans for a United States Peace Corps have been received in India with widespread interest and considerable hope but also with distinct caution.
TAMPA, Fla., March 26 -- The Yankees score a sparkling 6-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today. But the afternoon was not an altogether pleasant one for Manager Ralph Houk.
Researchers at Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia have found sufficient nickel in cigarette smoke to lead them to believe that metal may produce lung cancer in smokers.
A.G. Edwards Sons and associates are offering to the public today securities of the Jefferson Lake Asbestos Corporation in units priced it $80 each.
Mozart's "Don Giovani" was given its final performance of the season by the Metropolitan Opera Saturday night, but there was certainly no end-of-season pall over the proceedings.

"Never sign a blank income tax return." That is the latest word from the Internal Revenue Service, which is concerned about the fact that a few dishonest tax practitioners have been victimizing their clients.
Joan Wall, mezzo-soprano, usually gets to sing only small parts at the Metropolitan Opera. But last night at Town Hall she had a whole evening to show why she should get big parts.
HOBOKEN, N.J., March 26 (AP) -- A motor no bigger than a human thumb may provide the answer to maneuvering satellites in outer space, Stevens Institute of Technology said today.
One of the most irritating and, in a sense, damaging aspect of the advertising business is a preoccupation with accounts lost, accounts gained and rumors of accounts lost accounts gained.

The Greyhound Corporation will take this year delivery of 255 Scenicruiser buses, powered for the first time in the company's history by V-8 diesel engines, F.W. Ackerman, president, announced. A cash payment of $11,900,000 will be made for these buses and for ten transit buses that Greyhound will acquire in 1961, he said.
THE President of Yeshiva University likes to describe himself as "a rabbi who doesn't preach, a doctor who doesn't cure and a professor who doesn't teach."

In his column of March 19, James Reston with more charm than persuasiveness criticizes the decision of the Administration to vote for the Angola resolution before the United Nations Security Council. According to Mr. Reston, the Administration in its youthful exuberance got its priorities mixed and forgot that strengthening the Atlantic alliance is really task Number One.
ALBANY, March 26 -- Following is a summary of the more important actions taken by the 1961 session of the Legislature:
Net income of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., in 1960 rose to $5,151,728, or $1.81 a common share, from $4,809,798, or $1.69 a share, in 1959, the textile concern reported yesterday.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 26 -- Delegates to the biggest political meeting of Africans ever held in South Africa decided today to form an organization to fill the gap left when the Government banned their two political parties.
MEXICO CITY, March 26 (AP) -- Twenty-five lead-producing countries agreed over the week-end to reduce lead stocks to a level of about 2 per cent below estimated 1961 world consumption.
The twenty-seventh annual appeal of the American Merchant Marine Library Association has been announced.
The owners of the two-story bank building on North Village Avenue off Sunrise Highway, Rockville Centre, L. I., have announced plans for converting it to general office use.
BOSTON, March 26 (UPI) -- The Boston Celtics won the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division playoffs today with a 123-101 victory over the Syracuse Nationals.
Girl bell-ringers greeted Palm Sunday worshipers yesterday on the steps of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at Ninety-first Street.

VIENTIANE, Laos, March 26 -- A wounded prisoner who was captured in a recent clash with Government troops has admitted in a Vientiane hospital that he was a member of a regular Vietnamese Communist unit operating in Laotian territory.
CAIRO, March 26 -- This capital is the hunting ground of two international groups that began this week-end to pursue influence and friends by sharply contrasting methods.

Now that the human effects of rapidly increasing automation have become a primary American concern, every well-conceived effort to cushion the employment shocks attracts nation-wide attention. Such a one is now getting a test in Oklahoma City. The antiquated Armour Co. meat packing plant there was closed last July and its operations were transferred to the company's more highly automated and efficient plants elsewhere.
Four operas will be given final performances in the penultimate week of the Metropolitan Opera's New York season.

The opportunity to obtain an educational television station in New York City, supported in your excellent editorial of March 24, must not be lost. I hope there will be such an overwhelming public demand for it that the Federal Communications Commission will become convinced that it would not be in the public interest to transfer the license to anyone else.
NEW ORLEANS, March 26 (UPI) -- Jack Nicklaus of Ohio State defeated Jim Key of Columbus, Ga., 4 and 3, today to take the Western amateur golf tournament.

Dr. John R. Heller, president of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Center, said yesterday the cost of bio-chemical laboratory research had risen about 2,000 per cent in the last few years. He said cancer could be conquered if sufficient money and research were applied to finding its cause.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 26 -- The Socialist party scored some gains in early returns from today's election, in which nearly 6,000,000 Belgians cast ballots for the national Parliament and provincial assemblies.

It is too bad that the delegates to the forthcoming centennial of the first Confederate shell fired at Fort Sumter cannot meet and be lodged in the battered and time-worn fort itself. However, the segregation issue which has stirred up half-forgotten -- and better forgotten -- memories has been compromised by the decision to meet, dine and lodge some or all of the delegates at the nonsegregated Charleston Naval Station.
Trading in the over-the-counter market last week continued at a hectic pace for the second week in a row.

The issue of church and state, though currently a key question in the debate over Federal aid to education, is by no means an American phenomenon. The problem of public support for non-public education has had to be faced in the policy decisions on school financing and control in many nations, including those with greater religious homogeneity than the United States.

PARIS, March 26 -- The Algerian provincial Government, which claims to represent the Algerian people, was indirectly informed today that France intended to consult with other political elements on methods of deciding Algeria's political future.

SOUTH BOSTON, Va., March 26 (AP) -- The chairman of the National Civil War Centennial Commission's executive committee tee said today he was opposed to a compromise decision changing the meeting place of the organization's national assembly to the Charleston (S.C.) Naval Station.
The last ship of a famous intercoastal passenger fleet, the Grace liner Santa Paula, has been sold to foreign interests and will be removed from United States registry.

CHICAGO, March 26 (AP) -- Tornadoes struck along a squall line extending from Texas to Kansas today. They destroyed several homes and buildings, damaged others and tore up power and communications in several communities.

CHICAGO, March 27 (UPI) -- Murray Balfour scored his second goal of the game after 12:12 minutes of a third sudden-death overtime period to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to a 2-1 victory over the Montreal Canadiens. The triumph gave the Hawks a 2-1 lead in the National Hockey League Stanley Cup semi-final play-off series.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Inter-American Development Bank today announced a $3,000,000 loan to the National Development Bank of Paraguay.

THE team that will represent this country -- in fact, the North American continent -- in the next world championship matches, watch begin April 15 in Buenos Aires, will have some intensive practice this week-end in New York.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 26 -- Six experts proposed today an international "development loan fund" to sustain primary producing countries suffering from wide fluctuations in proceeds from their commodity exports.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Pentagon is planning to combine Air Force fleets of fighter planes and transport airliners with Army paratrooper and reserve infantry units into a single new command under an Army general.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 26 -- President Kennedy and Prime Minister Macmillan reached "absolute agreement" today at all aspects of a common power to preserve a truly neutral Law against threats of Communist domination.

An artist who spirited his 5-year-old daughter from a Connecticut hospital where she had been a patient for a year said yesterday he had acted because she had asked if she could see her sister and two brothers.

HONG KONG, March 26 -- The wife of a critically ill American held prisoner by Communist China flew into Hong Kong today with the hope that she would be able to effect his release when she visits him this week.
ALBANY, March 26 -- Three Constitutional amendments involving the extension of $650,000,000 in state credit will be submitted to a vote next November.
GENEVA, March 26 -- An irregular trend predominated on the Swiss stock markets last week, with a tendency toward a consolidation of prices that shifted to a wide retreat on the last day of trading.
MIAMI BEACH, March 26 (AP) -- Gary Player won the $25,000 Sunshine open golf tournament today with a 72-hole 273. Arnold Palmer was second by a stroke.
A scheme for changing the atmosphere of Venus to make that planet habitable for humans has been suggested by an astrophysicist.

The following table gives the amount of dealings in the stocks from which the averages are computed, the combined trading in both classes of issues, as well as the total -- transactions for week and month:
An indoor preview of Easter lilies, daffodils and azaleas greeted yesterday's visitors to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden and the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The American Civil Liberties Union said today that Federal loans to church schools would violate the Constitution.
KEY WEST, Fla., March, 26 -- Following is the text of a joint communique issued today following a conference here between President Kennedy and Prime Minister Macmillan:
"There is no substitute for life insurance when it comes to providing death protection. "Life insurance is not the best way either to save or invest money."

As another season on Broadway draws to a close, theatregoers and critics alike can be heard in all quarters bemoaning the state of contemporary American drama. Some look back longingly at the products of yesteryear; others probe in search of basic causes on which to base their remedial prescriptions.

"An Omnibus of American Song," which was seen yesterday afternoon over Channel 4, was a sixty-minute medley of songs of the last century or so, hardly a very demanding assignment for a program accustomed to charting new horizons in television.

The Petroleum Stabilization Bill now being considered by the Philippine Congress is being watched with keen interest by the world oil industry. If enacted, the law would limit imports of crude oil and petroleum products by foreign-owned companies into the Philippines, but would permit unrestricted imports by companies in which Philippine citizens hold interests of 60 per cent or more.

Prices of cotton futures eased generally last week. Although active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ended the week up 6 points to down 8 points from the previous Friday, the only gain was recorded for the October delivery.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- President Kennedy, back from a conference with Prime Minister Macmillan on the Laos crisis, received a message tonight from President de Gaulle on the same matter.
The merger or centralization of the separate intelligence services of the armed forces, now under study in the Pentagon, offers seeming advantages but at the risk of major dangers.
The Republic of Panama has protested to the Kennedy Administration a recent National Labor Relations Board decision to assume jurisdiction in labor disputes on certain foreign-flag ships.
Eastern News Distributors, Inc., has bought the three-story office building at 253-55 Seventh Avenue, between Twenty-fourth and Twenty-fifth Streets.

"Moby Dick" will be performed as a monodrama by Philip Hanson. Adapted and directed by Mr. Hanson, the offering will be introduced by John Lotas on April 10 at the Madison Avenue Playhouse, 120Madison Avenue at Thirty-first Street.
WOULD you like to know what might constitute important, interesting and substantial violin fare of the last ten years or so?

The Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut offered a list of fourteen names yesterday for consideration for the Federal bench if, as proposed, eleven new judgeships are created in the region.
Senator Kenneth B. Keating said yesterday that John Hay Whitney "must definitely be considered" as a possible Republican-Fusion candidate for Mayor.
CHICAGO, March 26 (AP) -- Fansteel Metallurgical Corpora tion of suburban North Chicago and Wesson Tool Company of Detroit said Fansteel had contracted to acquire Wesson for $6,300,000.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, March 23 -- United States, Canadian, French, British, Australian and New Zealand airlines are closely affected by pending changes in the South Pacific. They mark a further stage in sharp exchanges over reciprocal rights.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 26 -- The Congolese central Government declared its willingness today to "examine" a United Nations plan for replacing Belgian technicians in the Congolese administration.
SEBRING, Fla., March 26 (UPI) -- Phil Hill and Olivier Gendebien split $1,500 in prize money today for winning the Sebring twelve-hour endurance race for sports cars in a Ferrari.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26 -- The experts are generally agreed that the slickest-fielding third baseman in the American League is young Brooks Robinson of the Orioles. One vehement dissenter, however, is Brooks Robinson himself.

In your editorial of March 16 regarding parking garages in central Manhattan, proposed by Traffic Commissioner Wiley and vetoed by the City Planning Commission, you comment on the worsening traffic congestion in New York City.

CAIRO, March 26 -- Since Mr. Williams' African tour and our Security Council vote on Angola there is a general impression that Washington has suddenly evolved a brand-new African policy. President Kennedy's Administration is taking a far keener interest in Africa than any of its predecessors, but this results largely from historical necessity.
MOSCOW, March 26 (UPI) -- Space news was dominant today as speculation mounted that the next Soviet space traveler would be a man.
CINCINNATI, March 26 (UPI) -- The Cincinnati basketball team came back today to a roaring two-hour celebration of its National Collegiate championship.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- In an article last week about the President's therapeutic use of the rocking chair for exercise, Dr. Janet G. Travell, the White House physician, was quoted as having said that anyone interested in buying one like Mr. Kennedy's could write to her for the manufacturer's name.

Children from three Protestant churches ate matzohs and drank grape juice yesterday with young students of the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue's religious school at an interfaith and interracial model Sedar.

BELA SZILAGI, who was one of the three Leventritt finalists who played off in Carnegie Hall last October for a prize that was never awarded, gave his first New York recital late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.

The scheduled airlines of the International Air Transport Association carried 1,919,750 passengers over North Atlantic routes in 1960, an increase of 24.7 per cent from 1959. Cargo increased 28.7 pert cent to 51,651 short tons and mail 28.9 per cent to 17,755 tons.
TUNIS, March 27 -- The long-awaited talks on Algeria will begin April 7 in Evian-les-Bains, on the French side of the French-Swiss border.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI) -- The United States and the Philippines signed an agreement today setting a longstanding financial dispute.
The sixth game of the World chess championship in Moscow between Mikhail Tal of Latvia and Mikhail Botvinnik of the Soviet Union ended in a draw yesterday after twenty-five moves.
NEW DELHI, India, March 27 -- The population of India was officially estimated today at 438,000,000, which represents an increase of about 21.5 per cent in the last ten years.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The State Department reported today that the United States C-47 transport plane missing in Laos since Thursday had been shot down by rebel ground fire. One of its eight passengers survived the crash, the State Department said.
The Irving Trust Company has promoted Fred E. Borchert Jr. and Edward C. Rogers to vice presidencies, it was announced yesterday.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 27 -- The right of the Saddle Brook Township Committee to establish a municipal authority to own and operate the water and sewer system was upheld today in Superior Court here.
Brooklyn College has resigned from the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference and will be replaced by Iona College of New Rochelle, N.Y., at the close of the 1961 season.

The creation of a huge national research library that scholars would consult by an automatic long distance dial system was proposed yesterday by the chairman of the mathematics department of Dartmouth College.

AN extra coat for the country and week-ends in town is a great addition to a wardrobe. Macy's has such a find in burlap at $25 on the third floor. Tapered wide from a narrow shoulder, it has low, deep pockets, an over-sized Peter Pan collar and three big wooden buttons.
DETROIT, March 27 (AP) -- This week brings an end to the auto industry's slowest first quarter production since 1952.
Directors of the General Fireproofing Company have elected Alfred J. Ball president and chief executive officer, it was announced yesterday.

Events tonight: "Don Carlo," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, conductor, Isaac Stern, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Maya Hoffman, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Giuseppe Anedda, mandolinist, assisted by Marcel Frank, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
Net income of The Times-Mirror Company declined last year despite a sharp increase in revenues, Norman Chandler president, disclosed in the annual report issued yesterday.
Teachers and school administrators here are seeking ways to solve reading problems that were pointed up in a report last week.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 27 -- United Nations headquarters announced today the creation a "neutral zone" at one of the three major border crossing points between the Congo and Ruanda-Urundi.
A near sellout crowd of 18,156 that paid ,$55,561.54 watched Vittorio (Argentina) Apollo and Buddy Rogers wrestle to a draw at Madison Square Garden last night.

A group of younger members of society under the direction of Peter Monroe Smith have arranged a "dusk to dawn" dance, to be held at the River Club on Saturday. It will be followed by a pink champagne Easter morning breakfast at the Embassy Club of the Sheraton-East.
AKRON, Ohio, March 27 (UPI) -- The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, announced today that agreement was reached to purchase the Dayco Corporation tire division in Dayton, Ohio.

Earnings of the Minerals Chemicals Philipp Corporation rose in 1960 to $8,712,862, or $1.65 a share, from $8,412,894, or $1.60 a share, a year earlier, the Menlo Park, N.J., company announced yesterday. Net income before taxes rose to $13,559,717 from $12,989,822 in 1959.

COLUMBIA, S.C., March 27 (AP) -- Magistrate Frank Powell today found 136 Negroes and one white youth guilty of breach of the peace in a mass trial arising from a Negro anti-segregation march on the state capital three weeks ago.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- President Kennedy was urged today by Congressmen from textile states to impose textile import quotas by country and category of products.
TRENTON, March 27 -- The Legislature today approved a bill to assure 150,000 New Jersey residents employed in New York the same state income tax deductions New York grants to its residents.
Herman F. Marks, former executioner for Fidel Castro's forces, testified yesterday that he had never renounced his United States citizenship or taken an oath of allegiance to Cuba.

TRENTON, March 27 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner blamed Governor Rockefeller of New York today for the bi-state stalemate over legislation that would permit the Port of New York Authority to undertake two new projects.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 27 -- Premier Gaston Eyskens resigned today after election returns showed considerable losses for his Christian Social party, even though it remained the nation's dominant political group.
LONDON, March 27 (Reuters) -- Leicester City defeated Sheffield United, 2 -- 0, at Birmingham tonight and advanced to the English Football Association Cup final.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Douglas Dillon, Secretary of the Treasury, said today that the United States "is entirely satisfied" with the extent of West Germany's revaluation of the Deutsche mark earlier this month.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Supreme Court struck down today an unusual Georgia rule that provides that a criminal defendant may not be questioned by his own lawyer at trial.

Winners of the fifteenth annual Tony Awards will be announced April 16 at the American Theatre Wing's dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria. Emblematic of "distinguished achievement" on the Broadway stage, the Tony is a solid silver medallion, named in memory of Antoinette Perry, the wing's wartime chairman.
Chance Vought Corporation and Ling-Temco Electronics, Inc., have been holding talks, which presumably could lead to a merger, it was reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Rules Committee sent to the House floor today the Kennedy Administration's bill to rehabilitate depressed areas.

IN the opening scene of "Cool Wind Over the Living," the current production on Channel 13's "The Play of the Week," a young couple are reclining on the floor of a cluttered New York flat. The jets on the kitchen gas stove are open.
PARIS, March 27 -- France will lift almost all of her last remaining quotas on imports early next month at the same time that cuts in tariff go into effect.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 27 (AP) -- A former City Commissioner, Clyde Sellers, filed suit today against The New York Times and four Negro ministers for $500,000.

A stockholder's suit seeking dissolution of the Jacob Ruppert brewing company was dismissed yesterday in State Supreme Court. Justice Edgar J. Nathan Jr. ruled that the plaintiff had failed to prove his case.

ST. LOUIS, March 27 (AP) -Walt Bellamy of Indiana and Tom Stith of St. Bonaventure were the first two choices in the National Basketball Association draft today. Then the lesser-known players took the spotlight.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Senate granted the Development Loan Fund today the $150,000,000 denied it by the House of Representatives earlier this month for operations through June 30.
Eleven men are the right number for a football squad, but scarcely enough to move a walrus, the Coney Island Aquarium found yesterday.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad March 27 (Reuters) -- Echoes of President Kennedy's inauguration address were detected in a speech by Prime Minister Macmillan today. He had his first meeting with the President yesterday in Key West, Fla.

The Murchison brothers of Dallas, Tex., who have started a proxy contest for control of the Alleghany Corporation, holding company, yesterday charged Allan P. Kirby, Alleghany's chairman,, with "an utter, lack of appreciation" of the functions and a "surprising ignorance" of the operations of the company's principal asset.
The sale of wine in France might seem, at first glance, to be an activity completely immune to American marketing methods.
The Park Department is cracking down on itinerant troubadours in Washington Square Park.
CHICAGO, March 27 -- A commuters' group, for the second time in a year, asked a fare increase today to prevent the Chicago North Shore and Milwaukee Railway from going out of business.

The six-building complex at Madison Avenue and Forty second Street, vacated by the Union Carbide Corporation when it moved into its new skyscraper at 270 Park Avenue, has been sold to Koeppel Koeppel Inc., real estate concern.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The House Ways and Means Committee approved today a scaled-down version of President Kennedy's plan for higher Social Security benefits. Its approval included optional retirement for male workers at the age of 62.
IN FAIRNESS to Edward R. Murrow, director of the United States Information Agency, there is more to the story of "Harvest of Shame" that now can and should be told.

Dr. Leo Szilard, Professor of Biophysics at the University of Chicago, was among the first to conceive of the possibility of an atomic chain reaction. In 1959 he shared the Atoms-for-Peace Award with Prof. E.P. Wigner. In a forthcoming book, "The Voice of the Dolphins," Dr. Szilard tells five stories of the world of tomorrow, satirizing the political dilemmas of this century.
No decision has been reached concerning a stock split by the Hershey Chocolate Company, but indications of the possibility of such a move were given at the annual meeting yesterday in Hershey, Pa.

BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, March 27 (AP) -- Some 2,000 students at Bowling Green State University staged demonstrations tonight through this city's downtown business district. They later agreed to boycott classes until their grievances were adjusted.
PHILADELPHIA, March 27 -- The American Association of School Administrators was told today that the nation's schools were failing in a basic job.

Improvements in school bus service, which would more than double its present cost, have been proposed or considered by school principals taking part in a Board of Education survey of pupil transportation.

Steel output in the United States last week showed its first signficant improvement in five weeks. Production of raw steel climbed to 1,611,000 tons from 1,574,000 a week earlier, according to figures released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

JERSEY CITY, March 27 -- The Jersey City Association for the Separation of Church and State was refused today on a request for an order enjoining Jersey, City from constructing an endocrine laboratory in the Jersey City Medical Center.
JACKSON, Miss., March 27 (UPI) -- Nine young Negroes staged the first "sit-in" demonstration in Mississippi's capital city today. They were arrested.
A man whose first conviction had been upset because of police brutality was given a reduced sentence yesterday in the slaying of a patrolman ten years ago.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 27 -- Kaiser Bauxite Company has been awarded a contract to supply the United States Government with 400,000 tons of bauxite for stockpiling.

Investment advisory services and market letters appeared to be the strongest influences on yesterday's stock market. For the most part, prices milled about, for investors were uncertain of the outcome of the crisis in Laos.

The Humble Oil and Refining Company, domestic affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), announced yesterday the acquisition of the service station business of the Sun Flash Oil Company, Columbus, Ohio. Sun Flash operates twelve service stations in Ohio.

Although the situation in Laos remains fluid and subject to sudden change, there is rising hope that the conflict in and over this strife-torn kingdom can be settled by peaceful means and without the threatened head-on clash between the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization and the Communist bloc.
CHICAGO, March 27 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

LUTECE was the original name of Paris. It also is the name of a recently opened restaurant in Manhattan that is at once impressively elegant and conspicuously expensive. The Lutece is at 249 East Fiftieth Street.

In his recent housing message President Kennedy indicated that he would propose a new Cabinet-rank department on housing and urban affairs. Since more than half of the country's population is now congregated in 168 metropolitan areas, the urgent need for such a department is compellingly clear.
ST. LOUIS, March 27 (AP) -- Robert Tomarchin was denied probation and sentenced to two years in prison today for stealing Mr. Moke, a talented chimpanzee, from the St. Louis Zoo in December, 1959.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The space agency will soon open a significant new chapter in the science of astronomy by using a satellite to peer into unexplored regions of the universe.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- President Kennedy will ask Congress to appropriate 10 per cent more than President Eisenhower requested for the space program next year and almost twice as much as he asked for Federal aid to airport construction.

Magistrate Samuel Ohringer ruled here yesterday that it was in the American tradition to express one's reaction to a political speech by booing and that the intensity of the disapproval did not militate against the ideal.

ANDOVER, Me., March 27 (AP) -- A field engineer said today that Andover had been chosen as the site of a $7,000,000 ground station for American Telephone and Telegraph Company's satellite communication tests.

New York City has borrowed $25,000,000 on tax anticipation notes due on May 6 at an interest rate of 2 per cent, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said yesterday. The notes are dated March 29 and are subject to prepayment on and after April 28.
WESTFIELD, N.J., March 27 -- New Jersey plans to increase its subsidy to railroads by about 10 per cent to provide essential commuter service for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

In Illinois it looks as if the big banks might not fare as well with branch banking as banks in New York have. The Illinois Bankers Association announced yesterday a vigorous campaign against "onslaughts of two giant Chicago Loop banks" trying to legalize branch banking.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court granted a hearing today to Robert Shelton, a copy editor on The New York Times, convicted of contempt in 1957 for refusing to tell a Senate hearing whether he was a Communist.

RED BANK, N.J., March 27 -- The 173-mile Garden State Parkway had the lowest traffic fatality rate among the major toll highways of the nation during 1960, the New Jersey Highway Authority, operator of the parkway, reported today.
Commodity futures prices staged a broad decline on New York exchanges yesterday. Trading was brisk in most cases and only three commodities managed to go against the downward trend.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Treasury's short-term bill rates jumped upward again on today's sale of the regular weekly issues, after falling for three weeks. The apparent explanation was the additional short-term borrowing that the Treasury is doing at this time.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 27 -- Notwithstanding the almost hourly cries of film producers that they are ushering in the millennium, the undertaking of something really unusual in Hollywood is more than unusual.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- A "fact sheet" on guerrilla tactics made available at the Pentagon today stresses that the Army would train foreign military personnel rather than assume the burden of guerrilla warfare.

Burton N. Pugach, the disbarred lawyer awaiting trial on charges of throwing lye into the face of a former fiancee, obtained an order yesterday requiring a United States Attorney to show cause why a judge, a district attorney and a police lieutenant should not be arrested and prosecuted.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 27 -- Ghana called today for United Nations support in isolating South Africa until she changed her "inhuman" racial policies.

NEW DELHI, India, March 27 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today that he saw a "marked change" in the United States' approach to world affairs. He said he hoped this would produce "good results."
Because two young salesmen joined forces just fifty years ago with a few dollars and an idea, more than 85,000,000 women each year find it easier to combine a trip to the beauty salon with shopping.

LISBON, Portugal, March 27 -- A mob of 20,000 Portuguese stoned the United States embassy today. The demonstrators milled outside the building, waved anti-American placards and shouted hate slogans until the police finally dispersed them two hours later.

DETROIT, March 27 (UPI) -- Rolling twenty-four strikes for a 735 series in the doubles, Arthur Schwass Jr. of Buffalo took the regular division all-events lead in the American Bowling Congress tournament today. His total included a 614 in the singles and a 588 in the team competition.
GENEVA, March 27 -- The United States called on the Soviet Union today make clear soon its view of what constitutes reasonable and adequate controls for a treaty banning nuclear weapons tests.
DANBURY, Conn., March 27 -- Republicans elected a Mayor here today by the narrow margin of 172 votes. The victory ended a six-year reign by Democrats.
A warrant was issued yesterday for the arrest of Jason Robards Jr. after the actor failed to appear in court for trial on charges of drunken driving and leaving the scene of an accident.
LONDON, March 27 -- Three young opponents of nuclear weapons made a protest boarding of the United States Polaris-bearing submarine the Patrick Henry at her Holy Loch base in Scotland today.
The Transit Authority set out yesterday to revive the Age of Chivalry by suggesting that any male subway rider may qualify as a knight.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 27 (UPI) -- Larry Jackson, an eighteen-game winner for the St. Louis Cardinals last year, suffered a fracture of the lower jaw today during an exhibition game won by the Los Angeles Dodgers, 11 -- 2.
A spokesman for the New York World's Fair yesterday denied Joseph T. Sharkey's statement that the fair had asked the city to buy $24,000,000 in fair bonds.

TOBIAS STONE, who conducts a department in the Bridge World magazine devoted to very difficult questions about card-playing, decided that East's defensive task in this deal was too difficult for his readers to solve.
It takes more than adequate shelter to make a retirement house a home, a New York City Housing Authority aide said yesterday.

GENEVA, March 26 -- The United States is not getting far with the Russians at the resumed conference on a nuclear test ban, but the British are at least happy with Washington's policy and this may prove more important in the months ahead.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 27 (UPI) -- Four Soviet-bloc correspondents who were denied a trip to New Hampshire will visit Rhode Island this week with a group of foreign newsmen.
Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education, said yesterday the board would continue to press for the $25,000,000 it originally had requested for teacher pay increases.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI) -- The United States Food and Drug Administration announced today a new regulation aimed at tightening its control over new drugs.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, March 27 (Reuters) -- A constitutional conference that eventually will lead Tanganyika to independence opened today in an atmosphere of cordiality.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Newton M. Minow, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today the nation's radio and television networks had lived up to their responsibility for providing "full and scrupulously fair" coverage of the 1960 Presidential campaign.

Most of the top men selected by the New York Knickerbockers yesterday in the National Basketball Association draft probably will be signed to professional contracts. How many make the grade remains to be seen.

Mrs. Robert F. Warner of Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y., will entertain members of the junior committee working in behalf of the Graham Home for Children at a cocktail party this afternoon in the Versailles Room of the Park Lane.
A dinner dance, to be held at the Plaza on May 17, will benefit the Jacob A. Riis Neighborhood Settlement.
Elizabeth Taylor, the actress, returned yesterday from London, where she was ill with double pneumonia.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 27 -- Suffolk County's administration was told today that money strings must be tightened and efficiency increased to cope with the sprawling county's "astonishing" growth.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., March 27 -- An assistant vice president of the First National City Bank of New York was found dead in his garage today, a week after his wife was found dead in similar circumstances.

PARIS, March 27 -- The plans for the opening of negotiations between France and the Algerian rebels on April 7 were officially confirmed here. The confirmation was made against a background of stepped-up Moslem terrorism and of general tension in Algeria.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The United States has proposed the resumption of talks aimed at setting up direct commercial air flights between the United States and Soviet Union.
More than 800 women from Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx paid tribute yesterday to Sophie Tucker, at a luncheon of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York at the Plaza Hotel.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 10 to 23 points yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 27 (Reuters) -- South Vietnamese and Cambodian representatives have reached agreement on means of settling a refugee problem that has recently strained relations between their countries, official sources here said today.
Orders for machine tools, the machines used to make machinery, dropped sharply again last month, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday.

WE see where one of The Experts said the other day -justifying the inclusion of toy guns in a selection of educator-approved playthings -- that play with a toy gun gives a child "a sense of power and freedom, provides an opportunity to channel play to the side of right -- of law and order" -- and teaches the young "to use their play guns properly."

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 27 (UPI) - Mrs. John F. Kennedy, accompanied by four children, two nurses, two secretaries and a Welsh terrier named Charley, flew here today in the family plane for an Easter holiday.

CHICAGO, March 27 (AP) -- Toe Blake, the coach of the Montreal Canadiens, today was fined $2,000 by the National Hockey League's president, Clarence Campbell, for striking Referee Dalton McArthur during last night's game with the Chicago Black Hawks.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI) -- President Kennedy agreed today that the Tennessee Valley Authority directors had a "firm base" for their selection of the site for a new steam plant.

MOST people who meet Paula Ben-Gurion are impressed with the housewifely qualities she combines with a singular devotion to her husband, Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel, and to the causes he believes in.
ALTHOUGH planes get to Puerto Rico in three and one-half hours from New York, the sea passage has one great advantage. It takes four days.

The five-story walk-up apartment building at 541-51 West 204th Street, at the northwest corner of Nagle Avenue, has been acquired by Geisinger Germain, real estate operators. The property was sold by the Realty Equities Corporation through Irving M. Nason, broker.
YONKERS, March 27 -- There's no doubt that the harness racing set has become international-minded lately.
Two major chemical producers announced yesterday plans for a new fiber manufacturing and marketing venture in Europe.
Thomas E. Stakem Jr., chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, said yesterday the agency was reappraising the Government's surplus-ship disposal program.

Ohio Edison Company and its Subsidiary, Pennsylvania Power Company, reported yesterday new highs in 1960 for operating revenues, net income, sales of electricity and customers. Walter H. Sammis, president, reported to stockholders that "although there was a noticeable curtailment in industrial activities nationally in the latter part of 1960, sales of electricity by the two companies amounted to 8,752,515,324 kilowatt-hours or 5.4 per cent more than in 1959."
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The Kennedy Administration contended today that the public was willing to pay higher road-use taxes to complete the interstate highway program on schedule in 1972.

ALBANY, March 27 -- Governor Rockefeller has signed a bill permitting the state to join the Federal program that provides thirteen more weeks of unemployment compensation to workers whose regular benefits have expired.
The New York County Medical Society last night overwhelmingly adopted a resolution against compulsory membership in the American Medical Association.
MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, B.W.I., March 27 -- Walter Colquitt's Pipe Dream today became the Class B fleet winner in the first Miami-to-Montego Bay yacht race.
The appointment of George Arlen as president of the Wel-by division of the Elgin National Watch Company was announced yesterday by Henry M. Margolis, chairman of Elgin.

The regular 1961 session of the New York Legislature left enough important unfinished business to justify Governor Rockefeller in calling a special session for completion and rectification. A special session next fall had already been contemplated for reapportionment of the state's Congressional seats in adjustment to the 1960 census.
CHICAGO, March 27 (AP) -- Liquidation and short selling almost without let-up turned grain futures prices downward today on the Board of Trade and the market closed on a generally weak range.

Both sides rested yesterday in the $1,050,000 negligence suit brought against the city by the father of Arnold Schuster, who was murdered after he had informed the police of the whereabouts of Willie Sutton, the bank robber.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 27 -- Uruguay told the General Assembly today that the United Nations force in the Congo had "guiltlessly" caused "exasperation" among the Congolese and should be gradually withdrawn.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Experiments with a radioactive form of fluoride have confirmed that fluoridation treatment of water supplies is safe for the public, a scientist told Congress today.

FORT PIERCE, Fla., March 27 (UPI) -- Prosecution rebuttal witnesses testified today that Joseph A. Peel Jr. repeatedly had demanded immunity in exchange for information concerning the disappearances of Circuit Judge and Mrs. C.E. Chillingworth.

A protest against an employment contract granted in 1957 to Horace C. Flanigan, chairman of the Manufacturers Trust Company, has been filed with G. Russell Clark, State Superintendent of Banks, and the Federal Reserve Board.
The merging of service intelligence units at the Department of Defense level looses several major dangers.

Hugh W. Long Co.'s consolidated net income for 1960 amounted to $982,194, equal to 98 cents a share on Class A and B shares of comon stock, according to the annual report. This compared with $932,933, or 95 cents a share, a year earlier.

NO matter what happens to us all we can't say Low didn't warn us. He is the greatest political cartoonist in the modern world, and he doesn't find it so modern at that. Man's love of repeating his errors is probably Low's most dependable guarantee of personal affluence in times of want and tumult.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara ordered the heads of the military services and other defense agancies today to make certain that Negroes and members of other minority groups are given equal opportunity for employment.

Mike Flanagan, a 22-year-old senior from the University of Washington, yesterday won the national intercollegiate all-events bowling championship staged annually with the American Bowling Congress tournament.
Massachusetts Investors Growth Stock Fund ended its first 1961 fiscal quarter on Feb. 28 with new highs in net assets and share value, according to the quarterly report released yesterday.

" Gone With the Wind" will be revived April 26 at Loew's State Theatre, following the long-running reserved seat engagement of "Ben-Hur." The drama will be presented on a continuous run basis, for its fifth official release since it opened in 1939.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- In his advocacy of a gradual rise of the minimum wage from $1 to $1.25, and the addition of millions of workers to its beneficiaries, the President has stressed two arguments outside the economic area. One is humanitarian -- that it would provide a "decent" living wage-standard for large groups of unskilled and semi-skilled workers.
Ignoring parking tickets is not a serious enough offense to bar a man from citizenship, the United States Court of Appeals ruled yesterday.

The National Labor Relations Board yesterday denied a petition for a rehearing in a case in which it assumed jurisdiction of labor disputes involving crews of foreign-flag ships normally serving United States ports.
" The Joey Bishop Show," which had a trial run last night on the Columbia Broadcasting System, will be televised next season by the National Broadcasting Company.

ST. LOUIS, March 27 (AP) -- A 47-point scoring effort by Elgin Baylor paced the Los Angeles Lakers to a 121-112 victory over the St. Louis Hawks tonight. The triumph gives the Lakers a 3-2 lead in the National Basketball Association's Western Division play-offs.

Seventeen circus elephants had commuter problems last night. They arrived eleven hours late by train from Haddonfield, N.J. -- at 9:10 P.M. at the Harlem River yards of the New Haven Railroad -- shaking their heads and stamping their feet.
A word needs to be said in amplification of Kenneth Holland's timely point in his letter published March 12: that the formation of a Peace Corps is not so novel or visionary an idea as many suppose.

BANGKOK, Thailand, March 27 -- The seven nations allied with the United States in the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization are expected to give speedy approval for military intervention in Laos if peaceful approaches fail and the strife-torn kingdom requests outside aid against the pro-Communist rebels.

The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad operated last month at a net loss of $4,815,684. This raised its deficit for the first two months of this year to $7,802,998. In calendar 1960, the B. O. cleared $2,611,646.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Senator Wallace F. Bennett said today that the Kennedy Administration was using veil and chisel to obliterate the Eisenhower Administration's record of post-office construction.
The United States' approach on aid to under-developed Affrican countries is misguided, a specialist in African affairs said yesterday.

The Belgian parliamentary elections on Sunday have solved nothing. In fact, they have merely had the negative result of forcing the Eyskens Government to resign, leaving the country with no majority, no obvious leader and no clear trend.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27 -- A couple of old and almost forgotten hands rose to trip the Yankees today.

When the circus opens in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night it will have a few features designed to keep pace with the age we are living in; a lot of others are designed to perpetuate the thrills and antics that have been circus fare since Charles Ricketts exhibited his English horses before the first President of the United States in Philadelphia and before the second President here in New York on Greenwich Street.
Dr. Lyle C. Fitch resigned as $30,000-a-year City Administrator yesterday, effective April 16. Corporation Counsel Charles H. Tenney is expected to succeed him.
Roy Rubin, the coach at Columbus High in the Bronx, has been named coach of the Long Island University basketball team.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Senate approved by voice vote today the nomination of Ralph Paiewonsky, a wealthy distiller, to be Governor of the Virgin Islands.

Mrs. Francis R. Masters, left, and Mrs. James P. Gallatin meet at Carlton House to complete plans for theatre party at April 11 performance of "A Far Country'' in the Music Box Theatre. The event will benefit the Masters Nursery and Masters Childrens' Center.

Two stockholders of National Theatres and Television, Inc., announced yesterday that they had started a proxy contest for election as independent directors at the annual meeting on April 11 in Beverly Hills, Calif. The two dissenting shareholders are Leonard Davis, New York group insurance consultant, and Philip Handsman, a lawyer.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- A study made by officials of the United States Patent Office indicates that American companies may find it advantageous to obtain Soviet patents on goods they export to Russia. Department of Commerce figures show exports to the Soviet Union in 1960 were valued at $38,368,000, including more than $16,500,000 in machinery.
The Protestant Council of the City of New York expressed "vigorous" opposition yesterday to the use of Federal tax funds for supporting church-related or other private schools.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- President Kennedy and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union met for almost an hour today on the problem of Laos.
CINCINNATI, March 27 (UPI) -- Fans of the University of Cincinnati basketball team today fired a salvo at Gov. Michael V. DiSalle for proclamations honoring the Ohio State team.

TOPSFIELD, Mass., March 27 (AP) -- George L. Rockwell, 42 years old, who describes himself as the No. 1 Nazi in the United States, was arrested today on a trip here to attend a lecture on hate organizations.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 27 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that he planned to write a second book, "dealing primarily with my eight years in the Presidency and the lessons I believe can be drawn there-from."

PHILADELPHIA, March 27 (AP) -- The manager of the No. 1 heavyweight contender, Sonny Liston, confirmed today his fighter had been offered a $125,000 minimum guarantee to meet Ingemar Johansson in Sweden next September.
PARIS, March 27 -- Employes of France's single television station have announced a strike for Easter week-end, and no one is more upset than lovers of TV sport.

TRENTON, March 27 (AP) -- A three-judge court today suggested that New Jersey authorities tell Dr. Albert E. Weiner when he can expect an end to their investigation into the death of fifteen of his patients.
A group in the Flight Engineers' International Association yesterday threatened a renewal of a strike against major airlines.
MOSCOW, March 27 -- The Soviet Union indicated today that it was prepared to accept, conditionally at least, Western proposals on halting the fighting in Laos.

PARIS, March 27 -- President de Gaulle favors a program for Laos embracing an immediate halt in arms shipments, a ceasefire, the organization of a control commission and the formation of a "really representative" government.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 27 -- Because coaches don't have to observe the niceties of protocol with the diplomatic exactitude of managers, Signor Antonio Cuccinello is more outspoken about Jim Landis than is his boss, Senor Alfonso Ramon Lopez.
A former honor detective was sentenced in Kings County Court yesterday to ten to twelve years in Sing Sing Prison for participating in an armed robbery.

Blood will be given today to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program by members of Local 1 of the Amalgamated Lithographers of America at Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street. Blood will also be donated at the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., 40-22 Lawrence Street, Flushing, Queens.

The South African Government's policy of separate development is aimed at safeguarding the future of the various nations, black and white, living within the borders of the same country. There could be differences of opinion on this policy. South Africans accept this fact and exercise their right to criticize Government policy in accordance with the established principle of freedom of speech.

Chico Vejar, the Stamford (Conn.) middleweight, retired from the ring last night with a flourish. Capping a 117-fight professional career, Vejar won a unanimous decision over tough Willie Greaves of Canada in the ten-round feature at St. Nicholas Arena.
LONDON, March 27 -- Industrial share groups had either irregular movements or a majority of small losses in the stock market here today.

STUART, Fla., March 27 -- Capt. David Strain ruled today, after several hours of deep-water fishing, that the angler who had caught the most kinds of fish had the edge over the one who had taken the most fish and the one who had taken the biggest. This was regarded by one angler as a judgment equal to any of Solomon's and by two others as arrant prejudice.

DETROIT, March 27 (AP) -- Sol A. Dann, apparently on the verge of losing his fight to postpone the annual meeting of Chrysler Corporation, said today "I no longer intend to be a leader of any dissident (Chrysler) stockholders group."
Clifford Odets has been chosen to receive this year's award for drama by the American Academy of Arts and Letters. It consists of a gold medal and a cash prize of $1,000.
Edward Steichen, 82-year-old photographer, was honored last night at a dinner in the Museum of Modern Art.
LONDON, March 27 -- A Labor party demand for debate on the issue of potential British troop movements to Laos was rejected today by the Speaker of the House of Commons.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 27 -- The Theatre Guild American Repertory Company came to Belgrade, saw and conquered, to the acclaim of audiences and critics alike.
The Treasury's financing operations continued yesterday to be the center of interest of the market for debt securities.
ST. LOUIS, March 27 -- The St. Louis Board of Aldermen has enacted a new city building cede. Supporters predict that it will usher in a construction boom.

John E. Hand, a real estate management agent and Democratic political figure, and two other realty operators went on trial in Manhattan Arrest Court yesterday. They are charged with failing to provide essential services in a tenement at 200 East Twenty-eighth Street last winter.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 27 -- Only four of the ninety-nine members have paid any part of their assessments toward last year's more than $48,500,000 cost of the military operations in the Congo, the United Nations declared today.
Harmony has been restored between the music teacher and her piano students who last week complained of sweatshop conditions.
LOS ANGELES, March 27 -- Dr. R. Bernard Finch and Carole Tregoff, his red-haired mistress, were convicted today for the murder of his wife.
DIAMONDS may be a girl's best friend but the author of that sage piece of investment advice prefers a simple bracelet of gold beads for herself.
LONDON, March 27 -- The United States gained a friendly but cautious welcome today for its new four-point plan for increasing and more equitable sharing of aid to under-developed countries.

WADI MISHMAR, Israel, March 27 -- A Brooklyn girl and Mrs. David Ben-Gurion, wife of the Israeli Premier, got into a friendly but spirited argument deep in the Judean desert today about whether the United States or Israel was the better place to live.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, March 27 -- President Janio Quadros' candidate for Mayor of Sao Paulo, Brazil's largest city, was badly defeated today.
Pete Seeger, 42-year-old folk singer, went on trial yesterday in Federal court on charges of contempt in refusing to answer questions before the House Un-American Activities Commitee.
Although gross revenues of Hilton Hotels Corporation set a new record in 1960, net earnings of the hotel chain dropped, Conrad N. Hilton, president, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision that the Federal Trade Commission had the right to see copies of confidential census reports prepared by manufacturers for the Bureau of the Census.
DES MOINES, Iowa, March 27 (AP) -- Flood waters poured down Iowa rivers tonight, causing flooding described as the worst in modern times in some towns.

The rare prospect of seeing twin fillies race intrigued many of the 30,699 breed-improvers at Aqueduct yesterday. As it turned out, only one of the twins got to run. It was her first start and she won it.
George Meany received the annual award of the Four Freedoms Foundation last night for distinguished service in the cause of freedom.
Two patrolmen were injured seriously yesterday when their unmarked car overturned on the New England Thruway while they were chasing a speeding motorist, who escaped.
Representative of five civic groups and three authorities on urban renewal yesterday protested Mayor Wagner's proposal to redevelop fourteen blocks in Greenwich Village.
VIENTIANE, Laos, March 28 -- The military situation in Laos remained relatively quiet today for the third consecutive day.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Stewart L. Udall, the Secretary of the Interior, told a news conference today that he was considering another national park in the canyon country of southeastern Utah, where the Green and Colorado Rivers meet.

The postwar years have seen the most remarkable progress in the development of life-saving, life-prolonging and pain-relieving drugs in the entire history of man's struggle against disease and suffering. Until now, safety control of these new drugs has depended in large part on the manufacturer and his scientific staff, the Food and Drug Administration relying on the scientific data supplied by the makers of the new chemicals.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- There will be a $2,826,000,000 deficit in the Federal budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1, according to estimates published by the Budget Bureau today.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that five scientists had been selected to receive the Ernest O. Lawrence Memorial Award for 1961.
Premier Tage Erlander of Sweden said on his arrival in New York yesterday that "there are a great many matters of interest" to discuss at his meeting with President Kennedy today in Washington.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 28 -- A Congolese representative said today that misunderstandings and discord would not have arisen in the Congo if Rajeshwar Dayal of India, the Secretary General's special representative, had not cut off contact with the Government.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad experienced a $2,430,557 deficit last month and reported yesterday that its net loss for the first two months this year had reached $5,053,004.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 28 (AP) -- Larry Jackson of the St. Louis Cardinals is expected to be sidelined up to four weeks with a fractured jaw because of a freakish accident yesterday.

ALBANY, March 28 (AP) -- There was no comment at Governor Rockefeller's office today on President Kennedy's assertion that New York State could move faster on road-building. Mr. Rockefeller is vacationing in Puerto Rico.
LONDON, March 28 -- Hunters armed with machine guns have shot what is believed to be the world's last surviving herd of Arabian Oryx, a large and graceful desert antelope.

NORWALK, Conn., March 28 -- The Charter Revision Commission has voted to make any bond issue above $100,000 subject to a referendum. It also decided to retain the Board of Estimate and Taxation but gave authority over budget matters to the Common Council.
