An unidentified man was struck by an IND Eighth Avenue uptown express 600 feet north of the West Fourth Street station about 7:20 last night. He was in critical ocndition at St. Vincent's Hospital.
Peepholes only fourteen inches above the pavement are puzzling sidewalk superintendents on lower Broadway.

Philipp Brothers, a division of the Minerals and Chemicals Philipp Corporation, has leased two floors in the Hanover Bank Building at 350 Park Avenue, corner of Fifty-first Street. Bertram F. French, vice president of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., and Joseph P Gavron of the Joseph P. Gavron Company, were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- There is nothing ordinary about John Kenneth Galbraith. He is a Harvard professor who is known to an unusual number of backroom politicans, an economist whose books are best sellers anti a former Fortune editor who has expanded his writings to virtually every area of American life.

Not many companies have the storage space or the need to keep records upward of 100 years old. But the insurance business has unusual requirements in this respect and, as a result, two documents -- one dated Feb. 8, 1861, the other Oct. 17, 1859 -- are being used as the basis of an unusual advertisement.
An agreement to extend present air-cargo rates on the North Atlantic to June 30 was announced yesterday by the International Air Transport Association.
KANSAS CITY, March 28 (UPI) -- Bill Bridges and Walt Bellamy scored 21 points apiece tonight and led the West to a 103-100 victory over the East in the tenth Shrine all-star basketball game.
FORT MYERS, Fla., March 28 -- As far as the Yanks are concerned, Danny Murtaugh's Pirates are still the baseball champions of the world.
NUREMBERG, Germany, March 28 -- A four-engined Czechoslovak airliner plunged in flames into a wooded area thirty miles north of here today, killing all fifty-two persons aboard.
Joseph T. Sharkey, majority leader of the City Council, accused the World's Fair Corporation of seeking a $24,000,000 "handout" from the city to help finance the 1964-65 fair.
Blanche Thebom was named as an "official New York City representative to Tokyo" yesterday at a ceremony and reception held at Sherry's in the Metropolitan Opera House by the Metropolitan Opera Guild.
The Broadway Maintenance Corporation lost a motion in Queens Supreme Court yesterday for an injunction to reinstate its contract to service 52,000 city parking meters.
" Not in the mood" -- that is the description the University of Michigan's Survey Research Center applies to consumers in explaining their reluctance to dig into their pockets.
Three men were arrested yesterday and charged with complicity in a Harlem tavern hold-up last Thursday in which a woman patron was shot dead.
KANSAS CITY, March 28 (AP) -- The National Basketball Committee of the United States and Canada today made three major rules changes and moved to improve the conduct of coaches during games.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 28 (UPI) -- A committee of the California Legislature began hearings today on the John Birch Society, an ultra-conservative group.

HAVANA, March 28 -- Maj. Ernesto Guevara, Minister of Industries, told a shouting crowd of workers today that the fight between the Cuban Government and Yankee imperialism was "to the dearth." The victory of the Cuban revolution would mean the destruction of the United States, he said.

LONDON, March 28 (AP) -- Three United States oarsmen who hope to be on the winning side in Saturday's Oxford-Cambridge rowing race put in another tough day of training today. Then they went home to dinner and beer.
CINCINNATI, March 28 (AP) -- "What will happen to the Reds?"

TUNIS, March 28 -- A spokesman for the Algerian nationalist Provisional Government implied tonight that prospective peace negotiations with the French Government, scheduled to begin April 7, were in grave jeopardy.
LISBON, Portugal, March 28 (AP) -- Ambassador C. Burke Elbrick presented a strong oral protest today against a mob attack that damaged the United States Embassy here last night.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., March 28 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that it was starting a gradual reduction in the purchase of electric power for its plants here and at Paducah, Ky., and Portsmouth, Ohio.
DETROIT, March 28 (UPI) -- The Detroit Red Wings beat the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight for the third straight time in their Stanley Cup semifinal hockey series. The score was 4 -- 1.
ALBANY, March 28 -- A $5,000,000 bequest to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City by a Glens Falls woman was upheld today by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 28 -- The United Nations was advised today to make a new approach to the problems of lightly industrialized countries through a study of the causes of their economic underdevelopment.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Nine new Ambassadors won quick Senate approval today without floor discussion or a vote of record.
JACKSON, Miss., March 28 -- Fifty students of Jackson State College for Negroes were stopped short of a march on the city jail today by the police using clubs, tear gas and two German police dogs.
The Lionel Corporation and American Bosch Arma Corporation are holding merger talks.
Major financing plans were announced yesterday by large companies including United States Steel Corporation.
TRENTON, N.J., March 28 AP) -- New Jersey's Civil War Centennial Commission decided today to drop its boycott of the national commission's assembly in Charleston, S.C., on April 11 and 12.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- President Kennedy urged a speed-up in long-range missile strength today but he cut back the B-70 supersonic bomber program and dropped the nuclear plane project.

CHICAGO, March 28 (UPI) -- Bill Hicke and Dickie Moore scored two goals apiece tonight in leading the Montreal Canadiens to a 5 -- 2 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks. The triumph squared their Stanley Cup semi-final series at two games each.
SEATTLE, March 28 (AP) -- A dispute over the size of longshore gangs idled the Seattle waterfront today for the second day as a stop-work meeting of about 1,500 longshoremen continued.
DETROIT, March 28 -- A Federal judge today refused Detroit Attorney Sol A. Dann's request for a six-months delay of Chrysler Corporation's annual stockholder meeting.

HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, March 28 -- The last stragglers of a group of Indonesian infiltrators having been rounded up, this capital of Netherlands New Guinea again has relapsed into tropical languor.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Administration sent Congress a voluminous legal memorandum today to buttress President Kennedy's contention that across-the-board loans to sectarian schools would be unconstitutional.
A national "self-triggering" plan for economic controls such as rationing is ready for action if there is a nuclear attack on this country, a Federal official said here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Following is the text of the special message to Congress today on the defense budget by President Kennedy:

Commodity futures prices on New York exchanges had a touch of spring fever yesterday. With few exceptions, prices moved lazily, trading was light, and brokers and traders alike attributed the quietness to the balmy weather.

The Byline Award of the Newspaper Reporters Association of New York City, a gilded reproduction of a reporter's police card and a mahogany plaque, has been won by William P. Haddad, a New York Post reporter.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Political candidates who appear as guests on debate-type radio or television programs are opening the way for their opponents to obtain equal time free of charge, Senators were told today.

A group of Staten Island residents has nothing against the $320,000,000 Verrazano-Narrows Bridge that is going up between the island and Brooklyn, but it wants the workmen to be a little less noisy about it.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 28 (UPI) -- Studebaker-Packard Corporation reported today that its auto operations thus far this year "have been conducted with considerable losses."
The March 18 Times story describing the American Medical Association's attack on the Socialist party for its support of socialized medicine contains several inaccuracies which should be corrected.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Following are excerpts from a memorandum on the constitutional question of Federal aid to sectarian schools prepared by the legal staff of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare in cooperation with attorneys of the Department of Justice:

Financial Industrial Fund, Inc., reported yesterday net assets of $219,880,413, equal to $4.61 a share on 47,701,589 shares outstanding on Feb. 28, end of the fiscal quarter. This compared with $169,233,970, or $4.21 a share on 40,169,851 shares outstanding a year earlier.
Detroit, Mich., borrowed $27,011,000 in the public market yesterday to finance urban renewal projects and improvements to sewers, highways and the public school system.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Administration supporters predicted passage of a $394,000,000 bill to rehabilitate depressed areas as debate on the measure opened today in the House of Representatives. Voting is expected tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- The House of Representatives passed the first Kennedy Administration appropriation bill today after cutting $89,936,000 from new funds requested for the Treasury and Post Office Departments.

Five men were indicted here yesterday on charges of having conspired to forge and cash stolen savings bonds. A Federal prosecutor said the alleged ring had handled more than $1,000,000 in bonds stolen in New York and seven upstate communities.
David Rockefeller told fellow-members of the New York Young Republican Club yesterday that he was not interested in running for Mayor.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 28 -- Adlai E. Stevenson told a caucus of African nations today that they could count on "substantial" aid from the United States if they showed themselves capable of careful and realistic planning.

The twelfth annual Robert J. Flaherty Award, presented by the City College Film Institute, has been given to "Primary," a documentary account of the 1960 Wisconsin Presidential primary between President Kennedy and Senator Hubert Humphrey.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 28 (UPI) -- Six unhappy boys who went to defend the honor of their beloved Cincinnati basketball team paced a jail floor today.

Dr. Lyle C. Fitch, after some years in municipal service, most recently as City Administrator, is resigning to return to the Institute of Public Administration, where he will be associated with Dr. Luther Gulick, the first City Administrator. His letter of resignation reviews the numerous and varied management improvement studies made under his able direction.
LOS ANGELES, March 28 -- Georg Solti resigned today as musical director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI) -- President Kennedy has asked Congress to provide $10,000,000 to start developing a supersonic airliner that could whisk passengers from New York to London in about two hours.
Representative Francis E. Walter, chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, testified here yesterday as a defense witness in the trial of Pete Seeger, the folk singer.

LONDON, March 28 -- The House of Commons approved tonight the introduction of a private bill to increase the salaries of Government ministers. The chief sponsor of the measure, Ronald Bell, Conservative, appealed to the House to "thrust this bounty on a reluctant administration."
The Justice Department opened an investigation here yesterday of charges of price-fixing conspiracies in the processed-meat industry.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Investigating Senators heard testimony today that many mentally ill persons were denied their civil rights, with the nation's capital held up as an example.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Explorer X encountered magnetic fields far out in space that were "considerably stronger" than had been expected, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

VERO BEACH, Fla. -- There is an air of unreality about the career of Ed Roebuck, the ace of the Dodger bullpen last year just as he had been at Ebbets Field in 1957. In the two seasons in between, his market value shrank to the vanishing point. Though top-flight relief pitchers are almost beyond price, he was considered so worthless that no ball club in the majors would pay even $1 for him.

CROTON FALLS, N.Y. March 28 -- James R. Worley said today that legal expenses and six months of unemployment during his sixteen-month fight to regain his position on the Fox Lane High School faculty made an appeal from the Appellate Division's decision "economically impossible."
Fendall W. Yerxa resigned last night as vice president and managing editor of The New York Herald Tribune. No date was set for his resignation to take effect.

TRENTON, March 28 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner opened a drive today to retain the identity of Station WNTA as a New Jersey television channel and to develop its programing to reflect New Jersey interests better.

KEARNY, N.J., March 28 -- The Kearny works of the Western Electric Company had its third best sales year in 1960 with the volume at $395,600,000, it was reported today. This was 22 per cent above the 1959 level.
The traditional Easter fashion show and luncheon, to be held in the Rendez-Vous of the Plaza on Sunday, will benefit the Judson Health Center.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Wednesday, March 29 -- A survey by Thailand and the United States in northeastern Thailand indicates that the people there have little hope for a Western victory in Communist-threatened Laos.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Government borrowed $1,500,000,000 of short-term cash today at discounts averaging 2.473 per cent. Bids by would-be investors were more than double the amount of securities being offered for sale.
ALBANY, March 28 -- A $40,000,000 expansion of medical care for the state's needy aged will go into effect on Saturday.

MIAMI, March 28 (AP) -- A former attorney for the Teamsters Union was injured today when he turned the ignition key in his automobile and set off a dynamite bomb. The blast smashed the 1959 Cadillac of Hyman I. Fischbach, 53 years old, and blew all the front windows out of his house.
Jason Robards Jr., actor, was found gulty, in Special Sessions Court yesterday of driving while intoxicated and of reckless driving.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Wednesday, March 29 -- The United States and its seven allies in the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization warned the Communists today to keep their hands off Laos or risk "appropriate" retaliatory action.
TAMPA, Fla., March 28 (UPI) -- Warren Giles, the National League president, said today the death of Powel Crosley Jr. was "a distinct' loss to the City of Cincinnati and to the National League."
Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons has voted to continue its 112-year association with Bellevue Hospital, but it will study a proposal to affiliate also with Harlem Hospital.
The evening of April 24 has been chosen for this year's Goddard-Riverside Gala at the Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- The creation of a Government science academy modeled after West Point was opposed today by the head of the agency that would operate it under a bill before Congress.

CHICAGO, March 28 (AP) -- Heavy selling set the feed grains back sharply again today on the Board of Trade and extended the losses for two days to around 4 cents a bushel in corn and oats, more in rye.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 28 -- Mrs. Margaretha Varnik, a refugee from Estonia, had good reason to be happy today.

IT is likely that a casual bridge player would have done better with the South hand in this deal than did the actual holder of the South hand, a highly reputed player. The play that decided the issue -- and lost -- was not one that the average player often makes.
The proposed sale of Bull Lines became the subject yesterday of an antitrust inquiry by the Justice Department.

President Kennedy moved yesterday to make our "strong military position" still stronger by asking Congress for nearly $2 billion more for national defense. This request is based on a still incomplete reappraisal of our defense posture, which in the President's mind has already revealed enough to call for immediate short-term and long-term action involving substantial changes in our defense concepts.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 28 -- A $65,000,000 plan to redevelop the heart of downtown Stamford was made public today.
LONDON, March 28 -- Peter Brook, Michael Elliott, Donald McWhinnie and Peter Wood have agreed to become associate directors of the Royal Shakespeare Theatre.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Wednesday, March 29 (AP) -- The text of the resolution on Laos unanimously adopted today by the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization's Council of Ministers follows:
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Robert M. Morgenthau of the Bronx has been selected as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

The typical struggle between a vigorous President and a lethargic Congress is being re-enacted this year with more than the usual drama because of two factors: (1) the extraordinary energy of the President himself; and (2) the extraordinary recalcitrance of a Congress so closely divided that almost every major vote hangs in the balance.
GENEVA, March 28 -- The West ruled out today any staffing arrangements that would create conflicts of interest and loyalty in the projected control organization for enforcing a nuclear test ban.

Drexel Co. and associates are offering to the public today 500,000 common shares of Greenfield Real Estate Investment Trust, Philadelphia, at $20 each. The company is one of the first trusts to be organized since the passage of the Real Estate Investment Trust Act by the Federal Government last year.
That Maya Hoffman is a pianist with musical sensibility there can be no doubt, but she overreached herself last night at Town Hall.

Sales of Sears, Roebuck Co., giant mail-order and retail chain, set a new record for the sixth consecutive year in fiscal 1960, but net income failed to do as well. This was announced yesterday in Chicago as the company released its annual report.
Japan's largest maker of transistor radios and household electrical appliances expects to move heavily into the United States market this year.
For those who appreciate skill and daring in race driving, last Saturday's twelve-hour endurance contest at Sebring, Fla., provided some great performances.
BOSTON, March 28 (UPI) -- President Kennedy opened the 1961 Cancer Crusade with a telephone call to one of his brothers today.
CHICAGO, March 28 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 770 persons had been injured in the city last week. This was a drop of 256 from the period the year before.
LONDON, March 28 -- The British Government is prepared to exploit the position of Prince Souvanna Phouma as a link between the two warring factions in Laos.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Administration's brief on the constitutionality of aid to church schools calls attention to a little understood but important matter -- the difficulty of getting the Supreme Court to decide the constitutional question.
Long Gone John withstood a challenge by Sweet William and captured the $10,000 feature at Aqueduct yesterday.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York is expanding its published series of financial statistics by putting out five new series related to the public market for United States Government securities, where the business often exceeds $1,000,000,000 a day.

LONDON, March 28 (AP) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower joined the Golf Society of Great Britain today. He voiced the hope that he would visit Britain soon to play some of the country's best-known courses.

SUNNY spring days and bursting buds bring the reminder that many of the best things in life come without charge. And it is not only Mother Nature who offers free wares. There are, for instance, any number of booklets on food that are available for the price of a postage stamp.
Business in the market for United States Government securities again was mostly in the new issues of discount bills yesterday.

The Chase Manhattan Bank has leased a building to be erected for a branch at Avenue U and East Sixty-sixth Street in the Flatbush Gardens Shopping Center in Brooklyn. The building, which will contain 4,800 square feet of space, will have a drive-in. J. Yudell Realty, Inc., arranged the lease. The center, which has a Waldbaum supermarket, has parking space for 250 cars.
Jaja Wachuku, Nigeria's chief United Nations delegate, declared yesterday that Africa was becoming a third force between East and West and was demonstrating its strength in the United Nations.

Directors of Lane Bryant, Inc., proposed yesterday an increase in authorized common stock to 2,000,000 shares from 1,000,000 to provide for a three-for-two stock split. Shareholders at their annual meeting on May 15 will be asked to approve the change. If it is approved, the new shares will be distributed on June 30 to stock of record of June 2.
Three persons were killed and five injured in a flash fire that swept a Chelsea tenement early this morning.
LOS ANGELES, March 28 (UPI) -- Attorneys for Dr. R. Bernard Finch and Carole Tregoff prepared today appeals to save them from possible death in the gas chamber.

I was struck, here in Nepal, by your editorial of March 7. This contained Dr. Warren Heller's estimate "that the unused productive potential in [the American] economy last year was equivalent to an average loss of $500 for every family in the nation."
ALBANY, March 28 -- Teachers, even very able ones, must abide by the procedures laid down for running their schools, the Appellate Division ruled today.
Pampered pachyderms were pedicured, cantankerous camels were combed, prancing ponies were primped and temperamental tightrope walkers were on tenterhooks.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 28 -- Three Ghanaian soldiers of the United Nations force in the Congo have been missing for four days and are presumed dead. United Nations sources announced tonight.

The Esso Standard division of the Humble Oil and Refining Company will reduce today wholesale and retail prices of home heating oil, kerosene and Diesel fuel by one-half cent a gallon in New England, New York, Virginia and West Virginia. Reductions ranging from one-tenth to one-half cent will be made in other East Coast states and the District of Columbia.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- President Kennedy asked Congress today for a $125,670,000 increase in the space agency's budget to permit the accelerated development of huge launching vehicles that would match or excel the weight-lifting capacity of Soviet rockets.

The Board of Education announced yesterday it would extend "open enrollment" next fall to 4,433 pupils in the first and second grades in twelve schools. The pupils normally would attend over-crowded neighborhood schools with predominantly Negro and Puerto Rican enrollments.

JACKSON, Miss., March 28 (AP) -- Thousands of Mississippians filed in review through twin rows of cheering onlookers, past the Governor's stand, to a special Secession Day ceremony today that began the state's four-year Civil War centennial celebration.

A consultant's report to the Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee claims that a $650 to $800 million Federal subsidy to New York commuter rail roads (to "start" cutting costs and improving service) would be "far less a burden on the taxpayer than providing alternative commuter facilities."

PARIS, March 28 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, former neutralist Premier of Laos, expressed the belief today that the Soviet Union would accept, in most essentials, the plan put forward by Britain, on behalf of the West, for a Laotian settlement.

NEWLY settled in a back flat one flight up at 44 East Fiftieth Street is a festive store called, appropriately, The Mexico Shop. It was opened by Rosario de la Vega Nilsen in January as the New York branch of her summer store in Booth Bay Harbor, Me.

Western Electric Company had in 1960 its biggest year in terms of production and sales, according to the annual report released yesterday. The company, the manufacturing and supply arm of the Bell System, is 99.82 per cent owned by Bell.

FORT PIERCE, Fla., March 28 (AP) -- Testimony ended today in the Chillingworth murder trial. Final arguments by opposing attorneys will be heard tomorrow and the fate of Joseph A. Peel Jr. will be placed in the jury's hands Thursday morning.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 28 (Reuters) -- Gen. Manghistu Neway, former commander of the Ethiopian Imperial Guard, was sentenced today to be hanged in public for his part in last December's attempted coup against Emperor Haile Selassie.
A Brooklyn jury awarded $30,000 in negligence damages last night to Max Schuster, whose son was killed nine years ago after helping the police to capture Willie Sutton, the bank robber.
The 'Tom Ewell Show" will probably end its days with the Columbia Broadcasting System in July.
PARIS, March 28 -- The Fifth Republic has lost one of its institutions.

Stocks went through an in conclusive session yesterday More issues rose than fell and there was a slight increase in aggregate market value but both The New York Times and the Dow, Jones Co. averages were down.

Richard F. Vaughan of Princeton, a past president of the American Hockey Coaches Association, hurls a challenge at his fellow coaches in the current issue of United States Amateur Hockey. Writes Dick: "I hereby challenge all A.H.C.A. members to show their faith in the American boy by adopting the following code:
JERUSALEM, March 28 -- The Knesset, Israel's Parliament, voted unanimously today to dissolve as a result of the crisis brought on by the Lavon affair.

George Balanchine's beautiful ballet built on Mozart's "Divertimento No. 15" was restored to the repertory of the New York City Ballet last night at the City Center after an absence of two seasons. That is far too long an absence; indeed, this is a ballet that should not be allowed any time off at all, for it is a truly lovely work.

TELEVISION portrait of Will Rogers --warm, enormously amusing and moving -- was offered last night on Channel 4 in one of the best filmed installments of the "Project 20" series of the National Broadcasting Company.

THE Fifteenth Annual Egg Rolling Contest will be conducted on Saturday at 2 P.M. on the Great Lawn between Eightieth and Eighty-fourth Street in Central Park. The contest is open to boys and girls 5 through 13 years old. Entries may be filed today and tomorrow at the Arsenal, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, or on the second floor of Arnold Constable, sponsor of the contest.

Almost two years ago, it was disclosed that Garson Kanin had set his heart on dramatizing and directing "Death of a Man," based on Lael Tucker Wertenbaker's absorbing book, published by Random House. The story concerns Mrs. Wertenbaker's husband, Charles C. Wertenbaker, a victim of cancer at the age of 54.
A former state license inspector was indicted here yesterday on charges of selling answers to examination questions to eight persons seeking beauticians' licenses.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Democratic Congressional leaders were briefed by President Kennedy today on his meetings with Andrei Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, and Prime Minister Macmillan on the situation in strife-torn Laos.

Of all the institutions in our society, none seems to have captured our linguistic imaginations as much as a deck of cards. Over the eight or nine centuries since cards were invented, our language has been steadily enriched by colorful expressions that first originated either with the pasteboards themselves or with individual card games.

CAIRO, March 28 -- One of neutralism's most important leaders is President Nasser of the United Arab Republic. Nasser calls his policy "non-alignment," but it is neither quite so "non-aligned" as he fancies nor as "aligned" as we sometimes imagine.
Commercial paper dealers raised by one-eighth percentage point yesterday the rates paid to investors on the short-term, unsecured obligations of business companies sold in the open market.
LUANDA, Angola, March 27 -- Strains on United States-Portuguese friendship are growing in proportion to the rise of violence in Portuguese Angola.
NEWARK, March 28 -- State subsidies of millions of dollars annually will not halt the deterioration of passenger railroad service, spokesmen for northern New Jersey commuter groups said today.

A Board of Education commission that is seeking to determine procedures for a collective bargaining election for teachers discovered yesterday that many teachers did not know how collective bargaining operated.

THE story of Bartok's First Violin Concerto is a curious one. He completed it in 1908; it was composed for a Hungarian violinist, Stefi Geyer, with whom the composer was in love. She never played it and kept the manuscript.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 28 (AP) -- A Mace-B guided missile crashed and exploded here today seconds after it was launched.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- The Air Force postponed today for at least six months any decision to close procurement facilities at Griffiss Air Force Base, Rome, N.Y.
Cotton futures on the New{ York Cotton Exchange .moved 6 points up to 2 off yesterday. The declines were in the far months.
A program of contemporary Netherlands chamber music in the Donnell Library last night was discouragingly short in works that had something fresh to say or a personality to reveal.

STUART, Fla., March 28 -- This has been a winter of fine fishing in these parts, on the whole, but sometimes with not enough fishermen to do it justice. Transport troubles, including an airline strike, had something to do with that.
Older persons should live amidst a "beauty that will wear well," a designer told an institute on housing for the aged yesterday.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 28 (AP) -- Caroline Kennedy went shopping today. She bought her pet dog a new collar and leash and visted a toy shop.

YONKERS, N.Y., March 28 -- A man and his wife were found dead today in their duplex apartment at 470 Tuckahoe Road. The Westchester County medical examiner, Dr. Victoria Bradess, ordered autopsies on the bodies.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 28 (AP) -- Two Rastafarian cultists convicted of murdering a fellow member of their back-to-Africa movement, were hanged today in St. Catherine District Prison.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 28 -- France has informed the United Nations that she will not pay any part of the costs of the military operation in the Congo.
LLOYD HARBOR, L.I., March 28 -- A forty-two room mansion in this North Shore village has been purchased for the Ambassador to the United Nations from the new Republic of the Ivory Coast.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- President Kennedy has advised New York State that it can speed construction of its interstate highways, but it will have to use its own money.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee assailed today the budget message President Kennedy submitted to Congress Friday. In its publication Battle Line it declared:
New procedures for checking the "hidden" materials and workmanship in city school buildings were disclosed yesterday.

The clatter of shuffleboard disks', the grind of roller skates and pop of cap guns were heard through the streets of New York yesterday as the temperature reached 73 degrees at 1:20 P.M., a new high for 1961.

Portuguese feelings over their African colony are understandable. It was, no doubt, natural that they should be upset when Adlai Stevenson put the United States on record in the Security Council in favor of a United Nations investigation of Portuguese rule in Angola.
Lower selling prices for paper are continuing to affect earnings of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company, David L. Luke, president, reported at the annual meeting at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday.
WARSAW, March 28 -- Twenty-seven students of the United States National War College completed a forty-eight-hour survey of Poland today.

" Last Plane for Shanghai," a novel by Richard Tregaskis, will be published next Monday by Bobbs-Merrill. Laid in China during the summer of 1943, it is a story of a love affair between a disillusioned journalist, trying to recover from a shattered marriage, and a woman who is married to a traitor.

MOSCOW, March 28 (UPI) -- Leaders of the Warsaw Pact met today in the Kremlin to study the Laotian crisis, "cold war" issues such as disarmament, the Congo and Berlin and to work out a twenty-year economic plan for the entire Communist bloc.

Net assets of the New York Life Insurance Company at the end of 1960 reached a new high of $7,157,885,018, marking the first time the concern's assets have topped $7,000,000,000. A year earlier, the assets aggregated $6,923,547,193.

ONE of the interesting and disturbing aspects of the contemporary literary scene is the number of young novelists of great talent whose books are devoted to the self-destruction of psychopathic characters, the moral corruption of privileged characters and the general rottenness of society itself.
LONDON, March 28 -- The stock market presented a brighter picture here today with prices moving ahead in most sections.

Thanks to aid from the Lincoln Center of the Performing Arts, the New York Philharmonic will expand its program of concerts for school children this year and will be able to offer them without charge.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- A rebel group of flight engineers threatened to renew a wildcat strike against major airlines today but later reportedly unanimously agreed there would be no work stoppage now.

Cincinnati and Providence, this year's basketball kingpins, will compete in the tenth annual Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden next December. The festival dates are Dec. 26, 28 and 30.
YONKERS, March 28 -- "No matter what the distance of the race, a good standardbred can go as far as required."

PHILADELPHIA, March 29 (AP) -- Connie Mack Stadium, the scene of many a memorable major league baseball game, was sold today. The new owners are expected to tear it down and use the site for building purposes.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 22:

The rash and rush of renewals without an over-all city development plan, including lines of traffic, may well create new traffic snarls and even more serious impediments to the proper growth of the city.
VIENNA, March 29 -- The United States Government transferred control of more than $400,000,000 worth of counterpart funds to the Austrian Government today.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 29 -- Contracts totaling $10,578,545, of which $10,197,714 will go to companies in areas of substantial unemployment, were announced today by the Tennessee Valley Authority.
LONDON, March 29 -- A perceptible sharpening of Soviet political and diplomatic attitudes led British diplomats today to expect new Russian moves on Germany and Berlin.

MIDDLETOWN TOWNSHIP, N.J., March 29 -- Two persons were killed and three others were injured today in the crash of a Jersey Central Railroad passenger train and a Middletown Road Department truck at an unguarded crossing.

BANGKOK, Thailand, March 29 -- United States sources said today that the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization's resolution warning against a continued Communist push in Laos had been supplemented by a private warning in blunter terms.

The response to President Kennedy's "Alliance for Progress" plan for Latin America from some of the leading statesmen of the hemisphere and a number of the most responsible newspapers has been gratifying. This is important because the success of the Kennedy program depends in large measure on the cooperation of the Latin-American governing classes.

IS there a slump in the reading of Civil War books? Homage to the centenary has certainly swelled the supply. But the innumerable new titles do not seem to be overcrowding those odd barometers of the people's choice, the best-seller lists. A pity. There are good ones around.
Merry Ruler established himself yesterday as the boss of Aqueduct's 3-year-olds. This he did by scoring his second victory in two starts at the track against opposition of his age.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A sixth United States carrier is on the way to reinforce the Seventh Fleet in the Southeast Asia area. The anti-submarine carrier Kearsage, with Marine HUS Sikorsky helicopters aboard, sailed before the recent easing of the Laotian crisis.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Fulton Freeman, a veteran Foreign Service officer, was appointed by President Kennedy today, to be United States Ambassador to Colombia.
A comprehensive attack on reading problems has been started in the city's elementary schools.

Now that the shock troops of the new jazz wave, spearheaded by Ornette Coleman, have battered a wide hole in the conventional picture of jazz, one might reasonably expect the appearance of someone who will pick up the pieces scattered by this onslaught and put them into viable shape.

The presidents of two Gulf steamship companies said yesterday they were willing to make prompt restitution to the United States Government of any overcharges they might have made for hauling grain shipments overseas under the nation's foreign aid program.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation cleared $6,990,000 in the fourth quarter of 1960, reducing its net loss for the year to $42,934,000, according to the annual report. The company had a net profit of $8,733,000, or $1.21 a share, in 1959.
The Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut said yesterday it was recommending eighteen persons for Federal judgeships instead of fourteen as originally announced.
BOSTON, March 29 (UPI) -- The New England Council issued the following report today:

IN recent years Puerto Rico has been portrayed in some advertisements as a land where business executives relax at lovely lagoons after work, where post-debs lean over colonial balconies and muse, "I'm falling in love with old San Juan" and where bevies of sprightly girls caper across the green hills.
CHICAGO, March 29 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
TOKYO, March 29 (UPI) -- Japan is steadily liberalizing her attitude toward imports from the United States, the head of a United States trade mission just arrived in Japan said today.
Applications for extend unemployment compensation under the Federal program recently enacted will be received by the twenty-eight offices of the Division of Employment in the city beginning April 10.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Horace C. Flanigan, chairman of the Manufacturers Trust Company, today gave the Senate some details about his $125,000-a-year pay, his $100,000 life insurance, his $25,000-a-year pension and the chauffered car, airplane and Waldorf-Astoria suite he can use.

"The Republican campaign is getting under way -- as of now." This brave trumpet call to action was sounded not yesterday, not last week, but exactly two months ago by Bernard Newman, Republican leader in New York County. He announced on Jan. 29 the creation of an inter-borough 100-member Republican City Advisory Council for the 1961 mayoral campaign.

An inquiry to determine if New York can have a noncommercial education television station on one of the existing seven channels in the area was voted yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission in Washington.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Mortimer M. Caplin, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, said today that if all types of income were given equal treatment, tax rates could be cut about one-third.
Two high schools in the New York suburbs were among ten in the country named yesterday by the American Association of Physics Teachers as outstanding in their science and mathematics programs.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 29 -- Asian and African representatives are asking members of the United Nations to apply economic and diplomatic sanctions against South Africa if her Government persists in its policy of apartheid, or racial separation.

Reynolds Metals Company is negotiating to sponsor a $30,000,000 urban renewal project in Louisville, Ky., and has entered a bid on a $60,000,000 project in Santa Monica, Calif., Albert M. Cole, executive vice president of Reynolds Aluminum Service Corporation, said yesterday.

JACKSON, Miss., March 29 (UPI) -- Club-swinging police and two German Shepherd dogs today chased more than 100 Negroes from a courthouse where nine Negro students were convicted for staging Mississippi's first sit-in demonstration.

After five sessions in which prices showed mild declines, stocks broke loose yesterday and advanced to a goad gain in heavy trading. The forward movement -- anticipated by the chartists and Dow Theory adherents -- was general.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A major scientific advance was reported today in fathoming the complex biochemical and genetic processes going on in all living cells.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- President Kennedy and Premier Tage Erlander of Sweden agreed today that the West should do its utmost to strengthen the United Nations and the position of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.

Kidder, Peabody Co., Inc., and associates are offering to the public today 100,000 common shares of the Michigan Gas Utilities Company at $16 a share. Michigan Gas also announced that it planned to offer privately $3,500,000 of first mortgage 4 7/8 per cent bonds due in 1986.

Net earnings of the Aerojet-General Corporation for the three months ended on Feb. 28 rose to $2,498,082, or 54 cents a common share, from $2,134,113, or 47 cents a share, in the fiscal 1960 period, Dan A. Kimball, president, reported at the annual meeting in Akron, Ohio, yesterday.
HOLYOKE, Mass., March 29 (AP) -- Mrs. Raymond J. Feyre, already the mother of six children, gave birth to quadruplets today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 29 -- More than 100 representatives of twenty-seven nations and international organizations completed today a tend-day conference in Rome on the temporarily distressed fish meal industry, with assurances that recovery was under way.

MIAMI -- Jack Harshman fouled off the pitch and the ball shattered the right hand of Gus Triandos, the Oriole catcher. It knocked Gus out of participation in the second all-star game at Los Angeles in 1959. The problem of a replacement was immediately presented to Casey Stengel, the managerial mastermind of the American Leaguers.
A Fire Department sound truck cruised the streets of Chelsea yesterday, its loudspeaker blaring a warning against the peril of smoking in bed.

TUNIS, March 29 -- The Algerian nationalist Provisional Government indicated tonight in a communique that "consultations" by the French with other Algerian factions during the peace talks scheduled to begin April 7 would block the talks.

LOS ANGELES, March 29 (AP) -- Bob Pettit scored with twelve seconds remaining in an overtime period tonight and led the St. Louis Hawks to a 114-113 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers before a record home crowd of 14,863.
Labeling their offense "incredibly stupid," Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld fined Fortune and Anthony Pope $25,000 each yesterday for violating the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI) -- The Justice Department said today it would ask the United States Court of Appeals to order fifteen white Tennessee landlords to renew leases with twenty-three Negro sharecroppers prevented from farming land they had rented in the past.

Production of electric power eased in the week ended last Saturday to 14,291,000,000 kilowatt-hours from 14,295,000,000 the week earlier, the Edison Electric Institute reported ye yesterday. A year ago the figure was 14,062,000,000 kilowatt hours.
Ninety-two automobiles have been lopped off the municpal automobile fleet in two years, Mayor Wagner said yesterday. The resulting saving totals $315,000.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Senator Thruston B. Morton of Kentucky protested today that radio advertising practices used by a New York broadcaster during the 1960 campaign constituted an abuse of broadcasters' rights to editorialize.
Insurgent Democrats in Greenwich Village last night picked James S. Lanigan, a 42-year-old Harvard-educated lawyer, to run against Carmine G. De Sapio for district leader in September.

PARIS, March 29 -- French spokesmen declined today to discuss France's refusal to pay her share of the United Nations' costs in the Congo, but recalled the Government's reservations on military intervention there by the world organization.
KENOSHA, Wis., March 29 (AP) -- The American Motors Corporation announced today that it would raise Rambler production by 46 per cent and add about 4,000 employes starting on April 15.

Spruille Braden, former Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, called here yesterday for an "effective blockade" of Cuba as a step toward ending Communist intervention in that country.

The half-way mark has been passed in the 1961 campaign of the American Red Cross in Greater New York, 315 Lexington Avenue, New York 16, for $5,500,000 to provide the funds needed to carry on Red Cross services for the year ahead. Much of the money will be used for New York's support of national programs, including disaster relief and rehabilitation.
JACKSON, Miss., March 29 -- For the first time in their seven-year history, the Citizens' Councils face significant opposition in Mississippi, the state that gave them birth.

PALM DESERT, Calif., March 29 -- Members of the Japanese national student federation, known as Zengakuren, apologized today to former President Eisenhower and the American people for the part they played in last year's student riots.
LUANDA, Angola, March 28 -- In analyzing the violence in Angola in the last few weeks three points stand out.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 29 -- The Long Island Rail Road police pulled 33-year-old Albert Smith from atop a box car on a slow moving freight train last night.
CINCINNATI, March 29 (AP) -- A Cincinnati land developer, Kenneth Hammond, has undertaken a $35,000,000 resort area project at Jamaica in the West Indies.
LONDON, March 29 (Reuters) -- Three British breweries plan to merge into a new, 126,000,000 ($352,800,000) brewery group, it was announced today.

The nation's gasoline inventories reached a new peak of 226,668,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported. This represents an increase of 1,149,000 barrels from the 225,519,000 a week earlier. The previous peak of 225,987,000 barrels was established in the week ended on March 25, 1960.

NUREMBERG, Germany, March 29 (AP) -- The German police hinted today that sabotage might have caused the flaming crash of a Czechoslovak airliner loaded with Communist-bloc technicians, twenty-two of them Russians.

General Sessions Judge Charles Marks sentenced a confessed rapist and robber to sixty to 100 years in prison yesterday. It was one of the longest sentences ever given in a non-murder case in the history of the court.
Prices of United States Government obligations and other high-grade debt investments declined yesterday in a quiet trading session.
The board of directors of the Bulova Watch Company has elected Brig. Gen. Kenneth E. Fields (U.S. Army, Ret.) as executive vice president, it was announced yesterday by Harry B. Henshel, president.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A table in today's editions of The New York Times, comparing budget estimates of President Kennedy and President Eisenhower, contained several errors. Following are the correct figures:
The International Paper Company and the Lily-Tulip Cup Corporation announced yesterday that they had formed a jointly owned company to produce bleached paperboard for the two concerns.
A gunman in a white mask held up a gem merchant in his midtown office yesterday and escaped with diamonds the merchant said were worth $900,000.
A MONUMENTAL ceramic mural executed jointly by the contemporary Spanish artists Joan Miro and Joseph Llorens Artigas is having its American unveiling today at the Guggenheim Museum.

SITTING tight-lipped and stiff-backed on the edge of their seats, the six college boys quietly nursed their bourbon and displayed their best company manners. Their hostess, Mrs. Thomas W. Chrystie, the widow of a distinguished Columbia College alumnus, tried vainly to draw them into conversation with her five other guests: Prof. and Mrs. Moses Hadas; Prof. Edwin B. Matzke, and Samuel Walker, a Columbia trustee, and Mrs. Walker.

TOMORROW, at sunset, families of the Jewish faith will gather to celebrate one of the oldest holidays in the world. It is the festival of Passover, a name deriving from the miracle in Egypt more than 3,000 years ago when the Lord fulfilled His promise to Moses and passed over the homes of the Israelites while smiting the Egyptians.
ALBANY, March 29 -- The controversial Youth Court Act, which was on the statute books for five years without going into effect, has been repealed.
DENVER, March 29 (AP) -- The Colorado Supreme Court ordered today that Mrs. Vi Murphy, a Colorado Springs newspaper reporter, begin serving a thirty-day sentence for contempt on Monday.
YONKERS, March 29 -- Su Mac Lad, the gelding that last season banked more money ($159,662) than any other trotting horse, will make his first 1961 start tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway.
Admission of three new general partners was announced yesterday by investment banking concerns affiliated with the New York Stock Exchange.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29 -- It may have demanded considerable patience on the part of Ralph Houk, the manager, but the Yankees today got around to winning a game of the exhibition campaign on Al Lang Field.
G. Mennen Williams, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, expressed confidence yesterday in the usefulness of American private enterprise in the free countries of tropical Africa.

Much as we admire General de Gaulle, and we admire him as one of this century's greatest statesmen, we deeply regret his decision to follow the Soviet Union's example in refusing to pay a proportionate -- or in fact any -- share of the cost of the United Nations' military operation in the Congo.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 29 -- The question of whether Nassau County Executive A. Holly Patterson will continue as leader of the county Republican party remained unresolved today after a meeting of local Republican officials.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The military defense budget of the Administration for fiscal 1961-62 explains one reason why analysts of the vote for President in 1960 are unable to discover persuasive evidence that the campaign issue over the defense programs of the Eisenhower Administration had any controlling influence on the narrow national voting choice.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Administration supporters broke the Republican-Southern Democratic conservative coalition long enough today to push President Kennedy's $394,000,000 bill to aid depressed areas through the House of Representatives.

Two members of office personnel and two maintenance men have been added to the management division of the Kraham Realty Company, brokers and realty agents of Kew Gardens, Queens. The division now has a personnel of twenty-four, not including building superintendents and handy men.
The anti-Tammany faction of the Democratic party in the city voted last night to oppose the drive to seat Peter J. Crotty of Buffalo as Democratic state chairman.

Today's new film is "One- Eyed Jacks," a Western drama directed by Marion Brando, at the Capitol Theatre, Broadway and Fiftieth Street. Mr. Brando and Karl Malden play leading roles in the Paramount release, which was produced in color by Frank Rosenberg.

THE steady upward move of skirts is now a certainty this spring, making a shapely leg as important as a pretty face. Although a woman cannot change the structure of her legs, there are numerous ways of improving and correcting certain faults, according to Miss Charlotte Hess of Helena Rubinstein.
NORWALK, Conn., March 29 -- The bells of St. Mary's rang out today for the Angelus.

With the need for harnessing the savings of advanced nations to the world's backward areas becoming more urgent, study is being given to new ways to stimulate the flow of private investment money to underdeveloped nations.
GREAT NECK, L.I., March 29 -- A $2,385,000 bond issue to build a new grade school to relieve overcrowding in northern Great Neck was defeated tonight by a vote of 1,712 to 1,183.
AS a child prodigy, Daniel Ericourt knew Debussy. As a mature artist the French-born pianist became one of the better-known exponents of his compatriot's music.

HONOLULU March 29 (UPI) -- Hawaii will become the headquarters for one of the largest food companies in the United States if stockholders and Federal officials approve a planned $117,000,000 merger of two island companies and one on the mainland.

Two artists made their first appearances in Puccini's "Turandot" with the Metropolitan Opera last night. One was Leontyne Price, who took over the part of Liu as scheduled. The other was Giulio Gari, who replaced Franco Corelli as Calaf in the second and third acts of the opera.
MIAMI, March 29 (AP) -- Ingemar Johansson received permission today to leave this country and expressed amazement at American justice.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. March 29 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad is expected to renew its commuter service contract with New Jersey for another year. This became clear today following a public hearing on the contract at city hall here.

A FASCINATINGLY authentic look at the West, in which Billy the Kid finally was identified on television as "a homicidal moron from the slums of New York" and Calamity Jane as an "excessively soiled dove," gave the National Broadcasting Company last night its second filmed documentary hit in as many evenings.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- The Justice Department was reported today to be studying information volunteered by Bernard Goldfine, Boston industrialist, involving a number of prominent persons.
The ninety-first annual Ringling Bros. and Barnum Bailey Circus got off to a rousing start in Madison Square Garden last night.

Interests identified with Brown Guenther, architects, and the Cauldwell-Wingate Company, builders, have bought the property at the northwest corner of St. Nicholas and Fairview Avenues in the Inwood area of upper Manhattan.
The sale of Bull Steamship Company, Inc., to McLean Industries, Inc., was halted yesterday by the Department of Justice, informed shipping executives reported.
LORRAINE HANSBERRY'S fine play, "A Raisin in the Sun," has been turned into an equally fine screen drama. It opened at the Forum and the Trans-Lux Fifty-second Street yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, introduced his controversial bill today to place major professional boxing under tough Federal policing.
GENEVA, March 29 -- The United States asked today that a system of space satellites for patrolling a ban on nuclear testing be fully operational six years after ratification of such a ban.

The State Commission Against Discrimination, which for many years received virtually all its complaints from the New York City area, yesterday reported a growing use of its facilities by minority groups in upstate areas.

LONDON, March 29 -- Formation of a Council for Freedom in Portugal and Colonies, headed by three Labor Members of Parliament and sponsored by about fifty prominent Britons, was announced today in a further move toward a "united front" of opponents of the Salazar regime in Lisbon.
COLOR is in the air for spring. The stores are alive with it. Women welcome it. The experts urge wearing not one brilliant hue but several at a time.
The Living Theatre said yesterday that although it still did not have sufficient funds it would "in all likelihood" make a seven-week tour of Europe with three productions starting in June.

W.F. Gaunitz, former president of Associates Investment Company, South Bend, Ind., may become president and a director of General Acceptance Corporation, Allentown, Pa., the company announced yesterday.
Maundy Thursday will be marked today in a number of the city's churches. The holiday celebrates the Last Supper of Jesus with his disciples before the Crucifixion, on Good Friday.

There's no need trying to keep this one secret -- it was the very devil of a winter. Record snows, record cold and both compounded until a man seriously wondered whether he would live long enough to reach the office, get alone struggle home at night. For much of the winter, the yard was covered by a couple of feet of snow.

Charges that John E. Hand, a management agent and Democratic figure, and Hugh K. McGovern, a realty operator, had failed to provide essential services in a tenement on East Twenty-eighth Street were dismissed in Upper Manhattan Arrest Court yesterday.
Should new schools be built near airport runways?

Events tonight: "Wozzeck," Metropolitan Opera, 8 o'clock; New York Philharmonic preview concert, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Martha Lipton, mezzo-soprano, Women's Chorus of Schola Cantorum, Boys Choir of Little Church Around the Corner, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Music of Ray Crabtree, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:15.
WORCESTER, Mass., March 29 -- The resignation of Roy Leenig as head basketball coach at Holy Cross College was reported imminent today.
Mikhail Botvinnik of Moscow extended his lead yesterday in the twenty-five-game series for the world chess championship.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., March 29 -- Officials of Essex County municipalities through which the proposed east-west freeway would pass objected today to the passage of legislation to finance it before firm plans showing how it would affect their communities were completed.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A drive for separate legislation authorizing Federal loans for construction of private schools got under way today with the introduction of a bill in the Senate.

CHICAGO, March 29 (AP) -- The steepest general slide in several weeks sent nearly all grain futures prices to their lowest levels of the season in an explosive burst of selling shortly after noon today on the Board of Trade.

The men and women who assist and advise President Kennedy are discussed by Judith Friedberg in a book called "The New Frontiersmen." The author for several years has worked for agencies of the Government in Europe and in Washington, and has been a reporter here and abroad.

Another proxy solicitation by the management of the Alleghany Corporation, its third for the annual meeting on May 1 in Baltimore, was mailed to the holding company's stockholders last night. Control of the company, held by Allan P. Kirby, chairman, is being contested by the Murchison brothers of Dallas, Tex.

THERE is no error in the diagram of the bridge hand and bidding. It was the West hand (shown where North's hand usually appears) that bid one heart, and the North hand (shown in the usual West position) that overcalled with four no-trump, even though North's strength consisted of one lonely jack.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 29 -- The United States recommended the framework of Puerto Rico's Operation Bootstrap today to under-developed nations looking toward industrialization.
Several thousand members of nearly fifty New York local unions picketed Macy's for an hour yesterday in support of the store's organized workers.

CHICAGO, March 29 (AP) -- Parts of at least, seven states remained under water today as rivers and streams overflowed their banks. Thousands were homeless and the threat of more rain or snow posed new dangers.
Richard Rothenberg, the smallest member of Columbia's fencing team, was honored last night for being scholastically the college's highest ranking athlete.

Backed by a unanimous resolution of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization, the United States and its allies now await with guarded optimism the Soviet response to their proposals for settling the conflict over Laos by negotiation and not by force. The optimism rests on the preliminary, though conditional, Soviet assurances on this score.

New York City banks have been chafing in recent years at deposits lost because more and more of their large corporate customers pared working balances and invested idle cash in such securities as Treasury bills.
BANGKOK, Thailand, March 29 (AP) -- Following is the text of the communique issued today by the Council of Ministers of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization after its seventh annual conference:

Assets of the American Heritage Life Insurance Company increased to $19,658,863 in 1960 from $11,717,234 a year earlier, according to the annual report. Net investment income also increased during the year, rising to $508,368 from $306,341 a year earlier.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, March 29 -- Tanganyika is to become independent Dec. 28.

Eighty inspectors of the Markets Department cracked down yesterday on butcher shops and meat markets in a drive against short-weight sales of food in pre-holiday shopping. By the end of the day the inspectors had served forty summonses.
LONDON, March 29 -- The United States won agreement today on most of the points of its new plan for increasing and improving aid to the under-developed countries.

"We would not be able to master our sheep if it were not for the Kelpie," said J.K. Roche of North Adelade, a 31-year-old Australian rancher, real estate dealer and dog judge at one of the recent shows.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- President Kennedy today nominated Joseph P. Hoey, assistant district attorney of Kings County, as United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York.

The May and July cottonseed oil positions climbed to new seasonal highs in early trading yesterday on the New York Produce Exchange. Commission house buying firmed quotations at the opening. Selling against purchases of soybean oil were noted.
MOSCOW, March 29 (AP) -- The Warsaw Pact conference ended its second meeting today amid growing rumors that the Soviet Union might withdraw additional troops from member countries.

PARIS, March 29 -- France proceeded today with plans to consult "other factions" in the complex Algerian situation despite warnings by the principal Algerian rebel organization that such action jeopardized the chances of success of the forthcoming peace negotiations with it.
A HOST of fond and ribald images irradiate "Under Milk Wood," Dylan Thomas' earthy and rapturous incantation to a small Welsh town like the one in which he was born.
Kentucky raised $100,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance payment of a bonus to war veterans.

MANY cooks keep in the refrigerator sharp American cheese and Parmesan cheese, grated or ready to grate. With these cheeses and a few eggs a delicious and satisfying puffy omelet can be made in very few minutes. Asparagus, coming into the market now, suggests an attractive accompaniment.

The American Red Cross in Greater New York this month is conducting its annual campaign for members and funds. The goal is $5,500,000 -- the minimum urgently needed for local, national and international Red Cross services in the year ahead.

A PRE-EASTER search of shops this week turned up any number of bright ideas for last-minute additions for spring costumes. Without going any farther than the first floor, the following "extras" were uncovered: Tailored Woman has a whole wardrobe of handbags for the price of one.

The United Federation of Teachers, (A.F.L.-C.I.O.) which called the city's first teachers' strike last November, threatened yesterday to "continue pressure on City Hall" until its salary demands were met.
A sharply critical analysis of the economic programs of the Kennedy Administration was given last night by the former Secretary of Labor, James P. Mitchell.

Pete Seeger, the folk singer, was convicted of contempt of Congress yesterday by a jury in Federal Court. He was found guilty on all ten counts of an indictment charging him with refusing to answer questions by the House Committee on Un- American Activities.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 29 -- Maj. Gen. Joseph D. Mobutu reported today that military forces loyal to the regime of Antoine Gizenga had pulled back along a 200-mile zone between Eastern and Equator Provinces.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- President Kennedy asked Congress today for more money to study the secrets of the oceans. "Our very survival may hinge upon it," he said.

GOLDEN, Colo., March 29 (AP) -- Joseph Corbett Jr., 32 years old, was convicted late today of murdering Adolph Coors 3d thirteen months ago in a $500,000 kidnap scheme. The verdict carries a mandatory sentence of life in prison.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, March 29 -- Leaders of eighteen Latin-American democratic parties, representing eleven separate countries and Puerto Rico, have declared their solid support for the principles contained in President Kennedy's "Alliance for Progress" speech made earlier this month.

The Liberal party released its appraisal of the 1961 legislative session yesterday. It is being sent to Governor Rockefeller and legislators elected with Liberal support. The memorandum says, "Generally speaking, the Legislature enacted a body of good legislation."
A small budget campaign, costing less than $100,000, has had such a remarkable impact that it is worthy of special note.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Congress agreed late today on a fifteen-month extension of the President's authority to prohibit Cuban sugar imports and to share its quota among other foreign and domestic producers.
LONDON, March 29 -- Britain's' international balance of payments position deteriorated last year.
LONDON, March 29 -- The appointment of a special committee of inquiry to review Britain's security policies was announced today in the House of Commons.
Supporters of the Society of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center will herald the coming of summer at a tea dance May 15 at the Pierre.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 29 -- Britain and Canada prepared today to come to the aid of the United Nations in its growing financial crisis.

The Catholic position on education (which is merely a reaffirmation of the natural law, and would be a position that would exist even if there were no Catholics) is that the parents of children have the natural duty, and correlative right, to educate their children so as to enable them to live proper lives.

Brazilian airline executives here foresee a pooling arrangement for the country's three international carriers, one of which serves New York, as a result of a meeting called by President Janio Quadros of Brazil for next Monday.
LONDON, March 29 -- The stock market maintained its advance here today, particularly among industrials.

American Cyanamid Company announced yesterday it had signed an agreement for Cyanamid to purchase Wasco Chemical Company, Inc., Cambridge, Mass., producer of cast plastic products for the construction industry. Terms of the transaction were not released, but the agreement calls for the exchange of Cyanamid common stock for substantially the entire business and assets of Wasco, which has four plants and employs more than 400.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Supreme Court was asked today to decide whether a Vermont school district might constitutionally pay tuition for students at Roman Catholic parochial schools.
CHICAGO, March 29 (AP) -- Ray Patterson, with his brother Floyd watching at ringside, won the final bout and led New York to a 9-to-7 triumph over Chicago in the Golden Gloves tonight.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 29 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy announced today the appointment of Mrs. John N. Pearce to a newly created position of curator of the White House.
The Ne(v York Philarmonie !has announced the names of ]twenty-one soloists scheduled to appear with the orchestra in Ithe 1961-62 season.
A 16-year-old youth was killed and a 19-year-old drugstore clerk was wounded in unrelated shootings in Harlem last night.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fell 7 to 12 points (35 to 60 cents a bale) yesterday.
CINCINNATI, March 29 (AP) -- The ownership of the Cincinnati Reds will pass to a charitable foundation, but with the expressed desire from Powel Crosley Jr. that the club remain here.
Arrangements are being made to usher in "Sail Away," a musical comedy by Noel Coward that has been marking time since 1959, to New York in October.
The Philadelphia and Reading Corporation has assumed active control of Fruit of the Loom, Inc., as a consequence of its acquisition of about 95 per cent of the outstanding stock of Fruit of the Loom.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI) -- John R. Neale served as chief of the United States foreign aid mission in Peru while he was the main stockholder in a cattle business helped by aid funds, House investigators were told today.

NORWALK, Conn., March 29 -- The young patients at Norwalk Hospital think Animal Day is such a happy event that sometimes they delay going home until after the animals' visit each Tuesday. Yesterday was no exception.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The United States finally gave its capital the vote today. As a result, for the first time in more than 160 years, Washingtonians will be able to vote for President and Vice President in 1964.
Your editorial of March 25 "Triangle Fire Anniversary," suggesting that the Albert-Folmer bill be vetoed, proved more than timely.

Homeward-bound commuters on the New Haven Railroad found themselves in a state of confusion at Grand Central Terminal last night after a derailment of two cars had caused power to be shut off on eleven tracks.

Bob Banner, executive producer of "The Garry Moore Show," has obtained television rights to "Once Upon a Mattress." He plans to adapt the musical comedy for a special hour-long show starring Mr. Moore and Carol Burnett.
Time, Inc., the nation's largest publishing company, raised its earnings and set a new record in revenues last year, James A. Linen, president, and Andrew Heiskell, chairman, reported today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. March 29 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold implied today that the Government of the Congo was frustrating United Nations efforts there.
Passover, the ancient festival of freedom, will begin tomorrow at sundown for the Jewish people.
The wife and children of Bernard Weinberg, a director of Consolidated Sun Ray, Inc., have sold 14,300 shares of common stock, reducing their holdings in the comany to 202,268 shares.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 29 -- The United States and the Soviet Union agreed today to recommend that a debate on the disarmament question be postponed until the autumn session of the General Assembly.

UNION SPRINGS, N.Y., March 29 (AP) -- "Ladies and gentlemen, this is a Federal Communications Commission agent. Radio station WHTR is now going off the air permanently because of unlicensed, unlawful broadcasting on a noncommercial frequency."
The recent history of Laos suggests that when peace is restored there, the really difficult task will arise: the task of solving the problems that led to the rupture of peace in the first place.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Kennedy Administration was described today as not entirely satisfied with the warning that the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization gave to the Communists on Laos.

Earnings of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., and its subsidiary in 1960 were slightly more than double those of the year before, the company reported yesterday. The gain was achieved despite the loss of about 4,175,000 passengers during the year. The company said that the greatest single cause of this loss was "the one-waying of Third and Lexington Avenues on July 17, 1960."
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- President Kennedy asked Congress today to help the home owner carry out his own "do it yourself" urban-renewal program.
PRETORIA, South Africa, March 29 -- The twenty-eight South Africans on trial since 1956 for high treason were found not guilty today and discharged.
Mrs. Robert E. Coulson will give a tea at the Union Club Tuesday to honor the debutantes who are to be presented at the Mistletoe Ball at the Pierre on Dec. 23, and their mothers.

The appointment of Sigo L. Lawrence as general merchandise manager of the soft goods division of Gimbels New York and its branches, effective April 10, was announced yesterday by Julius Schutzman, executive head of the Gimbels New York organization.
The recent history of Laos suggests that when peace is restored there, the really difficult task will arise: the task of solving the problems that led to the rupture of peace in the first place.

FOOD, farmers and his fellow men are the three foundation stones upon which George Stanley McGovern has built his philosophy of life. It can be summed up in one statement by the 38-year-old South Dakotan, now director of the Food-for-Peace program:

THE newest antiques shop to intrigue collectors of eighteenth-century pieces is David Laurence Roth, Inc., 833 Madison Avenue. Strollers in the vicinity of Sixty-ninth Street will find this shop hard to miss. For in honor of today's opening the store's large picture window displays a lovely English garden banked with orange and gold azaleas, interspersed with garden urns.

Christians over the city will pause today to recall in prayer and meditation the Crucifixion of Jesus Christ. The solemn rites will culminate on Sunday in the joyful celebration of the Resurrection on Easter Day.

New securities offered here to the public in March declined for the third successive month from the offerings of a year earlier. Last month's total of new bonds issued rose, however, to the largest amount since last August and stock flotations to the highest level since November, 1960.

When the Moiseyev Dance Company from Moscow opens its second American tour at the Metropolitan Opera House on April 18, under the direction of S. Hurok. Its program will include ten new numbers, one of which is a world premiere.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 30 -- Adlai E. Stevenson said today that he saw "no other solution" for the Congo except a federal system and noted, with implied approval, that Congolese leaders were "groping" for such a solution.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 30 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller of New York today described as "a tempest in a teapot" the criticism by Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey on the stalemate on legislation to acquire the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
FORT PIERCE, Fla., March 30 (AP) -- Joseph A. Peel Jr. was convicted today of having plotted the murder of Circuit Judge C.E. Chillingworth, but the jury recommended mercy.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 30 -- The United States indicated today that it would not support punitive measures against South Africa as a means of opposing the policy of racial segregation there.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- About 100 Navy flag officers from stations and commands outside Washington reported to the Navy Department today for a two-day briefing session.

The recent Times editorial commended the legislative program and the general contribution of the Prison Association of New York, whose name has since been changed to the Correctional Association of New York. We endorse the emphasis given in the editorial to the proposition that "crime and delinquency cannot be reduced merely by stricter enforcement and longer periods of detention."
The Central Railroad Company of New Jersey will apply today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for a Federal guarantee of a $15,000,000 loan.
MIAMI BEACH, March 30 (AP) -- Two upsets in the quarter-finals today blocked an all-Australia final in the thirteenth annual Good Neighbor tennis championships here.
Employes of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company voted unanimously last night to reject a two-year contract offered by the company. Their union has threatened to strike at midnight tonight.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 30 -- King Baudouin today appointed Pierre Harmel, Minister of Public Administration in the present caretaker Cabinet, to advise him on the political effects of last Sunday's national election.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 30 -- The United States came to the aid of the United Nations today in the organization's growing financial crisis.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI) -- Following is the list of military installations to be reduced or discontinued by the United States:
CLEVELAND, March 30 (AP) -- Eight persons, four of them small children, died in a fire that destroyed an East Side tenement house before dawn today.

A new roar is resounding in the jungle of fashion cosmetics marketing. Lanolin Plus, Inc., has entered the traditional domain of such marketing lions as Revlon and Northam Warren with a nail enamel and strengthener called Color Plus.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 30 (AP) -- Enver Hoxha, First Secretary of Albania's Communist party, refused to attend the Warsaw Pact conference in Moscow this week because he feared for his life, a foreign diplomatic source said today.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30 (AP) -- The appointment of Leo Durocher as manager of the new Houston club in the National League became a distinct possibility today following a twenty-minute conference between Durocher and Houston's general manager, Gabe Paul.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Pentagon made known today the sites of the fifty-two domestic military bases or installations that are being closed or reduced for economy reasons. Twenty-one installations abroad will also be hit by the new economy drive.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI) -- The Senate passed and sent to the White House today a $1,600,000,000 supplemental money bill. It eliminated nearly $2,900,000,000 earmarked earlier for the farm program.
CHICAGO, March 30 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Mrs. Clyde J. Harris will give a tea tomorrow afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria for persons who are taking part in plans for the twenty-eighth annual ball of the Kosciuszko Foundation. Mrs. Harris heads the reception committee for the event, which will take place next Friday at the Waldorf.

VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., March 30 (UPI) -- The Air Force failed today to orbit a Discoverer Satellite with a recoverable capsule carrying living tissue to gauge cosmic radiation that might face the first United States astronaut.

Production of lumber totaled 217,054,000 board feet in the week ended March 25, compared with 216,811,000 board feet in the prior week, according to reports received yesterday from regional associations. In the 1960 period the figure was 263,247,000 board feet.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 30 -- Matters still aren't moving so smoothly with the Yankees as Manager Ralph Houk would like. But they are improving. There was ample evidence of this today as the Bombers beat the Detroit Tigers, 5 to 4, for the second successive day.

ROME, March 30 -- In a tribute to the humility shown by Jesus at the Last Supper, Pope John XXIII knelt and washed the feet of thirteen student priests during the Holy (Maundy) Thursday Mass this evening. The mass commemorates the institution of the Eucharist, the sacrament of the Lord's Supper.
