Dealer transactions in United States Government securities declined $18,000,000 to $1,516,000,000 on a daily average basis in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Dealer transactions in United States Government agency securities declined $33,000,000 to $85,000,000.

The Commission on Governmental Operations of the City of New York issued a final report yesterday in which it declared the principles it had urged to improve the city's fiscal position had "stood the test of analysis over the past year."

MENLO PARK, N.J., March 30 -- A retired Scottish seaman, turned back yesterday at the gangway of the Queen Elizabeth, will get his final wish after all -- to return to his family home in Dundee on the Firth of Tay to die.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 30 -- President Kennedy announced tonight the selection of a National Advisory Council for the Peace Corps.

Net earnings of the Union Pacific Railroad Company in the first two months of this year were higher than in 1960 because of a substantial rise in income from Wyoming oil operations, the concern reported yesterday.
The Norfolk and Western Railway and the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway announced yesterday that they planned to go into the barge line business.

PARIS, March 30 -- France and the Algerian rebel Provisional Government issued today simultaneous and similarly worded announcements of the opening of peace talks at Evian-les-Bains, on Lake Geneva, April 7.
DETROIT, March 30 (UPI) -- The recession-troubled automobile industry will end the first quarter of 1961 on an optimistic note.

Commodity futures prices closed irregularly higher in dull trading yesterday on the New York exchanges. All markets will be closed today in observance of Good Friday. There was evening up of holdings in preparation for the long weekend.
BALTIMORE, March 30 -- The Mount Washington Lacrosse Club defeated Hofstra College, 21-8, today. The victory was unbeaten Mount Washington's third straight over college competition.

The International Longshoremen's Association welcomed yesterday a suggestion by Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey that a poll of dock workers be made on legislation designed to increase the Waterfront Commission's powers.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 30 -- The General Assembly's Political Committee complied today with a joint request from the United States and the Soviet Union that a debate on disarmament be postponed until the next session of the Assembly in September.
BAYONNE, N.J., March 30 -- A heavy trailer-truck smashed into a car on the New Jersey Turnpike this afternoon, killing a young Brooklyn rabbi and two of his sons.

The following table gives the amount of dealings in the stocks from which the averages are computed; the combined trading in both classes of issues, as well as the total daily transactions for week and month:

Genesco, Inc., whose manufacturing operations range from shoes and clothing to fine jewelry and silverware, announced yesterday that it had entered the perfume business by acquiring Parfum Givenchy, Inc, Parfum Millot, Inc., and the Paul D. Blackman Corporation.
APARTMENT dwellers in Ghana suffer as much from the shortage of space in their homes as do New Yorkers, a native of that African country said this week.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 30 (UPI) -- Ed P. Schafer's 3-year-old pacer, Lumber Dream, the favorite, won the Santa Anita Purse today by fourteen lengths in the brilliant time of 1:58 2/5 over a mile track.
Although the golf scores of President Kennedy and former President Eisenhower are guarded secrets, Mr. Kennedy apparently is the better natural golfer.

THE changing society of Great Britain was the theme of last night's filmed installment of "C.B.S. Reports" over Channel 2. Not only did the program perform the happy function of restoring Eric Sevareid to television at his perceptive and witty best; it also was a valuable insight into the diverse forces that are reshaping the durable isles.
Since 1886, countless civilians have entered the pseudo-Gothic, wine-red building at 39 Whitehall Street, which is almost within saluting distance of Governors Island, and have left it as soldiers.
A father and stepmother were held for homicide in Queens yesterday on charges of beating their 13-year-old daughter to death because she had been getting unsatisfactory grades in school.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Factory sales, inventories and new orders in February gave strong new evidence that the recession was reaching bottom.
The news that it's thirty years since a hotel was last built in Our Town comes as a shock to those of us who have always looked upon New York as much for fun as for commerce and finance.
KEARNY, N.J., March 30 -- The Western Electric Company has 3,000 goldfish it wants to give away, or maybe it's 5,000.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These rates do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.
Midtown Park Avenue was dressed for Easter with beds of lilies and other spring flowers yesterday.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., March 30 -- The X-15 rocket plane attained a world altitude record of more than thirty-one miles today despite an engine failure immediately after it was launched. The test pilot, Joseph A. Walker, flew the snub-nosed experimental ship 31.25 miles above the earth -- so high he said he could see all the California coast, as well as part of Oregon and Lower California, Mexico.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- President Kennedy rests in Florida and Congress has dispersed for the Easter holiday. Thus, this capital has a few moments of unaccustomed leisure to look back on the first seventy days of the Kennedy Administration.

President Kennedy's message on foreign aid is marked by an enormous advance in sophistication and thinking about the foreign aid problem. In no manner is this more clearly shown than in his recognition of the impact on foreign aid of the enormous growth of population.

The United States monetary gold stock held steady at $17,389,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This was the fifth consecutive week in which the gold stock remained unchanged or rose.
THE Composers' Showcase last night presented a program of beautiful chamber music. All of it was by Walter Piston.

Preliminary estimates of 1960 operations of Webb Knapp, Inc., indicate the company will show a "modest" profit, William Zeckendorf Jr., executive vice president, said yesterday at a meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 30 -- The heads of the "independent states" of the proposed Congo confederation will meet in Katanga Province next Wednesday, the Government of Premier Joseph Ileo announced tonight.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 30 -- Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union signed a new five-year trade agreement today cvering the 1961-65 period. It provides for a steady increase in exchanges up to a level two and a half times the 1960 volume.

Mayor Wagner submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday a record expense budget of $2,542,120,936 for the fiscal year starting July 1. It was $189,062,426 higher than the current budget of $2,353,058,510.

LIKE garlic, charm deliberately introduced into a work of art is an ingredient that must be used with utmost discretion. In his sensitive and appealing portaits and conversation pieces at the Davis Galleries, 231 East Sixtieth Street, Aaron Shikler employs it with dangerous liberality for today's puritanical taste.

It is of the utmost importance to the future of New York City, its schools and citizens that the present possibility of acquiring Channel 13, Station WNTA-TV, for non-profit, educational and cultural television should not be allowed to slip by.

The appointment of Puerto Rico's Teodoro Moscoso as United States Ambassador to Caracas, Venezuela, is one of the truly felicitous initiatives of the Kennedy Administration. Mr. Moscoso's fellow Puerto Rican, Arturo Morales Carrion, was previously named a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State in the Bureau of Inter-American Affairs.

WITH the opening of an Americana 1961 festival today, shoppers will have no difficulty in finding American furnishings in Altman's. Room settings flank the Country Shop on the seventh floor, table settings are shown in the main alley on the fourth floor and accessories take over the fifth floor.

A 4,000-mile "run" by three British track stars threatened yesterday to dislocate Anglo-American athletic relations. The finish line of the trans-Atlantic race is the University of Southern Illinois' varsity team.

In a critical column from Cairo published March 25 C.L. Sulzberger attributed to The Port of New York Authority responsibilities which rest only with the Federal Government. The Port Authority has no jurisdiction whatsoever over rules and regulations governing United States customs and immigration practices.
WASHINGTON, March, 30 (UPI) -- A top cast of present and former champions will be asked to testify at Senate hearings on legislation to create a Federal boxing commissioner, it was learned today.
LONDON, March 30 -- British leaders urged former Premier Souvanna Phouma tonight to return to Laos and work for a broadly based neutral government.
ALBANY, March 30 -- The state's law against selling obscene literature was upheld today by the Court of Appeals.

SESTRI LEVANTE, Italy, March 30 (AP) -- A Rome-bound express train from Turin caught fire tonight in a tunnel near this Riviera resort. Flames and smoke trapped its 450 passengers, including foreign tourists, and killed at least five.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 30 -- The United Nations has managed to pay off an old debt -- the $8,200,000 borrowed three years ago to clear the Suez Canal. The funds were borrowed from eleven countries, with the United States providing $5,000,000.
Reductions in air cargo rates up to 40 per cent on domestic eastbound flights were announced yesterday by Trans World Airlines. The new rates will become effective Sunday.

State Supreme Court Justice Birdie Amsterdam granted yesterday a temporary injunction sought by Pepsi-Cola United Bottlers, Inc., to restrain the estate of James W. Carkner from selling 282,380 shares and Mrs. Grace Carkner from disposing of 9,900 shares of Pepsi-Cola General, Inc., pending trial of the issues.
A strike of keepers and other employes at the Bronx Zoo and the Coney Island Aquarium at midnight tonight was threatened yesterday by a union of Civil Service employes.
Stock transactions on the New York Stock Exchange in March and the first three months of this year were the largest on record for the periods.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Expectations grew here today that the Soviet Union would soon make its counter-proposal for a peaceful settlement of the Laotian crisis.
The Bleecker Street Cinema and the New Yorker Theatre, which specialize in unusual revival programs, have scheduled extended film series to begin their second seasons of operation.
JACKSON, Miss., March 30 -- The Sovereignty Commission agreed today to continue granting state funds to the Citizens Councils for pro-segregation propaganda.

New York City will participate in a care for the aged program under legislation recently enacted by the state, Welfare Commissioner James R. Dumpson announced yesterday. Under the Federally aided program, welfare recipients more than 65 would be given complete care and services.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Kennedy Administration has decided, at least for the time being, not to add to the $104,000,000 Eisenhower budget request for civil defense.
The city's Health Code laws apply to the city as well as to any other tenement owner and operator, a magistrate in Upper Manhattan Summons Court observed yesterday.

Carol Kuzen, Jay Reid and Madeline Miyamoto, the biggest hits at Fairleigh Dickinson University since midnight math, arrived in Duisburg, Germany, yesterday for the women's world junior fencing championships.
Following are excerpts from the communique issued at the close of the Warsaw Pact meeting in Moscow yesterday, as transmitted by Tass, the official Soviet press agency:
Four college students with tired feet marched into Times Square yesterday to wind up a 237-mile hike designed to spur President Kennedy's physical fitness program.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $26,000,000 to $78,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $102,000,000 to $611,000,000.
The Board of Education's plan to improve the reading ability of pupils suffered a setback yesterday, less than twenty-four hours after it had been announced.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Top executives of the largest railroads attacked today proposals in Congress for stricter rate-making regulations in the transportation industry.

Candidates for the Presidency in 1964, and thereafter, will find it worth while to cultivate the goodwill of permanent residents of the District of Columbia. These persons, if of proper age and otherwise qualified, can now vote for electors to the Electoral College. Their three additional votes in the College might turn a close election.
Following is a digest of Mayor Wagner's message to the Board of Estimate and the City Council yesterday, submitting his executive budget for the fiscal year 1961-62, which begins July 1:

The Mount Pleasant and North Castle, N.Y., Central School District sold yesterday $3,150,000 of bonds due from 1962 to 1990 to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates. The price paid was 100.059 for obligations bearing 3 1/2 per cent interest.

A new book by Paul Taborl, author of "The Natural History of stupidity," will be published by the Chilton Company of Philadelphia tomorrow, April Fool's Day. It is "The Art of Folly," which chronicles the whims and fantastic events that have characterized the lives of "homo sapiens" through the ages.
Three hundred and forty-two city-owned properties brought prices amounting to $2,401,810 at a three-day auction sale that ended yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A dramatic expansion of the Food-for-Peace program into "an instrument of the nation's foreign economic policy" was recommended today by its director, George S. McGovern, in a report to President Kennedy.
BONN, Germany, March 30 -- Steps to acquaint the German people with the role of German Jewish soldiers in World War I were announced tonight by a spokesman for the West German Defense Ministry.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI) -- The Democratic National Committee has yet to pay the pipers for President Kennedy's inaugural eve gala, and the pipers are beginning to get impatient.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- Paul G. Hoffman, managing director of the United Nations Special Fund, presented before the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations today a plan for foreign aid to assist in the development of low-income countries.

Stocks ended the day, the month and the first quarter yesterday on an uncertain note. There was a small loss, on average, in the prices of securities listed on the New York Stock Exchange. However, more issues rose than declined.

THE eggs have it this week-end. The Easter shopper who cannot afford the variety in Tiffany's window that casually drips diamonds from its broken shell, can at least splurge on the unadorned supermarket version.

Bonds called for redemption before maturity aggregated $52,458,000 in March, compared with $29,971,000 in February and $34,302,000 in March, 1960. This was the highest level of prepayments since September, 1960, when $52,559,000 of bonds was redeemed.

PARIS, March 30 -- "West Side Story" came to Paris tonight and a glittering audience of diplomats and show-business personalities were on hand to greet it. The performance at the Alhambra-Maurice Chevalier marked the first social appearance of recently arrived United States Ambassador James M. Gavin.
Ingemar Johansson arrived by plane from Palm Beach, Fla., late yesterday. He was on his way to Europe.
LONDON, March 30 -- Strong and persistent buying of brewery shares was the highlight of the stock market here today and gains between a shilling (14 cents) and 4 shillings (56 cents) were common.
The country's biggest commercial hydrofoil vessel will be ready for testing this summer and the Maritime Administration is seeking an operator.
BANGKOK, Thailand, March 30 -- Secretary of State Rusk scored an impressive personal success among the delegates attending the Southeast Asia Treaty conference just concluded here.
CHICAGO, March 30 -- Two Chicago utilities, Illinois Bell Telephone Company and Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company, announced major financing steps today.
HAVANA, March 30 -- Premier Fidel Castro turned from the affairs of state to golf yesterday and expressed confidence that he could beat President Kennedy at the game.
ALBANY, March 30 -- Two former agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were appointed to newly created state police positions today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 30 -- Brazil, the kingpin of world coffee production, is determined to stabilize its inflation-ridden economy without undermining international coffee prices.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 30 -- Hawaii freight operations of Matson Navigation Company resulted in a loss before taxes of $35,000 on gross revenue of $72,000,000 during 1960, according to the company's annual report issued today.

If Mayor Wagner's surgical incision has substantially healed by early next week he plans to leave the city for a short vacation, his City Hall office announced yesterday. There was no indication of where he would go.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 30 -- News that the sprawling Raritan Arsenal in near-by Edison will be closed within three years drew mixed reactions today from public officials.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- When Sonny Randle was in the seventh grade, he was hit on an ear by a pitched ball. He dropped his bat, walked away and hasn't played baseball since. But he was an important figure in the early pre-season exercises of the St. Louis Cardinals, his grossly inadequate diamond background to the contrary.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 30 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Commercial Credit Company approved today a share-for-share stock distribution. The distribution will be made on May 1 to stockholders of record of April 5.

THE annual ceremony of opening the trout season will be held tomorrow with customary pomp and the prospect that the celebrants will be more numerous than ever, good weather or bad. There are reasons for this brilliant outlook.

MIAMI, March 30 (UPI) -- Investigators said today they had arrested the inventor of device that permits callers to make free use of the telephone company's do-it-yourself long distance dialing system. It also allows callers to get their dimes back on local calls from pay telephone booths.
The break in the North Atlantic telephone cable that occurred a week ago yesterday has still not been repaired because an ice field is barring the way of the cable ship.

Positive signs indicating that "the general business decline is abating" and that "steel production should rise faster than the over-all economy" were noted yesterday by a leading steel industry official.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Most members of Congress went home today, ready to combine the Easter vacation with the annual mid-session sampling of public opinion.

ALEXANDER M. SOBEL, the chief tournament director of the American Contract Bridge League, celebrates this week both the thirtieth anniversary of his professional life as a director of bridge tournaments and his sixtieth birthday, which was Tuesday.

HAVANA, March 30 -- Government radio commentators urged Cubans today to go to the new Government beaches and sports centers for diversion and to "meditate" on the benefits of the revolution during Holy Week.
An investigation is being made by the city Fire Marshal's office into a $500,000 fire last Saturday morning at the Ace Wire and Cable Company, 151-02 Eighty-third Street, Howard Beach, Queens.
Will the family of a renowned young pianist killed in a 1953 airline crash collect only $8,300 damages because of a controversial international treaty?

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City declined $15,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. In the comparable week a year ago, there was no change.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A new approach to the problem of wiretapping was proposed today by Senator Thomas J. Dodd.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 30 -- Murray Rose, a constant factor in a sport of ephemeral values, stroked smoothly to the 1,500-meter free-style title as the Amateur Athletic Union's national indoor swimming championships opened today.
LONDON, March 30 -- Britain's Foreign Secretary declared today that there was "a very real danger" that the Communists would take over South Vietnam.

A plan to merge the Chance Vought Corporation and Ling-Temco Electronics, Inc., has been approved in principle by the boards of both companies, a joint statement announced yesterday. The merger plan is subject to approval by stockholders of both companies.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 30 -- Two historical portraits -- one of George Washington, the other of Gen. Nathanael Greene -- that had been presumed lost since about 1783, when they left this country for England, have been returned to their homeland.

The oysters Jacqueline, the lobster with Nairobi sauce and the beef Bourguignon were good Chez Health Department yesterday. The ice cream wasn't bad, either, but it had to be made by prescription and flown in from Chicago.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Activities of the John Birch Society drew demands in Congress today for an investigation of the ultra-conservative organization and its leader, Robert H.W. Welch Jr.

Stuart T. Saunders, chairman of the board of American Coal Shipping Company, said yesterday that the company hoped to dispose of its only operating subsidiary, the A.H. Bull Steamship Company, "at an early date."

WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI) -- Government officials denied today that they had looked the other way while the chief of the foreign aid program in Peru built up a $200,000 interest in a Peruvian cattle business.
The State University will challenge a court decision that would force the Commissioner of Education to arbitrate grievances of faculty members.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 30 -- Joseph V. Kelly, former Riverhead Town Supervisor, was found murdered this morning in his ransacked bachelor apartment. He had been stabbed many times in the back and chest with a penknife, apparently after a struggle.
YONKERS, March 30 -- Su Mac Lad led from start to finish and achieved the fastest clocking of the local harness-racing season in winning the $25,000 Inaugural Trot tonight at Yonkers Raceway.
The chairman of the National Mediation Board will enter the dispute between 800 lighter captains and seven port railroads next week in an effort to head off a strike threatened for April 12.
A further downward drift of prices in the market for United States Government securities was checked yesterday by purchases of the Federal Reserve System.
Four days of Easter weather, with only the suggestion of a nip in the air, have helped the stores considerably in their efforts to brighten the Easter parade.

MOSCOW, Friday, March 31 (AP) -- The only reference to Laos in the Warsaw Pact communique today was in a passage in which the West was accused of making desperate efforts to prevent "disintegration" of the colonial system.
DALLAS, Tex., March 30 (AP) -- Mr. Ling had given notice to Chance Vought that they planned to conduct a proxy fight to gain control of the company at its annual meeting on April 25.

Dennis McDonald has been removed as vice president and treasurer of Theatrical Interests Plan, an investment-producing group with more than 800 stockholders. Mr. McDonald will remain under contract though, as an employe until September.

International revenues of Trans World Airlines, Inc., which last year rose 35.2 per cent over those of 1959, were responsible for lifting total revenues of the airline 8.6 per cent to a record of $378,350,375 from $348,458,430 the year before.
VIENTIANE, Laos, March 30 -- The Laotian Government hailed today the communique of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization conference that ended yesterday in Bangkok, Thailand.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 30 (UPI) -- The Alabama Supreme Court upheld today the revocation of a "quickie divorce" obtained by a Yonkers, N.Y., couple in 1954.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) made an $8,400,000 loan yesterday to the Protectorate of Uganda for the extension of the electric power transmission and distribution systems of the Uganda Electricity Board.

A TALL, teen-age boy in the cafeteria lunch line at The Wheatley School, Old Westbury, N.Y., exhibited an astonishingly healthy appetite one day this week. He loaded his tray with double portions of the cold plate lunch -- two hero sandwiches with sliced tomato and American cheese filling, two mixed green salads, two glasses of grapefruit juice, two containers of milk and two wedges of lemon chiffon pie.

The basic philosophy and practical procedures of President Kennedy's program for aid to the under-developed countries are rapidly winning such widespread international acceptance as to raise genuine hope for his projected new partnership between the northern and southern halves of the world and, with Latin America, an alliance for progress.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Which state was No. 38 to ratify the twenty-third amendment giving the District of Columbia the vote in Presidential elections? Kansas? Ohio? Maybe New Hampshire?

Tenzer, Greenblatt Fallon Kaplan, lawyers, have leased a floor in the Pfizer Building at 235 East Forty-second Street, corner of Second Avenue. They plan to occupy the space about May 1. Helmsley-Spear, Inc., is the agent for the building.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Census Bureau reported today that, for the first time in history, the median age of the people of the United States had declined.
A four-story red brick schoolhouse, a relic of the horse-and-buggy age, was purchased yesterday morning at a city auction for conversion into a miniature version of the Lincoln Center of the Arts.

An $8,000,000 emergency relief program by the state for the three major commuter railroads serving the city became law yesterday. At the same time the railroads agreed to provide a total of 230 new cars.
New York University is bowing to criticism of its proposals for a limited number of middle income cooperative apartments south of Washington Square.
CHICAGO, March 30 (AP) -- The grain futures market finally straightened out today for a short but slow run into higher ground on the Board of Trade.

In the performance of Berg's "Wozzeck" given last night by the Metropolitan Opera, two singers took over their roles for the first time this season. They were Lorenzo Alvary, who was the Doctor, and Albert Da Costa, the Drum Major. Among others in the cast were Eleanor Steber, HelTnann Uhde, Paul Franke and Charles Anthony. Karl Boehm conducted.
Like the weather, the business outlook has improved, but the First National City Bank of New York says the prospects are not yet clear, although definitely encouraging.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Rail and truck loadings of freight last week were sharply below the 1960 level and little changed from the preceding week of this year.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- The State Department reported fresh evidence today of a survivor from the United States plane downed in Laos and announced moves seeking his release from pro-Communist guerrillas.
BONN, Germany, March 30 -- Count Karl von Spreti, the West German Ambassador to Cuba, has been asked to return home for consultations, the Foreign Ministry announced today.

The Mesabi Iron Company announced yesterday it had received a favorable ruling from the Commissioner of Internal Revenue on its proposed plan to liquidate the company and transfer its assets into trusts.
MOSCOW, Friday, March 31 -- The Communist bloc's Warsaw alliance called West Germany today "the major hotbed of war danger in Europe" and pressed a demand for a peace treaty with both Germanys.
"The Defenders," a courtroom drama starring E.G. Marshall and Robert Reed in a father-and-son law partnership, will make its debut next fall over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.

Three awards for humanitarian service to retarded children will be made at the twelfth anniversary dinner dance of the New York City Chapter of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children, Inc., to be held May 20 in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor.
The Metropolitan Opera has commissioned Marvin David Levy, 28-year-old American composer, to write an opera based on Eugene O'Neill's "Mourning Becomes Electra."
NEW DELHI, India, March 30 -- Nigeria has agreed to let Indian troops land on her territory for airlifting to the Congo, authoritative sources said today.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 21 -- Communist guerrilla leaders in the jungles of South Vietnam have threatened to assassinate village notables who vote for President Ngo Dinh Diem in the republic's first Presidential election April 9, according to reports to the Government.

NEW DELHI, India, March 30. -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that he had had very useful talks with Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru on the Congo and Laos. Mr. Nehru said they had "agreed largely" in their approach to the issues.

The International Soccer League listed a full schedule of games yesterday for its second season. Competition will open in the Polo Grounds on May 17 and end with the American Challenge Cup final on Aug. 6.
Pleasure boat waterways will be criss-crossed this summer by the wakes of many combination power plants known as inboard-outboard engines. This is a trend.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The news reporters of diplomatic matters in Washington who found high-level State Department officials disappointed with the txt of the SEATO resolution as to the situation in Laos are responsible and experienced.

Now that Governor Rockefeller has signed the bill killing the Youth Court Act -- before it had taken effect -- a leading question arises: What should be done at the next legislative session to accomplish the desirable objectives of the measure now defunct? Most important, of course, is the need for judicial tribunals with special competence to deal with cases involving offenders under 21.
ALTHOUGH continental Americans are familiar with Puerto Rico's Operation Bootstrap, not many know about Operation Serenidad.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 30 -- Rafael Durand Manzanal was named administrator of the Economic Development Administration today. He replaces Teodoro Moscoso, who was appointed yesterday as the United States Ambassador to Venezuela by President Kennedy.
ALBANY, March 30 -- Bills to continue rent controls on business and commercial properties for another year, until July 1, 1962, are awaiting action by Governor Rockefeller.
New York State unemployment, for the second month in a row, has reached its highest level since the postwar recession of 1949.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 9 points (45 cents bale) off yesterday.

BANGKOK, Thailand, March 30 -- Some delegations wanted either a firmer or a softer declaration on Communist aggression in Laos than emerged from the meeting of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization here. But Secretary of State Dean Rusk and other foreign policy chiefs felt the eight-nation alliance ended its seventh meeting yesterday in a spirit of greater unity than had been demonstrated since its formation in Manila in 1954.
David Dubinsky wept publicly yesterday as he recalled the early days of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, which he has headed since 1932.

Thirty-five detectives and Federal Bureau of Investigation agents sought clues yesterday to the gunman who escaped Wednesday with $900,000 in diamonds from a dealer's office at 62 West Forty-seventh Street.

THERE'S nothing like a lost treasure to stimulate the desire to travel. Perhaps Joseph Kessel would have gone to Mogok even if he had not heard about the former highwayman and bandit turned respectable jewel merchant whose fabulous hoard of precious stones had disappeared under darkly sinister circumstances.
Eddie Arcaro went home happy from Aqueduct yesterday, but the same could not be said of Hirsch Jacobs.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Senator William Proxmire charged today that "oil interests have achieved enormous power in the Kennedy Administration."
An off-duty patrolman was overcome by smoke yesterday after rescuing six persons from a Brooklyn tenement fire.
MANY of Italy's most eminent contemporary painters and sculptors are represented in the exhibition, "Modern Mosaics of Ravenna," at the Museum of Contemporary Crafts, 29 West Fifty-third Street.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 31 (UPI) -- The Milwaukee Braves made a bid to strengthen their mound corps today by acquiring Myron (Moe) Drabowsky and Seth Morehead from the Chicago Cubs. The Cubs received two infielders, Andre Rodgers and Daryl Robertson, in exchange for the pitchers.

As the nation's largest voluntary nonsectarian family agency the Community Service Society of New York, 105 East Twenty-second Street, New York 10, spent a record total of $3,766,551 in serving families, individuals and the community in its fiscal year from Oct. 1, 1959, through Sept. 30, 1960. The figures are given in the agency's 1959-60 annual report, recently issued.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The Justice Department said today that Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy was looking into the constitutionality of the proposed Delaware River Basin Compact at the request of the House Judiciary Committee.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, March 31 -- Troops of the Government of President Moise Tshombe captured Manono, capital of the "independent state" of Luluaba, in northern Katanga, yesterday.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 31 -- The White House described as "strictly routine" tonight investigations being made by the Secret Service of alleged threats by pro-Castro Cubans to kidnap President Kennedy's 3-year-old daughter, Caroline.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI) -- The Department of Labor reported today that the number of persons drawing unemployment compensation declined by 30,400 in the week ended March 18. It was the fourth consecutive decline.
MEXICO CITY, March 311 '_?I) -- The announcement yes-[ erday of Thomas C. Mann's esignation as-United States l nbassador to Mexico drew taxed reaction here toda.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 31 -- Morocco, Tunisia and the Sudan have agreed in principle to participate in New York's 1964 world's fair, according to Charles Poletti, former Governor of New York.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 31 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion advised President Kennedy today against attempting to impose a Middle East settlement upon Israel and the Arab states.
Passover, the Jewish festival commemorating the liberation of the Israelites from Egyptian bondage more than 3,000 years ago, began at sundown yesterday.
LONDON, March 31 (AP) -- Ingemar Johansson returned to Europe today claiming he was wrongly counted out in his world title fight against Floyd Patterson.

The negotiations between the French and the Algerian rebels for a cease-fire and self-determination for Algeria are now in jeopardy. The talks were to begin in Evian-les-Bains on April 7, but the Provisional Government in Exile announced in Tunis yesterday that it is "reconsidering" its decision, and a spokesman said flatly that "as things stand at present" the representatives of the Algerian National Liberation Front (FLN) will not go to Evian.
CINCINNATI, March 31 -- Virtually one-fourth of the 14,500 employes at the General Electric Company plant in Evendale will lose their jobs within thirty days, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A "needle" and "thrust" strategy by which Republicans hope to keep the Kennedy Administration politically off balance and to present an appearance of alertness and aggressiveness has taken shape in the last few weeks.
Easter Sunday, the most joyful day in the Christian calendar, will be marked tomorrow by Christians over the world.
ALBANY, March 31 (AP) -- The State Conservation Department is optimistic about the opening of the New York State trout season tomorrow.

DETROIT, March 31 -- Federal Judge Ralph M. Freeman issued an injuncttion today barring Sol A. Dann from further soliciting anti-management proxies against Chrysler Corporation in violation of Security and Exchange Commission rules.
The new Army-green uniform is helping to attract recruits to the Women's Army Corps, according to Lieut. Col. Helen H. Corthay, the corps' chief recruiter.

THE great musical drama that Bach made out of the "Passion according to St. Matthew" was presented last night in Carnegie Hail. The fact that it was Good Friday added to the poignancy and emotional impact of the performance, and prompted the wish that the work could be heard annually on that day.
LEXINGTON, N.C., March 31 (AP) -- Search parties slogged through mud and rain today seeking four crewmen missing in the fiery crash of a B-52-G jet bomber fifteen miles southeast of here.

You are to be highly commende for your March 25 editorial "Tri angle Fire Anniversary" in which you urge the Governor to veto depending Albert-Folmer measure which would stay until April 1, 1961 the operation of the Abrams which was effective July 1, 1960.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31 -- If it should come to pass that the Yankees meet the Pirates in another world series, it is quite possible that Ralph Houk picked up some valuable information today. For unless all signs point differently, he'll do well to keep Ralph Terry in hiding.
BRIDGE literature bristles with such esoteric terms as "blocking play" and "entry play" that may be meaningless to the casual player.

BENECIA, Calif., March 31 -- Benecia, California, first capital and the site of an arsenal since the state entered the Union in 1850, was more than up in arms today. The population of 7,200 virtually exploded on announcement of the planned closing of the Army installation here.

HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, March 30 -- The Dutch and Papuans are hurt because the United States has declined to send a representative to the inauguration of the Netherlands New Guinea Legislative Council April 5.
Wallingford Riegger, the composer, was in critical condition yesterday in Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital after brain surgery.

Mrs. Edith Price's Yes You Will made his expected stretch and won the $10,000 feature Aqueduct yesterday. To the write-players among the 113 shivering spectators, the jury was quite satisfactory, and though Yes You Will paid by $3.70 for $2.
EDISON, N.J. March 31 -- The main topic of conversation in this area today was the Pentagon's decision to close down the Raritan Arsenal within three years.
MOSCOW, March 31 -- A mud slide at a reclamation project in the Ukrainian capital of Kiev March 13 killed 145 persons and injured 143. Scores of homes and public buildings were demolished.

NO MOTHER TO GUIDE HER,"* by Anita Loos, is a historical novel about Hollywood. All the antique jocosities are here in a spirited revival. If were had never been a gilded age on that tarnished coast of glamour Miss Loos, author of "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," would be the very person to invent it.

HONOLULU, March 31 -- The Matson Navigation Company, which has served the Hawaiian Islands for nearly eighty years, is fighting for survival today against some of the toughest opposition in its history. Ironically, it comes not from competing steamship lines but from the people it serves.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 31 (AP) -- Benny (Kid) Paret will risk his welterweight title against Emile Griffith in a fifteen-round bout in Convention Hall tomorrow night. Endurance is expected to be a decisive factor in the outcome.

"THERE is something about this man that drives me nuts," an intimate of Robert Henry Winborne Welch Jr. for many years said of him yesterday. The speaker, who declined to have his name used, said Mr. Welch appeared to be personally considerate, kindly, and a good family man.

Lawrence D. Maran, realty investor, has sold the five-story apartment house at 2133-37 broadway, southwest corner of twenty-fifth Street, to a syndicate of investors who were presented by Gartenberg Kenoff, lawyers.

TRENTON, March 31 -- Four andidates for Governor have :manded equal time from VNTA-TV in New York City as result of a three-hour teleision appearance by James P. iitchell, also a candidate, last unday night,

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, left New York International Airport last night for a three-day meeting of the executive committee of the International Transport Workers Federation opening April 12 in Tel Aviv, Israel.
LONDON, March 31 -- About 13,000 marchers set out today for London from Aldermaston, Berkshire, and Wethersfield, Essex, in protest against Britain's defense policy and Western nuclear weapons.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 31 -- The African group of nations, meeting privately here today, was reported to have decided unanimously to ask punitive measures against South Africa because of its policy of racial separation.
CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, March 31 (AP) -- The flooding Cedar River, striking a multi-million dollar blow to eastern Iowa, ended its rise here this afternoon.

HARLINGEN, Tex, March 31 -Closing of HarUnger Air Force Base, which has 2,300 military personnel and 800 civilian workers, will have a temporary economic impact on this community of 40,000 population, but the town should, continue to grow and prosper, in the opinion of civic and financial leaders

Mikhail Tal, the defending champion, defeated Mikhail Botvinnik in the eighth game of their world title chess match in Moscow yesterday, according to Tass, the official Soviet news agency. The game lasted twenty-nine moves. Pressure on the queens' side of the board, effectively timed and executed by Tal, proved decisive.
AMMAN, Jordan, March 31 -- King Hussein is moving to strengthen the discipline of the Jordanian Army following a flare-up of personal and tribal rivalries in the officers corps.
The moral that Magistrate Morton R. Tolleris impressed on Clement De Fabio in Upper Manhattan Arrest Court yesterday was: Leave summonses to policemen and cap pistols to children.

What may have been the first public recital ever played on the tuba in New York was given in Carnegie Recital Hall last night by Roger Bobo. The young performer is a member of the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra and a graduate student at the Eastman School of Music.
PARIS, March 31 -- France greeted with official silence and private indignation today the Algerian rebel decision to boycott the scheduled peace talks next week.

EACH day, as youngsters thrill to the lofty antics of the circus aerial ballet, a lithe blonde stands in Madison Square Garden checking the girls' movements as intently as if their lives depended on it. And, in a sense, they do.

TAMPA, March 31 (AP) -- A proposal to allow Pacific Coast League teams to use a tenth player as a regular batting substitute for pitchers was rejected, 8 -- 1, today by professional baseball's Playing Rules Committee.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., March 31 (UPI) -- Joseph A. Walker zoomed to an altitude of 169,600 feet yesterday on the X-15, the National Aeronautical and Space Administration announced today.
YONKERS, March 31 -- All the way from Sydney, Australia, to this horse-conscious spot at the edge of Westchester County have come three of the finest pacers from Down Under.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A Virginian thinks he has a solution for many railroad and highway shipping problems -- putting truck trailers on the rails. Guy T. Tripp of Richmond has been notified that this patent for a flange to adapt a motor-vehicle wheel to a railroad track will be issued by the Patent Office on April 11.
The Federal Maritime Board has ordered Flota Mercante Grancolombiana, S.A., to pay an importer $143,370.98 because it had refused to ship his bananas.
We should like to clarify the issues raised by the editorial of March 18, on the Mayor's decision to close the in-patient services at Gouverneur Hospital.
Officials of a Queens manufacturing company will be questioned informally on Tuesday by the State Investigation Commission, the agency's chairman said yesterday.

Few large issues of new securities are slated for sale in the public capital market next week. Nevertheless, volume will be high because one of the three major competitive sales is a $190,000,000 bond issue of California.

IN a friendly argument with an amateur archaeologist in the Judean desert as to whether Israel or the United States is the better place to live, Mrs. David Ben-Gurion said recently: "Life is full here. Life is empty there. Hustle, bustle, you open a can, use a pressure cooker."

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The index of primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday to 119.5 per cent of its 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

CAIRO, March 31 -- In both external and internal affairs President Nasser of the United Arab Republic considers himself ideologically neutral or, as he prefers to say, "non-aligned." But some countries are more neutral than others. The U.A.R. is no Switzerland nor even India.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 31 -- A Scarsdale High School cast will present Thornton Wilder's "Our Town" before youthful audiences in Europe this summer if "angels" smile upon the venture.

The election of John L. Gushman as president, chief operating officer and a director of the Anchor Hocking Glass Company was announced yesterday. As president, Mr. Gushman succeeds William V. Fisher, who was named chairman and chief executive officer.
Deaths due to pneumonia and influenza have increased in the last five weeks from an average of sixty a week to 101, the city Health Department reported yesterday.

A Japanese course overlooking the Pacific Ocean has been chosen as the site of the world amateur team golf championship in 1962. This was made known yesterday by Joseph C. Dey Jr., secretary of the World Golf Council, sponsor of the biennial event.
PARIS, March 31 -- By almost every test, the American is taxed less heavily than the European.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A leader of the John Birch Society confirmed today that the ultra-conservative organization was promoting a massive letter-writing campaign for the impeachment of Chief Justice Earl Warren.
CASABLANCA, Morocco, March 31 -- The new King of Morocco declared today that his country's immediate needs were on an economic and social level and that political democracy would come later.
A re-examination of the city's educational program has been started, Superintendent of Schools John J. Theobald disclosed yesterday.

Spring comes to New York in ways that appear to have nothing to do with the weather. In fact, these signs have nothing to do with robins or crocuses, either. For example, some New Yorkers can tell that spring is comings because their friends have returned to the city.
A new skirmish was fought yesterday in the battle for Channel 13.

James S. Lanigan, the choice of insurgent Democrats to challenge the district leadership of Carmine G. De Sapio, criticized the political and administrative capacities of Mayor Wagner in a radio interview last night.

A special two-week symposium on motion pictures for adult audiences will start on Thursday at Smith College in Northampton, Mass. The college has scheduled seven campus programs that will include the screening of films of contemporary interest, with commentaries by faculty members and film representatives.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 31 -- Eighteen Latin-American nations moved today to put the main financial burden of paying for the United Nations' operations in the Congo on the five permanent members of the Security Council and on Belgium.

LONDON, March 31 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, former Premier of Laos, said today that he was ready to call for the ending of Soviet military aid to his country provided United States aid ended at the same time.

New sports fans go out on the Richmond and pitch against some are noted players in baseball, none of those few was George Plimpton, editor of the literary quarterly, The Paris Review. In the help of Sports Illustrated magazine and Toots Bohr, Mr. Plimpton pitched during a warm-up session at an all-star exhibition game, facing players from the American and National League teams.
Net income of the Fairbanks Whitney Corporation dropped to $733,116 last year from $3,198,206 in 1959, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

SAN MARINO, Calif., March 31 (UPI) -- Representative John H. Rousselot, saying he is a member of the John Birch Society, asserted today he would welcome investigations of the organization to clear up misconceptions about it.

MEXICO CITY, March 31 -- This capital, and the entire nation for that matter, is in the midst of one of Mexico's longest holidays. The holiday began yesterday (Holy Thursday) and will continue four and in some instances five days over the Easter week-end.

PRESQUE ISLE, Me., March 31 -- "We'll take it in stride." That statement 'sums np,the attitude of this central Axcos-/ took County community, home of the nation's first operational missile base, a base that President Kennedy declared this week would be closed.
TRENTON, March 31 -- New Jersey's first state health code, designed to assure public health standards in all 568 municipalities, becomes effective tomorrow.

PARIS, March 31 -- Suspicion in the bombings early this morning in Evian-les-Bains, where negotiations are scheduled to begin April 7 on an Algerian peace, has centered on Right-wing opponents of the negotiations.

BELMONT, Mass., March 31 (AP) -- Robert Welch, founder of the John Birch Society, today gave a reporter a quantity of literature issued by the organization, including a pamphlet listing the society council.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Federal Communications Commission has begun an inquiry into how to handle the commercial development and control of space communications.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 31 (UPI) -- Dr. Dan Kilroy, chairman of the California Athletic Commission, said last night that Sonny Liston, the top contender for Floyd Patterson's world heavyweight title, would not be permitted to fight in California under present conditions.

A random survey of the processed-meat industry, which is being investigated by the Justice Department for possible price fixing, shows the cost of processed meats here has risen about 30 per cent in ten years. This compares with a rise of 19 per cent for fresh meat.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 31 (UPI) -- Hank Bauer of the Kansas City Athletics said today that 1961 would be his last season as a baseball player because "the legs ain't what they used to be any more."
The Eaton Manufacturing Company, Cleveland, maker of automotive and aircraft parts, is acquiring the Dill Manufacturing Company, Cleveland producer of tire valves.

GARDEN GROVE, Calif., March 31 -- A Marine Corps staff sergeant from East Meadow, L.I., charged with forging and cashing Government checks amounting to $100,000, was arrested here today by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents.
Residents of the Edgehill area in Riverdale, the Bronx, are protesting an effort to build a ten-story apartment house in their neighborhood, which is now restricted to single-family houses.

DUISBURG, Germany, March 31 (AP) -- Fencers from countries in the Soviet bloc walked out of the junior world fencing championships today to protest a ban on Communist East Germany's national emblem, the hammer and compass.

WASHINGTON March 31 (UPI) -- The Government started today proceedings to deport Frank Costello of New York, long a leader in the underworld, who is nearing the end of a five-year sentence in the Federal Penitentiary at Atlanta for income tax evasion.

ATHENS, March 31 -- In a country such as Greece, where Western theatrical arts were born, critics tend to be as severe with stage performances as they would with an architect who tried to redesign the Parthenon.
Easter, the most joyful of Christian holidays, and Passover, the Jewish festival of freedom, are being celebrated this week-end here and over the world.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI) -- The Defense Department reduced the April draft call to 1,500 men today. That is the smallest for any month since the Korean War started.
PANAMA, March 28 -- Relations between the United States and Panama, on the brink of an explosion six months ago, have taken a remarkable turn for the better.

MONTREAL, March 31 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens learned today that they will be without the services of Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion for tomorrow night's fifth game of the Stanley Cup semi-final series with the Chicago Black Hawks.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 31 -- The United States appears to be ready to offer its prescription for a solution of the Congo crisis.
PARIS, March 31 -- A French decorator spent four days at the White House in February examining the decorations and furnishings at the invitation of Mrs. John F. Kennedy.
CAIRO, March 31 -- The third All-Africa Peoples Conference ended its work here today with new resolves to combat influences that it identified almost exclusively with Western "imperialism."
The Equity Library Theatre, the acting profession's own showcase for performing talent, may do a program of free children's entertainment in Central Park this summer.

Roman Catholic, Protestant and Eastern Orthodox church leaders issued their annual Easter messages yesterday hailing the Risen Christ and calling on churchgoers to pray for a world of peace and justice.
MIAMI, March 31 (AP) -- Eight horses were entered today in the $100,000-added Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park tomorrow. Jack Price's Carry Back is the 2-to-1 favorite.

LONDON, March 31 (Reuters) -- The Tottenham Hotspurs returned to winning form today by beating their London neighbor, Chelsea, 4 -- 2, at Tottenham in an English League First Division soccer championship contest.
Unionized employes of the Bronx Zoo and the Aquarium agreed last night to postpone a strike scheduled for last midnight to permit a State Supreme Court hearing of the issues today.
JUNEAU, Alaska, March 31 (AP) -- The Alaska Legislature discovered to its horror yesterday that it had unwittingly repealed a legislative pay law.

WARSAW, March 31 -- In the opinion of diplomatic observers here, the communique issued by the Warsaw Pact meeting in Moscow early today was calculated to step up Western pressure on West Germany to come to terms with its East European Communist neighbors.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The Missouri-Kansas-Texas (Katy) Railroad Company and the Monon Railroad Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to underwrite proposed borrowings totaling $9,500,000.
PARIS, March 31 (AP) -- Plans for reorganizing the French Defense Ministry to concentrate more power in the hands of the Minister, Pierre Messmer, were announced tonight.

LOS ANGELES, March 31 -- A million-dollar scientific gamble, financed mostly by the nation's taxpayers, paid off early today when researchers brought up samples from the ocean floor more than two miles below the surface of the Pacific.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 31 -- The Government-owned Panama Line was directed by President Kennedy today to cease all commercial operations, effective April 20.
"'WAY OUT," Channel 2's new spooky series, romped gaily through its first episode last night in a sparkling little production.
More than 2,800 employes of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company went on strike at 12:01 A.M. today.

DIMITRI MITROPOULOS had been scheduled to conduct Mahler's Third Symphony with the New York Philharmonic this season. He died before the engagement. Last November he was working on this very D minor Symphony with the orchestra of La Scala in Milan.
Students from Columbia and Barnard are taking time from their studies to help pupils in near-by elementary and junior high schools.
A world-wide showcase of cars will go on display today at the Coliseum at Columbus Circle as the fifth International Automobile Show starts a nine-day run.

ROME, March 31 -- The left-wing, Socialist leader, Pietro Nenni, has narrowly averted a split in his party by consenting to the election of a "unitarian directorate," in which the pro-Communist element of the party is amply represented.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Organized labor has quietly pledged its help to the Peace Corps.

A twenty-story office building costing $9,000,000 is planned in St. Louis, according to an announcement here yesterday by Collins, Tuttle Co., New York real estate concern. The structure will be erected at Sixth and Olive Streets and will be the first major project of its kind in St. Louis in thirty years.
NEWTON, N.J., March 31 -- Today was a day of forgiveness for the holders of 254 overdue books belonging to the Dennis Memorial Library here.
TUNIS, March 31 -- Peace talks between the French and Algerian nationalist governments appeared today to be stalled indefinitely. They were scheduled to open in Evian-les-Bains April 7.

DETROIT, March 31 (AP) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers, joined James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters Union, in denying a report today that Mr. Reuther had appealed for the return of the teamsters to the merged labor federation.

The question of who gave the Coramine to Hirsch Jacobs' filly remained a mystery yesterday at Aqueduct.

BELMONT, Mass., March 31 (AP) -- Robert H.W. Welch, founder of the ultra-rightist John Birch Society, denied today that he had ever called former President Dwight D. Eisenhower a "card-carrying Communist."

Goats suffering from a hereditary muscle disease identical to one that offlicts humans have been relieved of all their symptoms by depriving them of water, according to a report by two scientists today.

In your editorial of March 27 on "Retraining Displaced Workers" you note that not as many as might be expected of the Armour packing house workers who were left without a job when the plant closed last July took advantage of the training offered under a pilot retraining program set up for the displaced workers.

PALM BEACH, March 31 -- President Kennedy signed tonight a bill extending the Sugar Act for fifteen months. The President also signed the third supplemental appropriations bill increasing funds available to Government agencies for the fiscal year of 1961 that ends June 30.

MEXICO CITY, March 31 -- Former President Lazaro Cardenas took issue today with those in Mexico who have challenged his support of Premier Fidel Castro and of Cuba in the controversy with the United States.

With the days growing longer and balmier, the mounted police who patrol Central Park shift to their summer schedule today. The patrols will extend over a longer period, but there will be fewer men and horses on duty during a given period.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 31 -- Since 1953, a committee set up by the United Nations General Assembly to investigate and report on conditions in South-West Africa has failed to gain entrance there.
LONDON, March 31 -- The absence of a time limit in the Warsaw Pact's demands for free-city status for West Berlin and a peace treaty for Germany evoked cautious relief from British diplomats today.

A "summit" meeting between Premier Khrushchev and his East European puppets has ended with a communique which reaffirms the continued validity of the Communist manifesto of last November, describing "peaceful coexistence" and "total disarmament" -- Soviet style -- as the road to Communist domination. But viewed in the light of this basic directive on Communist strategy, and compared with the usual sound and fury of Communist pronouncements, the present communique is rather more moderate.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk will make a personal report to President Kennedy in Florida tomorrow on the recent foreign ministers' conference of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization.
TOKYO, Saturday, April 1 (UPI) -- Communist China rejected today British and American proposals for a cease-fire in Laos as a first step.
LONDON, March 31 (AP) -- Pink tights and electronics have invaded the Oxford-Cambridge crew race this year.

Ninety-one British educators who are paying their own way went their first full day here yesterday learning how American teachers are taught.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Perini Corporation, Framingham, Mass., owner of the Milwaukee Braves baseball club, today asked Government clearance to make a public offering of 1,451,998 shares of its common stock. Perini primarily is a construction company but owns 99.88 per cent of the Braves.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 1 -- A leadership training workshop for senior citizens groups will be held at Adelphi College here on April 6, April 13, April 20, April 27, May 4 and May 11.

Tanganyika used to be a part of German East Africa. The British took it in 1918 by right of conquest, and since the end of the second World War it has been a British trust territory. Nearly all of this population is African, with a tiny fraction of Indians, Pakistanis and Europeans.

The new Administration's revisions of former President Eisenhower's security budget estimates for the 1962 fiscal year were projected against the background of intense activity and impending change in the Pentagon.

Midway, thirty miles south of Savannah, presents the unusual paradox of a New England town set down in the midst of a peaceful southern landscape, of colonial New England architecture surrounded by old moss-draped oak trees.

The steel industry's high-pressure campaign to raise productivity and combat rising costs is about to add an important new dimension. The impact of this development will be felt not only in steel but in the chemical, oil and coal industries as well.
BALTIMORE, April 1 (AP) -- Dr. Robert H. Reddick, sentenced in 1958 to five years in prison for forging a medical license, will be paroled Monday, it was announced today.

THE intimate and profound relationship between T. Williams' essay in the Book Review ("A Real Good Hearty War Dies Hard") and James Baldwin's in the Magazine ("A Negro Assays the Negro Mood") is quite striking -- and yet unacknowledged by either of them.

At the start of 1961 the John Birch Society had organized one to 100 chapters in each of thirty-four states and the District of Columbia, according to its founder Robert H.W. Welch Jr. of Massachusetts.

I was interested to read about the report of the Joint Commission on Mental Illness and Health, stating that we are falling far behind in our care of the mentally ill in the United States. In 1957-59 I served as executive director of a state commission in Massachusetts which came to similar conclusions.

PARIS -- Instead of strolling along Paris' wide boulevards to shop or watch the crowds on a clear, sunny spring or summer morning, it is more fun to set aside several hours for a real walk. This not only is the best way to absorb Paris' unique beauty but it also puts one in sharp condition to make the most of Paris' renowned haute cuisine afterward.

An American delegate to the U.N., Philip M. Klutznick, used a striking phrase when he addressed the Budget Committee last week. He said that "honorable states and men." try to provide for the payment of their bills. He was referring to member nations which are in arrears in their contributions to the cost of the U.N. operation in the Congo.

IN his review of Graham Greene's novel "A Burnt-Out Case," Robert Gorham Davis defines the term in the title as that "used for those victims of leprosy who can be cured because the disease has eaten about all that it wants -- toes, ears, fingers.

PRESIDING over Room 412 of the Juilliard School of Music is the dean of American piano teachers, a tiny woman of 81 who combines the autocracy of Catherine the Great with the informality of a taxicab driver, and who, only a few weeks ago, made a public appearance to play Chopin's E minor Concerto.
A new concept that places more value on recent engineering graduates than on experienced engineers may be here to stay.

SAN ANGELO, Tex., April 1 (AP) -- Abilene Christian College bettered the National Collegiate record in the mile relay with a time of 3 minutes 8.9 seconds today on the way to the championship of the San Angelo relays.

YONKERS, April 1 -- Conditions changed rapidly at Yonkers Raceway tonight. A track that was soaking just before the first race was fast enough by the fifth to produce a snappy mile by some good pacers.
CAIRO, April 1 -- The Cairo branch of the First National City Bank of New York, which was the only American bank operating in Cairo, was transferred today to Egyptian control.

I have read James Baldwin's "A Negro Assays the Negro Mood" (March 12) and as a Southerner by birth and breeding I can only hope to God that his warning, and that of others, does not go unheeded or we will surely have sold our heritage for a mess of pottage.

THERE are, I imagine, some readers of this column who know only hardcover books -- who patronize public or rental libraries, and visit the newsstands, if at all, only for reprints of their favorite hardcover authors.

OLYMPIA, Wash., April 1 (AP) -- Washington's Legislature ended a twenty-two-day special session with a bitter political row early today after adopting a record $1,160,000,000 budget and adding $50,000,000 to state taxes.
The United HIAS Service last night adopted an annual budget of $2,319,420 for migration, resettlement and related services to more than 30,000 Jewish men, women and children over the world.
KOVACEVAC, Yugoslavia, March 27 -- Yugoslavia is setting up local conciliation commissions to try to settle small civil disputes before the lawyers take over.
GERARD ENDRES, a traffic patrolman who lives in Queens, never drives his own car into Manhattan. He says he and his wife, Gladys, can't take the strain of metropolitan driving.

TO most golfers, Pinehurst, N.C., is a familiar name. In recent years Pinehurst visitors have been discovering another attraction -- Clarendon Gardens -- a 166-acre estate of planned and natural plantings.
RIO DE JANEIRO April 1 -- President Janio Quadros is facing a test of his national leadership in the crisis of Brazil's inflation.

THIS is Easter, and the main book news of the morning concerns a very old account of it, in its newest form. That is, of course, The New Testament of "The New English Bible," which was reviewed in these pages a fortnight ago. The Oxford and Cambridge University Presses, which brought it out, obviously have a success on their lists both here and in England.
ALGIERS, Algeria March 28 (AP) -- The Cities Service Oil Company has struck oil in the northeastern Sahara, and French sources described the find as a possible new major field.

THE heaths and heathers too often are overlooked as colorful additions to the home landscape. They bear small but abundant blossoms over a long period, and the evergreen foliage offers wide variation in texture and color.
IN the many pages of the Old Testament, there are exactly two references to the glamorous lady whom Charles E. Israel makes the heroine of his new and colorful novel.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- With no election in the offing this year, the Kennedy Administration is embarked nevertheless on a nationwide program of wooing the American farmer. The aim is to sell him on an approach to solving the farm problem that differs basically from the approach of the Eisenhower Administration.
California apparently lost its bid yesterday to replace New York as tennis capital of the country.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 1 -- The good ship Bonjour, accused of radio piracy, is riding at anchor off the Swedish Main and giving off music.

New York City's budget is the third largest in the United States, after those of the Federal Government and California. Last week Mayor Robert Wagner submitted to the Board of Estimate his budget for the fiscal year starting July 1. It is a record $2,542,100,000 -- almost $200,000,000 higher than the present year.

MORE enduring than a fast-fading suntan are the impressions a tourist brings back from Florida. Most vivid and important of these was the weather. It was perfect. Of recent years managers and ballplayers were becoming increasingly disillusioned with the Sunshine State as a training base. They grumbled that rain and unseasonably cold spells interfered with the conditioning.
This morning, in the ancient city of Jerusalem devout worshipers converged to commemorate Calvary and the Resurrection. Easter is the most holy of days in Jerusalem.

DETROIT automobile executives have been saying for years that the United States motor-car industry moves forward by evolution -- not by revolution. Now they're finding it difficult to make the facts fit the theory.
The suggestion from the White House that rocking chairs are good for you has not taken British physicians by surprise.

HAVANA, April 1 -- Six persons were reported today to have been wounded yesterday in a riot that broke up the presentation of the traditional Passion Play at Guines, a town thirty-five miles from here.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. -- Mindful that tourism has become big business, the United Nations is making a major effort to help newer countries cash in on the travel boom. The economic potential of tourism to these developing countries is one of the main themes to be developed at the forthcoming sessions of the Economic and Social Council, which opens its thirty-first meeting here on Tuesday.
Seventeen children lay strangely silent in their cribs in the Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital in Brooklyn last week.

THERE is a smoother road ahead for the buyers of new cars, with manufacturers paving the way with expanded warranties. American manufacturers have extended their warranties to 12,000 miles or twelve months, whichever comes first.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, April 1 -- Malaya's three race courses had well-filled grandstands today. Long queues were at the pari-mutuel windows and anxious bettors stood on tiptoe as frames listing horses, jockeys and post positions were hoisted.
SINCE the spring season just ahead will be a congested one, here is a listing of events, telling more or less who is doing what and when.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 1 -- Struggling miserably through the heat and humidity of its worst season, swatting vainly at mosquitoes and sending the consumption of beer and malaria pills sky high, Leopoldville had a respite this week from some of its more famous troubles.
About 3,500 persons, mostly teen-agers and college students, gathered near the United Nations yesterday in an Easter March for Peace that called for a ban on nuclear bomb tests.
DALLAS CENTER, Iowa, March 30 -- The beds were of hay and the floors were concrete, but it was a maternity ward as antiseptic as those in hospitals for human beings.

Many of the flourishing well-dressed New Yorkers parading on Fifth Avenue after church services today will be on their way to brunches and luncheons to be held in near-by hotels and restaurants for the benefit of charitable organizations.

Kahn, representing the former, and Mrs. Alan Northcote Sidnam, representing the latter, are co-chairmen with Jay Dorf.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., April 1 -- A new aircraft company has contracted for the assembly of modern-day autogyros at the Fairchild Aircraft Company plant here -- the biggest plant in a community that is one of the country's most depressed.
Civil Aeronautics Board action has eased the threat of an air cargo rate war over the North Atlantic, but basic differences over the future of the industry remain to be resolved by the airlines.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 1 -- Industrialization of the world's economically retarded areas will be the major concern of the eighteen-nation Economic and Social Council session opening at the United Nations Tuesday.
VIENNA -- On the other side of the near-by Iron Curtain, both Hungary and Rumania hope for an expansion of tourist trade this year. Hungary expects to welcome about 20,000 visitors from the West.
MADISON, Wis., April 1 -- Gov. Gaylord A. Nelson has won bipartisan support for a broad, coordinated ten-year program to save and enlarge Wisconsin's "vast but endangered outdoor resources."
TELEFOMIN, Trust Territory of New Guinea, March 23 -- Perhaps the last uncounted savages of the South Pacific live in the few remaining "uncontrolled" regions of the New Guinea Highlands.

THE scene is an auto dealer's service center in Milan, Italy. As a snowstorm that is almost a blizzard wails outside, a small German car carrying a young American couple enters. The car is just a week old and the Americans are heading south in search of some winter sun.
DETROIT, April 1 (AP) -- After nearly fourteen years of litigation the $4,500,000 estate of Earle R. Milner, chain hotel owner, was settled today essentially along the lines established in his will.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Nearly 300 colleges and universities have indicated interest in helping train members of President Kennedy's Peace Corps in a survey conducted by the American Council on Education.
BONN, Germany, March 31 -- A message over the special telegraph line between Bonn and Cadenabbia, an Italian resort on Lake Como, set the Foreign Ministry to scurrying the other day.

ROCKDALE, Fla. -- Railroad devotees who may have been wondering whatever became of U.S. Railroad Car No. 1, the famous "White House on Wheels" used extensively by Presidents Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman, need wonder no longer.

THE seventh novel of Nancy Mitford begins with Alfred Wincham's being unexpectedly appointed British Ambassador in Paris. This is the kind of accident that might happen to any of us if we were Nancy Mitford characters; but it is rather a shock that it should be Alfred, a misty character whose only importance is that long ago (in the author's "Love in a Cold Climate") he married the charming Fanny Logan.

I enclose for your examination an invitation sent me by the Junior Council of the Museum of Modern Art to submit entries for an exhibition that will explore the renewed interest of American painters in the human figure.

The word Tory derives from an Irish word meaning pursuer and was originally applied to Irish outlaws. In the seventeenth century the Duke of York (later James II) had many Irish friends; his supporters against Parliament and the merchants of London came to be called Tories.

The basic substances of which all living things from bacteria to man are constituted are the chemical entities named proteins. There is an infinite variety of proteins, each part of the body of any species being made up of proteins characteristic of the organs, tissues and fluids of that species.

THE world's greatest need today is mutual confidence. Westerners and Communists do not trust each other, and this is the cause of most of our present troubles. Because we mistrust each other, we have armed ourselves to the teeth with the deadly and costly weapons that science has now put in our hands.
ALBANY, Calif., April 1 (UPI) -- Songman, an outsider in the betting, won the $10,000-added California Derby Trial at Golden Gate Fields today, beating Flutterby by a neck.

NATURALLY enough, one doesn't hear the term "pleasure car" any more. It belonged to another era: a time when traffic jams were unknown, when roads were uncertain, and the automobile was more than a household appliance.

Perhaps James Baldwin should place some of the blame for the hundred years of segregation on the Negro himself. As long as he meekly protested, with an occasional legal reinforcement from a Milquetoast N.A.A.C.P., as long as he was ashamed of kinky hair, and showed it, his gain was bound to be minimal.

A LATE-MODEL stock car broke all records for a 500-mile race when it averaged 149.601 miles an hour at the Daytona (Fla.) International Speedway on Feb. 26. It covered the 200-lap course almost eleven miles an hour faster than the best time ever made at the Indianapolis Speedway, where cars designed and built for racing are put through their paces each Memorial Day.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 1 -- Forty-one candidates are entered in a race here for nine seats in a new Council-Manager form of government to be started July 1. The special election will be on May 9.
CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, April 1 (UPI) -- President Kennedy declared flooded sections of eastern Iowa a disaster area today as the Cedar River began receding here.
Furness Lines has announced the retirement at the end of the month of James N. Findlay, who has been passenger traffic manager of the company since 1934.

ATHENS, March 30 -- Hope of better days is reflected in official Greek estimates on economic prospects for the current year. Marked improvement in economic conditions was predicted following a long period of recession.
PEIPING, April 1 (Reuters) -- A California woman lauded today the care her seriously ill American husband is receiving as a prisoner in Communist China.

THERE is a hopeful theory current in Downing Street that a happy new partnership between John Kennedy and Harold Macmillan is emerging from their meetings, differing in kind though not in weight from the old and now vanished Eisenhower-Macmillan partnership.

THE 1960 awards of the American Hemerocallis (Daylily) Society are headed by Mrs. H.W. Lester's Fairy Wings, Stout Medal winner for the year and the recipient of 157 votes. A number of years ago, shortly after Fairy Wings was introduced, I saw it first in Mrs. Lester's own garden in Atlanta, Ga.

NOT long ago, Harry Reasoner and a few of his colleagues in the news department at the Columbia Broadcasting System had some time to spare and they collaborated on creating what they called a "Cliche Football Team."

NEW DELHI, India, April 1 -- Twelve tribesmen armed with bows and arrows were killed yesterday when the police fired on a crowd of 10,000 armed tribesmen in the former princely state of Bastar in central India, according to a report reaching here tonight.

The famed "widows' and orphans' stock," the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's common, continues to confound the experts. The skeptics of a few years ago no longer challenge its status as a real growth stock.

DELEGATES at Geneva are now in the thirtieth month of hard bargaining on a treaty to end nuclear test explosions.
