The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman reaffirmed yesterday the Christian belief in everlasting life and warned that that life must be earned and not thought of as the last word "in Social Security or old age pension plans."
ST. HELIER, Jersey, Channel Islands, April 2 (AP) -- A thousand brides came down to breakfast today with not a single blush.

PAU, France, April 2 (UPI) -- Jack Brabham, the world champion, clipped 1.7 seconds off his lap-record time for the 2.76-kilometer Pau course in a Works Cooper today to lead the field in the second day's trials for tomorrow's Grand Prix race. Brabham's best lap time was 1 minute 32.07 seconds.

The pace of trading in over-the-counter securities slowed materially last Monday and Tuesday and prices backed away somewhat from their earlier highs. Renewed buying developed late on Wednesday and on Thursday dealers reported that their business was "unbelievably" large, with bidding for individual issues done "as if there will be no more tomorrows."

" A Nearness of Evil," a first novel by Carley Mills, is planned for April 28 publication by Coward-McCann. It is a fictionalized treatment of a notorious murder case and trial, with the locale shifting from Paris to the Riviera to New York's upper East Side.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 2 -- An Indian stop - gap resolution to ameliorate the United Nations' financial crisis is expected to be adopted tomorrow by the General Assembly.

CONSIDERABLE commotion was caused not long ago when word leaked out that Ryne Duren of the Yankees had been fined $200 for violating the curfew rules. For several reasons, this episode attracted more attention than it ordinarily would have.
Benny Goodman and Morton Gould provided what might be mildly called a change of pace last night at one of Max Pollikoff's Music in Our Time concerts at the Lexington Avenue "Y."

A firmer undertone prevailed in the foreign exchange market during the past week. With most of the world capitals having a short business week in observance of the Easter season dealings here were relatively light.
The floating rig drilling into the floor of the Pacific Ocean has reached the mysterious "second layer" and has found it to be basalt, a lava-like rock.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Monday, April 3 (UPI) -- A medical commission early today ruled out the possibility that some of the victims of the mysterious crash of a Communist Czechoslovak plane near Forchheim, Germany, had died of gunshot wounds.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Kennedy moves into his eleventh week in office with a record that lacks the dramatic success of the early Franklin D. Roosevelt days, but that compares favorably with the Eisenhower months.

CAIRO, April 2 -- Whether we admire him or not, there is no blinking the fact that Gamal Abdel Nasser is the best-known leader in the Arab world today. His relations with us have been marred by misunderstanding. And, because of our strikingly different views of Israel, they will never be truly close until there is Palestine peace.

MIAMI, Fla., March 31 -- "This is an explosive situation that hasn't exploded." That was the way a Federal official described the impact of 50,000 Cuban refugees on Miami. The refugees -- there are about enough to fill the 52,000-seat Polo Grounds -- have come to this resort city to escape the regime of Premier Fidel Castro.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., April 2 -- The police intensified today an investigation of teenage narcotic addiction that may involve about fifty youths.
MINEOLA, L.I., April 2 -- Two men were accused today of stealing $2,500 from sixty telephone coin boxes by blasting them open with a sawed-oft rifle.
An ancient rite brought tidings of Easter to the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. John Heuss, rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church at Broadway and Wall Street, told worshipers yesterday that the Resurrection of Jesus Christ "is the one single historical fact which proves that life goes on beyond the grave."

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 2 -- Moise Tshombe, President of Katanga Province, whose troops reoccupied Manono and ended dissident control there last Thursday, has the only fully organized, well-trained, well-led and disciplined army in the Congo.

Nel, Director of the Information Service of South Africa, writes in his letter printed March 28 of "various nations, black and white, living within the borders of the same country," and defends the thesis that the white South African Nationalist Government attempts to safeguard the rights of all South African peoples.
The United States economy may have reached the bottom of a business cycle, the National Bureau of Economic Research said yesterday following a statistical study.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI) -- Americans for Democratic Action accused Congress today of cutting President Kennedy's program to "paltry proportions." An official of the Council of State Chambers of Commerce called for deeper slashes.

STRATFORD, Conn., April 2 -- A man ran into a burning house to rescue his wife today, but both were killed. Their 10-year-old son watched firemen fight the flames and struggle unsuccessfully to rescue his parents.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 2 (UPI) -- Ben Hogan, Cary Middlecoff and Billy Casper were among those playing practice rounds on the Masters golf course today. They said the links were in excellent shape for the 72-hole championship starting Thursday.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The United States is planning to send another 1,500-man battle group to fill out stand-by manpower requirements for the Far East.
ROME, April 2 (AP) -- Two Italian archaeologists cast doubt today on the authenticity of the Punic War burial ground at Cannae, the scene of Carthage's greatest victory and Rome's worst defeat.

The Federal Reserve Board has turned down the application of the Marine Midland Trust Company of Southern New York, Elmira, N.Y., acquire the First National Bank and Trust Company Ithaca, N.Y., a merger previously approved by the State Banking Department.
DENVER, April 2 (AP). -- A former convict was shot to death by a priest tonight during an attempted burglary of the rectory of St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church in North Denver.
" The Resurrection of Jesus Christ was inevitable," the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken told his congregation at the Riverside Church yesterday.
" BREAK OF DAY," a one-hour opera, written especially for television, was given on WABC-TV yesterday afternoon.
Two airliners with landing-gear trouble circled over Boston and Montreal for hours last night and then came in safely within half an hour of each other. The planes carred a total of 119 persons.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The United States will insist on an effective and verified ceasefire in Laos before it goes to an international conference to achieve a political settlement there, authoritative sources said today.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 2 -- Jack Sutphen, the skipper of Rum Dum, became the Larchmont Yacht Club frostbite titleholder today as the winter dinghy season ended without racing.

A New York business man said yesterday that his concern had provided $300,000 worth of radio equipment on the ship that is beaming music and advertising into Stockholm. The Swedish Government is charging that the broadcasts constitute radio piracy.

CHICAGO, April 2 (AP) -- The heaviest and most prolonged selling of the year dealt grain futures a severe blow last week and prices ended the period with their steepest general slide in several months.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 2 -- Two Israelis said to have been involved in abducting Adolf Eichmann from Buenos Aires last May are to be invited to appear as witnesses at his trial next week, the judges announced today.

The Times has always taken the editorial position that all city employes deserve adequate salaries. In your editorial of March 21 you discuss Mayor Wagner's wage proposal for city employes without criticism except to state that "the real test * * * will come when teachers' increases are decided."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 2 -- Israel accused Jordan today of an attempt to "stir up tension" by calling for a Security Council meeting to protest an Israeli parade scheduled for April 20 in Jerusalem.

State and city mediators continued their efforts early this morning to head off a possible strike at five Macy's department stores in the metropolitan area. No agreement had been reached by 3 A.M. but the talks continued.

For a time in Carnegie Hall last night the sound of the music was all sweetness and nostalgia. The tone of the violin was supple and smooth, and the melodies it played had the gentle gayety and sentimentality of Vienna in another time.

AS a graduate student of agricultural economics, Geoffrey Hoyt Moore took courses in statistics and economic theory at Rutgers under Dr. Arthur F. Burns. Professor Burns, the noted theorist on business cycles and successor to Wesley Clair Mitchell at the National Bureau of Economic Re search, reshaped the young Moore's career.

FALL RIVER, Mass., April 2. -- The Fall River S.C. defeated the Italian-American All Stars of Connecticut in a second-round National Challenge Cup game, 2-0, today. Mario Rodriguez scored both goals in the second half.
The appointment of Mrs. William Michelfelder as director of public relations at Columbia College was announced yesterday by Dean John G. Palfrey.
The revival of the rocking chair, which started about a year ago, has gained impetus with President Kennedy's use of a rocker in his White House office.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI) -- Seven million jobs must be created during the next twelve months to achieve "reasonably full employment," the National Planning Association said today.

SEOUL, Korea, April 2 (AP) -- Club-swinging South Korean policemen halted an anti-Government rally in Taegu today. News reports said an undetermined number of persons were injured in clashes between the police and demonstrators.
" The Bob Cummings Show," a new comedy series, will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Thursdays from 8:30 to 9 P.M., beginning next fall.
DAKAR, Senegal, April 2 (AP) -- Vice President Johnson arrived tonight to head the United States delegation at ceremonies marking, Senegal's first anniversary of independence.

Governor Rockefeller took a calculated risk in insisting that the proposals to have the Port of New York Authority take over the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad and undertake the construction of the $335,000,000 World Trade Center be coupled in a single bill.

HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, April 1 -- Steamy, torpid Hollandia is beginning to star with talk of Papuan nationalism.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange last week fell 13 points (65 cents a bale) to 44 points ($2.20 a bale) below levels of the previous week.
GENEVA, April 2 -- Price changes were very narrow on the Swiss stock markets last week and volume was generally below the levels reached earlier in the year.
LOWICZ, Poland, April 2 -- The town of Lowicz turned out today in a mixture of traditional peasant costumes and machine-made spring finery to celebrate Easter Sunday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 2 -- The population of the world will pass 3,000,000,000 this year, it was predicted here tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The National Science Foundation, which received from the Kennedy Administration the largest budget increase in its ten-year history, will use some of the money to improve science education in colleges.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., April 2 (AP) -- Hank Aaron hit three consecutive home runs today and Warren Spahn pitched a five-hitter as the Milwaukee Braves scored a 9-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.
President Kennedy has penned a wonderful welcome to British tourists on arrival to these shores.
BUENOS AIRES, April 2 -- Maj. Gen. Raul Alejandro Poggi, a military engineer, takes over as Commander in Chief of the Argentine Army Tuesday.

Johnny Murphy, a former New York Yankee pitcher, was signed yesterday as a scout by the New York Baseball Club of the National League. He will supervise scouting activities for the new team in the Metropolitan area and in New England.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Federal spending for goods and services, if it follows the outline of President Kennedy's budget messages, will rise by $2,500,000,000 next year, according to preliminary estimates by Government specialists.

The Civil Aeronautics Board has estimated that Federal subsidies to the thirteen local-service airlines in this country will come to $68,198,000 in the fiscal year starting July 1. This is $6,094,000 more than was granted the "feeder" lines in the current fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- Representative Emanuel Cellar, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, called on President Kennedy today to apply the broad reorganization powers recently voted to him by Congress to the Federal Maritime Board and the Maritime Administration, which are interrelated units of the Department of Commerce.

Earl Equities, Inc., Stanton F. Roth, president, has acquired a long-term leasehold on the twelve-story office building at 49-51 West Forty-fifth Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue). The leasehold was obtained from Haur Associates, Inc., Martin Urban, president.

A NOSTALGIC remembrance of the vitality of New York City in the Nineteen Twenties was presented last night on the "Twentieth Century" program over Channel 2. Though hardly a very generous account of the buoyant age, the program nonetheless was a welcome change in video reprises of the jazz era.
Amerada Petroleum Corporation's net income last year was $27,569,000, equal to $4.37 a common share, the company reported over the week-end.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- Five appointments in the office of the Interior Department solicitors were announced today by Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall.

In an interview published in The Times of March 26 New York City's Planning Commission* Chairman James Felt called for a comprehensive transportation study for the whole metropolitan region. We welcome this new support for a proposal our association and others have been urging for some time.

Having written two consecutive Broadway hits, "A Visit to a Small planet" and "The Best Man," Gore Vidal is preparing his third entry. It is an adaptation of "Romulus the Great," a comedy by Friedrich Duerrenmatt, remembered for his grisly melodrama "The Visit," in which the Lunts were seen.
New York's 1961 Easter parade was wind-blown but well-behaved -- and for ten minutes wore a bonnet of snow.

JERUSALEM (Jordanian Sector), April 2 (UPI) -- King Hussein of Jordan, bowing to centuries-old tradition, restored the keys to the roof at the Church of the Holy Sepulchre here today to the Copts and 2,000 Egyptian Copts called off an Easter-week boycott of Jerusalem.
SOME of the circumstances surrounding Abraham Lincoln's immortal address at Gettysburg were dramatized in "Not in Vain," an occasionally interesting telecast on Channel 4 Saturday night.

BUCHANAN, N.Y., April 2 -- The $100,000,000 atomic-powered generating plant that the Consolidated Edison Company had planned to have in full operation here by today will not be able to start testing its output until late fall.

Night life in Manhattan has been a shade more romantic and continental since a place called Roma di Notte on Second Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street installed a pair of romantic, continental singers last week.

SEVERAL stores in the metropolitan area will open camping shops in the coming weeks. These departments will offer special services, clothing and equipment for children slated for camp this summer. Listed below are the stores and some of the services offered:
NEWARK, April 2 -- A 16-year-old boy was arrested today as a bank robber.

WILMINGTON, N.C., April 2 (UPI) -- Jerry Barber of Los Angeles sank a 4 1/2-foot putt on the first hole of a sudden-death play-off against Chandler Harper today and won the thirteenth annual Azalea invitation golf tournament.
Now is the time for all good men who earned more than $600 last year to come to the aid of their two rich uncles.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Representative Peter Frelinghuysen Jr. of New Jersey has urged the Governors of New York and New Jersey to expedite the Port of New York Authority's final report on a proposed jet airport in Morris County.

Net operating earnings of member banks in the Second Federal Reserve District rose 14.5 per cent in 1960 above the record high earnings of 1959, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
The mutual fund industry is like a giant sloth. It lets its critics attack it as they see fit. Then, reluctantly, the industry decides that it must fight back.

Two American economists have developed a mathematical technique for predicting the degree of economic dislocation any substantial disarmament would produce in this country. The same method can also estimate the effect of major Government and private measures aimed at minimizing the dislocation in employment and production that substantial disarmament might bring about.
PA DONG, Laos, April 2 -- Communist forces are closing in on this mountain stronghold of Laos' fierce Meo tribesmen and it may have to be abandoned in the next few days.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 2 (AP) -- The flood waters of the Cedar River were nearing the Mississippi River tonight after having surged past the communities of Cedar Bluffs, Cedar Valley and Rochester without causing much damage.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 2 -- The Bounty seems to be sailing tranquil seas again.
A civilization with no re-beliefs is doomed, the Rev. D. David H.C. Read asserted yesterday.

With the arrival of warm weather and the desire to build, to repair and to garden, home owners should be aware that the Government stands ready to help with these projects. The Department of Agriculture has available a new 1961 list of information bulletins covering a wide variety of subjects. These were produced with the taxpayers' money but, unfortunately, many taxpayers who could make good use of them are not even aware that they exist.
The sun rose twice for a goodly number of Easter Sunday celebrants yesterday morning.

A Soviet delegation of inland waterway boatmen has found that a riverman's life on the Mississippi today has little resemblance to that described by Mark Twain, whose works have consistently been best sellers in the Soviet Union.

It was hoped with the coming of spring the lady of the house would have been so busy with her curtain hanging, window cleaning and kitchen refurbishing that she would have overlooked a certain desk which stands in a corner of the dining room and in and on which rest many items essential to the head of the house.
A new, yet startingly familiar, kind of advertising is beginning to appear with increasing frequency on the international scene.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI) -- The head of the Peace Corps said today that it would use security checks to protect it from Communist infiltration.

J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., large textile concern, announced over the week-end the election of Alex W. Anthony, Irving B. Cohen and George H. Roderick as vice presidents. At the same time, the company also announced the resignation of John M. Hughlett, a vice president and a director.
Undaunted by slashing gusts, some 300 pacifists walked eighty-seven Manhattan blocks yesterday in an orderly protest against the East-West armament race.
HAMILTON, N.Y., April 2 (AP) -- Mrs. Arthur Linsley of Hamilton, wife of a Colgate University professor, took her children, 4-year-old Barbara and 6-year-old David, for a drive in the country today.
THE New York Bridge Whist Club had a house-warming party Saturday in its new quarters at the Ritz Tower Hotel, Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Avenue.
Snow squalls swept the Boardwalk and two men went swimming at Coney Island yesterday, the resort's traditional opening day.

State Senator Joseph Zaretzki yesterday called the failure to continue the Temporary Commission on Revision of the Constitution one of the major deficiencies of the legislative session that ended March 27.
The National Bureau of Economic Research will try to find out whether society realizes a monetary return on its investments in education.
Amid the splendor of ecclesiastical pageantry and medieval liturgy, Cardinal Spellman celebrated a solemn pontifical Easter mass at 10 A.M. yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 2 -- Nassau and Suffolk County population increased by 54,212 in nine months from April, 1960, through Dec. 31, 1960, according to an estimate today by the Long Island Lighting Company.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- W. Averell Harriman said today that Premier Krushchev was "practicing Brinkmanship" but he did not want war.

RUBARB, rather surprisingly, can prove a lively topic of conversation, at least if introduced in certain circles. Recently a young man whose home town was Utica, Mich., extolled the merits of hothouse rhubarb.
ROME, April 2 -- At the close of Easter Sunday rites in St. Peter's Basilica, Pope John XXIII sent his good wishes and imparted his benediction today to Roman Catholics throughout the world.

ANNAPOLIS, Mid., April 2 (AP) -- Navy led all the way today in the third race over the 15.3-mile Chesapeake Bay course and took the honors in the two-day thirty-second annual McMillan Cup sailing event.

LONDON, April 2 -- The short Easter holiday week of trading ended on the stock market Thursday with prices moving up and The Financial Times industrial shares index only am fraction of a point below its historic peak.

An agreement has been entered into between W. J. Sloane, Inc., furniture chain, and Leonard J. Novogrod, its president, for the sale of the Sloane interests. Mr. Novogrod heads an major investment group in which the City Stores Company holds a major interest.
PITTSBURGH, April 2 -- Orders for steel rebounded in the closing days of March.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- Management of the Chicago and North Western Railway Company blamed the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad today for the breakdown of merger talks between the two carriers.

One of the most significant aspects of the crisis in Laos is that it is testing not only the possibilities of a modus vivendi between Mr. Khrushchev's Russia and Mr. Kennedy's United States but also the state of relationships between the Soviet Union and Communist China.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- The State Department expressed concern today over the reported delay in the French-Algerian peace talks.

The dismissal of three television lighting directors by the Columbia Broadcasting System resulted yesterday in a walkout of about 300 stagehands working for the network. There was no immediate effect on regularly scheduled shows carried by the network.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 2 -- Increased security guards protected President and Mrs. Kennedy at Easter services today at St. Edward's Roman Catholic Church.
The Metropolitan Opera will close its season on Saturday evening, April 15, with a performance of Alban Berg's "Wozzeck."
LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, April 2 -- The long-delayed negotiations between the central Government of Premier Joseph Ileo and the Leftist regime of Antoine Gizenga will get under way tomorrow.
Elsa Marie Ludewig, a clarinetist in the Eastman-Rochester Orchestra, gave a recital Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall that was distinguished and musical.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 2 (AP) -- Ohio University today captured the eight-team Greenbrier intercollegiate golf tournament for the third straight year, finishing thirty-six strokes ahead of the nearest competitor.

PEACE CORPS volunteers will not be the first young Americans to live abroad as members of foreign communities. Over the past decade 5,000 high school students have spent summers as "sons" and "daughters" of families on three continents.

MIAMI BEACH, April 2 (AP) -- Roy Emerson of Brisbane, Australia's No. 3 tennis player, won the Good Neighbor men's singles today by defeating Wolfgang Stuck of West Berlin in five sets, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3.

Employes of the Bronx Zoo and the Coney Island Aquarium went on strike yesterday, and as a result the animals and fish had Easter Sunday virtually to themselves. Both places were closed to the pub lic.
BERLIN, April 2 (UPI)N City officials today that at l'ast 4,000 refugees of an Easter-thne influx of 7,000 refugees fleeing Couununist East Germany had chosen freedom in West Berlin.

The Democratic organization in Rockland, the home county of Michael H. Prendergast, is bypassing him and submitting its recommendations for Federal jobs directly to John M. Bailey, the Democratic national chairman.
BOSTON, April 2 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics overwhelmed St. Louis, 129 -- 95, today in the opener of the National Basketball Association's play-off finals.
TAOS, N.M., April 2 (AP) -- The nation's older skiers held their annual meet today at Taos Ski Valley. Eric Windifch of Arapahoe, Colo., turned in the best time, a clocking of 1 minute 24.6 seconds.
Robert Logan flew home to Scotland last night to die.
The Resurrection of Jesus Christ, with its promise of eternal life for all mankind, was joyfully yet reverently celebrated yesterday by millions of Christians over the world.
DUISBERG, Germany, April 2 (AP) -- Sweden took the first three places today in the epee competition of the world junior fencing tournament.

Your editorial on court rules, if not especially perceptive, was at least moderate Jackson A. Dykman's letter published March 18 in support of your position included a gratuitous attack on lawyers who handle negligence or accident cases. These lawyers represent individuals of all classes.
Six films are scheduled to arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:
The tenor voice of Emile Griffith, the welterweight champion of the world, was missing from the choir of the St. James Missionary Church yesterday for the first Sunday in months.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 2 -- The appointment of Dr. Kenneth T. Bainbridge as George Yasmer Leverett Professor of Physics at Harvard University was announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- A series of charges made in a Soviet Embassy bulletin in Addis Ababa about discriminatory practices affecting Negro diplomats in the United States were termed absurd by a State Department spokesman.

THE women of the United States, given, the opportunity, might well elect John Henry Cutler President. If they do, Duxbury's loss will be Washington's gain. For the editor of the Duxbury (Massachusetts) Clipper has delivered himself of a provocative new book "What About Women?" (Ives Washburn, Inc.; $3.95) that should endear him to females everywhere.
A Federal court jury here yesterday rejected a $1,150,000 damage claim brought against an Australian airline by the family of William Kapell, the young concert pianist who died in a 1953 plane crash.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 3 -- The influential Asian and African bloc split tonight on whether to demand punitive measures -- including sanctions -- against South Africa for persisting in her policies of racial separation.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI) -- Reassignment of four generals to new post was announced today by Secretary of the Army Elvis J. Stahr Jr.

LONDON, April 3 -- A suspicion that the Soviet Union may wish to prolong the fighting in Laos until a special international conference meets to deal with questions of the country's political future is growing in diplomatic circles here.

PAU, France, April 3 -- Jimmy Clark, driving a Formula One factory Lotus ran away with the Gran Prix de Pau today, trouncing Jack Brabham, the world champion; Maurice Trintignant, Jo Bonnier, Oliver Gendebien and other name drivers with the greatest of ease.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Following is the text of a State Department pamphlet on Cuba issued today:

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 3 -- Indonesia reaffirmed today her full support for Communist China's claim to Taiwan. In return Communist China pledged full support for Indonesia's claim to Netherlands New Guinea.
RAMSEY, N.J., April 3 -James P. Mitchell said tonight he opposed any general sales or personal income tax at the state level in New Jersey.

ALBANY, April 3 -- Governor Rockefeller returned today to his Capitol office and to 1,087 unanswered questions. The questions involve whether he should sign or veto that number of bills left him by the 1961 Legislature. He has until midnight, April 24, just three weeks away, to do so.
ROME, April 3 -- A renewed demand for curbs on the freedom of the press in Italy was made today by the authoritative Jesuit magazine Civilta Cattolica.

THINGS started looking up a bit yesterday in the lower New York State trout fishing situation. If the State Department were dealing with the matter, it would announce that this Government viewed current developments with guarded optimism.

Nearly 20,000 students have been graduated from the city colleges' four-year teacher education program in the last decade -- enough to fill half the teaching positions in the city school system -- the Board of Higher Education reported yesterday.
Earnings and case sales of the Pepsi-Cola Company in 1960 were the highest in its sixty-year history, Herbert L. Barnet, president, disclosed in the annual report today.
A floor at 733 Third Avenue, the office tower being built by the Durst Organization, has been leased for twenty years by Parade Publications, Inc., publisher of a syndicated Sunday magazine.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court refused today to resolve a legal conflict over damage suits by coal-mine operators against the United Mine Workers.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, April 3 (AP) -- A million-dollar breach of contract suit was filed in United States District Court today by the Televiews News Company of Davenport against two Pennsylvania publishing concerns.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI) -- The Senate Democratic whip, Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota, said today that Congressional cuts in a supplemental appropriations bill last week left the Administration "in a very difficult situation," particularly in financing of the farm surplus program.

FOR the tiniest feet in the world, new booties are available in Altman's infants' department on the second floor. One pair of rayon satin footlets, designed for babies from one to four months old, is decorated with delicate Orlon lace and ribbon.

PARIS, April 3 -- The announcement of the visit to France by President and Mrs. Kennedy was welcomed here as a mark of deference to President de Gaulle and an opportunity to settle outstanding French-United States disagreements.

" May I buy a ticket?" a woman asked a clerk in the bustling lobby at 195 Broadway yesterday. When the clerk looked surprised and queried her further, the woman said, "Why I thought this was Penn Station!"
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- National Airlines said today it planned to offer its 400,000 shares of Pan American World Airways capital stock for sale to the public.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 3 -- Fifteen public members were appointed today by President Kennedy to his President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity.
Earnings of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway showed a sharp drop for March and the first quarter of this year from the levels of 1960, the company reported yesterday.
THE chronically spotty galleries far downtown offer at the moment some interesting shows of considerable variety.

MIAMI, April 3 (AP) -- Corporal J.P., a 30-1 shot, and Greco Pacific, at 70-1, won the first two races at Gulfstream Park today and accounted for the largest daily double in the track's history -- $4,580.70 for $2.
Steel production again showed a small but noteworthy gain last week.

If deposits can be called the food of banking, the big New York City banks have been on relatively lean diets in recent years. In fact, they have stressed their hunger for more deposits in many ways, including a campaign for permission to raise interest rates.

APPARENTLY, not all of Britain's young, angry and social-minded playwrights write in anger. At least one of them, N.F. Simpson, a London school teacher, regarded abroad as a new and original talent, can be downright amusing when directing shafts of satire at modern man.
Seattle, Wash., is planning the sale of $7,500,000 of harbor improvement bonds on May 4.

The timely report of Peter Braestrup (The New York Times of March 24 dateline) on ballistic missile bases sited in the United States focuses attention upon the vulnerability of Atlas-Titan launchers and their proximity to United States populations.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court let stand today a ruling that the next phase of the seven-year legal battle between the Kohler Company of Wisconsin and the United Automobile Workers be fought here rather than in Chicago.

Supporters of the long-contested merger of the Congregational Christian Churches and the Evangelical and Reformed Church, to form the United Church of Christ, won an interim victory yesterday in Federal Court.
UNIONTOWN, Pa., April 3 (AP) -- Dr. David Wesley Soper, a writer on religion and a professor of philosophy at Beloit College in Wisconsin, was critically injured today in an auto crash.
ANKARA, Turkey, April 3 -Gen. Ismet Inonu, former President of Turkey, has issued a statement calling for a "radical change" in the country's political life.

The British have a well-earned reputation for "muddling through." If ever there was a political muddle in Great Britain it is to be found now in the Labor party. On Sunday the Young Socialists Conference asked for the resignation of Hugh Gaitskell, the party leader. They also joined the exciting drama of "unilateralism" -which consists in trying to get the British Government to give up the nuclear bomb without waiting for general disarmament
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Treasury bill rates bounded upward again on today's sale of the weekly issues.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 3 (UPI) -- A dozen students of Bowling Green State University, unhappy about a ban on beer and good-night kissing, complained today to state legislators. They plan to ask the Ohio General Assembly to investigate their grievances against the university.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- A White House order requiring all Government employes and their dependents to use American-flag carriers when traveling overseas by sea or air is urged in a letter to the President from Senator Warren G. Magnuson, chairman of the Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee.
International House will hold its sixth annual Festival of Arts for the benefit of its scholarship fund on April 20, 21 and 22.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Senator Stephen M. Young, Democrat of Ohio, has described Robert H.W. Welch Jr., founder of the John Birch Society, as a character assassin and a "little Hitler."

U.N. Secretary General Hammarskjold received authority yesterday "to continue until April 21, 1961, to incur commitments for the U.N. operations in the Congo at a level not to exceed $8 million per month." This temporary and strictly tactical victory seemingly means that if the Secretary can get the money he will not be accused of embezzlement if he spends it on preserving peace and security in the troubled African republic.
Judge Mitchell D. Schweitzer of General Sessions Court told four grand juries he was empaneling yesterday that "under no circumstances" were they to submit a presentment to the court.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Consumer installment debt declined in February for the second month in a row. The trends toward smaller extension of new credit and higher repayment of old credit continued.

PITTSBURGH, April 3 (UPI) -- The United Steelworkers asked industry leaders today to join in urging Congressional action to "end the depression in steel" and "wipe out the threat to the nation's economic welfare."

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona said today he would offer an amendment to President Kennedy's school aid bill providing for federal loans to church schools and other private schools.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI) -- The green lawn of the White House was covered today with broken egg shells, lost gloves, jelly beans, colored straw, hunks of chocolate rabbits and thousands of happy children and parents.

MOSCOW, April 3 (AP) -The British Ambassador, Sir Frank Roberts, called at the Soviet Foreign Ministry today in an effort to bring nearer together the Soviet and Western positions on how to stop the fighting in Laos.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- President Kennedy's Peace Corps announced today the appointment of Harry H. Pollak as trade union liaison man with the corps.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce eased today restrictions on certain types of exports to Hong Kong and Macao.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 3 -- India and a group of African powers have drafted a resolution under which the General Assembly would impose a time- limit of twenty-one days for the withdrawal of Belgian officers and mercenaries from the Congo.
CHICAGO, April 3 -- Trial began here today in a $300,000 libel suit involving the alleged anti-cancer drug Krebiozen.

The Grace Line has announced substantial reductions in the minimum rates for its thirteen-day Caribbean luxury cruises aboard the liners Santa Rosa and Santa Paula. It also has announced similar reductions in fares for the seventeen-to-nineteen-day cruises aboard its fifty-two-passenger combination passenger-cargo vessels.

A petite Scarsdale dynamo with a penchant for fine arts and field hockey is also an ardent radio ham. She is Debora Ginsburg, who became seriously interested in the magic of sending messages by radio about five years ago. Her parents encouraged her hobby as long as it did not disrupt her school studies.

A suspended patrolman, who is awaiting trial on charges that he took part in a hold-up last July to raise funds for an African nationalist group, was indicted again yesterday for burglary and grand larceny.

Operating revenues of the New York Times Company rose to a record $112,149,302 in 1960, or $8,879,620 above the 1959 level. But the gain was more than offset by increased operating expenses and net income on a consolidated company basis fell to $1,652,392, or $12.70 a common share, from $3,001,460, or $29.02 a share.
It is possible that there is no more ancient way of gaining man's attention than by the ringing of a bell.

WINTER PARK, Fla., April 3 -- Rollins defeated Amherst and Fordham in rowing today on Lake Maitland. Rollins, stroked by Ed Rupp, a national champion from the New York Athletic Club, was timed in 5 minutes 51 seconds for the mile-and-an-eighth course.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 3 -- The Army lacrosse team defeated Oxford-Cambridge, 12 to 4, in an exhibition game today. It was the fourth match in the goodwill tour of the Oxford-Cambridge team.
Mayor Wagner moved yesterday to set up machinery for the city's participation in any broadened urban-renewal program that Congress might approve.

THE "neutral mediator" who carried the Congo confederation proposal from President Joseph Kasavubu yesterday to Mr. Kasavubu's bitter rival, Antoine Gizenga, is a wise and tenacious Congolese. He has managed to keep a high position despite the gyrations of his country's politics.
ALBANY, April 3 -- New York State spent more than $2,000,000,000 in the fiscal year that closed last Friday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 3 -- Duke Maas, the 30-year-old relief pitcher who was one of the seven players the Yankees lost in the American League expansion draft last December, returned to the Bombers today.

CLEVELAND, April 3 (UPI) -- The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad disclosed today that it had asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to include it in the proposed merger of the Norfolk and Western and the New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad and the lease of the Wabash Railroad.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -The Interstate Commerce Commission said today that bankruptcy and a subsequent reorganization of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad would not solve the financial ills that have troubled it for years.

LOS ANGELES, April 3 (AP) -- Different views were voiced today on the death of Capt. John Birch, for whom the society was named. Captain Birch was killed Aug, 25, 1945, while on an intelligence mission in central China for the Office of Strategic Services.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program announced a plan yesterday to attract more individual blood donors.
" The United States Steel Hour," an hour-long drama series now in its eighth year on television has been renewed for the 1961-62 season. The one-year contract becomes effective June 28.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -The United States called on the regime of Premier Fidel Castro tonight "to sever its links with the international Communist movement" and "to restore the dignity" of the original Cuban revolution.

TRUC GIANG, Vietnam, April 3 -- The efforts of the Communist Viet Cong guerrilla organization to destroy the Government of President Neo Dinh Diem have intensified sharply with the approach of South Vietnam's first Presidential election. The election is scheduled for Sunday.
In weather more conducive to football, Columbia opened its baseball season yesterday by beating Manhattan College, 5 -- 3, at Baker Field.

The father of a large family lives in perpetual dread of many things, naturally, not the least being the milkman's bill, but what strikes him as the most unpleasant reality of all is the frequent ritual of the birthday party.
A state Supreme Court justice in Albany yesterday directed the state Education Department to review the status of Harry R. (Bobby) Sand, assistant coach of the 1949-50 City College basketball team.

The John Burroughs Medal was awarded last night to Dr. Loren C. Eiseley, anthropologist, writer and provost at the University of Pennsylvania, in recognition for his latest book, "The Firmament of Time."
PARIS, April 3 -- A riderless steeplechaser leaped the rail at Auteuil yesterday and plowed through the crowd, injuring six persons, two seriously.
The exclusion of American underwriters from insuring United States aid cargoes to some countries was assailed yesterday by a leading marine insurance official.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -The Inter-American Development Bank announced today that it would act as financial agent in a $1,250,000 loan that has been made to a small farm colony in Brazil. The loan was made by the United States.

KAMINA, the Congo, April 3 (AP) -- The United Nations was completing the airlift of nearly 1,000 Indian troops to this big military base in Katanga Province today in defiance of a warning by President Moise Tshombe that the move could mean war.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 3 -- Science and technology have contributed remarkably during the last few decades to potentialities for the discovery and exploitation of ground water reserves. SAN JUAN, P.R. ON week-ends the Teatro la Mascara is playing a Spanish version of Thornton Wilder's "Our Town."

Five men and a corporation were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of selling $1,000,000 worth of unregistered stock of the nowbankrupt Automatic Washer Company of Iowa.
DAKAR, Senegal, April 3 -Africans were charmed today by Vice President Johnson's show of simplicity and friendly interest in their progress and preoccupations.

OVER the past week-end, when the team officially designated to represent the United Sates in the matches for the 1961 world championship played a series of five practice matches against a group of other prominent American players, it was agreed that the results would be "off the record."

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 3 -- President Kennedy announced today that he planned to fly to Paris May 31 for three days of conferences with President de Gaulle.
CHICAGO, April 3 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
