WARSAW, April 3 -- The Polish Communist party has issued a secret memorandum decreeing a short-term policy of comparative moderation in the Government's handling of the Roman Catholic Church.
Mrs. Shirley Kaye said yesterday that she had submitted her resignation, effective April 1, as Democratic woman leader in the Seventh Assembly District.
The market for prime debt investments was unsure of itself yesterday. Prices tended to decline on light business.

DETROIT, April 3 (AP) -After the slowest first quarter production in nine years, the auto industry anticipates an increase in car output for the second three months of 1961, according to Automotive News, trade publication.

" L'Avventura," an Italian language romantic drama with English sub-titles, opens today at the Beekman Theatre, Second Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street. Monica Vitti, Gabriele Ferzetti and Lea Massari play leading roles in the Janus Films release, which was written and directed by Michelangelo Antonioni.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk and other high State Departmen officials spoke today at a foreign policy briefing for broadcasters of the country. President Kennedy will address the group tomorrow.
FRANCO CORELLI sang his first Metropolitan Don Carlo in the Verdi opera of the same name last night at the opera house.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., April 3 (UPI) -- A national officer of the Birch Society said today that the Kennedy Administration included "weak-in-the-head personalities" who might act in the interests of the Communists.

Jack Benny and Isaac Stern engaged in some musical horseplay at Carnegie Hall yesterday and the Philadelphia Orchestra enjoyed itself to the last measure. Informality was the tone of an afternoon rehearsal for an evening video-taping of "Carnegie Hall Salutes Jack Benny," an effort to honor the comedian and collect contributions for the Carnegie Society, the hall's fund-raising arm.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 3 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold won strong support today for his efforts to keep the United Nations from bankruptcy.
A sharp spurt in automobile sales across the country last month and brisk business at the International. Automobile Show at the Coliseum here led automotive leaders yesterday to predict good times.
Eastern Air Lines has announced a plan to decentralize its operation and increase personal supervision over its 105 field stations in the United States, Canada, Mexico, Bermuda and Puerto Rico.
WHITE PLAINS, April 3 -Westchester County has "ridden out the '60-'61 recession in remarkable fashion," Edwin G. Michaelian, the County Executive, said today.
Harry Waltzer, business agent of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union of New York and Vicinity, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court to extortion and racketeering charges.
CHICAGO, April 3 (AP) -- A late rally canceled out numerous losses in the grain futures market today and prices finished mostly steady to strong although a few weak spots remained in corn and wheat.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -Lofti, a small piggyback satellite that failed to separate from its carrier, has made some unexpected discoveries that may lead to "remarkable advances" in communications, the Navy said today.

Some bowlers in the New York area have raised objections to paying membership dues to the American Bowling Congress in each league in which they bowl. These bowlers may have even more to complain about shortly.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 3 -- The first high-level conciliation efforts between the Congolese central Government and the rival regime of Antoine Gizenga took place in Stanleyville today.

SAIGON, Vietnam April 3 (Reuters) -- Communist guerrillas have launched widsepread attacks in what the South Vietnam Government believes is a campaign to upset Sunday's Presidential elections, authoritative sources said today.

The news item in your issue of March 18 relating to the sale of the Walt Whitman plaque on the building at Fulton and Cranberry Streets is a poignant reminder that this plaque was probably the only thing approaching a memorial to the poet to be found anywhere in Brooklyn.

BONN, Germany, April 3 (UPI) -- Four young American soldiers were under United States Army custody today for allegedly beating up a Soviet lieutenant colonel while on a drinking spree last night, informed sources said today.

The fossilized skeleton of a hitherto unknown soaring reptile has been discovered in New Jersey by three teen-age boys. The discovery, a scientist said yesterday, "has opened up a whole new facet of vertebrate evolution."

LAUREL, Md., April 3 (AP) -- Herberto Hinojosa, who rode five winners on Saturday, had four more today at Laurel Race Course. One of the four was George A. Garrett's Bonzo in the featured Lawrence Clark Purse.

AN exhibition of vermeil appointments for the home that opens today at Tiffany's can be viewed like a Paris fashion showing: The very few who can afford an original design will have a creation of lasting value; others must wait for the design inspiration to influence more modest-priced objects.
A Brooklyn luncheonette owner yesterday turned over to the Walt Whitman Birthplace Association a plaque commemorating the American poet.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- The Indian Claims Commission awarded the Cherokee Indian Nation of Oklahoma today $14,789,476 on claims involving Oklahoma land.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 3 -- Rauf Denktash, deputy leader of the Turkish Cypriote community, advised Turkish importers today not to pay taxes or customs duties.
The National Republican Club moved yesterday to its new home at the Dryden East Hotel, 150 East Thirty-ninth Street.

Howard Grant went in for a lot of flying yesterday. The first time he used a jet plane, which brought him from Florida to New York. The second time was aboard Mrs. George D. Widener's Evening Glow, at Aqueduct.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 3 to 17 points (15 to 85 cents a bale) yesterday.
JACKSON, Miss., April 3 (UPI) -- The Mississippi Supreme Court ruled today that a Negro on trial was not necessarily entitled to have Negroes included in his jury.

A new book by Theodore H. White, called "The Making of the President 1960," which Atheneum will publish July 6, has been chosen as the midsummer selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club. It is an analytical account of the "decisions, acts and accidents," beginning months before the conventions, that ultimately put John F. Kennedy into the White House.
ALBANY, April 3 (AP) -- New York state's program observing the Civil War centennial will open here April 17.
Sea-Land Service, Inc., announced yesterday that it would took about $27,000,000 in financing in an attempt to introduce trailership operations in an intercoastal shipping service by June, 1962.
TUNIS, April 3 -- The United States Ambassador to Tunisia, Walter N. Walmsley Jr., received two Ministers of the nationalist Algerian Provisional Government at his residence here today.

Leading banks reported yesterday net operating earnings for the first three months of 1961 down as much as 12 per cent from the level of the year before. Lower interest rates on loans, combined with a continuing rise in expenses, were blamed.

LONDON, April 3 -- Disturbances erupted near the United States Embassy in Grosvenor Square tonight when several thousand demonstrators tried to stage a sit-down protest against United States Polaris missiles.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- The Space Agency said today it would finance two parallel studies on the use of thermal arc jet rocket engines for space missions.

Jack P. Schleifer and Milton Schwartz, New York realty investors, took title yesterday to the Connie Mack Stadium in Philadelphia, home of the Phillies of the National League. They signed a contract to buy the baseball landmark last week.

The New York Telephone Company has published a guide to help Spanish-speaking subscribers find anything they need, from "abanicos electricos" (electric fans) to "zapatos usados" (used clothing, or more literally, worn shoes).

Economists, business men and other observers and participants in the current economic scene could not find much to rejoice about in this year's first quarter. It was a period in which the recession that began roughly a year ago continued to hold sway. Unemployment set unhappy records for the period since the Great Depression of the Nineteen Thirties, exacting an all too high human cost.
OTTAWA, Ill., April 3 (UPI) -- Chester Weger, a young woodsman, was sentenced to life imprisonment today for the murder of one of three matrons found bludgeoned to death in Starved Rock State Park.

The first art exhibition to be sponsored by the American Church Union for the benefit of the Episcopal Guild for the Blind will take place on Monday and Tuesday evenings at the Little Studio Creative Art Center, 787 Madison Avenue.
DES MOINES, Iowa, April 3 (AP) -- The National Farmers Organization initiated today a test holding action for higher prices for cattle, hogs and sheep.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review the convictions of two labor union figures, Dave Beck, former head of the Teamsters Union, and Maurice A. Hutcheson, president of the Carpenters Union.
Obdulio Nunez of Puerto Rico defeated Phil Moyer of Portland, Ore., on a technical knockout last night at the St. Nicholas Arena.
The Union Pacific Railroad disclosed yesterday that it had purchased 600,750 shares, or about 9 1/2 per cent, of the stock of the Denver and Rio Grande Western Railroad.

NEW DELHI, India, April 3 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru warned today that activities to oust Rajeshwar Dayal, the Indian who heads the United Nations mission in the Congo, could have "some effect on the maintenance of our forces there."

HONG KONG, April 3 -- Communist China announced tonight the release of Robert Ezra McCann, a 60-year-old American business man who has been imprisoned in Tientsin as a spy for ten years. Mr. McCann is said to be dying of cancer.
THE Samuel Beckett play, "Waiting for Godot," has such passionate supporters and detractors that its current revival on "The Play of the Week" undoubtedly will rekindle the established controversies.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 2 -- African diplomats using public conveyances in Washington must enter special cars bearing signs "for Negroes," the Soviet Embassy asserts in its current bulletin, issued here.

IN "Don't Tell Alfred"* Nancy Mitford is so merry about French and British pomposities that she almost forgets the obligatory swipes at Americans. This will never do. Our place in the world entitles us to far more disrespect when skilled satire is at play.

Each April 19 Maine and Massachusetts celebrate Patriots Day, marking the courage and devotion of those sturdy Americans who first stood fast in the face of tyranny at the Revolutionary battles of Lexington and Concord.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -A Cuban gunboat intercepted and detained the American cable-repair schooner Western Union Friday, but let the vessel go when a United States destroyer and naval planes rushed to the scene, the State Department said today.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
Leonard B. Rist has been appointed special representative for Africa by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank).

The near-by potato futures were strong yesterday on the New York Merchantile Exchange. Trading reflected continued firm cash prices in Idaho and improved demand for Maine supplies. Trade buying and light short covering set off profit taking and scattered selling.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company expects to spend "somewhat more" than the $80,000,000 previously announced for capital improvements this year.

The early Easter and weather better than that of a year earlier combined to push sales of the eight major New York department stores and their branches 19 per cent above the 1960 level in March, a survey by The New York Times disclosed yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, April 3 -Thomas J. Anderson, a publisher and member of the Birch Society's national council, charged here today that General Eisenhower had been a "dupe" of the Communists.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 3 -- The Yankees, still in a horrendous batting slump, lost again today, this time in sixteen innings to the Philadelphia Phillies.
PARIS, April 3 -- The war in Algeria continued unabated over the Easter week-end.

HAVANA, April 3 -- Robert Taber, an American who is one of the leaders of the Fair Play for Cuba Committee in the United States, said today that he had "no immediate plans to return to the United States."
Mayor Wagner called yesterday for representatives of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company and its 2,00 striking employes to meet with him at 2 P.M. today at Gracie Mansion.
CHICAGO, April 3 (UPI) -Selection of forty-one "notable children's books of 1960" through a poll of librarians has been announced by the American Library Association.
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 3 -Iain Macleod, Britain's Colonial Secretary, tried unsuccessfully today to break the political deadlock in Kenya over the release of Jomo Kenyatta, former Mau Mau leader.
G. Russell Clark, State Superintendent of Banks, said yesterday that he would be willing to testify if the Federal Reserve Board decided to reconsider its disapproval of an upstate bank merger.

A group of tenants charged in State Supreme Court yesterday that the State Rent Commission had issued eviction notices to them "that were not in accordance with the law." The tenants asked the court to dismiss the notices.

" Luther," which deals with Martin Luther, Protestant reformer, as a young man, has been withdrawn from Gian Carlo Menotti's Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy. Because of its theme, there had been rumors that John Osborne's drama would not be permitted to go on in Italy, which helps the festival with financial support.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -The next steps to bring about a political settlement of the conflict in Laos will top the list of problems to come under review in five days of meetings between United States and British leaders opening here tomorrow.
An electrical fire under a car of a New Haven Railroad train in the Bronx last evening delayed 40,000 rush-hour commuters for up to eighty minutes.
MIAMI, April 3 -- The day after manana. That is the jubilant day when the impoverished Cuban refugee -- there are 50,000 of them here -- expects to return to his homeland.

Your March 23 editorial "Of Sealing Wax and Ships," on the seizure by the postal authorities of material from Communist-controlled countries, fails to take into consideration the fact that much of the material is not intended for those who are "sufficiently mature to choose their own reading-matter or to resist the wiles of Communist propaganda."

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., April 3 -- The executive committee of the Rockland County Democratic party affirmed its loyalty tonight to Michael H. Prendergast, the state chairman, and demanded the resignation of William A. Zeck, county chairman.
FAR out was the phrase for last night's program at the Village Gate. And what it showed was that Japanese, when they set their minds to it, can go further out than Americans.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -Premier Tage Erlander of Sweden cautioned the United States today against trying to reduce unemployment through a protectionist, or high-tariff, trade policy.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday a gain of 14.1 per cent in net income for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28. Net income for the first two months of 1961 was 13.2 per cent higher than in the 1960 month.
Attorneys for the New York Zoological Society and for a union representing 300 striking employes agreed yesterday to meet today at the Bronx Zoo's Administration Building.

The Times recently reprinted the "Commissioner's Plan" of New York City and commented on the "lost" parks and squares that in 1811 had been proposed to be kept open in the future building up of Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The Federal Government and institution of higher learning continue to be fair targets of the celebrated observation by Charles Dudley Warner: "Everybody talks about the weather, but nobody does anything about it."
YONKERS, April 3 -- Roosevelt Raceway served Yonkers Raceway with a show cause order tonight involving Masina, the French 5-year-old trotting champion.
TAKE the basic theme of "Lysistrata," the gods on and off Olympus and the music of Offenbach, add a low Broadway common denominator and you have "The Happiest Girl in the World."
A strike at five Macy department stores was averted yesterday when terms for a two-year contract covering 8,500 employes were reached after a twenty-one-hour negotiating session.
A spectacular surge of trading activity in American Telephone and Telegraph Company dominated the stock market yesterday.
The eleven-member commission appointed over the weekend by Mayor Wagner to draft a new Charter for the city will go to work today.

WHEN Steve Owen coached the football Giants, he liked to tell the story of the Indian tribe in his native Oklahoma that sought the services of a rainmaker. Not a drop of water had fallen in months. The crops had shriveled in the parched earth. The river beds were dry, the wells empty.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI) -- Najeeb E. Halaby, head of the Federal Aviation Agency, urged the nation's airlines today to be more candid with their customers.
The Sante Fe Opera will go to the West Berlin Music Festival in September and perform stage works of Igor Stravinsky and Douglas Moore.

WILTON, Conn., April 4 -The Soil Conservation Service of the United States Department of Agriculture and the state Department of Agriculture have begun an economic survey of flood damage over a fifty-year period.
A training center to teach Latin-American armies anti-guerrilla and guerrilla tactics will be established this summer by the Army in the Canal Zone.
One could hardly imagine a more ideal part for Laurel Hurley than that of Adina in Donizetti's "L'Elisir d'Amore."
DAKAR, Senegal, April 4 -- Premier Mamadou Dia announced today an ambitious four-year plan for economic and social advancement. He called for economic and technical assistance from friendly nations.

Governor Rockefeller has returned from a brief vacation and started work on 1,087 bills left behind by the Legislature. But even with the application of maximum wisdom on this legislation, which must he signed or vetoed by midnight April 24, he cannot recover unaided from what the Legislature did not do in its disorderly final week.
JERUSALEM, April 4 -- The assistant defense counsel for Adolf Eichmann reported today that he had failed to get any witnesses to testify on behalf of the former Nazi at his coming trial in Israel.
BONN, Germany, April 4 -The West German Government is not obligated to pay the defense for Adolf Eichmann, a court costs in Cologne ruled today.

After refusing an exhibition permit to a cut version of the film, "The Savage Eye," a Chicago censor board has approved the complete, uncut film for public showing, it was announced here yesterday by the Trans-Lux Distributing Corporation.

A tie bid of 100.35 for $30,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds of Southern California Edison as 4 1/2 per cent obligations resulted yesterday in an award to Blyth Co. and associates in a run-off.
A Civil War manuscript attacking General Ulysses S. Grant's "grave neglects" of military tactics in the Battle of Shiloh has been published for the first time by Columbia University.

Events tonight: "Rigoletto," Metropolitan Opera, 8 o'clock; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Charles Munch, conductor, Byron Janis, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Folk-introit program, "Upstate Meets Downstate," Town Hall, 8; Siegfried Behrend, guitarist, Judson Hall, 8:45.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- Sales of manufacturing corporations increased by $7,700,000,000 last year, to a record of $345,700,000,000, but profits dropped $1,100,000,000, to $15,200,000,000.

SAPELO ISLAND, Ga., April 4 (AP) -- Tobacco heir Richard J. Reynolds announced today that he had taken a fourth wife in a shipboard wedding in the South China Sea. His third wife promptly branded the marriage illegal.
Top-level changes in the management of the International Finance Corporation (I.F.C.) were announced yesterday.
PARIS, April 4 -- A bomb explosion damaged the Paris Bourse this afternoon and caused injuries to about thirty persons, five of whom were hospitalized.

HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, March 27 -- A Harvard anthropological expedition, led by Robert G. Gardner, has discovered in the heart of Dutch New Guinea a savage tribe whose culture is focused on war -- the Willigiman-Wallalua people in the lofty Baliem Valley.

" Maybe we're kind of square because we dig Brahms," a 15-year-old French horn player said without conviction to two companions yesterday on De Kalb Avenue. They were watching 4,000 teen-agers wait to get into a rock 'n' roll show at the Brooklyn Paramount Theatre.

AN anonymous Texas housewife some years ago created one of the sweetest mysteries of life. Fortunately, however, she decided not to keep the secret of her very special cake a mystery forever. She lent the recipe to a friend, who lent it to a friend, who lent it to a friend.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 4 -- Canada warned United Nations members today that their disputes in New York were preventing a solution of the political problem in the Congo.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) asserted yesterday that increased taxes on foreign investments might hinder rather than help reduction of the deficit in the nation's balance of payments problem.
LONDON, April 4 -- A letter to Premier Khrushchev demanding Soviet nuclear disarmament was delivered to the Soviet Embassy here today by three members of the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament.
Ceremonies marking the end of a twenty-five month reconstruction job on the Riverside Drive viaduct between St. Claire's Place and 135th St. will be held at 10 A.M. today.

LONDON, April 4 -- Strong demand, stimulated by optimism regarding business prospects at home and in the United States, resulted in a new record being set in industrial share prices when the stock market reopened here today after the Easter holiday.

Mayor Wagner plans to designate two new Neighborhood Conservation Districts -- areas of sound but decaying tenements in which residents, property owners and community groups join with municipal agencies to stem the spread of blight.

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 4 (AP) -- Charlie Sifford, who has won the national Negro golf championship five times will compete in the Greater Greensboro open golf tournament April 13-16. He will be the first Negro to compete in a Southern tournament sponsored by the Professional Golfers Association.

Dr. Ray E. Trussell warned yesterday that ten of New York's twenty-two municipal hospitals would face a critical medical manpower shortage by July 1. "The city," said the recently appointed Commissioner of Hospitals, "is over-extended on its ability to render care of a general hospital nature."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 4 -- The Soviet Union gave full support today to a move by twenty-five African states for sanctions against South Africa because of her policy of apartheid, or racial separation.
BOSTON, April 4 (UPI) -- The New England Council issued the following report today:
STANLEYVILLE, April 4 (AP) -- President Cleophas Kamitatu of Leopoldville Province declared today the Congo will always be united "and will have only one Central Government, based at Stanleyville."

A number of residents in Herkimer, Ithaca, Ilion and Little Falls, N.Y., complained yesterday that they had received citations from Magistrate's Court here for failing to pay parking tickets -- tickets they said they had never received.

General Electric Credit Corporation raised by one-eighth and one-quarter percentage point yesterday the rates it pays on most maturities of its unsecured short-term obligations sold directly to investors.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Britain and the Soviet Union are expected to issue a joint call in two or three days for an immediate cease-fire in Laos.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- Federal Judge Julius H. Miner moved today to reach an out-of-court settlement of a $300,000 libel action against Dr. George D. Stoddard, chancellor of New York University. The case involves Dr. Stoddard's criticism of Krebiozen, a drug alleged to be valuable in treating cancer.
WHEN is an ash tray more than an ash tray? When it is made of Steuben crystal according to this concern, which is now demonstrating how twenty-four ash trays can make a table setting.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 4 -- President Janio Quadros authorized the Brazilian Government's shipping line today to acquire thirty-six ships from Yugoslavia.

First-quarter earnings of the P. Lorillard Company are expected to show a substantial gain above those for the 1960 period on a slight rise in sales. This statement was made yesterday at the company's annual meeting in the Biltmore Hotel by Harold F. Temple, president and chief executive officer.

Net operating earnings of The First National City Bank of New York for the first three months of 1961 were $17,134,000, or $1.37 a share, the bank reported yesterday. This compared with combined net operating earnings of the bank and the First National City Trust Company of $18,992,000, or $1.52 a shar, in the 1960 first quarter.

United States wrestlers, who have been seriously handicapped by the wide variance in the collegiate rules under which they have been primarily trained and the code in worldwide use outside of this country, have received heartening news.

Northeast Airlines, Inc., whose directors approved a proposed merger agreement with Trans World Airlines, Inc. last year, has informed T.W.A. that it did not believe it desirable to extend beyond March 31, the expiration date in which T.W.A. directors might act on the proposed merger.

Women were put in their rightful place recently by Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg. He said he had chosen a woman to be his consultant on the rights of workers because she was the most competent person for the job and not because she was a woman.

MOSCOW, April 4 (UPI) -The Soviet magazine Ogonyok, which set off a diplomatic flurry last January by asserting that eleven missing United States airmen were in Russian hands, was criticized publicly today for "damaging the interests of the Soviet states."

WASHINGTON, April 4 -The chairman of the Senate Housing subcommittee predicted passage of the Administration's program today after testimony from Robert C. Weaver, head of the Housing and Home Finance Agency.
Two insurance companies took over responsibility for the repair and maintenance of 52,000 on-street parking meters here at 12:01 A.M. yesterday.
DETROIT, April 4 (AP) -Michigan voters have called a constitutional convention to decide whether the state's constitution should be revised, allowed to stand or be replaced.
ST. LOUIS, April 4 -- Mayor Raymond R. Tucker was reelected to a third term today by a resounding margin over Ben H. Lindenbusch, his Republican opponent.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 4 -- France announced today that she could not approve this year's expected total of $120,000,000 in costs for the United Nations military operation in the Congo.
A 34-year-old conductor has won the first Walter J. Naumburg Foundation Conducting Award and, as a result, will direct the New York Philharmonic.
ALBANY, April 4 -- Governor Rockefeller approved a bill today to strengthen the Waterfront Commission's ability to deal with criminals on the New York and New Jersey docks.

The proclamation by President Kennedy that the month of April be set aside as Cancer Control Month points up the need to devote larger facilities to finding a means of controlling this dread disease. Cancer strikes in approximately two of three American families. Through the medical and allied health professions the nation will be alerted during the coming weeks to the great strides already made and those that must be made in the future.

RUBE LAZARUS is "a walking library -- you don't have to pick up a book, he'll give you the citation and the paragraph number." Even more, "Rube knows where the bodies are buried." Those are views of friends and sometimes unwilling admirers of Reuben Avis Lazarus, who is created with having drafted more laws affecting the City of New York than any man in history.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points off to 2 up yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

Taxpayers who become dizzy at the thought of figuring their New York State income taxes will be relieved to know that the state now will figure the taxes for them -- if they file a short form (IT-200). The State's short form has been reduced from a full-size sheet of paper to a tabulating card with instructions on the back.
Sales and earnings of the International Basic Economy Corporation in 1960 were the highest in its thirteen-year history, according to the annual report released today.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -The Civil Aeronautics Board cleared the way today for the creation of the nation's largest airline with the approval of the proposed merger of United Air Lines and Capital Airlines, Inc.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 4 -- Foreign Minister Joseph M.A.H. Luns will arrive in the United States tomorrow to "discuss a number of outstanding problems between America and the Netherlands."
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 4 -Both sides have taken the offensive this week in the fierce jungle fighting between communist guerrillas and South Vietnamese troops.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 4 (AP) -- Dr. Frank P. Graham, the United Nations mediator, was described in the South Carolina Senate today as a spokesman for Communist causes who sought to indoctrinate "Leftist" leanings into the youth of the nation.
THIS deal, played at the Mayfair Bridge Club in New York, might be called a bridge problem, but it is unlike the standard type of bridge problem.
The work of drafting a new Charter for New York City got under way yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 4 -- The opening of the Economic and Social Council was blocked today when the Soviet Union challenged the legality of the session.

ROCHELLE PARK, N.J., April 4 -- State Senator Walter H. Jones assailed tonight what he characterized as a "low blow" by James P. Mitchell, his most formidable opponent in the contest for the Republican nomination for Governor.

The quiet which has prevailed of late along the advertising news front, was shattered yesterday by word that the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company and Foote,_Cone Belding, Inc., had come to a parting of the ways.

The problem that the United States has had for years in taking a position on the rival claims of Indonesia and the Netherlands to sovereignty over West New Guinea is not becoming any easier with the passage of time.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 4 (AP) -- Gov. John Patterson today gave reporters a copy of a proposed law that would give the Chief Executive strict control over liquor advertising in newspapers and magazines in Alabama.

Fordham University's kidnapped mascot, a yearling ram named Rameses XIX, turned up outside Madison Square Garden yesterday, his fleece trimmed in a contemptuous poodle cut and tinted a tattle-tale Kelly green.
GENEVA, April 4 -- The Soviet Union raised the West's expectations at the nuclear test-ban conference today and then dashed them again -- all in thirty minutes.
A group of leading physicists from the United States, the Soviet Union and other nations was told last night that underground nuclear blasts may produce detectable electric signals.

A gift of $1,000,000 has been made to the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University and it will be used to establish a David and Irene Schwartz Pavilion when its new University Hospital is built.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The United States said today it was trying to get French Government and Algerian rebel representatives to sit down at the conference table and settle their differences "calmly."

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- When the Kennedy Administration publicly denounces the Cuban Government as a "Soviet satellite" which confronts the Western Hemisphere with a "grave and urgent challenge," it is obvious that the Cuban crisis is entering a new and critical phase.
MIAMI, April 4 (UPI) -Two American fliers arrived in Miami tonight after their release by the Cuban Government, which had held them incommunicado since March 24.

YONKERS, April 4 -- Yonkers Raceway officials will enter New York State Supreme Court in Mineola, L.I., tomorrow morning to show cause why they should not he enjoined from permitting Masina, a French trotter, to race at their track in her United States debut before she races at Roosevelt Raceway.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Commerce Department's Business Advisory Council -- a blue-ribbon group of corporate and financial executives -- accepted a greater degree of Government regulation today.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- The Army made public today extracts from the service record of Capt. John M. Birch, for whom the ultra-rightist Birch Society was named.
BUENOS AIRES, April 4 -- A visit of the United States Ambassador yesterday to Cordoba University was marked by tomato-throwing and insults by a small group of students.
CHICAGO, April 4 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Charles A. Buckley Jr. said last night that he had dropped all connection with an application for a zoning variance in Riverdale, the Bronx, that has aroused indignant opposition among residents.

LUIGI PIRANDELLO'S "The Mountain Giants," which he left incomplete at his death, was given the first of two "dramatic reading" Monday night at The Living Theatre. It would be hard to imagine a more appropriate showcase or style for this strange work, the fourth act of which was reconstructed by Stefano Pirandello from his father's death-bed utterances.
A New York County grand jury began hearing evidence yesterday in the college basketball inquiry.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 4 -- The Soviet Union suggested today that United Nations information services were needed more "in some Western countries" than in the territories of Africa.

The threatened port-rail strike in which Francis A. O'Neill Jr. took a personal hand yesterday as chairman of the National Mediation Board arises from a complicated, and, in some respects, puzzling dispute.

The State Department's White Paper on Cuba is a document of high quality. This is a carefully drawn up and brilliantly argued case. Within the limits of what it sets out to do, it will be hard, if not impossible, to refute on its own terms. If the Cubans wanted to answer it effectively, they could only do so by replying on a plane equally high and academic in its tone and content.

One more effort to convince Allan P. Kirby of Morristown, N.J., and the Murchison Brothers of Dallas, Tex., that "millionaires don't fight" failed over last week-end. As a consequence, more than 1,000,000 shares of Alleghany Corporation common stock have been purchased at prices ranging up to 15 1/2 in the last two days by the two factions.

DETROIT, April 4 (UPI) -Robert (Corky) De Graff, a 25-year-old Grand Rapids (Mich.) bowler, today became the youngest man in American Bowling Congress history to fire a 300 game in its annual tournament.

Daitch Crystal Dairies, Inc., reported yesterday that sales in the year ended on Dec. 31 climbed to a record of $90,882,428, but that net income slid to $154,739, or 10 cents a share. In 1959, the food store chain cleared $902,553, equal to 57 cents a share, on sales of $83,480,114.
Pete Seeger, 42-year-old folk singer, was sentenced yesterday to one year in prison for refusing to tell the House Un-American Activities Committee about possible Communist affiliations.
The medical profession can make a significant contribution to the nation's effort to assist the countries of the Middle East, Asia, Africa and Latin America.
The chief spokesman 3,500,000 British employes in shipbuilding and metalworking industries called yesterday an international conference combat the slump in ship construction.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 4 (AP) -- The national police said today that searchers had spotted a Chilean airliner that had crashed last night with twenty-four aboard in the Andes. The Chilean Air Force later denied the report. There was no explanation of the conflicting reports.
NEW DELHI, India, April 4 -- A top Soviet Communist is scheduled to arrive here tomorrow in an apparent effort to influence the coming national convention of the Indian Communist party.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- National unemployment decline by 200,000 between mid-February and mid-March, but the total of 5,495,000 was a post-war record for the month, the Labor Department reported today.

Louis J. Lefkowitz, the State Attorney General, has supported Wiltwyck School for Boys in its court appeal to move to Westchester County from upstate. The school, which cares for emotionally disturbed children under 12 years of age, will argue it appeal tomorrow.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan pledged yesterday to support legislative action that would restore to grand juries the right to make presentments.

LISBON, Portugal, April 4 -- Six men who have been in political asylum in the Brazilian Embassy here for several weeks were allowed to leave for Rio de Janeiro by air today. With their departure there are no more oppositionists in asylum in any embassy.

Virginia Electric and Power Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for February and for twelve months ended on Feb. 28. The company also reported that it added 21,534 customers during the twelve-month period, of which 18,394 were electric and 3,140 gas users.
An accident in the fourth race at Aqueduct yesterday resulted in the death of Roy L. Gilbert, a jockey.
Fred Astaire will become a television fixture next season.

LEOPOLDVILLE, April 4 -- United Nations headquarters here withheld all information about the events in Elisabethville today. There were strong indications that spokesmen were under formal instructions not to give out information.
STRATFORD-ON-AVON, April 4 -- The Royal Shakespeare Theatre opened its 102d season tonight with a lilting production of "Much Ado About Nothing."
Heaviness prevailed in most Treasury securities and other prime, fixed-income investments yesterday. Business continued light.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 4 (AP) -- Carmen Molino of the New York Athletic Club scored an upset in the Amateur Athletic Union national wresting meet by pinning Larry Lauchle, a member of the 1960 Olympic team, in 2 minutes 8 seconds tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- After eight years of trying the Government deported today Carlos Marcello, alleged rackets chief in New Orleans.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -The Democratic National Committee is preparing to match President Kennedy's popularity with voters against the political hesitancy and opposition of Congress.

The official results of the Sebring, Fla., twelve-hour race on March 25 show that the winning Ferrari, driven by Phil Hill and Oliver Gendebein, covered 208 laps of the 5.2-mile course for a total distance of 1,081.60 miles, with an average speed of 90.133 miles an hour.
DALLAS, Wednesday, April 5 -- A conservative Republican professor drew at least 100,000 votes more than his nearest exponent in a sixty-four-candidate special Senate election in Texas yesterday.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 4 -If it's work the Yankees need to whip themselves into shape, they certainly are getting it, though with unfortunate results.

Excavation work was started yesterday for Tower East, a thirty-five-story apartment house at 190 East Seventy-second Street in the blockfront on the west side of Third Avenue between Seventy-first and Seventy-second Streets.

AKRON, Ohio, April 4 (UPI) -- An amended $500,000 libel suit against J.P. Seiberling, president of the Seiberling Rubber Company, was dismissed today. An earlier suit was dismissed less than a month ago.
CHICAGO, April 4 (AP) -- The third general advance in grain futures prices in three successive trading days added another cent or so to nearly all contracts on the Board of Trade today.

The programs of the Save the Children Federation, created here in 1932 to aid needy children in the South and now an agency of international scope, will be the beneficiary of a fund-raising event being arranged by its New York Women's Council for April 14.
The United States Maritime Administration announced yesterday that it had arranged in the British marine insurance market for special types of coverage on vessels whose mortgages it has guaranteed.
SIGMUND FREUD, whose passion to know has influenced profoundly so many plays for decades, has been turned into a key figure of a gripping drama.
A triple keel-laying -- unusual in this country's shipbuilding -will take place in Baltimore at noon on April 13 during Pan American Week.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 4 -Enrollments in the major political parties in Nassau County increased by 74,485 from 1959 to 1960, according to official figures released today by the county Board of Elections.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Secretary of Defense outlined today Administration steps to reduce the danger that an ambiguous warning signal might set off a false alarm that could lead to all-out nuclear war.
All eight semi-finalists from the Eastern region have gained the finals of the Metropolitan Opera auditions.

PARIS, April 4 -- President Kennedy's decision to visit General de Gaulle is entirely admirable. The two men, separated in years by more than a generation, are nevertheless today's outstanding Western leaders. They share a belief in the value of strong personal leadership.
The New York Stock Exchange, taking note of recent hear trading in securities, warned the public yesterday against unsound investment practices.

Responding to a call from Mayor to resume contract negotations, officials of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company and a union of 2,800 striking employes will meet today in another attempt to settle their dispute.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, April 4 -- Thousands of knife-wielding, stone-throwing Africans ran wild in Elisabethville and its suburbs today in a rampage against United Nations troops. By nightfall, much of Elisabethville and its environs resembled a city at war.

Birmingham, Ala., borrowed $6,500,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements. The money was raised by the sale of serial bonds to First Boston Corporation and associates at an interest cost of 3.713 per cent.

Tentative agreement of the Permian Corporation and the Dakamont Exploration Corporation to merge was announced yesterday by Walter R. Davis and Cortlandt S. Dietler, presidents of the respective corporations.

Who says American boys are getting soft? Yesterday hardy contingents from New York University and Fordham faced frigid, fugitive winds to play a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference baseball opener at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx.
HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., April 4 -- The Government will spend $193,000 in the next three years to aid in the rehabilitation of emotionally disturbed children living in Westchester foster homes.

AMMAN, Jordan, April 4 -- King Hussein said today that as a result of current moves to improve relations between Jordan and the United Arab Republic, he thought there was "every chance" of a meeting between him and President Gamal Abdel Nasser.

The eleven-story and penthouse loft building at 119 to 125 West Twenty-fifth Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, has been bought by the Twenty-fifth Street Loft Company for investment. The plot is 100 by 100 feet.

CHICAGO, April 4 (UPI) -- Glenn Hall scored his second straight shutout tonight to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to a 3-0 victory over the Montreal Canadiens for a berth in the Stanley Cup championship round against the Detroit Red Wings.
Plans for a 108-family middle-income cooperative apartment project in the upper Bronx were announced yesterday by the Housing and Redevelopment Board.
The title of an impending off-Broadway musical is causing distress and talk of possible litigation along literary row.

Three buildings and a packing lot at the southwest corner of Second Avenue and Forty-eighth Street have been purchased by Evelyn J. Lubin from clients of Walter Scott Co. A large apartment building is planned on the site.
A Mediation efforts were pressed yesterday to avert a strike of 550 lighter captains against seven port railroads. The walkout is scheduled for 7 A.M. next Wednesday.

BONN, Germany, April 3 -- As the trial of Adolf Eichmann approaches in Israel, West Germany has begun an intensive effort to shore up its reputation abroad against the expected adverse reaction to a new recounting of the Nazi horrors.
Strict enforcement of truck parking rules in the garment district led yesterday to protests by representatives of the trucking industry there against "mass ticketing."

NEW JERSEY'S trout fishing season will be opened at 8 A.M. Saturday and the chances of somebody catching some fish are pretty good. The streams are in reasonable shape and the state says it has put plenty of trout in them.

THE engaging tale of the Bonjour the pirate radio ship that is riding at anchor off the Swedish coast and beaming advertising commercials to Stockholm listeners, has invited some speculation: could the same thing happen three miles off Coney Island?
An association of physicians and dentists was certified yesterday by the city Labor Department as exclusive bargaining agent for all doctors in the Department of Health.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 4 -- Roman Catholics and Protestants concerned with Federal aid to nonpublic schools were admonished here today not to debate the issue on religious grounds.

An advisory committee of educators has been appointed to help resolve some of the problems created by the decision of the State Education Department last fall that parents may inspect the "confidential" school records of their children.
The city decided yesterday to make $24,000,000 in aid available to the sponsors of the 1964-65 World's Fair.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 4 -- President Kennedy posed today for his first authorized pictures on a golf course. But he declined to swing or hold a club while the photographers were working. For reasons he has never made clear, the President has been unwilling to allow news photographers near him while he was on the links.

After reading in The Times of the terrorist tactics of the White Citizens Councils in Mississippi and seeing the picture of Negro crowds being attacked by police dogs I found myself, quite by chance, watching "Ruggles of Red Cap" on television, and listening to Charles Laughton's deeply moving recital of the Gettysburg Address.
OTTAWA, April 4 (UPI) -The St. Lawrence Seaway Authority today held out little hope of opening navigation on the inland waterway before late April.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 4 (AP) -- An error by the United States Embassy in Moscow has prevented four leading Soviet scientists from attending the 100th anniversary ceremonies at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a spokesman for the institute said today.
A white envelope worth a Rolls-Royce and then some was lost and found at the International Auto Show in the Coliseum yesterday.

Domestic sugar futures prices fell yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The market closed at or near the lows of the day, off 2 to 7 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). The volume was 34,550 tons, the largest since June 17, 1960, when 44,800 tons were traded.
PARIS, April 4 -- Czechoslovakia and Hungary have withdrawn without explanation from the Theatre des Nations, the international drama and music festival that will begin here Friday night.

Advertisements for Old Taylor bourbon in 1915, an example of which is reproduced above, were markedly different from most of the liquor advertising done today. But as Old Taylor prepares to launch its 1961 campaign, several elements of the earlier advertising approach are still discernible.

LITERARY fashions and attitudes differ from country to country in odd ways. One that has interested me for some years is the difference between the American and English regard for historical fiction. In both countries industrious hacks grind out quantities of mechanical trash.
A huge wave of trading engulfed the stock market yesterday.

Harvard University may be short a faculty member or two because of graduations to President Kennedy's Administration, but the Crimson showed no evidence yesterday of a dearth of experienced lacrosse players. The Harvard team started its annual spring tour by overwhelming City College, 23 -- 3, at Lewisohn Stadium.
MIAMI, Fla., April 4 (AP) -Classroom Bible reading was defended as a necessity for a nation's welfare, and attacked as an infringement of religious liberty, in a Miami courtroom today.
Floyd Patterson wants to defend his world heavyweight title. But how soon he will be able to do it and against whom remain "if" propositions.

Liszt composed all but one of the works on the piano recital given in Carnegie Recital Hall last night by the gallantly indefatigable Herma Menth. They included the Fantasy and Fugue on B-A-C-H, Valse Impromptu, Ballade No. 2, "Waldesrauschen," "Harmonies du Soir," "Gnomenreigen," "Liebestraum No. 2," and "Mephisto Waltz."
MIAMI, Fla., April 4 -- The place is not quite estimable enough to be called a cottage but not crude enough to be called a shack.
BALBOA, C.Z., April 4 -- To meet a shortage, the Panama Canal is calling for shipmasters to train as pilots.

Parents' representatives complained yesterday to Borough President Edward R. Dudley of Manhattan that home economics equipment in George Washington High School had been lying idle for three years in a room needed for instructional purposes.

" Web of Hate," a novel by Frederick Mayer, Professor of Humanities at the University of Redlands in California, is planned for April 23 publication by Whittier Books. It will be distributed by Twayne. The theme of the story is that unless the Germans realize their individual guilt for Hitlers' holocaust, the democratization of Germany will have little chance of permanent success and neo-nazism will continue to simmer under the surface.
AFTER a certain horrendous scoring experience last winter. Arnold Palmer used a tongue-in-cheek approach whenever he made a speech.

HAVANA, April 3 -- The twenty-two United States citizens serving long terms in Cuban prisons are suffering severe privation, according to Gilbert du Dardel, counselor of the Swiss Embassy. The embassy is in charge of the United States diplomatic and consular relations with Cuba.

Much public confusion has arisen concerning the welfare bill, sponsored by Senate Majority Leader Walter J. Mahoney, passed by the Legislature and now before the Governor. It has been termed a compromise, although it contains residency requirements for public assistance, which is the basic issue.
CINCINNATI, April 4 (AP) -- Warren C. Giles today added two umpires to the National League staff for the 1961 season.

HAVANA, April 4 -- The Cuban Government press emitted cries of rage today over the United States appeal that the Castro regime cut its ties to international communism and "restore the dignity" of the Cuban revolution.

A serenade by members of the Kips Bay Boys Club chorus under the direction of Mrs. Charles McArthur will be a feature of the ninth annual Kip Bay dinner dance in the ballroom of the Plaza on April 20.

BOSTON, April 5 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics shook off early ineptness and gained a 116-108 victory over the St. Louis Hawks tonight. The triumph gave a 2 -- 0 lead to Boston in the four-of-seven-game National Basketball Association championship play-off.

Earnings of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company for the first quarter of this year were estimated yesterday at "slightly over $3,000,000 on sales of approximately $128,000,000." This represented a sharp drop from the $12,145,496, or $1.20 a share, cleared on sales of $158,200,000 in the 1960 period.

Differences between Russia and Communist China on ideology and foreign policy have been especially evident with regard to India. While Communist China has been engaged in a stubborn dispute with India over the Sino-Indian boundary, Russia has fostered good relations with Delhi and shown, at times, open disapproval of Peiping's attitude on the border question.
The New York Committee for Democratic Voters, organized to combat Tammany Hall, faced mounting pressure last night to make an early decision on the candidate it will back for Mayor.

Raymond International, Inc., world-wide foundation and heavy construction concern, has elected as a director George S. Hills, a senior member in the New York law firm of Rogers, Hoge Hills, it was announced yesterday by George F. Ferris, chairman of Raymond.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 5 -- Judge Bohdan Winiarski of Poland was elected president by the fifteen members of the International Court of Justice today. Judge Ricardo J. Alfaro of Panama was named vice president.

CHICAGO, April 5 (AP) -- Trade in grain futures slowed considerably today and prices finished mostly within minor or minimum fractions of their preceding closes. However, rye was rather weak in spots and soybeans advanced.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Small business men and state and local development companies in areas of high unemployment were offered today a special cut-rate interest charge of 4 per cent by the Small Business Administration.
Henry F. Scheetz Jr., a director of the Brown Company, has sold 14,300-common shares, reducing his holding in the company to 24,946 shares.

The Bankers Trust Company has named Alexander B. Adams and Philip Greene as vice presidents, it was announced yesterday by William H. Moore, chairman. Mr. Adams and Mr. Greene were formerly assistant vice presidents.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The United States is planning to expand existing projects for stand-by Government and military command posts in planes and aboard ships at sea for use in war.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 5 -- Twenty-five thousand Indonesian rebels in north Celebes were officially reported today to have laid down their arms in a mass surrender that broke the back of the three-year-old revolt there.
Inventories of major petroleum products declined slightly last week as refiners made further cutbacks in their operations.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) -- Senator Barry Goldwater said today that he knew liberal Democrats as well as conservative Republicans who were members of the John Birch Society.

The medical manpower shortage in at least ten of the city's twenty-two hospitals, building up to a major crisis this summer, has at least one good feature. It is generating growing pressure for changes in the organization of hospital services in the city, both public and private -- changes that will not only reduce manpower problems but will also put a brake on rising costs and improve patient care.

GENEVA, April 5 -- Vice President Johnson arrived tonight to get a first-hand report for President Kennedy on the stalled negotiations with the Soviet Union for a treaty prohibiting nuclear weapons tests.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 5 (AP) -- Lawrence Robinson of The New York World-Telegram and Sun today was elected president of the Golf Writers Association of America.

Backed by a generally favorable response to the "new look" he is imparting to American foreign policy, President Kennedy has now embarked on a series of bilateral conferences with the principal Western leaders in an effort to give a similar "new look" to the Atlantic community and bring it more closely in line with a changing world situation.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 5 (UPI) -- Stoy Decker, president of Louisville Local 86 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and two former officials of the union were convicted by a Federal Court jury today in an embezzlement-conspiracy case.

About 150 members and guests of the National Council of the Metropolitan Opera gathered at the opera house yesterday morning for the opening of the council's semi-annual conference. Those attending came from all sections of the United States and from Canada.
LEOPOLDVILLE, April 5 (AP) -- Mr. Gizenga has agreed to meet a member of Premier Ileo's Government to examine possibilities toward an all-Congo political settlement, informed sources reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) -- Karl S. Betts, executive director of the Civil War Centennial Commission, told a House Appropriations subcommittee, in testimony made public today, that local organizations were so eager to re-enact incidents of the Civil War that it was almost impossible to restrain them.

PARIS, April 5 (AP) -- The Soviet Union has shipped ten and one-half tons of gold worth about $12,000,000 into Paris in the last two days. The eventual destination and purpose of the shipments could not be determined.
"Advise and Consent," the drama adapted by Loring Mandel from Allen Drury's Pulitzer Prize novel, may undergo revisions to emphasize that its viewpoint is not anti-liberal.

"EICHMANN AND ISRAEL," shown last night on Channel 2, was an uneven documentary that too often strayed from its subject.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 5 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold indicated today that the United Nations was preparing a major show of force in Katanga Province.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 5 -- The Soviet Union dropped its demand today that the United Nation hear its complaint concerning United States plane flights over Soviet territory.

DARIEN, Conn., April 5 -- The Board of Education has voted to expand high school courses to include electives in Asian history and in a combined economics-geography course. Classes in these subjects will start next fall.

Supersonic airliners probably will have to be flown for a year or more in cargo operations before they are considered safe enough for passengers, the head of the Federal Aviation Agency said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- President Kennedy and Prime Minister Macmillan were reported to be in agreement today on the need for better planning and closer coordination in Western efforts to meet the challenge from the Communist bloc.

The State of California borrowed $190,000,000 in the bond market yesterday at an interest cost of 3.8661 per cent. Most of the money will be used to help war veterans to finance the purchase of homes and farms.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 5 -- In recent days there has appeared in film industry periodicals a full-length portrait of a nattily dressed, gray-haired executive-looking man who would be the soul of dignity but for a human skeleton sitting jauntily on his lap.

LONDON, April 5 -- The Soviet Government has not yet accepted a British proposal that a cease-fire in Laos will have to be verified before an international conference is convened to discuss the country's future.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5 (UPI) -- Paul Arizin, Philadelphia Warrior star and the third highest point-scorer in National Basketball Association history, today said that he was retiring. He had a nine-year professional career.

A 3.7-mile, $34,800,000 extension of Van Wyck Expressway in Queens was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

The National Broadcasting Company agreed yesterday to pay a record sum of $615,002 for television and radio rights to the 1961 professional championship game in the National Football League. Under a two-year contract the company will pay the same fee in 1962.

JACKSON, Tenn., April 5 (AP) -- The Tennessee Supreme Court upheld today the revocation of the Highlander Folk School's charter and ordered the integrated institution closed.
GUATEMALA, April 5 -- Carlos Marcello has been granted permission to remain in Guatemala, it was announced this afternoon.

The size of refrigerator-freezers has not changed but the capacity has, according to General Electric, which introduced its eighteen and eight-tenths cubic foot refrigerator-freezer yesterday. This new model is the same size as the ten cubic foot model the company made a decade ago.
MINEOLA, L.I, April 5 -- Where Masina, the French trotting star, will do her high stepping in this country first -- Yonkers or Roosevelt Raceway -- was still an unanswered question today.
Money, which has settled many an argument, continued to "talk" yesterday in the Kirby-Murchison fight for control of the Alleghany Corporation.

"The Fiercest Heart," a drama of Boer settlers traveling across Africa, will be the next attraction at the Paramount Theatre, following "All Hands on Deck." The Twentieth Century-Fox release, from a novel by Stuart Cloete, was produced and directed in color by George Sherman.
Corporation Counsel Charles H. Tenney dismissed a $13,200-a-year city lawyer yesterday, saying the lawyer had not done his assigned work for the last two years.
Brig. John H. Hardy has retired as chief representative of The Cunard Steamship Company, Ltd., in the United States and Canada.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 5 -- The president of the Bolivian States Mines Corporation announced today that agreement had been reached officially on Washington. Operation Triangle to aid the tin industry here.

Sir Oliver Franks, chairman of Lloyd's Bank, Ltd. of London, is among a group of five new trustees who have been elected to the board of the Rockefeller Foundation. John D. Rockefeller 3d, chairman of the foundation's board, announced the election yesterday.
DALLAS, Tex., April 5 (AP) -- John Tower, a conservative Republican, and William A. Blakley, a conservative Democrat, won run-off spots today in the race to become the junior Senator from Texas.
CHICAGO, April 5 -- -The National Farmers Organization reported sharp gains today in its holding action for higher prices for livestock.
DETROIT, April 5 (UPI) -- The auto industry today turned in a sparkling sales report for last month, raising hopes of a spring breakthrough in the once-sagging new car market.

CLARKSBURG, W. Va., April (AP) -- Eastern Greyhound lines will spend about $7,000,000 this year for new buses and the refurbishing of old ones. R.F. Shaffer of Cleveland, the company's executive vice president, told a safety banquet that night that 100 new buses would be purchased this year at cost of $46,000 each.

Counsel for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York suggested yesterday four ways by which Federal aid to education might include benefits for those attending parochial and other private schools without violating the Constitution.

The New York Athletic Club's hopes of retaining the team title in the Amateur Athletic Union free-style wrestling championships suffered a blow tonight when Greg Ruth was forced out of competition.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 5 (AP) -- The giant Investors Mutual, Inc., held its annual meeting today but there wasn't so much as a whisper about the controversy swirling about its parent holding company, the Alleghany Corporation.
BRASILIA, April 5 -- President Janio Quadros has opened a campaign with dramatic overtones to win public support for his Administration's measures against inflation.

Cocoa futures prices opened strong yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Early buying was influenced by reports that carry-over stocks in Nigeria and Ghana amounted to about 100,000 tons, considerably less than most in the trade had expected.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 5 (UPI) -- Marvin L. Kline, former executive director of the Sister Elizabeth Kenny Foundation, was sentenced today to up to ten years in prison for grand larceny.
VIENTIANE, Laos, April 4 -- The Government of Laos said today that it was ready to meet with "any Laotian leader" to discuss the formation of a coalition regime.
HONG KONG, Thursday, April 6 -- Robert E. McCann, cancer-stricken American business man who was released by the Chinese Communists after ten years in prison, crossed the border into Hong Kong today.

Your editorial of March 31 felicitating the soundness of the Kennedy Administration's Latin-American blueprint is indeed commendable, particularly where you discuss the social and economic revolution which has been the basis for the success of "Operation Bootstrap" in Puerto Rico.
Pleasant weather and school holidays combined yesterday to lure thousands of visitors to midtown New York for what amounted to a post-Easter parade.

The merger of Talman Bigelow, Inc., and Robert A. Whittemore, Ltd., brokers in selling, leasing and managing apartment buildings, was announced yesterday. The new company will be known as Talman Bigelow, Whittemore, Ltd., and will have offices at 699 Madison Avenue.
Sales of savings bonds exceeded redemptions in March for the third consecutive month, the Treasury reported yesterday. However, the margin was smaller than in February.
Mayor Wagner left yesterday to spend about ten days in South Florida recuperating from his recent operation.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Republicans lost the first round of an attempted political comeback in the nation's big cities but professed some satisfaction from their showing in the St. Louis race.

HAVANA, April 5 -- The Government "energetically rejected" today a United States protest against the interception of an American cable repair schooner by a Cuban gunboat and countered with an angry protest over the alleged violation of Cuban territory by United States military planes.

A pledge to shut down any plant operated by Indian Head Mills, Inc., if it did not make its own way was given yesterday by James E. Robison, the concern's president.

Tom Stith and Whitey Martin, co-captains of St. Bonaventure's 1960-61 basketball team, yesterday signed contracts with the New York Knickerbockers of the National Basketball Association. They were the Knicks' first two choices in the annual draft.

Richard Rodgers and Alan Jay Lerner, who have had hand in the creation of more than fifty musicals, some of them among Broadway's greatest successes, have joined forces to write another. It will be presented in the fall of 1962.

Stocks dipped yesterday lowing a warning by the New York Stock Exchange against unwise investment practices Trading was still heavy by mal yardsticks, although we below the 7,000,O00-plus share that changed hands on Tuesday.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 5 -- Nassau County Executive A. Holly Patterson announced today he would resign as Nassau Republican leader and Town of Hempstead leader and would not run again for County Executive.

HONOLULU, April 5 (AP) -- A new theory that anesthetics may cause unconsciousness by "short-circuiting" the brain was proposed tonight by Dr. Linus C. Pauling, Nobel Prize-winning Professor of Chemistry at the California Institute of Technology.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Perhaps none of the adages that contain an element of basic truth has been more lavishly used to advance conflicting purposes than the French proverb: "The more it changes, the more it is the same." But a measure of support for the verity of the saying is implicit in similarities between several fundamental policies of the brand-new Administration and the preceding one.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, April 5 (AP) -- Irish troops took control of Elisabethville airport today. A United Nations source reported President Tshombe had backed down from his threatening anti-United Nation position.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 5 -- Pete Hall hit a three-run homer in the seventh inning and led Rutgers' baseball team to a 6 -- 3 victory over St. John's in the season opener for the Scarlet today.

Foreign-Minister Raul Roa of Cuba asserted yesterday that the State Department's latest denunciation of Premier Fidel Castro's regime "constitutes formalization of the undeclared war which the United States is making against us."

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 5 -- Deane Beman, the National Amateur champion, won the introductory competition to the Masters tournament today. Over the miniature course of the Augusta National Golf Club that consists of nine par-3 holes, Beman scored a five-under par 22.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The new president of the United States Chamber of Commerce praised President Kennedy's foreign policy today but condemned Administration proposals for what he called "excessive" spending.

NO more fitting memorial to the late Adele Rosenwald Levy could have been conceived than "Masterpieces," the loan exhibition of paintings and drawings opening today in her honor. The display is for the benefit of The Citizens' Committee for Children of New York, Incorporated, at Wildenstein's, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street.

Mrs. Dorothy Clark Norman is chairman and Mrs. T. Markoe Robertson is vice chairman of the second annual cocktail dance for the benefit of Music for the Blind. The event will be held April 16 in the Persian Room of the Plaza.

The lively, laughing, bubbling, exciting world of the circus -- a world that appears to be festooned With an endless variety of cotton candy, colored balloons and prancing ponies -- has its commercial marketing side.
they were, they weren't admitting they invested without investigation.

American marine insurance underwriters and brokers yesterday expressed strong resentment over an announcement by the United States Maritime Administration that it had arranged special types of coverage in the British market on $220,000,000 of vessels whose mortgages it had guaranteed.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Clark M Clifford, former White House aide, has been retained by the General Electric Company to deal with claims arising from the company's anti trust law conviction in Philadelphia.
Mayor Wagner attacked the Legislature yesterday for what he called "another instance of discrimination against the city of New York in the granting of state aid."
LOS ANGELES, April 5 -- Dr. R. Bernard Finch and Carole Tregoff were given life sentences in prison today for murdering his wife in West Covina on July 19, 1959.

An all-white dog stood in the center of the Western Reserve Kennel Club show ring in Cleveland last Sunday and received the plaudits of the crowd. It was the 3-year-old bull terrier, Ch. Dancing Master of Monty-Ayr, owned by Dr. E.S. Montgomery, a physician from Natrona, Heights, Pa., and he had just been proclaimed the best of 1,165 dogs by Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt.

The extraordinary nature of the current recession is vividly illustrated in the new data on employment and unemployment last month. On the one hand, employment rose more than seasonally and set a new March record of more than 65,500,000. Looked at alone, this might suggest that a vigorous recovery is under way. But unemployment declined less than seasonally and set a new postwar record for March at almost 5,500,000.
PARIS, April 5 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma said today that he was ready to enter political discussions on a future Laotian government, but not in Vientiane.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- President Kennedy's appointment of Frederick Reinhardt as Ambassador to Italy was approved today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. The committee also approved three other nominations for ambassadorial posts.
LONDON, April 5 -- The stock market lost a little of its exuberance today, although the steady demand for industrial shares persisted.
LONDON, April 5 (AP) -- Laurie Brown, giant star of Britain's Olympic soccer team, was named today to play for the New York Americans in the International League season this summer.

LAKELAND, Fla., April 5 -- Fordham University's three eight-oar crews scored a sweep over Florida Southern and American International College today. The varsity eight defeated Florida Southern by a third of a boat length.
A complaint by a Greenwich Village coffee house operator that he had been harassed by the police after stopping cash gifts to them was being investigated yesterday by the Police Department.

To see Teddy Wilson seated comfortably at the piano in the Embers these evenings, one might almost think that time had stood still. The distinguished executive gray of his hair seems to be the only indication that a quarter of a century has passed since he was the coolly reposed pianist in the Benny Goodman Trio and Quartet.
VIENTIANE, Laos, April 5 (AP) -- Latoian paratroopers dropped near a rebel spearhead north of this capital today in an attempt to cut it off, Western military sources said.

The New York Times on April 3 published a letter from Franklyn Weslock discussing raises for city employes. In his communication Mr. Weslock dismisses the increase in pension contributions by the city in the current budget and in the budget of 1961-62 as a "partial return" of the employe's own salary deductions for pensions.
LONDON, April 5 -- One of the West's key diplomats in the exchanges with the Soviet Union over a settlement in Laos is Sir Frank Roberts, a man of formidable energy, industry and ambition.

BUENOS AIRES, April 5 -- Admiral Isaac F. Rojas, who was Vice President of Argentina under Provisional President Pedro E. Aramburu in 1956 and 1957, has been placed under ten days' house arrest for sharp criticism of the present Government.
CAMAU, Vietnam, April 5 -- Loyal militiamen in this watery, southernmost province of South Vietnam sleep by day and fight by night in ceaseless nocturnal warfare with Communist guerillas.

One of the relatively unsung heroes, of the Civil War was briefly back in the news recently after a long lapse. This is Col. Robert Gould Shaw, whose monument on Boston Common was suggested by Bruce Catton as the scene of ceremonies April 12 to mark the 100th anniversary of the firing on Fort Sumter.

MICHAEL TREE, violinist, and Heida Hermanns, pianist, appeared together at the Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association last night to perform four infrequently heard works.

The $1,000,000 Brink's robbery on Jan. 17, 1950, is the subject of two books to be published soon. One, to be issued next Tuesday by Random House, is called "The Men Who Robbed Brink's: The Inside Story of One of the Most Famous Hold-ups in the History of Crime."
LAGOS, Nigeria, April 5 -- Nigerina, which consists of three regions, is to have a fourth. Western Nigeria, smallest of the three present regions, will be divided into two.
LONDON, April 5 -- "We would like President Kennedy to send his Peace Corps here," said the big man with a face weathered by nearly a quarter of a century of African sun.

An authority on airlines thinks that final approval by the Civil Aeronautics Board of the merger of Capital Airlines, Inc., into United Air Lines will not touch off other airline marriages.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- A statement distributed by the Republican National Committee today said a student conference here last week "did not truly represent the views of American youth concerning the Peace Corps."

The conviction of Admiral Charles H. Gillilan, retired, for conspiring to sell $400,000 worth of soft drink flavoring to the Navy in violation of the conflict-of-interest law was reversed yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.
Earnings of the American Tobacco Company set a record in the first two months of this year, Paul M. Hahn, president, reported at the annual meeting yesterday in Flemington, N.J.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) -- A Senate subcommittee accused the Defense Department today of handing unearned bonuses to defense contractors who developed marketable inventions with Government money.

BONN, Germany, April 5 -- Karl Marx, editor and publisher of the leading Jewish weekly in West Germany, expressed fear today that the forthcoming trial of Adolf Eichmann might tempt "irresponsible" persons here to reawaken resentments against the Jewish people.

BOSTON, April 5 -- A member of the Interstate Commerce Commission asserted today that the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad could be bankrupt by the end of May ess it received substantial sh assistance.
