CHARLOTTE AMALIE, Virgin Islands, April 5 (AP) -- Ralph M. Paiewonsky was inaugurated as Governor of this United States territory today. He pledged himself to a development program highlighted by plans for a university that he said could become a Caribbean cultural center.

The Southern Appalachians have no monopoly on exporting country musicians. Last night five performers from the Catskill Mountains joined two city singers, Pete Seeger and Bill MacAdoo, in an "Upstate Meets Downstate" concert at Town Hail.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Peace Corps has found a training camp site in the tropical mountains of Puerto Rico.
Henry F. Markwalter, one of the deans of the steamship operating industry in this port, announced yesterday that he was no longer associated with Luckenbach Steamship Company.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 5 -- The New York Yankees today bade farewell to St. Petersburg as their springtime training base. And they made the occasion a notable one.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Further reservations were expressed today about President Kennedy's proposal to provide low-cost housing through forty-year mortgages requiring no down payment.
A glut of investment money seeking short-term accommodation swamped the market for Treasury debt investments yesterday and drove down yields sharply on the Federal Government's discount bills.

Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Zionist Organization, expressed "regret" yesterday that he had been made to "appear on the same platform" with Dr. Elmer Berger, executive vice president of the American Council for Judaism, on a telecast last night.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point up to 10 off yesterday. The far months were weakest.

PARIS, April 5 -- Former Premier Pierre Mendes-France condemned today tactical "tricks" by France and the Algerian rebels that menaced the chances for negotiation of a peace of reconciliation in the six-and-a-half-year-old Algerian war.

ACCORDING to his associates, Joshua Logan cooks in three styles -- those of Dixie, France and Japan. A native of Louisiana, his motion-picture work has taken him within recent years on extended visits to the Cote d'Azur and Tokyo.
A bicycle-riding rabbi won an acquittal yesterday on charges of illegally pedaling through Central Park.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 5 -- The United States served notice on the African nations today that it would vote against the imposition of sanctions on South Africa because of that Government's policy of apartheid, or racial separation.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The United States accused the Cuban Government today of mistreating twenty-two United States citizens in Cuban jails.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 5 -- Roland Sheldon, who was pitching for Auburn in the Class D New York-Pennsylvania League last year, today was chosen the winner of the Dawson Memorial Award as the Yankees' outstanding rookie this spring.

DISGRUNTLED race-goers seem to think that they have an inherent right to boo jockeys, revile them, curse them and sneer at them. But the railbirds continually forget that riding is one of the most hazardous sports professions. Every time a jock climbs aboard a horse he is taking his life into his hands.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 5 -- A small Liberian tanker loaded with high-octane gasoline burst into flames in Kaohiung harbor in South Taiwan tonight. Chinese Nationalist authorities evacuated residents from the city's crowded waterfront.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 5 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold told the General Assembly today that he would resign if it requested him to do so. Striking back at Soviet demands that he get out because of his Congo policy, Mr. Hammarskjold asserted that the Assembly could proceed on the basis that it had before it his "standing offer of resignation."

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The American Civil Liberties Union denounced today as "totalitarian tactics" the methods used to deport Carlos Marcello, New Orleans racketeer. His lawyers sued to force his return from Guatemala, where he was flown yesterday.
Members of the trucking industry, protesting the strict enforcement of traffic regulations in the garment area, took their fight to Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy yesterday.
Production of electric power dropped to 14,163,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended last Saturday, the smallest output this year, The Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, April 5 (AP) -- Stockholders of Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which was fined recently for antitrust violations, today overwhelmingly rebuffed a proposal to oust the company's three top executives.
Four IRT subway workers who were involved in an accident in the Bronx on Feb. 20 were disciplined yesterday by the Transit Authority. Three of the four were suspended for three days each.

Edward Seinfeld's Clear Road won the race that served as the feature at Aqueduct yesterday. Overlooked by the 27,751 speculators in attendance, Clear Road returned $24.50 for $2 in defeating the Wheatley Stable's Stretch Drive by two and a quarter lengths.

The New York State Department of Education will ask the Board of Regents next month to include an examination in English composition in the high school Regents tests. The move is part of a state-wide modernization and improvement of English teaching.
Owners off Automatic coin-operated laundries won the first round yesterday in a fight to reverse a local law requiring city licensing and regulation.
ROME, April 5 -- Gillo Pontecorvo, brother of Bruno Pontecorvo, Italian-born atomic scientist who defected to the Soviet Union about ten years ago, was denied a visa today to visit the United States.

Net operating earnings after taxes of the Chase Manhattan Bank for the first three months of 1961 were $17,035,181, or $1.22 a share, compared with $17,988,313, or $1.29 a share, for the first three months of 1960.

DAKAR, Senegal, April 5 -- Vice President Johnson concluded his goodwill mission to Senegal today with a bilateral agreement that will bring the first United States technical and economic assistance to this new African nation.
DETROIT, April 5 -- David Sarnoff proposed today that heads of states use global television for face-to-face "summit meetings" while millions watch around the world.
A frequently prosecuted owner of two West Side tenements escaped a ten-day jail term yesterday after pleading he lacked funds to heat the building.
The only noteworthy activity reported yesterday at the Bronx Zoo was that of a 12-foot 10-inch Indian rock python, which began to lay a clutch of eggs.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Kennedy-Macmillan conversations in the White House and on the Honey Fitz on the Potomac this evening have been extremely friendly, which is another way of saying that they have avoided, or at least minimized, the main issue.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI) -- Pan American World Airways filed a protest today against a National Airlines plan for public sale of 400,000 shares of Pan American stock acquired in 1958.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 6 -- A special ambassador of President Janio Quadros left today for seven Communist countries with orders to do as much trade not involving dollars as possible.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 6 -- Australia challenged the Soviet bloc and France today to pay their shares of the United Nations military operation in the Congo or face the loss of their voting rights in the General Assembly.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 6 -- The Soviet Union condemned Israel today in the Security Council for proposing to move heavy military equipment into Jerusalem for an Israeli Independence Day parade April 20.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI) -- Lieut. Col. John S.D. Eisenhower, son of former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, was granted indefinite leave without pay from the Army today to assist his father.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- William A. Patterson, president of United Air Lines, said today that United's acquisition of Capital Airlines, Inc., would result in a 30 per cent improvement by fall in service to the sixteen cities now served by both carriers.

Earnings of Commercial Solvents Corporation for 1961 should be "somewhat higher" than the $1.70 a share cleared last year, provided present economic trends continue, Maynard C. Wheeler, president, said yesterday at the annual meeting in Baltimore. Earnings in 1960 were the highest in a decade.
LONDON, April 6 -- A five-man Royal Commission on the Press began today a thorough examination of the economic aspects of newspaper and magazine publishing.

CHICAGO, April 6 (UPI) -- Ralph Capone, aging brother of the late Al Capone, Chicago crime leader of the prohibition era, has been served with a subpoena in a thirty-three-year-old income tax case, Internal Revenue agents disclosed today.

TENDER, green stalks of asparagus at greengrocers' now are one of the most enticing reminders that it is spring. A glance at the price tag on this vegetable will disclose that it also costs less now than a week ago.

PARIS, April 6 -- Vice President Johnson pledged the United States today to do "everything in its power" to strengthen the North Atlantic Treaty Organization with the long-term objective of "a true Atlantic community with common institutions."

The Father's Club of the Catholic Church of Our Lady of Pompeii, 25 Carmine Street, will present a musical revue, "If You Knew Caesar," the church auditorium today tomorrow and Sunday. There will also be performances at Friday and on April 15 and 16.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI) -- President Kennedy has pledged "concrete support," if requested, for a new combined effort by African countries to spur economic cooperation and development.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- James M. Landis, President Kennedy's special adviser on the regulatory agencies, proposed today that the Federal Trade Commission be given injunctive power to halt deceptive advertising.

Following the dismissal of a stockholders' suit by the Supreme Court of Delaware yesterday, the Reynolds Metals Company said the path was clear for its proposed acquisition of the United States Foil Company and the reclassification of its stock.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 6 (UPI) -- Maj. Robert S. Fitzgerald, leader of the Air Force Thunderbirds, who fly supersonic acrobatics, was killed today when his F100F jet crashed.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 6 -- King Baudouin gave the task of forming a new Belgian Government to Theo Lefevre, president of the Christian Social party, today.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The Bureau of Roads said today that twenty-one states so far had agreed to pool information on motorists who had lost their licenses for drunken driving or involvement in a fatal accident.

Paramount Pictures Corporation announced yesterday it had acquired a 50 per cent interest in Talent Associates, Ltd., the independent television production company headed by Alfred Levy and David Susskind.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Prime Minister Macmillan in his talks with President Kennedy has been pressing for an expansion of international monetary reserves to facilitate growing world trade and avert periodic crises in currencies of leading trading nations.

Halleck of Indiana, the party's House leader.

CHATHAM, N.J., April 6 -- The construction of a jet airport in the Great Swamp in Morris County would be feasible from an engineering standpoint, but other factors would complicate the project, according to a survey released today.

" The Edge of Freedom," a report on neutralism and new forces in sub-Saharan Africa and eastern Europe, has been written by John B. Oakes, a member of the editorial board of The New York Times. He has traveled extensively in Africa and Europe and has interviewed persons in all walks of life in those regions.
MIAMI, Fla., April 6 -- For nearly nine months Cuban exile military forces dedicated to the overthrow of Premier Fidel Castro have been training in the United States as well as in Central America.
GENEVA, April 6 -- The United States applied pressure on the Soviet Union today in an effort to get the stalled negotions for a nuclear test-ban treaty moving again.

THIS deal was played while the United States international team, which will play for the world championship at Buenos Aires later this month, was practicing against New York players who tried to duplicate the bidding the United States team will encounter.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 6 (AP) -- Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today he would tour the nation starting about May 1 and discuss critically the errors of the "first 100 days of the Kennedy Administration."
BOSTON, April 6 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy has borrowed for display at the White House eleven oil paintings and water colors from the collections of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts.
A six-year-old income tax evasion indictment against one of Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr.'s Congressional secretaries was dismissed yesterday on a motion by the Government.

HAVANA, April 6 -- President Osvaldo Dorticos Torrado today termed the pamphlet on Cuba issued Monday by the United States "another step in the efforts of that country to destroy the Cuban revolution."
I have read your article on the shipping page of March 31 entitled "I.L.A. Welcomes Poll on Dock Bill."
WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today it was changing the second stage of its giant Saturn rocket to make it more powerful and more reliable.
A General Sessions Court jury began deliberating at 1:11 P.M yesterday in the first-degree murder trial of Francisco Molina.
A nonprofit dental insurance plan said yesterday it was offering for the first time in this country group coverage for even the costliest dental services from the day of enrollment.
LONDON, April 6 -- Prices of most industrial shares continued to advance in the stock market here today despite an increase in profit taking near the end of the three-week bookkeeping account period.

ATLANTA, April 6 (AP) -- The Georgia Supreme Court set aside today a death sentence given a young New Jersey negro who pleaded guilty to the rape-murder of an 8-year-old girl of his own race. The court held that the Negro's constitutional rights had been violated.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 6 -- Twenty Montclair High School seniors have been acting as tax consultants to fellow students. So far they have saved their clients about $3,000. The tax consultants, members of the Income Tax Committee for the Aid of Fellow Students, have been staying after school to fill out tax forms.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 6 -- Theo Lefevre, chosen by King Baudouin today to form a new Belgian government and therefore the most likely man to become its Premier, ended a radio speech tonight with the remark that he was not sure he would be happy in his task, but he would not be "insignificant" in carrying it out.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- George McLain of Los Angeles, president of the National League of Senior Citizens, testified today that Federal red tape had handicapped a new program of housing for elderly persons.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 6 -- "A Day of the Arts," to include two morning sessions, luncheon and one afternoon lecture will be given in the art gallery of the Greenwich Library next Thursday. It will be sponsored by the Smith College Club of Greenwich as a benefit for its scholarship fund.

TEANECK, N.J., April 6 -- Charlie Linfante gave four hits, struck out eight and hit a three-run homer to lead Fairleigh Dickinson to a 8-3 baseball victory over Manhattan College today at the winner's field.

Masina, the cause celebre of the latest feud between the mints that are known as Yonkers and Roosevelt Raceways, will -- if permitted by law -- make only two appearances in this country tins year. Both win be in trotting events at Yonkers, after which the 5-year-old mare will return to Europe to complete a crowded schedule of races in Italy and France.

The election of Morris Natelson as a director of the Maryland Cup Corporation was announced yesterday by Arthur H. Shapiro, president. Mr. Natelson is a partner in Lehman Brothers, investment bankers, and a director of the Alaska Pipe Lines Company, the Great Western Financial Corporation, the Neiman Marcus Company, the General Realty Utilities Corporation and the United Piece Dye Works, Inc.
ALTHOUGH "The Painted Days" is a play with an Irish setting that does not deal with the Trouble, it is beset by a mess of troubles.

A 26-year-old tenor, George Shirley of this city, won yesterday the opera auditions sponsored by the National Council of the Metropolitan Opera. The singer, the first Negro to win the auditions, will receive a contract with the Met and the Chambers Scholarship of $2,000.

City Labor Commissioner Harold A. Felix met for two hours yesterday with representatives of the New York Zoological Society in an effort to end the strike that has closed the Bronx Zoo and the Coney Island Aquarium since Sunday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 6 -- A pay-television system was displayed here last night by National Telefilm Associates, Inc.

Representatives of sugar-producing countries on four continents presented arguments at a meeting of the Sugar Club yesterday for obtaining bigger shares in United States sugar imports. The speakers, representing Taiwan, Australia, Brazil and Mexico, asserted that such increases in their exports were important to the United States, since dollar payments were needed to develop this nation's own export markets, as well as to the producers, who need funds to bolster their economies.

JERSEY CITY, April 6 -- Two presentments by a special Hudson County grand jury investigating drug counterfeiting criticized the Federal Food and Drug Administration today, its New York district office and the New Jersey State Board of Pharmacy.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Senate confirmed four of President Kennedy's ambassadorial nominations today. They included the first American of Mexican descent to be named to an Ambassador's post.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended last Saturday were 5 per cent above the year-ago level.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) -- Five railroad unions proposed today a form of the guaranteed annual wage for 210,000 locomotive engineers, firemen, conductors, brakemen and switchmen.
Pan American World Airways will be flying only jet airliners on its New York-Puerto Rico run at the end of this month when it removes the remaining piston-powered aircraft from the route.

Charles Pfizer Co., manufacturing chemists with plants and offices in about fifty countries, will move its headquarters starting at 6 o'clock this evening from 800 Second Avenue at Forty-second Street to a new building across the street at 235 East Forty-second Street.

Sea anchors are an old-time device familiar to most seasoned yachtsmen. They have tied a line to an empty galvanized or canvas bucket, tossed it overboard and tried to keep their bow into the wind to avoid broaching and capsizing.

Ninety-seven days of darkness, temperatures 67 degrees below zero and the nearest girls 180 icebound miles away were some of the memories of an Arctic winter brought back yesterday by two 18-year-old Boy Scouts.
Sir Winston Churchill is scheduled to arrive here next Wednesday aboard the yacht Christina after a cruise that began at Gibralter and included stops in the West Indies.

SCARSDALE, April 6 -- Raises of $500 to $750 will be granted to staff members of Scarsdale's District 1 School System in the next school year. The raises will make them among the highest paid elementary and high school employes in the nation.

At the beginning of the Christian Era world population was approximately 200 million. For a long time the increase was slow and irregular. World population did not exceed a billion until about the middle of the nineteenth century. Now we have an estimate from the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs of a population of three billion by the end of this year.
ALBANY, April 6 -- Legislation extending the life of the New York-New Jersey Transportation Agency for five years more was signed by Governor Rockefeller today.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday that gross revenues rose slightly for the first two months of 1961, but net income for the period, as well as gross revenues and net income for February, fell from the 1960 levels.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points off to 10 points up yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

MOSCOW, April 6 (AP) -- The official newspaper of Soviet youth Komsomolskaya Pravda, has been attacking jazz for years as a capitalist evil. Today it proposed a nation-wide system of what amounts to a network of jazz night clubs.

ONE of the cruelest recorded judgments by one artist on the work of another is Delacroix's phrase, jotted down in his journal after a visit to the retrospective of his enemy, Ingres, in 1855. "The complete expression," he called it, "of an incomplete intelligence."

Jesse Weingart and Irving Fagenson, the owners of the New York team in the National Bowling League, lost their franchise yesterday. They resented the league's action, which cost them more than $100,000.
The Getty Oil Company reported yesterday that its net income in 1960 rose to $10,821,655, or 68 cents a share, from $10,661,083, or 67 cents a share in 1959.

The chairman of the National Mediation Board said yesterday that both sides in the dispute involving 800 lighter captains and seven port railroads "owe a duty to the public to keep these railroads operating."

An effort to embroil the New York Central Railroad in the Kirby-Murchison proxy contest for control of the Alleghany Corporation has been firmly repulsed. Alleghany is the big holding company that controls the Central.

ALGIERS, April 6 -- A bomb attack against the United States Consulate, attributed to European extremists, caused heavy damage tonight, but no one was hurt. A simultaneous attempt to set fire to the local United States cultural center failed.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Navy disclosed plans today to introduce into its submarines a new type of electrical power plant that is expected to rival the revolutionary capabilities of nuclear propulsion.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 6 -- A leading Roman Catholic spokesman indicated yesterday that the church's position on Federal aid to private schools might be drastically changed to include a request for outright grants similar to those advocated for public schools.
The Italian Star of Solidarity, first class, was awarded yesterday to Mrs. George D. Woods, a trustee of the Institute of International Education.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Controller of the Currency Ray M. Gidney has agreed to withhold approval of further bank mergers disputed by the Department of Justice until cases involving Philadelphia and Lexington, Ky., banks are settled in the courts.
TUNIS, April 6 -- President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia called on the French Government today to give up "maneuvers of division" directed against the Algerian nationalists.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 6 -- How to make money on a college campus? Sell cooking utensils.

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 6 (AP) -- President Ngo Dinh Diem wants an increase in the $150,000,000 annual aid that South Vietnam gets from the United States. He believes more money is needed to crush the Communist guerrilla movement.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy termed the John Birch Society "ridiculous" today. He said people should stop paying so much attention to it.
Pianists from member nations of the United Nations are being invited to take part in the Dimitri Mitropoulos International Music Competition, which will be held next December.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board revoked today the license of an airline captain who turned his flight over to another pilot unqualified to fly the plane involved.

The United States monetary gold stock held steady at $17,389,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, marking the sixth consecutive week in which the gold stock remained unchanged or rose. The figures were reported by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday.
Members of the Child Care Women's League Inc., will hold their annual dinner party April 16 at the Copacabana.
LONDON, April 6 -- Members of the New York Society of Security Analysts and of the Society of Investment Analysts, a British group, exchanged ideas at a joint meeting here tonight.

Prospects for an early end to the nearly seven-year-old war in Algeria have dimmed again following postponement of the peace talks between the French Government and the Algerian rebel leaders that were scheduled to open in Evian today. As both sides proclaim their continued readiness to negotiate, it must be hoped that this is indeed a postponement and not a collapse of the talks.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The White House has a new chef after all. He is Rene Verdon, a tall, 36-year-old Frenchman with an impressive culinary background here and abroad.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The Navy is about to try to barter surplus United States farm products for foreign oil. The idea is to reduce the outflow of dollars from this country.

A shoe manufacturer distributed his fall collection in an art gallery yesterday to prove his contention that shoes are an art form. In the spacious, stark-white Stuttman Gallery, at 13 East Seventy-fifth Street, Schwartz Benjamin, manufacturers of Custom Craft and Rinaldi shoes, compared shoe forms with sculpture and leather colors with oil and water colors.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 6 -- Speaking with the quiet, assurance that has characterized his leadership ever since he succeeded Casey Stengel as manager, Ralph Houk today predicted the Yankees would win another American League pennant this year.
Floyd (Babe) Herman, who once doubled into a double play for the Brooklyn Dodgers, signed yesterday as a scout for the New York's new National League baseball club.
Hambros of London, leading European merchant banker, is coming to New York.
NEW CITY, April 6 -- Milton Grant of Pearl River resigned tonight as the Republican chairman of Rockland County.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Rail and truck freight loadings last week were sharply down from year-ago levels but were slightly above those of the preceding week of this year.

Daily average borrowings by Federal Reserve member banks rose $29,000,000 to $107,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Average daily reserves in excess of requirements declined $62,000,000 to $537,000,000.

Gross revenues of the Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., rose to a record high of $3,645,700,000 in 1960, Albert L. Nickerson Jr., president, disclosed in the annual report issued yesterday. Revenues in 1959 were $3,516,600,000.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 6 -- Fifteen Asian and African members made public today a resolution under which the General Assembly would create a new Conciliation Commission for the Congo.

A special cultural program for New Yorkers and visitors to the 1964-65 World's Fair will be presented at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, despite the refusal of the City Council to cooperate.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, questioned today what he termed the "highly irregular deportation procedures" used in the case of Carlos Marcello.

The Federal Reserve System was an aggressive buyer in the United States Government securities market in the week ended on Wednesday. Purchases were extended to securities maturing in more than ten years.
PARIS, April 6 -- Three Algerian terrorists invaded a hospital in suburban Montfermeil today and killed two persons and wounded twelve in a hunt for a member of a rival nationalist organization.

A dinner dance for the benefit of the Child Adoption Service will be held May 10 aboard the Brasil. The white, 617--foot South American cruise ship of the Moore-McCormack Lines will be at Pier 32 at the foot of Canal Street in the North River on a three-day layover.
WEST MILFORD, N.J., April 6 -- A single- engine plane crashed in dense woods here today, killing its three occupants. All three were Long Island men.

Now that the "old guard" of French filmmakers has returned to popularity, as exemplified by "Love and the Frenchwoman" currently thriving at the Paris Theatre, the young French directors are turning their attention to the American production scene.
" MANY years ago I think I was the only girl who worked -- I didn't like to admit it. Now it is the fashion to work," said Senora Enriqueta Aza of Spain.

CHICAGO, April 6 (AP) -- The most active demand in two weeks raised old crop soybean futures contracts almost 10 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade today. The new crop months and grains were mostly steady to easier in relatively dull dealings.

In his letter published March 30 Charles A. Hickmann implies that the American tradition of public education and the American conception of church-state separation represent a misreading of "the natural law" and an abuse of "the natural rights" presumed to derive therefrom.

Meison of the White Oak Stable held on just long enough to win the feature purse at Aqueduct yesterday. The 3-year-old son of Loujac, with John Rotz riding, scored by a neck over the favored Jets Pat of the Boncrist Stable in the six-furlong race.

The market for United States Government securities scored its first decisive gain yesterday since early in March, as a broad demand for short- and intermediate-term Treasury issues appeared in the wake of the Federal Reserve's massive open-market purchases early in the week.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- The developer of the controversial cancer drug Krebiozen was asked today to appear in Federal District Court on Monday for a conference on a $300,000 libel suit involving the drug.
Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College for the last eight years, has been appointed the first chancellor of California's State College system.
The supersonic airliner probably will be propelled, figuratively speaking, by "rubber engines" able to change shape for different speeds and altitudes.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6 -- Arnold Palmer appeared ready to break away from the field in the opening round of the Masters golf tourney today, but he didn't quite make it. Instead, he found himself in a tie for the lead at 68 when bespectacled Bob Rosburg came in toward the end of the afternoon with an identical score.
Negotiations between the Brooklyn Union Gas Company and a union representing its 2,800 striking employes were broken off again yesterday after two days of talks at the city Labor Department.
SUMMERSVILLE, W. Va., April 6 (AP) -- A Presbyterian minister, his wife and their two children were killed today in the crash of their single-engine plane on a farm about 12 miles southeast of here.
The New York Yankees, no less cherished despite losing the world series in Pittsburgh last fall, will receive a gaudy welcome from the city on Monday.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 6 -- The Congolese Central Government and the rival regime headed by Antoine Gizenga have reached an agreement in principle to engage in full-scale negotiations soon. The time and place of the talks have yet to be fixed.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The attacks on and defenses of the John Birch Society, including a call for Congress to "investigate" it that Congress very sensibly seems to have no intention to heed, support a growing impression that ridicule is becoming a lost art in American public controversies.
Additional motorcycle and mounted patrolmen will reinforce the protection of the city's beach and park areas this summer.
EVERY Wednesday morning Dona Felisa Rincon de Gautier, Mayor of San Juan (population 600,000) meets with citizens who need advice or assistance.

IT will be a colorful summer for terrace entertaining if Macy's has anything to say about it. Everything from bright raspberry to striking grass green is used for the coordinated linens and accessories in the table settings and displays opening today on the sixth and eighth floors.
HUSBANDS are often snort-changed in share-and-share-alike marriages, Dr. Abraham N. Franzblau, a psychiatrist, told a recent meeting, at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue.

IN a drafty, garagelike structure at 100 South Street, facing the Fulton Fish Market and the East River, Valentino Longo is working these days with the speed and skill of a surgeon. Mr. Longo is a shad boner and one of the best in the business.
While United States unemployment is running at the highest levels since World War II, West Germany is importing labor from other countries because it has more jobs than workers.

In college baseball as a rule, catching the ball is more important than hitting it. The latest empirical evidence supporting this axiom was recorded yesterday as New York University shut out Columbia, 2 -- 0, in a nonleague game at Baker Field.
Grand Rapids, Mich., is planning the sale of $13,120,000 of water and sewer revenue bonds on May 2. The issue will come due from 1962 to 1985.

TRENTON, April 6 -- Charles R. Erdman Jr. resigned unexpectedly late today as Republican state chairman in protest against what he called unfair campaign tactics by former Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell, one of the party's three candidates for the gubernatorial nomination.
The comparison of drug-induced mental derangements with the "real thing" was questioned here yesterday by a Veterans Administration psychiatrist.
YONKERS, April 6 -- Su Mac Lad, clearly the best of last years American trotters and evidently the same his time around, easily won his second straight race tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

MIAMI, April 6 (AP) -- Chris von Saltza of Saratoga, Calif., added two titles today to her long string and Becky Collins of Indianapolis broke the American record for the 400-yard individual medley. Their performances highlighted the first day of the Amateur Athletic Union women's indoor swimming championships.

Mayor Wagner's routine announcement that the city's Department of Health will establish, through a $34,000 item in his 1961-62 executive budget, a fourth diabetes detection center -- in Queens -- illustrates how, through the taxes we all complain about, government can save lives by taking its service to the people.

CHICAGO, April 6 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks knocked the Detroit goalie, Terry Sawchuk, out of action tonight and beat the Red Wings, 3 -- 2, in the opener of the four-of-seven-game series for the Stanley Cup hockey championship.
The widening of Thirty-seventh Street from Madison to Eleventh Avenue to a uniform breadth of thirty-six feet is expected to begin late next month.

Mayor Wagner was reported yesterday to be concerned by information that the City Welfare Department had failed to distribute Government food surpluses recently increased by the Kennedy Administration.
SAIGON, April 6 -- The Government announced today the details of nine engagements between loyal forces and Communist Viet Cong guerrillas in the last week at widely separated places.

LONDON, April 6 -- The impression that the Soviet Government, prodded by the Chinese Communists, wants the ceasefire in Laos to begin the same day that a fourteen-nation international conference opens is gaining ground among diplomats here.
What appears to be a major advance in decoding the chemical messages that determine the fate of all living things was reported here yesterday by a young space communications scientist.

NORFOLK, Va., April 6 (AP) -- Alan Henry Strauss, 28 years old, a lawyer, of San Mateo, Calif., will be tried here next month in Federal court on a charge of having caused a false bomb scare aboard a jet plane of the Braniff Airlines.

The six-story building containing 110 apartments at 9502 Kings Highway, near Lenox Road, in the East Flatbush district of Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Realty Equities Corporation. It occupies a plot 150 by 155 feet.
POCATELLO, Idaho, April 7 (AP) -- There were five technical knockouts in quarter-final-round bouts of the Amateur Athletic Union boxing tournament today.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7 -- Gary Player of South Africa emerged as Arnold Palmer's cheif challenger for the honors in the Masters golf tournament today.
An 11-year-old boy is going to get a set of model electric trains for Christmas right out of Grand Central Terminal itself.

The first annual Rodgers and Hammerstein award to the person who has contributed "most to the theatre in the Southwest" during 1960 has gone to Paul Baker, director of the Dallas Theatre Center in Texas.

TUNIS, April 7 -- The battle of the Tunisian film tax has been settled by negotiation, and American and Western European motion pictures are appearing again on screens here after an embargo of five months.
The new Moderator of the Presbytery of New York will be installed at 9:30 A.M. Monday in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at Seventy-third Street.

In her letter published April 5 regarding the welfare bill before Governor Rockefeller, Frances Haight states that public assistance should be granted on the basis of need. I agree. And for this very reason I support wholeheartedly the measure which has passed the Legislature and is now before the Governor.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Kennedy and Prime Minister Macmillan were reliably reported today to have agreed on the desirability of the earliest possible formation of a new government in Laos.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- President Kennedy's $3,200,000,000 housing bill drew endorsements today from mayors of big cities and public-housing supporters, while bankers opposed forty-year mortgages on homes.

TWO Russians and a Mexican shared the New York Philharmonic program yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. There also were two conductors and a pianist to enliven the proceedings. Elyakum Shapira, one of the three young assistant conductors this season, led off with the "Sinfonia India" by Carlos Chavez.

It is good news that a liaison has been worked out between the Peace Corps and organized labor. The appointment by A.F.L.-C.I.O. President Meany of staff specialist Henry Pollock as a consultant at corps headquarters, and the meetings that have been held between federation and corps officials, promise cooperation that is badly needed in several ways.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The United States Court of Claims today denied a claim by the Borough of Ringwood, N.J., for $146,133.08 against the United States. The court made the denial in a recommendation to Congress.
For the sixth time in the last three years the Board of Higher Education was confronted yesterday with the problem of selecting a new municipal college president.
Governor Rockefeller indicated last night he would sign the compromise welfare bill that the Legistlature left with him when it adjourned March 27.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 7 (AP) -- Circuit Judge Walter B. Jones refused today to nullify the sale of a Negro minister's car to help satisfy a $500,000 libel judgment.
The new contracts offered by Group Health Dental Insurance mark a notable advance in the protection they give to subscribers and in the fairness of the fees that are charged for it.

New York loses more than a fine college president in the resignation of Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, whose inspiring leadership has contributed to the improvement of City College for nearly a decade. It loses also one of its finest citizens, an exemplar of and spokesman for civil liberties, academic freedom and high moral principles, who has left his impress on the mind and heart of the community.
The National Association of Manufacturers reminded Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy yesterday that it had had a code of ethics for many years.
A leading Southern Baptist churchman said yesterday that "the religious freedom" promised by the Soviet Union's Constitution was "a deliberate and confusing" misnomer.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 7 -- The General Assembly unanimously called on South Africa today to desist from pursuing tyrannical policies and racial practices in South-West Africa.

The president of the Cuban Revolutionary Council said here last night that a general revolt against the Castro regime was "imminent." Asked for an approximate date he shook his head, smiled and said: "Soon."
MANILA, April 7 (AP) -- Robert Ezra McCann was flown to Clark Field today on his journey back to the United States after ten years in a Chinese Communist prison.
PRETTY blooms are appearing on every type of lingerie from half slips to simple, little shift nighties, elaborate peignoirs and, of course, the current rage -- the muumuu.
ATLANTA, April 7 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. drew a $25 fine today and six months at hard labor in a traffic case that figured in the Presidential campaign.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- The "Ev and Charlie" show came under fire from opposing wings of the Republican party today but its star actors defended it stanchly.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- The accidental shooting down of a big bomber by a fighter in New Mexico today occurred despite elaborate safety precautions, Air Force headquarters said tonight.
JERUSALEM, April 7 -- Mixed emotions are evident here as Israel awaits the opening of the Eichmann trial Tuesday.
Your editorial of March 30 on the 1961 Mayoralty campaign prompts me to bring to your attention some additional facts.

If Carl Ullrich's fondest dreams come true this afternoon, he will be treading water -- fully dressed -- in a particularly murky section of the Harlem River, just a short pull east of the point where Dutch traders once bartered with the Indians.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Ten more American oil paintings and water-colors have been cellected from famous museums for display in the White House living quarters.

By nature a conservative organization, the Canadian Chamber of Commerce advanced yesterday what seemed at first glance a liberal proposal. It urged deficit financing in the 1961-62 Canadian budget, to be brought about by lower personal and corporation income taxes.

It is welcome news that the Board of Education's cooperative education program, now operating in forty academic and vocational high schools, will be expanded next fall to include six additional schools. Begun in 1915 on an experimental basis, this largely unsung program now enables nearly 4,000 city students to alternate classroom instruction with salaried on-the-job work experience.

Three men admitted last night that they had staged twenty robberies of medical and dental offices in the last two months, the police reported. The men had been arrested late yesterday as they ran out of a physician's office at 1 West Seventieth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Three-year-old Caroline Kennedy and four little playmates had a romp on the White House grounds today to the delight of tourists and photographers. Pierre Salinger, White House press secretary, later asked news photographers assigned to the White House not to take any more pictures of the President's daughter at play on the lawn.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) -- The State Department said today $1,500,000 should be "appropriate and adequate" to reimburse New York City for the around-the-clock police protection it gave to world leaders who attended the United Nations meeting last fall.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) -- President Kennedy has drafted but has not yet signed an order banning outside employment by members of the armed forces, a military service journal said today.
Five men were seized yesterday in the $62,981 hold-up on Thursday of The New York Daily News.
CHICAGO, April 7 (AP) -- The grain futures market managed some broad price swings in spots today but closed with relatively small net changes on the Board of Trade.
Mikhail Tal of Latvia, the world chess champion, and Mikhail Botvinnik of Moscow, the challenger, resumed play in their title match at the Variety Theatre in Moscow yesterday.

Unemployment wears many faces, all of them dour. In a surplus foods warehouse in Charleston, W. Va., a jobless truck driver tugs at a sack of dried beans and sighs: "Well at least I won't have to pay any gas bill this month. The company shut it off."

SAN FRANCISCO, April 7 -- A strike by 7,000 members of the International Association of Machinists closed 127 concerns in the Bay area today. Both sides will meet with a Federal mediator tomorrow in an effort to end the walkout.

The president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has called on the United States Government to guarantee private investments in South America against losses resulting from political actions.

Nearly 150,000,000 Christians over the world will observe Easter Sunday tomorrow. They are members of the Eastern Orthodox faith whose calculation of the day Christ rose from the tomb frequently varies from that of the Western churches.

JUDGING from the number of shoppers invading the new Lamston's dime store at Lexington Avenue and Sixty-first Street, this shop is a welcomed addition to the block. Included in offerings at this store is breakfast, which is served as early as 8 A.M.
CURIOSITY as to what Polish advance guard painters are doing should be satisfied by the exhibition of work by six contemporary nonobjectivists at Galerie Chalette, 1100 Madison Avenue.
THE COMEDY THEATRE, which used to be called the Finch College Theatre, made its debut last night with "The Magnificent Hugo," a comedy. Unfortunately, there wasn't much comedy in the Comedy Theatre.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 6 -- An attack by the Royal Army yesterday against pro-Communist forces in northwest Muong Kassy was seen here today as a move to impress on the rebels the need for an early cease-fire.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 7 -- On the evidence of four academic reporters who gave ear-witness accounts today, more than 100 savants from thirty-one nations have wrestled to a series of draws with a multitude of problems in scientific and engineering education.
Major financing plans by the Continental Oil Company and Norway are under way, indicated by filing of registration statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 7 -- Following are excerpts from an address tonight by Prime Minister Macmillan at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology:

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 7 -- The Soviet Union presented a draft resolution to the General Assembly today that did not demand the evacuation of the United Nations force from the Congo and the replacement of Dag Hammarskjold as Secretary General.

CINCINNATI, April 7 (UPI) -- The late Mrs. Louise Taft Semple left a trust valued at $3,000,000, to help University of Cincinnati develop a department of classics "second to none," it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Mildred Elizabeth Gillars, the American woman who broadcast Nazi Germany's propaganda to United States troops during World War II as "Axis Sally," will be freed from prison July 10.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, April 7 (Reuters) -- The Pakistan Government disclosed today that it had carried out an air attack on an ammunition cache near the Afghanistan border.

Kim Hoffman, an interior designer, will discuss "Tapestry in the Home" and "The Art of Tapestry," illustrated by slides, on Tuesday at 6:15 P.M. in the Donnell Library Center Auditorium, 20 West Fifty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) -- The number of workers drawing unemployment benefits dropped by 141,000 to 3,085,400 during the week ending March 25, the Labor Department reported today.
Igor Y. Melekh, a Russian United Nations employe who escaped prosecution on an espionage charge at the request of the State and Justice Departments, sailed for home last night.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 7 (AP) -- Union meatcutters and clerks went on strike today at seventy-five upstate outlets of the Loblaw chain and four other supermarket chains halted most of their operations in the strike area.

A pending suit by the Department of Justice to block the proposed merger of Philadelphia National Bank and Girard Trust Corn Exchange Bank has not deterred the two Philadelphia banks from planning stockholders meetings on May 9 to vote on the plan.
Bank clearings in the nation's twenty-six leading cities rose to $131,394,549,000 in March, its highest level for any month on record, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 7 (AP) -- Dale Lewis, the University of Oklahoma's heavyweight National Collegiate and Amateur Athletic Union free-style champion, was upset tonight in a second-round Greco-Roman match in the A.A.U. wrestling meet by Pat Lavell of San Francisco.
Francisco Molina, a supporter of Fidel Castro of Cuba, was convicted last night of second-degree murder in the slaying of a 9-year-old girl Sept. 21.

The time of the year approaches when the man of the house should be watching for those sudden first sprouts of delicate green on trees in the country or Central Park or planning some of the spring's perfect weather week-end drives into the country.
The University of Vermont's baseball team spent a long, fruitless day in the metropolitan area yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Two rival bakery workers unions agreed today to a truce in their three-year-old feud, with the aim of talking about a merger.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Air Force has arranged a barter deal in which the United States Underseas Cable Corporation will lay a cable for the Atlantic missile range in return for surplus agricultural products.
Two foreign steamship lines announced appointments to top positions yesterday. And an official of an American trans-Atlantic airline was honored for his efforts in promoting air cargo's development.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 7 -- Yugoslavia lashed back today at two of her most persistent Soviet bloc critics -- neighboring Albania and Czechoslovakia.
Stocks ended a hectic week yesterday with good gains in active trading.
LONDON, April 7 -- In the heaviest Friday's trading for eighteen months, buyers again outnumbered sellers in the stock market here today.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that its future formal decisions in airline proceedings would be written by specifically assigned individual members of the five-man board.
LOS ANGELES, April 7 (UPI) -- Davey Moore will put his world featherweight title on the block tomorrow night against Danny Valdez of Los Angeles.
Irene Dalis sang her first Kundry at the Metropolitan Opera in last night's performance of Wagner's "Parsifal."

MIAMI, April 7 (AP) -- Thirteen-year-old Donna de Varona of Berkeley, Calif., the youngest member of last year's United States Olympic team, broke the American record for the 200-yard individual medley today in the Amateur Athletic Union women's swimming championships.
Many parties were given last night in connection with the seventeenth annual Bal des Berceaux, which was held at the St. Regis Roof.
PARIS, April 7 -- The French police began a counter-attack on Right-wing terrorism today with surprise raids on the homes of extremists in Paris and provincial cities.

Yields on short-term United States Government securities declined further yesterday in a trading session that restored to the Treasury market some of the breadth and activity that had been absent recently.

The volume of state and local long-term financing amounted to $2,101,114,401 for the first three months of 1961. This compared with a volume of $1,884,900,000 in the 1960 period and $2,156,954,999 in the 1959 period. The record for a first quarter is $2,206,277,313, established in 1958. The figures were reported by The Bond Buyer, a trade publication.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced here yesterday an "all-out campaign against Mississippism."

Fifteen of the twenty-one works in the repertory that the New York Philharmonic will play during its forthcoming tour of Japan are by twentieth-century composers. The high percentage of contemporary music was dictated in part by three concerts that the orchestra is giving in Tokyo in a festival series called East-West Music Encounter.
ALBANY, April 7 -- Mayor Wagner was empowered today to fill vacancies on the New York City Board of Education with somewhat less regard for where the candidates live in the city.

THE South hand was played by B. Jay Becker in this deal when he represented the United States in play for the world championship, at Turin, Italy, last spring. Mr. Becker lost his contract but all his teammates and all other observers agreed that he had made the best play.
MANCHESTER, England, April 7 (AP) -- Mechanical harvesting of part of the United States cotton crop involves a deterioration in the quality of the cotton, British cotton men were told today.

Public utilities have been very much in the news this week, notably because of the debate over the fate of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad and the extraordinary behavior of American Telephone and Telegraph Company stock last Monday. In considering these and similar matters it would seem wise that we recall some fundamental principles of the public utility concept in this country.
MINNEAPOLIS, April 7 -- The Democratic National Committee started the machinery today for the 1962 Congressional campaigns.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., is going to get back part of the $222,499,642 it paid in Federal income and excess profits taxes for 1950.

Battered stage props, dusty costumes and broken furniture cluttering the curb at the rear of the Lyric Theatre off Times Square were the left-overs yesterday of many dreams of theatrical glamour and fortune.
WEST NEW YORK, N.J., April 7 -- Charles E. Erdman Jr. gave unqualified support today to the nomination of State Senator Walter H. Jones as the Republican candidate for Governor.
Daytime living in the Fort Wadsworth neighborhood of Staten Island and may get even noisier, but residents are looking forward to getting their sleep at night.
Food Giant Markets, Inc., Los Angeles, is negotiating to acquire the Katz Drug Company, Kansas City, Mo., it was disclosed yesterday.

The average rate of interest charged on short-term loans to business concerns by New York City banks in the first half of March was 4.66 per cent, according to the quarterly survey of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 7 -- Viruses have for the first time produced tumors in human beings, according to a report here today.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Union Carbide Corporation of New York received a patent this week for the latest thing in pushbutton mining. Miners can use it to dig coal without ever going inside the mine.
The Kroger Company, the nation's third largest food store chain, reported yesterday that sales and earnings declined in the first quarter of this year from the levels of the 1960 period.

LONDON, April 7 -- The next Soviet move toward a settle ment in Laos is expected this week-end. However, qualified diplomatic sources expressed doubt today that it would be the decisive step toward a cease-fire that the West awaits.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., April 7 -- The Government accused the Chrysler Corporation today of attempting to reduce competition from the Studebaker-Packard Corporation in the compact-car field.

ST. LOUIS, April 7 -- As spring training is designed to prepare major league clubs for anything that may arise when the championship season starts, it can be taken as a fact that the Yankees and Cardinals used this day to good advantage.
Two indicted electrical inspectors will go on departmental trial April 17, the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity announced yesterday.

About 100,000 New Jersey anglers are expected to flock to their favorite fishing holes today in a scramble for 224,100 trout. The fish have been distributed for the trout season, which officially opens at 8 A.M.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 7 -- President Francois Duvalier offered Mole-Saint-Nicolas -- a natural harbor on Haiti's northwestern tip forty miles from Cuba -- to the United States for a naval base today.
Futures price for commodities moved generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Week-end evening of positions accounted for most of the volume.

The twelve-story office and bank building at 303 West Forty-second Street and 699 Eighth Avenue on a plot forming an "L" around the northwest corner of the two thoroughfares has been sold by Garment Center Garage, Inc., Irving Maidman, president.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Administration pledged itself today to move to cancel contracts with any employer who refused to comply with President Kennedy's recent ban against anti-Negro discrimination in Government work.

An active week is ahead for the new capital market, with $122,770,000 of fixed-interest securities listed for competitive sealed bidding and an additional $227,000,000 worth scheduled for public offering through financing agents appointed by the issuers.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) -- President Kennedy reviewed the economic situation today with his chief advisers in that field.
CHICAGO, April 7 (UPI) -- The assitant editor of the official publication of the world's largest Roman Cathoilc Archdiocese called attacks on the John Birch Society "deserved and fortunate" today.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A plan for global training of guerrilla fighters is being circulated at the Pentagon as a background paper for senior officers.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) -- Senator James O. Eastland of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee said today American Communists had a new plan for world conquest based on eroding United States power.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 4 to 11 points (20 to 55 cents a bale) yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices remained unchanged at 119.5 per cent on its 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 7 -- A United States aid official was injured today by a grenade tossed over the wall of his home. The official lived two blocks from the Presidential Palace and near the residence of United States Ambassador Elbridge Durbrow.

The City Investigation Department issued thirty more subpoenas yesterday for Greenwich Village coffee-house owners and managers in an investigation of reported pay-offs to policemen and other municipal employes.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Vice President Johnson returned tonight from his diplomatic mission abroad and, on calling at the White House, received high praise from President Kennedy. In his journey to Puerto Rico, Senegal, Geneva and Paris, Mr. Kennedy said, the Vice President "represented our country with great distinction" and contributed "a good deal to strengthen the support NATO must have if it is going to continue to be an effective shield."

PARIS, April 7 -- When he talks with General de Gaulle next month President Kennedy will find it necessary to raise two questions himself if he has any hope of effecting a major policy reconciliation. At present, although we are on most friendly terms with our oldest ally, our attitudes are basically divided in NATO and U.N. France is conducting a polite sitdown strike in both organizations.
BAHREIN, Saturday, April 8 -- The British Liner Dara caught fire in a raging storm in the Persian Gulf today. Agents for the ship said 247 passengers and crew were believed to be missing.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Kennedy proposed today a $10,000,000 United States contribution to preserve ancient Nubian temples and other monuments on the Upper Nile.

On April 9 the Republic of Vietnam's Presidential elections will be held. The people will choose from among three candidates, including President Ngo Dinh Diem. Thus within six years the Free Vietnamese will have participated in four free elections -- all part of the slow, difficult process of building responsive political institutions in this Southeast Asian nation.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Business inventories were reduced in February as much as in January, and more than the average for the closing months of last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Events today; "Wozzeck" at 2 P.M. and "Turandot" at 8, Metropolitan Opera; New York Philharmonic Young People's Concert, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 12 noon; Boston Symphony Orchestra; Charles Munch, conductor, Adele Addison, soprano, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Oberlin College Choir, Town Hall, 2:15.
Federal mediators tried again yesterday to settle a dispute between approximately 630 lighter captains and seven port railroads.
An operating room in a New York hospital is the scene of a special hour-long program on WNEW-TV (Channel 5) at 10 P.M., Sunday, April 30.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 7 -- Prime Minister Macmillan said tonight that the time had come when it was necessary to "achieve some real unity of political purpose and method in the Western alliance."

AN American tourist often returns from France with as vivid an impression of that country's cuisine as of its chauteaux. But there is nothing new in the idea that travel broadens the palate as well as the mind. Centuries ago explorers and crusaders alike returned to their native hearths with a penchant for the spiced foods they had encountered on their wanderings.
LONDON, April 7 -- Mergers, actual, proposed and rumored, are causing more ferment in Britain's brewing industry nowadays than the yeast in its vats.
Networks of steel, now catching the eyes of hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers in midtown and upper Manhattan, will ease the lot of larger numbers of bus commuters next year.

Stanton Management, Inc., has sold the vacant land occupying the blockfront on the north side of Pugsley Avenue, between Bruckner Boulevard and Chatterton Avenue, the Bronx. The plot, 211 by 240 by 190 feet, was bought by clients of Lichtig Abrahams, lawyers. It will be improved with a cooperative apartment house for 120 families. Goldberg-Kornspun Associates, Inc., was the broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee Company.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- New ambassadors to Peru and the Republic of Togo were designated today by President Kennedy.
MIAMI, April 7 -- This is a city of open secrets and rampaging rumors for the legions of exiled Cubans who plot the downfall of Premier Fidel Castro and his regime.

WASHINGTON, April 7-- Assistant Attorney General Lee Loevinger, the new antitrust chief, promised today to dispel any notion that violation of the antitrust laws was no more serious than the offense that brings a parking ticket.
TRENTON, April 7 -- A group of Cub Scouts in near-by Titusville stood a bit taller today. The $284.96 that had been missing from the pack's funds for three months was found in a peanut brittle can.

PARIS, April 6 -- The main European central banks have found a way of doing something that has always baffled mathematicians -- make two and two add up to more than four. At the beginning of last month, there was a fixed total of monetary reserves of gold and convertible currencies in the United States, Britain and Western Europe combined.

Don Poggio, Gustave Ring's Argentine-bred distance runner, yesterday made up for his previous sorry appearance at Aqueduct. In the Display Handicap at the Big A last November the South American campaigner was sent off the favorite at 11 to 20, but his saddle slipped and he was eased up at the end.

HAVANA, April 7 -- Premier Fidel Castro declared tonight that the May 1 celebration in Havana would be a military display to warn his enemies not to attack and to show that all the people of the island support his revolution.
GRANTS, N.M., April 7 -- An F-100 Air National Guard fighter, on a training mission over western New Mexico, accidentally fired a Sidewinder missile into a B-52 today.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 7 -- The National Catholic Education Association heard a message from President Kennedy today hailing "the extremely important" contribution that religious-supported private education can make to the country.

A preview of the plans being shaped by the Kennedy Administration to transform the North Atlantic alliance from a purely military defense organization into a closer political, economic and even ideological Atlantic community has been given by Vice President Johnson in a speech at the alliance's headquarters in Paris.
An insurance expert said yesterday that proposed financing of medical care for the aged through Social Security might eventually endanger the nation's internal peace.

ABOUT fifty housewives -- armed with a brace of questionnaires that run to a combined total of seventy-three pages -- are at work in this area, putting some 500 of their housekeeping sisters through a financial inquisition few husbands would dare attempt.

SAIGON, South Vietnam Saturday, April 8 (AP) -- One Vietnamese was killed and an American and eight other persons wounded in a pre-election hand-grenade throwing today in front of a United States military enlisted men's quarters in the heart of the capital.
There will be a jazz festival at Newport, R.I., this summer, it was announced yesterday.

BOSTON, April 7 (UPI) -- The Pilot, official organ of the Boston Roman Catholic Archidiocese, said today that the John Birch Society movement, "with all kinds of good intentions allowed, is unbalanced, excited and definitely out of focus."

Guests at the Kosciuszko Foundation's ball at the Waldorf-Astoria last evening performed Polish country dances and the Grand Polonaise, as is the tradition at the event, which has been held annually for the last twenty-eight years.

BUENOS AIRES, April 7 -- Just imagine this scene of domestic disaster: An Argentine hurries home after a day of toil to find that there is no water for a bath and that the steak has spoiled in the non-operating refrigerator.
YONKERS, April 7 -- Keen's Victorwin, the only one of the seven starters who supposedly didn't "belong" in the season's first free-for-all pace at Yonkers Raceway, got the job done tonight.
MANUEL ANTONIO DE VARONA Y LOREDO, now here helping to draft a program for Cuba's "new revolution," has been a revolutionary for thirty-seven of his fifty-two years.

A new book by John Wilcock, author of "Mexico on $5 a Day," will be published April 27 by Lyle Stuart. It will be "The Village Square," a collection of his humorous commentaries and interviews culled from his weekly column in The Village Voice.
Appropriately for the centennial year of the Civil War, "Gone With the Wind" is heading toward New York like a comet.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 7 (UPI) -- Robert A. Taft, a member of the Ohio Legislature, said today one of the problems of the Republican party in recent years had been the alignment of about 90 per cent of reporters with the Democrats.
The father of a 5-year-old boy who had been dismissed from a kindergarten class in public school as "too immature" sued yesterday for the child's reinstatement.

The General Accounting Office has advised the Federal Maritime Board to brush up on its arithmetic and inaugurate other practices that would make the agency's ledgers more acceptable to the nation's Controller General.

A broken water main near the corner of Fifth Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street forced the evacuation of approximately 1,000 tenants and office workers from a twenty-one-story building at 230 Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon.

THE explorer looks for the unknown. He finds it. The wild, unspoiled beauty of it pleases him no end. He wants to share his pleasure generously. Whereupon he writes a book about it all, sells as many copies of that book as he possibly can, and thus attracts to his paradise multitudes who might otherwise not go traipsing around invading savage grandeurs.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 8 -- Victor Romagna of Larchmont, accompanied by Susie Gilbreth, won with Scusi in the Interclub race as the Larchmont Yacht Club's annual two-day spring frostbite regatta opened today.

Students at the Berkeley Institute, their parents and the school's alumni will take part in the all-day program of events on Thursday to mark the school's seventy-fifth anniversary. The celebration will be in the school at 181 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn.

SCARSDALE, N.Y. April 8 -- Members of the Junior League of Scarsdale, assisted by their husbands and friends, will present "More Fun And Frolics," a follies, at the Scarsdale High School on May 19 and 20.

Deputy Police Commissioner Walter Arm said yesterday that the Police Department did not know of any secret tape recording that is said to cover a discussion by Greenwich Village coffee-house owners about police pay-offs.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -- The Florida turnpike, the 110-mile highway between Miami and Fort Pierce formally known as the Sunshine State Parkway, will be extended to central Florida and possibly to north Florida, according to plans announced here by Gov. Farris Bryant.

TORONTO, April 5 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's major lake shipping lines are considering placing their fleets under Bermuda registry to compete more effectively with British flag vessels operating in the St. Lawrence Seaway, according to The Toronto Telegram.

ACCRA, Ghana, April 8 -- President Kwame Nkrumah announced tough measures today to curb the activities of some members of his party that he said were weakening the regime and dissipating confidence in Ghana abroad.

The annual mother-daughter luncheon of the Calhoun School will be held Tuesday at the Pierre. Mrs. Sam Bramson has been named chairman of the event, proceeds of which will aid the scholarship fund of the school.

BAYONNE, N.J., April 8 -- This city, which became a separate municipality 100 years ago today, will spend much of the next three months celebrating the anniversary. There will be a nostalgic look into the past and planning for a resurgence of business and industrial activity.

DETROIT, April 8 -- Howie Young and Alex Delvecchio scored first period goals tonight and led the Detroit Red Wings td a 3-1 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks. The triumph evened the National Hockey League Stanley Cup play-off finals at one game apiece.
Power hitting and sharp fielding gave the St. John's nine an 11-2 victory over Ford ham yesterday in silver-flask weather at the Creedmor State Hospital field in Queens.

A tiny device called a potentiometer, or "pot," is used in hundreds of applications, costing as little as 10 cents or more than $500, depending on the type of work it is called on to do.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 8 -- John Martin, dance critic for The New York Times, was made a Kentucky Colonel here at a dinner tonight. The commission was given by Lieut. Gov. Wilson Wyatt.

THE most controversial name in British politics today is that of Iain Norman Macleod. The rate of growth of the world's merchant fleet, which slowed during 1959 and 1960, is expected to accelerate over the next two years.

In reference to Mr. Crowther's editorial on Negroes in films (April 2), I feel obligated to write a few words in defense of Atlanta. In my mind, you seem to be condemning an entire city for the actions of one woman, its film censor.

MUSICAL Francophiles who would like to spend April in Paris but won't be able to may find comfort in some recent recordings of French music. Most of the works involved are relatively modern, and nearly all have the perennially fresh quality that characterizes French music at its best and makes it seem especially suitable, somehow, for springtime listening.

LITTLE ROCK, April 8 -- The Ministerial Association here has offered to help the Little Rock School Board prepare the city's people for an extension of integration in the public schools.

Nixon will begin May 5 at Chicago. It is also the objective of the consultation with General Eisenhower which the Republican leaders in Congress, Senator Dirksen and Representative Halleck, have arranged for May 1 at Gettysburg.

MONTREAL -- Unlike their counterparts south of the border, the major railroad systems in Canada are making a major effort to retrieve and retain passenger traffic. While many railroads in the United States have adopted policies that only further discourage their waning passenger business, the Canadian National Railways and the Canadian Pacific Railway are wooing and pampering their customers as never before.

KINGSTON, Jamaica -- A subtle change is taking place in Jamaica. Its tourist industry, now a successful twenty years old, has settled down into a pattern all its own, one that gives every indication that the island long will retain the charm for which it has been noted for decades.

ORADELL, N.J., April 8 -- Henry Cabot Lodge arrived in New Jersey today to help James P. Mitchell's campaign for the Republican nomination for Governor.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Pacific Northwest fears that a Kennedy Administration proposal to supply surplus power from the Bonneville Power Administration to southern California may threaten the power supply at the source in the Northwest.

Worried presidents, deans, department chairmen and professor then leap to explain the phenomenon of dishonesty among the brainiest segment of our youth.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 8 (AP) -- Dick Wilson of the University of Toledo won the 114.5-pound Greco-Roman title in the Amateur Athletic Union wrestling championships tonight. He was voted the meet's outstanding performer.

Joseph Goldstein, head of a Washington excursion boat line, has announced the purchase from the City Investing Company, of the four boats and other properties of the Wilson Excursion Lines, which operates in New York, Philadelphia, Boston and Baltimore.

Daffodils hold their trumpets high above the grape hyacinths and scilla. Forsythia forms a golden screen for the display of early bulbs. In the South azaleas, dogwood and rhododendron brighten spring gardens.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., April 8 -- After four hours of shooting in a fifteen-mile-an-hour northwesterly wind, Harry C. Barr Jr. of Riverside, Conn., topped a field of 150 today to win the Thomas H. Lawrence Memorial trapshoot at the New York Athletic Club's range.

Since launching its first satellite on Jan. 31, 1958, the United States has launched thirty-eight earth-orbiting space vehicles, of which twenty-two are still in orbit and ten are still transmitting useful information. WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Kennedy and Prime Minister Macmillan concluded today their lengthy review of major world problems. They agreed more on the nature of common difficulties than on their solutions.

LONDON, April 8 -- Both the man in the street and officials in government offices felt a good deal better tonight about Britain's relationship with the United States. The old firm, they thought, was still in business.

THE most ingenious calculating machines ever devised have attempted to pick the correct order of finish in the pennant races. They have fallen flat on their electronic faces. They failed dismally. As a matter of fact, a statistician once figured that the odds against an accurate forecast are one in 1,625,702,400.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8 -- Gary Player left no doubt about the lead in the Masters golf tournament today. The 25-year-old South African professional swept past the defender, Arnold Palmer, with a crackling 69 in the third round for a 54-hole aggregate of 206.

GOROKA, Australian Trust Territory of New Guinea, March 24 -- A bizarre, lethal, shaking disease called kuru afflicts 300 to 400 natives of the Fore tribe in a mountainous region of the Eastern Highlands. In three to nine months all but a few of them will be dead.

MAAYAN ZVI, Israel, April 8 -- Survivors of German concentration camps await with dread the opening of the trial of Adolf Eichmann. Too many ghosts and too many harrowing memories will be revived for them when the proceedings open Tuesday in Jerusalem's Beit Haam, or House of the People.

For the buff who wishes to explore sparsely traveled trails in the hinterlands of the Civil War, this pioneer work by Robert Huhn Jones, who teaches history at Ohio's Kent State University, may have attraction. Tightly written, this book is a guide to sources rather than a revelation of people and events; and yet, if you are looking for a winter's profitable entertainment, it may be difficult to find a more stimulating companion.

PORTSMOUTH Va. -- Four events of national interest will take place in Virginia during the last thirteen days of this month. The annual Dogwood Festival, centering in Charlottesville, will be held April 19-21, and the twenty-eighth annual Historical Garden Week will be observed throughout the Commonwealth from April 22 to 29.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 8 -- Haiti's legislatiure was dissolved last night by Presidential decree.

HARTFORD, April 8 -- Redistricting of the State Senate and a huge reduction in the size of the House of Representatives were voted in the House this week as the General Assembly entered its final two months of sessions. The House is controlled overwhelmingly by Republicans.

HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, March 30 -- The Dutch and the Australians are following different lines in developing their halves of New Guinea. These differences seem unimportant at this primitive stage of the island's political development.
JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, April 7 -- There are three ways to tell time here: "Arab" time, "European" time and standard time. That's the kind of place Jidda is.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Kennedy's food-for-peace director, George S. McGovern, urged the President today to endorse an $11,000,000,000 program to feed and clothe the hungry and ragged of the world in the next five years.
LOS ANGELES, April 8 -- The Soviet Union is streamlining its way to a greater lead over the United States in space exploration.
