WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The gap between the Kennedy Administration's goals and its programs is increasingly evident. Its goals are clear enough: unity of the free world as defined in the Kennedy-Macmillan communique today; full employment at home; increasingly free trade for the free world; a more effective conventional and nuclear deterrent pending a safe system of inspected disarmament; a faster rate of industrial growth, etc., etc.

Jorge Fernandez of Buenos Aires, totally undisturbed by a disadvantage in weight, age and wagering, slammed his way to a unanimous decision over Denny Moyer of Portland, Ore., at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

ATLANTA, April 8 -- Mr. and Mrs. James Dixon Robinson Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Crawford Robinson, to Arthur Anderson Huber. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Walter Huber of Sharon, Conn.

A group of a hundred scientists, engineers and oil-field workers aboard an offshore oil rig 260 miles south of Los Angeles completed a sixty-hour operation on March 31 by bringing up a cylindrical core of gray-green clay some 25,000,000 years old from a depth of 234 feet below the ocean floor and more than two miles below the surface of the Pacific.

JERUSALEM, April 8 -- In an atmosphere mixed with feelings of vindication, scorn, anxiety and outright fear, the stage has been set here for the trial of Adolf Eichmann for one of the most horrible crimes in memory: the deliberate, planned murder and pillage of millions of people who happened to be Jews.

HOME gardeners can still register for five April courses that will be given at the New York Botanical Garden, Bronx Park. These short courses will cover a variety of subjects -- from cryptogamic botany and rose culture to landscaping.

THIRTY-FIVE years ago this month the great modern dancer Martha Graham gave her first recital on Broadway. With it, she initiated a change in all of dance -- not just in the so-called "modern" area, but in ballet and theatrical dance as well -- that has been going forward ceaselessly ever since.
NEW DELHI, India, April 8 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru angrily denounced today the disruptive forces that he said were exploiting religion, regional origin and caste to prevent Indian unity.
BONN, Germany, April 8 -- Tanned and cheerful, Chancellor Adenauer returned from his Italian holiday today to face a heavy schedule of diplomatic activity.

There are signs on City Island that the recession has made some owners who use their boats for fun wary. The island is the narrow finger of the Bronx that is the commercial heart of New York City's yachting.

AMONG the hot spots in the cold war today, one of the hottest is South Vietnam. Here a real shooting war is going forward between Communist guerrillas and defenders of freedom. THE NATION DIVIDED. Edited by Paul Angle. (Fawcett. 50 cents.) From "The American Reader," which offers eyewitness accounts of important events in American history, five volumes are being published in paperback.

MATHILDE KSCHESSINSKA and Her Serene Highness, the Princess Romanovsky-Krassinsky, are one and the same. Kschenissinka was one of the great dancers of the imperial Ballet in St. Petersburg. She also was one of the first to achieve an international reputation, even before she left Russia.

The American Merchant Marine Library Association will sponsor its fortieth annual New Work Book Week beginning April 24. One of the activities in Association with it will be a tea at the home of Mrs. Cleveland Bacon of 875 Park Avenue on April 25.

Store sales are still in the vanguard of the economic recovery. The gains made by retail merchants since the beginning of the year are continuing, despite cool and rainy weather in some parts of the country. With better weather, merchants generally would have exceeded !9.60 volume for the week before Easter even though the holiday fell two weeks earUer this year.

Robert Moses, president of the New York World's Fair 1964-65 Corporation, has rejected without argument criticism of the plans for the fair recently expressed by Leon Gordon Miller, president of the Industrial Designers Institute.

TELEVISION and radio will begin coverage this week of an historical courtroom event -- the Israeli trial of Adolf Eichmann, the former Gestapo colonel accused of having directed the annihilation of millions of European Jews during the Nazi regime.
Several major railroads are investigating a new form of high-speed land vehicle to challenge the airplane in carrying passengers between big cities.

Foreign exchange market was quiet during the past week. British pound sterling showed some improvement while the Canadian dollar had a firm undertone for most of the sessions. Some European currencies eased.

YONKERS, April 9 -- A clergyman in blue jeans led his congregation in a special Sunday service today -- painting the inside of the old tenement next door that is being converted to handle the overflow Sunday School population.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The director of the Food-for-Peace Program said today that the United States had shipped enough food into the Congo to save 300,000 persons from starvation for a year.

UNITED STATES NAVAL BASE, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, April 9 -- The Navy has strengthened its defenses here recently, but a visitor would never realize it while strolling among the six swimming pools, five outdoor movie houses, twenty baseball fields and the golf course, riding stables, yacht club, tennis courts and bowling alleys.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 9 (AP) -- Roy Emerson of Australia defeated Luis Ayala of Chile today in the men's singles final of the second annual Masters tennis tournament. The scores were 6 --4, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 0.

PITTSBURGH, April 9 -- The bottom in the steel recession has been reached but there was no sign last week that a sharp uptrend was imminent. Rather, it was said; there will be slow rise in order flow and output. In some cases there may be a drop in some weeks.

The Musicians Emergency Fund, founded just thirty years ago today, has used music with a two-pronged purpose: to bring economic help to those who perform it, spiritual succor to those who require it. The fund was born in the depression when the greatest need was to help musicians, old, ill or hard hit economically. The fund provided concerts and thus jobs, opened a placement bureau, arranged for performances of opera.
IN an unguarded moment not long ago, the fast-talking Charlie Dressen, manager of the Milwaukee Braves, let slip an honest appraisal of his outfield situation.

Michael H. Prendergast said yesterday that he and Carmine G. De Sapio had been marked for political oblivion by a Kennedy campaign aide on the ground they were "captives" of Italian and Jewish minorities.

TRENTON, April 9 -- The Federal Bureau of Public Roads has approved a portion of the realigned Route 78, the new Route 22, that will extend through sections of Essex and Union counties, it was disclosed today.

President Kennedy announced last month that his Administration would not permit racial discrimination on Federal contracts. Last week the accompanying order went into effect. Two existing committees have been combined into the President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunities, headed by Vice President Johnson and Labor Secretary Goldberg.

President Kennedy will head the list of speakers in a "Salute to General Omar N. Bradley" May 30 at the Waldorf-Astoria. Frank Pace Jr., general chairman of the evening, also has announced that Mrs. Kennedy will attend the dinner.

"Chaos in Laos," by Bernard B. Fall, Professor of International Relations at Howard University, is planned for summer publication by Public Affairs Press of Washington, D.C. Based on first-hand knowledge of that country, it gives a view of its major characteristics, as well as a perspective on the tensions of the last two years.

WITH the appointment of Rene Verdon, a French chef, to the White House, it is probable that the odors of poule au pot and pot au feu will emanate from the mansion's kitchens during the weeks to come. This is not the first time, however, that French cuisine has made its mark on the first family's table.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -Military leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will meet here tomorrow at a time when major alterations in Western defense policies are under discussion by the allied governments.
A request by the New York City Charter Revision Commission for an initial appropriation of $25,000 will come before the Board of Estimate at a special meeting at 10 A.M. Thursday.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 9 -- A branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People launched a campaign here today to discourage blackface minstrel shows.

Contracts between the television and radio networks and the Directors Guild of America are scheduled to expire at midnight tonight. The guild represents about 900 directors, associate directors and stage managers in broadcasting.
Oscar Moore, a 23-year-old New York Pioneer Club runner, rallied to win yesterday's eighteen Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union run over Bronx leads with a record-breaking performance.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 9 -- Cuban charges of United States "aggression and intervention" against the Government of Premier Fidel Castro are expected to be debated within the next few days.

PARIS, April 9 -- While the forthcoming Kennedy-de Gaulle colloquy is bound to encounter trouble on NATO, nuclear arms and Big Three relationships, the two Presidents should find a solid basis for agreement on Europe and on Africa. There Gaullist policy is essentially parallel with ours.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9 -- Heavy rain washed away play in the fourth round of the Masters golf tournament today. All of the day's scores were erased, and everyone remaining in the field will play the final eighteen holes tomorrow.

IT is one of the recurring jests among diplomats that Dr. Joseph Marie Antoine Hubert Luns, the big man (he is six feet four inches) with the big name should serve as Foreign Minister for one of the world's smallest countries, the Netherlands.

JERUSALEM, April 9 -- Beit Haam, or the House of the People, looked more like a fortress than a court of law today as it was opened to receive newsmen who will cover the trial of Adolf Eichmann starting there Tuesday.

EXPERTS from nearly all fifty states attend the national tournaments of the American Contract Bridge League, but the big regional tournaments, which are next-highest in rank, draw players from a radius of 500 miles or more.

Mayor Wagner's office announced yesterday that $3,180 would be distributed among fifty city employes for suggestions for increased economy and efficiency in city government. The awards, ranging from $10 to $1,000, will be made by the Mayor at City Hall after he returns from Florida, where he is recuperating from surgery.
TRENTON, April 9 -- Eddie Sachs of Center Valley, Pa., won the 100-mile Indianapolis-type auto race before a crowd of 20,000 today.

LENINGRAD, U.S.S.R., March 23 -- Married life began today for Edward and Galina Vinokurov, as it does for a majority of Leningrad couples, in a former palace of the Czars. The city administration calls it the Palace of Weddings.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits said today that although Senator Barry Goldwater was having his day, the conservatives could not win control of the Republican party.
Greenwich Village folk song fans battled the police for two hours in Washington Square yesterday afternoon. Ten demonstrators were arrested and several persons, including three policemen, were hurt.

LEONIA, N.J., April 9 -- The Leonia Bank and Trust Company deposited about 2,000 pounds of ham, baked beans, potato salad and petits fours in its customers yesterday and got back goodwill -- with interest.
OTTOMAR BORWITZKY, first 'cellist of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, made his New York recital debut in Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday night. He was assisted at the piano by Wolfgang Kaiser.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 9 -- Attacks in the United Nations on South Africa's racial policies and complications arising from the country's withdrawal from the British Commonwealth appear to be causing mounting apprehension among opponents of the ruling Nationalist party and within the party itself.

Two paragraphs dealing with efforts to cushion the impact of automation on jobs were inadvertently garbled in the final article of a series on hard-core unemployment in yesterday's editions of The New York Times.

Seventeen members of the Holy Union Sisters Orchestra and Glee Club made their New York debut yesterday afternoon with a concert at the St. Francis de Sales school hall, 120 East Ninety-seventh Street, off Park Avenue.
Although contracts have not been signed, it is understood that Jule Styne and Roger L. Stevens have agreed to present a joint venture, "The Nose of Jerry Pepper," starring Milton Berle.

Public indignation will be aroused and grow with time if TV Channel 13 is sold by its owners to commercial interests in preference to the group of public spirited citizens who have offered to purchase and operate in the public interest as a nonprofit enterprise dedicated with educational and cultural purposes.
"The Apartment" was voted yesterday the best film of 1960 in the thirty-eighth annual poll of critics, commentators and reviewers conducted by The Film Daily, a trade paper.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The Air Force said today that all aircraft training intercept missions had been suspended following the accidental shooting down of a B-52 in a mock battle Friday.
"It was a mad-house all week. The public was buying and price was no object. They just wanted their orders filled."

PARIS, April 9 -- A once-brave effort to solve the practical problems arising from Western Europe's division into two trade blocs has quietly faded out. It was called the Committee of 21, or the Committee on Trade Problems. Established in January, 1960, it has not met since last June, and it probably will never meet again.

Spring arrives officially today with the return of big-league baseball, and never before has an impending season appeared so intriguing with unanswered questions. Will President Kennedy, rookie right-hander, open the season in Washington with a fast ball, a curve or a slider? And speaking of new men on the job, will the renovated Washington Senators emerge from second-division obscuration to become the terrors of the American League?
CHICAGO, April 9 (UPI) -- The outlook for iron ore mines in the Lake Superior region is the bleakest in more than twenty years, industry officials said today.
WARSAW, April 9 -- No crops were harvested last year from more than one-fifth of China's arable land, the Chinese Communist envoy to Poland has disclosed.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Like Washington's famous cherry blossoms, the diplomatic program of the Kennedy Administration is in full bloom.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The Navy, in a newly issued policy statement, takes the position that its long-heralded plans for a nuclear surface fleet must await the day when nuclear ships are about as cheap as conventional ships.
BONN, Germany, April 9 -- Chancellor Adenauer and Dean Acheson discussed for nearly five hours today the future of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

A new dimension has been added to the disturbed picture of passenger transportation in the cities and suburbs. The Federal Government has decided that the continuing shrinkage of commuter rail and bus service and the inadequacies of rapid transit within many cities have become a national problem.
The New Frontier In the Pentagon still has a hazy look.

TELEVISION coverage of the trial of Adolf Eichmann, opening tomorrow, began in earnest yesterday with a series of programs reviewing the preparations for the court proceedings in Israel and discussing some of the ramifications of events in Jerusalem.

MIAMI, April 9 -- In a major strategy decision worked out in recent days, Cuban anti-Castro rebels were reported tonight to have agreed to concentrate on multiple guerrilla landings in Cuba instead of attempting a large-scale invasion.

Orders were heavy last week for merchandise to sell in special promotions and for early summer events, according to word from the resident buying offices. Rainwear was a leader, and summer cottons were in demand in better and popular-price dress departments.
A group of New Yorkers of Sicilian extraction is starting a fund drive to assist a Princeton University archaeological project in Sicily.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- A group of leading business men and educators called upon Congress today to appropriate "now and in one lump sum" the $500,000,000 it authorized last year for an Inter-American social progress fund.
The bright scarlet doors of a building of dark simplicity in Chinatown swung open yesterday around noon, and a stream of laughing, chattering, smartly dressed young people emerged into the sunlight.

PARIS, April 9 -- The spectacular success of the sale to the German public of 60 per cent of the shares of the Volkswagen automobile company has given both encouragement and food for thought to those in Europe who believe in wider share ownership.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Monday, April 10 -- President Ngo Dinh Diem and Vice President Nguyen Ngoc Tho were returned to office with about 78 per cent of the total vote, according to complete unofficial returns from South Vietnam's first Presidential election yesterday.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., April 9 -- The white-framed bell-tower Army chapel at former Camp Shanks, since 1954 a Presbyterian church, was destroyed by fire this morning that was discovered twenty minutes before Sunday School classes were to start.

ALBANY, April 9 -- Democratic legislative leaders accused the Rockefeller administration today of collecting $180,000,000 more in taxes than the state needed during the fiscal year that ended March 31.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 9 -- There has been fighting between Somalis and Ethiopians and deaths on both sides in the last week, the Ethiopian Government disclosed today.

Legislation recently signed into law will allow non-residents paying New York State income taxes to itemize their personal deductions -- but not on 1960 returns filed this year. The new law begins with income earned in 1961. Non-residents must pay New York State taxes on their 1960 New York State earnings under the old rules.
GENEVA, April 9 -- Swiss issues generally inched upward in last week's four days of trading on the Swiss markets, but volume was relatively small and there was no real trend.

Which days, above all others, stand out as beacons of memory among the thousands that make up a crowded lifetime? There are the usual milestones: first day at school, confirmation, graduation, first job, marriage, birth of a child, followed inevitably by the passing of loved ones.
The appointment of Milton Friedman as regional chairman of the National Academy of Abritrators was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The State Department has apologized to Dr. William Fitzjohn, Charge d'Affaires of the African state of Sierra Leone, who was denied service at a restaurant in Hagerstown, Md.
Senator Wayne Dumont Jr. is playing the role of a modern Daniel in urging in the Republican primary campaign for Governor that New Jersey enact a broad-based tax.

BUFFALO, April 9 (AP) -- Talks aimed at settling a work dispute that has stopped most bus service in the Buffalo area were adjourned tonight. Indications are that 250,000 daily riders will have to find other transportation tomorrow.
Robert Pritchard gave a debut piano recital last night at Town Hall that was exciting and musical, yet disappointing.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 9 -- At Kanchanaburi on the River Kwei, a Thai pulp and paper mill that was operating six months ago with a deficit has more than doubled its daily output. Prospects indicate that henceforth it will turn a profit each year equivalent to many thousands of dollars.

CHICAGO, April 9 (AP) -- Trade in grain futures was slow and dull most of the time last week but most contracts ended with small gains mainly, the brokers said, because of the broad setbacks of the previous week.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- One of the hottest legislative battle of this session of Congress will reopen in a new setting this week when the Senate takes up the minimum wage bill.
THE woman who contemplates working after her children are grown or in school is often stumped by the questions. "Where do I begin? What do I do?"

NEW HAVEN, April 9 -- Dr. John Perry Miller, Professor of Economics at Yale, has been named Dean of the Yale Graduate School. He will succeed July 1 Dr. Hartley Simpson, Dean since 1956, who is to devote full time to research and writing.
GRANTS, N.M., April 9 (AP) -- Two members of a B-52 crew shot down accidentally Friday by a National Guard fighter plane were found alive today, bringing the number of survivors to five.

Warner, Burns, Toan Lunde, architects, leased a floor at 724 Fifth Avenue, near Fifty-seventh Street, and will move from 420 Madison Avenue after alterations are completed at the new location. The Fifth Avenue property, which is owned by David W. Frankel, was modernized recently.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 9 -- Support for "classification" -- some system of authoritatively grading movies on their suitability for different age levels -- is stirring in unexpected quarters in the film industry.
Protostantism has never had it so good, a leading New York minister said yesterday, despite "the doleful prophets, breast-beaters and hand-wringers."

HONG KONG, April 9 -- A study of the latest Chinese-Soviet trade and aid agreements has led observers here to the conclusion that Moscow is doing relatively little to help ease Peiping's economic difficulties.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, has asked the Federal Communications Commission to allocate at least one of the New York City area's seven commercial television stations for noncommercial, educational programing.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 9 -- Jack Sutphen won the Interclub Class title as the Larchmont Yacht Club's annual spring invitation two-day regatta for frostbite dinghies ended today. A total of 103 yachts from twelve fleets participated, sixty of them in the Interclub division.

LONDON, April 9 -- The Financial Times industrial shares index moved up to a record high last Tuesday and climbed even higher during the rest of the week. It was a week of steadily increasing trading on the stock market.
LONDON, April 9 (AP) -- The difficult art of being a good mother-in-law is analyzed in a pamphlet distributed today at many Roman Catholic churches in Britain.
The Robert Kreis Chamber Players, an orchestra of twenty musicians, made its New York debut in Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon.

The head of the city's Commission on Intergroup Relations declared yesterday that discrimination in housing and limited job opportunities were forcing a ghetto-like existence on Negro and Puerto Rican citizens here.

Samuel Dilworth-Leslie, a young pianist who has played here previously as Samuel Dilworth, returned to Carnegie Recital Hall late yesterday afternoon for his first appearance following a period of military service.
With the rustling of spring there often comes the rustling of account changes. In this respect, the spring of 1961 is like many springs that have gone before.
MOSCOW, April 9 (AP) -- Indications of new stumbling blocks to peace in Laos arose here today. There were no signs that the Soviet Union was planning to accept Western proposals for a cease-fire.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- Ch. Conifer's Lance, a 4-year-old Irish setter belonging to Frank and Katherine Wheatley of Allen Park, Mich., became the best-in-show winner of the country's largest bench competition tonight.
Bronx Zoo pickets became snake charmers yesterday as they marched with boa constrictors, rat snakes and a sizable African rock python crawling over their, shoulders and strike placards.

ALBANY, April 9 -- Controller Arthur Levitt reported today that county governments would levy almost $276,000,000 in real property taxes this year. This would be about $9,000,000, or 3 1/2 per cent, more than they collected last year.

ST. LOUIS, April 9 (AP) -- Bob Cousy and Frank Ramsey spearheaded a third-quarter comeback today that propelled the Boston Celtics to a 119-104 triumph over the St. Louis Hawks. The victory gave the Celtics a 3 -- 1 grip on the National Basketball Association championship play-off.

POPULAR history -- unlike popular plays on the stage or large or small screens -- unfolds almost every day in the published book lists. They can reach back across the centuries or loot the contemporary, pursue the kingly or only the lieutenants of a particular time.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The Post Office Department announced today plans to add 10,000 regular employes to its payroll by shortening the hours worked by substitute employes.
BERUSSELE, Belgium, April 19 (UPI) -- Jack Brabham of Australia, driving a Cooper, won the Grand Prix of Brussels for Formula One cars today. He finished first in two of the three heats.
The results were announced today of the third annual poll of the All American Press, made up of editors and publishers of thirty-five foreign-language newspapers and magazines.
The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale observed the fortieth year of his pulpit career yesterday.

Operating revenues of Consolidated Freightways, Inc., rose to a new high in 1960, but the trucking company sustained a net loss of $2,674,587 in contrast to a net profit of $2,591,930, or $1.35 a share, in 1959.
Collections under the city's truck and taxi use-tax law have fallen almost 30 per cent short of the $5,500,000 the levy was expected to raise.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 9 -- Substances have been found in cigarette smoke that inhibit the action of other chemicals there that have been said to cause cancer.
More than 8,000 safety officials will come here this week to attend the thirty-first annual convention and exhibition of the Greater New York Safety Council, which begins today.
Representatives of twenty Latin-American nations, not including Cuba, took part yesterday in the ceremony opening Pan American Week.
Prices of cotton futures in the domestic market stayed within a narrow trading range last week, but they were on moderately firmer ground as the week ended.
The New York Yankees, who open their season against the Minnesota Twins at Yankee Stadium tomorrow, will warm up today by batting out speeches and fielding confetti.
HAVANA, April 9 -- Premier Fidel Castro warned his people today that the rationing of "certain products" would soon become necessary in a "fight to the death" against enemies of the revolution.
Cardinal Spellman's campaign for school construction in this area has received subscriptions totaling $38,092,525, it was announced yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Record attendance and sales were reported yesterday as the International Automobile Show ended its nine-day run at the Coliseum.
ST. LOUIS, April 9 -- The Yankees today concluded their exhibition campaign in a drizzling rain that washed out their final game with the St. Louis Cardinals.

THERE is no magic involved in making last year's clothes look like new. In many cases a needle and thread will do the trick, although some revamping requires outside help. Here are ideas for the home seamstress as well as some services that will give an assist where needed.
SANTA ISABEL, Spanish Guinea, March 30 -- The lovely Spanish island of Fernando Po, of which this town is the chief port, is a haven of peace and order off the restless continent of Africa.

Two apartment houses on a plot 40 by 100 feet at 589-91 Third Avenue between Thirty-eighth and Thirty-ninth Streets have been sold by the A.E.S. Realty Company to clients of Walter Scott Co. The houses, across the street from two proposed office buildings at Third Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, were sold for cash over mortgages of $190,000.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 9 -- A United Nations commission reported today that political leaders from Nigeria and Cameroon had taken an active part in and supplied funds for the campaign that preceded the recent plebiscite in the northern part of the British Cameroons.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Internal Revenue Commissioner Mortimer M. Caplin said today that Alvin York, World War I hero, "was given no special advantage" to help him settle his tax troubles.

One of the many lessons parents must teach a child is that of the meaning and importance of time. According to Dr. Penelope P. WASHINGTON, April 9 -- President Kennedy is expected to ask Congress this week for legislation to create a Cabinet department of urban affairs.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- On the nineteenth anniversary of the fall of Bataan in World War II the name of that Philippine battlefield and that of Corregidor were given to streets in the Capital.
MANAMA, Bahrein, April 9 (AP) -- The blazing British liner Dara was taken in tow today and British and American sailors went aboard to fight the flames in a salvage operation.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 3 -- Sentiment on the Amsterdam Bourse during the past holiday-shortened week was aided by a number of good features, including foreign buying and favorable company news.

WARSAW, April 9 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka told Polish farmers today there was no way except socialization to create a successful farm economy in Poland.

Licia Albanese's sole appearance this season as Liu in the new production of "Turandot" at the Metropolitan Opera House was made on Saturday night. It was a memorable performance, almost a capstone in the soprano's long and honorable career here.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 9 -- Maj. Gen. Joseph D. Mobutu, the Congo's army commander, flew to Bumba in the north central part of the country today for a meeting with Gen. Victor Lundula, military commander in the left-wing Stanleyville regime, official Congolese sources reported.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The three semi-finalists were chosen today for the Merriweather Post Young Music Talent Contest -- two pianists and a violinist.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 9 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, Democrat of Minnesota, said here today that he did not think there was need for a Congressional investigation of the John Birch Society, but that he thought the Justice Department should keep an eye on it.
Rear Admiral R.K. James, chief of the Navy's Bureau of Ships, has advised workers at the New York Naval Shipyard at Brooklyn that he has found their response to a call for cost cutting disquieting.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 9 -- The Junior Essex Troop took A team honors tonight in the ninth annual junior Olympics at the Thomas School of Horsemanship.
MIDDLEBURG, Va., April 8 (AP) -- President Kennedy learned through an announcement at mass today of the quiet integration of three lunch counters here. He had figured unknowingly in the event.

PROVIDENCE, April 9 -- A Sealyham terrier from New Jersey was selected tonight as the best of 550 dogs in the fifty-seventh annual all-breed show of the Rhode Island Kennel Club.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Senator Kenneth B. Keating was annoyed recently when he received a letter postmarked Indio, Calif., on which postage was due. But the New York Republican's irritation gave way when he discovered that the letter was from former President Eisenhower.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., April 9 -- Pete Schlegel, a 20-year-old college sophomore, won the seventh annual 500-bird trapshooting marathon today at the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island range. He finished one target ahead of Harry C. Barr Jr. of Greenwich, Conn.

Private institutions of learning, especially in urban centers, are faced with difficult problems in meeting the expected doubling of college enrollment by 1970. WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Foreign Minister Joseph M.A.H. Luns of the Netherlands had a lengthy talk with President Kennedy today as part of the Administration's continuing search for a common policy to strengthen the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 10 -- President Ngo Dinh Diem's overwhelming victory in yesterday's election is being hailed here as a crushing repudiation of Communism as well as a public tribute to the strong-willed leader, however much some of his policies may be criticized.

NEWARK, April 10 -- While public attention in New Jersey is focused on a three-man race for the G.O.P. nomination for Governor, a behind-the-scenes struggle is under way for Democratic state chairman. The Columbia Broadcasting System news division has directed Douglas Edwards to relinquish his role as host and narrator of "Circle Theatre."

MANAMA, Bahrain, April 10 (UPI) -- The fire-swept British liner Data sank today while three frigates were towing her to shore. Authorities abandoned hope for 212 persons, including two Americans, missing in the fire.

TODAY will be the wedding day of Peter Leventritt, who is president of the Card School in New York, and Mrs. Faith Stevens Igleheart, who met her husband-to-be when she went to his school to brush up on her bridge game.

THE prospect of travel often turns a woman toward a short hair style because it will be easy to take care of. There are many ways to maintain a coiffure -- short or long -- even though constantly on the road.

A certified public accountant was sentenced yesterday to eighteen months in prison for giving a $25,000 bribe to an Internal Revenue agent to have a client's tax obligation reduced from $2,500,000 to $75,000.
There are crimes -- historic crimes -- so monstrous that they shatter the bounds of normal legal procedure and dwarf both the criminal and any punishment that may be inflicted on him.
BONN, Germany, April 10 -- Chancellor Adenauer declared tonight that Nazi sentiment had been eradicated completely from the German people.

A recent major ship sale reportedly was approved "in principle" by the Federal Maritime Board before the president and most stockholders of American Export Lines knew they were in the market for a fleet.

The volume of retail sales in the nation rose 1 per cent in March above the adjusted level for February, the Department of Commerce reported yesterday in a preliminary evaluation of consumer buying in the month.

LAUREL, Md., April 10 (AP) -- Orleans Doge defeated a field of Chesapeake Stakes nominees today in the $4,500 Colonel Matt Winn Purse. The result of the seven-furlong race was far from convincing to the 9,578 fans at Laurel Race Course.
DETROIT, April 10 (AP) -- Rigid production controls in the automobile industry combined with improving sales have reduced the inventory of new cars to 936,000 units.
I realize that this is a rather late date to bring to your attention a small objection to your editorial entitled "Why the Hurry at Albany?" in the issue of March 23.
A motion to dismiss perjury actions against nineteen contestants on rigged television quiz programs was denied yesterday by General Sessions Judge Gerald P. Culkin.

MANY seasoned travelers long ago discovered T. Anthony as the place to go for luggage and travel accessories. This shop at 772 Madison Avenue (at Sixty-sixth Street) has a wide assortment of handsome luggage of all types.
GUATEMALA, April 10 -- The forces training in Guatemala are not going to invade Cuba unless there is an attack on Guatemala, President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes said today.
PITTSBURGH, April 10 (AP) -- The New York correspondent of the Moscow radio participated in a broadcasters conference here today although this city is officially off-limits to him.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 10 -- Indications that the rising incidence in the last twenty years of arteriosclerosis among young persons may be related to the growing use of drugs were reported here today.

The Borden Company announced yesterday that it had acquired Wyler Co., Chicago, a manufacturer of dehydrated food products. Wyler will operate as a division of Borden under the supervision of the Borden Foods Company.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) April 10 -- The Israeli police have taken extraordinary precautions to prevent anyone from killing Adolf Eichmann or giving him the means to commit suicide.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 10 -- Sierra Leone, a British African possession since 1788, will attain sovereignty on April 27 in circumstances that mark it as distinctive.

Stepping up its down-to-the-last-tie fight against the proposed merger of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway and the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, the New York Central Railroad cried "bankruptcy" yesterday. That dire fate awaited it, the Central indicated, if the two carriers were permitted to merge, leaving the Central in the cold.
Fredric March is considering the role of the Angel of God in "Gideon," based, on episodes in the life of the Biblical figure.

Robert E. Simon Jr., New York realty investor and former head of Carnegie Hall, Inc., has bought Sunset Hills Farms, a tract of 6,750 acres in Fairfax County, Va., near Washington. The reported price was $12,800,000.

IF Nietzsche proclaimed the death of God, then a considerable portion of modern art seems to have proclaimed the death of nature. Nature, however, is a hard thing to kill, and the raw material of natural fact passes through three extraordinary sensibilities in exhibitions currently on view.
ALBANY, April 10 -- The state extended its residential rent controls today for two more years, with greater safeguards for tenants.

The Municipal Investment Trust, the first fund authorized to convey the privilege of tax-free income from local governments to holders of participating certificates, is offering its certificates to the public today at a unit price of $1,010.83.
The Navy's airships, except for two for research purposes, may be slated for retirement.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), April 9 -- The code of criminal procedure under which Adolf Eichmann is being tried in Israel differs from that in the United States in a major respect: there is no trial by jury in Israel.
Paris, April 10 -- Hopes for resuming negotiations for peace in Algeria centered tonight on the news conference President de Gaulle will give tomorrow at Elysee Palace.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 10 -- Yale scored five goals in the fourth period and defeated the Oxford-Cambridge lacrosse team today, 11 -- 7.

JACKSON, Miss., April 10 (AP) -- The Justice Department began investigation today of reports of discrimination against Negroes seeking to vote in the Mississippi counties of Madison, Walthall and Forrest.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- It "will take time" to get unemployed workers back on the job and to get idle factories producing again at satisfactory rates, Congress was told today.
MINEOLA, L.I., April 10 -- Nassau County Republican leaders agreed unanimously today to support Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino of Long Beach as the new county leader.
BUENOS AIRES, April 10 -- president Arturo Frondizi declared today that vested-interest groups and "extremist social agitators" were hampering progress in under-developed countries.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Rolando Masferrer Rojas, a leading supporter of Fulgencio Batista, ousted Cuban President, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today for efforts to overthrow the regime of Fidel Castro.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) -- House Republicans said today that the typical American worker might ultimately be forced into premature retirement at the age of 62 if Congress approved President Kennedy's Social Security proposals.
LONDON, April 10 -- Viscount de L'Isle and Dudley was named Governor General of Australia today.
Broadway took a brief look over the shoulder of pay television yesterday and came away undecided whether it had a friend or foe.
Three District Attorneys joined the city Police and Law Departments yesterday in a general crackdown on obscene periodicals.

In your editorial entitled "Diplomacy vs. Justice" on April 1 your seem to have failed to view the Melekh espionage case in the context of diplomatic immunity merely because the Government itself initially rejected it.
A tenants' suit to set aside an eviction notice issued by the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission was dismissed yesterday by the State Supreme Court.

MOSCOW, April 10 -- The British Ambassador, Sir Frank Roberts, made a brief visit to the Soviet Foreign Ministry today to try to obtain an East-West agreement on negotiating a settlement of the crisis in Laos.
SADDLE RIVER, N.J., April 10 -- The Saddle River Council unanimously approved an amendment to the zoning ordinance tonight that will in effect keep Seton Hall University out of the community.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Baseball plunged headlong today into the brave new world of tomorrow. It pried open the first 162-game schedule ever designed for the big leagues and also began the first ten-team set-up the American League ever has had.

BILOXI, Miss., April 10 (UPI) -- The Federal Reserve System's new policy of buying longer-term securities is hardly a conspicuous success, Dale E. Sharp, president of New York's Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, said today.
TRENTON, April 10 -- Boys who attend Amherst College may now apply for new scholarships from a $200,000 trust fund -- if they do not smoke, drink or gamble.
CHICAGO, April 10 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

NOW is the time to get hold of some Cahills and Hendricksons against the time when Mayflies will begin to hatch pretty soon, which brings up the question among certain experts whether fisherman think better than fish.
A demonstration of closed-circuit television that could lead to a marked advance in traffic control was staged yesterday for Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley and members of his staff.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 2 to 11 points (10 to 55 cents a bale) yesterday.

Fifteen hundred junior high school pupils from the city's Higher Horizons" project will make over the house Thursday morning for the American hakespeare Festival's presentation of "Twelfth Night"' at tratford, Conn.
GENEVA, April 10 -- The Soviet Union continued today to pick and choose among Western concessions at the nuclear test-ban conference without offering to meet the price tag attached to them.

The bond market had an off day yesterday both in activity and in price. The implications of the further rise in common stock values in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange was one of the big reasons.
CHICAGO, April 10 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks scored three goals in less than seven minutes of the second period tonight and beat the Detroit Red Wings, 3 -- 1.

Irving Lazar, who represents Alan Jay Lerner, author of the book and lyrics Frederick Loewe, composer, and Moss Hart, director, could not be reached last night for confirmation.

Lack of cooperation between private physicians and the forces of public health is a major reason for the present resurgence of syphilis, an expert from the Department of Health, Education and Welfare said here yesterday.

"LONDON looks good enough to eat -- which is more than can be said for some of the food. Next stop France, and some REAL meals." This type of postcard commentary from an American vacationing in Europe is, alas, all too familiar.

DETROIT, April 10 (AP) -- Second-seeded Erwin Klein of Los Angeles won the men's United States open table-tennis singles championship last night in a five-game duel with seventh-seeded Mike Ralston of Sherman Oaks, Calif.

A debut, two conductors, a first time in a role and three other changes of cast were the extraordinary events at last night's' "La Boheme" at the Metropolitan Opera. Not to mention the feature attraction of the evening: Victoria de los Angeles as Mimi.
Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia, the challenger in the return match for the world chess championship at the Variety Theatre in Moscow, outplayed Mikhail Tal of Latvia in the tenth game yesterday.
A local "doctors' dilemma" resolved itself here yesterday and resulted in accolades to six persons instead of merely one.
LOS ANGELES, April 10 (AP) -- An attempt to recover the capsule from the satellite Discoverer XXIII failed today when the capsule went into orbit instead of returning to earth.

Carlos Marcello, reputedly a major figure in gambling and other illegal enterprises, is doubtless a person this country could do without. Because he arrived in the United States at the age of eight months and has been convicted of selling marijuana, he is unquestionably deportable. But neither bad character nor deportability can justify the tactics used by the Immigration and Naturalization Service last week to get him out of the country.
TRENTON, April 10 -- A special New Jersey Senate committee heard conflicting testimony today on the merits of a bill to ban racial discrimination in private housing in the state.
Ngo Dinh Diem's re-election to the Presidency of South Vietnam on Sunday was really a double victory, a victory over his two opponents on the ballot and over the Vietnamese Communists.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), April 10 (AP) -- With Adolf Eichmann going on trial, the search continues for some of his close associates in the Einsatzgruppen (operational groups in charge of mass liquidation).
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 -- Gary Player of South Africa became the Masters golf champion today after shooting his weakest round of the tournament -- a two-over-par 74.

The May, July and September world sugar positions climbed to new highs for the lives of the contracts yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Trading was influenced by reports of increased anti-Castro activity in Cuba and rumors that rebel activity will increase and be unified.

Steel production continued to edge upward last week with mills producing more metal than at any time since last June. Raw steel output rose to 1,696,000 tons from 1,632,000 two weeks ago and 1,611,000 three weeks ago, according to figures released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.
CHICAGO, April 10 (UPI) -- Republican leader Charles H. Percy said today "to coll former President Eisenhower a Communist is like calling a disciple of Jesus an advocate of the devil."
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Treasury bill rates declined on today's sale of regular weekly issues, reversing a short-lived upturn.

Nippon Telegraph Telephone Public Corporation filed a registration statement yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering $15,000,000 of dollar bonds guaranteed by Japan and to be offered in two parts.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 10 -- Representatives of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold were reported today to be seeking a tacit acceptance by the Congolese central Government of a United Nations military drive against Katanga Province mercenaries.
HAVANA, April 10 -- The Cuban Government was reliably reported today to have begun a campaign to kill or capture the anti-Castro rebels in the Organos Mountains.

LONDON, April 10 -- A Columbia Broadcasting System report on Britain, which in many parts was frankly critical of this country's methods and attitudes, was shown to British television audiences last night by the British Broadcasting Corporation.

Sloan Wilson, the novelist, and Sig Shore, film producer, have formed Value Productions to co-produce independently, "A Sense of Values," Mr. Wilson's best-selling novel published last November by Harper.
Jose Stable, a Cuban welterweight, easily outpointed Billy Collins of Detroit in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
An informal referendum will be held to determine if folk singers should be allowed to sing in Washington Square on Sundays, Newbold Morris, the Commissioner of Parks, indicated yesterday.
JERSEY CITY, April 10 -- Three of the twelve municipalities in Hudson County have lower property tax rates this years, the Hudson County Board of Taxation said today.
The metropolitan area faces a shortage of 1,000 technical and skilled employes by 1964 for its fast-growing electronics industries, a state survey showed yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 10 (AP) -- A strong demand for old crop soybean futures hoisted those contracts to their highest levels in more than four years again today on the Board of Trade on gains running to 6 3/4 cents a bushel.

Israel's seizure of Adolf Eichmann in Argentina for trial in Israel has provoked widespread controversy about various legal aspects of the case.

A double-barreled warning of more troubles ahead for the nation's ailing airlines was fired yesterday by C.R. Smith, president of American Airlines, Inc. American cleared $10,000,000 last year, but this year has operated at a deficit.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Kennedy opened the 1961 baseball season today with two good pitches, but his support couldn't get the new Washington Senators off to a winning start. The President cheered as the Senators took an early lead and groaned with the rest of the crowd when sloppy Washington fielding gave the Chicago White Sox the game, 4 to 3.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- A considerable increase in the Soviet airlift of arms and equipment to rebel forces in Laos caused official concern here tonight.

A 37-YEAR-OLD actor-writer from the West, Philip Hanson, has attempted to transmute Herman Melville's titanic whale story, "Moby Dick," into a living work for the stage. As presented last night at the Madison Avenue Playhouse, he enacts about twenty characters, narrates portions of the sea saga, sings chanteys of the deep and accompanies himself on an instrument called an Autoharp.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Most appropriately, the professional baseball season of 1961 was opened in this capital today, and by the President of the United States. There are multitudes aware of this occasion who recall only 1492 and 1776 as other important dates in American history.

ROUBAIX, France, April 10 -- In choking dust on a bumpy, pot-holed cobblestone road nine feet wide, the car had evidently attempted to pass the bike racer. Caked with filth, aching with thirst, still pedaling furiously after five hours, the rider didn't see the car until it hit him.
BOSTON, April 10 (UPI) -- The Boston Celtics hope to wrap up their third straight National Basketball Association title tomorrow night when they meet the St. Louis Hawks at the Garden.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 10 -- Delegates to the forty-ninth annual meeting of the Western Petroleum Refiners Association were told here today that it was the responsibility of industry to maintain close cooperation with colleges and universities regarding the need for trained manpower.

The National Institute of Arts and Letters announced yesterday that its Rosenthal Awards, created to encourage younger people of talent, would be awarded to John Knowles, author, and Zubel Kachadoorian, painter.
New York City expressed interest yesterday in the expanded shopping list of surplus foods available to persons on welfare through Federal and state channels.
J. Truman Bidwell, an independent floor broker specializing in institutional business, has been nominated for a one-year term as chairman of the New York Stock Exchange.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 10 -- The United States joined leading Asian and African states today in calling for the dismantling of regimes set up earlier this year in Ruanda-Urundi, allegedly at the direction of the Belgian administrators.
The pretty girl is probably the marketing man's best friend. At least he depends on her more than anything else to catch the eye of the public.
DETROIT, April 10 (AP) -- Bob Thiel of Chicago moved into second place in the classic all-events division of the American Bowling Congress tournament today after toppling 1,935 pins in nine games.
Stocks moved ahead yesterday to score a good gain.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The House of Representatives received today the biggest authorization bill in Congressional history. It called for new missiles, aircraft and naval vessels costing $11,974,800,000.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday that operating revenues and net income set records in the quarter ended on Feb. 28. The period covered is traditional for telephone reports.
MOSCOW, April 10 (AP) -- A Foreign Office spokesman said late tonight he had no information on rumors that the Soviet Union had sent a man into space.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 10 -- United Nations members were strongly urged today to take "separate and collective action" against South Africa to bring an end to her policies of apartheid, or racial separation.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 10 -- James P. Mitchell campaigned from the slums of Newark's Central Ward to the expensive areas of this and other west Essex suburbs today.

VALLETTA, Malta, April 10 (AP) -- Mrs. Mittie Mary Starr Rogers, 47-year-old daughter of Sir Abe Bailey, the late South African millionaire, was found dead aboard her 278-ton yacht Verona in Malta Harbor today. The police said foul play was not suspected.
MONTREAL, April 10 (UPI) -- A Polish immigrant engineer was held without bail tonight on a charge of spying for a foreign power, believed to be the Soviet Union.
FLORENCE, Italy, April 10 (AP) -- The United States gave details here today of plans to land on the moon a camera to send television pictures back to the earth.

Emil Lence, a former fight promoter, is leading the field in the race to obtain the New York franchise in the National Bowling League. The franchise has been without an owner since the league ousted Jesse Weingart and Irving Fagenson last Thursday.
HANDEL'S "Belshazzar" is is one of his most dramatic oratorios, and last night at Carnegie Hall the Cantata Singers gave a performance of it that revealed the work's manifold virtues.
Sales and earnings of the Magnavox Company rose to new highs last year, Frank Freimann, president, reported yesterday.

Martin Mayer, author of "Madison Avenue, U.S.A." and "Wall Street: Men and Money," has written a report on American schools from kindergarten through the secondary grades. It will be issued April 25 by Harper and will be called "The Schools."

PARIS, April 10 -- Wilfrid Baumgartner, France's Minister of Finance, made a favorable report today on the French economy. But he tempered his optimism with a warning of inflationary dangers that could wreck the results achieved.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Space Agency disclosed to day plans to step up the man-in-space program.

Neither the weather nor the program was inviting, but 22,316 race-goers turned out at Aqueduct yesterday. They saw Fred W. Hooper's Winonly speed over a sloppy track to a convincing victory in the featured Woodhaven Handicap.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The White Sox marred the debut of the Senators today as the 1961 major league baseball season opened at Griffith Stadium with President Kennedy in attendance.

Big league baseball fans turn their attention today to the sixteen clubs that rested yesterday while the Washington Senators played their traditional Presidential opener against the Chicago White Sox.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) -- The United States Tariff Commission refused today to increase import duties on rayon staple fiber.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Joe Mooney, Washington's new groundskeeper, had his crew at work at 6 A.M. today to get the field in shape for the major league baseball opener. Heavy rain last night had left the field in poor condition.

ALBANY, April 10 -- A special commission to revise the state's eighty-year-old Penal Law and its Code of Criminal Procedure was authorized in a measure signed by Governor Rockefeller today. He noted that no major changes had been made in the two statutes since they were enacted in 1881.
Federal mediators announced last night the settlement of a dispute between 630 lighter captains and seven port railroads.
The apartment house at 72 Bedford Street, which occupies land once owned by Aaron Burr, has been sold by the heirs of Samuel Horowitz, who acquired the property in 1900.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture forecast today that this year's winter wheat crop would amount to 1,098,735,000 bushels. This would be nearly 2 per cent less than last year's harvest but would still be the third largest winter wheat crop on record and almost a third greater than average.
The sale of $177,000,000 of revenue bonds to finance an extension of the Massachusetts Turnpike to Boston was postponed indefinitely yesterday. The deal had been scheduled for tomorrow.

In all this talk about the midtown parking garages, one of the most important elements of public interest has been overlooked. That is the strong sense of duty and of courage displayed by Chairman Felt, Vice Chairman Bloustein and the Commissioners of the City Planning Commission.

Greenwich Village coffee houses won a victory yesterday when a city magistrate dismissed a charge against one of them that it had operated as a cabaret without a license.
Agreement has been reached on a formula to save the Dakota, one of the city's most colorful apartment houses, from demolition.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 10 -- President Sukarno formally opened the Asian-African People's Solidarity Council meeting today with a renewed appeal for a second Asian-African conference to combat "neocolonialism."

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, April 10 -- The International Court of Justice began hearing today a case between Cambodia and Thailand over the ownership of an ancient temple, with former Secretary of State Dean Acheson at the counsel table and his old friend, Dr. Philip C. Jessup, on the judges' bench.

YONKERS, April 10 -- Su Mac Lad, the standardbred who supposedly doesn't need help, received some today in the drawing for Thursday's $65,600 Gotham Trot. The star 7-year-old gelding drew the pole position.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 10 -- The Inter-American Development Bank's annual meeting of governors opened here today on note of harmony and praise for the Kennedy Administration's Latin-American policy.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Tuesday, April 11 -- The trial of Adolf Eichmann before an Israeli tribunal opened today. The former Nazi faced a court of three judges on charges of having delivered millions of Jews to extermination camps in World War II.

Sales of E.I du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., were $512,000,000 in the first quarter of 1961, a decline of 4 per cent from the $534,296,000 in the corresponding period last year, Crawford H. Greenewalt, president, reported at the annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., yesterday.
Six leading unionists have joined the American Friends Service Committee in calling a conference on "Peace, Jobs and Freedom," to be held Friday and Saturday at the Morrison Hotel in Chicago.

Two candidates who had been considered strong prospects for the coaching job with the New York Rangers dropped from contention yesterday. John Bergen, the president of the National Hockey League Club, said that neither Pat Egan nor Frank Eddolls was any longer in the running.

PARIS, April 10 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, former Premier of Laos, will interrupt his forthcoming visit to Moscow to make a brief trip to Washington for consultations on the crisis in his country.
TUNIS, April 10 -- Informed Algerians in Tunis indicated today that they expected the postponed peace negotiations with the French Government to open before the end of the month.

JOHN DOOLEY can write an occasionally lively lyric and give it wing with an agreeable tune but he is a clumsy hand with a book. "Hobo," which opened last night at the Gate Theatre, reflects his unbalanced attainments.
Plans of Transamerica Corporation to reacquire the Pacific Finance Corporation through an exchange of shares were announced yesterday.
A petition to compel the Board of Education to reinstate a 5-year-old boy in kindergarten was temporarily denied yesterday in State Supreme Court.
Lisa Lane, the United States women's chess champion, is a member of the eight-player team that will represent the New School for Social Research in a match against Columbia University tonight.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 10 -- After reaping the acclaim of Israeli theatregoers, the Theatre Guild American Repertory Company, fatigued and illness-stricken, flew to Ankara, Turkey, today to continue its State Department-sponsored tour.

The State Banking Board will hold a special meeting Thursday to act on the application of the Bankers Trust Company to form a new bank holding company to acquire the County Trust Company of White Plains, largest bank in suburban Westchester County.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- A "welcome corps" set up by private civic groups to make foreign visitors feel at ease was proposed today by Senator Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York.

A 490-foot freighter and a seventy-seven-foot fishing trawler collided early yesterday in fog and heavy seas about forty miles southeast of Cape May, N.J. The trawler sank. One of the five crew members was killed and three were missing.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 -- In a game dominated by phlegmatic craftsmen who scrutinize each blade of grass before they shoot and prima donnas who throw tantrums in the rough, Gary Player is an amiable, diplomatic, entertaining Bohemian.

LONDON, April 10 -- A wave of heavy buying gave the stock market its busiest session here today in more than fifteen months. The buying was concentrated, as it has been for the past week, on industrial shares.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) -- The International Coffee Agreement, which controls the bulk of the coffee sold on the world market, announced today a quarterly export quota of 8,990,199 bags for the April-June period.

BONN, Germany, April 10 -- Chancellor Adenauer indicated today that the Kennedy Administration had shelved the question of providing nuclear arms for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization pending new disarmament negotiations with the Soviet Union.

A Grand Ball, like the one given in 1850 by Dom Pedro 2d, Emperor of Brazil, will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on May 10. The event will benefit the National Society for Crippled Children and Adults (Easter Seal Society).

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 10 -- A promising experiment in air-traffic control, prompted mainly by the collision Dec. 16 of two airliners over Staten Island, is under way in the Pittsburgh area.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 10 -- An unknown producer has beaten Hollywood's big operators to the story of the rocket ship X-15.
BALTIMORE, April 10 (AP) -- Baltimore whooped it up today for its first major league baseball pennant winner.
