RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 10 -- Suffolk County's controversial $2,300,000 property-and-tax-map project was canceled today by the Board of Supervisors. The board also approved a measure to start a county airport and air terminal system.
MOSCOW, April 11 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Communist party and the Council of Ministers announced tonight a decision to form a State Committee for Coordinating Scientific Research.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- President Kennedy's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity pledged today a vigorous effort to eradicate discrimination in Government employment and by Federal suppliers and contractors.
MILWAUKEE, April 11 (AP) -- Daryl Spencer cracked Warren Spahn's first pitch in the tenth-inning for a home run today and lifted the St. Louis Cardinals to a 2-1 victory over the Braves.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) -- Representative Overton Brooks, chairman of the House Space Committee, said today he was "not entirely satisfied" with the space budget proposed by President Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Joseph C. Swidler of Nashville, Tenn., nominee for the Federal Power Commission, told the Senate Commerce Committee today that he believed the commission should be an aggressive agency.

Sales of Melville Shoe Corporation in the first quarter of 1961 showed a gain of 21.7 per cent, Ward Melville, chairman, told the annual meeting yesterday. He said that sales were expected to rise the rest of the year, compared with 1960.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 11 -- The greatest surprise in six years awaits commuters on two yet undetermined New Haven Railroad trains this week.
CHICAGO, April 11 (AP.) -- Admiral Arleigh A. Burke, Chief of Naval Operations, said here today that communism might conquer the world because of what he termed traditional Yankee optimism.
In the advertising news this morning there is a phenomenon that takes place every, now and again.
The harsh statements on Algeria made by President de Gaulle at his press conference yesterday in Paris have come with the impact of an atomic bomb.

LONDON, April 11 -- The British Government hopes it will be possible for the Soviet Union and Britain to announce a joint appeal for a ceasefire in Laos and to issue invitations to a conference on the country "in the near future," Edward Heath, Lord Privy Seal, said today.
NEW DELHI, India, April 11 -- Defense Minister V.K. Krishna Menon defended himself today against persistent criticism of his direction of India's armed forces.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- A slightly trimmed version of President Kennedy's bill to increase the minimum wage was approved today by the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee. Debate was scheduled for Thursday and Friday.
JERSEY CITY, April 11 -- All nine members of the Board of Education as of April, 1959, were indicted today on charges of conspiracy to defraud.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 11 -- The West has apparently decided to put off until fall any attempt to solve the United Nations financial crisis at this session of the General Assembly.

Operations of W.R. Grace Co. resulted in a consolidated net income of $16,220,381, or $3.22 a common share, for 1960, the company reported yesterday. In 1959, earnings were $16,466,440, or $3.35 a share.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- President Kennedy is now deeply involved in a moral and political question that has troubled statesmen and philosophers ever since the days of Pericles. This is how to reconcile the nation's self-interest with its ideals and treaty commitments.
Pedro Ramos, a young man torn between baseball and patriotism, chose yesterday to concentrate on baseball. He concentrated so well that he ruined the opening of the Yankees' 1961 championship season.

As the married taxpayer looks over the raw materials of his tax destiny -- his income tax returns, his check stubs and other records of his 1960 income and expenses -- he may recall the basic rule that filing' a joint Federal income tax return generally results in a lover tax than the filing of one return for his wife and one for himself.

The fourteenth annual Loyalty Day Parade of the New York County Veterans of Foreign Wars will be held on Saturday on April 29, with Carmine G. De Sapio, the New York County Democratic leader, as grand marshal.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 11 -- The General Assembly was asked today to remain technically in session through the summer to oversee the carrying out of an amnesty and elections in the United Nations trust territory of Ruanda-Urundi.
Cleveland, Ohio, borrowed $14,520,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- President Kennedy gave the nation tonight a first-hand, camera's-eye view of his feelings about the Presidency, the operation of the White House and his top staff aides.

YONKERS, April 11 -- Roger, Harry and Ivey's Rexall Boy from Mineral Point, Wis., scored his third victory in four starts during the meeting by taking the Tuckahoe Trot in 2:05 1/5 before 17,970 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
OTTAWA, April 11 -- Prime Minister Macmillan said today he did not believe that "new countries crowding in upon us" would bring turmoil and chaos to the world.
A few land-bound souls have questioned the whole idea behind man-in-space programs. Why send a man into space?

Further changes in the official results of the twelve-hour endurance sports car race at Sebring, Fla., on March 25, were announced yesterday. Two revisions affected the top ten over all. The German Porsche driven by Bob Holbert of Warrington, Pa., and Roger Penske of Villanova, Pa., was moved from sixth to fifth place, shifting position with the Ferrari driven by Jim Hall of Dallas and George Constantine of Southbridge, Mass.
A recruiting mission from Western Nigeria is scheduled to arrive in New York today in search of qualified Americans willing to contract for two or more years of service in Africa.

Paperboard production fell to 305,857 tons in the week ended last Saturday from 320,592 tons the week before, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. A year earlier the figure was 316,815.

Two hundred and twenty-nine fewer persons were injured in automobile accidents here last week than in the like period a year ago, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. The total injured last week was 782.
The Composers Group of New York City gave a Carnegie Recital Hall concert last night.

TORONTO, April 11 (AP) -- The International Soccer League said today that it had been refused permission by the Ontario Football Association to bring six international teams here from New York for a series of exhibition games.
Tenants came to the aid of the superintendent of a West Side tenement yesterday that apparently had been abandoned by its owner.

The communique on the new trade agreement between the Soviet Union and Communist China has added an important dimension to knowledge of the current relationship between the two key Communist powers. For the first time we now know that Peiping's agricultural difficulties last year put it in a very difficult economic position vis-a-vis Moscow, making it impossible for the Chinese Communists to fulfill their export commitments.
The men running Project Mercury, this country's "man in space" program, estimate that, "with luck," they may have an astronaut in orbit by the end of this year.
Sir Winston Churchill will pay a visit of less than twenty-four hours here today, en route from a Caribbean cruise to London.

Mayor Wagner, who is on a vacation retreat in Florida, announced his support yesterday of the ban issued by Newbold Morris, the Commissioner of Parks, against folk singing and guitar playing in Washington Square Park.
MINEOLA, L.I., April 11 -The Federation of Nigeria is seeking property on Long Island or in Westchester County for her embassy staff, which now is in temporary quarters in New York.
LOS ANGELES, April 11 (AP) -- A bitter exchange between attorneys highlighted the trial of Frankie Carbo and four others for conspiracy and extortion today.
PANAMA, April 11 (AP) -- The Panama Canal Company announced today it was shifting its Panama Line terminal in the United States from New York to New Orleans.

HOUSTON, April 11 (AP) -- Bernard Bartzen, the No. 1 United States amateur, was upset by Frank Froehling, the 1960 junior Wimbledon junior champion, today in the first round of the River Oaks tennis tournament.

STRATFORD-ON-AVON, England, April 11 -- The Royal Shakespeare Theatre introduced a slightly modified "Hamlet" and a new Prince of Denmark tonight as the second offering of its current festival season.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board made a strong appeal today for price reductions as a means of solving the nation's economic problems.

MRS. JOHN F. KENNEDY gave her first extended interview on television last night. Not only was her exceptional videogenic quality reaffirmed, but also in the informal discussion she was a lady of captivating graciousness and charm.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Before an overflowing and enthusiastic crowd in the new State Department Auditorium, site of President Kennedy's press conference, Yoko Matsuda, 18-year-old violinist, won the $2,000 first prize of the National Symphony's Merriweather Post Contest, which is held annually in conjunction with the Music for Young America concerts.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 11 -- Dr. Robert Servatius, chief defense counsel for Adolf Eichmann, declared in court today that he would prove that the Israeli Government had ordered the kidnapping of his client in Argentina.

The ancient conflict between executive and legislative powers, the prerogatives of Congressional committees and the personal authority of a veteran Congressman are all involved in the hearings on a $12 billion defense authorization measure which opened yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- President Kennedy said tonight "if we don't move now" to aid Latin-American nations, Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba "may become a greater danger than he is today."

CHICAGO, April 11 -- A man charged with spying for the Soviet Union went free today in Federal Court here as the Government kept its word not to prosecute him if a Russian, accused of being a co-conspirator, left the country.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), April 11 -- Diplomats, tourists, press representatives from all over the world, and a handful of Israeli citizens filled Beit Haam, the House of the People, for the opening today of the trial of Adolf Eichmann.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- President Kennedy now has the impression that the British Government is seriously thinking about joining the European Economic Community, or Common Market.
PHILADELPHIA, April 11 -- A city agency charged Philadelphia's hotel and restaurant industry today with discrimination in the hiring and assigning of employes.
LONDON, April 11 (AP) -- The Nazi horrors of a generation ago dominated European newspaper headlines today as Adolf Eichmann went on trial in Jerusalem.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 11 -- A representative of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba was received by President Janio Quadros in Brasilia yesterday, it was reported today.
NEW VERNON, N.J., April 11 -- The immediate need for a fourth major airport in the metropolitan area was disputed in a survey made public today.

Events today: "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Bach's B minor Mass, presented by the Oratorio Society of New York, T. Charles Lee, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8; Handel's "Esther," Johannes Somary, conductor, Town Hall, 8:30; Russell Oberlin, counter-tenor, Kaufmann Concert Hall, Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, 8:30.
GENEVA, April 11 -- The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe began its sixteenth session here today with Cyprus present as a member for the first time.

A MINOR aftermath of the Civil War, one not likely to get much attention in this year's centennial celebration, was the sudden popularity of peanuts in the North. Before the war, the ground nut, goober or pindar, to call the peanut by some of its other names, was virtually, unknown north of the Mason-Dixon line.
Warner Brothers has purchased the film rights to the hit musical "Camelot."
MARALAL, Kenya, April 11 -- Kenya should be granted immediate independence, Jomo Kenyatta said today.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Dr. John S. Badeau of New York, former president of the American University in Cairo, has been picked by President Kennedy as his Ambassador to the United Arab Republic.

While Allan P. Kirby is believed to have been the principal purchaser of the more than 100,00 common shares of Allegheny Corporation traded Monday on the New York Stock Exchange, the Murchison Brothers of Dallas, Tex., on the same day closed a deal for about 150,000 Alleghany shares -- off the board, it was learned yesterday.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 11 -- A bomber traversing a clear sky at 50,000 feet would hardly be spotted by the man in the street were it not for the white contrails it frequently leaves behind.

Dr. Wallace S. Sayre, Professor of Public Administration at Columbia University, said yesterday that he believed organized crime and religious bodies had far less influence in municipal government than many people, appeared to believe.

The combined profits of American Export Lines and the Isbrandtsen Steamship Company will more than double if the operations of both fleets are combined, a Federal Maritime Board examiner was told yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 11 -- Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon said today that the United States regarded "both economic stagnation and social injustice as totally intolerable" in the Americas.

Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia, the challenger, won the tenth game of the world chess championship yesterday, according to a report from Moscow. Mikhail Tal of Latvia resigned without resuming the game, which had been adjourned after forty-two moves.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Officials said today the United States Government was disturbed by Moscow's delay in accepting a Western plan for an immediate cease-fire in Laos.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation's backlog of orders is at its highest level since last June and the company's operating rate has been rising in every month since last October, it was disclosed yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders in Wilmington, Del.
The Soviet launching of a man into space was the culmination of many preliminary firings, virtually all of which appear to have been made down the same missile range.
The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad, which operated last year at a net loss of nearly $20,000,000, expects to be "in the red" again this year even if its gross revenues are higher than 1960's $200,419,579.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) -- The Netherlands Foreign Minister, Joseph M.A.H. Luns, said today that the Kennedy Administration has been actively studying ways of giving the North Atlantic Treaty Organization its own atomic forces.

About 500 members of Lighter Captains Union, Local 996 of the International Longshoremen's Association, voted overwhelmingly last night to accept a contract settlement voted earlier yesterday by seven port railroads.

Primarily as a member of the human race, and then as an Indian, I am delighted and deeply touched by the noble service Mrs. Welthy H. Fisher has been offering in Lucknow, at Literacy Village, which you reported on April 2.

Property owners, housewives and representatives of civic and religious groups and of municipal agencies appeared all day yesterday before the city's Board of Standards and Appeals. The board was holding its weekly hearing on applications for zoning variations.

Harry Canelstein, New York and Florida realty investor, has sold the North Bellmore Shopping Center at 1526 to 1540 Newbridge Road, corner of Bellmore Avenue, in North Bellmore, L.I. Frederick Katzenell, a New York investor, was the buyer.

An agreement between Joseph R. Vogel, president of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, and Goffredo Lembardo, president of Titanus Films of Italy, whereby the two companies will enter into an arrangement for the co-production of six features over the next three years, was reached here yesterday.
A laundry man of Bethpage, L.I., pleaded guilty in the Federal Court, Brooklyn, yesterday as a participant in a Chinese smuggling ring.

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 11 -President Ngo Dinh Diem today described his re-election by an overwhelming majority Sunday as a "victory of the whole people'' and a grave setback to Communist subversives who tried to wreck the elections by violence.

JERSEY CITY, April 11 -- Earnings of the Union Bag-Camp Paper Corporation continued to decline in the first quarter of 1961 but incoming orders have shown "a decided pick-up," Alexander Calder Jr., president, reported at the annual meeting here today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 11 -- The United Nations Security Council called on Israel today to forego the use of heavy military equipment in an Independence Day parade set for April 20 in Jerusalem.
The president of Pease Elliman, Inc., a leading real estate concern here, was indicted yesterday on charges of income tax evasion through fraudulent claims for entertainment and travel expenses.

Every source of information indicates that the United States is going to support an invasion of Cuba by counter-revolutionary forces. It may be too late to reconsider this established policy, but it is not too late to weigh its possible consequences.

If agricultural credit is any indication, farmers and ranchers can expect "improved" financial conditions this year. That was the gist of a semi-annual survey by the agricultural committee of the American Bankers Association, which polled almost 1,000 banks with agricultural loans outstanding.
LONDON, April 11 -- The stock market lost much of its impetus here today. The Financial Times industrial shares index declined for the first time since March 28, falling 1.5 points to 353.1.
Most of the features of flight into space that the Soviet astronaut experienced in orbit for the first time had been sampled by him and several other men in tests on earth.

QUEBEC, April 11 (Canadian Press) -- Price Brothers Company, Ltd. announced today an agreement to acquire 51 per cent of the common stock in Anglo - Newfoundland Development Company, Ltd., now held by Associated Newspapers of London, England.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 11 -- Decision in the case of Roosevelt Raceway v. Yonkers Raceway, Stanley Tanenbaum and Henri Levesque was reserved today by Justice Cortland A. Johnson of the New York State Supreme Court after he listened to arguments.

ALBANY, April 11 -- A higher-education program that will make $12,300,000 in new financial assistance available to college and university students in New York State this year was approved by Governor Rockefeller today.

A further price slide in high-grade corporate bonds took place yesterday as the second major refunding of the year -- a sale of $45,000,000 of New England Telephone and Telegraph bonds -- reached the market.

LEOPOLDVILLE the Congo, April 11 -- Plans for a political conference between Antoine Gizenga, head of the regime in Stanleyville, and two Cabinet ministers of the central Government appeared to be meeting growing, difficulties today.
The State Department has acted wisely in inviting Prince Souvanna Phouma to come to Washington.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 11 (AP) -- Bill Virdon hit a three-run homer with two out in the ninth inning today, to lift the world champion Pittsburgh Pirates to an 8-7 Victory over the San Francisco Giants.

The A.C. Gilbert Company, long noted for model trains will broaden its transportation toy line this fall with a new live of model airplanes, the company's annual meeting was told yesterday in New Haven, Conn. Gilbert also makes model highway systems, construction and science sets.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 11 -- New Jersey accused the National Civil War Centennial Commission of "pathetic mismanagement" tonight and asked that President Kennedy remove Maj. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant 3d as chairman.

MIAMI, April 11 -- Preparations for action against the Castro regime by Cuban exiles in the United States and Central America were reported tonight to be mounting steadily despite the reported indecision of the Kennedy Administration on how much to aid this undertaking.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 11 (AP). -- "The times in which we live demand a return to the word of God," the Rev. Thomas F. Zimmerman of Springfield, Mo., told the National Association of Evangelicals today.
MINEOLA, L.I., April 11 -- Eugene H. Nickerson of Roslyn was designated today as the Democratic candidate for County Executive by the executive committee of the Nassau Democratic County Committee.

CINCINNATI, April 11 (UPI) -- Jim O'Toole's four-hit pitching, backed up by a fourteen-hit attack that included two homers, enabled the Cincinnati Reds to open the season today with a 7-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
CHICAGO, April 11 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
A group of tenants charged in State Supreme Court yesterday that they had been evicted in 1959 to make way for a luxury apartment building that was still not under construction.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The financial savings of individual Americans declined last year to $11,200,000,000, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. Savings in 1960 compared with $13,000,000 in 1959 and $16,000,000,000 in 1958.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, April 12 -- Pierre Salinger, White House press secretary, announced early today that "American tracking stations have confirmed the fact that the Soviet Union has launched a satellite today."

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Air Force protested to Congress today that the Administration's decision to curtail development of the B-70 supersonic bomber would create an imbalance in the nation's future retaliatory power.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Vice President Johnson, Chairman of the President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity, met last week-end with a group of Negro leaders in Nashville, Tenn.
Jerry Lucas of Ohio State will head the men's and women's Amateur Athletic Union basketball squads that will report here Sunday before heading for a tour in the Soviet Union.
An April Fool's joke that backfired resulted in the ouster yesterday of Irwin Becker as editor in chief of an evening session newspaper at City College.
The City Council passed its own bill yesterday calling for the appointment of a commission to draft a new City Charter. The vote was 21 to 3.

The Chase Manhattan Bank has appointed two vice presidents in its personnel department, David Rockefeller, president, announced yesterday. The new vice presidents are Harold B. Coburn and Robert W. Scofield.
Taxpayers are getting their 1960 income returns in ahead of schedule here this year -- the deadline is next Monday -- but they appear to be having more trouble in figuring out the forms.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 3 to 5 points yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today "if we use our wits we shall not need to use our weapons."
PARIS, April 11 -- President de Gaulle presented today a mixture of incentives for Algerian rebel cooperation with France and renewed threats of the consequences of a "rupture."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 11 (AP) -- The satellite Echo I is proving more durable than scientists expected it would. In recent weeks the 100-foot balloon of thin plastic has actually been going up instead of down. Launched from Cape Canaveral on Aug. 12, the satellite was expected to last only a few weeks.
Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., a treatment school/for disturbed and delinquent boys, will be the beneficiary of the May 5 performance of "Carnival,." the musical, at the .Imperial Theatre.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 11 -- Twenty-four African states submitted today a comprehensive program for the long-term social and economic development of Africa under the auspices of the United Nations.

CEDAR GROVE, N.J., April 11 -- A mental patient fleeing from Essex County Hospital here today commandeered a car driven by a 32-year-old housewife and threatened the life of the woman's 2-year-old son during a fifteen-minute ride.

In the Union of South Africa Prime Minister Hendrik Verwoerd is undoubtedly more famous than Alan Paton. But in the rest of the world the champion of apartheid, who has announced that his country will cease to be a member of the British Commonwealth as of May 31, is not nearly so well known to many thousands of people as the wiry little novelist.

Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy's order putting five hundred additional foot patrolmen on the city's streets between 6 P.M. and 2 A.M. every night, because that is the tour when most crimes occur, seems to be an action of impeccable logic. If such deployment of police forces hasn't been customary before, we can only assume that shortage of men was so desperate that equal distribution of strength into three shifts seemed essential.
NEWARK, N.J. April 11 (AP) -- The G. Krueger Brewing Company of Newark, which lost $1,050,000 last year will close its plant here on May 1, the company announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Frank B. Ellis, the new Director of the Office of Civil and Defense Mobilization, is pressing a demand for a program almost tripled in size. He has indicated an adherence to the demand even if it means his resignation.
IN the three years that Barbara D'Arcy has been the designer of Bloomingdale's model rooms, she has attracted a devoted following among sophisticated New Yorkers.
Shirley Booth will star as Hazel, the outspoken maid of cartoon fame, on the National Broadcasting Company television network next season.

LOS ANGELES, April 11 -- The founder of the John Birch Society, Robert H.W. Welch Jr., addressed more than 6,000 persons tonight, the largest audience in the two-and-a-half-year history of the controversial right-wing political organization.
TODAY the team that will play for this country -- and, in fact for this continent, for Canada, Mexico and the West Indies are included -- will fly to Buenos Aires for the world championship matches.
John Canarina and Maurice Peress, two New Yorkers, and Seiji Ozawa of Japan will be next season's assistant conductors of the New York Philharmonic.
TRENTON, April 11 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court today upheld the reapportionment of the state Assembly's sixty seats according to the result of the recent census.

THE first ballplayer to emerge from the dugout runway on to the field yesterday morning was Roger Maris. The flags atop the Yankee Stadium ramparts crackled like bullwhips in the wind. Maris shivered.
EVANSTON, Ill, April 11 (AP) -- shareholders of American Photocopy Equipment Company approved today a three-for-one stock split. They increased the number of authorized shares from 3,000,000 to

LIKE many Jews during World War II, Moshe Landau lived a double life. However, the head of the three-man tribunal now hearing the Adolf Eichmann case in Jerusalem had fled Germany earlier and his dual role was played out in Palestine.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Today the First Lady created another first -- she gave a party for more than 200 women of the press. It was expressly intended to be a party rather than a press conference and it succeeded admirably.

BALTIMORE, April 11 -- The Los Angeles made a successful American League debut today. On the six-hit pitching of Eli Grba and the distance clouting of Ted Kluszewski and Bob Cerv, the new Pacific Coast team defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 7 -- 2.
Benton Bowles, Inc., has named Victor G. Bloede, Ken McAllister and Lee Rich as senior vice presidents. All three are directors of the agency.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 11 -- Attorney General Gideon Hausner of Israel offered today to examine some witnesses in the Eichmann case in West German courts.

Investors Diversified Services, Inc., announced yesterday a decline of 20 per cent in sales of the five mutual funds in its group in 1960. Net income of the company, the nation's largest mutual fund management and sales company, fell about 4 per cent in the year.
The pull over that is now the top news for spring is slated to become the backbone of any summer wardrobe.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., April 11 -- Two New York challengers appeared likely winners today in their stock proxy battle to gain representation on the board of National Theatres and Television, Inc.

Bank customers soon will be able to make deposits of currency, coin and checks and. obtain a receipt automatically using a new machine unveiled .. yesterday by Refiectone Elec' tronics, Inc., of. Stamford, 'Conn.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Chancellor Adenauer of West Germany arrived here tonight for his first meetings with President Kennedy.
GENEVA, April 11 -- The United States called on the Soviet Union today to make a constructive contribution to the nuclear test-ban talks by showing a willingness to give as well as take.
LONDON, April 11 -- The Government outlined today what it considered the financial and economic obligations of the nationalized industries.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) -- George Meany, president of the merged labor movement, opposed "buy American" campaigns today and said they could cause serious damage to United States workers and industries.

The New England Telephone and Telegraph Company accepted yesterday a bid of 100,181 for $45,000,000 of thirty-eight year, 4 5/8 per cent debentures, setting an interest cost to the utility of 4,615 per cent.

THE National Orchestral Association completed its sojourn at Hunter College last night. It said farewell to the auditorium by filling its great wide stage with talented young instrumentalists creating a happy clamor in Resphighi's "Roman Festivals."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 11 -- Former Secretary of State. Dean Acheson quoted the Roman poet Horace, the King James Bible, Shakespeare, the Oxford Dictionary and many legal authorities today in arguing for Cambodia before the International Court of Justice that Thailand was subject to the tribunal's jurisdiction.

Three New York University professors who believe that education can be as exciting as a detective thriller were named yesterday as 1961 winners of Great Teacher Awards, presented by the university's Alumni Federation.

Dr. Harold C. Urey, whose research helped, develop the atomic bomb, cited the danger of atomic war last night as a reason for the world's democracies to set up a Federal union with a strong central government.
Armed rebellion as means of achieving political independence was ruled out yesterday by Kenneth Kaunda, president of the United National Independence party of Northern Rhodesia.

BONN, Germany, April 11 -The Foreign Ministry announced today the conclusion of a "basic understanding" whereby West Germany would prepay $587,000,000 o fits $787,000,000 post-war debt to the United States.

The Clopay Corporation has announced the acquisition of the assets and business of the Duro-Gloss Rubber Company, New Haven, Conn., for an undisclosed amount of cash. Duro-Gloss makes calendered rubber coatings, saturated fabrics and plastic coated textiles.

Employment in the steel industry during February showed its first increase in a year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The number of hourly and salaried workers employed by steel producers rose to 484,286 from 477,543 in January.

Short covering of the May world sugar position raise prices yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. There was switching from May to September and October. The position goes off the board on Friday. Trade and commission house buying offset liquidation in the other positions. Most months hit new highs for the lives of the contracts.

An American edition of a novel by Yashar Kemal, called "Memed, My Hawk," is planned for June publication by Pantheon Books. The story is about the life of a Turkish rebel and peasant leader who becomes the avenger of his people against the oppression of the rich and powerful.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, April 11 (UPI) -- President Moise Tshombe blocked United Nations bank accounts in Katanga today.

The nation's largest brokerage concern, Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., has elected George J. Leness, an expert in underwriting, as its new president, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Leness, formerly a vice president and head of the underwriting department, succeeds Michael W. McCarthy, who has been named chairman and chief executive officer.
BOSTON, April 11 (UPI) -- The Kansas City Athletics opened their 1961 campaign today with a 5-2 triumph over the Boston Red Sox. Boston committed four errors.
Ismael (Milo) -- Valenzuela, a 26-year-Girl jockey who speaks Spanish in addition to English, continued to impress at Aqueduct yesterday in a language racegoers know best.

GENEVA, April 11 -- The Eichmann trial means infinitely more than the application of justice to a single miserable bureaucrat whose job was murdering 6,000,000 human beings. It is a reminder of the ghastly chasms into which any paths of prejudice may lead, whether based on color, creed or bone structure.

As one who has spent a considerable -- perhaps the happiest -- part of his professional life having direct responsibility for the presentation of evidence to New York County grand juries, may I take violent exception to your April 7 editorial "The Embattled Grand Jury."

DETROIT, April 11 (AP) -- Vic Power and Jim Piersall got four hits apiece during an eighteen-hit assault that carried the Cleveland Indians to a 9-5 triumph today over the Detroit Tigers. Jim Perry of the Indians allowed seven safeties and went the route in the American League opener for both teams.

The National Biscuit Company (Nabisco) and the Cream of Wheat Corporation announced yesterday that they had agreed in principle on a consolidation. It would involve an exchange of stock with a present market value of almost $30,000,000.

Baseball arbiters are human after all. Members of that much-maligned breed halted a game between New York University and City College after six and a half innings yesterday because the weather was unfit for either man or umpire.
The right of Board of Education to establish collective bargaining as a compulsory measure for teachers was challenged yesterday by the Joint Committee of Teacher Organizations.
BOSTON, April 11 -- The Prudential Insurance Company of America postponed further action today on its proposed $150,000,000 center in Back Bay.

BOSTON, April 11 (AP) -- Bill Russell, the man most responsible for establishing the Boston Celtics as professional basketball champions, enabled them to retain that distinction tonight. He was the leader in a 121-112 victory over the St. Louis Hawks.

Critics of a bill delaying the effective date for the installation of sprinkler systems in factories were assailed yesterday by State Senator Daniel G. Albert. He said they misrepresented the purposes and effect of the measure.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Like the Wright brothers' first flight a half century ago, the Soviet feat of placing the first man in space may ultimately add a new dimension to warfare in which space craft are used to win wars on earth.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Wednesday, April 12 -- The Attorney General of Israel, Gideon Hausner, resumed this morning his defense of the right of his country to try Adolf Eichmann for the murder of millions of Jews.
NEWARK, April 11 -- The Central Railroad of New Jersey today asked the state Division of Railroad Transportation for permission to abandon twenty-five non-rush-hour and weekend passenger trains.

Steven Hill, who plays Dr. Sigmund Freud in the new drama, "A Far Country," was stricken with a virus infection last evening. As a result, the producers decided to call of the performance just as the curtain was about to go up at the Music Box Theatre on West Forty-fifth Street.
American education today seems designed "to turn out people friendly enough to accept the insults to the human intelligence perpetrated by politicians and advertisers," declares a prominent educator.

CHICAGO, April 11 (AP) -- A surprisingly bullish Government report set off a burst of buying in soybean futures on the Board of Trade today and all contracts raced ahead with the old crop months hitting the limit of 10 cents for a single day.
WASHINGTON, Aril 11 -- Following are President Kennedy's remarks at the meeting at the White House today of the Presidents' Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity:

VIENNA, April 11 -- Dr. Alfons Gorbach, head of the People's party, was sworn in this morning as the fourth post-war Chancellor of Austria, in succession to Julius Raab, who resigned for reasons of ill health.
The biggest deficiency in the 1961-62 city budget is in education, the Citizens Committee for Children said yesterday.
LEVITTOWN, L.I., April 11 -~A 30-year-old mother of three children was arrested on charges of bookmaking here today by Nassau County vice squad detectives~

WASHINGTON, April 11 -Congress is showing some disenchantment with one of President Kennedy's proposals for easing the balance-of-payments problem -- a bill that would permit payment of higher interest rates on foreign government funds deposited in American banks.
WASHINGTON, April 11 The population center of the United States has moved again.

NORTH WILDWOOD, N.J., April 11 -- State Senator Walter H. Jones, candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor, combed the southern extremities of New Jersey today in his quest for voter support the April 18 primary election.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Government lawyers were urgently studying today the laws prohibiting activities, in the United States directed at the overthrow of a foreign government.

ALBANY, April 11 -- It seems pretty clear now that the Beaverkill in the form that it has been known to generations of trout fishermen is doomed by the automobile. The relocation of Highway 17 along its banks and across its bed is virtually certain to go through.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 11 -- The court procedure under which Adolf Eichmann is being tried was modeled largely after the British, just as is procedure in the United States. Applicable in theory is the British rule that a person can be charged with contempt of court for saying or writing things about an accused person that might be detrimental to his defense.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 (AP) -- Temple University conferred honorary degrees today on Sir John Cockcroft, Nobel Prize winner and Master of Churchill College, Cambridge; Dr. Hans Thirring, director emeritus of the Institute of Theoretical Physics, University of Vienna, and Dr. Fred L. Whipple, chairman of the Department of Astronomy, Harvard University.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Apr. 12 -- The Soviet Union announced today it had won the race to put a man into space. The official press agency, Tass, a man had orbited the earth in spaceship and had been brough back alive and safe.
PHILADELPHIA, April 11 (AP) -- Eleven electrical companies, convicted as conspirators in antitrust price-fixing and bid-rigging, were sued by the Government today for "millions" in damages.
LONDON, April 10 -- Britain will intensify her efforts to join the European Economic Community in the next few years, authoritative sources said today.
ALBANY, April 11 -- New York City received authorization today to establish a Public Defender system for representing needy persons in court.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The average factory employe worked longer hours and enjoyed a modest increase in pay last month, the Labor Department reported today.
PARIS, April 1l -- France proclaimed today a virtual strike against the United Nations.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 12 -- A judge today threw out garnishment proceedings against a pro-integration group seeking part of the salaries alleged to have been paid four four Negro ministers.
ALBANY, April 12 -- Governor Rockefeller moved today to speed construction of urban renewal projects in the state and reduce the ultimate cost of such programs.

THE first tape recordings of the trial of Adolf Eichmann, which were shown on American television stations yesterday, reflected alert and competent camera work for the most part. There's no gainsaying that the sustained visual coverage affords a very real sense of presence at the courtroom drama in Jerusalem.

Alfred Ryder, who is making his directorial debut with "A Far Country," the drama about Sigmund Freud and the origin of psychoanalysis, became one of its stars at yesterday's matinee. Mr. Ryder, who has been an actor for thirty years, stepped into the role of Freud after Steven Hill became ill.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., April 12 -- Robert H.W. Welch Jr., leader of the controversial John Birch Society, said tonight he was opposed to Chief Justice Earl Warren because "he has taken the lead in the drive to convert this country into a democracy."
The year 1960 may have been one of recession for many businesses and people, but this is not apparent to the income tax collectors at 484 Lexington Avenue.

An executive of American Export Lines yesterday vigorously disputed a portrayal of his company as a villainous Goliath of the steamship industry.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI) -- The Senate passed and sent to the House today legislation authorizing $20,000,000 in Federal grants to fight juvenile delinquency.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 12 (UPI) -- The life of a space man may sound glamorous, but whirling through an orbit around earth in a small capsule -- Russian or American -- shapes up as anything but a joyride.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- A House Education and Labor subcommittee added provisions for construction grants of $900,000,000 today to the Administration's bill to aid higher education.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 15 -- The forty-ninth annual meeting of the Western Petroleum Refiners Association ended here this week, with a strong probability that this was the last session of the organization under its present name.

Fordham's baseball team beat Brooklyn College, 11 -- 1, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference game at Roosevelt Field, Brooklyn, yesterday. The game was called because of darkness at the end of the eighth inning.

John Mitchell, the coffee house owner who touched off the current investigation of alleged pay-offs by Greenwich Village cafe owners to policemen and other city employes, went to Police Headquarters yesterday to "cooperate fully" in the inquiry.

THIS has been a fine week for Handelians. On Monday night the Cantata Singers did "Belshazzar," one of the dramatic oratorios written at the peak of Handel's powers. And last night at Town Hall a group of devoted artists and citizens presented his "Esther," which was the oratorio that began the great series.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 12 (UPI) -- Circuit Judge Eugene Carter dismissed disorderly conduct charges today against a white college professor who participated in an integrated luncheon here in March, 1960.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 12 (UPI) -- The Air Force fired its new Blue Scout II rocket nearly 1,200 miles into space today to map nuclear radiation, but lost a ninety-pound instrument capsule ten hours later in the Atlantic.
CHICAGO, April 12 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follow:
A public offering of $40,000,000 of 5 1/4 per cent debentures of Spiegel, Inc., due April 1, 1983, is being made today by Wertheim Co. and associates.

TUNIS, April 12 -- The reopening of Algerian peace talks, stalled prior to their scheduled start last week, was said today to depend now on results of secret contacts in Switzerland.

DARIEN, Conn., April 12 -- His Highness Jaya Chamaraja Wadiyar, Maharaja of Mysore, finally made it to Darien this afternoon, but he saw little of the Connecticut town he had heard so much about at home in India since 1955.

Price fluctuations in the market for high-grade debt investments moved within narrow limits yesterday.
LONDON, April 12 -- Losses outnumbered gains in most sections of the stock market here today. As the market receded from its recent peaks, considerable profit taking followed.

TRENTON, April 12 -- Charles R. Howell, New Jersey Banking Commissioner, today approved a plan whereby safe drivers in the state will pay less for insurance coverage and accident-prone motorists will pay more.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI) -- The Federal Reserve Board has refused to allow a Columbus, Ohio, bank holding company to acquire control of the Hilliard Bank in the Columbus suburb of Hilliards.

GLOUCESTER CITY, N.J., April 12 -- At noon tomorrow, beneath a sycamore tree on the banks of the Delaware River, the "Gloucester tenth" of the Proprietors of West Jersey will convene, as they have each April 13 since 1688.

" Reconsiderations," the latest book by Arnold J. Toynbee, will be published by Oxford University Press on May 4. Issued as the twelfth volume in the British historian's "A Study of History," the book of almost 800 pages is devoted mainly to the author's answers to criticisms of his work since the first three volumes of the series appeared in 1934.

NEW ORLEANS, April 12. -- The Chicago Tribune filed a brief in the United States Court of Appeals here today asking the dismissal of libel suits brought against The New York Times in Birmingham, Ala. The suits grew out of articles on racial conditions there.

Although the City University of New York became a legal reality only on Tuesday, officials started work yesterday on transforming the former municipal college system into a full-fledged university.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 5 to 13 points (25 to 65 cents a bale) yesterday.
Montgomery Ward Co. announced yesterday that its sales in the four weeks ended on April 5 were $88,157,404, an increase of 10.2 per cent above the volume of $79,993,473 in the 1960 period.
Sir Winston Churchill received an enthusiastic, if impromptu, harbor welcome here yesterday morning as he arrived for a private visit of less than a day.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The United States Government gave Chancellor Adenauer today a new pledge to stand firm on Western rights in West Berlin and to respond promptly to any attack on the city.

A scheduled television debate between Norman Cousins and Leo Cherne has been canceled by the National Broadcasting Company. Dealing with relations between the United States and the Soviet Union, the debate had been taped March 25 and was to be televised Saturday evening on "The Nation's Future."

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- President Kennedy gave a firm pledge today that the United States armed forces would not intervene in Cuba "under any conditions" to help bring about the downfall of Premier Fidel Castro.
A Bronx grand jury that has been investigating a tow-car racket indicted nine persons yesterday on misdemeanor charges of illegally soliciting business.

Electric power production rose to 14,182,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended last Saturday from 14,163,000,000 kilowatt-hours the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

Former-Senator Herbert H. Lehman yesterday received the George Washington High School citizenship award for distinguished service to state and country. The award is presented annually by the student body.

ROME, April 12 -- News of the successful Russian space flight was heralded here today in banner headlines. Romans snapped up the papers, emptying kiosks in a matter of minutes, then stood about discussing the event.

The International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday another record in sales and earnings for the first quarter of 1961.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Treasury sold $2,000,000,000 of one-year bills today at discount rates averaging 2.827 per cent. That was more than the cost of a smaller issue sold three months ago, but substantially less than the cost of three other one-year issues sold in the last twelve months.

The New York Shakespeare Festival plans to open its season in a temporary theatre in Central Park this summer because completion of the new amphitheatre there has been delayed. The opening has been postponed from June 29 to July 5.

Loew's Theatres, Inc., which is building two of the three major hotels under construction in Manhattan, announced plans yesterday for two smaller hotels on Eighth Avenue.
Truckers in the garment center yesterday won a two-hour extension of parking privileges from Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley.
A group of investor-owned utilities plans to build a 4,000-mile network of extra-high-voltage transmission line linking an eight-state area in the Southwest.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 12 (AP) -- The Redstone rocket that the United States had hoped would boost the first man into space stands on a launching pad here. The Russians beat its firing date by at least two weeks.

It cannot be said that the public is waiting breathlessly to see whether Michael H. Prendergast, the state Democratic chairman, is unseated by the Kennedy Administration; but the contest is still of considerable political interest.
HAVANA, April 12 -- Maj. Raul Castro, Armed Forces Minister, authorized sugar workers today to arrest, try, sentence and execute any saboteur caught in the mills or cane cooperatives.

KATONAH, N.Y., April 12 -- Seventy-five years ago, when she was 9 years old, Josephine Van Tassel took down Louisa M. Alcott's "Little Men" from the shelves of the Katonah Library and read it to her younger sister, Margery, 7.

The new office of the Chief Medical Examiner, a modern, gray and blue building dedicated more to the living than to the dead, officially became the headquarters of Dr. Milton Helpern and his staff yesterday.

YONKERS, April 12 -- The withdrawal this morning of Hoot Frost cut the starting field for tomorrow's night Gotham Trot at Yonkers Raceway to an even dozen. Del Miller, who had planned to drive the Canadian Armstrong Brothers' trotter, declared the 4-year-old bay horse from the mile-and-a-quarter event after he had been unable to arrange for air transportation from California.
MOSCOW, April 12 -- Yuri Alekseyevich Gagarin conquered Moscow today in one hour and forty-eight minutes.

Cottonseed oil declined sharply in active trading yesterday on the New York Produce Exchange. Closing prices tumbled 26 to 33 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). The volume was 1,093 tank cars, 60,000 pounds to a car, the third largest this year.

" Shalom" (the Hebrew word for peace) is the title of the first Broadway musical dealing with contemporary Israel. Robert Weede and Molly Picon will be starred in the show, written by Don Appell (book) and Jerry Herman (music and lyrics).

We welcome the news, as reported in The Times of April 4, that the city is planning to take full advantage of a broadened urban renewal program as soon as one is enacted by Congress. However, no mention is made of plans to include decent housing for the low-income group.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 12 -- A relatively simple blood test promises to provide man for the first time with a precise way to determine what he should eat for optimal health.

NEWARK, April 12 (AP) -- Vincent J. Murphy, secretary-treasurer of the New Jersey American Federation of Labor, today was appointed president of the labor organization to succeed the late Louis P. Marciante.

FEW women have mastered the art of giving orders to a man and having him like it, especially if the man is a sensitive opera singer. Carolyn Lockwood has. Tact and talent have enabled her at 28 years of age, to carve a career in the tempestuous, Europe-dominated world of opera where nothing is as rare as an American director except an American woman director.
The deep ocean drilling ship Cuss I has completed its historic test boring into the Pacific Ocean floor off Guadalupe Island, the National Science Foundation announced yesterday.
Thanks to a baseball executive, Dan Topping of the New York Yankees, many of the scheduling difficulties of the expanded National Football League have been solved.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Interunion Working Committee set up to negotiate a federation of printing, paper, and related trade unions wound up its second two-day meeting here.
TURIN, Italy, April 12 -- Communist and Socialist unions at the Fiat auto works gained in strength today as 74,000 workers and administrative personnel voted during the annual shop steward elections.
CHICAGO, April 12 (AP) -- Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker predicted a resurgence in conservatism in the United States and the ultimate repeal of the income tax tonight.

One baseball after another exploded off Yankee bats and disappeared into the deeper nooks and crannies of the Stadium yesterday. They landed about twenty hours too late, however, to alter the Bombers' won-lost record of 0 -- 1.
A LOOSE-LIMBED youngster who sprawls over the furniture and makes himself at home wherever he goes is the picture of mental health, a psychologist observed recently.

Fred Goldberg has been named executive director of advertising, publicity and exploitation for United Artists Corporation, the company announced yesterday. He replaces Roger H. Lewis, whose resignation takes effect June 1.

Record sales and earnings of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., in the twenty-six weeks ended on Jan. 28 lifted the results for the fifty-two-week period above those of the correspond ing period a year earlier, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday.
The consuls general or their representatives of twelve Latin-America countries were received at City Hall yesterday by Acting Mayor Abe Stark.
Frank A. Kelly, a vice president of the Fund for the Republic, proposed last night that "the American people should give to the Russian people a great work of art depicting man's climb to the stars."
A consultant to the Legislature criticized the lawmakers last night for failing to adopt a bill to revise and simplify the state's Civil Practice Act.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 12 -- The United States insisted today that all matters connected with Palestine Arab refugees, not their property rights alone, be considered in the General Assembly next fall.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Kennedy Administration is preparing an omnibus farm bill that would give producers and the Secretary of Agriculture the major role in developing price-support and production-control programs.
Art that flourished thousands of years ago on rocks in a once-verdant and peopled Sahara will be shown in reproduced form in this country today at Columbia University's Casa Italiana.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 5:

The eighteenth anniversary of the Warsaw Ghetto uprising against Nazi troops was observed here yesterday with a ceremony in Times Square and memorial Services at United Hias Service, the Jewish migration agency.
AN enterprising Soviet Tass agency reporter has turned up the fact that there are about 1,200 persons in the Moscow area named Gagarin.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- President Kennedy said today that his Administration was "considering what longer-range steps could be taken" to ease the problem of unemployment, which is expected to last beyond recovery from the recession.

The successful launching by Soviet scientists of a man into space and his safe return after orbiting the earth in eighty-nine minutes will be hailed as one of the great advances in the story of man's age-old quest to tame the forces of nature. It marks the crowning achievement so far in space technology, and provides the most dramatic evidence of Soviet leadership in the field of powerful rocket engines.
PHILADELPHIA, Pa. April 12 (UPI) -- Stockholders of Philadelphia Electric Company approved today a proposed two-for-one split of common stock.

MASPALOMAS, Canary Islands, April 6 -- On a sunny headland here, twenty-four United States scientists are hurrying preparations for the day when a capsule bearing an American is expected to hurtle 100 miles over their heads at more than 18,000 miles an hour.
MOSCOW, April 12 -- Man's first flight into space took a 27-year-old Russian on a 108-minute single spin around earth today at a speed of more than 17,000 miles an hour.
Tin prices on the London Metal Exchange rose sharply yesterday to their highest level since April, 1953, as buyers sought to keep pace with the recent boom in the Singapore market.

PARIS, April 12 -- A careful analysis of President de Gaulle's statements yesterday on Algeria does not support the view, expressed in some quarters here and abroad, that he adopted a "hard" line likely to block negotiations with the rebels.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 (UPI) -- A Federal District Court was requested today to open the records of five grand juries that indicted twenty-nine electrical companies on charges of price-fixing and bid-rigging charges.
HAMPTON, Va., April 12 (AP) -- The three United States astronauts in final training for a space flight voiced disappointment today that a Russian had beaten them into orbit.
HAVANA, April 12 -- The Cuban Government's press, radio and television services devoted today to the "great triumph" of the Soviet Union over the United States by putting a man into space.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., April 12 (AP) -- Gov. S. Ernest Vandiver said today that the average man had reason to remember Franklin Delano Roosevelt "every day of his life for the things he did for the average American."

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Discovery of a new chemical element, which may have been a short-lived "dinosaur" of matter at the creation of the universe, was announced today by the Atomic Energy Commission.

Earnings for General Cable Corporation in the first quarter should cover the dividend of 50 cents a share, J.R. MacDonald, chairman and president, told the annual meeting at Perth Amboy, N.J., yesterday. Last year the company cleared 74 cents a share in the first quarter.

There was a feeling among those at the International Kennel Club show in Chicago last week-end that the event finally was ready to take its place among the truly large shows of yesteryear. There were 2,917 dogs, the first time the competition had neared the 3,000-dog level. Laurence Alden Horswell o! East Elmhurst, Queens, a specialist in dachshunds and a close dog-show observer, summed up the sit uation.

PERSONS 65 and older are twice as likely to be hospitalized as younger persons, according to Dr. Clement Martin, medical director of the Continental Casualty Company. Once they are confined in a hospital, they are likely to be there twice as long as the average younger person.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- If the dictators of the great Communist states had not continuously belied their professions of peaceful intent by belligerent words and acts against the non-Communist nations and their free institutions, the space-flight around the earth by a Russian Air Force major would have been bailed with unmixed joy by everyone.
A group of investors headed by Louis C. Lerner, Boston financier, has bought a major stock interest in the Maxson Electronics Corporation in recent months.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The Justice Department today filed a civil anti-trust action at Providence, R.I., to break up the association of four concerns described as doing the bulk of the nation's central fire and burglar alarm business.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Three months of furious activity and image-building have strengthened President Kennedy's personal popularity with the voters but have generated little or no new support for his domestic programs.
MOSCOW, April 13 -- Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin described his flight into space in ecstatic terms today.

LISBON, April 13 (AP) -- All Portuguese security and army forces were ordered to stand by tonight in a "state of prevention." Under this order, all troops are restricted to their barracks, but there are no restrictions on civilians.

Events today: "Aida," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Zino Francescatti, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; Ronald Rogers, pianist, and George Shirley, tenor, presented by Concert Artists Guild, Town Hall, 5:15; Concert of Music by Miriam Gideon, Carnegie Recital Hall, 6; Glee Club Concert by Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, Town Hall, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Senate Finance Committee cleared the nomination of Stanley S. Surrey as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Tax Policy today after three weeks of delay. The Senate confirmed him almost immediately.

Once again the United Nations debates ways and means of redeeming a pledge first made in substance by the victors of the last World War, adopted in its present form by the General Assembly as far back as 1947 and maintained at the cost of another sanguinary if inconclusive war. This pledge calls for the creation of a "unified, independent and democratic Korea" by means of free elections under U.N. auspices.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 13 (AP) -- The New York Times took three pending libel suits to Federal Court today. An attorney in one of the suits immediately filed a motion to remand it to state court.

The development of a new oral contraceptive drug said to suppress heat in female dogs without destroying their ability to bear healthy litters was announced yesterday by the Upjohn Company's veterinary division.

PARIS, April 13 -- Ahmed Balafrej, special Moroccan Ambassador, appealed to President de Gaulle today to free five imprisoned Algerian ministers as "a gesture that would be appreciated by the Algerian Provisional Government."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 13 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold informed West Germany today that use of a German plane for transporting arms to the Congo was a violation of United Nations resolutions.

RACINE, Wis., April 13 -- William J. Grede, member of the council of the John Birch Society, corrected an impression today that as a member of the board of directors of the National Association of Manufacturers he had voted for the censure of the Birch group.
In Topics of April 6 you give several reasons for holding the ceremonies commemorating the opening of the Civil War near the monument to Robert Gould Shaw on Boston Common.
LONDON, April 13 -- Paddy Chayevsky's "The Tenth Man" divided drama critics at its opening at the Comedy Theatre here tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 13 -- Drafting difficulties tonight held up the completion of a proposed Latin-American resolution taking a neutral stand on the dispute between the United States and Cuba.

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 13 (UPI) -- Charlie Sifford, who today becomes the first Negro ever to play in a Professional Golfers Association tournament in the South, shot a 68 to take the first-round lead in the $22,500 Greater Greensboro golf tournament.
MOSCOW, April 13 (UPI) -- A technically forbidden "cult of personality" was being built up today around Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin, who was the first man to orbit the earth.

The Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company is in the public capital market today, seeking about $50,000,000 through a sale of $25,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent sinking fund debentures and 250,000 shares of 3 per cent convertible preference stock.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) April 13 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion today made Israel's compliance with a Security Council resolution for the withdrawal of heavy armament from her scheduled Independence Day parade conditional upon Jordan's compliance with the requirement giving Jews free access to the holy plates in Jerusalem.
Even those Democrats on Manhattan's West Side who thrive on primary fights are looking in disbelief at the free-for-all scramble under way there for a City Council nomination.

It is fortunate for us, as we watch the progress of the Cuban counter-revolution, that President Kennedy is a student of history. Otherwise he might not know what a slim chance this exile movement has for success in bringing to their fellow Cubans the "freedom, democracy and social justice" they vow will follow their invasion.
When is a commuter not a commuter?
RICHMOND, Va., April 13 -- President Kennedy and his program apparently hold greater appeal in the South today than at the time of his election.
GENEVA, April 13 -- The Soviet Union warned today that the United States proposal to test the possibility of concealing underground atomic explosions could lead to a new nuclear arms race.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The State Department reported today that there had been a slight increase in the Soviet airlift of arms to rebel forces in Laos during the last few days.

JACKSON, Miss., April 13 -The Board of Trustees of St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Private Day School has voted to remove the rector, the Rev. Edward H. Harrison, from the board because he attended a racially integrated meeting in his parish house. The school has only white pupils.

To Yankee worshippers, yesterday's rainstorm was tantamount to a conspiracy hatched by the weatherman in league with the Minnesota Twins to save the erstwhile Washington Senators from a well-deserved comeuppance.

Carnegie Hall, the world-famous home of musical and artistic endeavor, housed an entirely new audience yesterday -- the annual meeting of stockholders of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation. It was the first time in the seventy-year-history of Carnegie Hall that it had been used as such a forum.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Peace Corps is getting applications from volunteers at the rate of 250 a day.
Although marooned by bad weather in the Hudson River most of the day, Sir Winston Churchill expressed his delight yesterday over a "most pleasant surprise."

VENICE, Italy, April 13 -- Stench bombs were released and the police were called to maintain order in one of the most violent musical demonstrations of post-war Italy. It occurred tonight during the world premiere of Luigi Nono's "Intolleranza 1960" at the Teatro Fenice.
ALBANY, April 13 -- Racial and religious discrimination in the sale or rental of much of the state's private housing was outlawed today for the first time on a state-wide basis.
The Department of Marine and Aviation began a search yesterday for a steamship line in need of a pier. It rents at $157,526.40 a year.

Industrial unions with 6,000,000 members designated a committee yesterday to demand swift action by merged labor to end interunion warfare. The unions also authorized plans for independent political and organizational activities under the industrial union banner.
THREE landscape painters, who cling with different kinds and degrees of tenacity to the particular visual experiences that have stimulated them, are having exhibitions this week.

ROME, N.Y., April 13 (AP) -- A State Supreme Court jury that had deliberated since Tuesday found six Utica men guilty tonight of perjury or attempting to incite perjury in connection with a state investigation of vice in Utica. The trial began Jan. 16.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 13 -- A United Nations spokesman charged today that a seven-ton arms shipment flown to the Congo's Katanga Province by a German charter plane Monday had originated in Brussels.

The State Commission Against Discrimination voted unanimously yesterday to appeal a State Supreme Court decision barring it from investigating charges of discrimination in institutions under the jurisdiction of the Board of Higher Education.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 13 -- The wailing of sirens awakened Jerusalem this morning. The sirens signaled the beginning of the Day of the Holocaust, commemorating the victims of Nazi persecution. The trial of Adolf Eichmann had been recessed until tomorrow because of it.
Alexander Aldrich, director of the state Division for Youth, has set up a research unit to test the usefulness of new youth programs, he told the Women's City Club yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -Representative Francis E. Walter introduced in the House today new legislation that would revise in some respects this country's immigration policies.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany said today that it appeared Adolf Eichmann "was the biggest of the murderers." He said Israel's reasons for trying Eichmann were "fully understandable."
LOS ANGELES, April 13 -- Richard M. Nixon is setting up an intensive national speaking tour next month as an apparent riposte to antagonists of his titular leadership of the Republican party.

CINCINNATI, April 13 (AP) -- Jerry Lynch, who specializes in pinch hits, belted a homer in the eighth inning today. The three-run wallop brought the Cincinnati Reds a 5-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
Yesterday's entry of the new one-year Treasury bills failed to impart to the market for short-dated debt securities the activity that had been expected.

MIAMI, April 3 -- Cuban rebel leaders in Florida do not believe that President Kennedy's opposition to an invasion from the United States against Premier Fidel Castro will affect their military preparations in this country.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -Department store sales in the nation in the week ended last Saturday were 16 per cent below the level of a year earlier.
Today is "C" day -- conversion day -- in the Kirby-Murchison fight for control of the Alleghany Corporation, the big holding company.
OCEAN CITY, N.J., April 13 -- James P. Mitchell called on State Senator Walter H. Jones tonight to answer conflict-of-interest charges made against him.

ONCE upon a time the various sports seasons were sharply defined, each remaining circumspectly within its duly allotted chronological brackets. But with the expansion of leagues, schedules or both, the overlapping becomes more acute with every passing year.
The best highway-accident record in the state's history was compiled last year, and the trend is continuing, the Motor Vehicle Commissioner, William S. Hults, said yesterday.
Mrs. Edison Dick was sworn in yesterday as the United States representative on the Social Commission of the United Nations Economic and Social Council.
PHYLLIS GOLDMAN, who married a fat man in 1951, is looking forward to celebrating her tenth anniversary this summer with a thin man.

Heavy commission house selling, hedging, belated profit taking and stop-loss selling dropped cocoa futures to the lows of the day early in the session yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Trading was influenced by rumors that German first-quarter grindings were lower than last year.
STAMFORD, Conn., April 13 -- In an appropriately winterlike setting, an engineering concern demonstrated today the prototype of a snow-melting machine it intends to market.

Garden enthusiasts of the city have received a reminder from Air Pollution Control Commissioner Benline not to burn garden debris during their spring clean-up work. Such burning, as the Commissioner says, is against the law. And the resulting smoke is a respiratory irritant that is especially harmful to all bronchitis, asthma and hay fever sufferers.
LUANDA, Angola, April 13 (Reuters) -- The Angola Defense Council called up Angola military reservists today as the territory mobilized to suppress a wave of anti-white violence.

LONDON, April 13 -- Viscount Stansgate, who was a Member of Parliament as Anthony Wedgwood Benn, was denied permission to appear as a petitioner at the Bar of the House of Commons today to plead against his becoming a peer.

The State Banking Board turned down yesterday the proposal of the Bankers Trust Company to acquire the County Trust Company of White Plains through a new holding company. Bankers Trust is the sixth largest bank in New York City.
A sociologist reported last night that 2,567 persons had appealed for help in obtaining a sterilization operation in the twelve-month period between Nov. 1, 1959, and Oct. 31, 1960.
A memorial service for the 6,000,000 Jews who died in the Hitler regime was held last night under the auspices of the Labor Zionist movement at Farband House, 575 Avenue of the Americas.
RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, April 12 -- A family dispute between King Saud and Crown Prince Faisal is developing into a national political quarrel.

Pink was the motif in the Terrace Room of the Plaza last night for the Cherry Blossom Ball for the benefit of the Judson Health Center. Cherry blossomes and dogwood decorated the room and pink candles and pink cloths were used on the tables.
Relative humidity may be a key factor in the epidemic spread of virus diseases such as influenza, a study suggests.

FLORENCE, Italy, April 13 (AP) -- The Soviet Union unveiled today a movie of the space dogs Belka and Strelka and is expected to follow with one to prove that Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin made man's first orbital flight.

MOBILE, Ala., April 13 (UPI) -- The Justice Department filed suit today against the Dallas County Board of Registrars and the State of Alabama, charging discrimination against prospective Negro voters.

One of the curious phenomena of our times is the way a large segment of world opinion has come to accept as a matter of course the efforts of Communist states to destroy governments to which they are hostile by the export of terrorism and other forms of subversive aggression.
CHICAGO, April 13 -- A leader in the Louisiana branch of the John Birch Society said today he would assemble scattered conservative groups into a national party for the 1964 Presidential campaign.

Three new squadrons were approved and one was dropped at the meeting this week at the Hotel Astor of the United States Power Squadron's governing board. This changed the number of units in pleasure boating's largest body to 304 squadrons and a membership of approximately 55,000 amateur mariners.
Lennen Newell, Inc., has appointed Curtis Berrien a senior vice president and creative director of the agency, effective May 1.
An advance contingent of the world's biggest floating tennis tournament -- Jack Kramer's professional troupe -- returned to New York yesterday without racquets.

We would have thought that New York had a sufficiency of political parties, Republican, Democratic and Liberal. Apparently the leaders of unions with 1,000,000 members here feel otherwise, or at least have their doubts. They have set up a fifteen-man committee to study the formation of an independent political party for municipal, state and national elections.
