CASTELSARRASIN, France, April 13 -- President de Gaulle indicated today that the Algerian rebel Provisional Government would play a major role in building the "new Algeria" and said France's help could be had if desired.
SEOUL, Korea, April 13 -- Premier John M. Chang called on Communist North Korea today to accept the competence and authority of the United Nations to deal with the question of Korean unification.

Tickets are still available for the theatre party to "Carnival," at the Imperial Theatre on April 25 for the benefit of the Child Development Center. They may be obtained from Mrs. Gillette Boland at 232 East Sixty-second Street.
A wind-driven northeast rainstorm accompanied by sleet and snow battered the metropolitan area yesterday and stirred up heavy seas off the New England coast.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- President Kennedy gave Congress today an outline of his ideas for improving the Federal regulatory agencies. He put special emphasis on reform of the Federal Power Commission, which regulates natural gas prices.

Under the law, taxpayers are expected to keep up to date on their income tax payments and for most wage earners withholding assures that they do. But, for those who do fall behind, both the Federal and New York State governments provide a system of quarterly payments.
A RICH tapestry of American history was unfolded last night in a vividly dramatic and informative program entitled "Carl Sandburg at Gettysburg" over the Columbia Broadcasting System.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 13 -- Plans to hold a major inter-American economic conference by July to put President Kennedy's Alliance for Progress in operation have been virtually completed here.

Roosevelt Raceway withdrew its Supreme Court application yesterday for a temporary injunction to prevent the 5-yearold French-bred mare Masina from trotting at rival Yonkers Raceway. Masina is the European champion.
THE bidding of this hand was unusual, Seldom does a player jump to game in a four-card suit or suppress six-card support for his partner's suit, as South did in this case.

A $1,075,000 damage suit brought by Local 824 of the International Longshoremen's Association against the Waterfront Commission, the New York Shipping Association, American Export Lines and others was dismissed yesterday by the State Supreme Court on technical grounds.
The three-year-old tax-fraud indictment against Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. was dismissed yesterday in Federal Court on a motion by the Government.

Stocks moved indecisively yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. When the day had ended The New York Times and Dow, Jones Co. averages were up and Standard Poor's Corporation's index down. Moreover, more stocks fell than rose.
"LIFE can be much fuller with the children along," according to a much-traveled mother of two young-daughters who refused to accept the idea that traveling with children is next to impossible.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- It will cost more to mail letters and postal cards to foreign countries beginning July 1.
In a letter published on March 19, Ralph H. Lane refers to the case of Holland in arguing against equality of aid to public and private schools.
Stormy weather cut the number of visits made yesterday to Internal Revenue offices by the Government's favorite customers -- taxpayers.
AMONG the state-side Americans immersed in the cultural life of Puerto Rico, take appropriate notice of Elmer Adler and Barry Yellen.

Every now and then some American gets up and says that the United States is a Republic and not, as some suppose, a democracy. The latest person to come up with this remarkable discovery is Robert H.W. Welch Jr., head of the John Birch Society, who says that Chief Justice Earl Warren "has taken the lead in the drive to convert this country into a democracy."
BALTIMORE, April 13 -- A vaulted fabricating shop in the Sparrows Point Shipyard of the Bethlehem Steel Company, near here, was the scene today of a rare gesture in Pan-Americanism.

The property at the southwest corner of Second Avenue and Sixty-third Street has been leased by Beeksmad, Inc., Violeta Smadbeck, president, to the Carlyle Construction Corporation, Irving Dimson, president. Carlyle plans to erect a twenty-one-story building with 189 apartments containing two to six rooms on the site.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., April 13 -- The leader of the John Birch Society, after a four-day visit to southern California, has left mixed reactions.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 13 -- The primordial genetic material in sperm has been isolated intact for the first time, the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology was informed today.

DALLAS, April 13 (UPI) -- Sandra Haynie, a 17-year-old Fort Worth golfer, playing in only her third open tournament for money, took the first-round lead in buffeting winds today in the Civitan women's open tournament. She shot a two-over-par 73.

THERE is an undercover story at Macy's centering on a synthetic rubber fiber called spandex. Since its debut two years ago, an increasing number of women are coming to know it under a number of brand names, according to Matilda Glaser, the store's girdle and bra buyer.
A group of applicants for a proposed Greenwich Village cooperative took a newspaper advertisement yesterday to express disapproval of Mayor Wagner's proposed West Village urban renewal project.
The Port of New York Authority is planning the sale of $35,000,000 of consolidated revenue bonds on May 3.
ALBANY, April 13 -- Professional teachers' organizations in the state were freed today from the same financial supervision as labor unions are now subject to.
Aaron Wagman, one of two gamblers arrested last month on charges of bribing basketball players, was indicted here yesterday for bribing a detective.

Salavador Dali dripped sticky water and temperament all over his pinstripe blue suit and the floor of an elegant suite in Hampshire House yesterday. He was demonstrating his new stage props made of evanescent soap bubbles.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -Rail and truck freight loadings last week both were down from year-ago levels. Rail loadings were unchanged from the preceding week of this year and truck loadings were up slightly.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- President Kennedy and Chancellor Adenauer ended two days of meetings with a joint pledge today to strengthen the military defenses of the West and to work for closer economic cooperation in the Atlantic community.

A relocated "Bus Stop" will make its debut next fall over the American Broadcasting Company television network. The setting of the William Inge play was a small town in Kansas, but A.B.C.'s version will push westward to Sunrise, Colo.
TEL AVIV, Israel, April 13 -- The suspension of the Seafarers Union of North America by the International Transport Workers Union was confirmed today by Peter De Vries, the general secretary.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) -- A nursery school has been set up in the White House for 3-year-old Caroline Kennedy and her friends. The President's daughter and about ten of her playmates started the "play group" this week.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 (AP) -- Jim Duffalo a rookie, pitched and batted the San Francisco Giants to a 6-5 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates in twelve innings of seesaw baseball today.
Mayor Wagner charged yesterday that a taxpayer's suit contesting the validity of his new Charter Revision Commission had been instigated by Carmine G. De Sapio, leader of Tammany.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- In his press conference yesterday President Kennedy clarified but did not end the debate within his Administration about how far to go in helping the Cuban refugees overthrow the Castro Government.
CHICAGO, April 13 (UPI) -- The report on Chicago election irregularities was filed in criminal court todal, but not enough errors were found to change the winners.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare issued today a study to be used in the drive for passage of President Kennedy's aid-to-education program.

TORONTO, April 13 (Canadian Press) -- D. W., Ambridge, )resident of Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., said today production of newsprint for the first three months of 1961 was 5.9 per cent below the 1960 level.
Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City declined $79,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
QUANTICO, Va., April 13 (AP) -- Ed Collymore, a former Villanova sprinter, won the 100 and 220-yard dashes today and his Quantico team dominated the all-Marine track and field championships.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These rates do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.
PEIPING, April 13 (Reuters) -- Chuang Tse-Jung, a 19-year-old Peiping student, upset Ichiro Ogimura of Japan, a former champion, in the world table tennis tournament today.

CARACAS, April 13 -- The Venezuelan Treasury will show a deficit equivalent to about $120,000,000 in United States money at the end of this fiscal year in July, the Ministry of Finance announced here today. However, if loans received during the period were to be added, the deficit would amount to $400,000,000, it was noted.
City employe organizations thanked the Board of Estimate yesterday for pay increases and pension benefits contemplated in the new budget, but they said these were not enough.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 20 to 35 cents a bale yesterday.

The junior and senior memberships of the New York Chapter of the American-Scandinavian Foundation will celebrate the foundation's fiftieth anniversary with a dance at the Savoy-Hilton this evening. Proceeds will go to the scholarship fund of the foundation.

For the first time in many years the Police Department radio cars have taken on a new look. On each of the front doors the vehicles carry a "reflectorized" police shield for added effectiveness on night patrols and at roadblocks.
Oliver H. Payne, a prominent Wall Street lawyer and executive, was fatally stricken by a heart attack as he was driving with his wife on Second Avenue last night.

LISBON, Portugal, April 13 Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar took over the Defense Ministry in a Cabinet shuffle today. He will thus have direct control of defense measures in Angola, the West African territory where Portuguese rule is under armed attack by African nationalists.

Net sales of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation in its latest fiscal year came to $285,327,445 and net earnings after taxes were $8,863,350, the annual report disclosed yesterday. The period covered is the year ended Jan. 28.

Few persons would think of a safety deposit company as a place to spend a quiet afternoon or hold a meeting of friends. Yet the Safe Deposit Company of New York, which marks its 100th anniversary tomorrow has many of the aspects of a private club.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Legislation to permit optional retirement for men at 62 years of age and carry out most of President Kennedy's other Social Security proposals was cleared today for a House vote.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Republican leaders agreed today to ask Congress to record once again its opposition to admission of Communist China to the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Senate began debating an increase in the minimum wage today but was slowed to a crawl by the tactics of some Southern Democratic and Republican opponents.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Space agency officials attributed today the United States loss in the race to put a man in space to a long Soviet start. They told Congress nothing could be done to accelerate the Mercury Astronaut program.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Democrat of Manhattan who is chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, promised today to withhold his anti-segregation amendment from pending school aid legislation.

The board of directors of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company raised the quarterly dividend on the common stock yesterday to 30 cents a share from the 25 cents paid in previous quarters. The higher payment will be made on June 1 to stockholders of record of April 26.

An appeal by the New Rochelle Board of Education from a lower court finding that it practiced segregation in its school system was dismissed as "premature" yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.

CHICAGO, April 13 (AP) -Renewed demand strengthened soybean future prices here today and all contracts recovered about half or more of their broad setbacks of the preceding session on the Board of Trade.

MILWAUKEE, April 13 (UPI) -- Lindy McDaniel walked Mel Roach with the bases filled in the eleventh inning today, and the Milwaukee Braves scored a 5-4 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. Only 6,448 fans saw the game.

Two councilors in charge of "matters of war" and "matters of the interior" were named yesterday by Dr. Jose Miro Cardona, president of the Revolutionary Council seeking the overthrow of Premier Castro.

There is an inclination to categorize American youth as soft, lazy and lacking in ambition. It's not difficult to marshall facts in support of thing harsh judgment. Viewers-with-alarm should be wary of making it a blanket indictment, however. It doesn't apply in all cases.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -Following is the text of President Kennedy's special message to Congress today on regulatory agencies:

PRINCETON, N.J., April 13 -- An attempt will be made to develop lawyers without the lawyers' traditional verbosity. It will be reflected in admission tests given by eighty-six law Schools in November.

DETROIT, April 13 -- The Ford Motor Company announced today that it had purchased two manufacturing plants of the Electric Autolite Company, the use of the latter's trade name and certain other assets.

Production of lumber rose to 218,881,000 board feet in the week ended last Saturday from 203,642,000 board feet a week earlier, according to reports received yesterday from regional associations. In the corresponding 1960 period the output was 260,035,000 board feet.
The police arrested yesterday a burglar known as the "Gray Ghost" who is reputed to have stolen $150,000 in articles from Park and Fifth Avenue apartments in the last three months.

"Senator from Vermont," the autobiography of Ralph E. Flanders, will be issued next Thursday by Little, Brown. The author tells of village life in Vermont, of a poor boy who made his way to the top and how he used his New England principles of morality and practicality in the everyday affairs of government.

Young Rubicam, Inc., filed strong protests yesterday with each of the three major networks and with the National Association of Broadcasters, saying that any increase in television advertising time might prove another step "toward a chaos of commercialization extending from coast to coast."
HOUSTON, April 13 (AP) -- Neale Fraser and Roy Emerson of Australia gained the semi-finals of the twenty-seventh River Oaks tennis tournament today.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People urged Congress today to forbid racial discrimination in Federally supported housing programs.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, April 13 (AP) -- Bishop Thomas F. Reilly arrived in this capital tonight and reported that terrorist mob attacks had wrecked his home at San Juan de la Maguana.
HAVANA, April 13 -- Dr. Juan Orta, former head of the Office of the Premier in the Fidel Castro regime, has taken asylum in the Venezuelan Embassy.
LOS ANGELES, April 13 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillips, capitalizing on three Dodger blunders, scored four runs in the last two innings tonight and defeated Los Angeles, 8 -- 7.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The opening session of a Senate investigation of price-fixing by electrical equipment manufacturers broke up in a wrangle today. The dispute was touched off by Republican demands that the hearings be postponed or conducted behind closed doors.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- President Kennedy will observe day and night flight operations from the aircraft carrier Independence off the Florida east coast April 22 and 23, the White House announced today.
LONDON, April 13 -- Anthony Neil Wedgwood Benn, Viscount Stansgate, is no longer welcome in the House of Commons.

EVEN in these of days jet-propelled travel, it is not easy to visit twenty-one countries between the hors d'oeuvre and dessert courses of a single dinner. Yet this feat will be accomplished tonight by some 300 persons.
MAPLEWOOD, N.J., April 13 -- Although they have no vote, a number of teen-agers here are taking part in a fight to unseat Dennis F. Carey as Essex County Democratic chief.

TO Charles Lin Tissot, crystal can be shaped as easily as cake frosting. But in viewing Mr. Tissot's most recent crystal and glass confections opening in an exhibition today at Tiffany's, no one would believe it.

When the anniversary of V-E Day is celebrated in Coutances, France, this spring, the little town near the Channel will hold a ceremony to welcome back two storied World War II flags. After the town's liberation by the United States Army in 1944, the French flags went to the Fairfax County, Va., home of W. Fred Jordan.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 13 -- Premier Viggo Kampmann summoned the presidents of the federation of trade unions and the employers' federation tonight and asked them to resume negotiations for a wage agreement in an attempt to end a strike of 40,000 transport workers and 10,000 metallurgical workers.

Daily average borrowings by Federal Reserve member banks fell $55,000,000 to 52,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Average daily reserves in excess of requirements rose $42,000,000 to $597,000,000.

The United States monetary gold stock rose $1,000,000 to $17,390,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The gold stock has either remained unchanged or has risen for seven consecutive weeks.

HUNTINGTON STATION, L.I., April 13 -- Governor Rockefeller asserted tonight that Suffolk County would be returned to "solid" Republican control at next November's elections. The Democrats won control of the county government in 1959.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company disclaimed yesterday any goal of monopoly in the use of satellites for intercontinental communications.
Lord Casey of Berwick, former Foreign Minister of Australia, warned here yesterday that the "population explosion" in Asia was making countries there a fertile field for communism.

A major project involving the transportation and sale of natural gas was announced yesterday by the Humble Oil and Refining Company, principal domestic affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 13 -- The General Assembly overwhelmingly condemned South Africa's racial discrimination tonight as "reprehensible and repugnant to human dignity."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 13 -- A shocked General Assembly heard an African diplomat read today a hate letter he had received and tell of vandalism at his suburban home.

Alexander Guterma, convicted stock manipulator, and four others were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for conspiring to defraud the public of $8,000,000 in the sale of stock through the use of false and misleading literature.
BATA, Rio Muni, April 1 -- In this jungle province Spain is building an African-European community modeled in her own image. It appears to be a successful experiment.

A midtown mecca for interior designers and their clients is moving eastward. If history repeats itself, shoppers for fabrics and wallpapers may soon find their destination in and around Fifty-sixth Street and Third Avenue away from the hub now located at Fifty-third Street and Madison Avenue.
PALO ALTO, Calif., April 13 (AP) -- Dr. Philip B. Gallagher, 33-year-old solar research scientist, was killed today when he accidentally touched a 5,000-volt high-tension wire.

There were two wonders at Aqueduct yesterday. Not necessarily in the order named, one was that there was any racing at all and the other was that a "hard nutty core" of 16,107 turned out for the program.

BECAUSE the fresh-water angler can't reasonably think about fishing this weekend, he might as well think about whether Governor Rockefeller is going to approve a bill on his desk to provide one little stretch of fishing-for-fun stream.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Administration tightened its controls over Pentagon publicity today, censoring an admiral's speech and withholding usually available details on tracking the Soviet man in space.

Parsons Gardens, a group of two-story apartment houses at Seventy-fifth Road and Parsons Boulevard, Flushing, Queens, has been sold by Kessler-Hess, Inc., the builder. It was acquired by a syndicate of investors for $2,000,000.
CHICAGO, April 13, (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

LONDON, April 13 -- The United States and Britain regard the Soviet attitudes toward the nuclear test ban negotiations and the United Nations and its officials as a test of Russian willingness to improve relations, Prime Minister Macmillan said today.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, April 13 (AP) -- An American mercy flight brought an ailing Soviet scientist from deep in Antarctica, but the scientist said today that the trip had not been necessary.

DETROIT, April 13 -- The American Bowling Congress today took a step toward settling the differences with the Bowling Proprietors Association of America that were caused by the tournament eligibility rule of the proprietors' organization.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 13 -- An Arab speaker accused the United States today of allowing "zionist pressure" to influence its attitude toward Arab refugees from Palestine.

This is Pan American Day -- the seventy-first anniversary of the Inter-American System. No celebration of this day in the United States has been held in a time of such "clear and present danger" and such awareness of what we have to lose, of what Latin America means to us.

BONN, Germany, April 13 -- The commanding general of an American front line Army division was reported today to have been urging the views of the ultra-conservative John Birch Society on his troops for the last six months.
YONKERS, April 13 -- Su Mac Lad, who is good and getting better, won the $65,600 Gotham Trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight, as had been expected by most of the 14,627 fans.

Gross revenues and net income of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., in the three months ended on March 16 were the highest for any quarter since the company's separation from Loew's on March 12, 1959. As a result, six-month figures were substantially ahead of those for the similar period a year ago.

LONDON, April 13 -- Business moved indecisively on stock markets here today. In the industrial market buyers were cautious with the approach of the budget and profit taking continued with the result that prices fell during the morning.
LINCOLN, R.I., April 13 (AP) -- Robert Wallis' Marine Blues survived a foul claim after the Hope Valley Purse and became the fourth longpriced winner today at Lincoln Downs.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said today that he was opposed to the Federal Government's becoming a partner in a proposed four-state compact to develop water resources in the Delaware River basin.

ANY fish is a poor fish indeed right now. After a brief period in the limelight, it has fallen into public neglect now that both Lent and Passover are over. Most varieties have decreased in cost this week-end, with whitefish heading the decline (minus 10 cents) closely followed by large flounders (down 9 cents a pound).

In a move to upgrade school supervision, the Board of Superintendents of the city school system proposed yesterday that future principals and assistant superintendents serve an internship period before assuming their new positions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 13 -- During the week-end, when most members of the Hollywood world will be talking and worrying about who will win Oscar awards on Monday, Andre Previn, usually well-groomed young pianist-arranger-composer, will be hot and disheveled as he conducts an orchestra preparing music for the Oscar presentations.
The wholesale commodity price index was 87.3 on Wednesday, unchanged from the 19-month high set Tuesday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 85.8 on April 5, 1960.
HARTFORD, April 13 -- Connecticut, completing a two-year study of racial integration, has found that 90 per cent of the Negroes questioned favored moving into private white residential neighborhoods.

"MY only aim is to rove through the soul of this wonderful man, to admire the landscape and sometimes to point out some detail." So writes Jean Dutourd describing his purpose in writing his new book, "The Man of Sensibility."* Through whose soul does M. Dutourd invite his readers to accompany him?
Pied d'Or of the Calumet Farm probably will be the favorite for the fifty-third running of the Excelsior Handicap at Aqueduct today.
Another major producer yesterday clambered aboard what appeared to be the developing bandwagon of manufacturing color television sets.

BANGKOK, Thailand, April 5 -- With the rest of the world debating such politically explosive concepts as "colonialism" and other cliches of the "cold war," you might get the notion that the Thais are sitting it out. "If you denounce 'colonialism,' people here don't know what you're talking about," one Thai remarked the other day.
NASSAU, Bahamas, April 14 (AP) -- Sam Griffith of Miami won the 180-mile Miami-Nassau powerboat race for the fourth time today in a record 4 hours 20 minutes 45 seconds.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 (AP) -- Mike McCormick, a left-hander for the San Francisco Giants, blanked Philadelphia three hits tonight, 2 -- 0, beating a right-hander, Art Mahaffey in a pitchers' duel.
Broadway, ever so quick to come to the assistance of others, dug into its collective jeans yesterday for a cause of its own -- the aspiring and needy playwright of talent.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- For the first time in nine years the President of the United States will not greet personally the 3,000 business men delegates to the annual meeting of the United States Chamber of Commerce, which opens here May 1.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. April 14 -- South Korea won the right today to take part immediately in the United Nations' debate on the reunification of Korea.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 14 -- Rutgers University today backed up two of its young poets.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 14 -- The Israeli tribunal trying Adolf Eichmann reserved decision today on his plea that it lacks jurisdiction.
CARACAS, Venezuela, April 14 -- Three hundred students demonstrated in the streets of Caracas today against the appointment of Teodoro Moscoso, a Puerto Rican, as American ambassador to Venezuela.

The plot of land at 13 to 23 West Thirteenth Street and 18-20 West Fourteenth Street has been leased by Prussin, Bregman Stolz, builders, for improvement with two twelve-story apartment houses. Leo Stillman is the architect. William Alfred White, Inc., was the broker in the lease.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 14 -- The United States told the General Assembly today that the United Nations should encourage the leaders of the Congo to write a new constitution for the bitterly divided African republic.

The Temporary State Housing Rent Commission yesterday turned over to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office evidence purporting to show that five property owners and an architect were guilty of violations of the housing sections of the Administrative Code.
MINEOLA, L.I., April 14 -- Two men believed to be members of a ring that defrauded the Meadowbrook National Bank of $194,000 by cashing bogus Treasury coupons were arrested today.

A resolution providing for secret balloting of stockholders for election of directors, similar to those introduced in proxy statements of several major corporations, is listed for the first time in the annual meeting notice of the General Motors Corporation.

WHITE PLAINS, April 14 -- Percy Grainger, the Australian-born composer, bequeathed his skeleton to the University of Melbourne for "possible display in the Grainger Museum," the filing of his will disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, April 14 --Federal and state payments to the nation's jobless reached a record monthly total of $450,000,000 in March, Labor Department spokesmen estimated today.
WASHINGTON, April 14 --Hairsplitting debate and a series of formal speeches moved the Senate a little closer today to a decision on the Kennedy Administration's bill to increase the minimum wage.
GREENWICH, Conn., April 14 -- A proposal to have teachers work a twelve-month year for more money has been placed before the Board of Education.

This Sunday's walking tour in the series, sponsored by the Museum of the City of New York is entitled "The Grandeur That Was Home." Conducted by Henry Hope Reed Jr., architectural historian, the walk will begin at St. Ignatius Church, Eighty-fourth Street and Park Avenue at 2:30 P.M.
MOSCOW, April 14 -- Moscow gave a great ovation today to Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin, the first man to fly into space.
Communist China's rural commune have been altered in recent months almost to the point of extinction.

Under attack as he is, with his leadership of Tammany seriously threatened, Carmine G. De Sapio has worsened his position with the public by joining in the assault on City Charter revision. It is of no substantial significance whether he instigated the taxpayer suit that challenges constitutionality of the 1961 law establishing a Charter Revision Commission.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 14 -- While going through a sheaf of Nazi documents a few weeks ago in preparing Israel's case against Adolf Eichmann, Attorney General Gideon Hausner stopped abruptly at one.

A group of volunteers under the chairmanship of Mrs. Peter Capra will staff the Opportunity Shop's booth at the New York Antiques Fair. The fair will be held at the Seventy-first Infantry Armory, Park Avenue at Thirty-fourth Street, from Monday through Saturday.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 14 (AP) -- Bermuda today squared the Amorita Cup sailing series with the United States at two victories apiece.

CHICAGO, April 14 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks scored three third-period goals tonight and defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 6 -- 3, in the fifth game of the Stanley Cup hockey finals. The Hawks now lead in the four-of-seven series, 3 games to 2.

"EVERY woman over 40 should have a vital interest outside her home," declares Virginia B. Clute, a wife, mother and fashion consultant, whose first pay check was earned after she was 40. Now, at 50 plus, she has started her own business.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 14 -- The United States told the Arab states today that they, not Washington policy, had injected political discord into a General Assembly debate on Palestine Arab refugees.

There must be something radically wrong with those responsible for Dr. Buell G. Gallagher's resignation as president of City College. How can the people of the City of New York afford to lose this great public servant? As your editorial of April 8 appropriately points out, here is a man who has achieved a remarkable record in his few years as president of one of our finest institutions of higher learning.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy has called 175 of his high-ranking officers to a meeting on Tuesday to tell them what he expects on the enforcement of gambling laws.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Federal Reserve Board has approved a proposed Boston bank merger to which the Department of Justice objected on grounds of its effect on competition.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- R. Sargent Shriver, director of the Peace Corps, announced today that he would visit seven African and Asian nations to discuss specific aid projects.
LONDON, April 14 -- The first live television broadcast from the Soviet Union to Britain was presented today by the British Broadcasting Corporation.

Governor Rockefeller's signature has officially set in motion a development that has been too long delayed. This is to provide New York State with a comprehensive, first-rate system of public higher education. The program thus launched has many facets, some capitalizing on existing strong points, others proposing new approaches to the huge task of finding proper places of learning for the steadily increasing number of college and university students.
CHICAGO, April 14 -- Representative Edgar W. Hiestand rejected today, as "political suicide and a disaster for the Republic," any proposal for a Right-Wing national political party.
DETROIT, April 14 (AP) -- Jim Landis' scratch single in the fifth inning ruined Frank Lary's bid for a no-hitter today as the Detroit Tigers gained a 7-0 triumph over the Chicago White Sox.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, April 14 (AP) -- Three Roman Catholic aides of Bishop Thomas F. Reilly left the Dominican Republic today in the wake of mob violence in San Juan de la Maguana.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI) -- President Kennedy named James W. Wine, lawyer, churchman and former Democratic campaign official, as Ambassador to Luxembourg today.
BOSTON, April 14 (AP) -- The New England Council issued the following report today:

A chunky, round-faced, saucer-eyed man named Bill Dana, whose trade-mark on television and in West Coast cabarets is a character called Jose Jimenez, is the latest of the new-wave, stand-up comics to make it to a Manhattan night club.

The metropolitan area's rapid growth in the next twenty-five years will require at least $42,000,000,000 in public investment to provide the essential facilities, the Regional Plan Association said yesterday.
ALBANY, April 13 -- Tuition at the units of the State University will remain unchanged for the 1961-62 school year.
THE first "live" television link between the Soviet Union and the Western world was a stunning technical success yesterday.
BATON ROUGE, La., April 14 -- Kent Courtney of New Orleans, now attempting to organize a new political party, has been identified in Louisiana with strongly conservative, mostly unsuccessful causes.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Kennedy Administration has accelerated by one year the timetable for landing the first man on the moon, an official of the space agency disclosed to Congress today.

LOS ANGELES, April 14 (UPI) -- Mrs. Walburga Oesterreich, a key figure in the "batman" murder case more than thirty years ago died last Saturday. She left her entire estate, believed to be in excess of $1,000,000, to the man She married sixteen days before her death, it was disclosed today.

GENEVA, April 14 -- The Soviet Union refused today to consider opening its territory to international inspection earlier than four years after ratification of the projected treaty to ban tests of nuclear weapons.

MOSCOW, April 14 (AP) -- A book about Yuri A. Gagarin went on sale in Moscow today. It contains a mass of information about him and many philosophical notes. One of the notes compares his space flight to the story of the creation in the Bible.

LEWIS GANNETT has shaken the great tree of poetry and brought down a tremendous harvest. He calls it "The Family Book of Verse."* If ever there was a book that had something in it for everyone, this is it. I can't think how true democracy could be displayed more affably on the printed page.
The Metropolitan Opera will be able to mount only two new productions during its 1961-62 season.
The Directors Guild of America early this morning gave its members temporary permission to continue working for three major networks without a contract.

On an average night in the south Bronx Patrolman William Giddings Walks five miles, issues one parking ticket, breaks up two family fights, and tussles with two or three winos who insist upon sleeping in hallways.

TOKYO, April 14 (AP) -- Communist China today swept both the men's and women's singles titles in the world table tennis championships played at Peiping. The results were reported by Hsinhua, the official New China News Agency.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Navy is having trouble firing Polaris missiles from submarines in underwater tests, official sources disclosed today.
HAVANA, April 14 -- The destruction by fire of El Encanto, Cuba's largest department store, touched off today the heaviest attacks against the United States heard so far in this island.

Navy's junior varsity crew received a promotion last night. After a late workout on the Harlem River, Coach Paul Quinn announced that the erstwhile jayvees would be the varsity in their season's opener today against Columbia.
DETROIT, April 14 -- The rift between the American Bowling Congress and the organization of lane owners widened today at the annual A.B.C. convention at Cobo Hall.
The biggest bank merger in Canadian history was approved by stockholders of the Canadian Bank of Commerce and the Imperial Bank of Canada at special meetings in Toronto yesterday.
The market for high-grade debt investments ended the week on a firm note yesterday. The volume of business continued light and prices fluctuated within narrow ranges.
NICE, France, 'April 14 (AP) -- Twenty-four modern paintings estimated to be worth at least 2,000,000 francs ($400,000) were stolen hit night, and recovered by luck within twenty minutes.
Once again the end of a legislative session finds the city -- and its newspaper editorial pages -- wringing their hands over the disgraceful spectacle presented by our lawmakers at Albany.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission last night accused five publishers of paying illegal promotional allowances to certain newsstand chains and other retailers of their books and magazines.
A storm is brewing in world transport labor circles over the suspension of the Seafarers International Union by the International Transport Workers Federation.

WITH spring in full swing the city dweller covets invitations to the country for a glimpse of the crocus in bloom, the forsythia in bud or just a good brisk walk in the greening woods. On these occasions a small week-end gift is appreciated, but often overlooked because of lack of time to shop around.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Kennedy Administration asked Congress today to raise postal rates about $741,000,000 a year.
The long dispute involving airline flight engineers appeared yesterday to be further away from a solution.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Senator William Proxmire, Wisconsin Democrat, called General Walker "a pitifully misguided general" today.
PHILADELPHIA, April 14 (AP) -- Sonny Liston, the leading contender for the world heavyweight title, today threatened to quit the ring unless Joseph (Pep) Barone stepped out as his manager.
Mikhail Tal of Latvia, the defender, outplayed Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia yesterday in the twelfth game of their match for the world chess championship at the Variety Theatre in Moscow.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy, in her search for authentic White House antiques, has found a historic pier table in the Presidential mansion.

PERIGUEUX, France, April 14 -- President de Gaulle turned his speech - making tour of southwestern France today into a campaign to persuade the Algerian rebel Provisional Government to negotiate peace.

The Alleghany Corporation's treasury was swelled last night by some $10,000,000 of new cash. This was paid to it principally by two groups -- Allan P. Kirby and his associates and the Murchison brothers of Dallas, Tex., and their associates.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- President Kennedy called today for a summer meeting of Latin-American finance ministers to set up the machinery for his proposed Alliance for Progress.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI) -- A Federal Court today convicted two persons of conspiring to block a Senate rackets committee investigation of James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters union.
Fred J. Thompson, the 59-year-old drifter accused of the rape-slaying of 4-year-old Edith Kiecorius last February, was transferred yesterday from Bellevue Hospital to Bronx City Prison.
WOODBURY, N.J., April 14 -- State Senator Walter H. Jones chided James P. Mitchell tonight for what he implied were Mr. Mitchell's lack of qualifications to be Governor.
JERUSALEM, April 14 -- The United States has made several private expressions of concern to Israel over her plans to bring heavy armament into Jerusalem for her independence day celebration Thursday.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 14 -- Growing expenses and "a vertical drop of revenues" have plunged the Congo into "grave but not desperate" financial straits, the governor of the National Bank of the Congo said today.

The chairman of the city's housing board yesterday characterized as "self-serving" a letter he had received from Assemblyman Louis De Salvio attacking plans to survey an area of Greenwich Village for possible redevelopment.

The eighty-seventh Kentucky Derby will be raced in Louisville in just three weeks and 3-year-old horses eligible for that $125,000-added race will be seen in the California Derby and the Chesapeake Stakes today.
Council Majority Leader Joseph T. Sharkey called a special meeting of the City Council today in an apparent switch of tactics on Charter revision.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., has discovered that time and money can be saved in enameling refrigerators by the use of citric acid, the chemical that puts the tang in soft drinks.
The Herbert Investment Company, a Miami holding company headed by Herbert N. Schwarz, has acquired a majority interest in Seaporcel Metals, Inc., Long Island City, Queens, it was announced yesterday.
New issues slated for the public capital market next week total nearly $450,000,000, including a $300,000,000 debentures issue of the United States Steel Company.

Jacques Barzun, scholar-critic-author-teacher-lecturer, is an avid fancier of detective stories. A collection of his favorites is planned for May 26 publication by Criterion under the title "The Delights of Detection."

Part of an alleged $5,000 down-payment fee paid by wholesale newsdealers to insure labor peace was collected in the building that housed the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, according to testimony in Federal Court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI) -- Senate subcommittee suggested today that seventy four elderly Federal judges retire from full-time duty so younger men could be named.

Ellsworth (Spider) Webb of Chicago, idle since Feb. 26, 1960, returns to the ring tonight at St. Nicholas Arena in the feature ten-round event against Dick Tiger, the British Empire middleweight champion.
SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., April 14 (AP) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said tonight it was expected that the Russians might get the first man into space.
First-quarter earnings of the General Electric Company plummeted $10,138,000 from the 1960 level on a sales gain of $35,189,000.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy recommended to the White House today that Cecil F. Poole, 47-year-old Negro lawyer of San Francisco, be appointed United States Attorney for Northern California.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 14 -- The Royal Laotian Army's move to recapture the initiative in the civil war by sending paratroopers and helicopter-borne infantry behind the enemy lines appears to have been a failure.
The bulk sulphur carrier Marine Merchant was battered by a spring gale off Maine yesterday and was abandoned by her crew of thirty-five. The men were picked up from lifeboats and put ashore.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Wilma Rudolph, the Olympic track star, missed a plane here today because of an unexpected talk with President Kennedy -- but Vice President Johnson got her another reservation.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The United States has prodded the Soviet Union for an early reply to the British plan for a verified cease-fire in Laos.

LINDAU, Germany, April 14 -- The most important of our current negotiations with Russia are the resumed tripartite talks in Geneva. These talks, in which Britain is the third participant, seek an international treaty outlawing nuclear tests and establishing a workable control system to bar violations.

The directors of the American Hospital Supply Corporation proposed a three-for-one split of the common stock yesterday. They also voted to increase the dividend on the present stock to 75 cents a share a year from 65 cents.
A week-end conference on religious drama opened last night at Riverside Church.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 14 -- Emperor Haile Selassie said today that Ethiopian ministers had been shirking their duties and responsibilities and turning too much to him for decisions.
A 41-year-old ex-convict was sentenced yesterday for a fourth time to a long prison term as a participant in a $42,323 Long Island bank robbery.
Birgit Nilsson sang her first Metropolitan Aida last night in a performance of the Verdi opera that also featured the debut of a Yugsoslav mezzosoprano, Biserka Cvejic.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- President Kennedy said today that the first meeting in Paris next week of the economic policy group of the new Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development was symbolic of Western cooperation and unity in seeking solutions to common problems.

Steel production appears headed for significant increases next week in a least two leading districts -- Youngstown and Pittsburgh. In Youngstown six open hearth furnaces will be returned to operation at the Brier Hill Works of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company.
CHESHIRE, Conn., April 14 (AP) -- The president of the New York Stock Exchange tonight advocated reductions in taxes on dividends and capital gains.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Industrial production rose slightly in March to break a nine-month decline, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
QUANTICO, Va., April 14 (AP) -- Irvin (Bo) Roberson, the former Cornell star athlete now in the Army, set meet records in the broad jump and 100-yard dash today at the opening of the Quantico Relays.
AUGSBURG, Germany, April 14 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker denied today that his division's information program was dominated by the John Birch Society.
LISBON, Portugal, April 14 -- The Portuguese Government has arrested a Brazilian accused of having tried to smuggle explosives into the country to blow up the United States Embassy.
CHICAGO, April 14 (AP) -- Sammy Taylor, with a 3-and-2 count and two out in the ninth inning, slammed a two-run homer to give the Chicago Cubs a 3-2 victory today over the Milwaukee Braves.
ST. LOUIS, April 14 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds scored five runs in the ninth inning tonight, for a 7-3 victory over the Cardinals. The triumph was the Reds' third straight.
RIO JANEIRO, April 14 -- Brazil and the United States agreed today on a $70,000,000 deal that will provide 1,000,000 tons of surplus wheat for Brazilian consumption this year.

Many thousands of years ago when spring arrived perhaps man came forth from the cave he had wintered in, shrugged off the itching, bearskin he had been wearing for the past few months and in the warming sunshine set off to hunt some lighter apparel -- his spring suit.
ALBANY, April 14 -- A four-year Republican deadlock, over the issue of residence requirements for relief ended with the stroke of a pen today.

Market measuring rods were of little use yesterday. Stocks closed either up a little or down a little, depending on the average or index used. Volume, however, picked up smartly and the tone was far better than it had been on Wednesday and Thursday.
MOSCOW, April 14 (UPI) -- Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin parachuted to earth from his flight into space and landed on both feet, an eye-witness dispatch reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee said today that Dean Acheson, on his present trip to Europe, was wearing two hats -- one as a United States official, the other as a private lawyer.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr.'s contention that his trial on income tax fraud charges was "politically motivated" is "ridiculous," United States Attorney Morton S. Robinson said yesterday.
LONDON, April 14 (Reuters) -- A leading British lawyer said today that the Soviet Union's manned space flight could not be accepted legally on the evidence published so far.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Republican Senators lost a move today to block a public investigation of price-fixing charges in the electrical industry.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., April 14 -- Two barge captains who were lost when their barges capsized in the Hudson River in yesterday's rain and wind storm were identified today by their employer, the New York Tray Dock Corporation.
HONG KONG, April 14 -- Persistent rumors of underground opposition to the Communist regime in China are reaching Hong Kong.
LONDON, April 14 -- The stock market marked time today and a slight forward movement was restrained as dealers awaited the Government's new budget on Monday.
DETROIT, April 14 -- New car sales during the first ten days of April were slightly above those of early March, but remained at one of the lowest levels in nearly six years.
THE New York Philharmonic is ending its regular concert series this weekend, but its duties for the season are far from over.

A $70,000 antique English commode, over which English and American dealers fought a fierce, if silent, auction battle at the Parke-Bernet Galleries here last week, was auctioned previously for $8,000, the galleries disclosed yesterday.

A concert devoted to music by Miriam Gideon was given in Carnegie Recital Hall late yesterday afternoon. The Quartet for Strings, a Sonata for 'Cello and Piano and two vocal works -- "The Hound of Heaven" and Sonnets from Shakespeare -- made up the program.
Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges called last night for "a rising tide of two-way tourist travel between the United States and other countries."

A fireman who went into a bar in 1955 to make a routine test of the fire resistance of a window display found the answer when the bar burned down. Yesterday his routine inspection cost the city $45,000 in an out-of-court settlement.

The state moved yesterday to protect cultural organizations from having their names linked, without their permission, to advertisements for brassieres, whisky, nightclub acts or other commercial projects.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Chancellor Adenauer sent a message today to Premier Khrushchev.
The spring exodus to Europe marked a record yesterday with the sailing of seven liners carrying 6,200 passengers.

BRASILIA, April 14 -- President Janio Quadros said today that Brazil "supports and defends the right of self-determination of Cuba and favored "any effort" to heal the breach between Havana and Washington.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Average prices in primary markets dipped 0.1 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday to 119.4 per cent of their 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange dropped 11 to 35 points, except the new October, which was up 22 on a closing bid price. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
Spurred by heavy commission house buying, wool prices advanced yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Trading during the session was active.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Protestant leaders urged today "abandonment of drastic revision" of the immigration national origins quota system.

JOSE LIMON created a most amusing novelty for the dancers of the Juilliard School of Music, which was presented in the first of two performances last night in the school's concert hall. If it was not designed perhaps as an enduring work of art, it is nevertheless a tour de force of notable skill.
CHICAGO, April 14 (AP) -- Old crop soybeans futures backed and filled over a rather broad range on the Board of Trade but the new crop contracts and grains drifted in meager dealings.

Monsanto Chemical Company's consolidated sales and earnings in the first quarter showed their first upturn since the second quarter of 1960, but still were below those of the first quarter of 1960, the company announced yesterday.

BONN, Germany, April 14 -- The flow of money into West Germany is continuing unabated despite the recent revaluation of the Deutsche mark, according to figures released today by the Federal Bank in Frankfurt.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The United States announced today that 1,263,776 tons of sugar which normally would have been obtained from Cuba during the last nine months of this year will be purchased from sixteen other countries.

Your editorial of April 7 on the situation in Algeria calls for some clarification. In particular, I refer to your statement that "the rebel leaders * * * are raising new conditions. They not only attempt to veto French discussions with other elements of the Algerian 'populations,' clearly reserved in the French proposals and previously agreed by the rebels, but also demand the release of some previously, imprisoned rebel leaders."

PARIS, April 14 -- Two semi-documentary films -- one produced in the Ivory Coast and the other in Israel -- were previewed here today. Neither used professional actors, and both gained in dramatic impact by the course of current history -- in Africa and in the courtroom in Jerusalem where Adolph Eichmann is being tried.
Dr. Ezequiel Padilla, former Minister of Foreign Affairs for Mexico, called for a united Western Hemisphere yesterday to meet the challenge of international communism.

In his New York debut recital in Carnegie Recital Hall last night, Leslie Meadow sang in a manner that grew more in communicativeness and tonal smoothness as the evening wore on. By the time he reached two songs by Kodaly, "Farewell Carnival" and "Solitude," sung in English, he was creating specific moods with expressive pharsing and well-focused tones.
BOSTON, April 14 (AP) -- Bernard Goldfine, textile industrialist, will go on trial May 15 on charges of evading nearly $800,000 in personal and corporate income taxes.
THERE is a commendable new French pastry shop across the East River from Manhattan. Called La Marjolaine, it is at 50-17 Skillman Avenue, Woodside, L.I.
THIS year's play for the world bridge championship begins today in Buenos Aires and will continue through next Sunday. Teams from the United States, Argentina, France, and Italy are competing.
Matthew S. Crinkley, executive vice president of Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., answered charges yesterday against its ship-sale transaction with American Export Lines.
The rate of world population growth anticipated for the period 1961-2000 is even higher and the situation more serious than suggested by your editorial of April 7.

YONKERS, April 14 -- Su Mac Lad and Air Record, one, two in last night's Gotham Trot, will be the American representatives in Thursday night's United Nations Trot, a $50,000 invitation race at a mile and a half at Yonkers Raceway.

LONDON, April 14 -- Prime Minister Macmillan suggested tonight that the United States, Britain and France might act as "trustees" of the nuclear deterrent to meet the defense requirements of their European allies.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 14 -- Suffold County's five-year-old scandal investigations were ended unofficially here today at an extraordinary session of the State Supreme Court.
BALTIMORE, April 14 (AP) -- Zorro Versalles and Camilo Pascual led the Minnesota Twins to their second straight victory tonight. The Twins won, 3 -- 2, from the Baltimore Orioles.

Superintendent of Schools John J. Theobald said yesterday that 10,000 seventh-graders here could not read third-grade books. He also reported that the annual test this year showed 67,067 of the city's 172,000 junior high school pupils were more than two years behind in reading.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 14 -- Premier Pedro G. Beltran of Peru closed the annual meeting of the governors of the Inter-American Development Bank today with a stinging attack on "the Communist revolution in Cuba."

Looking forward to the Ethel Walker School's golden anniversary in the next academic year, the alumnae of the school in Simsbury, Conn., are planning a benefit. A scholarship will be provided with proceeds of a theatre party at the May 25 performance of "Carnival!" at the Imperial Theatre.
Two officers and a director of the Continental Vending Machine Corporation have reduced their holdings in the company, according to the American Stock Exchange's latest report on trading by insiders.
PARIS, April 14 -- In the beauful spring of 1961, Western Europe is prospering as never before, but it is still far from affluent.
If the West does not make a stand against Communist aggression in Laos, Sir Leslie Munro asked last night, where does it make its stand?
Three days after man's' first space flight there are still several puzzles concerning the circumstances of the trip.
Sir Winston Churhill bade a silent, smiling farewell yesterday as he ended a two-day private visit in New York.
Cardinal Spellman will make a plea to his parishoners tomorrow to give at least one day's pay to the 1961 appeal of the New York Catholic Charities.
Emile Griffith, the millinery clerk who recently won the world welterweight title by knocking out Benny (Kid) Paret, will make the first defense of his championship against Gaspar Ortega of Mexico.

With representatives of nine New York and New Jersey teams competing, the thirty-third annual women's collegiate fencing tournament opened at Hunter College in Manhattan yesterday.
Income taxpayers besieged the Internal Revenue offices at 484 Lexington Avenue yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, April 14 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates survived a ninth-inning Dodge rally and scored a 6-3 victory tonight before a crowd 28,371.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI) -- Joe McClain pitched the Washington Senators to their first victory tonight, beating the Cleveland Indians, 3 -- 2, on a seven-hitter. A crowd of 10,126 saw the game.

The project of transforming the North Atlantic alliance from a primarily military organization into a true political, economic and even ideological. Atlantic Community advanced another long step as a result of the wide accord reached between President Kennedy and Chancellor Adenauer.
The long-awaited American premiere of what is reportedly one of the most significant postwar German films. "The Bridge," has been set for May 1 at the sixty-eighth Street Playhouse.

Events today: "Don Carlo" at P.M. and "Wozzeck" at 8, Metropolitan Opera; Concert for Children, sponsored by the Parents League of New York, Leopold Stokowski, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Concert for Children, New York College of Music, 3:30; Ena Bronstein, pianist, Town Hall, 5:30; Amsterdam Concertgebouw Orchestra, Bernard Haitink, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; American Mandolin Orchestra, Thomas Sokoloff, Town Hall, 8:30.
LONDON, April 14 -- A pronounced swing to the Conservative party appears to have taken place in this week's county council elections in England and Wales.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy, wife of the President, attended the opening of the Opera Society of Washington's performance of Bizet's "Carmen" last night at Lisner Auditorium.

American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Inc., disclosed yesterday that it would seek stockholder permission at the annual meeting on May 16 to double its authorized stock to 10,000,000 shares from 5,000,000. The company now has 4,232,731 shares outstanding.

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 14 (AP) -- Mike Souchak and Billy Maxwell moved into the 36-hole lead of the $22,500 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament today with totals of 138. The first-day leader, Charlie Sifford, fell to third with a 72 for 140.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 14 -- Army's baseball team spent seven busy innings shagging extra-base hits and collecting some intangible yet cherished souvenirs today in an exhibition game with the Yankees.
CAPE TOWN, South Africa, April 14 (AP) -- Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd told Parliament today that the country was in a very serious position and preparing for any eventuality.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, introduced legislation today to repeal the ten-year-old law permitting, restricted stock option plans used by many corporations for their executives.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 14 (AP) -- An explosion and fire aboard a forty-two-foot pleasure craft today injured five members of the University of Florida football coaching staff and a Tampa television executive.
Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges said yesterday his department would present to President Kennedy by Monday a "preliminary recommendation on urban development and mass transportation."
DETROIT, April 15 (AP) -- The Maccabees, an elder among America's fraternal insurance societies, now is operating as a mutual life insurance company.

LOS ANGELES, April 15 (AP) -- Bill Virdon hit two home runs and Bob Friend pitched his first complete game here in nearly three years as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4 -- 1, tonight.

Mail Order took the express route in the $29,400 Excelsior Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. With Larry Adams keeping him in the lead all the way, the Alamode Farm's 5-year-old gelding won by four lengths.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 15 -- The Congo will face a public-health hazard if continuing United Nations pressure forces Belgian physicians to leave, a Belgian doctor warned here today.
PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- Ground was broken here yesterday for organized labor's first full scale hospital here.

GUATEMALA, April 15 -- Guatemala is undergoing one of her periodic spells of political and economic uneasiness.

IN an appreciative introduction to the third of Ben Lucien Burman's literary nosegays to the mythical -- and usually peaceable -- kingdom of Catfish Bend, the poet Robert Hillyer points out that the animals in these tales speak American.

CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- The building industry has hit the bottom of the recession and is on the upgrade, C.J. Haggerty, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Building and Construction Trades Department, said here today.

THE present stirrings in some quarters about the seamy qualities of some films and the widespread attempts to revive the notion that censorship or some form of classification will maintain the "purity" of the screen bring us back to the old question that has been asked time and again for fifty years: What do we expect the medium of motion pictures to convey?

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- Mudcat Grant of the Cleveland Indians continued his mastery over the Washington Senators in the American League today, pitching his team to a 3-1 victory before 9,616 paying customers.
HORTICULTURAL leaders were honored last week by the Garden Club of America. The medals were presented in New York by Mrs. Charles D. Webster, president.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y. April 15 -- Fordham University swept all the events today in a triangular intercollegiate rowing regatta on the Pelham Bay Lagoon off Travers Island.

LAUREL, Md., April 15 -- Orleans Doge surged from way behind to win the $29,200 Chesapeake Stakes at Laurel today. And thus the 3-year-old bay son of The Doge, who used to win here himself, joined the illustrious list of contenders for the forthcoming Kentucky Derby at Louisville.
Promoting exports at an import show may seem, in the popular view, a little like trying to sell catnip at a dog show.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today it had adopted a new research program that will use some of the equipment and employes of the concerns involved in the abandoned nuclear plane project.

THE Edgar M. Leventritt Foundation's announcement that it would not hold its annual competition this fall means that 1961 will be a slim year for American instrumentalists who want to compete for fame in their own country.
Male athletes may have more height, weight, reach, speed and even more savoir-faire than their female counterparts, but in sheer stick-to-itiveness, women fencers proved yesterday they excelled.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 15 -- The preliminary legal skirmishing in the trial of Adolf Eichmann has ended.

AMERICANS just can't seem to get it through their heads about Congress. LITTLE wars -- the Spanish termed them guerrillas -- harass the peace of the world in many areas and may long do so. Internal political uprisings or aggressive actions across borders, they enlist the arts of sabotage, espionage, infiltration and confusion. And they call for a special fighting man -- versatile, fast-thinking, tough.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, April 15 -- This new state is experiencing financial growing pains.

YONKERS, April 15 -- The second annual "Volumes for Vassar" benefit book sale of the Vassar Club of Westchester will be held in a tent at the Cross County Shopping Center here from April 26 through 29.

TRITOMA (kniphofia) used to be thought of as the orange-red, fall-flowering plant called red hot poker. However, in the last few years great strides have been made by crossing and re-crossing this species with other early-blooming ones. As a result, quite a list of fine, hardy, earlier blooming varieties is available in coral, gold, white and ivory.
A United States Government study has found that Soviet investing of capital in industry and agriculture during recent years has been significantly higher than that in the United States.

Re "Teen-Age Tyranny Extends Its Empire" (March 19) by Grace and Fred M. Hechinger: perhaps one way of deflating this tyranny is to replace "teen-ager" with a less glamorous word, recorded in Henry Cockeram's English dictionary of 1623.

PRESIDENT KENNEDY'S wish not to be called publicly by his nickname is being respected by the men and women who report the news and write the headlines. For one thing, they like him personally, always have -- every Ike, Dick and Henry knows that -- and for another, the "JFK" which he himself suggested takes up less than does - - - -.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The White House denied any knowledge today of aerial bombings in Cuba except for what had appeared in news reports.
LONDON, April 15 -- The scale, direction and momentum of the Soviet Union's political and economic effort in Africa still are being, debated by Soviet leaders, according to qualified sources here.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- A team of top-ranking United States officials left for Paris today to explore new arrangements for economic and financial cooperation among the nations of the West.

PARIS, April 10 -- A model of an ancient Polish fortified city, reconstructed on the basis of new archaeological studies, went on exhibition today as a feature of "the beginnings of the Polish state," an official French-Polish project at the University of Paris.

VIENNA, April 15 -- The "Second Congress of Vienna" will end officially next Tuesday. On that date representatives of more than eighty governments are scheduled to sign an agreement codifying diplomatic immunities and usages.

OF all the young composers who have emerged in Europe since the war, Pierre Boulez is certainly among the most distinctive. His talent has been saluted even by Stravinsky, who is not given to underwriting reputations in a moment of charitable absentmindedness.

DETROIT, April 15 -- A preliminary phase of the Government's bus manufacturing antitrust suit against. General Motors Corporation ended in United States District Court here on Monday, almost five years after the suit was filed.

THROUGH love of the Russians, Wright Miller has come to understand them. Thus nobly inspired and well equipped, he has written a perceptive and often eloquent book that can instruct the old Russian bands as rapidly as the randomly curious.

LONDON, April 15 (AP) -- Annonuncers on the Moscow radio seemed troubled today in reporting Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin's remarks on how he landed after orbiting the globe in a space ship. Correspondents were eager to know whether Major Gagarin had returned to earth by parachute or aboard the capsule in which he was launched into space.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- When the Soviet Cosmonaut, Maj. Yuri Alekseyevich Gagarin, safely returned to Russian soil early Wednesday morning after an historic trip through space, official Washington was still asleep. Its reaction upon arising amounted to little more than a yawn that the inevitable had occurred.
NEWPORT, R.I., April 15 -- A plan to raise funds for restoring Newport's Colonial homes and furnishings was announced today.
LAWN mowing time is nigh. To be sure that the power mower will be ready for use, there are several important steps to follow.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 (AP) -- Joseph (Pep) Barone intimated today that a change in managers wouldn't get Sonny Liston a shot at Floyd Patterson's heavyweight title. But Barone said he might step out anyway as Liston's manager.

BOSTON, April 15 (AP) -- The Coast Guard has announced that a three-man board of inquiry will attempt to determine cause of the loss yesterday off the New England Coast of the 8,000-ton freighter Marine Merchant.

ORLEANS, Vt. -- This is the time of year when natives of the Green Mountain State, as well as hundreds of springtime visitors, patiently await word that "the steelheads are jumpin' at Orleans." That means that the steelheads, or rainbow trout, have begun their annual spring run up the Willoughby River here, a phenomenon that has almost as much fascination for ordinary sight-seeing tourists as it does for dyed-in-the-wool fishermen.

THE new Phlox decussata varieties are an improvement over the old sorts in clarity of color, in sturdiness of plant and especially in disease resistance. Especially worthy of trial are the new phlox that were bred in England by Captain Symons-Jeune.

The Women's Division of the Joint Defense Appeal, the fund-raising arm of the American Jewish Committee and the Anti-Defamation League, will hold its twentieth anniversary luncheon at the Plaza on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Kennedy Administration, in consultation with Allied Governments, is considering a major revision in military policy for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

RED BANK, N.J. -- The Garden State Parkway, the shortest distance between home and a wide choice of vacation points along the New Jersey seashore, had the lowest fatality rate last year of any toll road in the United States. As far as Parkway officials are concerned, this safety record was no accident.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Chancellor Adenauer of Germany, like Prime Minister Macmillan of Britain, has left the White House with a high opinion of President Kennedy.

The eighth annual house and garden tour for the benefit of the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of the New York University Medical Center will take place May 18. Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel is chairman of the event.

The idea is intriguing, but unfortunately in a contending and jealous world our vices may get more attention than our virtues.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 (AP) -- Dallas Green of the Philadelphia Phillies shut out the Giants, 2 -- 0, on five hits today, ending a three-game San Francisco winning streak.

BOSTON, April 15 (UPI) -- Carl Yastrzemski, a rookie outfielder, drove in two runs and scored the other today in the Boston Red Sox' 3-0 victory over the Los Angeles Angels. Ike Delock held the Angels to four hits.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., April 15 -- A fifteen-month study of the Negro community here by a group of Wesleyan University faculty members is to start soon. The study will include a survey of economic status and housing needs of the 300 Negro families in the area.

DETROIT, April 15 -- Billy Bruton's first American League hit -- a three run homer in the fourth inning -- paced the Detroit Tigers to a 6-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox today before 5,371 chilled fans. WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Brookings Institution has named nine business executives as its first Public Affairs Fellows. They will spend six months in Washington -- two weeks in orientation and twenty-three weeks on working assignments at the policy-making level in a Federal agency.

MYSTIC, Conn., April 15 -- The Munson Institute of American Maritime History will hold its seventh annual summer session beginning July 3 at Mystic Seaport, here, Edouard A. Stackpole, institute director and curator at the seaport, has announced.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 15 -- Fighting a brisk cross-wind, Navy's lightweight crew-defeated Columbia and Princeton in the opening meet for all three schools on Lake Carnegie today.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga. -- A separately housed Franklin D. Roosevelt Museum was opened here last week as part of the Little White House memorial to the late President.

CINCINNATI, April 15 -- Maj. Gen. Clement F. St. John, the commanding general of Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, has been selected a vice president of the University of Cincinnati and director of its medical center.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 15 (AP) -- The United States won the Amorita Cup for International One-Design Class yachts today with a 43 1/4-42 victory over Bermuda in the fifth race of the series. The teams had been tied with two victories apiece going into today's races.

Navy's newly designated varsity crew scored impressively in beating Columbia on the Harlem yesterday. The eight that had been promoted on Friday evening from junior varsity status defeated the Lions by two and a quarter lengths.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- Americans are claiming larger average income tax refunds this year -- $117 against $108 in 1960.

A BULKY shape clad in gray, a cap waving in response to cheers -- once a year this hoped-for glimpse of Mao Tse-tung, Chairman of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist party, is bestowed upon the citizens of Peiping. On that day the people are called to parade in front of the ochre reviewing stand of Tien An Men, the Gate of Heavenly Peace.

TRENTON, April 15 -- The creation of county-operated junior colleges to help handle the increasing number of students resulting from the population explosion was urged today in a report issued by the New Jersey Board of Education.

MOSCOW, April 15 -- The world's first space traveler, Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin, said today that Soviet scientists were already working toward creation of space ships that would carry man to the moon. He said at a news conference that he would like to make the first trip.

BUFFALO, April 15 -- Mayor Frank A. Sedita's sixteen-month battle for the right to seek re-election this fall for another four-year term will come to a climax Wednesday before the Court of Appeals in Albany.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 13 -- "Even if you want to forget all about the War, you just can't overlook a thing like its 100th anniversary," the National Parks Service historian at Fort Sumter said here today.

SET Reginald Allen down on an uninhabited Pacific island and he would probably be happier than he is in his present position. The executive director for operations of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts admitted as much as he gazed wistfully out of the windows of his office on the fifteenth floor of the Coliseum.

RYE, N.Y., April 15 -- Robert P. Hughes, who was "dumped by the party" after six years as Mayor of this city, has not decided whether he will fight for renomination in the Republican primary next Sept. 7. Meanwhile, at the will of Governor Rockefeller, he is retaining his $11,700-a-year post as deputy director of the state Civil Defense Commission.
BALTIMORE, April 15 (AP) -- Steve Barber, a left-hander, pitched the Orioles to an 8 -- 0 victory over the Minnesota Twins today.

American schools have rediscovered foreign languages. Now a frantic search for good teachers and good teaching has begun. Mao Tse-tung was born in November, 1893, in the Hunanese village of Shao Shan and was educated as a teacher in Changsha, the provincial capital. His political career began in 1917 when he was 24. By then he had rebelled against the established order and had gathered about him a care of youths, some of whom are prominent today.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 15 -- The Central Government and representatives of President Moise Tshombe of Katanga opened talks here today on the normalization of economic relations between Katanga Province and the rest of the country.

CHESHIRE, Conn., April 15 -- Sam Huff, Bill Stewart and the Rev. Robert G. Keating will speak at Waverly Inn here on April 28 at the ninth annual awards dinner of the UConn Club.
RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, April 12 -- The day of the "foreign expert" is dawning here as Saudi Arabia prepares her first economic development program.

THE best literary magazine in South America is Sur of Buenos Aires; it has been the best for precisely thirty years. Its appearance in January, 1931, was a bright note in a time of singularly ill omen. Its "trigesimo aniversario" number, just out, shows how well it defied the omens and pointed its arrows toward the future.

BECAUSE he was a recent indigent, insane (by contemporary standards) and born in Italy -- a country whose immigration quota is heavily oversubscribed -- Christopher Columbus could never have qualified for a United States tourist visa. Nevertheless, he was the first "foreign visitor'' to these shores.

ST. LOUIS, April 15 (AP) -- Ernie Broglio, a twenty-one-game winner for the St. Louis Cardinals last season, shut out the Cincinnati Reds, 4 -- 0, today. He gave two singles in a rain-shortened five-inning game.
Our "British cousins" seem to be making progress in atomic power at about the same rate as we are.

THE revival of interest in crystal for home decoration culminated in an exhibition of twelve crystal gardens, which opened last week. These Italianate sixteenth-and seventeenth-century creations on display at Tiffany's until May 5, are the product of Charles Lin Tissot's dreaming and designing over the last decade.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Soviet Union has promised to reply within a few days to Western proposals for an early and peaceful settlement of the Laotian crisis.
ALBANY, April 15 -- Governor Rockefeller is back on the campaign trail.

HAVANA, April 15 -- Two youths were executed by firing squad in La Cabana Fortress across the bay from Havana last night. They had been convicted of terroristic acts in the Isle of Pines by a military court in the fortress yesterday afternoon.

LONG since, it has become the custom among us reviewers to get upset when Conrad Aiken publishes a book. The line which that upset takes is pretty consistent. It is a complaint that so prodigious and distinguished a writer (and Aiken is now in his seventies) is still less defined, less honored and, above all, less read than he deserves to be.

Is the post-war surge of religious feeling coming to an end? There are signs that it is. One is that the nation's Protestant, Catholic and Jewish leaders find they are unable to attract enough youths to religious vocations.

A small, sturdy Navy cargo ship that has seen service in ice-choked Arctic waters will be transformed into an elaborate seagoing scientific laboratory that will increase this country's knowledge of the Antarctic.

HAVING followed Warren Tute's progress book by book, this reviewer is particularly pleased to report that in this latest novel he has at last achieved an unmistakable success.
