A group of citizens interested in educational television for New York City appeared last night to have a strong chance of acquiring Station WNTA-TV for noncommercial programing.

IN this electronic age it is a rare soul who has not wondered or worried over the effects of television on children. DALLAS, April 15 (UPI) -- Louise Suggs ignored cold, strong winds today and moved three strokes ahead at 218 after three rounds of the $10,000 Civitan women's open golf tournament. Miss Suggs had a two-over-par 37, 36 -- 73 today at the Glen Lakes Country Club.

AN increasing number of business executives are facing a problem far removed from the profit-and-loss, tax-loophole and mass-marketing puzzlers they used to encounter in their Harvard "B School" textbooks. JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 15 -- President Sukarno signed regulations today permitting only eight political parties, including the Communists, in Indonesia's guided democracy. The fate of two additional parties will be decided later.

The French ballet stars Liane Dayde and Michel Renault are donating their services in the ballet Raymundo de Larrain is creating for the Embassy Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria April 28. The Yankees, with a helping hand from their old Kansas City cousins, the Athletics, crashed through with their first victory of the season at the Stadium yesterday. Before a gathering of 11,802 chilled fans, Ralph Houk's Bombers brought down the Athletics, 5 to 3, in the opener of a three-game series.

The New York City Charter, drafted twenty-four years ago, has often been criticized because the powers it created in many cases overlap or conflict. SALISBURY, South Rhodesia, April 16 (UPI) -- Duli Chid a Rhodesian boxer who trained with a set of "magic" pipes applied by his witch doctor, failed to show up today for his fight with C.D. Mienie of South Africa.

RETALHULEU, Guatemala, April 16 -- The Pacific slope area surrounding Retalhuleu, which in the last several months developed into a focal point of preparations for a possible armed clash with Cuba, now appears to be almost inactive.

Dr. Robert M. Hutchins announced yesterday that the Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions would undertake a two-year study of the American character. He is the president of the center, which has its headquarters in Santa Barbara, Calif.
The Transit Authority has a new poster depicting some of its subway and bus riders as charging bulls, blocking hippopotamuses and ostriches with their heads in the sand.
I have read with great interest the series of four articles on unemployment by A.H. Raskin. They present a remarkably compact summary of the whole problem.

MUNICH, April 16 -- Recently a European envoy to the North Atlantic Council reported to his Foreign Minister: "Something is moving at last in NATO." This is true. The whole alliance is suddenly filled with an enthusiastic spirit after months of lassitude.

Now that most persons agree the recession is coming to an end, business men and economists around the country are trying to anticipate the pattern of recovery. Will there be a sharp upturn or a slow, laborious upward climb?
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- A machinist union condemned "moonlighting," or multiple job-holding, today as a factor in unemployment and a threat to good working conditions.
MOSCOW, April 16 (Reuters) -- Two ways of retrieving a space ship from orbit were described today in an article in Ekonomicheskaya Gazeta (Economic Gazette).
An interview with Capt. Orestes Acosta, who said he was one of the Cuban Air Force pilots who attacked Cuban cities Saturday, was released early today by United Press International.

Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley criticized the City Planning Commission yesterday for its rejection of his program for fifteen parking garages to be built in midtown Manhattan at a cost of $52,000,000.
Ten apartments in the Manhattan House will have their doors open to visitors on the afternoon of April 25 in a fund-raising effort for the Neighbors United.

Garson Kanin confirmed a report yesterday that the way had been cleared by him to undertake the staging of "Sunday in New York," a romantic comedy by Norman Krasna. Consequently, Mr. Kanin has deferred his adaptation of Lael Tucker Wertenbaker's "Death of a Man," which is to be staged by him.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Government officials were avoiding probing questions today on the point of origin of the B-26 planes that bombed three Cuban military air bases yesterday. The questions were prompted by some puzzling circumstances attending the attack and the statement made by one of the pilots, who landed his damaged bomber at Miami International Airport.

AN Associated Press dispatch from Buenos Aires last night had the United States leading Argentina by thirty-two international match points and France seven points ahead of Italy in the second day of the world-championship bridge matches being played there.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Air Force scientists have discovered, they say, that the earth is completely enveloped by a three-mile-thick band of tiny particles -- mainly of sulphur -- starting at an altitude of about eleven miles.

FREDERICKSBURG, Tex., April 16 -- Texas welcomed Chancellor Adenauer today with cheers, songs, a barbecue and a ten-gallon hat. The West German leader, usually aus tere, responded first with surprise, then with smiles and jokes.

MUTTONTOWN, L.I., -- Billou Farms' Silver Lady, ridden by Bernie Traurig of Syosset, L.I., won the working hunter championship of the Glen Head Horse Show tonight. The gray mare beat Ralph Petersen's Gangster by 2 points.
MADRID, April 15 -- A few days ago the extreme right-wing Spanish newspaper Arriba paid a generous tribute to the retiring United States Ambassador, John Davis Lodge.

Jerry Lucas, the Ohio State star, arrived yesterday, confident that he and his all-star team-mates would give Soviet basketball players something to "jump about."

Roman Catholics were asked yesterday to give at least one day's wage or income to the 1961 fund appeal of New York Catholic Charities.

A depressingly persistent downpour drenched the city and the metropolitan area most of yesterday. It kept many New Yorkers indoors, stalled motorists, hampered major league baseball schedules and brought seagulls in to Central Park.

Foreign exchange market maintained a steady undertone during the past week. British pound sterling and Canadian dollar fluctuated narrowly on moderate dealings.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -President Kennedy plans to ask Congress tomorrow for legislation creating a new Department of Housing and Urban Affairs. But the exact boundaries of the authority of the proposed agency of cabinet rank remain a matter of controversy within the Administration.
LUANDA, Angola, April 16 (Reuters) -- Troops flew here from Portugal today as authorities mapped plans for a showdown with rebels on the fighting in the north of this West African territory.

"THE BROTHERS M,"* by Tom Stacey, is the most unusual and the most ambitious novel written about Africa in many years. Harry Canelstein, New York and Florida realty investor, has contracted to buy the shopping center at 221-13 to 221-25 Linden Boulevard, corner of 221st Street, Laurelton, Queens. Salvatere Pisano of the Acro Realty Corporation was the broker in the sale.

At President Kennedy's invitation, Prime Minister Karamanlis of Greece is visiting Washington to discuss the problems of his country, a keystone in the southern flank of the North Atlantic alliance. PARIS, April 17 -- Moscow's Vakhtangov Theatre opened tonight the dramatic series of the Theatre des Nations with a presentation of "An Irkutsk Story," a modern Soviet play by Aleksei N. Arbuzov. The performance was received enthusiastically by the audience at the Sarah Bernhardt Theatre.

Universal Match Corporation announced yesterday that merger talks with Universal Controls, Inc., had been "temporarily deferred" because directors of the latter company failed to meet requirements set by Universal Match.
TORONTO, April 17 (Canadian Press) -- Gunnar Mining, Ltd. northern Saskatchewan uranium producer, cleared $5,184,263, or $1.46 a share, in 1960, compared with $8,951,234, or $2.56 a share, in 1959.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 17 -- A United Nations source indicated tonight that a new Congo supply line was being opened for troops and possibly for supplies going to Katanga Province.
MIAMI, April-17 -- Intercepted military messages by radio were the first source today, of direct information from Cuba on the invasion by anti-Castro rebels.
The vanguard of 60,000 corporation executives and their office managers watched machines "talking" to machines over special telephones at the New York Coliseum yesterday.
A "propaganda" car to spur public and industry interest in automotive safety design was shown yesterday by the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company.
New York University yesterday completed its basketball coaching staff for the 1961-62, season.
A profit projection figure prepared by the American Export Company's controller for the line's board of directors was assailed yesterday as based "on ignorance."
LONDON, April 17 (Reuters) -- Tottenham Hotspur tonight clinched the English Soccer League's First Division championship with a 2-1 victory over its nearest rival, Sheffield Wednesday.
The Chase Manhattan Bank has filed an application with the State Banking Department to open a branch at 2035 Crompond Road, Yorktown Heights, Westchester County.
A group of young men and women who are members of the National Arts Club have arranged their annual spring ball for April 29 in the gallery of the club at 15 Gramercy Park.
PARIS, April 17 -- The United States will propose tomorrow the establishment of three "working groups" to make detailed studies of the three main economic problems confronting the Western world.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 17 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold appealed today for support in his efforts to stave off a worsening of the United Nations' financial crisis.
President Kennedy thinks of Robert W. Dowling as a man "whose dynamic dedication to all that is healthy in man and society is an inspiration."
In its latest note to Britain on Laos the Soviet Union has again failed to be specific with regard to the timing and verification of a cease-fire in the Laotian civil war.

ONE of the disadvantages a mid-April trout season opening came to the front a couple of days ago when Massachusetts spring fishing began: it is exactly the same time that the fast-water canoeists exult in risking their lives.
LOS ANGELES, April 17 (UPI) -- A $38,000,000 payment for a 260-acre motion picture lot cleared the way today for the construction of Century City.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Dr. Henry D. Smyth, a former member of the Atomic Energy Commission, was reported tonight to be under serious consideration by the Kennedy Administration as the new United States representative to the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna.

LONDON, April 17 -- The battle of conversation between Joe Brown, the lightweight champion of the world, and Dave Charnley, the challenger, ended today. Tomorrow night their fists will do the talking before a crowd of 18,000 at Earls Court Arena.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 17 (AP) -- Barbara McIntire, who won last year, scored an easy first-round victory today in the North and South women's amateur golf tournament. But three of her chief challengers in the field of thirty-two lost.
ADDIS, ABABA, Ethiopia, April 17 (Reuters) -- Emperor Haile Selassie has completed a major ministerial reshuffle, which has been under way since an abortive coup d'etat in December.

IT is always a pleasure to see craft and skill in action. Some fine technicians have put their skills to work in current exhibitions: Marvin Cherney at the Crystal Galleries, 54 East Fifty-eighth Street; Frank Gaudio at the Grippi Gallery, 200 East Fifty-ninth Street, and "Three Young Americans," Donald Berry, Eva Hess and Harold Jacobs, at John Heller's, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street.

For the second night of her season at "the Fifty-fourth Street Theatre, Martha Graham last night introduced two of her familiar works into the reportory and repeated the premiere of the opening night, Visionary Recital."
AUSTIN, Tex., April 17 -- Chancellor Adenauer of West Germany has warned that reforms and rejuvenation are urgently needed in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization lest the alliance disintegrate.
Brass music was the feature of the Carnegie Recital Hall concert of the National Association for American Composers and Conductors last night.
Gian Carlo Menotti's "The Saint of Bleecker Street" will be revived here by the Xavier Symphony Society at the end of April and the biginning of May.
Whitey Ford and Mickey Mantle, who have been doing business together for a number of years, worked as a tandem yesterday as the Yankees gained a sparkling 3-0 triumph over the Kansas City Athletics.
BOGOTA, Colombia, April 17 -- Heavy concentrations of helmeted troops and policemen were strategically placed in this capital tonight to prevent outbreaks by supporters of Fidel Castro.

YOUNGSTERS in schools that are about to be desegregated through "open enrollment" procedures should be prepared for the coming change, a specialist in intergroup relations said yesterday. However, she implied, over-zealous and short-sighted campaigns to "teach tolerance" by denying differences can sometimes aggravate the very misunderstandings they aim to eliminate.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. -- April 17 -- The United States proposed today a resolution on aid to Palestinian Arab refugees that it described as being "devoid of controversy."
The five-story apartment house at 2135-39 Grand Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by the Gran Reality Company for cash over mortgages of $290,000, according to Leonard, Levites, Schiller, brokers.
Leading sales finance companies announced reductions yesterday of one-eighth to one-half percentage point in the rates on their unsecured short-term obligations sold directly to investors.

Rear Admiral Winfield Scott Cunningham arrived at Wake Island on Nov. 28, 1941, to take command of the island's defenses. On Dec. 23, after fifteen days of attacks by the Japanese, he surrendered his forces to the enemy. The story of the defense became the basis of a motion picture glorifying the action.
Four New York and New Jersey official agencies are making a joint study of how 1,676,000 persons employed in the main business district of Manhattan travel to and from their jobs.

The nomination of W. Scott Cluett, of Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., for president of the Bond Club of New York was announced yesterday. Mr. Cluett would succeed Raymond D. Spitzer, of White, Weld Co., who has headed the club for the past year.
Steel production continued its upward course last week. Industry output climbed to an estimated 60 per cent capacity, compared with 58 per cent two weeks ago and 56 per cent three weeks ago.

Tom Mboya, Kenya's African nationalist leader, warned here yesterday that the African and Asian nations might withdraw from the British Commonwealth unless South Africa was excluded from the Commonwealth's system of economic preferences.

The Seeburg Corporation and the American Machine and Foundry Company have joined with the British Australian Tobacco Company to form Seeburg Automatic Products, Ltd., a vending machine operation in Australia.

EDGEWATER, N.J., April 17 -- The annual spawning run of the shad up the Hudson River started in earnest today. Fishermen from this waterfront town and far up the valley were ready with nets strung along the western edge of the channel.

AT least two triangles involving a man, a woman and a tree seem to have had considerable effect on man's eating habits. The most ancient example may have given rise to the apple industry, while a more recent version is supposed to have given birth to the maple syrup industry.
There are discrepant trends in the Administration's new defense budget and in the plans and studies now being made in the Pentagon.

The first benefit of the Friends of Retarded Children of Westchester County, an auxiliary of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children, will be a theatre dance program for children by the Merry-Go Rounders, a professional troupe sponsored by the Westchester Children's Theatre.

LONDON, April 17 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Selwyn Lloyd proposed to Parliament today a budget for 1961-62 designed to curb inflation, encourage exports and increase the nation's rate of industrial expansion.
The schism between the men of letters and the men of science is not so wide or deep as some have pictured it, Dr. Alan T. Waterman, director of the National Science Foundation, said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- President Kennedy sent a far-reaching farm bill to Congress today, with a statement stressing "the interrelation between prosperity on the farm and economic health in the city."
A public offering of $9,000,000 of 6 1/2 per cent twenty-year debentures and 400,000 common shares of Winston-Muss Corporation is being made today by Lee Higginson Corporation and associates.

TRENTON, April 17 -- New Jersey residents will nominate major party candidates for Governor tomorrow, along with candidates for ten of twenty-one State Senate seats and for all sixty seats in the Assembly.

Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., raised its sales and earnings in the first quarter by 5 per cent from the 1960 levels, and both figures were records for the period. John E. McKeen, president of the company reported the results to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

Mikhail Botvinnik and Mikhail Tal adjourned their thirteenth game yesterday in the world chess tournament in Moscow after forty moves.
An agent for four tenements owned by Herbert S. Wolfe, a convicted abortionist who was jailed last year for a month on housing violations, was fined $625 yesterday in Housing Court.

Frederick S. Beebe has been elected chairman of The Washington Post Company and vice chairman of Newsweek, Inc.
LONDON, April 17 -- The Conservatives have been in power for ten years, and they are still winning, Labor's Daily Herald lamented today.

JACK PRICE, a comparative newcomer to the turf, has shocked and outraged all true believers in the godlike quality of thoroughbreds. The little guy from Cleveland has assumed the attitude that he is a hardboiled business man who regards his high-towered 3-year-old, Carry Back, as merely a money-making machine.

ALBANY, April 17 -- Governor Rockefeller signed a bill today that requires New York City to set up a central bureau at which the records of all housing violations will be available for inspection, building by building.

CHICAGO, April 17 (AP) -- Soybean futures and their byproducts were under heavy selling pressure almost all day on the Board of Trade today and losses were at or near the permissible limits for a single day.
Masina, the highly-touted French mare, gained an advantage over Su Mac Lad, the top United States candidate, when post positions for the $50,000 United Nations Trot were drawn yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 17 -- Dr. Raul Roa, Foreign Minister of Cuba, charged today that his country had been invaded this morning "by a force of mercenaries, organized, financed and armed by the Government of the United States."

JEWELRY fanciers with a fetish for collecting pretty colorful guard rings will fine many to fascinate them as Eve's Jewel Boutique. In her tiny pink, red and white shop 794 Madison Avenue (at Sixty-seventh Street) Eve has assembled an assortment at extremely reasonable prices.

Manhattan Syndicate, Inc., Gerald Hershcopf, president, has sold the property at 470 to 474 Third Avenue, northwest corner of Thirty-second Street, to Julian L. Cohn, a builder. The buyer plans a nineteen-story apartment house on the site.
The story of how children in a lower East Side tenement were diverted from delinquency came out yesterday at the Board of Estimate's budget hearing.

This will be Homecoming Day for some of the deposed New Yorkers who will be in the line-up of the Los Angeles Angels when the West Coast club plays here today for the first time. The Angels meet the Yankees at the Stadium at 2 P.M.

Permit me to take exception to Prof. Michael Cardozo's letter in The Times of April 11. Professor Cardozo is wrong in criticizing The Times' editorial of April 1, dealing with the Melekh case. The State Department was right in originally rejecting diplomatic immunity for Mr. Melekh and wrong in granting it later.

TO the disappointment of bridge players in this country, but strictly in accordance with the pre-tournament prognostications of the "wise money" in Europe, the world-championship matches in Buenos Aires have started out with Italy in the lead, France second, the United States third and Argentina a poor fourth.

The election of Gene K. Beare as president of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., was announced yesterday. The organization is a wholly owned subsidiary of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation.

Superintendent of Schools John J. Theobald gave New Yorkers sensationally bad news about their schools when he announced that over 67,000 youngsters of the junior high school enrollment of 172,000 are more than two years retarded in their reading. About 10,000 seventh-graders, he said, are unable to read third-grade books.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the new Soviet note on Laos did not satisfy the United States on the timing and verification of a cease-fire.

Twenty-nine local government agencies working on slum clearance and urban renewal projects will borrow $96,000,000 in the public market on short term on April 25. The money will be raised on notes guaranteed by the Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose again yesterday as the market staged a slow but unbroken advance and ended with a gain of almost one-half of 1 per cent in aggregate market values.
MOSCOW, April 17 (UPI) -Maj. Yuri Gagarin is moving up in the world now that he has been acclaimed as the first man to soar out of it.
TUCSON, Ariz., April 17 -- By the year 2000 most Americans will be drinking water that is re-used three times or more, Senator Robert S. Kerr said today.

HARRISBURG, Pa., April 17 -- Thousands of persons welcomed former President Dwight D. Eisenhower and Mrs. Eisenhower home to Pennsylvania today. The gathering was the state's official welcome for General Eisenhower, who left the White House Jan. 20.

All outstanding stop orders in American Stock Exchange round lots must be cancelled at the close of business on Friday, the exchange ruled yesterday. Thereafter, until further notice, Edward T. McCormick, Exchange president, announced yesterday, specialists may not accept such orders.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- President Kennedy's request for a Latin-American aid appropriation of $500,000,000 received a sour reception in Congress, according to testimony that was disclosed today.

The Maryinsky Ballet Company from Leningrad will make its first North American tour under the auspices of S. Hurok next season. Stockholders and top management are finding themselves pushed to the wall this year, as the campaign to plug what some persons call "tax loopholes" gains momentum. Babu and Air Pilot, the oldest as well as the longest-priced horses in the race, were first and second in the featured U.S.O. Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

The Alumni Association of the Institute of Political Studies of the University of Paris has arranged its second annual Soiree Sciences Po for April 28 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

A slowdown, primarily in the volume of waterborne imports that has persisted, throughout the first quarter of this year, has been responsible for a substantial reduction in customs revenues in the Port of News York.

The public will get the vicarious thrill of orbiting the earth in a space capsule and being picked up at sea by a helicopter during the color movie "Man In Space," opening today at the American Museum of Natural History.
A behind-the-scenes rift, stemming from objections to the procedure employed in presenting special Antoinette Perry theatre awards to David Merrick and the Theatre Guild, came to light yesterday.

ALBANY, April 17 -- The bitter struggle that split the North and South a century ago was vividly recalled today as the state opened its centennial observance of the Civil War.

Jesse Weingart, a co-owner of the original franchise for a New York team in the new National Bowling League, notified the league yesterday that he intended to sue because his franchise rights had been terminated.

The establishment of a New York City university suggests the exciting prospect of a unique municipal medical school. WASHINGTON, April 17 -Senators investigating pricefixing and bid-rigging by electrical equipment manufacturers learned today how the companies frequently agreed among themselves on which was to be the low bidder on Federal, municipal and corporate contracts.
