Gus Hall, general secretary of the Communist party in the United States, issued a statement yesterday calling the invasion of Cuba "an act of perfidy," "open export of counterrevolution" and an "act of imperialist aggression."

BUENOS AIRES, April 18 -- Expanded technical aid for Latin America in the form of increased training of both labor and management in production skills is being planned by international experts meeting here today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 18 -- An Arab-supported resolution that would have the General Assembly act to safeguard the "property rights" in Israel of Palestinian refugees was approved today.

World sugar futures prices on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange moved higher again yesterday in the most active day of trading this year. The market continued to be heavily influenced by Cuban developments.
The Labor Department's chief manpower analyst said here yesterday that five groups represented "intractable problems of unemployment" in this country.

I belong to a small group of people of the Warsaw Ghetto who survived the Nazi slaughter. Out 500,000 Jews, only about twenty thirty thousand remained -- about to 3 per cent of the population. The others were murdered without exception: the aged, children and infants.

THE long-expected erection of new short-wave radio facilities in Cuba, over which Premier Fidel Castro can beam his revolutionary views to the Western Hemisphere and much of the rest of the world, appears to have been completed.
Federal subsidies for the construction and operation of United States-flag ships in foreign trade were defended here last night as necessary to the nation's defense and commercial well-being.

" Our Share of Morning," the personal experiences of Paul Burmetz in eluding the Germans during the war, will be issued April 28 by Doubleday. Mr. Burmetz was a young mathematician at the Physics Institute in Vienna when the Germans invaded Austria in 1938.

A group of 500 chanting pro-Castro demonstrators, many carrying anti-United States placards, picketed outside the United Nations building yesterday in protest against alleged United States participation in the rebel attacks on Cuba.
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 18 -The Kenya African Democratic Union agreed tonight to cooperate in the formation of a government, thus resolving a deadlock that had lasted forty-eight days.

Automobile accidents involving personal injuries totaled 706 in the city last week. This was sixty-three fewer than the number recorded for the same period a year ago, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday.

The threats from the Russian and Chinese Communists to intervene militarily on behalf of the Castro regime cannot be accepted by the United States. There will be widespread agreement with President Kennedy's firm reply to Premier Khrushchev: "In the event of any military intervention by outside force we will immediately honor our obligations under the inter-American system to protect this hemisphere against external aggression."

THE favored Italian bridge team, world champions three times during the last six years, played according to form in its first sessions against the United States in the world tournament at Buenos Aires Monday and got off to a lead of twenty-nine international match points.
ALBANY, April 18 (AP) -Governor Rockefeller, replying to criticism from a labor leader, said today his record spoke for itself.

THIS is the "tired" season. It comes at the end of a long, hard winter. It is the time of year when many parents rest in southern vacationlands. Part of the rest cure consists of leaving their adolescent children at home.
LONDON, April 18 -- The Soviet Union has demanded what amounts to a veto on the findings of the International Control Commission in Laos when that body is reactivated.

The Board of Estimate hearings on Mayor Wagner's $2,542,120,936 executive budget for 1961-62, which are a three-day town meeting, occurred at a time when they were blanketed by world events. Nevertheless some important points were made, and recorded, for Mayor Wagner to consider as one of his most important responsibilities upon return from Florida.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Senate Democrats and liberal Republicans easily defeated today four proposals that would have limited the Administration's bill to increase the minimum wage and extend its coverage.
As soon as "Becket" received the Tony award for being the best play of the season, David Ierrick, producer, accelerated reparations to bring the winner back to New York.

The proposed acquisition of the fourteen-ship fleet of the Isbrandtsen Steamship Company, Inc., by American Export Lines would leave Export $2,825,625 short of meeting its cash requirements over a five-year period, a Federal Maritime Board examiner was told yesterday.
MONTREAL, April 18 -- Delegates to a conference on supersonic airliners took a worried look today at some old subsonic problems.
BOSTON, April 18 (AP) -- A slim schoolteacher from Groton, Conn., and a couple of lean, hard Finns rank as the likely favorites for the sixty-fifth running tomorrow of the Boston A.A. Marathon.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The danger now in U.S.-Soviet relations is that Premier Khrushchev will overplay his hand.

It was gratifying to note that you published on March 30 the letter of Charles A. Hickmann, so ably presenting the Catholic stand on the school question. May I make a few remarks about Allie L. Olafson's interesting letter of opposition published April 7.

MIAMI, April 18 (UPI) -- A Cuban broadcast said tonight at least 200 persons had been arrested in the small beach resort of Varadero on the north coast. The broadcast said "we have made a total clean-up here and have sent 200 prisoners to Matanzas (the provincial capital)."
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 20 points off to 8 points up yesterday. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 18 -- The United States agreed today to take on again nearly half of the financial burden of the military operation in the Congo as an emergency move to prevent the bankruptcy of the United Nations.
The New York Telephone Company has started construction of a twenty-one-story building without windows on the blockfront on the west side of Tenth Avenue between Fifty-third and Fiftyfourth Streets.
Construction will begin today on a deep-level express tunnel for the Sixth Avenue IND subway between the West Fourth Street and Thirty-fourth Street stations.
PITTSBURGH, April 18 (AP) -- The Pirates won their home opener today, beating the Chicago Cubs, 5-3, on a two-run rally in the seventh inning.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- The Kennedy Administration so far has not kept its promises of an open-door information policy, a committee said today in a report to the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

BALBOA, C.Z., April 18 -- For the first time since 1957, the Panama Canal was forced today to issue draft restrictions for larger ships. Such restrictions are customary when the level of Gatun Lake, through which ships pass across the Continental Divide, falls to eighty-four feet.

Attorneys for the American Jewish Congress and the American Civil Liberties Union issued a statement here yesterday terming a decision last Saturday of a Dade County Circuit Court judge on Miami's religion-in-the-schools case "a victory for religious freedom."

The Melville Shoe Company has leased a floor in the nine-story storage warehouse building at 628 West Forty-fifth Street, southeast corner of Twelfth Avenue, for its Miles division. The floor containing 11,000 square feet of space, will be used for storing pocketbooks and handbags.
Chief of Chiefs, the third choice in a four-horse field, won the $10,000 White Skies Handicap yesterday before a crowd of 23,118 at rain-soaked Aqueduct.
MOSCOW, April 18 -- Premier Khrushchev's message today to President Kennedy:

JERUSALEM, Wednesday, April 19 -- Israel has embarked on the rough equivalent of a filibuster in the Israeli-Jordanian Mixed Armistice Commission in an apparent effort to avoid condemnation for having massed tanks and heavy armaments in Jerusalem.
LONDON, April 18 -- A former Government official was charged today with communicating information that might be directly or indirectly useful to an enemy power.
MIAMI, April 18 -- Miami's 30,000 Cuban exiles hovered between enthusiasm and anxiety today as they awaited news of the outcome of yesterday's landing in Cuba by anti-Castro forces.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- President Kennedy's education program made its first progress in Congress today when a House subcommittee approved a $2,400,000,000 college aid bill.
UNITED STATES NAVAL BASE, Guantanamo Bay Cuba, Wednesday, April 19 -- The apparent arrest of several Americans in Havana was reported here today.
ACCRA, Ghana, April 18 -- President Kwame Nkrumah announced today that Ghana was sending an Ambassador to Stanleyville accredited to the Communist-backed government of Antoine Gizenga.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara defended again today the Administration's decision to cut back the B-70 high-altitude, high-speed bomber program.
CHICAGO, April 18 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 18 -- A reinforced police guard was on duty tonight around the United States Information Agency building in downtown Belgrade. Three large plate glass windows were smashed by stones during the early morning hours to protest developments in Cuba.
The Moiseyev Dance Company returned to the Metropolitan Opera House last night and performed a rousing rock 'n' roll number before a glittering audience.

Heaviness returned to the market values of prime corporate debt investments yesterday. The trading session saw little business in United States Government securities outside the short-term area. An atmosphere of caution prevailed in the secondary market for local government obligations.

DETROIT, April 18 -- The management slate of the Chrysler Corporation won an overwhelming victory at the company's annual meeting today despite a barrage of criticism and constant heckling by a hostile stockholder group.

KNOXVILLE, TENN., April 18 (AP) -- The first witnesses in a Federal antitrust suit against the United Mine Workers Union testified yesterday that the union had used violence in trying to force small coal, operators to sign contract with it.

THE choice at fresh fruit counters at this time of year is slim. Grapefruit is deliciously juicy and tart. Oranges can be very good and so can fresh strawberries, although the price tag on the latter is often high. Bananas are always "in season," but most other offerings leave something to be desired.

WINNIPEG, Man., April 18 (Canadian Press) -- The Hudson's Bay Company reported today a trading profit of $7,280,000 after taxes for the year ended Jan. 31, 1961, compared with $6,986,000 in the preceding year.

After the gold watch, what comes for the retired person? Milk toast, and bitter memories or a carefree life? In an economic discussion of old age, "After the Gold Watch, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, comments on the fast rising number of older citizens.

Morehead Patterson, chairman of the American Machine and Foundry Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday, that sales, rentals and earnings in the first quarter of this year were at record levels.

YONKERS, April 18 -- Much is being made of Thursday night's $50,000 United Nations Trot, in which Su Mac Lad and Air Record have been invited to race against a French mare, Masina, and other European standardbred aces.
Charlie Conerly, a quarterback who will be 40 years old in September, signed his 1961 contract with the New York Giants yesterday.
Following is the text of a communique issued yesterday in New York by the Cuban Revolutionary Council:

President Kennedy's message on the Federal regulatory agencies represents a forward move the importance of which is measured by the pervasiveness of their power and the need for their improvement. It is hard to think of any aspect of our economic life that is not affected by the rulings of these agencies.
BOSTON, April 18 (AP) -- Bill Pleis, a rookie left-hander, came to the rescue of Jim Kaat in the eighth inning today and preserved a 3-2 victory for the Minnesota Twins over the Red Sox.
LONDON, April 18 (Reuters) -- Britain's trade gap -the surplus of imports over exports and re-exports -- rose to 74,100,000 ($207,480,000) during March, the British Board of Trade disclosed today.

The New York City Housing Authority borrowed $26,450,000 on temporary loan notes yesterday to finance development of the Robert A. Taft Houses, a Manhattan project sponsored by municipal tax forgiveness.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Amalgamated Clothing Workers notified the White House today that it was calling off its boycott of Japanese textiles used in the manufacture of men's clothing.

The trend of the rubber industry now is upward, the presidents of the United States Rubber Company and of the B.F. Goodrich Company told shareholders at their annual meetings yesterday. This year's capital expenditures of the two big producers will be the largest for any year in their history.
Assisted by an earlier Easter this year, the nation's major retail chains showed a gain of 13.9 per cent in March from the 1960 level, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 18 -- Italy was elected today a member of the United Nations Economic and Social Council, breaking a deadlock that had existed since the General Assembly met last December to fill the vacancies.

Francis M, McDermott, an expert on air traffic control who has been critical of Federal Aviation Agency policies in this field, has resigned as executive director of the Air Traffic Control Association.
Yesterday morning, Erskine Bars was picked up for littering the subway and was fined $5 by Magistrate Edward J. Chapman in Upper Manhattan Summons Court.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- The United States has informed the Netherlands that it is ready to resume talks on landing rights at Los Angeles for KLM Royal Dutch Airlines.
" I am not sure who's attacking Cuba," Adlai E. Stevenson said last night, "but I know who's attacking us."
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- President Kennedy asked Congress today to create a Cabinet-level Department of Urban Affairs and Housing.

DALLAS, Tex. (AP) -- A $4,750,000 decline in gas revenues last month from the 1960 level still leaves Lone Star Gas Company first-quarter profits slightly above last year's, L.T. Potter, reported at the annual meeting.

The largest of the so-called "tax-free exchange"" type of mutual funds -- Federal Street Fund, Inc. -- has started its operations with assets of $153,502,419, making it the thirty-third largest mutual fund in existence.
The rebel landings in Cuba temporarily have halted a basketball tour of the Soviet Union by thirty-one American men and women.
PALO ALTO, Calif., April 18 -- Stanford University set out today in pursuit of $100,000,000.

THE "drowned-in-fur" look was thrown out the window into the rain yesterday at Gunther Jaeckel's salon in Bonwit Teller. It was replaced by elegant, "little nothing" furs that were rich in dressmaker details.
James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor in the Eisenhower Administration, came from behind last night to capture the Republican nomination for Governor in New Jersey.
ALBANY, April 18 -- An investigation of the administration of the Levittown, L.I., school system was ordered today by James E. Allen Jr., state Commissioner of Education.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 18 -- For the first time since 1956, the steadily ascending graph of world coffee production was reversed last year with a fall of 18 per cent from the preceding year's peak, the Food and Agriculture Organization reports in its latest Bulletin of Agricultural Statistics.
Liquidity, or the ability to sell readily, has gained in importance in the last few years the syndication of real estate, according to a leader in the held on Long Island.

The official Soviet statements issued yesterday on the subject of Cuba contained, among their many distortions, two that deserve particular attention since they refer to the broad spectrum of Soviet policy.
MOSCOW, April 18 (AP) -- Following is the text of a Soviet Government statement on Cuba as distributed today by the Soviet press agency Tass:
TUCSON, Ariz., April 18 -- The proposed Delaware River Basin compact was hailed today as the possible forerunner of further Federal-state development of national water resources.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 (UPI) -- Bob Purkey scattered six hits and Gordon Coleman clouted a three-run homer in the six-run third inning as the Cincinnati Reds routed the San Francisco Giants, 9 -- 1, and gained the National League lead tonight.
GENEVA, April 18 -- The United States and Britain made a major tactical move today in the deadlocked nuclear test-ban conference. It met a cool Soviet reaction.
Two major developers, both engaged in the city's slum clearance program, have qualified to bid at tomorrow's auction of city property in the Brooklyn Civic Center area.

The American Bankers Association, which numbers as members 96 per cent of the 14,000 banks in the United States, has named a vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas as its new permanent executive.

BELKACEM KRIM, the Algerian rebel Deputy Premier who is expected to head the Provisional Government's delegation in peace talks with the French, is at once the pragmatist of the Algerian revolution and its architect.
The Red Cross will receive blood today at Manhattan College, Riverdale, the Bronx.

THE National Design Center] is doing its part toward reducing migraines in early mar-I riage. What might be called the most comprehensive home! furnishings show ever to be compiled with the bride in mind opens today at the center at 415 East Fifty-third Street.
A long, thin, sharp-featured 30-year-old man named Adam Keefe is the first comic to reach the big-time night-club circuit via the Greenwich Village coffeehouses.

TUNIS, April 18 -- The Algerian rebel Provisional Government was reported today to be preparing for peace negotiations with the French Government. The talks are expected to begin at Evian-les-Bains, in southeastern France, between April 28 and May 5.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The selection of missile sites upwind from major population centers has needlessly exposed several million Americans to dangerous fall-out in the event of atomic attack, a physicist charged today.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Administration will ask Congress to extend the life of the Civil Rights Commission, which is now scheduled to go out of business next November.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma of Laos abruptly canceled today his trip to Washington to discuss with officials an easing of the Laotian crisis.
Advertisers and their agencies who had hoped for help from the National Association of Broadcasters in their fight against increased commercial time on television are going to be disappointed.

The Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation is increasing its production of Gulf-stream jet transports from two to three a month, it was reported at the annual meeting in Bethpage, L.I., yesterday. Company officials said that Grumman had sold seventy-two of the planes so far and that the Navy was considering the purchase of some.

John Fleming bills himself as a baritone-actor, and quite rightly. Last night in Carnegie Recital Hall, he sang a program of folk songs. In the middle of it, as he has done in previous appearances, he read one of the Devil's speeches from Shaw's "Don Juan in Hell." In both kinds of performances he was expert.
LONDON, April 18 -- Yesterday's budget message had a buoyant effect on the stock market here today and rises again predominated in most sections, particularly among the blue chips.

Hilton Credit Corporation, pressed by the necessity of creating a large reserve against possible credit losses, will show a net loss of about $4,000,000 in its fiscal year to end on April 30, 1961. This was disclosed yesterday in a telephone interview with Benno M. Bechhold, president of the credit card organization.

Top honors for television news and public service programming went to the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System, respectively, in the presentation of the George Foster Peabody awards for 1960 yesterday.

Persons prominent in politics and religion are among those who have sent special messages for the tribute to Robert W. Dowling. They will be read Saturday at the Metropolitan Opera House in a program arranged by the Children's Asthma Research Institute and Hospital.
Private gardens and historic areas in Bucks County, Pa., have been chosen for the annual spring garden tour of the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. It will take place on May 10, rain or shine.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Wednesday April 19 -- Following are texts of resolutions offered here last night on Cuba, the first by the Soviet Union; the second by Argentina, Colombia, Chile, Honduras, Panama, Uruguay and Venezuela; and the third by Mexico:

WASHINGTON, April 18 -Mrs. John F. Kennedy created today an eighteen-member advisory committee to work with her Fine Arts Committee for the White House in seeking historic furniture for the Executive Mansion.
The State Commission Against Discrimination asserted yesterday that laws banning bias in housing really worked.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- President Kennedy's answer to Premier Khrushchev:

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- The 2,528 delegates to the Seventieth Continental Congress of the Daughter of the American Revolution are being asked to vote tomorrow in opposition to President Kennedy's Peace Corps.

The bulk of American maritime labor -- four unions with about 150,000 members -- withdrew yesterday from the International Transport Workers Federation in protest over the suspension of one of the four.
CHICAGO, April 18 (AP) -Losses that ran to 18 cents a bushel on old crop soybean futures through yesterday and early transactions today on the Board of Trade finally were halted by a renewed demand.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI) -- The House refused today to bar racial segregation at activities sponsored by the Civil War Centennial Commission. The Representative who advanced the idea was accused of starting the war all over again.
France's principal spokesman in the United States reassured Americans last night that there were no essential differences of goals or policies between the countries.
A festival devoted entirely to low-budget American films produced independently outside the usual commercial channels will be held in Spoleto, Italy, this summer.

Grants of $2,000 each will be made to eighteen artists, writers and composers by the National Institute of Arts and Letters at its annual ceremonial next month with the affiliated American Academy of Arts and Letters.
WARSAW, April 18 -- A mob of 500 Polish students and Communist agitators demonstrated at the United States Embassy today against the "Yankee imperialist" invasion of Cuba.

LOS ANGELES, April 18 (UPI) -- Duke Snider, who had been counted on to provide power for a predominantly young Los Angeles Dodger line-up, will be lost to the club for at least a month because of a broken right elbow, physicians said today.
LOS ANGELES, April 18 (AP) -- Ken Boyer slammed two home runs for St. Louis tonight, but three Dodgers also connected and Los Angeles defeated the Cardinals, 5 -- 4.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 18 -- Britain called today for immediate General Assembly confirmation of a recent plebiscite in her African trust territory of the Cameroons.

Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld yesterday acquitted four of seven defendants and a corporation of antitrust violations in the distribution of newspapers and magazines in the metropolitan area. His action came after the Government had completed its case.

In The Times of April 12 James Reston makes reference to the fact that "while the papers have been full of reports of United States aid to overthrow Castro, the moral and legal aspects of the question have scarcely been mentioned."
MOSCOW, April 18 -- Premier Khrushchev told President Kennedy today that the Soviet Union would render the Castro regime "all necessary assistance" to beat back the rebel attacks on Cuba.

Montgomery Ward Co. rolled up the greatest sales volume in its history in the fiscal year ended last Feb. 1, but earnings fell 50.9 per cent from those of the preceding year, the annual report issued yesterday disclosed.

OXFORD, Miss. April 18 -- The University of Mississippi journalism student who has charged state officials and the Citizens Council with "slandering" him in a confidential report was defeated today for editor of the student campus newspaper.

RKO General, Inc., a division of General Tire and Rubber Company, announced yesterday that it had contracted to buy a controlling interest in Video Independent Theatres, Inc. Details of the agreement were not disclosed.

Four dealers in bankers acceptances reduced by one-eighth percentage point yesterday the rates paid investors on these short-term obligations used to finance goods in shipment or storage. One, however, said it would attempt to resist the rate cut.

THEY are an ill-matched pair of roommates. Ted Kluszewski is one of baseball's mightiest muscle men, a bulging 245-pounder, Albie Pearson is one of the smallest, 5 feet 5 inches and a dainty 141 pounds. They have struck it off handsomely but the contrast between them seems to highlight the fact that the Los Angeles Angels are an inordinately strange collection of ballplayers.

PARIS, April 18 -- Dr. Dirk U. Stikker, the Netherlands Ambassador to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and a former Foreign Minister, was offered today the post of NATO Secretary General, virtually ending a two-month deadlock on the issue.

Shareholders in the First National City Bank of New York and the National Bank of Westchester, White Plains, at special meetings yesterday approved merger of the two institutions. The merger also must be approved by the Controller of the Currency.
Despite continued confusion in the Congo there are at least two new and hopeful developments there.

WHITE PLAINS, April 18 -- Westchester County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian today characterized as "a pattern of confused contradictions" a letter in which Supervisor John J. McGoey, a New Rochelle Democrat, challenged the legality of an award.

The elections of Charles A. Severs, James T. Bryan Jr. and Bart T. Kevins as vice presidents of Frank B. Hall Co., Inc., international insurance brokers and average adjusters, were announced yesterday by Egon H. Ottinger, president.

In the largest corporate debt financing since the company floated a similar issue in July, 1958, $300,000,000 of twenty-five-year 4 per cent sinking fund debentures of the United States Steel Corporation were placed on the market yesterday.

LONDON, April 18 -- Joe Brown, a champion with a hard jab, clever footwork and fifteen years of ring experience, easily beat Dave Charnley of Britain in their world lightweight title fight at Earls Court arena tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Voice of America has increased its Spanish-language broadcasts to nineteen hours a day to keep Latin America informed on the anti-Castro landings in Cuba.
More than 1,500 elderly persons yesterday cheered proponents of health protection for the aged through Social Security insurance and heckled its opponents.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 18 (AP) -- Barbara McIntire of Lake Park, Fla., recovered from the loss of four successive holes on the front nine today and defeated Mrs. Scott Probasco, Chattanooga, 3 and 2, in the second round of the North and South amateur golf tournament.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 18 -- The central government today made good its promise to lift a fourth-month economic blockade of Eastern Province, controled by the rival Gizenga regime.

ROME, April 18 -- Hope that the Ecumenical Council -- a world meeting of church prelates -- would get under way in autumn of 1962 was expressed today by Msgr. Pericle Felici, secretary general of the Pontifical Central Preparatory Commission.

CLEVELAND, April 18 (AP) -- The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and the United Rubber Workers reached a two year agreement today providing for hourly pay increases of 14 1/2 cent for tire plant workers and 7 1/2 cents for workers in industrial products plants.
The formation of the National Repertory Theatre, an vagrant group, was announced yesterday by the National Phoenix Theatre and the Colombia Artists Management.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -Premier Constantine Caramanlis of Greece told members of Congress today their votes for the Truman Doctrine and the Marshall Plan in 1947 "decided the fate of democracy all over the world."
The United States Government's determination to halt Communist subversion in Latin America, and Cuba in particular, has its roots in the Monroe Doctrine, first outlined 138 years ago.

EERYTHING dated from that fatal Saturday afternoon in December, 1929. No one living in Clorinda, Iowa, and over 12 years old would ever forget it -- the deaths of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Mortrude in a grotesquely horrible accident. The tractor with which Jesse Mortrude had been pulling up stumps actually ran over them both, pancaking their bodies into the ground.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 18 -- Adolf Eichmann was portrayed today as crueler and more relentless than his Gestapo chief, Heinrich Himmler, in pressing for the annihilation of European Jews.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- The Soviet bloc's contribution of small arms and other anti personnel weapons is Fidel Castro's best asset in combatting the revolutionary forces seeking his overthrow in Cuba.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- President Kennedy warned the Soviet Union tonight that the United States would tolerate no outside military intervention in Cuba.

The Police Department suspended three plainclothes men last night on charges of "consorting with known criminals and gamblers." It indicated that more suspensions would follow, as a result of a two-month investigation into police ties with gambling.
Lukas Foss, Elliott Carter and Francis Poulenc are the winners of this year's awards of the Music Critics Circle of New York.

Major Yuri A. Gagarin is a world hero because he risked his life to ride in a vehicle over which he had no control. He was virtually a passive passenger in a space ship designed, built and operated by others. Dogs and other animals had made similar trips before him.

Sixty-two youngsters, all under 16 years of age, competed in the Junior Navigators' Rally conducted last week-end by the New York Region of the Sports Car Club of America. The winner was 12-year-old John Ryer Jr. of Pawling, N.Y., who navigated for his father.
KEY WEST, Fla., April 18 (AP) -- Nine Cubans rescued at sea arrived here today, and seven expressed exasperation, that they had left before the shooting started.
VIENNA, April 18 -- Only thirty-six of the eighty-four delegations at the "second Congress of Vienna" signed an agreement today codifying diplomatic immunities and usages.
Winners of annual service awards of the Newspaper Reporters Association for outstanding contributions to the working press of the metropolitan area were announced yesterday.

" All the Way Home," which had announced its closing the day after it opened, yesterday made it all the way home to the Drama Critics Circle Award for the best American play of the season. The voting took place at the Algonquin Hotel.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Wednesday, April 19 -- The Soviet Union proposed last night that the General Assembly request all members of the United Nations to provide the "necessary assistance," if requested by Cuba, to repulse the "aggression" there.

BAD TOELZ, Germany, April 18 -- The Cuban affray focuses our attention on guerrilla fighting techniques. It is therefore noteworthy that for the last three weeks a U.S. Army airborne unit stationed in this Bavarian spa has begun calling itself informally "the President's own" in manner reminiscent of the English Queen's "own" Royal regiments.
MINEOLA, L.I., April 18 -- Nassau Hospital, the oldest voluntary general hospital in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, announced a $3,980,000 expansion program today.
PARIS, April 18 -- President de Gaulle's Right-wing opponents made a slightly veiled threat today to bring him before the bar of justice for violation of France's territorial integrity.
MEXICO CITY, April 18 -- The Mexican Government proclaimed today a policy of nonintervention in the Cuban situation.

Paperboard production rose to 315,490 tons in the week ended last Saturday from 305,857 tons the week before, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. A year earlier the figure was 324,743.

THE Moiseyev Dance Company from Moscow returned to the Metropolitan Opera House last night to begin its second visit to America, and what a marvelous evening it turned out to be! How was it the naive Mr. Barnum used to describe his show? Well, he should have seen this one first.

Mikhail Botvinnik of the Soviet Union yesterday gained another point in the world chess championship match in Moscow. Mikhail Tal of Lativa, the title-holder, resigned the thirteenth game without resuming play.

Alan Wood Steel Company expects to operate at a profit during the second quarter because of a pick-up in business that began at the end of February, Harleston R. Wood, president, told the annual meeting at Philadelphia yesterday.
The Philadelphia OrchestraI ended its New York season lastl night at Carnegie Hall. The program that Eugene Ormandy led opened with dreaw Brahms and ended with hair:,'aising I Walton.
Artur Rubinstein will play ten Carnegie Hall recitals in a period of almost a month and a half. They will all be charity benefits.

Two new brochures describing life and careers in the Women's Army Corps are being distributed by recruiting offices. The booklets, one for enlisted personnel and one for officers, follow the progress of the service woman from the time she takes the oath of the United States Army.

To return to the domestic television scene, the news department of the American Broadcasting Company, under the direction of James C. Hagerty, unveiled early yesterday morning its new nightly news program.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- A survey concluded today that heavy anti-Catholic voting saved Richard M. Nixon from a more decisive defeat by President Kennedy in the 1960 election.
The pull of old friendships and the pinch of a housing shortage have made holdouts against the city of the last thirteen families on one block of the Lincoln Square redevelopment area.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The space agency fired a sodium cloud 102 miles into the air above the Atlantic today in an effort to measure wind conditions.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Farm groups were warned today that unless Congress passed Administration-backed reforms, the present program of importing harvest labor from Mexico would not be extended.

A policy of "quantitative limitations" was urged yesterday by Sidney S. Korzenik, executive director and counsel of the National Knitted Outerwear Association, as the proper remedy for the effect of imports on the domestic knitwear industry.

Norman Thomas, Socialist party leader, charged yesterday that units of the Navy and other branches of the armed forces in this country had been indoctrinating their men with the views of the John Birch Society.

Reductions up to 7 per cent in prices of multiwall paper bags, a major industrial packaging product, were announced yesterday by two leading manufacturers. Other large producers indicated they probably would go along with the move.
QUONSET POINT, R.I. April 19 (UPI) -- Soviet scientist's stomachache cost the United States Government $124,000.
UNITED STATES NAVAL BASE, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, Thursday, April 20 -- Cuban workers here who heard reports of a new landing by anti-Castro rebels were visibly cheered this morning.

CARDIFF, Wales, April 19 -- The Spanish national soccer team, boasting half a dozen of the world's greatest soccer players, narrowly averted defeat in a World Cup qualifying match against Wales tonight.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., April 19 (AP) -- Sonny Liston bought his contract today from his manager, Joseph (Pep) Barone, and then challenged Floyd Patterson, the heavyweight champion, to get into the ring with him.
The wife and children of Bernard Weinberg, a director of Consolidated Sun Ray, Inc., have sold 15,700 shares of common stock, reducing their holding in the company to 186,568 shares.
TUCSON, Ariz., April 19 -- Problems of the drought-stricken West were given priority by Federal officials today as the eighth annual National Watershed Congress concluded.
Acting State Supreme Court Justice J. Irwin Shapiro yesterday denied a writ of habeas corpus to a Negro minister seeking to escape a South Carolina prison term on a conviction of vehicular homicide.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The United States Government announced today that it had decided to act immediately to help strengthen the Laotian Army.
CHICAGO, April 19 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

A scientific approach will be employed to find a worthy successor to "Medium Rare," the revue that celebrates its 500th performance tomorrow night at Chicago's Happy Medium. Those responsible for the long-run attraction, Robert Weiner young impresario, and the owners of the cabaret theatre, Oscar and George Marienthal, willtest entertainment recipes before using them in their next offering.
MIAMI, April 19 -- Following, in unofficial translation, is a Cuban Government communique, signed by the general staff of the armed forces, as broadcast by the national radio:

The inspector in charge of the Seventeenth Division in Queens and two lieutenants and sixteen plainclothes men were transferred yesterday. The Police Department said they had been lax in enforcing gambling laws.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Dr. Frank Press, a member of the President's Science Advisory Committee, told newspaper editors today that the United States could not afford to remain behind the Soviet Union in manned exploration of space.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The chairman of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee for defense characterized as inadequate today the Administration's requests for funds to improve the Army's ability to meet its world-wide commitments.

Operations of the Caterpillar Tractor Company in the first three months of this year resulted in an increase in earnings of 30.5 per cent from the 1960 level, although sales fell 8.2 per cent, the company reported yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 19 -- Mounting criticism of United States policy toward Cuba appeared in the Brazilian press today.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The General Accounting Office cited today two payments of $149,840 each for the same set of special tools as emphasizing the need for tightening Government defense contract practices.
The Puerto Rico Water Resources Authority plans to sell $22,000,000 of electric revenue bonds on May 9. The issue will be dated Jan. 1, 1961, and will come due serially from 1963 to 1998.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The White House assured the country's newspaper editors today that President Kennedy would enforce a policy of making available "as much information as possible" to the public.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- A coalition of Democrats and liberal Republicans defeated the chief threat to the minimum wage bill in the Senate today.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- A bill to create seventy new Federal judgeships breezed through the House today in a rare display of Democratic unity.
WARSAW, April 19 -- A mob of pro-Castro Poles attacked the United States Consulate in Poznan today, smashing windows and raising a Cuban flag over the building.

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, said yesterday that the "hasty" withdrawal of four American maritime unions from the International Transport Workers Federation was potentially harmful to international maritime labor in two ways.

MOSCOW, April 19 (Reuters) -- The First Secretary of the Communist party in the Astrakhan Region on the Caspian Sea has been discharged after agricultural and industrial output lagged under his regime, Pravda, the Communist party organ, reported here today.

Three score veterans of New York's Seventh Regiment assembled at City Hall Plaza yesterday, 100 years, almost to the hour, after their regimental predecessors had mustered to go to the defense of Washington in answer to President Lincoln's appeal.
MIAMI, April 19 -- A Cuban firing squad executed two Americans early today in Pinar del Rio on charges of counter-revolutionary activity. Seven Cubans were executed with them on similar charges.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Administration is in the midst of its promised "second-stage review" of the nation's economy. This is the second look that President Kennedy said he would make in April before deciding if further Government stimulants were needed.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that orders placed with manufacturers of durable goods rose in March for the second consecutive month. Sales also gained for the second consecutive month.

I am a patient at the Bird S. Coler Memorial Hospital and Home on Welfare Island. I am a victim of cerebral palsy, but despite this condition, I can take care of myself. I don't belong in any hospital. I am only 34 years old, but I have no other place to go.

In your April 14 letters under the heading "Commemorating the Civil War" Frances Grimes describes the impressions which motivated Augustus Saint-Gaudens, America's greatest sculptor, in creating the magnificent monument to Robert Gould Shaw on Boston Common. She did not mention (because of modesty) her source of information.
LONDON, April 19 -- Britain instructed her Ambassador in Moscow tonight to press the Soviet Government for a joint appeal tomorrow for a cease-fire in Laos.
The defense rested yesterday in the Federal Court trial of three former officials of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union who are charged with extortion.

GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., April 19 (AP) -- Leslie H. Warner stepped into the presidency of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation today and about 800 shareholders of the company were told of "another record-breaking year" for the company in 1960.
The Federal Communications Commission announced yesterday that it would permit FM radio stations to convert to stereophonic broadcasting starting June 1.

PITTSBURGH, April 19 (UPI) -- Commissioner Ford C. Frick presented world series rings to the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight and they responded by beating the Chicago Cubs, 4-1, on the three-hit pitching of Bob Friend.
MIAMI, Thursday, April 20 -- The Government of Premier Fidel Castro claimed today that it had "completely defeated" the invasion force that landed Monday.

MOSCOW, April 19 -- The Soviet Union withheld from its people today the news of President Kennedy's reply to Premier Khrushchev's pledge of all necessary assistance to the embattled Castro forces in Cuba.
A labor lawyer predicted yesterday that the membership of the National Labor Relations Board would be changed to create an atmosphere more favorable to union organization.
A cold, wet front continued to hold the Yankees in a grip of frustrated idleness yesterday. For the second successive day a game between the Bombers and the Los Angeles Angels was washed out.

LEO DUROCHER, shriven of his most recent sin but still urepentant, will return to the coaching lines for the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight, his three-day suspension at an end. Leo the Lion was put on ice by Warren Giles, the president of the National League, after a shin-kicking altercation with Jocko Conlan, the umpire.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 19 -- The Government announced today that it was easing a curfew that had been imposed yesterday in north and east Ceylon.

James P. Mitchell's Republican primary victory in New Jersey furnishes fresh evidence of the political value of "high visibility." This term, with wide currency in advertising, public relations and poll-taking, means that a man or a product is well known to the public.

IN his successful campaign for the Republican nomination for Governor of New Jersey, James Paul Mitchell made one of his most effective appearances about 3,000 miles from the nearest New Jersey polling place.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The American Society of Newspaper Editors may step into a legal battle involving libel suits against The New York Times in Alabama.
An $11,000,000 project to widen 3.4 miles of Grand Central Parkway from the Kew Gardens Interchange to Clear-view Expressway was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

In defending a prisoner's right to freedom on bail, State Supreme Court Justice A. David Benjamin was highly critical yesterday of Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz. The judge had revoked the $5,000 bail of a man charged with illegal possession of a dangerous weapon.
MIAMI, April 19 -- Cuban rebel recruiting organizations here are turning down applications from a mounting number of Americans who want to fight in Cuba.

" A SEVERED HEAD,"* by Iris Murdoch, is a novel about prosperous Londoners in a peculiar traffic jam of the emotions. You seldom see people falling so industriously in and out of love with members of the same small cast.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The chairman of the 1961 inauguration proclaimed it today the greatest financial success in the history of the events. But he withheld any estimate of how much money the events cleared.

THIS is a region of towering oaks and box hedges and a place where, as Ogden Nash put it, most of the populace comes from Long Island: "The Virginians from Virginia have to ride automobiles because the Virginians from Long Island are the only ones who can afford to ride horses."

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- President Kennedy canceled today his plans to witness weekend naval maneuvers off Florida and summoned all members of the National Security Council to a meeting Saturday morning.

Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, attacked yesterday the proposed merger of the First National City Bank of New York with the National Bank of Westchester, White Plains. He predicted that the proposal would receive, an adverse recommendation from the Department of Justice.
GENEVA, April 19 -- The Soviet Union and other members of its bloc walked out of a session of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe today following a flare-up over the situation in Cuba.
The nation's first oceangoing hydrofoil ship, the H.S. Denison, will make her first trip on dry land, the Maritime Administration said here yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 19 (UPI) -- The Washington Senators shelled three Chicago pitchers for eleven hits in eight innings today and gained a 7-2 victory, ruining the White Sox' home opener before 16,637 fans.

A reader of J. Donald Adams' comments on diaries, in his column in the book review not long ago, was moved to unearth a small volume inscribed, "Year Book 1931," containing a daily record written by at boy fifteen-turning-sixteen.
Robert Frost paid homage last night to the late Indian writer, Sir Rabindranath Tagore, whose poetry earned him the Nobel Prize and the name of "the Soul of Bengal."
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The Kennedy Administration has outlined a rural power development and expansion program that may touch off bitter clashes with private power interests.

Mayor Wagner has directed the heads of all city departments and agencies under his jurisdiction to make themselves available to him and his staff by telephone at all hours of the day and night, seven days a week.

Events today: Collegiate Chorale, Mark Orton, conductor, Mallory Walker, tenor, Vera Zorina, narrator, Town Hall, 8:30; concert of chamber music, Mannes College of Music, 8:30; "Cosi fan tutte," presented by the Opera Workshop, Manhattan School of Music, 8; Composers' Showcase, Museum of Modern Art, 8:30.

Prince Souvanna Phouma's pre-emptory cancellation of plans to visit Washington is not only irresponsible; it is tantamount to his affirming an attachment to the Communist side in the Laotian civil war. It therefore comes close to nullifying his role as a neutral nationalist who could bring anti-Communist and pro-Communist factions in Laos together.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman said tonight that the first comprehensive survey of world food shortages showed that the United States, even with its vast surpluses, could not fill the gap for a single year.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 19 (AP) -- The defending champion, Barbara McIntire; her Curtis Cup team-mate, Judy Bell; an alternate Curtis Cup team player, Barbara Williams, and a player here on a vacation, Mrs. Alex Welsh, won quarter-final matches today in the North and South amateur golf tournament.
The governing board of the United Lutheran Church in America has called on all members to give 10 per cent of their annual incomes to the church in accordance with the Biblical tithe.
National Y.W.C.A. Week, which begins Sunday, will be widely celebrated in Manhattan land Brooklyn.
THE United States lost ground in two matches yesterday as the world championship bridge tournament at Buenos Aires entered its fifth day. The tournament will continue through Sunday.

Savings in the nation's savings and loan associations rose $670,000,0O0 in March to $63,900,000,000, the United States Savings and Loan League reported yesterday. The increase, more than 8 per cent greater than that in March, 1960, was nevertheless the smallest since last July.

The Salute to Spring Ball held last night in the ballroom of the Plaza was given by the Renaissance of Italian Youth for the benefit of the orphanage of San Demenico in Picanello, Italy. It was sponsored by the Buitoni Food Corporation and Harry Winston, Inc.

GENEVA, April 19 -- The United States is considering whether to seek a suspension of the negotiations for a ban on nuclear testing in about three weeks if the current deadlock in the conference continues.

UNITED STATES NAVAL BASE, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, April 19 -- The power of the police state that Premier Fidel Castro has been building over the last two years is apparently being used to terrify the Cuban population.
MOSCOW, April 19 -- More than quibbling about formalities is involved in the negotiations here on Laos. The major stumbling block appears to be mutual distrust.

DETROIT, April 19 (UPI) -- The American Bowling Congress tournament had new pacesetters today for the first time since April 7 as Don Ellis and Joe Kristof of Chicago took the classic doubles lead with 1,331 pins.

Two men charged with setting up an illegal, telephone device for use by bookmakers were arraigned yesterday in Bronx County Court. The device, called a "cheesebox," automatically transfers calls from one telephone to another as protection against police raids.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Solicitor General Archibald Cox argued today that the apportionment of some state legislatures might violate the Constitution. Federal courts, he said, have the power to correct the violations.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 20 points up to 8 points off yesterday. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)
BEING besieged by a bevy of beautiful women is all in the line of business for one young man. He is Kenneth of Lilly Dache, who celebrated his thirty-fourth birthday yesterday.

Interpretive accounts of the emergence of the free African nations and of their leaders are given in "The New Leaders of Africa," by Rolf Italiaander, a Dutch writer and explorer. He has lived and traveled in Africa for more than twenty-five years and is acquainted with the political figures about whom he writes.
Chas, Pfizer Co., Inc., a leading producer of organic chemicals, drugs and pharmaceuticals, is negotiating to acquire the New England Lime Company of Adams, Mass., it was learned yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 19 -- Britain was accused by two Arab states today of armed aggression against the Persian Gulf territory of Oman on behalf of British oil and political interests.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI) -- Representative Edgar W. Hiestand introduced a resolution today to create a special House committee to investigate the John Birch Society and what he called a "smear campaign" against the John Birch Society.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 (AP) -- Cincinnati rallied for two runs in the ninth inning today and beat the San Francisco Giants, 4 -- 2.

URUGUAIANA, Brazil, April 19 -- The Presidents of South America's two major powers, Brazil and Argentina, will meet in this border town tomorrow for a broad discussion of issues facing the Americas, including the Cuban situation.

Electric power production rose in the week ended last Saturday to a three-week high of 14,434,000,000 kilowatt-hours, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the prior week the figure was 14,182,000,000 and a year ago, 13,617,000,000 kilowatt-hours.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Thursday, April 20 -- The General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee called early today for final steps toward independence for the British Cameroons.

Stocks opened lower yesterday, depressed by investors' uncertainties about the Cuban revolt. For two hours prices continued to slip, with the ticker tape behind the floor on three occasions, once by as much as five minutes.
Arthur J. Goldberg, the Secretary of Labor, announced last night that he would establish an Office of Automation and Manpower in his department today.

May I express my appreciation of two editorials on April 13, "The First Cosmonaut" and "De Gaulle and the U.N." The first editorial is a dignified and generous acknowledgment of an outstanding achievement irrespective of whether "our side" achieved it or not.
CHICAGO, April 19 (UPI) -- A Chicago management consultant has filed a $2,000,000 breach of contract and conspiracy suit against the C.I.T. Financial Corporation and four of its highest officers.

YONKERS, April 19 -- The opulent Su Mac Lad, who so far this year has known only success, and seven other top standardbreds are poised to start in the harness-racing season's first international spectacle -- the $50,000 United Nations Trot at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night.
HONG KONG, Thursday, April 20 -- A United States Air Force C-47 crashed into a hillside on the island of Hong Kong last night, killing all but one of the fifteen persons aboard.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Martin W. Oettershagen was sworn in today as administrator of the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation.

The history of charitable trusts highlights two hazards. These are sub-standard fiscal management and lapses caused by unanticipated changes in social conditions. While the courts have established procedures designed to overcome these hazards, one of the most satisfactory means of setting up a charitable trust or family foundation is through the medium of the Community Trust.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Thanks to Nikita Khrushchev, the President was given a prompt opportunity to make clear to the Communist and non-Communist nations, and to the fighters for the freedom of Cuba from dictatorship, that there are "conditions" which would make inevitable United States formal military intervention in the Cuban civil war.
LOS ANGELES, April 19 (AP) Wally Moon hit two home runs and drove in five runs tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 7 -- 2, before 14,775 fans.

Most market business in prime debt investments yesterday was transacted in the short-term discount bills of the Federal Government. But price gains reappeared elsewhere in the Treasury list in more abundance and in larger size than in the short sector.

New York City was accused yesterday of being too concerned with delinquents to help children before they get into trouble. A report sent to the Mayor, the Governor and the Board of Estimate declared that services for neglected and abused children could not be provided by voluntary agencies and must be given by the Department of Welfare.
A $75,000,000 development program for New York University, with the major expansion planned for the Washington Square campus, was announced yesterday by Carroll V. Newson, the university's president.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 19 -- Jewish Orthodox leaders today appealed to the United Nations to combat "the virus of anti-Semitism and make it an international crime."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 19 -- An excellent illustration of how Hollywood has changed since its pre-television hey-day was supplied today by William Wyler, one of the industry's leading directors.

The six-story building containing forty-eight apartments at 1114 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by the Pleasantville Realty Corporation. The sale was made by the Philip Fogel Company, broker, for George Wagner, a client of Nathan Greenberg, lawyer.
CHICAGO, April 19 (AP) -- A moderate to good demand stiffened the grain futures market today with some contracts posting their best advances in more than two weeks.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 19 -- The tribunal trying Adolf Eichmann heard today a tape recording in which his voice broke with disgust and remembered horror as he described the slaughter of European Jews in Nazi death camps.

Holding a small bag of candy, a blithe little French girl about 9 years old raced down the steps of a church in the Ardennes village of Stonne on Nov. 5, 1918. She presented the candy to the first American she had ever seen -- Maj. Thomas E. Stone, whose 307th Infantry Regiment had just rescued her and thirty-nine other Frenchmen from German captivity.
BOSTON, April 19 (AP) -- Eino Oksanen, a Helsinki detective, took the lead a half-mile from the end and won the Sixty-fifth Boston Athletic Association Marathon today.

Samuel and Milton Brause, realty investors, have bought the fees to the land that is occupied by the sixteen-story office and showroom building at the northeast corner of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) and Thirty-fifth Street, facing Herald Square.
JACKSON, Miss., April 19 (UPI) -- The police arrested four Negro college students today for staging the second anti-segregation demonstration here in less than a month.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 19 -- Fist fights between members of pro-Castro organizations and university students broke out in central Bogota tonight. The police prevented the clashes from growing into a riot at the end of two street demonstrations.
HOW many are the satires that have stumbled on the age of innocence? The latest to be defeated is "Smiling the Boy Fell Dead," a musical that opened last night at the Cherry Lane Theatre.
The election of Michael A. Brown and L.J. Forrest as vice presidents of Rayonier, Inc., was announced yesterday.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday another step toward broadening the investment policy of the five actuarial pension funds for city employes.
A well-dressed business man was found slain in Brooklyn yesterday in what detectives described as a "professional ride."

A SPECIALIST in educational photograph records recently described as "drive" most of the fare designed expressly for children. She believes that parents do more harm than good in inflicting this material on their young in the name of "education" or "culture."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 19 -- Britain told the Soviet Union that it could end the United Nations financial crisis today, if it chose to, simply by writing a check for the Communist bloc's $30,000,000 arrears.
GUATEMALA, April 19 -- Guatemala appears apprehensive over the fighting in Cuba and its effect in this country.

It comes as a surprise to most people to learn that for twenty-seven years the number and identity of New York State milk distributors have been under the absolute control of the incumbent Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets.

Admiral John M. Will, president and chairman of the board of American Export Lines, said yesterday that a "disastrous drop" in passenger volume had been mainly responsible for the company's poor financial showing in the first quarter of the year.
CHICAGO, April 19 -- From the four corners of the land they came -- some 20,000 strong -- to the annual meeting here today of American Telephone Telegraph Company.

The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange amounted to 3,723,105 shares last Friday, representing a decrease of 131,101 shares from the 3,854,206 shares reported a month earlier on March 15.

The six-story building containing seventy-two apartments and occupying a plot 114 by 99 feet at 208 East Twenty-eighth Street has been purchased by Pierpont Associates for investment. It was sold by a client of Irving Levitt, lawyer, for cash over a first mortgage of $168,000.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 19 (UPI) -- Reports reaching Yugoslavia said today that Gen. Enver Hoxha, first secretary of the Albanian Communist party, had won a power struggle by a ruthless purge of rivals to his leadership.

PARIS, April 19 -- The nations of the Atlantic community established today a limited, high-level working group whose undeclared purpose is to find the best way of improving the world's potentially shaky monetary system.
GREENWICH, Conn., April 19 -- Connecticut, where the country's first public library was opened, in 1803, finds its school libraries "completely inadequate."

Further prosecution of Jacob Brownstein, lawyer and convicted landlord, for alleged violations in a West Fifty-fourth Street tenement probably will be dropped by the city, according to Deputy Housing Commissioner Harold Birn.
The Chock full o'Nuts Corporation has ended its search for new agency and decided that it will set up its own house agency to handle the account.
The Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., has operated in the black for the second successive quarter, following a string of losses that started with the first quarter of 1959.

Fighting in Cuba pushed prices of world sugar futures up yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange for the third consecutive day. The market churned actively, but volume fell from the high set the day before.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 19 -- Britain and Canada announced today their support of a Latin-American proposal under which the General Assembly would ask members of the Organization of American States to help settle the dispute between the United States and Cuba.

Columbia University's Bancroft prizes, awarded annually for distinguished studies in American history, diplomacy or international relations, went last night to Dr. Arthur S. Link and Dr. Merrill D. Peterson.

Fred Hooper's Teacation saw to it that little mud bespattered the countenance of Ray Broussard in the $22,650 Distaff Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Getting off in front Teacation, remained at the head of the pack and beat six rivals in the seven-furlong sprint for fillies and mares.

VILNA, Lithuania, April 1 -- The university professor sat in the cafe listening to the murmur of Lithuanian, Russian, Polish and Yiddish from other tables. "Vilna has become a city of minorities," he said. "Russian is the common tongue."

Contract negotiations between pressmen employed by the major daily newspapers here and the Publishers Association of New York City will be resumed this morning at the association's offices, 220 East Forty-second Street.
JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, April 19 -- Israel walked out of a lengthy session of the Mixed Armistice Commission today, shortly before being censured for massing tanks and heavy armament in Jerusalem.
James P. Mitchell, who won the Republican nomination for Governor of New Jersey in the primary Tuesday, is expected to move swiftly to unite party factions as a prerequisite to victory in November.
Better cooperation in reporting cargo pilferage off the piers was urged on the shipping industry last night by Myles J. Ambrose, executive director of the Waterfront Commission.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Explorer X satellite has obtained the first direct evidence indicating that solar winds blow the sun's magnetic field out past the earth.

Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia drew nearer to the world chess championship in Moscow yesterday when he drew with Mikhail Tal of Latvia after thirty-three moves in the fourteenth game of the series.
The J.I. Kislak Mortgage Corporation, the largest mortgage banking concern in New Jersey, will move tomorrow from 32 Journal Square, Jersey City, to 581 Broad Street, Newark.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Senators investigating rigged prices in the electrical equipment industry decided today to summon high executives of the industry in an effort to fix responsibility for the conspiracy.

Confident that earnings were on the rise, William G. Stewart, president of Universal-Cyclops Steel Corporation, told stockholders yesterday that the company has noted "a significant improvement in the last several weeks."
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 19 (AP) -- The atomic submarine Robert E. Lee today fired a Polaris missile more than 1,100 miles while gliding submerged beneath the Atlantic Ocean thirty miles offshore.
Ground was broken yesterday for a new deep-level express tunnel for the Sixth Avenue IND subway between the West Fourth and Thirty-fourth Street stations.

VANCOUVER, B.C., April 19 -- M.J. Foley announced today that he had resigned as president of Macmillan, Bloedel and Powell River, Ltd., one of Canada's largest forest products companies, because of a "disagreement with certain aspects of company policy."

Former Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell's decisive victory in the New Jersey Republican primary carries more than usual significance. With three-quarters of the county machines lined up against him, he received nearly 45 per cent of the total vote to top his nearest rival by better than 42.000. It was an impressive result.

The American Kennel Club expects its judges to be honest in their personal and business affairs as well as in the dog world. They must be completely objective without regard to what they have heard or read of the dogs before them.
Plans to expand the New York Central Railroad's low-cost sleeper coach service between New York and Chicago were announced yesterday by Alfred E. Perlman, the railroad's president.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- A Cornell scientist said today he believed there was extensive water on the moon.
Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, called yesterday for regular disclosures of income by top elected and appointed officials, both state and Federal.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 19 (AP) -- The three bettors who picked it won $5,796.40 on their $2 tickets today as Keeneland paid the largest daily double in its history.
CHICAGO, April 19 -- A Federal judge advocated today a reinterpretation of the law on criminal insanity to make the broadest use of modern knowledge.
LOS ANGELES, April 19 -- Two minority stockholders from New York won seats on the board of National Theatres and Television, Inc., today in the denouement of a proxy fight.
More medical skills should be directed toward the relief of chronic pain, Dr. Janet G. Travell, personal physician to President Kennedy, declared here yesterday.

LONDON, April 19 -- Industrial shares edged upward on balance today although the Cuban situation and yesterday's weakness on Wall Street caused some hesitancy.

Martha Graham gave this season's first presentation of her full-evening work, "Clytemnestra," with her company at the Fifty-fourth Street Theatre last night. This is always a very special occasion, for here is one of the towering masterpieces of our time.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- M.S. Szymczak, the dean of the Federal Reserve System's board of governors, is contemplating resignation before his term expires next January. He would spend most of his time teaching at Georgetown University for a while, and later would join the New York investment firm of C.J. Devine Co.

THE Amsterdam Concertgebouw Orchestra last night, in its second and last New York concert, introduced Eugen Jochum to local audiences. Mr. Jochum, greatly active in Germany and elsewhere in Europe, is one of the more respected conductors, and his work is well known in America -- to record collectors, at least -- through the long series of disks he has made.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 19 (AP) -- Gary Cooper is critically ill, a family spokesman said today, and is confined to his Bel-Air home. Sources close to the actor said he had cancer and that he knew it.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Constantine Caramanlis, Prime Minister of Greece, concluded his political and diplomatic conferences with President Kennedy and other high United States officials today.

CLEVELAND, April 19 (AP) -- A three-run double by Steve Boros in the eighth inning off a relief pitcher, Frank Funk, gave the Detroit Tigers a 5-2 victory over Cleveland today in the Indians' home' opener.
The controversial issues of classification and censorship of motion picture will be examined by television programs on two networks.
A cutback in the allowable oil production in Texas and a price cut in one of the state's major producing regions were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The thousand-odd patents to be issued next Tuesday will bear the unfamiliar signature of David L. Ladd. He was sworn in this week as Commissioner of Patents, the second youngest commissioner in the history of the Patent Office.

Sales and redemptions of mutual fund shares set quarterly records in the first three months of this year, the National Association of Investment Companies reported yesterday.

Supporters and foes of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba staged demonstrations here yesterday. The Premier's opponents picketed near the Soviet Mission to the United Nations and his backers picketed near the United Nations headquarters.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 (AP) -- Robert E. MacNeal, president of the Curtis Publishing Company told stockholders at the annual meeting today that the company would have a deficit for the first quarter of 1961.
LEXINGTON, Mass., April 19 -- Visitors from new African nations were among thousands of persons who witnessed today the re-enactment of Paul Revere's historic ride.

LUANDA, Angola, April 19 -- Portuguese reinforcements were rushed into action today in northern Angola, where African rebels were reported to have seized a vast corridor stretching to the Congo Republic.

The logic of events, of population changes and of critical needs urgently supports President Kennedy's recommendation to Congress that a Cabinet-level Department of Urban Affairs and Housing be created. When 70 per cent of the nation's population lives in urban areas, and 130 cities have a population of 100,000 or more as the trend to urbanization continues and quickens, the problem of the city becomes also the problem of the nation.
GUATEMALA, April 19 -- Three men died of bullet wounds received in a shooting affray tonight when pro-Castro and anti-Castro demonstrators clashed in Central Park.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- President Kennedy named two law school deans today to the Civil Rights Commission.
VALLEY STREAM, L.I., April 19 -- Donna Safian, a 10-year-old, fourth-grade pupil at the Forest Road School here, thought carefully and then said in a soft North Carolina drawl:

BUFFALO, April 19 -- The development and production of atomic and thermonuclear weapons for defense continues to be the prime objective of the Atomic Energy Commission, Dr. Robert E. Wilson, a member of the commission since 1956, said here tonight.
VIENTIANE, Laos, April 19 -- The Laotian Government announced today that uniformed United States soldiers would assume positions as advisers to the Laotian Army starting tomorrow.

A woman took a step into a man's world yesterday when Mrs. Hilda Polson, a registered representative of Dreyfus Co., became the first woman member of the new National Stock Exchange. As far as the other big exchanges know, she is the only woman member of a stock exchange in this country.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 19 -- The General Assembly voted tonight to recommend that the Security Council consider the admission both of Mauritania and of Outer Mongolia to the United Nations.

CHICAGO, April 19 (AP) -- A United States District Court judge announced today that he would continue indefinitely a $300,000 libel suit trial to make way for a scientific test of Krebiozen, a controversial cancer drug.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- A $7,109,293 grant for the Lindsay Park middle-income housing project in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn was approved today by the Urban Renewal Administration. The money can be allocated after the approval of plans by city housing officials.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 19 -- Maj. Gen. Joseph D. Mobutu declared today that a "promise of regular pay and new equipment" had enabled him to win over field commanders who had been operating under the control of Antoine Gizenga, head of the regime in Eastern Province.
Bernard Newman, Republican leader of Manhattan, charged last night that Mayor Wagner had relegated city affairs to "a back seat" while he battled the Democratic bosses for control of his party.
Park Commissioner Newbold Morris called on the city yesterday to approve a $16,000,000 park-acquisition program "before it is too late."
CAIRO, April 19 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser and President Tito of Yugoslavia said tonight they were determined to take "all available measures" to help Cuba maintain her independence.

ALBANY, April 20 -- A television comedian's spoof of what he thought was a non-existent sleeping potion called Snooze has involved the comedian, the Jack Paar Show and the National Broadcasting Company in a libel suit.

Defense counsel in a Federal Court trial yesterday challenged Government evidence that three former union officials had extorted money from wholesale distributors of newspapers and magazines in the metropolitan area.

Amid talk of changes in the basic structure of Federal taxation it might be well to consider a modest proposal with less danger of disruptive effect upon the national economy, a proposal which achieves some of the objectives of tax reform as well as easing our principal economic problem -- cyclical instability.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) -- Twenty charitable and religious agencies that distribute United States foods abroad were told today that Government donations to their programs would go up "substantially."
As the bitter proxy battle for control of the Alleghany Corporation headed into its crucial stage, the management took a dramatic step yesterday.

When the Sacred Congregation of Rites in Rome decreed that St. Philomena be removed from the roll of saints it was fulfilling one of its major tasks in recent years -- the revision, standardization and reform of the liturgical calendar of the Roman Catholic Church.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- In the hours before daybreak last Monday, a force of about 500 exiles began to go ashore on the Cuban beaches. So tiny a force could hardly have been expected to play a weighty part in the course of world events.
CLYTEMNESTRA'S murder of Agamemnon in Greece so many centuries ago, is receiving extensive consideration in Manhattan halls of art this week.
