IT may be politic to forget the existence of number 13 in apartments and hotels, but the figure cannot so conveniently be ignored in anniversaries. This week marked the lace or thirteenth anniversary of the Helen Worth Cooking School in New York City. Mrs. Worth, however, is not (knock on wood) superstitious about the event.
MINNEAPOLIS, April 20 -- American business was assailed by Henry Ford 2d here tonight for permitting a climate that made possible the recent scandals in the electrical and automotive industries.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 20 (AP) -- United States military advisers in Laos today discarded all pretense of being civilians and made ready to enter front-line combat zones to instruct hard-pressed royal troops on tactics to use against pro-Communist rebels.
The Felmont Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday that it had abandoned its partial liquidation program and would seek instead to acquire 45 per cent of each shareholder's stock at $6.75 a share.
CHICAGO, April 20 (UPI) -- The Bowling Proprietors' Association of America filed an antitrust suit in Federal Court today against the American Bowling Congress.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 20 -- The typical Laotian soldier fighting the pro-Communist forces in this country is a laughing young peasant who has joined up for the relatively high pay and the status of a soldier, but he abhors killing.

National Dairy Products Corporation attained record sales and the second highest earnings in its history in the first three months this year, E.E. Stewart, chairman, and J. Huber Wetenhall, president, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

The United States monetary gold stock rose $1,000,000, to $17,391,000,000, in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The bank explained that the rise resulted from the slow accretion of domestic gold scrap rather than sales by foreign countries.

The President's tax message to Congress has many clear merits. It is a good thing to attempt to encourage productive investment aiding economic growth through tax credits. It is sound to eliminate the scandalous abuse of expense accounts, business gifts and "business travel." And if, as the President reported yesterday, some $3,000,000,000 worth of dividend and interest income escapes taxation today, then the case for application of withholding taxes to dividends and interest seems irrefutable.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 20 -- Huge earth-moving machines roared in the background at a ground-breaking ceremony here this morning for a $17,000,000 regional shopping center.

SEEKERS of refuge from the buffetings of contemporary styles would do well to visit the exemplary exhibition of Italian old master drawings from the collection of Mrs. Richard Krautheimer now being held at the Institue of Fine Arts, 1 East Seventy-eighth Street.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 20 -- The General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee voted today to recommend termination of British administration of two African trust territories, Tanganyika and the British Cameroons.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 20 -- A Rutgers University agriculture student has designed a garden for the blind that can be appreciated through its scents, sounds and tastes.
Mayor Wagner returned here yesterday and indicated that he had decided whether he would be a candidate for a third term. However, he refused to say what his decision was.

Dr. Arnold J. Toynbee, the British historian, said yesterday that the "ordinary citizen" now finds it harder to get at the truth about public events because news is controlled increasingly by powerful private interests and government agencies.

CLEVELAND, April 20 (UPI) -- Frank Lary gained his second straight victory of the season today as the Detroit Tigers beat the Cleveland Indians, 11 -- 4. Norm Cash hit a three-run homer to help Lary, who pitched all the way for the second time.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 20 (AP) -- Mike McCormick pitched a four-hitter for the San Francisco Giants today and beat the Cincinnati Reds, 2 -- 1.
Stockholders at the annual meeting of the Horn Hardart Company yesterday peppered management with a variety of complaints ranging from service at Automats to the company's financial position.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Senate passed President Kennedy's minimum wage bill today and moved his depressed areas legislation nearer completion.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 20 (UPI) -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, president of the American Red Cross, said today he did not foresee his organization sending aid to Cuba.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- President Kennedy's tax message met immediate Republican criticism today.
Prime-risk, fixed-income investments were in improved demand yesterday in all areas of the bond market.
YONKERS, April 20. -- Su Mac Lad, the 17-10 favorite, showed his hooves to the world's top trotters in the $50,000 United Nations Trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

MOSCOW, April 20 (AP) -- Pravda, newspaper of the Soviet Communist party, reiterated today that the Cuban conflict might bring war to the soil of the United States and declared "the sooner this will be realized in the United States the better."
Taking cognizance of a state Court of Appeals ruling, a Kings County Grand jury yesterday handed up a confidential report instead of a presentment.
WARSAW, April 20 -- Ambassador Jacob D. Beam protested to the Polish Foreign Ministry today against yesterday's mob attacks on the United States Consulate in Poznan.

Stockholders of Lehn Fink Products Corporation approved a proposed three-for-one stock split at a special meeting here yesterday. They also voted to increase the authorized common to 4,000,000 from 1,000,000 shares.

YONKERS, April 20 -- The night session at the United Nations cut the attendance of United Nations dignitaries at the United Nations Trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight. About fifty of the hundred ambassadors and other officials invited by Martin Tananbaum, the president of the track, turned out.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy said last night that Mayor Wagner had promised to help obtain more money to attract qualified men to the city's police service.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Two United States Navy task forces, each including an aircraft carrier, are on patrol in Atlantic waters, presumably within operational distance of Cuba.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 20 (UPI) -- United States Air Force authorities seized a Cubana airliner today when it made an unauthorized landing at the United States Kindley Air Force Base on a flight from Prague, Czechoslovakia to Havana.
ERNIE KOVACS, a man who at least tries to think with some originality in TV comedy, went way out last night in a half-hour of wackyism in which sight and sound were methodically offbeat.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- A business man once deducted as a business expense the cost of his daughter's debut because many of his customers were invited.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 20 -- Aton Schoolwerth, in the third start of his varsity baseball career, pitched a no-hit game today as Princeton crushed City College, 10 -- 0, on Stadium Field.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 20 -- The General Assembly is expected to end its session Saturday without having taken up two issues on which the United States has placed great emphasis.
NEWARK, April 20 -- State Senator Walter H. Jones' future role in the Republican party's plans to regain control of the state government in November remained unanswered today.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) -- Robert Paxton, former president of the General Electric Company, knew about the conspiracy to rig prices on electrical equipment at least a year before sixteen of his executives were convicted, Senate investigators were told today.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Freight loadings last week showed little change from the levels of the last few weeks, the rail and truck industries today reported.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Let us concentrate more on exploring the unknown regions a few miles beneath our feet and worry less about space thousands of miles over our heads.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Particles of heavier elements of the sun, ejected by solar flares, have been captured for the first time in the vicinity of the earth.
Friends of the Committee for the Rehabilitation of Crippled Children are planning to attend the supper dance arranged by the organization's auxiliary for next Friday at the St. Regis Roof.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- A new concept for building a large space-launching rocket, which would combine many of the advantages of solid-fueled and liquid-fueled rockets, was presented today to the House Science and Astronautics Committee.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Two prominent scientists expressed the fear today that the United States was in danger of losing its leadership in space research because of an inadequate budget.

The J.I. Case Company expects to operate at a profit in the quarter ending on April 30, William J. Grede, president, told the annual meeting in Racine, Wis., yesterday. The company, a leading manufacturer of farm equipment and machinery, had a net loss of $1,139,480 in the January quarter and a deficit of $39,814,973 in its fiscal year ended on Oct. 31.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Reported cases of infectious syphilis increased at a record rate during the three-month period ended last Sept. 30, Congress was told today.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -President Kennedy's proposal for a tax incentive to business investment in plant and equipment has several parts. All of them would be equally applicable to corner drugstores and giant corporations, with the exception of residential operations -- apartments, hotels and the like -- and public utilities other than transportation.
MOSCOW, April 20 -- Sir Frank Roberts, the British Ambassador, reported tonight that an agreement was imminent on a joint appeal by his nation and the Soviet Union for a cease-fire in Laos.

CARMEN BASILIO, an honest laborer in a trade that has not always been distinguished by honesty, has a business engagement in Boston tomorrow night. He will meet Paul Pender, the fractional holder of the world middleweight championship. A progress report of their negotiations will be available on television. Carmen's chances of success in this deal are considered dubious to an extreme. For him it will be just another payday.

UNITED STATES NAVAL BASE, Guantanamo Bay, April 20 -- Noisy victory celebrations marked by occasional bursts of shots fired into the air were staged today by Castro supporters in Havana and other Cuban cities.
Thousands of lunch-hour strollers near the Porth Authority bus terminal witnessed a chase in which six shot were fired yesterday. The police did not catch their suspect.
Private financial support to fifty of the nation's leading colleges and universities reached a record last year with a total of $283,512,000 in contributions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Friday, April 21 -- Italy, Australia, Peru, Ecuador and Guatemala endorsed yesterday a seven-power Latin-American proposal to refer the United States-Cuba dispute to the members of the Organization of American States.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- President Kennedy proposed today a $1,700,000,000 tax saving for businesses that invest in new machinery and production facilities. He coupled this with tighter taxation on expense-account spending, dividends and interest, and on businesses and movie stars operating overseas.
LONDON, April 20 -- Britain's Foreign Secretary warned the young people of the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament tonight against misleading "the greedy aggressor."

UNITED STATES NAVAL BASE, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, April 20 -- Cubans here said today that the Castro Governments' propaganda and control over information had contributed greatly to the regime's success in preventing serious civil uprising during the rebel attack at Banlia de Cochinos.

AS the popularity of pants for sports and at-home wear grows, so does the list of names denoting the various lengths. At last count there were an even dozen, including cabin or deck pants which end two inches below the knee.
PINEHURST, N.C., April 20 (AP) -- Barbara McIntire and Judy Bell, virtually inseparable companions on the golf circuit, gained the final today of the North and South women's amateur tournament.

In Union Square yesterday, whiskered men in Army surplus clothing shook their fists and argued until twilight, but their combined voices were but a whisper when compared with what occurred there 100 years ago.

Max Hirsch, the 80-year-old trainer for the King Ranch, consoled himself yesterday that "every day is a fresh beginning, every morn is the world made new." Those inspiring words of Susan Coolidge well expressed the venerable trainer's feelings when he learned that his eligible colt for tomorrow's Wood Memorial was sick.
MINNEAPOLIS, April 20 -- They'll ring in major league baseball in the upper Midwest tomorrow. From all indications, the noise will be deafening.
PITTSBURGH, April 20 (UPI) -- Glen Hobbie shut out the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3 -- 0, tonight on a six-hitter that enabled the Chicago Cubs to salvage one victory from a three-game series.
MARTHA GRAHAM introduced last night the second new work scheduled for her season at the Fifty-fourth Street Theatre, entitled "One More Gaudy Night," more or less out of "Antony and Cleopatra."
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Anti-Castro pickets tossed eggs at the Soviet Embassy today while a policeman stationed in front apparently was temporarily away on school-crossing duty.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- An Administration bill to increase Social Security benefits and payroll taxes sailed through the House of Representatives today with a minimum of controversy.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 20 -- The American Association of Advertising Agencies has decided to take forceful action to correct what was described as a "deep-seated emotional distrust of the ethics, believability and taste of advertising."
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) April 20 -- Adolf Eichmann steadfastly denied during his eight-month interrogation by the Israeli police that he had ever given orders for the killing of a Jew.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said today that, although he was not satisfied with a proposed agreement for developing the Delaware River Basin, he regarded this as "a temporary impasse."
Robert Moses received a public affairs award last night and took the occasion to assail those who have criticized his program for the city's physical improvement.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) -- Spurred by the Cuban crisis, the House Appropriations Committee quickly approved today President Kennedy's full request for $500,000,000 to launch a program of economic help and social progress for Latin America.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Federal Communications Commission indicated today that it may have changed its mind about allowing television networks to control time segments on local affiliated stations.
Sixteen public housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration borrowed $49,955,000 on issues of serial bonds yesterday to finance low-rent housing projects.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Postmaster General J. Edward Day has ordered that all Post Office contracts with outside organizations be made available to the public.
NEW DELHI, India, April 20 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru accused the United States today of having encouraged an invasion of Cuba.

Earnings of the Aluminum Company of America for the first quarter fell to $8,253,906, or 36 cents a share, from $12,635,046, or 56 cents a share, in the 1960 period, it was announced yesterday at the annual meeting in Pittsburgh.
Oklahoma City, Okla., received bids yesterday on $8,700,000 on an issue of airport revenue bonds.

The Air Transport Association of America has accused K.L.M. Royal Dutch Airlines of "flagrant violations" of the air agreement between the Netherlands and this country. This was emphatically denied yesterday by the Dutch carrier.
A record turnout of 1,500 athletes, representing 120 secondary schools, will get the metropolitan outdoor track season off as the two-day Queens-Iona Relays start at Randalls Island this afternoon.
Park Commissioner Newbold Morris said yesterday that new traffic studies were to be made to determine whether present speed limits on city parkways can be raised.
PHILADELPHIA, April 20 (AP) -- Charlie Lau singled home Roy McMillan in the eleventh inning tonight to give the Milwaukee Braves a 7-6 victory over Philadelphia and ruin the Phillies' home opener.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Total production of goods and services dropped to a rate of $499,500,000,000 a year in the first quarter, the Government estimated today. Personal consumption slipped for the first time since the recession began and the rate of inventory reduction continued to rise.

WHITE PLAINS, April 20 -- Under the bill signed into law by the Governor today, a commissioner, whose appointment by County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian will be subject to confirmation by the Westchester Board of Supervisors, will have direct charge of the combined park and recreation operations.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Following is the text of President Kennedy's special message to Congress on taxation:
YASSIADA, Turkey, April 20 -- Former Premier Adnan Menderes and former President Celal Bayar were sentenced to death today for having violated the Turkish Constitution.
LEWISTON, Me., April 20 (AP) -- Bates Manufacturing Company stockholders elected today two new directors -- Mrs. Jane Martin Ginsburg of New York and Ervin L. Miller of Auburn.

HOUSTON, April 20 (AP) -- Peter Thomson, an Australian who for twelve years has found golf tournament titles elusive in the United States, had birdies on the last two holes today for a five-under-par 65. This gave him a one-stroke lead over Chick Harbert in the first round of the $40,000 Houston Classic.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Republican Congressional leaders announced today they were setting up a group of experts to devise solutions to the problem of unemployment arising out of automation and other improvements in technology.

PLUMP and purple, the eggplant rests resplendent with a slim price tag at most city vegetable stands this week-end. It shed 6 cents this week and now sells generally about 20 cents below its price of a month ago.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Appeals declined today to decide whether a private restaurant could be sued for complying with a state segregation law in violation of federally protected rights.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Swiss Government has reported that about twenty Americans have been arrested in Havana, State Department officials said today. Three of the twenty were newsmen, the report said, but their names were not given.

BERLIN, April 20 -- East Germany announced today the ending of waterway tolls levied by its Communist regime for the last three years on barge traffic to and from Berlin. The tolls will be abolished May 1.
Business leases reported yesterday included spaces taken in three buildings in the Rockefeller Center area.
The Republic Steel Corporation's earnings for the first quarter tumbled to $5,822,521, or 37 cents a share, from $28,239,545, or $1.80 a share, a year earlier, the company announced yesterday.

A drive to increase the membership of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in the city from 27,000 to 50,000 by June 30 began last night with a rally at the Riviera Terrace, Broadway and Fifty-third Street. Three hundred persons attended.
BUFFALO, April 20 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller dedicated today a nuclear reactor at the University of Buffalo, the first atom-splitter of its kind at a university in New York State.

"The Million Dollar Incident," Jackie Gleason's comedy drama that is scheduled for telecast tonight, has been "censored." The action was taken by the Columbia Broadcasting System after the granting of an injunction barring the use of the name of the comedian's former manage, George (Bullets) Durgom.
MONTREAL, April 20 -- Travelers prone to claustrophobia will be happy to know that supersonic airliners apparently are going to have windows after all.

United States consumption of newsprint in March was below the year-ago level for the fourth consecutive month, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday. Production in this country and Canada rose to a new high in March, helping to set a new record for the first quarter.

JERSEY CITY, April 20 -- Baseball returned quietly and unobtrusively to Roosevelt Stadium tonight, causing only a mild ripple in the calm of the surrounding community. All but 2,351 residents stayed at home, presumably to follow the televised adventures of the Yankees, assorted good guys on horseback and poor old Brand X.
Blind boys and girls of our great city must look to thoughtful and generous people for their chance to be happy.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 10 points off yesterday.

Many persons entertained at prefatory parties and at the ninth annual Kips Bay Boys Club dinner dance at the Plaza last evening. The benefit marked the forty-sixth year of the club's founding to offer a program in sports, education and health services for boys from 6 to 18 years old.
HENRY FORD 2d regards himself primarily, as a business man and an industrialist who maintains in both his corporate and personal responsibilities a high ethical standard.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Senators clashed today throughout a three-hour hearing on President Kennedy's appointment of Julius C. Holmes as Ambassador to Iran.
A semi-official Greenwich Village community planning board voted last night to uphold Park Commissioner Newbold Morris' ban against folk-singing in Washington Square Park.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 20 (Reuters) -- Australia will vote against American and British proposals for open tournaments when the International Lawn Tennis Federation's annual meeting is held in Stockholm in July, it was learned authoritatively today.

LONDON, April 20 -- Qualified sources said tonight that the Soviet Union had omitted the item of verification of a cease-fire from its proposals for peace in Laos and had avoided a commitment to end the supply of the Communist forces there.
WASHINGTON, April. 20 -- President Kennedy said today that United States restraint was "not inexhaustible" and that it did no intend to abandon Cuba to communism.
World sugar futures continued to hold the trading spotlight in a mixed New York commodity market yesterday.

Production of lumber in the week ended last Saturday totaled 221,882,000 board feet, compared with 218,881,000 board feet a week earlier, according to reports from regional associations. A year ago the figure was 258,425,000 board feet.

Predicted-log cruiser racing or, more accurately, tests of navigational skill, had small beginnings on both coasts. The Pacific Northwest had its rugged, sometimes two-day event from Seattle waters to British Columbia.

PARIS, April 20 -- Dean Acheson, former Secretary of State and currently President Kennedy's consultant on Atlantic Community Affairs, conferred with President de Gaulle today at a moment when United States policy at opposite ends of the world -- in Cuba and in Laos -- has provoked grave doubts here.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -President Kennedy's Committee on Equal Job Opportunity has overcome its first hurdle in ending discrimination by defense contractors.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City declined $63,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank bf New York reported yesterday. This compared with a decline of $77,000,000 in the comparable week a year before.

Startling performances by a few individual stocks marked yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange but the net change was minor. Aggregate market value made an almost invisible gain and The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks registered a modest loss.

The New York University baseball team reinforced one-hit pitching with a sixteen-hit barrage yesterday to rout Brooklyn College, 16 -- 2, on the winner's Ohio Field in the Bronx.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 20 -- Israel celebrated today the thirteenth anniversary of her existence. There was dancing in the streets, bright displays of fireworks and a military parade in Jerusalem.

There was a parade with tanks and other heavy arms in the Israeli part of Jerusalem yesterday in honor of the thirteenth anniversary of Israel's independence. The day also happened to be the seventy-second anniversary of the birth of Adolf Hitler.
LONDON, April 20 -- Stock market price lists had a ragged appearance here today, although the industrials generally maintained their firmness.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Friday, April 21 -- The General Assembly overwhelmingly voted early today to call on Portugal to introduce reforms in her African territory of Angola.

Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman pleaded last night with representatives of the so-called Democratic reform movement to take a more "realistic" view of politics.
BONN, Germany, April 20 -- The West German Government has pledged credits totaling 1,600,000,000 Deutsche marks ($400,000,000) for projects in under-developed countries, it was announced here today.

The city already has assumed responsibility for 8,594 persons under the new system of medical assistance for the elderly authorized recently by Congress, Mayor Wagner said yesterday. The city's program, however, will not be fully operative until June 1.

The outlook is bright for The Living Theatre to make its planned seven-week tour of Europe this summer. The campaign for funds for the trip is gaining momentum and already $18,500 is on hand. If the venture is to be solvent $40,000 must be raised between now and June.
MOSCOW, April 20 -- The United States protested to the Soviet Union today against the turbulent pro-Castro demonstrations staged Tuesday before its embassy here.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The Daughters of the American Revolution, after adopting resolutions of far-reaching import with hardly a word, rose up in arms today against any proxy voting.

CHICAGO, April 25 (AP) -- The feed grains maintained a slight firmness today on the Board of Trade, but other grains and soybeans yielded to profit taking and lost a little ground.

MEXICO CITY, April 18 -- Mexico is tightening its controls on the mining industry through a new national mining law slated to go into effect the day after tomorrow. The new law is aimed at shifting control of the industry -- which is alomst 90 per cent foreign-owned -- into domestic hands.
ABILENE, Tex., April 20 -- The City Commission passed today a motion picture censorship ordinance under which parents can be fined if their children see "objectionable" films.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Leading editors received insights today on the thinking and working of the Administration, and the role of newspapers in those processes.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 20 -- Britain accused the Arab states today of having helped to foment rebellion and terrorism in the Persian Gulf sultanate of Muscat and Oman. The sultanate is under British protection.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- President Kennedy has taken the defeat in Cuba with the utmost seriousness. Behind his brave words to the editors today is a mood of self-examination and self-criticism.
"Let's have another martini on the expense account -- we might have to pay for them ourselves before long," said a business executive to an advertising man in the Twenty-One Club yesterday afternoon.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 20 -- The United States is considering establishing diplomatic relations with Outer Mongolia.
GENEVA, April 20 -- The United States said today that the latest Soviet demand at the nuclear test-ban talks could block any real progress in the entire field of disarmament.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The Air Force identified today fourteen of the fifteen persons killed when a C-47 plane, bound for Taiwan, crashed into a mountain yesterday shortly after taking off from Hong Kong.

The Washington Square College Alumni Association of New York University will honor Dr. Albert B. Sabin, developer of a live poliomyelitis vaccine, as its Man of the Year tomorrow at N.Y.U.'s Loeb Student Center on Washington Square South.

LOS ANGELES, April 20 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals bombarded Los Angeles pitching for seventeen hits tonight, including two home runs by Daryl Spencer and another by Ken Boyer, and whipped the Los Angeles Dodgers, 11 -- 2, before 12,054 fans.

DALLAS, April 20 (UPI) -- Rod Laver of Australia, the winner of last week's River Oaks tournament at Houston, rallied today to defeat young Frank Froehling in the first round of the Dallas Country Club invitation tennis tourney, 8 -- 6, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4.

Everything from a bachelor's buffet to a trousseau tea is on view at this exhibition presented by the Gorham Company and the National Society of Interior Designers.

The standards for the original listing of common stocks were raised by 25 per cent by the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. At the same time, the criteria for consideration of continued listing were revised accordingly.

About 1,000 anti-Castro Cubans marched from the West Side across midtown last night to the Soviet Mission to the United Nations, at Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street, to picket in protest against Soviet interference in Cuba.
BALTIMORE, April 21 -- Mickey Mantle, riding high on one of his earliest batting sprees in years, brought another game into the Yankee victory column tonight.

Gen. Maurice Challe, a reported leader of the Algiers uprising, was relieved a year ago tomorrow as Supreme Commander in Algeria in what was considered a "polite" purge by President de Gaulle of officers with political inclinations.

Mikhail Botvinnik, the challenger for the world chess title, had the superior position when the fifteenth game of his match with Mikhail Tal, the champion, was adjourned after forty-one moves yesterday at the Variety Theatre in Moscow.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 21 (AP) -- Barbara McIntire gained the lead on the first hole today and never relinquished it to beat Judy Bell, 3 and 1. The victory enabled her to retain the North and South women's amateur championship.
Women trained in such fields as social work, teaching, nursing and psychology were urged yesterday to become foster mothers when they interrupt their careers to rear their own families.

HARTFORD, April 21 (UPI) -- The United States Social Security number reported to have been found on a pilot shot down in Cuba this week belongs to a Connecticut cabinet maker, the father of nine children. He has never flown a plane and says he has no interest in Cuban politics.
CHICAGO, April 21 (AP) -- Activity in grain futures trade today was limited mainly to evening up commitments and prices scarcely stirred, except in soybeans, which finished moderately ahead.

CHICAGO, April 21 (AP) -- The American Medical Association said today that Secretary Ribicoff had told the newspaper editors "only part of the story" about the Administration's proposed medical-aid bill.

The marketing of the $300,000,000 issue of United States Steel Corporation debentures -- the biggest corporate debt transaction of the year -- was crowned with success yesterday as bond dealers bid in the public market for the bonds at prices equaling, and in some cases, exceeding the issue price of the distributing syndicate.

Justice Irving Saypol in Supreme Court, New York County, brushed aside legal objections yesterday that passage of a new Omnibus Banking Law made meaningless his decision ruling a 1960 act invalid. The law permitted New York City banks for the first time to branch or merge in suburban Nassau and Westchester County.
PHILADELPHIA, April 21 (UPI) -- A fine job of relief pitching by Don Elston helped the Chicago Cubs to score a 3-2 victory over the Philadelpia Phillies tonight.
The Greenwich Village coffeehouses lost a legal battle in Upper Manhattan Summons Court yesterday when it was ruled that five of them had operated illegally without cabaret licenses.

UNITED STATES NAVAL BASE, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, April 21 -- The Government of Premier Fidel Castro unleashed today a stream of boastful and scornful invective against the United States and especially against President Kennedy.
Gordon N. Ray, a foundation executive and literary specialist, warned biographers last night against distorting the lives of their subjects to prove a theory.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 21 -- Navy's unbeaten baseball team won its tenth game today, defeating Columbia, 3 -- 1, behind the five-hit pitching of Chuck Davis.
An active week is ahead in the market for new capital, with major issues valued at $184,000,000 scheduled for offering, either at competitive sealed bidding or by negotiated sale.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- A new restriction on information about missile firings has been ordered at the Pentagon. It prohibits official sources from releasing the results of missile launchings unless these are clearly within sight of the public.

DUTCH NECK, N.J. April 21 -- Compelling parents to send their gifted children to a public school instead of permitting them to be educated at home is "discrimination against the poor," a Municipal Court hearing was told today.

The demand of investors for the new convertible debentures of Haloid Xerox, Inc., was so great yesterday that the prices of the new securities was bid up to 140 in the public market on the first day of the subscription period.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The dismissal last month of spy charges against a Russian United Nations employe had no connection with the Soviet Union's release of the American RB-47 fliers, President Kennedy said today.

CHILDREN are being compromised by nursery schools that are cutting corners to reduce operating costs, an expert on day care charged recently. One money-saving tactic that reduces over-all costs -- such as the number of teachers and the amount of materials required -- consists of placing children who attend only morning or afternoon sessions in the same group as those children enrolled for the all-day program.

The successful Soviet attempt to be the first in putting a man into orbit around the earth deserve all the praise and respect that is due to such a major break-through in the developing technology of outer space. In this respect President Kennedy has properly expressed our congratulations to the scientists and engineers who accomplished this technological feat.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Maj. Ernesto Guevara, one of Premier Fidel Castro's closest advisers, was seriously wounded in the head earlier this week, according to information reaching here from a diplomatic source in Havana.

About 1,500 public officials of the city, state and nation, representatives of foreign governments, industrial leaders, exhibitors and prospective exhibitors will be the guests of Robert Moses at a luncheon today on the site of the 1964 World's Fair in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens.

Harry Mesknick, an investor, has bought the six-story office building at 12 West End Avenue, between Fifty-ninth and Sixtieth Streets, from clients of Walter Scott Co. The building, which is fully occupied, rents for about $12,000 a year.

From Wall Street yesterday came a true story with one of those unbelievable fairy-tale endings that could only happen to the mixed-up investors of today's markets. It all started, according to Jacques Coe, of Jacques Coe Co., when a male customer called his customer's representative at the brokerage firm and said he wanted to buy 300 shares of Supersonics.
Commodity futures prices in New York markets closed irregularly yesterday. Trading was generally light and listless.
Confused wording in a Board of Estimate resolution has brought about the cancellation the auction of two city-owned in near the Brooklyn Civic Center.
The ceremonial ball-throwing to open the St. Paul-Minneapolis -- or Minneapolis-St. Paul -- season isn't over yet, even though the first game is.
OKLAHOMA CITY, April 21 (UPI) -- A two-engine plane of the Federal Aviation Agency crashed and burned in a pasture southwest of here today, killing its three crew members.
Most of the East's eight-oared crews, having shaken out the kinks in shake-down cruises the past two weeks, will begin serious competition today on various waters.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 21 (AP) -- Four-and-Twenty raced to victory today in Keeneland's Forerunner Purse -- a $7,500 race that has produced more than its share of Kentucky Derby winners.
LAST night's special presentation, "The Million Dollar Incident" on Channel 2 was a ninety-minute show in which Jackie Gleason was involved to some extent.
Tammy Grimes, who plays the rambunctious, never-say-die Missouri farm girl with social aspirations in "The Unsinkable Molly Brown," becomes a Broadway star on Monday.
HAVANA, April 21 (Reuters) -- Sweeping new arersts crammed Cuba's already packed jails tonight. It was difficult to find anyone in Havana who did not know at least one person under arrest.

Spyros S. Skouras conceded yesterday before a Federal Maritime Board examiner that he did not know how long it took for his steamship company's vessels to get from a United States port to one of her Mediterranean destinations.
HAVANA, April 21 (UPI) -- Premier Fidel Castro's army officers credited a multiple-barreled Czech machine having beaten back the rebels who landed in Las Villas Province Monday.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 21 (UPI) -- The San Francisco Opera, one of the nation's foremost, today canceled its 1961 season because of labor trouble.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sectors), April 21 -- Adolf Eichmann told the Israeli police he would have killed his own father if his Nazi superiors had ordered him to do it in World War II.

The Union Carbide Corporation rolled up sales of $364,299,000 in the first quarter of 1960, exceeded only in the 1960 quarter, Morse G. Dial, chairman and chief executive officer, reported at the annual meeting here yesterday.

DETROIT, April 21 (UPI) Ward's Automotive Reports estimated today that auto output in the United States this week would be 125,817 units, with every auto assembly plant in the nation in operation for the first time in 1961.

PARIS, April 21 -- A French radio correspondent who has just returned from Moscow asserted today that Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin's journey into space was preceded by one four or five days before. The first space man was Serge Ilyushin Jr., son of the Soviet aircraft designer, he correspondent, Edouard Bobrovski, said.
Three former union officials were convicted in Federal court yesterday of extorting money from wholesale deliverers of newspapers and magazines in the metropolitan area.

MOSCOW, April 21 (UPI) -- In an apparent warning on the Cuban crisis, the Soviet Army newspaper said today that the Soviet rocket that had hurled Maj. Yuri Gagarin into space could be used for military purposes "if necessary."

PARIS, April 21 -We are an emotional, impatient people with a taste for quick results, a tendency toward extreme disappointment when these are not obtained and a habit of wishful thinking. All these characteristics played their role in the dismal Cuban affair.

LONDON, April 21 -- The events in Cuba and the involvement of the United States, whatever its extent, have caused sympathetic concern and criticism among friends of the Administration in the upper echelons of the British Government.
Mayor Wagner intervened yesterday in the three-week-old strike of the Transport Workers Union against the Brooklyn Union Gas Company and persuaded both sides to resume intensive negotiations.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- President Kennedy will confer with former President Dwight D. Eisenhower tomorrow on the situation in Cuba.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 21 (AP) -- Texas Southern set a first record of 0:41.1 in the 100-yard college race and Houston ran the fastest four-mile in race of the season in the opening session of the Kansas relays today.

Before Mayor Wagner returned from his recuperative vacation he had already warned City Hall that the master demands a taut ship from now on. All city department and agency heads are directed by executive order to be available on the telephone, during and after working hours, around the clock and seven days a week.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 21 -- James P. Mitchell, the Republican nominee for Governor, declared today that he would recommend that the Republican state convention put no pledge against new taxes in its platform this year.

The owl, which, real or in effigy, is supposed to scare away pigeons failed yesterday in the sculpture garden of the Museum of Modern Art. One of them was blandly ignored by a group of the city's feathered beggars.
Two policemen were suspended yesterday for allegedly buying forty quarts of untaxed Canadian whisky at a German freighter docked in Brooklyn.
MIAMI, April 21 -- Twenty armed men, led by a Miami Beach travel agent, made a daring but unsuccessful effort Wednesday night to rescue an American citizen from a Cuban firing squad.

The Studebaker-Packard Corporation reported yesterday that it had a net loss of $6,492,666 in the first quarter of 1961. The automobile manufacturer had a net profit of $2,801,639, or 23 cents a common share, in the 1960 period.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 21 -- The Brazilian Government favors preserving the objectives of democratic reform stated in the program of Premier Fidel Castro's revolution in Cuba but opposes Communist dictatorial means, a spokesman indicated today.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 21 -- The public relations program to improve the popular image of advertising that is to be undertaken by the American Association of Advertising Agencies has been received with some mixed feeling by members attending the association's annual meeting here.

Democratic insurgents in the Bronx said yesterday they were planning a new challenge to the county leadership of Representative Charles A. Buckley. They plan to enter a candidate against Councilman Maurice J. McCarthy in the primary.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI) -- President Kennedy announced today the Government would pay a special insurance dividend to veterans this summer to help spur the economy.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- President Kennedy said today that politics was not involved in his discussion yesterday with former Vice President Richard M. Nixon.

BOSTON, April 21 (AP) -- Paul Pender and Carmen Basilio finished preparations today for their scheduled fifteen-round bout tomorrow night for Pender's version of the world middleweight title. Each voiced respect for the other and expressed mild surprise at the 2-1 odds favoring the champion.
An address by Vice President Johnson will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Thursday, May 4.
ROME, N.Y., April 21 (AP) -- A city judge contends that the State Vehicle and Traffic Law on failure to yield the right of way is unconstitutional because it puts the burden of proof on the motorist.
MIAMI, April 21 (AP) -- Thousands of Cubans jammed downtown Miami to implore the Organization of American States to help rid their homeland of communism.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- President Kennedy announced at his news conference today that he was thinking of sending Vice President Johnson to Southeast Asia on a diplomatic mission. [Question 24, Page 8.]

SINCE the days of the earliest flower gardens in America, campanulas (bell-flowers) have been cherished plants. The genus of more than 300 species -- many of them native to the United States -includes annuals, biennials and perennials.

GUATEMALA, April 22 (UPI) -- Carlos Marcello, former New Orleans underworld figure, was being detained by Guatemalan authorities today pending a hearing on his assertion that he is a Guatemalan citizen.

YONKERS, April 22 -- Avoirdupois, since time immemorial a major concern among young women, middle-aged men, the policeman on the beat and the mailman, never has bothered harness racing drivers. Never, that is, until now.

BEAUMONT, Tex., April 22 (AP) -- Mary Lena Faulk of Sea Island, Ga., shot a four-underpar 69 today to take a onestroke lead in the $7,000 Babe Zaharias open golf tournament. She has a 141 total after thirtysix holes in the 54-hole tourney.
Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller has become honorary chairman for New York State and Mrs. Robert F. Wagner for New York City for the May Festival Ball on May 15 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

NEW DELHI, India, April 14 -- Nearly 5,000 children gathered on a broad lawn here recently for a four-hour exercise in creativeness. Their tools included crayons, water colors, sizable imaginations and varying degrees of skill.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 22 -- Advertising men paradoxically appear to be over-sensitive to criticism, yet, at the same time, inured to it.

THE European Travel Commission recently celebrated its tenth anniversary here and the climax of the week-long event was the announcement by Commerce Secretary Luther H. Hodges that "the United States has no intention of discouraging American travel abroad."

Governor Rockefeller was accused yesterday of seeking personal publicity with the mailing of 1960 state income tax refunds. The charge was made by Michael H. Prendergast, Democratic state chairman.
MAPLEWOOD, N.J., April 22 -- Independent Democrats in the Essex County suburbs said today they had made substantial progress toward developing an unbossed county political organization.

MACON, Ga., April 22 (UPI) -- John Morrison Birch, as a ministerial student here twenty-two years ago, held extremely controversial views, just as does the ultra-conservative society bearing his name today.
Sal Carillo's two-run single with the bases filled in the twelfth inning enabled New York University to defeat Manhattan, 5 -- 4, yesterday at Ohio Field, the Bronx.

THERE may be some good points in "The New English Bible." However, I think the many ludicrous, and sometimes asinine, translations of already excellent passages greatly diminish its worth. I think Martin E. Marty was remiss in not giving this point more attention.

The latest puzzle for accountants in the field of annual reports is the phrase "cash flow." More and more annual reports coming out these days are listing something called cash flow; more and more stock market analysts use the words, at times glibly. And, more and more, some leading accountants are worried about the trend.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 22 -- Robert Coulson, at the tiller of Novocain, won the Larchmont Yacht Club's annual frost-bite "ocean" race to Sands Point today. Finishing the five-and-a-half-mile voyage across Long Island Sound with a considerable lead over Arthur Knapp Jr. in Agony, Coulson captured the Half-Model Trophy.
DETROIT, April 22 (AP) -Joe Macaluso and Eugene Hering of Irvington, N.J., moved into the American Bowling Congress regular doubles lead today with a 1,342 total.

In another move to link the efforts of university scholars and school teachers, the National Council for the Social Studies yesterday published a comprehensive volume on "Interpreting and Teaching American History."

HISTORICAL novelist Elizabeth Linington, who turned to suspense writing only a year ago, is suddenly all over the place. Her record so far this year exactly equals John Creasey's: three books under three names in something over three months -- and her novels run longer than Creasey's.

PAUL HOROAN has already proved that his feeling for American history is warm and immediate, and that his knowledge of it is wide and accurate. TRIESTE, April 22 -- The city and port of Trieste have not prospered since their return to Italian administration less than seven years ago. The Triestenes say their city is slowly dying.

The Speyer Hospital for Animals at 350 Lafayette Street will benefit from the May 2 evening performance of the musical "Carnival!" at the Imperial Theatre.

World attention is focused on Cuba. The international political ramifications of the revolt against Premier Fidel Castro are apparent. The strife in Cuba also is causing severe repercussions in the supply and marketing of a major commodity -- sugar.
SAN JUAN, P.R., April 18 -El Comandante race track has been called the "sweetest track in the world," and for good reason. The running strip is composed in large part of the ground-up sugar cane.
The economic benefits of the 1964-65 World's Fair to New York City were stressed yesterday by Mayor Wagner in a speech on the third "pre-anniversary" of the opening of the fair.

PAGE, Ariz. -- A group of recreation experts, engineers, conservationists, Senators and Representatives will visit this Colorado River damsite community next week-end on a mission that could mean a new National Park for the Southwest, or possibly two such much-needed recreation areas.

IRVINGTON, N.Y., April 22 -- Mrs. Marianne Shaw Blanchard of Greenwich, Conn., widow of Harry Cutler Blanchard, was married here this afternoon to Maitland Lee Griggs Jr. of Ardsley. The Rev. H. August Kuehl performed the ceremony in St. Barnabas Protestant Episcopal Church.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn. -- This city will greet the arrival of spring again this year by marking its thirty-five miles of dogwood trails to guide sightseeing motorists. A special feature of the 1961 Dogwood Trails celebration is the first annual Dogwood Arts Festival, just begun, which will run to the end of the month.

AT least three regular postage items, possibly a fourth, will be added to United States emissions on or before July 1. These will be made necessary by rate increases for international mail effective on that date, as announced by Postmaster General J. Edward Day.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -The second Inter-American Music Festival opened here tonight with optimism about public response, but considerable distress about the cancellation of the Brazilian concert.

It would not be unlikely if some day the exploits of John Stewart and his unusual international detective force were made the subject of a new television series. If so, the case of the penciled moustache might be the subject of an early episode.

LEOPOLVILLE, The Congo, April 22 -- United Nations forces and units of the Congolese Army enforced a curfew and set up joint patrols yesterday in the city of Kindu to prevent an outbreak of violence, a United Nations spokesman announced today.

MOSCOW, April 22 -- Premier Khrushchev said tonight that the Soviet Union would continue to seek a broad agreement with the United States on East-West issues despite the dispute over Cuba. Investment clubs -- small groups of acquaintances who meet regularly to make cooperative investments -- are growing rapidly. It is not known how many of the groups exist but last fall the New York Stock Exchange estimated club members at 275,000. The National Association of Investment Clubs estimated that there now are some 350,000 members.

HOLLY SPRINGS, Miss. -- This picturesque town, "where the Old South meets the New," will round out the pilgrimage season in the Deep South next weekend, when it opens its historical homes to visitors. Twelve mansions are on the tour program, which is under the sponsorship of the local Garden Club.
VIENTIANE, Laos, April 12 -- This once wide-open administrative capital of "the Land of A Million Elephants," is being cleaned up.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Racial integration in the Government, which has been spurred by President Kennedy in recent weeks, has not yet touched the 195-man security force that guards Mr. Kennedy and the White House.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- The Space agency plans to orbit a Mercury capsule with a talking robot aboard. Its oncearound-the-earth flight is to be followed by recovery at sea.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Some of the damages to the interests of the United States in the world, and especially in the Western Hemisphere, that were inflicted by the failure of the attempt by anti-Communist Cubans to secure a firm foothold on the island are already apparent. Obvious as these are, because the expedition was encouraged and to an extent aided by the United States Government, they carry the potential of developing others more serious.

THE eighteenth century is made to order for Sir Harold Nicolson. A graceful and experienced guide to the makers of history and to the history they made, Sir Harold has a gallery of grateful subjects in an age that produced outsized apostles of common sense like Samuel Johnson, garrulous correspondents like Horace Walpole, and mysteriously contradictory figures (half drill sergeant and half poet like Frederick the Great).

Dr. Albert B. Sabin, developer of a live virus poliomyelitis vaccine that can be taken orally, received the Man-of-the-Year Award yesterday from the Washington Square College Alumni Association of New York University.

QUITO, Ecuador -- No matter what time of year a visitor arrives in Ecuador, he can always count on the Indian markets as a major item on his sight-seeing program. There is no need to double-check the itinerary.

WARSAW, April 22 -- Michal Brojdes, a prominent Polish lawyer, has been ordered to trial next month in a slander case that is expected to probe deeply into Poland's claim to enjoy a government of laws.

The attempt to spark a revolution in Cuba by landing a few hundred men and some inadequate supplies on the beaches and in the swamps has failed. OTTAWA, April 22 -Throughout the Cuban crisis Canadian Government spokesmen have shown sympathy and understanding about the United States' dilemma. CONAKRY, Guinea, April 22 (Reuters) -- Guinea's network of 300 state stores is being reorganized.

Beaumont Newhall, director of the museum, will plan and direct work beginning May 1 to remodel two large galleries at the museum for that purpose.
Belgian and Congolese officials expressed grave concern here yesterday over the fate of the Congo's national parks.

A FATHER cornered us recently in a state of extreme concern. "What's all this about school psychologists?" he wanted to know. A small group of parents at his children's school was pressing for the hiring of such a specialist.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 22 (AP) -- Michigan's Big Ten champions dominated the waterlogged nineteenth Ohio State University relays today.
George Meany said yesterday that management must stop fighting labor and start cooperating with it in order to save itself.

Bill Shea, who is credited with returning National League baseball to New York, is leaving the shouting to the fans now that Governor Rockefeller has signed a bill authorizing the construction of a new stadium by the city.

AS long ago as 1914, Ernest Newman wondered if we could not "imagine something like the second act of 'Tristan' with silent and only dimly visible actors, the music telling us all that is in their soul. . . ."

Membership in the American Bankers Association totals 17,328 banks and branches, 159 above the level a year ago, John B. Keeline, chairman of the organization committee, has reported. The report covers the six months ended Feb. 28, midpoint of the association's year.
New reconfirmation rules for international passengers on the airlines serving North America, Europe and the Far East will go into effect May 1.

Ever since man began observing the living world around him he has been fascinated and puzzled by the phenomenon described as "instinctive behavior." A few striking examples are the migration of birds and of certain species of fish, the "language" of the bees, the social organization of bees and ants, and the spinning of cocoons by silkworms and webs by spiders.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 22 -- The upper Midwest's enthusiasm at having become a part of major league baseball has yet to evidence itself at the box office.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 22 -- The engagement of Miss Mary Ellen Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Lewis, to Lawrence D. Frank has been made known by the prospective bride's parents. Mr. Frank is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Frank of Chicago.

A Soviet newspaper in the Kazakh Republic disclosed this month the formation of "Volunteer People's Armed Detachments of the Frontier Regions" to cope with frontier violations between the Soviet Union and Communist China.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -Secretary of State Dean Rusk said tonight he expected Britain and the Soviet Union to issue a call for a cease-fire in Laos within the next twentyfour to forty-eight hours.
HAVANA, April 22 (Reuters) -- Premier Fidel Castro was credited here today with personally sinking a ship during the rebel landing this week.

TWO meanings are attached to the title "April Morning." The first is a literal reference to the action that took place throughout the Middlesex countryside in 1775 when the British forces marched out to capture certain stores in Lexington and Concord.
The new twelve-story $14,723,000 City and Municipal Courts Building in the Manhattan Civic Center will be dedicated Tuesday at 11 A.M.
THIS is the time of the year when residents of the Northeast hear the call of the open road. The skies are cloudless, the breezes are balmy and the countryside begins its variegated blooming.

THE list of shrubs and trees that bloom in spring or summer has become so extensive that the new gardener often finds it difficult to make a selection. Over the years, however, certain species emerge as particularly pleasing, and a very personal roster of favorites takes shape.

LONDON, April 22 -- Hugh Gaitskell, leader of the Labor party, lashed out today against what he termed the "stupid snobbery" that, he said, sustains Britain's principle of inherited "privilege and power and prestige."
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg declared today that "we will have to do more than is being done" to combat "hard core" unemployment.

MADRID, April 22 (AP) -The Spanish Government has confined Gen. Raoul Salan and two other French Rightist leaders to Spain and will not permit them to join the Algerian uprising, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 22 -- East Orange officials are considering a $50,000,000 urban renewal project to revitalize the city's Brick Church commercial area.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -President Kennedy regards Premier Khrushchev's latest statement on Cuba as a reflection of "the Communist distortion of the basic concepts of the rights of man," the State Department said today.

MIAMI, April 22 -- The seventy-two-hour odyssey this week of a small invasion force of Cuban exiles on the bloody swampland beachhead in Cuba, ninety minutes by air from here, exploded as one of those historic shots heard around the world.
Lester Markel states that what we don't know will hurt us. True, but there is a vast difference between informing and influencing.

Retail trade got a lift last week from the warm weather and volume was about even with a year ago. With the different Easter dates in 1961 and 1960 out of the way, merchants look for a more meaningful interpretation of the weekly sales figures.
" I will allow that Abraham Lincoln was a great man," said a Virginia schoolgirl to a Northern visitor, "but Robert E. Lee was greater."

THE "wilderness-stone" in the title of Robert Nathan's latest book comes from Stephen Vincent Benet's great poem, "John Brown's Body," and Mr. Nathan makes it the keystone for a novel which is less novel than valedictory to the America and to the friends of his youth.

" ELEGY in Manhattan" presents affectionate remembrances of fifty-six big and small personages who were the author's friends in and around show business. Let me say at once to those of you who love Broadway: As surely as Jolson was its minstrel, Cohan its strolling player and Runyan its chronicler, George Jessel is its poet.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 18 (AP) -- The president of the Lake Carriers Association said here last night that Government action was needed to put United States shipping companies on the Great Lakes on sounder economic footing.

A STAGE-STRUCK girl of 12 is the heroine of this most appealing tale set with great care and some nostalgia in the New York City of 1925. Everything about the theatre fascinates Sara, above all, writing plays and, of course, starring in them.

In New York and other industrial states the long-term unemployed began drawing extended benefits last week under the new Federal emergency unemployment compensation bill. Those on the long lines at state job insurance offices were the fortunate among the country's 800,000 workers who have been idle for more than a half year.
THE season's most engaging display of upper gamesmanship has just been offered by Oliver Treyz, president of the American Broadcasting Company's television network.

ANYONE familiar with this column knows that it has a predilection for raising questions, and that often it attempts to answer them. The one that prompts me today is of a kind that eludes adequate answer, and for that reason it is perhaps not worth asking.

RABAT, Morocco, April 22 -The Moroccan Government dispatched heavy troop reinforcements today to the area along the Algerian border to prevent the spread of the French military insurrection into Morocco.

Yachting, considered a sport for the rich when steam-powered, oil-powered and huge sailing craft had crews of forty men, now is suited to the small pocketbook.

The Maritime Port Council of Greater New York voted last week to intensify its efforts to prevent passage of a New Jersey bill that would increase the "watchdog" powers of the bi-state Waterfront Commission.

Poor weather hurt retail sales in this area early last week. Department store executives estimated that volume dipped almost 5 per cent below the 1960 level. Generally, merchants said that the best business was done last week in hard goods, while soft good lines lagged.

THE most advertised theatrical operation of the year took place not too long ago on the stage of the Majestic Theatre. With a surgeon's eye, Alan Jay Lerner examined nearly three hours of words, lyrics and song that he had helped to create and knew so well that he could recite from memory.

Proceeds of an exhibition and sale of rare prints and drawings at the French Institute, 22 East Sixtieth Street, on the afternoons and evenings of May 3 through May 5 will benefit the Yorkville Youth Council.

President Kennedy and Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara will speak at New York's annual Press Week, which opens tomorrow and runs through Thursday.

But with the rise of Fidel Castro, the whole business turned sour.
