Those who read President Kennedy's tax message to Congress last week will recall that he stressed the "inter-relationship" of many of the proposals. He asked, therefore, that they be treated as a unit for consideration of both revenue and equity.

The National Association of Investment Companies placed March 31 net assets of 160 member companies at $19,439,086,000, against $18,943,263,000 on Feb. 28 and $15,313,037,000 on March 31, 1960, when there were four fewer companies. . . .
SHEBOYGAN, Wis., April 23 (UPI) -- The Kohler Company said today it was increasing the work week for former strikers from thirty-two to forty hours.

PARIS, April 23 -- Ambassador and Mme. Boonwaat of Burma gave a party at their embassy here last night. The guests were from many countries, and some were diplomats, but it was not a diplomatic function.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., April 23 -- A strong current of disagreement among members of the American Association of Advertising Agencies has led the association board of governors to take a second look at its proposed public relations program and apply the brakes to the broad campaign that had been planned.
Skip Shaw, a 36-year-old member of the Long Island Yacht Club of Babylon, L.I., became the Penguin Class Region I champion yesterday in sailing competition off City Island, the Bronx.

PARIS, Monday, April 24 -- When General de Gaulle was projected back to power he saw he must accomplish three things before order could be restored to France and peace to its blood-soaked Algerian appanage.
PARIS, Monday, April 24 -- As if convinced there was little they could do individually about the grave events in Algeria, Parisians went about doing what comes naturally yesterday.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 23 (AP) -- Jack Kralick pitched and batted the Minnesota Twins to a 1-0 victory over the Washington Senators today in 43-degree weather.

An account of an espionage trial, which ended at Old Bailey in London on March 22 with the conviction of five spies, two of them Americans, is the subject of a book that Atheneum will publish later this year. Called "The Naval Spy Trial," it is written by John Bullock and Henry D. Miller, both of The Daily Telegraph in London.
DALLAS, April 23 (AP) -- Bernard Bartzen, the left-handed Davis Cup player, rallied and swept three straight sets from Ham Richardson today to win Dallas invitation tennis tournament singles honors.
CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- Tornadoes swirled out of a turbulent squall line carrying heavy rain and hail and cut swaths of damage through Missouri, Iowa and Illinois today.
PARIS, April 23 -- Gen. Jean Olie, named commander in chief of the French forces in Algeria, has lived all sides of a soldier's life. He has fought and bled. He has led, cajoled and negotiated.

CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox defeated the Boston Red Sox, 7 -- 1, today behind the right-handed pitching of Bob Shaw after the Red Sox had taken a 4-3 decision in the first game. A pitcher, Tom Brewer, drove in two runs in the opener.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 23 -- Bulldozers are obliterating centuries and civilizations at the Twentieth century-Fox studio as part of the most ambitious real estate adventure in Hollywood history.

RICHMOND, Va., April 23 -- The Robert E. Lee who received command of Virginia's army and navy 100 years ago was not the white-bearded, gray-clad soldier whose image has become almost as familiar as his name.

MOSCOW, April 23 (AP) -- Two United States basketball teams opened their tour of the Soviet Union today with a victory and a defeat. The American men's team won, 78 -- 68, and the women lost, 65 -- 48.
KEY WEST, Fla., April 23 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the text of Premier Fidel Castro's radio and television speech at Havana today:

Unless prompt action is taken, the first wave of foreign tourists attracted by the new Visit U.S.A. program may encounter a discouraging gantlet of language barriers, conflicts of national habits and inadequate facilities.

Title to the Azores, a five-story luxury apartment building with a private beach fronting for 400 feet on the ocean, in the Lido section of Long Beach, L.I., has been taken by Azores Associates, a limited partnership.

One of the most searing, terrifying and altogether extraordinary compositions this listener has ever heard was played in the Donnell Library Auditorium on Saturday night in the final concert of the Composers Forum 1960-61 series.
A prisoner who walked out of Police, Headquarters last week gave himself up yesterady to the patrolman from whom he had escaped.

THROUGHOUT his long and distinguished career Lewis Mumford has been a writer of a special sort -- a critic, not of literature or of the visual arts, but of civilization itself. His special interests in architecture, city planning and "the culture of cities" re only subdivisions of his consuming interest in the past, present and future of mankind.
Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and its affiliate, Esso Research and Engineering Company, have commented on a $20,500,000 breach of contract suit brought against them by two Italian concerns.

About 1,000 anti-Castro demonstrators picketed Mexico's mission to the United Nations and consulate general, 8 East Forty-first Street, for an hour and a half yesterday afternoon. No incidents were reported.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. April 23 -- Puerto Rico's rapid evolution since 1940 under "Operation Bootstrap" by consensus has been fairly spectacular. Without deprecating the operation's accomplishments, an analysis submitted for scrutiny by the United Nation's Social Commission in the session that opened here last Monday rates as dubious its validity as a pattern for other emerging countries.

Any casual observer of our consumer-oriented, leisure society knows how hobby-conscious Americans are. Many hobbies have soared to popularity in recent years -- skiing, skin diving and hot rodding, to name but a few -- but none, with the possible exception of photography, remains so well entrenched as stamp collecting.

LOS ANGELES, April 23 (AP) -- Wally Moon slammed his eighth home run in twelve games and Roger Craig pitched a six-hitter today as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 5 -- 1, before 25,289 fans.

ALBANY, April 23 -- Democratic legislative leaders today accused Governor Rockefeller and the Republican-controlled Legislature of short-changing local school districts on "critically needed" state aid this year.
LONDON, April 23 -- The publication of Britain's budget for the coming fiscal year provided another stimulus to the stock market last week and another record high was reached.
The Kennedy bull market was more than pleasing to mutual funds through the first quarter.
Mayor Wagner predicted yesterday that in fifteen to twenty-five years "Staten Island will have experienced more development and more prosperity than in all of the 300 years gone by."
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- Personal incomes rose to records in every state last year despite the business slump in the last half.

MIAMI, April 23 -- Premier Fidel Castro warned today that he would not consider clemency for the 458 prisoners captured in the rebel landing in Cuba last week unless the United States halted aid to the Cuban rebels.

PITTSBURGH, April 23-- The improvement noted in the steel industry in recent weeks continued last week. There was enough evidence to indicate that it would persist for the next several weeks at least. By the time steel men will be able to determine, with some accuracy, whether or not the rise in steel orders and output is based on cyclical recovery as well as seasonal factors.
Sales of the Eastman Kodak Company for the first quarter were about equal to those for the 1960 period, but earnings were down, according to the company's report issued for publication today.
LONDON, April 23 -- The French generals' rebellion in Algeria was regarded today by shocked British political leaders and officials as an immediate danger to European stability at a critical moment.
Theodore Bikel could not resist the urge to make some topical comentary at his Town Hail recital yesterday afternoon.
Lloyd Stratton, who has been with The Associated Press for the last forty-one years, will retire May 1 as corporate secretary.

HAVANA, April 23 -- Premier Fidel Castro disclosed for the first time today the casualties suffered by his forces during the rebel attack on Giron and Largo beaches of Cienaga de Zapata on the south coast of Cuba last Monday.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg moved today to insure wider compliance with minimum-wage laws in construction done under Government contract.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Administration's legislative program faces another stiff test this week in the House of Representatives, this time on the depressed-areas bill.
A three-man team of international aviation experts has reported success in its mission to reduce red tape for the international air traveler in the South Pacific.

More than 1,000 Cubans attended mass yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street. The service was the regular 10 A.M. mass for Spanish-speaking persons.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 23 -- Israel will produce witnesses to substantiate the charge that Adolf Eichmann, with is own hands, beat to death a Jewish boy, a prosecution source said today.
Cotton futures prices moved irregularly on the New York Cotton Exchange last week, closing at $1.20 a bale lower to 50 cents a bale higher than levels of a week before.
An off-off-Broadway musical with Park Commissioner New-bold Morris as the villain was staged yesterday afternoon between police barriers on a street near Washington Square Park.

The election of Frank R. Milliken as president of the Kennecott Copper Corporation was announced yesterday. Mr. Milliken, 46, succeeds Charles R. Cox who had been president since 1950. Mr. Cox will continue as a director and member of the executive committee.
The Greater Boston Youth Symphony Orchestra and the Pilgrim Fellowship Choir of the Congregational Church of Manhasset, L.I., gave a joint concert in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon.

The International Bank, Washington, D.C., a holding company with banking, insurance and other interests here and abroad, cleared $246,649 in 1960. This did not include unrealized appreciation in the value of capital assets, according to George Olmsted, president and chairman.

THE religious ritual of greeting, watching and listening to Judy Garland took place last night in Carnegie Hall. Indeed, what actually was to have been a concert -- and was -- also turned into something not too remote from a revival meeting.
ALBANY, April, 23 -- A bill that would have prohibited police departments from setting a quota on traffic or parking tickets that must be issued was disapproved today by Governor Rockefeller.

At the recent Massachusetts Institute of Technology centennial celebration Dr. Julius A. Stratton stated that despite the frightening prospects of the potential evil unleashed by scientific advances -- "We have no alternative but to follow truth wherever it may lead us; one cannot escape evil by ignorance."
Richard J. Hughes, Democratic candidate for Governor in New Jersey, said yesterday he would ask his party this year to drop the no-new-tax plank that was in both its 1957 and 1959 state platforms.
The new Commissioner of Customs, Philip Nichols Jr., has joined the ranks of Federal officials determined to help smooth the path of the tourist arriving in the Port of New York by ship.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 (AP) -- Maury McDermott's pinch-hit three-run double in the ninth inning helped the St. Louis Cardinals post a 7-4 victory today after the San Francisco Giants had taken the double-header opener, 2 -- 1.
James P. Mitchell's victory in the New Jersey Republican primary is causing Republicans and Democrats to re-examine their thinking, strategy and prospects for this fall's New York City campaign.

PARIS, April 23 -- Of the million or so men in the French armed forces, most are concentrated in Algeria or in southern France and the Mediterranean area. In Algeria, the total strength of the French armed forces is believed to be about 500,000 more than 90 per cent army personnel.
A New York Athletic Club squad composed of former United States and European Olympic Fencing stars, won the Metropolitan saber team championship on its home strips yesterday.

The Red Cross in Manhattan and Brooklyn will receive blood donations one more day a week, beginning today, to accommodate persons who join the expanded family coverage plan for individual donors not affiliated with a group.

In a recent speech Henry Ford 2d, an outstanding business leader, has faced up squarely to the crisis of the corporation in our modern society. The nature of the crisis is clear. A series of developments over the past year -- developments affecting some of our most important and respected corporations -- has cast a dark shadow over the reputation of and public confidence in corporate leadership as a whole.

JEUMONT, France, April 23 -- To appreciate the meaning of this tiny town near Maubeuge on the French-Belgian frontier, it is necessary to imagine a similar place at the point where the Pennsylvania Railroad crosses from, say, Pennsylvania to Ohio.
MILAN, Italy, April 23 (UPI) -- The junior-welterweight world-title bout between the champion, Duilio Loi of Italy, and Carlos Ortiz of Puerto Rico was postponed today until May 10 because of rain.
One need not live in West Berlin to be an optimist but it might be helpful.

Citizens' Committee shares the concern expressed in your editorial of April 18 that so large a proportion of New York City's school children are at least two years retarded in their reading. This is only one of the many problems facing our schools today.

NEW HAVEN, April 23 -- An exhibition of eighty-four paintings and twenty-four sculptures from the Albright Art Gallery of Buffalo, N.Y., will be on view Thursday through Sept. in the Yale University Art Gallery.
PITTSBURGH, April 23 (UPI) -- Warren Spahn, the ranking left-hander of the Milwaukee Braves, turned 40 today and celebrated with a 3-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

THE third dimension of space is one that modern sculptors have attacked with vigor, and four sculptors twist and manipulate this third dimension with varying success in current exhibitions -- Louise Nevelson at the Martha Jackson Gallery, 32 East Sixty-ninth Street; Phillip Pavia at the Kootz Gallery, 655 Madison Avenue; Luciano Minguzzi at the Vivano Gallery, 42 East Fifty-seventh Street; and Jose de Creeft at the Contemporaries, 992 Madison Avenue.

HOUSTON, April 23 (AP) -- ay Hebert, the 1960 Professional Golfers Association champion, birdied three of the last four holes today to tie Ken Venturi at 276 -- four under par -- and give the $40,000 Houston Classic golf tournament its third straight play-off.

Jack Barry, former host of "Twenty-One" "Tic Tac Dough" and other quiz shows, will return to television as the host and producer of a program entitled "Kidding Around." Mr. Barry has been off TV since 1958.
The notorious brownstones in a dilapidated row on West 103d Street, just west of Broadway, are still padlocked by the city, as they have been for several months.
The Board of Education is considering measures to encourage more concerns to bid on school-construction contracts.

Marxist revolution is moral; counter-revolution is immoral. The United States may guarantee the integrity of Berlin; may send soldiers to Laos; it may not aid or supply Cuban freedom. The Soviet may flout the United Nations in Hungary, Laos, South Vietnam, the Congo; the United States must abide by the letter of the U.N. Charter.

Thirty-four nations and the Organization of American States have indicated their intention of taking part in the 1964-65 World's Fair here, according to its vice president in charge of international relations, former Gov. Charles Poletti.

Jerome Robbins' "Ballets: U.S.A." will make its third European tour this summer, under the auspices of the Rebekah W. Harkness Foundation. The company will open on July 12 in the Festival of Two Worlds at Spoleto, Italy, and will play engagements in Paris, Berlin, Hamburg, Munich, Copenhagen and London.

GENEVA, April 23 -- The Swiss stock markets absorbed with only a slight stagger last week the one-two punch of the events in Cuba and the uncertain outlook for Laos. They shrugged off a one-day setback in mid-week to resume their advance without hesitation.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- Households in many of the nation's larger cities are not as crowded as a few-years ago, the Census Bureau said today.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Kennedy has invited Governor Rockefeller to come to Washington Tuesday for a talk on the Cuban problem. The White House said the meeting had been arranged in a telephone conversation Friday.
KANSAS CITY, April 23 (AP) -- A wild pitch and a throwing error gave the Cleveland Indians the two runs they needed today to defeat the Kansas City Athletics, 10 -- 8. Each team used seven pitchers.

Five of the world's major religions were represented yesterday morning at the Universalist Church of New York, Central Park West at Seventy-sixth Street. The church, in observing its annual World Religious Sunday also celebrated the anniversary of its All Faith Chapel, opened five years ago.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Vice President Johnson's stock is high in the official Washington family.

AS the world - champion bridge matches at Buenos Aires entered the last of nine days' play yesterday, the United States team had cinched second place, but was accorded almost no chance of winning the championship.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 23 -- Restiveness has developed among army Units of Antoine Gizenga's Leftist regime in Stanleyville, Congolese Army sources reported today.
AMSTERDAM, April 23 -- The market was rather erratic here last week.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz was described by Governor Rockefeller last night as a man who has been a courageous fighter all his life for civil rights and equality of opportunity.
A six-story building and a single-story building at 208 to 212 West Sixty-fifth Street have been sold by Henry S. Schumer. They occupy a plot 75 by 100 feet near the Lincoln Square development.

BALTIMORE, April 23 -- The Yankees put in another session of utter frustration today in Baltimore's picturesque stadium while the majority of gathering of 18,704 chortled with glee. They lost a loud and long argument with the umpires, and they also lost the ball game.

The Prudential Insurance Company of America has presented a gold key to Edward W. Wherry, president of Bonwit Teller. It opens the door to the store's new three-story structure at Short Hills, Millburn, N.J.

A reunited Christendom encompassing Roman Catholics, Protestants and the Eastern Orthodox is impossible "in our time," the Rev. John Heuss said yesterday. Dr. Heuss is rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church at Broadway and Wall Street.
GREENSBURG, La., April 23 (UPI) -- St. Helena Parish (County) voted overwhelmingly yesterday to close the public schools rather than integrate them.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 (UPI) -- Art Mahaffey of the Phillies, shrugging off the pain of a stiff back, came within one strikeout of tying the major league record for a nine-inning game today when he fanned 17 batters in the second game of a double-header with the Chicago Cubs.

A 70-year-old veteran, dressed in a brigadier general's uniform, took constitutional control of the Fifth French Republic yesterday with the words: "I confirm myself in the French and republican legality * * * which I will maintain no matter whatever happens until the end of my term, or until I lack either force or life." Some listeners described his voice as calm, deliberate and firm, and some added that it was "cold with fury."
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., April, 23 -- Two spiritual leaders of Conservative Judaism differed sharply today on the controversial issue of Federal aid to religious and parochial schools.

DETROIT, April 23 (AP) -- Dick Brown's pinch-hit single in the eleventh inning drove in the winning run in the Detroit Tigers' 3 -- 2 victory over the Los Angeles Angels in the second game of a double-header today. The Tigers also won the first game, 3 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- All is not ease and concord in the second Inter- American Music Festival here. First came the cancellation of the Brazilian program for want of funds. And this afternoon the visiting Canadian orchestra did something that infuriated the festival's musical director.
The Rev. Dr. James I. McCord, President of Princeton Theological Seminary, cautioned churchgoers last week against giving way to "despair" over the slump in seminary enrollments.

Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, predicted yesterday the 2,800 Brooklyn Union Gas Company strikers would "overwhelmingly" approve a new contract offer in a referendum today.

May I reply to a recent letter from Harris L. Present, chairman of the New York City Council on Housing Relocation Practices? His comments might lead the uninitiated to infer that the City of New York makes no provision for those persons who are displaced by urban renewal projects. This is simply not so, and Mr. Present knows it.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg declared today that the law permitting Mexican farm laborers to come into the United States should be allowed to die unless it was changed to protect American workers from unfair competition.

BOSTON, April 23 (AP) -- Paul Pender, with a convincing decision over Carmen Basilio behind him, today turned his one good eye toward England. He said Terry Downes would be the next challenger for his limited version of the world middleweight championship.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., April 23 -- Pancho Gonzales and Barry MacKay were the winners tonight in a professional tennis program watched by 1,100 fans at the South Mountain Arena.
DEVELOPMENTS in the food field seem bent on making the refrigerator, the range and the recipe file obsolete.
The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America yesterday pledged to support Mayor Wagner for a third term if he decides to run again. The group claims a membership of 85,000 in the city.

The foreign exchange market was uneventful during the past week. British pound sterling was steady for the better part of the week then sold off towards the close. Canadian dollar moved within a narrow range on moderate dealings.

MONTREAL, April 23 (Canadian Press) -- Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion of the Montreal Canadiens today was named as right wing on the National Hockey Leagus all-star team with 177 of a possible 180 points.

TUNIS, April 23 -- Intelligence reports from Algerian nationalist military forces appeared to indicate today that there was no immediate menace to Tunisia from the French military rebellion in Algeria.
CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) International developments involving Cuba and Laos gave grain futures market its bullish nudge last week although it appeared to rather shallow it was far durable

LONG BEACH, L.I., April 23 -- In a race that might well have given traffic policemen nightmares and jaywalkers moral support, John Allen of Buffalo won the national Amateur Athletic Union fifty-kilometer walking championship today.
The tenth anniversary of the opening of the Sidney Hillman Health Center, which provides medical services to members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers Union, was celebrated yesterday.
The National Maritime Union notified George Meany yesterday that it was withdrawing from the no-raiding agreement of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

The vast growth of real estate investment syndicates has brought about the creation of a new Real Estate Syndication Section in the State Attorney General's Securities Bureau. The bureau enforces the state's securities laws.
The Rev. Hugh McCandless yesterday explained the attitude of the Protestant Episcopal Church toward the use of church facilities for the remarriage of divorced persons.

GREENLAWN, L.I., April 23 -- Bernie Traurig won two championships today at the Little Plains Horse Show. He rode his bay gelding Troublemaker to take the junior working hunter title and he also won the horsemanship championship.
DETROIT, April 23 (UPI) -- Max Legate and Bill Rericker of Cliff Anton's No. 1 team of St. Louis starred in the American Bowling Congress tournament today.
MIAMI, April 23 -- Cuban exile leaders here presented a picture of despair and confusion today.
IN many respects the American press probably is one of the most pampered institutions in contemporary life. By tradition its functions include the responsibility to appraise everything and everybody.

The fifteenth annual meeting of the United Nations Assembly reached its most dramatic moment last October, when Premier Khrushchev pounded on his desk with his shoe. It reached its anticlimax early last Saturday morning, when yawning delegates defied the Soviets by voting to continue payments for the U.N. troops in the Congo and by refusing to condemn the United States for its Cuban activities.

CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- Andy Phillip, a former University of Illinois all-American, today was named head coach of the Chicago team in the new American Basketball League. The league will begin operations next fall.
ATLANTA, April 23 (AP) -- Southern Negro leaders, successful in many school-integration moves, are now turning their attention more and more to job opportunities. They report some progress.

PARIS, April 23 -- The constitutional provision that President de Gaulle invoked for the first time today to give him virtually all power in France is the most controversial article in the Constitution of the Fifth Republic.
The concert given by the Bowdoin College Glee Club in Town Hall Saturday night honored its director, Frederic E.T. Tillotson, who is leaving this post after serving for twenty-five years.

PARIS, Monday, April 24 -- Premier Michel Debre warned France last night of an imminent invasion by mutinous soldiers from Algeria and called for a mass rising of the civilian population to oppose it.

The mistaken belief that men have the prerogative to determine or reject community with other men has caused the current "world-wide crisis, in human relationships," the Rev. Dr. Arthur L. Kinsolving said yesterday.

Governor Rockefeller's thirty-day period for signing of bills passed by the Legislature ends at midnight. The Governor can now consider at relative leisure the question whether he is content to let the record of the 1961 regular session stand without further effort at improvement and completion.

The expression "banking circles" takes on new meaning today when the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company opens a branch, its 107th in the New York City area, in a new eighteen-story building at 770 Lexington Avenue at Sixtieth Street.

The "West Side restaurant where a 9-year-old girl was killed last year during a fight between pro-Castro and anti-Castro elements was the scene of another battle last night between the supporters and opponents of the Castro regime.
The State Investigation Commission will open public hearings tomorrow "to detail the many serious abuses" in the operation of bingo games here and in other areas of New York.
The tenth anniversary of the Spence-Chapin Conner Shop will be celebrated at a garden party tea and fashion show tomorrow at Brookside, the home of Mrs. Ricardo C. Gonzales in Rye, N.Y.
Shakespeare's 397th birthday was toasted last night by 600 diners who paid $50 a plate to support free performances of his plays in Central Park.
Two Brooklyn youths were arrested yesterday on charges of killing two members of rival street gangs in separate incidents Saturday night.

SNEEDVILLE, Tenn., April 23 (UPI) -- Five men were arrested today after a feud between a sheriff and a constable had resulted in the killing of two deputies and the constable. A sixth had been arrested last night.
Representative Charles A. Buckley has invited both Mayor Wagner and Carmine G. De Sapio to speak at this year's annual fund-raising dinner of the Bronx Democratic county committee.

THE current "The Play of the Week," which opened last night on Channel 13, is the two-character psychological melodrama, "Close Quarters." On the home screen it is a work in which the moments of compelling tension are rather distantly separated, but Richard Kiley's performance and the novelty of the form afford an evening of modest theatrical interest.
Pan American World Airways argued yesterday against a Federal Court proposal that it divest itself of its 50 per cent interest in Pan American Grace Airways, Inc.
MANCHESTER, England, April 24 (AP) -- Brian London, the former British heavyweight champion, tonight stopped Billy Hunter of Detroit in eight rounds of their ten-round bout.

Walter E. Heller Co. has moved to expand its operations with the purchase yesterday of all the outstanding common stock of the General Capital Corporation of Miami, Fla. The transaction was valued at close to $2,000,000.

A curious struggle appears to be developing over the consumption of vitmans in the United States. The question at issue: Do people take too many vitamin pills or too few? On one side is the powerful drug industry, which is eager to increase its $500,000,000-a-year vitamin sales. On the other is the food industry and allied interests, who prefer that people eat better instead of gulping so many vitamins.

ROGER BURLINGAME'S "Don't Let Them Scare You: The Life and Times of Elmer Davis"* is a splendid tract for our day. It reminds us that fear itself is still our greatest peril in what President Kennedy has called this Decade of Danger.
Net assets of Massachusetts investors Trust were at a record high at the end of the first quarter, the nation's oldest mutual fund reported yesterday.
LONDON, April 24 (UPI) -- Rome's leading newspaper, Il Messaggero, urged Italy and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to throw full support behind President de Gaulle.

The hectic pace of trading in the first three months of this year was reflected in the first-quarter report of the New York Stock Exchange. The report, issued yesterday, showed gross revenues for the period of $5,887,847 and net revenues after operating expenses and reserves for Federal income tax of $423,075.
ITALY won the world championship again, just as everyone had expected, in the nine days of play that ended Sunday in Buenos Aires.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 24 -- Frederick H. Boland, president of the General Assembly, declared today that the second part of the Fifteenth session "on the whole was constructive and useful."

The Friendly Visitors, a group of volunteers who go into the House of Detention for Women with a program of recreation and aid to prisoners there, will hold their third annual tea Friday afternoon at the Tavern-on-the Green.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 24 -- Directors of the York Street Flax Spinning Company of Belfast, the largest group in the Irish Linen industry and long the dominant organization in the American and Latin American export trade, announced proposals today for voluntary liquidation.

Johnny Busso, a lightweight from Astoria, Queens, lost two decisions last night. After dropping a unanimous verdict to Joey Donovan, a neighborhood rival, in the ten-round main event at St. Nicholas Arena, Busso learned that he had been performing for no monetary reward.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanaugh Jr. ordered the closing of part of a Sheepshead Bay school yesterday because of hazardous conditions.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Kennedy Administration is considering application of a total embargo on United States trade with Cuba.
The thwarted attack on Cuba eight days ago has appeared to to unite the Cubans behind Premier Fidel Castro, according to two Canadian business men who returned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Spokesmen for the National Association of Manufacturers and for twenty-six state chambers of commerce opposed a bill today to legalize secondary boycotts in the construction industry.
Mayor Wagner made it plain yesterday that he would cut down on the number of dinners and evening social events that a Mayor is expected to attend.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., April 24 (UPI) -- Dr. Charles F. Crampton, 33 years old, prizewinning professor in the University of Florida's College of Medicine, was found dead in his laboratory last night.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The discovery of a foolproof may to induce breast cancer in a common strain of rats was supported here today.

PARAMUS, N.J., April 24 -- Michael H. Prendergast, New York State Democratic chairman, tonight attacked James P. Mitchell, Republican candidate for Governor in New Jersey, as a "key figure in a now thoroughly discredited regime."

The Dimitri Mitropoulos International Music Competition, sponsored by the Women's Division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, began publicly with a concert in Town Hall yesterday afternoon. The contest honors the late conductor of the New York Philharmonic and of the Metropolitan Opera.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 24 -- President Joseph Kasavubu said today he hoped that the Congolese people would be able to decide their future and determine the structure of their state before the United Nations General Assembly convened for its next session in the fall.
Giuseppe Gagliano, described as a former leading narcotics racketeer in New Orleans who was deported to Italy in 1955, was ordered out of the country again yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI) -- The House Ways and Means Committee approved today tax legislation designed to keep the 41,000-mile interstate highway system on schedule for completion in 1972.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The staff of a Senate subcommittee on Government Operations-found inadequacies today in Government efforts to coordinate and make available information obtained in a host of expensive scientific research projects.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy ordered yesterday that summonses be given to operators of all buses, trucks and autos that emit unnecessary smoke.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI) -- The Federal Government paid a rental charge of $174,300,000 in the fiscal year 1960 for 1,800,000 acres of land and 107,100,000 square feet of building space throughout the world.
In President Kennedy's strong speech on Cuba given at the meeting of the American Society of Newspaper Editors on April 20 three lessons were drawn from the Cuban tragedy.

ALBANY, April 24 -- Governor Rockefeller charged today that the proposed World's Fair cultural project in the Lincoln Center for the Performing Art had been jeopardized by political bickering in New York City and the "shocking cynicism" of Tammany Hall.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren charged in the Supreme Court today that Justice Felix Frankfurter was "degrading the court." The Chief Justice took exception to an oral dissent that Justice Frankfurter had just delivered. He said that it was not a proper statement of an opinion but rather a "lecture * * * a closing argument by a prosecutor to the jury."
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Research physicists reported encouraging evidence today that the laws of nature would permit man to control the thermonuclear process of the sun and the hydrogen bomb.
PARIS, April 24 -- This capital crackled with tension tonight as the alert was reimposed against a possible invasion from Algeria.
Two lots of eye make-up containing colors deemed unsafe by the Federal Food and Drug Administration were seized here yesterday, a Government official announced in Washington.
Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that New York City wanted to do all it could to see to it that the financially hardpressed New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad "keeps on running."
PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- The nation's building industry was warned today that it was spending much too little on research.
MIAMI, April 24 -- Cuban underground sources here said today their organization inside Cuba had been crushed for a long time to come.
NEW DELHI, India, April 24 -- The former Maharaja of Bastar, Pravin Chandra Bhanjdeo Kakatiya, was released from jail tonight. He had been held since Feb. 11 under the Preventive Detention Act.
GEORGE MAXIM ROSS' "Philoktetes," put on last night as an experimental, "week-end" production at the One Sheridan Square Theatre, unavoidably invites comparison with Jack Richardson's "The Prodigal."
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that 250 more special reading teachers would be provided for the city's schools in the fall through belt-tightening in the executive budget.

VIENTIANE, April 23 -- Three United States military advisers operating with Laotian Government troops were reported missing and possibly captured yesterday after pro-Communist rebels drove within fifty-five miles of Vientiane.
Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara announced here yesterday that there would be further major changes in the defense program.
TUNIS, April 24 -- The Algerian nationalist Provisional Government issued an appeal tonight to "all men and all peoples who love liberty" to fight the rebellion by mutinous French generals.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The State Department warned today that the United States would not participate in a fourteen-nation conference on Laos until there was an effective cease-fire in the country.

Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and associates are offering to the public today $27,000,000 of 4 7/8 per cent sinking fund debentures of the National Fuel Gas Company at 101.817 to yield 4.75 per cent. The underwriting group was awarded the twenty-five year debentures at a competitive sale yesterday on a bid of 100.971.

RABAT, Morocco, April 24 -- The Moroccan Government de clared a state of alert today and took security measures a fear mounted that French military insurgents in Algeria in tended to extend their rebellion to Morocco.

S.S. Neuman, president of Publicker Industries, Inc., reported at the annual meeting yesterday in Philadelphia that the company operated in the red during the first quarter but should show a profit for all of 1961.
JAFFNA, Ceylon, April 23 -- A bitter and deep-rooted dispute about language appears to have divided the Ceylonese people almost irreparably.
NEW DELHI, India, April 24 -- India summoned the International Control Commission for Laos today to meet as soon as possible.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 24 -- Gov. Luis Munoz Marin said today that the conviction is widespread in the Western Hemisphere that the United States' attitude toward the regime of Fidel Castro in Cuba was based on "Communist infiltration there and nothing else."
Four months ago, when John Effrat decided to produce "Talent '61," the annual showcase for unknowns aspiring to theatrical careers, he had no money, no theatre, no actors, no writers, no material.
Princeton University will continue its role of "angel" to a professional company in residence next season.

PARIS, Tuesday, April 25 -- The French people demonstrated a united front yesterday against the subversive military threat from Algiers. About 10,000,000 wage earners halted work for one to two hours during the afternoon to signify their solidarity with President de Gaulle in the defense of the republic and their desire for peace in Algeria.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- House Republicans opened one of their strongest attacks on the Kennedy Administration today, calling its farm policy an attempt at "complete regimentation of every segment of agriculture."
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., April 24 -- This village is so pleased with the Horatio Alger success of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Dean Arnold that it has renamed a busy downtown street Brick Oven Road.
WASHINGTON, April. 24 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Proposals to extend Secret Service protection to the Vice President-elect and any other person immediately in line for the Presidential succession were placed before Congress by President Kennedy today.

Work is more than sixty days ahead of schedule on the big Wanapum Dam project in Grant County, Wash., as it nears the second anniversary of construction. It was started in July, 1959. When it is completed, the $93,000,000 hydroelectric project on the Columbia River near Vantage, Wash., will add 831,250 kilowatts to the Northwest's power supply.
Concern over the situation in Paris was expressed here yesterday by American tourists planning to go there. Few, however, canceled reservations.
INDIANAPOLIS, April 24 -- (AP) -- The F.B.I. today began arresting thirteen insurance salesmen, eleven present and former soldiers and three Army civil service workers in the insurance fraud.
In recent comment and correspondence on your editorial page reference has been made to the Boston Common monument to Robert Gould Shaw, in connection with the opening of the Civil War.

Draft indebtedness of Latin-American importers to United States exporters increased sharply in March, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The bank's monthly survey of twelve large commercial banks showed that draft debt outstanding at the end of the month was $211,900,000, or $12,600,000 higher than a month earlier and the highest for any month since August, 1953.

I unreservedly support Gov. Gaylor A. Nelson's ten-year "crash" easement plan in Wisconsin for obtaining public access to his state's "vast but endangered outdoor resources," including its lakes, and his follow-up recommendations to the United States Senate Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 24 (UPI) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation disclosed today that it had uncovered a conspiracy involving $15,000,000 in fraudulent Army insurance. It said salesmen had gotten more than $600,000 in commissions on non-existent policies.
Lever Brothers took all of its business away from Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc. yesterday morning. The accounts were reassigned to the J. Walter Thompson Company and to Reach, McClinton Co., Inc.
An abundance of money seeking short-term investment reappeared in Wall Street yesterday, depressing the discounts and investment yields on Treasury bills to the lowest levels since late January.
Owners of new office buildings are said to be reappraising the value of prestige tenants who are small space users.

Mikhail Tal of Latvia, the defender, and Mikhail Botvinnik of Moscow played forty moves to an adjournment yesterday in the sixteenth game of the match for the world chess championship at the Variety Theatre in Moscow.
LONDON, April 24 -- Prices declined slightly in the stock market here today.
LONDON, April 24 -- The Government accepted without a vote tonight a motion in the House of Commons urging encouragement of British trade with the Communist Bloc.
HOUSTON, April 24 (AP) -- Jay Hebert sank an 8-foot birdie putt on the first extra hole of a play-off today and defeated Ken Venturi for first place in the $40,000 Houston Classic golf tournament.

The mutineers in Algeria have stated and may even have believed that they were saving Algeria and the mainland of France from communism. They were not. On the contrary, they have been taking action that if successful would open the way to communism, would destroy the unity of the Western world, would hopelessly divide the French people and would bring ruin to their country.

LONDON, April 24 -- The House of Commons, in a rare example of unanimity, expressed today to President de Gaulle and the French people Britain's "friendship and encouragement" in the Algerian crisis.

TIME was when medicines were drab to look at, unpleasant to smell and downright nasty to taste. In that same benighted era, household cleaners and similar chemical concoctions came in utilitarian cans or boxes and the overpowering smell when the lid came off was enough in itself to signal "Handle with care."

The son of James J. Moran, a former First Deputy Fire Commissioner who is serving a twelve-and-a-half-to-twenty-five year state sentence for extortion, moved in Federal Court yesterday for a suspension of his father's five-year Federal prison term.

SCARCELY four months before Hitler came to power in Germany, a young professor of Jewish history of Columbia University warned the Jewish people that they faced a crisis comparable to those that followed the first and second destruction of the Temple in Jerusalem.

PARIS, Tuesday, April 25 -- France underwent another night of alert against invasion by mutinous soldiers in Algeria after striking back yesterday with imposition of a complete blockade on the rebels.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Supreme Court held today that a state may exclude from law practice an applicant who will not answer questions about communism and may disbar a lawyer who will not respond to an inquiry into ambulance-chasing.

The question, "Are Labor Unions too Powerful?", will be debated on an hour-long telecast by James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and Arthur H. Motley, president and publisher of Parade Publications, Inc.
More than 200 volunteer nurses' aides, ranging in age from 18 to 50, were cited last night for meritorious service at the New York Foundling Hospital.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Supreme Court will consider whether a firm may retain profits earned by investment in a corporation, when one of the firm's partners was a director of the corporation.
ANKARA, Turkey, April 24 -- Progress in defense coordination was discussed today by the military committee of the Central Treaty Organization.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 24 -- Dr. Howard Hanson opened the thirty-first Festival of American Music tonight as he conducted the Eastman-Rochester Orchestra in Kilbourn Hall.

Mrs. Ada L. Rice's 4-year-old Chief of Chiefs played the leading role in a racing oddity at Aqueduct yesterday when he led home six rivals in exact post-position order in the sixty-eighth running of the Toboggan Handicap.
KANSAS CITY, April 24 (UPI) -- Earl Battey's three-run double in the tenth inning snapped a 6-6 tie tonight and helped the Minnesota Twins defeat the Athletes, 10 -- 6.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 24 (Reuters) -- About 3,000 Communist North Vietnamese agents and troops have infiltrated into South Vietnam during the last four months, military officials said here today.

The Securities and Exchange Commission asked yesterday the United States District Court in Newark, N.J., to appoint a receiver for two large investment companies, Townsend Corporation of America and Townsend Management Company.
BUENOS AIRES, April 24 -- The International Labor Organization's regional conference has agreed unanimously that social and economic reforms must be based on a free democratic government.

With yesterday's appeal by Russia and Britain for a cease-fire, the initial move in a program aimed at settling the dangerous war in Laos has at last been taken. The program provides for the supervision of a cease-fire by an international commission and for a fourteen-nation conference -- now scheduled for May 12 -- that will attempt to bring peace and unity to Laos by sponsoring a government of national union.
KARLSRUHE, Germany, April 24 -- Alfred Frenzel, former Socialist member of the West German Bundestag, went on trial here today before the Federal Supreme Court on charges of treason and perjury.
The General Motors Corporation charged yesterday in Federal Court that the Government's accusation that the corporation had engaged in criminal acts was "peculiar" and "perhaps invalid."

When "Gone With the Wind" reopens at Loew's State tomorrow, timed to the year of the Civil War centennial, it brings with it an impressive array of statistics. The rights to Margaret Mitchell's novel of the Old South were bought by David O. Selznick for $50,000, up to that time the highest price ever paid by a motion-picture producer for a first novel, and that was only the first of many records it has broken.
YONKERS, April 24 -- False Step, Arania and Apmat, pacers all, were back in their stalls at Yonkers Raceway tonight after taking the play away from the trotters.
A ten-pound, steel-rimmed seat cushion was hurled from an elevated train in Brooklyn yesterday and fell more than forty feet, striking and seriously injuring a boy walking home from school.
DETROIT, April 24 (AP) -- Production of 1961 model autos is holding surprisingly close to 1960 levels despite curtailed output from January through March.
CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- A fairly good demand started grain prices off on a generally higher trend and kept them in that direction all day on the Board of Trade. May wheat showed the only decline.
CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- William R. Reed received a five-year contract at an annual salary of about $20,000 today to serve as the new athletic commissioner of the Western Conference.
At least three times since the first apes evolved, asteroids appear to have collided with the earth or moon, strewing large areas of the world with debris.

PITTSBURGH, April 24 (UPI) -- Bill Mazeroski hit a home run tonight -- his first since the one that won the 1960 world series -- to highlight a 7-6 Pittsburgh Pirate victory over the Milwaukee Braves.

MOSCOW, April 24 (AP) -- The Soviet Union's gross industrial output for the first quarter of 1961 exceeded the level of the same period in 1960 by nearly 9 per cent, Tass, the official press agency, reported today.
Following is the text of the annual report of the board of directors of The Associated Press:
Grove Press announced yesterday that it planned to reprint Henry Miller's "Tropic of Cancer," a book that has never legally been permitted in this country.

BUENOS AIRES, April 24 -- Alvaro C. Alsogaray, powerful but embattled Minister of the Economy and a principal figure in Argentina's economic development and monetary stabilization programs, announced his resignation tonight.

ONE of New York's oldest informal dining spots is a brightly-lighted, cavernous place on the corner of Ludlow and Houston Streets. Known as Katz's Delicatessen, it is a wonderfully aromatic institution that reeks with the robust odors of garlic-flavored salami, pickles, mustard and freshly made sauerkraut.
The State Mediation Board will attempt today to end impasse over contract renewal terms affecting 15,000 service employes of 1,200 Manhattan apartment houses.

MOSCOW, April 24 -- The Soviet Union said tonight that the space ship in which Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin made man's first successful space flight had been used in two previous tests. These were in March, and took the dogs Chernushka and Zvezdochka into orbit and safely back to earth.

The Martin Company will dispose of its 15 per cent holding of stock in the General Precision Equipment Corporation, it was disclosed yesterday by Clarence Miles, legal counsel for Martin. These holdings were the target of a Federal court action brought last February by General Precision.
OCEANSIDE, L.I., April 24 -- Harry Cooper of Metropolis and Ben Roman of Rockrimmon won the first metropolitan Professional Golfers Association tournament at the Middle Bay Country Club today.

ALBANY, Tuesday, April 25 -- Governor Rockefeller yesterday vetoed a bill designed to make it clear that Mayor Wagner had the power to order private cars off the New York City streets during a weather emergency.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- New efforts by the Administration to crack the problem of hard-core unemployment and to push down mortgage interest rates were indicated today by Douglas Dillon, Secretary of the Treasury.

Don Claffey prepared for the recent Eastern intercollegiate match-game bowling tournament by making drastic changes in the weight and drilling of his ball. The experts frown on such changes prior to any tourneys. But Claffey paid them little heed and went on to win the title Sunday.

MOSCOW, April 24 (AP) -- The men's basketball team of the American Amateur Athletic Union went into overtime tonight to take its second straight game from the Soviet All-Stars, 84 -- 81. A seek-out crowd of 16,000 shouting jeering, whistling spectators did its best to upset the visiting players.

New York City Housing Authority is planning the sale of $7,870,000 of temporary loan notes for the financing of three State-aided projects -- Jonathan Williams Houses, in Brooklyn; Stephen Wise Houses, in Manhattan; and Arthur H. Murphy Houses, in the Bronx.

THE baseball Hall of Fame at Cooperstown has immortalized a myth. The pantheon was opened amid impressive ceremony in 1939, the centenial celebration of the first baseball game ever played. On a dusty field at Cooperstown in 1839, Abner Doubleday supposedly outlined a diamond with his walking stick and, like Athena springing "full panoplied from the brow of Zeus," baseball was created.
The apparent inevitability of victory for James R. Hoffa in his march toward a new five-year term as boss of the giant teamsters' union is a matter for general dismay.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 2 to 15 points 10 to 75 cents a bale yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The pilot of an airliner that crashed near Charlottesville, Va., a year and a half ago was so nervous that he should not have been flying, the Civil Aeronautics Board said today.

A NEW furniture-arranging kit allows homemakers to plan rooms in a professional manner and averts the backaches and frayed tempers that usually accompany a furniture-moving session. The decorating kit contains sixty-nine punch-out furniture silhouette templates of every size and type and a graph board large enough to layout a single room or an entire house.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 24 (UPI) -- New York State's $75,000,000 parks and recreation program is "a unique and bold pilot plan" for other states, Cecil E. Heacox, secretary of the Conservation Department, told the fortieth annual state recreation conference here today.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI) -- Federal Aviation Administrator Najeeb E. Halaby told Congress today the nation needed 465 new airports and improvements to 2,834 over the next five years.
Three oil companies reported yesterday increased earnings for the first quarter of this year.

The Medical Towers Building, a fifteen-story professional office center at 31-33 Lincoln Park, Newark, has been bought by the Realty Equities Corporation of New York. It was sold by the Heather Holding Company, which had owned it twenty years.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The revolt of the French generals in Algeria was viewed here today as a blow to the entire Atlantic community as well as to France.

Margaret McCaden, contralto, who began her training at the Peabody Institute in Baltimore and continued it in New York, made her local recital debut last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. She has, however, appeared here with small opera companies and with church and concert choirs.

BERLIN, April 20 -- East Germany is appealing to old-age pensioners, housewives and everybody else not yet gainfully employed to bolster the dwindling labor force and help the satellite regime master its economic difficulties.
MOTHS and carpet beetles are expected to cost Americans as much as $500,000,000 this year, according to the Exterminating Industry Institute.
MIAMI, Fla., April 24 -- The Castro Government said today that additional hundreds of rebel soldiers had been captured, bringing the total to 743. These are virtual hostages against new attacks.

RECENTLY, windows filled with beautiful baby christening dresses had enchanted passers-by lined up outside of Best's. Of white batiste and embroidered, tucked, ruffled and laden with lace, these tiny works of art are usually purchased by doting grandmothers and treasured for generations, according to Helfrid Larson, buyer for the Lilliputian Bazaar for the past twenty-six years.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The establishment of three assistant commissioners of the Food and Drug Administration and the appointment of three career officials to the jobs were announced today by Commissioner George P. Larrick.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- Harold Johnson, who took sixteen years to claw his way to the light-heavyweight title, needed only five minutes twenty-eight seconds to retain it tonight in his first defense.
New York's $600,000,000-a-year coat and suit industry and the International Ladies Garment Workers Union agreed yesterday on a new two-year contract.

Program changes in the Penn Relays and the condition of the Downing Stadium track on Randalls Island were the chief items of discussion yesterday at the weekly track writers luncheon in Leone's Restaurant.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The third concert of the Inter-American Music Festival provided a change of pace. It was given last night in the intimate Coolidge Auditorium of the Library of Congress and consisted of four relatively brief works for wind quintet.

RICHMOND, Va., April 24 (AP) -- The State Supreme Court upheld today the convictions of thirty-four Negroes under Virginia's strengthened anti-trespass laws.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 24 -- When Henry Weinstein, a restless plumpish young man, temporarily forsook theatre and television to try producing movies, he wondered how much truth there was in the strange stories he had heard about Hollywood.

PARIS, April 24 -- The hopes of the mutinous French generals and professional troops in Algeria of succeeding in their bid for power in France declined sharply at dawn today. With the organized forces and a newly formed popular militia alerted throughout metropolitan France, with political and social groups of all categories rallying to President de Gaulle, the chances of a successful coup by a relative ly small number of determined men were virtually eliminated.

ORAN, Algeria, April 24 (UPI) -- French insurgent forces here said today they had found copies of a French Government directive ordering a cease-fire against the Algerian Moslem rebels.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 24 -- Asian and African delegates met privately today to consider developments in Algeria, but decided to take no action for the moment.

President Kennedy yesterday welcomed President Sukarno of neutralist Indonesia with the dignity befitting the head of a nation of ninety million. He hailed his visitor as a "distinguished national leader," who also stands for freedom, independence and security for his country.
BALTIMORE, April 24 (AP) -- The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, which is planning to merge with the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway, reported yesterday it had a loss of $3,700,000 last month.

A representative selection, Bertrand Russell's writing to be published under the title "The Basic Writings of Bertrand Russell' to commemoration Lord Russell's eighty-nine birthday. The volume, edited by Robert E. Egner and Lester I. Denonn, contains eighty-one essays and excerpts from the author's work as a philosophies, psychologist, historian, mathematician, analyst of international relations, essayists, short story writer and autobiographer.
PARIS, April 24 (Reuters) -- One of the four Right-wing rebel generals in Algeria said tonight an underground organization worked for six months to pave the way for Saturday's military revolt.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Treasury bill rates fell to their lowest point of the year on today's sale of the regular weekly issues. The discount rate on the 182-day bills was one-quarter years that the series has been in existence. These developments were in line with trends that have been in process for several weeks.
Substantial wage increases and other benefits have been recommended for 1,300 telephone-answering operators in the metropolitan area by the industry's impartial chairman.

In a realignment of its top management, Benton Bowles, Inc., has named Robert E. Lusk as chairman. William R. Hesse, who had been executive vice president, has been appointed to succeed Mr. Lusk as president.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Tuesday, April 25 -- Adolf Eichmann's defense suffered a major blow today when the Israeli tribunal trying him for the wartime murder of millions of Jews decided to admit as testimony the statement of a former aide hanged as a war criminal.
ALBANY, April 24 (UPI) -- Governor Rockefeller signed today into law a bill revising and unifying nito one chapter the laws governing business corporations in New York State.

A device for sampling, inspecting and treating large piles of stored grain was put on display yesterday at Hutchinson, Kan. Its sponsors said it doubled the speed and increased the accuracy of the work.
PARIS, Tuesday, April 25 -- France exploded her fourth atomic bomb in the Sahara this morning.
JERUSALEM ( Israeli Sector), April 24 -- A Columbia University professor described today how the Nazis had destroyed the Jewish communities of Europe.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The two-masted schooner, Pioneer, long owned by George Vanderbilt and said to be the largest private sailing ship flying the American flag, is to become a floating laboratory.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- President Sukarno of Indonesia received a warm personal and official welcome from President Kennedy today as he arrived for talks on Far East problems. Nothing of substance was disclosed officially about today's conversations.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., April 24 -- The head of the Rabbinical Assembly of America appealed to the Soviet Union tonight to permit representatives of the Synagogue Council of America to establish and maintain contacts with Jews in the Soviet Union.
BALTIMORE, April 24 (UPI) -- Bubba Phillips' grand slam, the first such homer of his career, lifted the Cleveland Indians to a 5-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.
CAMDEN, N.J., April 24 (AP) -- Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation will show a consolidated net profit for the first quarter, Marshal G. Staub, president, told the annual meeting today.

Sales of Federated Department Stores, Inc., rose by 3.3 per cent to a new high in fiscal 1960, the company's annual report disclosed yesterday. However, share earnings were slightly lower than they were in fiscal 1959, although higher than in any other previous year.

ALBANY, April 24 -- The state modified for the first time today the tight restrictions of its twenty-five-year-old "Little Norris-La Guardia Act," which governs conditions under which injunctions can be granted against labor unions.

The Red Cross Blood Program called yesterday for volunteers to work days in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn. The volunteers help physicians and nurses with bloodmobile units or at blood centers, and perform non medical tasks.

The international situation in Algeria, Laos and Cuba induced the buying of commodity futures yesterday on the New York exchanges. However, most items closed irregularly in featureless trading. Sugar, cocoa, lead and copper rose; potatoes, rubber and hides declined, and rice movements for coffee, cottonseed oil and wool were mixed.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Mayor Wagner of New York was scheduled today to call upon President Kennedy tomorrow. The White House acknowledged the conference probably would touch on the confused New York Democratic leadership question.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The White House reaffirmed today that President Kennedy intended to retain Camp David as the name of the Presidential retreat in the Catoctin Mountains of Maryland.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 23 -- With South Africa becoming a republic in thirty-eight days, there are few signs among the country's people that republican status will bring unity to this land.
Strikers of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company rejected an appeal by Michael J. Quill and voted overwhelmingly yesterday to continue their twenty-five-day walkout.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 24 -- Manufacturers, buyers and executives from every continent converged on this resort today to view the latest in domestic and foreign knitting machinery, as the industry opened its forty-fifth biennial Knitting Arts Exhibition.

NEW ROCHELLE, April 24 -- The New Rochelle Board of Education adopted a plan tonight for desegregating the community's public school system in accordance with an order last Jan. 24 from Federal Judge Irving Kaufman.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, April 24 (AP) -- The United States Army announced today that Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker would be deputy chief of staff for operations at the Army's European headquarters here, presumably while the Army is investigating a report he propagandized the John Birch Society among his troops.

PARIS, April 24 (Reuters) -- Paris newspapers, with one exception, today hailed President de Gaulle's warning last night to mutinous leaders in Algiers as an effective rallying cry to the nation.

LISBON, Portugal, April 24 (AP) -- Portugal is pouring thousands of troops into her territories on opposite sides of Africa, seeking to curb terrorism in Angola and prevent it from starting in Mozambique.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 24 -- The abortive rebel landings in Cuba have provoked diplomatic speculation here that an emergency meeting of hemispheric foreign ministers might be called to consider the Cuban problem.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 24 -- "Unless population growth can be restrained, we may have to abandon for this generation our hopes of economic progress in the crowded lands of Asia and the Middle East," Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, said today.
DETROIT, April 24 -- With Frank Lary back at his old tricks on the mound, the Detroit Tigers polished off the Yanks, 4 to 3 today in the opener of a three-game series before 5,662 fans.

Kenji Kobayashi is a young Japanese violinist of taste and finesse. That helped to make Town Hall, where he made his local debut last night, a fine and musical place to be.

Mrs. Philip D. Wilson, chairman, has announced that tickets are still available for the May 10 evening performance of the new musical "Carnival!" starring Anna Maria Alberghetti at the Imperial Theatre. Proceeds will aid the Rehearsal club.
