WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The Supreme Court confirmed today to review a decision that only the National Labor Relations Board had authority to act in a labor dispute affecting a foreign-flag in the Port of Philadelphia.

A YOUNG man interested in both teaching and the Great Outdoors may now hope some day to hold the chair of sports fishing in a respectable university, pace gravely in gowned academic processions, serve polite sherry to bright students, and bullyrag dull ones with refined classroom sarcasm.
LONDON, April 24 -- Britain and the Soviet Union appealed tonight for a cease-fire in Laos as pro-Communist rebel forces were advancing toward the country's administrative capital of Vientiane.

Net income of the New York Telephone Company in the first quarter of 1960 was $36,153,218, equal to 52 cents a share, Clifton W. Phalen, president, reported yesterday. In the 1960 period $31,087,267, or 49 cents a share, was cleared on fewer shares outstanding.
Hope rose here last night that a sitdown strike of Danish seamen aboard five vessels in port might be ended today.
LONDON, April 25 -- Price elements were mixed and fall on the stock market here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 25 -- The Soviet Union and the United States exchanged angry words over Cuba today, each accusing the other of having dragged "cold war" issues into a debate of the Economic and Social Council.
PARIS, Wednesday, April 26 (Reuters) -- A tense scene was played over the Algiers radio in the closing hours of the revolt there last night.
NEWARK, April 25 -- Dennis F. Carey overcame tonight the fourth effort in five years to oust him as chairman of the Essex County Democratic Committee. His margin was 2 to 1.
Combined assets of the Eaton Howard mutual funds have exceeded $400,000,000 for the first time, according to reports issued yesterday.
PARIS, Wednesday, April 26 -- The French Parliament entered the troubled political scene yesterday for twenty minutes, then adjourned.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 25 -- The Military Committee of the Central Treaty Organization passed along to the Council of Ministers today the sensitive matter of establishing a military command structure for regional defense.

Everybody likes to drive on a fine, modern highway, but nobody wants to pay for it. President Kennedy, who delivered to Congress on Feb. 28 an admirable message on pay-as-we-go financing, has received from the House Ways and Means Committee a reply that reveals the habitual Congressional reluctance to make the voter pay for what he enjoys in good roads.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today President Kennedy's nomination of Julius C. Holmes to be Ambassador to Iran. The vote was 12 to 4.
WESTPORT, Conn., April 25 -- Forty-four members of parent-teacher associations here are holding kaffee klatsches night and day in an effort to win a battle for school funds.

VIEQUES ISLAND, P.R., April 25 -- Wounded evacuees of the rebel anti-Castro force that attacked Cuba are being brought to the Camp Garcia United States Marine Base here, according to an unimpeachable authority in San Juan.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that the situation in Cuba was a serious threat to the security of the United States. He urged all Americans to support President Kennedy in whatever action is needed to meet it.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., April 25 -- Jewish educators and spiritual leaders called today for a renascence of the synagogue and the prayer book as the dominating force in American Jewish life.
A brunch, fashion show and dance, called "Sunday in Rome," will be given Sunday in the Columns of the Savoy Hilton as a benefit for Boys Towns of Italy, Inc.
ALBANY, April 25 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today his disapproval of a bill that would have permitted a delay in the installation of fire-sprinkler systems in old factories.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman tried today to fend off Republican criticisms of the Administration's new farm bill.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara promised today that small business concerns would obtain a bigger share of the $23,000,000,000 or more of defense contracts awarded each year.
An absentee landlord from New Jersey was fined the maximum amount of $500 in Housing Court yesterday for violations of the Health Code in a tenement at 18 West Ninety-fifth Street.

The Ford Foundation program of getting young American composers together with high school music students will enter its third year with some of the schools footing part of the bill for the first time.
Voluntary uniformity in discounts given by newspapers to national advertisers was urged yesterday at the seventy-fifth annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- One of the Kennedy Administration's major objectives is the enforcement of high standards of quality and design in the nation's many Federally aided renewal projects, Dr. Robert C. Weaver declared today.
Corporation Counsel Charles H. Tenney will be sworn in by Mayor Wagner at 3 P.M. today as City Administrator.

A crowd of 17,000 is expected to attend the 100-mile midget championship race that will open the Langhorne (Pa.) Speedway season on Sunday. Forty-one drivers have entered the event, but only the fastest twenty-four cars will start in the race.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) -- Senator Henry C. Dworshak, Republican of Idaho, said today the Bureau of Indian Affairs was wasteful and inefficient.

FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, April 25 (AP) -- Thurgood Marshall, personal representative of President Kennedy at Sierra Leone's independence celebration, offered a United States pledge of lasting friendship with the new nation today.
The so-called "death-gamble" in the New York City teachers' retirement program was eliminated by the state yesterday.

Efficiency rather than more capacity is the aim of the British steel industry in the next five years, the Iron and Steel Board's annual report to the Government indicated yesterday. For the first time there will be ample iron and steel for the home market and the industry will be able to concentrate on production costs, it was said.
ALBANY, April 25 -- A bill permitting the state to make an earlier claim on abandoned bank deposits has been signed by Governor Rockefeller.
PARIS, Wednesday, April 26 -- The end of a venture into sedition by four French generals came with the same unexpected swiftness as its beginning.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today President Kennedy's request for authority to extend financial and economic aid to Iron Curtain countries to help them loosen Moscow's control.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 25 (AP) -- The recession has passed its low point and an upturn in the economy is expected around the middle of this year, the chairman of the National Gypsum Company told stockholders today.

Prof. Henry C. Wallich, in his letter published April 18, advances once again an old proposal for voluntary wage restraint. He suggests that wage increases be limited by consensus to 2 per cent a year, a figure identified as the historical rate of productivity gain over long periods.
The city's policy of licensing and fingerprinting entertainers and employes in public dance halls, cabarets and coffee houses was assailed yesterday by Stanley M. Isaacs.

IN "Happy as Larry," Donagh MacDonagh's Celtic essay in whimsey, the fantasy runs riot. Six tailors are ferried across the precipice of time to avenge a murder that took place fifty years ago; three haggard ladies of Hades respond to a call for help; a man is returned from the dead and the future corrects the misdeeds of the past.
MIAMI, April 25 -- The "disappearance" of a large part of the Cuban rebels' "liberation army" is causing rapidly growing unrest among Cuban exiles here.

AS a certain used-car dealer in Tel Aviv has learned, Judge Benyamin Halevi is not a man to be toyed with. The judge, one of the three who are sitting in the trial of Adolf Eichmann, had just bought a car from the dealer when he took it for a spin and a piston rod broke.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that a pilot's error during a potentially dangerous maneuver was responsible for the crash of an American Airlines Boeing 707 jetliner on a training flight Aug. 15, 1959.
GENEVA, April 25 -- The explosion of France's fourth atomic bomb did not bring Soviet criticism in the nuclear test-ban talks today.

ALBANY, April 25 -- A $2,500 increase in legislators' salaries was authorized by Governor Rockefeller today. Moments later the Republican legislative leaders came out for a $1,500 reduction in the legislators' expense allowance.

THE day America's track and field forces checked into the Villaggio Olimpico before the Olympic Games at Rome last summer the various coaches sorted out the groups of athletes to which they had been specifically assigned. George Eastment of Manhattan College drew aside each of the quarter-milers for fatherly chats.

The managements of the Townsend Corporation of America and of the Townsend Management Company expressed shock and surprise at the complaints filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission against them and their companies on Monday.

Ruggiero Ricci, American violinist, Maureen Forrester, Canadian contralto, Hans Richter Haaser, German pianist, and Henryk Szeryng, Polish-Mexican-American violinist, will make their Lewisohn Stadium debuts this summer.

A new contribution to the literature of World War II will be made tomorrow when Holt, Rinehart Winston publishes "The Watery Maze: The Story of Combined Operations," by Bernard Fergusson Before Dunkirk, the idea of detaching admirals, generals and air marshals from their traditional services and organizing them into a single, semi-independent unit was considered revolutionary.

The board of directors of the General American Transportation Corporation elected Spencer D. Moseley as president yesterday. Mr. Moseley, formerly assistant to the president, will continue as a director. He succeeds T.M. Thompson, who was named chairman and chief executive officer.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 25 -- Two German Jews who were Zionist officials in Nazi Germany faced Adolf Eichmann in court today and recalled meetings with him when he had been an arrogant Gestapo officer.

It was "go-to-meeting day" yesterday for stockholders around the country. The number of annual meetings reached a high for the year. There were no less than eighty meetings of those companies the securities of which are listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

Although the critically acclaimed "La Dolce Vita" is already established as the highest grossing Italian film ever released in the world market, Italian studios are continuing to model their major productions after "Hercules."
McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N.J., April 25 -- It was an odd place for a friendship to begin, 15,000 feet over Tunis. Especially when one "friend" shoots an airplane out from under the other.

John B. Oakes, new editorial page editor of The New York Times, has been a member of The New York Times staff for fifteen years, first as editor of the Review of the Week and, since 1949, as a member of the editorial board.

BOSTON, April 25 (AP) -- Gene Conley, fresh from his labors with basketball's Boston Celtics, beat the Washington Senators, 6 -- 1, today in his pitching debut with the Red Sox. He hurled a seven-hitter.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- An Air Force spokesman told Congress today that "we need something more than we presently have" to curb strikes on intercontinental ballistics missile sites.

In New York yesterday, air conditioning went on in many movie theatres, skaters took some final spins around Rockefeller Center's pond and tennis players, needing Park Department permits, deposited quarters in photo machines -- and complained when the results were something less than Cartier-Bresson.
MONROE, La., April 25 (AP) -- Eight Negroes, members of a "black supremacy" group, were sentenced today to fines averaging $830 each, or eight months in jail.
A speaking permit for a religious group that wants to present the views of an American Nazi leader here will not be canceled, a Park Department official said yesterday.

What did the President of the United States say to the Mayor of New York and vice versa? Well, we know that Mr. Wagner admitted the political situation in New York was "a little confusing." Let us try to imagine the rest.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 25 -- Adlai E. Stevenson spent his first relatively quiet day today since Jan. 20, when he took up his duties as chief United States representative in the United Nations.
Representatives of two Manhattan veterans' posts and a Jewish congregation admitted yesterday that they had filed false financial statements with official agencies about their bingo operations.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 25 -- An Atlas rocket carrying a Project Mercury capsule toward orbit veered off course and was destroyed today.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- There appeared to be a visible lessening of tension here tonight with the news of the collapse of the generals' revolt in Algeria.
BALTIMORE, April 25 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles did all their scoring in the first five innings and dealt a 5-2 defeat to the Cleveland Indians tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- There will be 139,061 eligible teachers graduating this June, but only 102,000 will see classroom duty.

Columbia, the gem of the successful 1958 America's Cup defense, gained a new owner yesterday. The 12-meter yacht became the property of Paul Vincent Shields of New York and Southampton, L.I., a 71-year-old Wall Street financier.

Five months ago John F. Kennedy was elected President by one of the closest votes in American history. The slightest change in public sentiment and he would have run second best. His margin of victory was probably due to his personal attributes and not so much to the views he expressed in the campaign.
European showmanship will go on United States television every Friday next season over the National Broadcasting Company network.
The fourth Salute to Spring will be staged tonight on the steps of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-first Street.

YOUNGSTERS who are learning to emulate the swashbuckling swordsmen of the motion-picture screen are discovering that behind the vacant smiles of their cinema idols lurk hair-trigger minds and surpassing mental and physical coordination, self-discipline and muscular control.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) April 25 -- A frail old man took the witness stand at the trial of Adolf Eichmann today and described the terror of the first Nazi deportation of Jews from Germany in 1938.
The Plaza Hotel, one of the few remaining strongholds of Edwardian elegance in New York, is yielding to television at last -- although in white Regency cabinets.
NEW HAVEN, April 25 -- $3,000,000 grant from the Food Foundation to expand international studies in areas non-neglected by American education was announced today Yale University.
Gordon Myers made his New York debut last night in a Carnegie Recital Hall piano program that it would have been a pleasure to be able to praise highly.

Chemical Bank New York Trust Company announced yesterday that Sherrill P. Newton and John G. Riddell had been elected vice presidents. Both were formerly investment tmst officers, connected with the bank's trust investment department at 100 Broadway.

Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation had first-quarter sales of $159,959,000, or 1.9 per cent below the record of $163,132,000 in the initial 1960 quarter, Thomas S. Nichols, chairman, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting in Saltville, Va. Net profit fell to $5,115,000, or 38 cents a share, from $8,567,000, or 64 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.
The nation's two major union of deep-sea unlicensed seamed are strongly at odds over each other's activities on the nation shallow draft inland waterway.

CHICAGO, April 25 (AP) -- The Government report on stocks of soybeans in all positions as of April exerted today fall the bullish price effect on old crop contracts that the Board of Trade allows in one day and those deliveries were bid up the 10-cent limit.
ALGIERS, Wednesday, April 26 -- The generals who led Algeria through four days of tumultuous rebellion slipped off today in defeat.
Sales and earnings of the General Motors Corporation, the world's largest automobile producer, declined notably in the first quarter of this year from the record levels of a year before.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Kennedy and President Sukarno of Indonesia joined today in cautioning newly independent countries to guard against attempts to subvert their freedom "by means of imperialism in all its manifestations."

An assertion that "nearly everything is on the positive side" in the long-term outlook for the economy was advanced yesterday by Raymond Rodgers, professor of banking at the Graduate School of Business Administration of New York University.
NEW DELHI, India, April 25 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru has tempered considerably his strong criticism of the United States regarding the rebel landings in Cuba last week.

MONTREAL, April 25 (Canadian Press) -- The port manager of Montreal, Guy Beaudet, said today that reports published last week that chaos was threatening the Montreal waterfront were "grossly exaggerated and meant nothing but detrimental publicity."

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 25 -- King Baudouin administered the oath of office today to a new coalition Cabinet headed by Theo Lefevre, president of the Christian Social party, as Premier and Paul-Henri Spaak, Socialist former Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, as Vice Premier and Foreign Minister.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Postmaster General J. Edward Day told Congress today that if it refused to increase mail rates by some $741,000,000 a year it would be abandoning a policy that it established in 1958.

TORONTO, April 25 (Canadian Press) -- Kerr-Addison Gold Mines, Ltd., cleared $1,298,533, or 27.4 cents a share, in the three months ended on March 31, compared with $1,322,803, or 28 cents, in the 1960 period.
PINEHURST, N.C., April 25 (AP) -- The medalist, Wayne Jackson, was defeated by Dale Morey, 3 and 2, in the opening round of the North and South amateur golf tournament today.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The State Department reiterated today that a verified ceasefire was "a first essential step" before the United States would join any international conference on Laos.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The House voted today the $600,000,000 requested by President Kennedy to launch a long-term aid program for Latin America.
Plans for the most extensive public housing program yet undertaken by the city were filed yesterday by the New York City Housing Authority.
LONDON, April 25 -- Prime Minister Macmillan stressed today the difficulties facing Britain in her movement toward joining the European Common Market.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The projection yesterday of the nation's airport needs by the Federal Aviation Agency offered nothing new to the controversy over a jet airport site in metropolitan New York.

Those rumors concerning Bette Davis' appearance in Tennessee Williams' drama, "The night of the Iguana," turn out to be correct. Verification was gained yesterday from Charles Bowden, co-sponsor with Ridge-Bullock.
United Press International added new dimensions to news coverage in the last year, Frank H. Bartholomew, U.P.I. president, said yesterday at the opening of the press service's annual meeting here.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Kennedy pledged today his determination to "step up our efforts" so that the United States would "prevail" on the new frontier of space.
In a spectacular rebound, the stock market recovered yesterday between 65 and 83 per cent of its Monday losses, depending on the index used.

EVERY year at about this time the Conservation Commissioner issues a public warning that the "adoption" of deer fawns and other infant wild animals is not only foolish and inhumane but also against the law. And every year the tender-hearted keep oft doing it.

A protest against the use of only two crew members in the cockpits of a new turbine-propeller airliner operated by Trans-Canada Air Lines was issued yesterday by C.N. Sayen as president of the International Federation of Air Line Pilots Associations.
HARVARD and Stanford University players won the annual intercollegiate bridge tournament this year, in a competition in which 170 American colleges took part.

A great university does not remain great by standing still. New York University, now celebrating its 130th anniversary, cannot be accused of even pausing for breath. President Carroll V. Newsom announces a new $75,000,000 three-year development program "to meet the minimum demands upon us" before a ten-year $102,500,000 program has even been completed.

Five men were honored yesterday at the eleventh annual Tiney Hillman Foundation foundation awards luncheon at the Commodore Hotel. Awards $500 went to the five men for book, news article and a television show. William L. Shirer, author of "The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich" received a special award.

Oregon borrowed $37,300,000 in the bond market yesterday. Of the securities sold, $30,000,000 were veterans' welfare bonds, and $7,300,000 were obligations to finance the construction of secondary educational facilities. Competition to purchase both issues was keen.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 25 -- The conference of Congolese leaders at Coquilhatville has become a test of strength between President Joseph Kasavubu of the Central Government and Moise Tshombe, President of Katanga Province.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. ordered the partial closing of a second Brooklyn public school late yesterday as confusion continued over a similar action in the Sheepshead Bay area Monday.
IT is no coincidence that when compliments about a blouse are handed out, that blouse often comes from Bonwit Teller.
Earnings of the United States Steel Corporation for the first quarter plummeted to their lowest level for a non-strike quarter in a decade, the company disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Most Latin-American diplomats here are not downcast by the defeat of the anti-Castro forces that landed in Cuba last week. They feel that it carried a lesson for their countries, and that the lesson will not be lost.
The United Whelan Corporation has sold Crawford Clothes, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary, to Sol Wolk Sons, Pittsburgh clothing wholesaler, it was announced yesterday by Charles Green, chairman.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 25 (UPI) -- Stephen A. Douglas, the "little giant" who was the political opponent of Abraham Lincoln, was honored today by the Illinois Legislature on the 100th anniversary of Douglas' struggle to keep southern Illinois in the Union.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange dropped 7 to 39 points (35 cents to $1.95 a bale) yesterday. Far July showed the extreme loss.

MIAMI, April 25 -- In predawn proceedings packed with drama, the Castro regime produced in Havana today a man presented as a captured rebel soldier who had once been a police spy and a killer in the ousted Batista dictatorship.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Mayor Wagner of New York discussed city and state Democratic politics with President Kennedy today, but said he had no solution to the factional fighting and "confused" situation.
The thirteen-story apartment building at 300 West End Avenue, corner of Seventy-fourth Street, has been purchased by Chamberlain Properties, Inc., realty investors and syndicators.
TUNIS, April 25 -- North Africans here greeted the news that the Algiers mutiny had collapsed with deep satisfaction today.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 25 -- The state Commissioner of Housing and Community Renewal warned tonight that the state would withdraw urban renewal funds from communities that delayed projects.
Arthur Hays Sulzberger retired yesterday as publisher of The New York Times and was succeeded in that post by his son-in-law, Orvil E. Dryfoos.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Kennedy will ask Congress tomorrow to extend and greatly liberalize the National Defense Education Act of 1958.
ST. LOUIS, April 25 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves scored three runs in the eighth inning tonight and defeated the Cardinals, 4 -- 3.
Orvil E. Dryfoos becomes publisher of The New York Times at the age of 48 after nineteen years of service on the newspaper.

The appointment of a man with the qualifications of Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor to review United States intelligence services and paramilitary activities suggests the seriousness of President Kennedy's determination to find out what went wrong in the intelligence operations that led up to the Cuban fiasco of last week. The implication is that changes in the functioning of the Central Intelligence Agency, its status and its personnel are contemplated.

AT the beginning of "The Heartless Light,"* an angry and immensely readable novel by Gerald Green, there is a list of the chief characters -- thirty-seven of them. It is proof of Mr. Green's sound professional skill that all of these ordinary, unimportant, unpleasant people fit neatly into his intricate plot.

All dogs in this city must be licensed by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals before Sunday, the society announced yesterday. Failure to obtain a 1961 license may cost an owner a $10 fine in addition to the $3 license charge.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- The Zenith Radio Corporation announced plans yesterday for entering the newly-authorized stereophonic FM radio field with a complete line of receiver models "at the earliest possible moment."
HOUSTON, April 25 (UPI) -- First-quarter earnings of Texaco, Inc., rose 11.1 per cent to a record of $108,141,171, or $1.75 a share, from $97,313,051, or $1.61 a share, in the 1960 period.
The promotion of Joseph A. Medernach to the post of vice president of Moore-McCormack Lines was announced here yesterday by William T. Moore, president of the steamship line.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- President Kennedy urged the American people today to unite in an hour of prayer at 11 A.M. on Memorial Day, May 30. He urged that they pray "for a new world of law yhere peace and justice shall prevail."
WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) -- Welfare Secretary Abraham A. Ribicoff agreed tonight to debate President Kennedy's plan for medical care for the aged with the head of the American Medical Association.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., April 25 -- The stately and ardent iambs of the Elizabethan, Christopher Marlowe, reverberated last night through the huge gleaming gymnasium of the University of Florida.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The "Aid-to-India Club" met here today for its fourth session on helping India with her third five-year plan.

Net income of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, Syracuse, N.Y., totaled $12,703,652 in the first quarter of 1961, compared with $11,966,677 in 1960. Earnings in the latest period, after preferred dividend requirements, were 86 cents a share, against 85 cents on fewer shares outstanding in the 1960 period.

The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday it had a net loss of $4,259,655 last month, in contrast to a profit of $2,075,554 in the 1960 month. The March loss increased the carrier's deficit for the first quarter to $17,489,954. In the 1960 period, the railroad cleared $3,294,805, or 51 cents a share.

The 1960-61 appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund brought a record contribution of $572,816. This total, announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the fund, compares with $557,701.89 for the 1959-60 appeal.
PARIS, Wednesday, April 26 -- The French Army mutiny in Algeria collapsed shortly after midnight, with its leaders apparently in flight.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The world's biggest device for probing the heart of matter has at last gone into action as a research tool.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Mayor Wagner won an apparent commitment today for changing a provision of the Kennedy Administration's housing bill that he said could end the Federally aided program in New York State.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 25 -- A quarrel between the ruler and the deputy ruler of Kuwait has raised a question as to who will inherit the Persian Gulf sheikdom, whose annual oil revenues exceed $4,000,000.
Following is the text of a statement made by Arthur Hays Sulzberger to the annual meeting of the New York Times Company yesterday:

PARIS, April 25 -- The diplomatic pattern emerging in Europe has already been changed by France's tragic minuet of death. General de Gaulle's dream of linking this country tightly with Spain and building a Mediterranean alliance may now be considered finished.

Edward W. Bradley's 2-year-old colt, Briar Lea, set a season record for five furlongs at Aqueduct yesterday when he finished first by eight lengths in the $6,000 Danbury. The record that he bettered was his own.

ALBANY, April 25 -- A bill to permit bank holding companies to obtain 100 per cent ownership of subsidiaries without the necessity of establishing "phantom banks" has been approved by Governor Rockefeller.
If the country has been in the grip of an economic recession, the City Transit Authority has avoided it.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 25 -- A new political party was being created in Israel tonight. The formation of the party sought to reduce the personal power of Premier David Ben-Gurion and to force important changes in the foreign and domestic policies of Israel.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) -- The President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity will meet with industry and labor leaders next week for a "thorough" review of the Administration's anti-discrimination order.
Benjamin M. McKelway of The Washington Star was re-elected president of The Associated Press yesterday.
A tree grows in the Bronx and thereby hangs a marketing tale.

Blood will be given today to the Red Cross at City College, West 139th Street and Convent Avenue; the Veterans Administration Hospital, 130 West Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx, and by employes of downtown insurance concerns, at the National Board of Fire Underwriters, 85 John Street.

The admitted deficiencies in reading and writing by almost 40 per cent of the junior high school pupils demand a better solution than the employment of 500 remedial-learning teachers. The expenditure of $585 by taxpayers last year to keep a student in our city's public schools has not produced students qualified in the basic skills.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. and Goldman, Sachs Co. and associates offered yesterday to the public $30,000,000 of twenty-five year 4 3/4 per cent debentures of Motorola, Inc., priced at 100 and accrued interest.

Anthoney J. Savello, a Queens landscape gardener who was convicted of desertion from the army last year, was ordered revered yesterday to all rights and privileges as a result of a reversal of his conviction.
KANSAS CITY, April 25 (AP) -- The Kansas City Athletics pummeled the Minnesota Twins, 20 -- 2, and young Norm Bass scored his first major-league pitching victory tonight.

Frank Pace Jr., former Secretary of the Army, received the eighth annual Gold Medal Award of the Amateur Athletic Union at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night. The award was in honor of his long service to amateur athletics and his record as an athlete, sportsman and public servant.

H. Louis Thompson, president of Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting in Philadelphia yesterday that he was hopeful the company would present a plan of diversification and building to its shareholders before the end of the year.

Gains in operating revenues, net earnings and sales of gas, electricity and steam for the quarter and twelve months ended on March 31 were reported yesterday by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.
Sheldon Bender, who once told Nat Holman not to put him in a basketball game because "I'm not ready yet," will receive an award from Holman tomorrow night.

A venerable passenger ship, one of two that have been given a new lease on life after being tied up at a Hoboken shipyard pier for more than two years, will head out to sea early this morning under a new name and a new flag.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Testimony that Ralph J. Cordiner, chairman of the board of the General Electric Company, knew in 1952 that company officials were con spiring with competitors to fix prices was placed today in the record of a Senate investigating committee.

COLOGNE, Germany, April 25 -- Chancellor Adenauer told cheering delegates to the Christian Democratic Union's election-year congress today that a coalition with the opposition Social Democratic party "is out of the question."

The internal warfare in the A.F.L.-C.I.O. indicates that the union of unions is in danger of breaking up. This is bad news for workers, employers and the country. In this time of test for all democratic institutions we cannot afford a return to the kind of cannibalistic conflict between rival labor organizations that preceded the merger in 1955.
BUENOS AIRES, April 25 -- Argentina was undergoing major shake-ups today in the Cabinet and in the restless army, with the prospect of more changes to come.

GALVESTON, Tex., April 25 (UPI) -- Compulsory health insurance through Social Security is a scheme "favoring tile rich at the expense of the poor," the head of the American Medical Association asserted today.
The recent death of James Lloyd Derby of New York at the age of 75 has recalled to surviving friends and associates his admirable character and his services to the country.
ALBANY, April 25 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today that the state would spend $50,700,000 on road and other projects for the 1964-65 World's Fair in New York City.

Leading choir soloists of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church will participate in the church's annual evening benefit concert next Tuesday in the Hunter College Playhouse. Proceeds will go to Youth Development, Inc., Interfaith Neighbors and other community youth organizations.
ALBANY, April 25 -- Employment in the state rose in March for the first time in four months, the state said today.

OUTDOOR-MINDED children and their families may enjoy a visit to Sterling Forest Gardens, a 125-acre attraction thirty-five miles from Manhattan. Now on display in this woodland setting are tulips, hyacinths, daffodils and other spring bulbs.

With the exception of wool and cottonseed oil, which were sharply higher in active trading yesterday, commodities on the New York exchanges registered narrow price movements in dull trading. Rubber, hides and soybean oil advanced; potatoes, cocoa and copper declined, and price movements for coffee, sugar and lead were mixed.

THINGS were definitely second-nightish for the American Ballet Theatre at the Broadway Theatre last night. Having put its best foot forward the night before, it seemed unable to get even its second best one into action on this occasion.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Senate-House conferees on the minimm wage bill today agreed essentially to take provisions of the Senate bill as desired by President Kennedy.

YONKERS, April 25 -- The owners of Bye Bye Byrd, the richest pacer around, and Mr. Budlong, who shows promise of moving into a similar category, have accepted bids for their standardbreds to compete in the $50,000 International Pace at Yonkers Raceway on the night of May 4.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Part of the official inquiry here into the Cuban fiasco will deal with the problems of a free press in a cold war.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., April 25 -- Rebukes to Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, were delivered today by Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York and Thomas J. Watson Jr., president of the International Business Machines Corporation, at I.B.M's annual meeting of stockholders here.

The six-story apartment house for forty-one families at 1925 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, has ben sold by the 1925 Ocean Avenue Realty Corporation. The plot is 80 by 100 feet. Assessed at $210,000, the property was bought by an investing client of Irving Bira, the broker in the sale.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 25 (AP) -- An Assistant Interior Secretary said today the Kennedy Administration was dedicated to the Federal power program, but was not against any one group.

Mikhail Tal of Latvia, defending his world chess title, and Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia played a second five-hour session in the sixteenth game yesterday in Moscow, according to Tass, the official Soviet news agency.
Presiding Justice Bernard Botein of the Appellate Division said yesterday that "anarchy" would result if prompt action were not taken on the groundwork for court reform.

Production of paperboard in the week ended last Saturday rose to a six-week high of 322,181 tons, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. This compares with 315,490 tons the week before and 291,076 a year ago.
LOS ANGELES, April 25 (AP) -- Stu Miller choked off a seventh-inning Los Angeles rally tonight and San Francisco beat the Dodgers, 3 -- 1, in their series opener before 29,240.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 25 -- The United States has proposed that President Kennedy's Peace Corps be the model for a United Nations effort.

Operations of the Procter Gamble Company in the nine months ended on March 31 resulted in an increase in earnings of about 10 per cent from the level of the corresponding three-quarter period of the year before, the concern reported yesterday.
PARIS, Wednesday, April 26 -- The mutiny in Algeria flickered out in darkness early today with few Parisians the wiser.
Rising prices in the market for United States Government securities held the center of interest in the market for prime, fixed-income securities yesterday.

The new $800,000 home ofI the Actors Fund of America willI be dedicated and officiallyI opened in Englewood, N. J., onI May 5. Vincent Freedley, president of the fund, will lay the[ cornerstone of the completedI building.
TRENTON, April 25 -- The State Health Commissioner warned the public today on the possibility of getting infectious hepatitis from eating raw clams.
George Meany prodded his critics in the industrial unions yesterday to come up with a specific plan to settle jurisdictional rows through arbitration.
BUENOS AIRES, April 25 (UPI) -- President Arturo Frondizi began reorganizing his Government today following a series of Cabinet resignations that coincided with a purge of top army officers.

TRENTON, April 25 -- James P. Mitchell, Republican candidate for Governor, said today he would engage in no joint appearances with his Democratic opponent, Richard J. Hughes, in the forthcoming campaign.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) -- A Senate-House conference committee quickly agreed today on compromise legislation to help needy children of unemployed parents. The program is expected to cost $200,000,000 during the next fourteen months.

MOVE over, "The Sound of Music." Make room, "Camelot." "Young Abe Lincoln," a musical for children, made it to Broadway yesterday afternoon and it should be a neighbor of the town's hit musicals for some time.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- A revised bill to reduce the amount of duty-free goods a tourist may bring into the country was approved today by the House Ways and Means Committee.

The police reported yesterday that 1,016 persons had been hurt in city traffic accidents last week, one more than in the like 1960 week. There were a total of 1,594 accidents, of which 721 involved personal injuries.
The eighth nation-wide civil defense test, Operation Alert, 1961, will begin today. Public participation by New Yorkers will be confined to a ten-minute period Friday afternoon.
"When I am not away from home I live in bed, to beat the lonesomeness," Mark Twain wrote in 1906, four years before his death.
GUATEMALA, April 25 (AP) -- Carlos Marcello, New Orleans underworld figure, was released today by Judge Rafael Alonso Parada.
Pierre Salinger, Presidential news secretary, said yesterday he felt the American press must assume some responsibility for the repercussions of the unsuccessful rebel attack on Cuba.
LONDON, April 25 -- The Laotian Government has accepted a British request for a cease-fire in fighting with Left-Wing rebels, the Foreign Office announced today.
'Round and 'round they'll go this week-end at the Penn Relays and the Drake Relays in track and field's twin baton-passing showpieces of the spring season.

AN elegant alternative to the usual buffet items of cold roast turkey and baked ham is rolled roast of veal in aspic. The preparation is far from formidable; in fact, any cook with a reasonable amount of experience can do it to perfection.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- On the day the anti-Castro forces landed in Cuba members of the Cuban Revolutionary Council were kept incommunicado by the Central Intelligence Agency in an old house near Miami, official sources here acknowledged today.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 25 -- Negroes have complained to the White House that they have been refused tickets to a South Carolina Democratic party dinner here tomorrow at which Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges will speak.

DETROIT, April 25 -- Foul weather continues to dog the Yankees as well as most of the other clubs in the American League's sprawling ten-club circuit. A drizzling rain and below 40-degree temperature forced the cancellation of tonight's Yankee-Tiger game.

THE maid situation continues to plague the American housewife. It seems that no one wants to be a true domestic. Even overseas help, the latest source to be tapped, has its ups and downs. For the last few years many young girls from Dublin to Berlin have made their way into homes here, either through agencies or through friends.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Two-thirds of the nation's 150 major industrial centers still show "substantial" unemployment in spite of reports of a pick-up in business activity.

The stockholders of Merck Co., Inc., elected Albert W. Merck as a director at their annual meeting in Rahway, N.J., yesterday. Mr. Merck is the son of the late George W. Merck, former chairman and president, and a grandson of George Merck, who founded the company in 1891.

Directors of Ingersoll-Rand Company and the Aldrich Pump Company have approved a proposal to merge, it was announced yesterday by Robert H. Johnson, chairman of Ingersoll-Rand, at the annual meeting at Phillipsburg, N.J.
Four gang members were arraigned on homicide charges in Broklyn Adolescent Court yesterday in the fatal shooting of an 18-year-old youth Monday night.

Sales of the Square D Company, manufacturer of electrical distribution and control equipment, came to $25,682,446 in the quarter ended on March 31, against $27,585,950 a year earlier, stockholders were told at the annual meeting yesterday in Park Ridge, Ill.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 25 (AP) -- The top management of the General Electric Company, shaken by antitrust convictions, braced tonight for a face-to-face accounting to its shareholders.

A PARISIAN-style sidewalk cafe, Alaskan, Chinese and Mexican games and a hot dog stand will be features of the second annual International Children's Fair to be held at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue on Saturday.

Mayor Wagner designated six square blocks of the upper East Side yesterday as the object of a two-year program to save the neighborhood from blight. The area, to be called the Carnegie Hill Conservation District, is the sixth such place to be designated in the last eighteen months.

FOR the four spring training periods prior to the last one Rogers Hornsby served as special hitting instructor to the Chicago Cubs during their exercises in Arizona. But Phil Wrigley revamped the educational curriculum of his Bruins this year, eliminated the top faculty post of manager and bobbed up with a professorial staff of nine coaches.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Justice Department asked the Federal courts today to force the reopening of public schools in Prince Edward County, Va.

A work stoppage by printers delayed publication of the early editions of today's New York Times. The New York Herald Tribune, The Daily News and The Mirror, not directly involved in the stoppage, delayed their own early editions until enough printers had returned at The Times to permit publication.
Governor Rockefeller said last night that the 1961 legislative session was "one of the greatest" in the state's history. It made significant contributions toward improving conditions, he declared.

The appointment of judges to fill the new places on the Federal bench is going to prove a test of the Administration's capacity to put ability above politics -- where that priority is most necessary. Attorney General Kennedy will take a large share of the praise -- or blame -- for the quality of the judges chosen.
DETROIT, April 26 -- The Yankees today plunged right into a deep freeze and brought down the league-leading Tigers.
Joan Plowright is leaving the east of "A Taste of Honey." A spokesman said yesterday that Miss Plowright, who was recently married to Sir Laurence Olivier, is pregnant.

BOSTON, April 26 (UPI) -- Federal Judge Charles E. Wyzanski Jr. apologized today for an "unjustifiable" attack on the Massachusetts Attorney General, Edward J. McCormack Jr. The judge also disqualified himself from a case that had touched off their quarrel.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- United States Ambassadors have been instructed to sound out Latin-American Governments on taking collective action against Cuba and Communist subversion in the hemisphere.
The Long Island Rail Road cut its net loss to $314,283 in March from $408,334 in the 1960 period, although operating revenues declined.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 26 (AP) -- Evidence in the trial in of two libel suits against The New York Times shows, the newspaper contended today, that four Alabama Negro ministers were improperly sued as co-defendants.

PALATKA, Fla., April 26 -- The way of the theatre is hard, and the difficulties multiply when the living professional threatre seeks to go where it is all but unknown except as an amiable amateur diversion.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 26 -- Valerian A. Zorin declared today that the Soviet Union was ready to come to Cuba's aid in the event of an attack.

The American Ballet Theatre presented last night the second premiere of its season at the Broadway Theatre, in the form of "Points on Jazz," choreographed Dania Krupska to a special score by Dave Brubeck.

However, history is not like a boxing match or a baseball game. It flows like a river. The United States and Cuba are too much intertwined by history, geography, economics and strategy to be separated.

In your April 18 editorial on the U.N. budgetary crisis, you say that "there can be no doubt that refusal to pay assessments levied by a majority vote in the U.N. may ultimately destroy the U.N. itself."
PARIS, April 26 -- Former Gen. Maurice Challe, the principal leader in the four-day French Army mutiny in Algeria, was flown to Paris this afternoon and locked up in the Sante prison.
ISLIP, L.I., April 26 -- An 18-year-old Brentwood youth was charged today with killing his older brother last night while the two fought with knives over which television show to watch.
Michigan borrowed $25,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to continue the permanent financing of the state's trunk line highway construction program.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 26 -- A former Viennese furrier faced Adolf Eichmann in court today and described the former Gestapo officer's actions during the Crystal Nnght program of Nov. 9, 1938.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 26 -- A jewel in its own natural setting, the $25,000 added Blue Grass Stakes will be run at the Keeneland race track tomorrow. Though overshadowed in importance by the triple-crown races for 3-year-olds, the Blue Grass is an immensely popular event in this region so rich in turf tradition.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has obtained television rights to all professional games in the National Football League during the regular seasons of 1961 and 1962. The league will receive $4,650,000 annually, which will be divided equally among the fourteen teams in the league.
Bumped at the start, George D. Widener's 3-year-old filly, Seven Thirty, closed powerfully in the last quarter-mile of the seven-furlong Comely at Aqueduct yesterday and won by three lengths.
CHICAGO, April 26 (AP) -- Traders in grain futures today wrung out all or nearly all the advance that seeped through the bullish market in yesterday's transactions.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The first of President Kennedy's "big five" bills was on its way to the White House today, by courtesy of thirty-one House Republicans.
LOS ANGELES, April 26 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers signed Don Newcombe last night and will farm him to Spokane of the Pacific Coast League.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 26 -- The promotion of thirty-three members of the Princeton University faculty was announced today by Dr. Robert F. Goheen, president of the university.

UNITED STATES NAVAL BASE, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, April 25 -- Premier Fidel Castro earned new respect in last week's battle with the Cuban rebels, not only from the Communist nations that have been supporting his regime, but also apparently from some of his own people.

A THOUSAND essays a year to the contrary notwithstanding, there may be no true mystery about the enduring appeal of the Civil War. Its chronicles provide limitless escapism for man's insatiable, deplorably combattical nature.
The recent show of strength long-term bonds of gilt-edge trade became more emphatic yesterday, except among hightrade corporate obligations traded over the counter.

DETROIT, April 26 -- The spring upswing in sales of new autos continued in the second ten days of April. Even so, however, the daily rate of purchase was running 20 per cent behind that of a year ago.
ALBANY, April 26 -The state announced $360,000,000 worth of new highway projects today for the fiscal year that began April 1. This includes a record $145,000,000 outlay for New York City.
CHICAGO, April 26 -- The Santa Fe Railway an the Post Office Department started an experiment involving "containerized' mail handling today, Ernest S. Marsh, president of the railroad, said.
The Lionel Corporation is planning to further expand its electronics business through a merger with Textron Electronics, Inc., 76 per cent owned subsidiary of Textron, Inc.

SYRACUSE, April 26 -- The management and the Board of Directors of the General Electric Company won an overwhelming vote of confidence today at a stockholders' meeting. The stockholders, at their longest annual meeting in memory here, were enthusiastic and noisy in supporting the leadership of the company under its chairman, Ralph J. Cordiner. The 2,756 stockholders rejected several anti management proposals by massive votes.
PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -The New York Herald Tribune won the F. Wayland Ayer Cup today for excellence in typography, make-up and printing.
TUNIS, April 26 -- Tunisian and Algerian leaders hailed President de Gaulle's victory over the French Armymutiny today as a major step toward solving the problem of Algeria's relations with France.

Foreign languages are in the air. Our new man in Paris, General Gavin, makes sure to speak in French to counteract contentions that he knows little of the tongue of the land to which he has been assigned.

Mikhail Tal of Latvia, the world chess champion, and Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia agreed to a draw yesterday without resuming play in the sixteenth game of their title match at the Variety Theatre in Moscow, according to Tass, the official Soviet news agency.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Since bad news subordinates the good, especially when it is the product of bloody violence, a report made in Washington during the Cuban crisis of democratic progress in another area of the Caribbean, and of the determination there to help keep international Communist regimes out of this hemisphere, went virtually unnoticed.
YONKERS, April 26 -- A crowd of 30,000, a handle of more than $2,000,000 and another victory for Su Mac Lad are the predictions for tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The United States is continuing to send military equipment to the Royal Laotian Army. The uninterrupted Soviet airlift to the pro-Communist rebels and continued rebel attacks were cited by the State Department spokesman today as among the reasons for this.
Easing of tension in Paris and Cuba brought a lull to most New York commodity markets yesterday. Trading was dull and prices closed generally mixed.

The New York City Transit Authority reports that over fifteen million more passengers rode its subways and buses in the first nine months of the present fiscal year than in the same period the year before.

Henry Irving Brock first came to work for this newspaper in 1902 and served it loyally and joyfully for most of the many years thereafter until advancing age made his retirement necessary. He was a Virginian who loved New York. Richly seasoned in the world's best literature, he was a philosopher, an enemy of intolerance, a man of strong and unyielding opinions, salted with gentle humor.

The spread of American jazz overseas has returned to us a charming dividend in Toshiko Akiyoshi, a pianist, who can be heard this week at the Half Note Club, 296 Spring Street. She is appearing with the Toshiko Mariano quartet, a group she leads jointly with her husband, Charlie Mariano, an alto saxophonist.
Members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association were told yesterday that the Shell Oil Company's allnewspaper campaign was going "extremely well."

The prospect of an amicable settlement in the Congo has dimmed again because of the outbreak of a wide-open conflict between President Kasavubu, recognized head of the Congo state, and President Tshombe of secessionist Katanga. The conflict assumed ominous proportions when Mr. Tshombe, who controls most of the Congo's wealth, walked out of a new "summit" meeting of Congolese leaders only to be arrested by President Kasavubu's soldiers.

Net new orders for metal-cutting and forming machine tools received by the industry in this country in March aggregated $69,550,000, representing a rise of 49.9 per cent from the $46,400,000 recorded in February. There were nineteen working days in February, compared with twenty-three in March.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Dr. Harold C. Urey, winner of the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, suggested today that the moon was considerably older than the earth. It may, he said, have formed 100,000,000 years earlier.

The electric utility industry expects to reach new highs in generating capability and production this year, despite th recession, the Edison Electric Institute reported in its twenty-ninth semi-annual electric power survey issued for publication yesterday.

Borough President Edward R. Dudley yesterday cancelled an unusual permit that had given the Slattery Contracting Company control over traffic on Twenty-seventh Street between Madison Avenue and Park Avenue South.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 2 to 14 points yesterday, except the new July, which advanced 5 points. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

A new study of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt from the point of view of leaders in other countries during the Roosevelt era will be published May 19 by Van Nostrand. Called "Roosevelt Through Foreign Eyes," the book has been written by Nicholas Halasz.
John F. Kennedy will pay his first visit as President to New York City today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The average of prices of goods that consumers buy declined slightly last month while the prices of consumer services continued to rise. The over-all consumer price level was unchanged. It has been relatively stable for five months.
CHICAGO, April 26 (UPI) -- Don Zimmer's home run with one out in the tenth sent the Chicago Cubs to a 3-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today.

Passels of cats, some cool, some hep and all fanciful, will patter around the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow night in a ballet created for this year's Embassy Ball by Raymundo de Larrain.

ALGIERS, April 26 -- A 9 P.M. curfew was imposed on Algiers today. It was the first of rigorous measures to stamp out the sparks of the four-day rebellion, which collapsed dramatically early in the day.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., April 26 -- The country's first running track constructed entirely of an all-weather material called Perma-Track was inaugurated at C.W. Post College today when the Athletic Association of Long Island Colleges held its second track and field meet.

UNITED STATES NAVAL BASE, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, April 26 -- Virtually all Cuban workers at this base will have to stay away from their jobs next Monday to attend May Day rallies and to hear denunciations of the United States and their Navy employers.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Whote House has told Cabinet officers and their subordinates to mention President Kennedy's name more often in their speeches.

WHEN the curtain goes up on a play at the Queen's Theatre, home of the Abbey Players, Philomena Fleming stands looking down on the full house from a box or from one of the three balconies. Her blue eyes have a serious look about them, and sometimes a suggestion of a furrow appears beneath the taut blonde hair that rims her pale, clear forehead.

As the overture to "South Pacific" began last night in the City Center at least one listener was seized by a strange and uneasy sensation. There seemed to be a tentativeness in the orchestra pit, a certain sort of lack of sweep and power.

BALTIMORE, April 26 (AP) -- A throwing error by the Orioles' first baseman, Jim Gentile, opened the door for three unearned runs by the Cleveland Indians tonight and paved the way for a 6-3 victory over Baltimore.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 26 -- Doubt was expressed here tonight by Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, that the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad could survive more than two years unless it was sold to a public agency.
Sanitation patrolmen mounted on motor scooters will soon search for litterbugs on such key streets as Madison and Fifth Avenues.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI) -- Trans World Airlines announced today it would start showing movies in the air on July 19. It will exhibit first-run, full-length movies on its long-range jet flights.

The chairman of the legislative committee of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York accused the State Banking Department yesterday of taking its cue from Federal authorities on savings bank matters.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 26 -- Hollywood paid tribute to young writers at the University of California at Los Angeles who won prizes in the seventh annual writing competition sponsored by Samuel Goldwyn.

The Zeckendorf Hotels Corporation has sold a ninety-seven-year leasehold on the Taft Hotel, Seventh Avenue and Fiftieth Street, to the Breitbart Corporation, Sheldon Lewis Breitbart, president. The buyers are realty investors and syndicators.
BOSTON, April 26 (AP) -- Dave Sisler made Jackie Jensen hit into a key double play today and preserved a 2 -- 1 victory for the Washington Senators over the Boston Red Sox.

The Republic Aviation Corporation has successfully tested a pinch plasma engine designed for interplanetary propulsion, Mundy I. Peale, president, reported at the annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, April 26 (UPI) -- Vinegar Bend Mizell pitched the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 3-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight. He hung on in the ninth after a homer by Frank Herrera and retired two pinch-hitters.

Dr. HAROLD CLAYTON UREY is, one of his colleagues said recently, "a pleasant man." "He gives you his full attention," the associate went on. "Then he'll start looking at his pictures of the moon, and you might just as well go away: he's thinking."
The present controversy over enlargement of Social Security to include medical aid for the aged brings to the fore a need to morally evaluate the propriety of compulsory welfare programs.
Contrasting strands of uncertainty made up the stock market yesterday. It ended up by some indicators, down by others. There were gains in the morning but from noon onward they were nibbled away.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 26 (AP) -- The United States Air Force opened an arms airlift to Government troops today after Vientiane officials charged the pro-Communist rebels had launched attacks on all fronts.

The other day a West Side stroller, on one of his almost-daily visits to Central Park, noticed at Central Park West and Eighty-fifth Street a pair of granite markers inscribed "Mariner's Gate." Although he had used this entrance quite often, it was the first time he had observed the markers.
