MIAMI, April 26 -- For all practical purposes the Cuban exile army was destroyed in last week's landing, according to statements by reliable sources here today.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 26 -- Striking dockers battled with the police on the quay at Aarhus in the most violent incident of the sixteen-day-old strike of 40,000 transport workers.

The State Investigation Commission reported yesterday that William P. Buckner, a convicted swindler, had received $172,529 from bingo games he promoted for seven nonprofit organizations in 1959 and 1960.
Cardinal Spellman charged yesterday that the Soviet Union viewed human life as "the world's cheapest commodity."
COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 26 -- The Government ordered a general mobilization today as a consequence of the civil disobedience campaign being conducted by the Tamil minority.

The United States Lawn Tennis Association and the West Side Tennis Club said yesterday that the 1961 national singles championships would be held at the Forest Hills stadium, in Queens, from Sept. 1-10.
Earnings of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation fell more than $10,000,000 in the first quarter of this year from the like period of 1960.

I am somewhat at a loss to understand either the general context or the inaccuracies of the article published in the financial section of the April 23 New York Times under the title: "Greek Debt Sheds Light on Surety."

The Pennsylvania Railroad reported yesterday that the comparative low level of business activity and the cost of additional wage increases and fringe benefits that became effective on March 1 had sharply increased its net deficits last month.

Governor Rockefeller's signature on a diluted billboard-control law, under which most advertising devices within 660 feet of interstate highways will be banned, is only a half victory for the preservation of scenic beauty in New York State.

VENICE, Italy, April 25 -- The rate at which Venice is sinking into her lagoon has increased greatly in recent years, and experts say the Queen of the Adriatic will cease to exist -- at least as a lagoon city -- in the not very remote future.

ST. LOUIS, April 26 (AP) -- A fifteen-hit attack, led by Hank Aaron and including home runs by John DeMerit and Roy McMillan, helped Don Nottebart and the Milwaukee Braves score an 8-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight and gain a sweep of the two-game series.
The annual benefit bazaar, garden party and tea of the Association Home will he held on the afternoon of May 17 at the home, 891 Amsterdam Avenue.

Dog show judges should not go hungry or be overworked or be stranded miles from public transportation, says Maxwell Riddle of Ravenna Ohio, who is one of them. Show-giving clubs should accord their abiters reasonable courtesy and not engage in "fishing" expeditions in an effort to find those whe will cut their fees, he declared.

A member of the former Moore commission said last night that "Charter revision for 1961 is dead" here. He laid the blame primarily on Mayor Wagner but also on delays by the Mayor's new Charter Revision Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- New efforts are under way to devise a compromise in the church-state dispute over eral aid to elementary and secondary schools. The discussions center on a proposal to combine the Administration's $2,298,000,000 school-aid bill with one to extend and liberalize the National Defense Education Act of 1958.
LONDON, April 27 -- The Soviet Government has cautioned Britain that the provision of military bases for West German forces in the British Isles would increase international tension.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun prosecution of persons involved in an alleged multimillion-dollar American Stock Exchange manipulation, the biggest since the scandal-ridden late Nineteen Twenties.

CINCINNATI, April 27 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds today traded Ed Bailey, a catcher, to the San Francisco Giants for Don Blasingame, a second baseman; Bob Schmidt, a catcher, and a player to be announced later.
ALBANY, April 27 -- The 1954 state law permitting real estate taxes on trailers was upheld today by the Court of Appeals.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 27 -- Moise Tshombe, President of Katanga Province, remained a virtual prisoner of Congolese soldiers today at the airport of Coquilhatville, capital of Equator Province.

Lucy Freeman, author of "Fight Against Fear" and "Hope for the Troubled," will have two new books published two weeks apart. The first will be "All the Way," written by Miss Freeman with Ted Atkinson, the fourth highest-ranking jockey in racing history.
LOS ANGELES, April 27 -- The lively Minnesota Twins turned back the lowly Los Angeles Angels today, 4 -- 2, in the first American League game ever played on the West Coast.

GENEVA, April 27 -- The United States warned today that the negotiations for a treaty to outlaw nuclear tests could be doomed by the Soviet demand for a three-man administrative council to oversee controls.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Six leaders of the world of art outlined today what each would do as President of the United States for a day.
MOSCOW, April 25 -- A comparison here of the tactics employed by Premier Khrushchev on Cuba and on Laos affords an insight into broad Communist strategy.

Six commercial television stations here have expressed a desire to contribute to the establishment and support of New York's first educational TV station. It is expected that the sale of station WNTA-TV (Channel 13) to an educational group will be announced soon.

The sanction of the State Department is being sought once more to take "West Side Story," now abroad, to Russia and Poland. This was one phase of a two-part conference that took place yesterday in Washington between Heath Bowman, chief of the State Department's cultural presentations division and Pete Kameron, co-lessee with Giora Godik of the successful Broadway musical.

Following is the text of President Kennedy's address last night to the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, as recorded by The New York Times:
The Board of Estimate adopted a record expense budget of $2,541,905,936 yesterday for the fiscal year starting July 1.

THE play variously called the throw-in, the end-play, the forced lead, the strip, the elimination, and other names, is not considered very difficult by advanced and expert players. However, it has always been ranked among the "post-graduate" plays in bridge because it requires advance planning.
SALLY ANN HOWES was a fair and radiant "Jane Eyre" in a television adaptation of the Charlotte Bronte novel on Channel 2 last night.

Lumber production in the week ended April 22 climbed to 233,426,-000 board feet, the best level of the year, according to reports from regional associations. In the prior week the figure was 221,645,000 board feet and a year ago it was 259,688,000 board feet.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged on far October to 4 to 22 points (20 cents to $1.10 a bale) up yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Kennedy Administration has, in effect, done away with the interest-rate ceiling of 4 1/4 per cent that was so much trouble to the Eisenhower Administration two years ago.
Flamenco music was the order of the evening in Town Hall last night as guitarist Carlos Montoya played his way through a program of songs and dances nurtured by Spanish gypsies.

Production of electric power eased in the week ended last Saturday to 14,311,000,000 kilowatt-hours from 14,434,000,000 the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. A year ago the figure was 13,567,000,000 kilowatt-hours.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 24 -- The movie industry is appraising some of President Kennedy's tax proposals more carefully than some of the scripts it buys. There are some in the industry who seem to think the tax plans were prepared particularly with Hollywood in mind.
A big increase in demand for local government bonds at the price levels generated by recent trading sessions was the outstanding development of the bond market yesterday.
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 27 -- The Russian Orthodox Church has applied for membership in the World Council of Churches.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 27 (AP) -- Ernest R. Breech was elected chairman of Trans World Airlines today, succeeding Warren Lee Pierson, who announced his retirement after fourteen years as chairman.

DETROIT, April 27 (UPI) -- The American Motors Corporation reported today that earnings for the second fiscal quarter fell by 80.56 per cent from the year-earlier level, while sales dropped about 38 per cent.
Gimbel Brothers, Inc., achieved the highest sales in its 119-year history in its fiscal year ended last Jan. 31, the annual report of Bruce A. Gimbel, president, disclosed yesterday.
The concerted effort to abolish the House Un-American Activities Committee can be viewed only with a mixture of admiration and trepidation.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., April 27 -- For her achievements in teaching American ideals to immigrants, Mrs. Joseph W. Rao tonight received the annual New York State Americanism Medal of the Daughters of the American Revolution.
ALGIERS, April 27 -- Europeans of Algiers surrendered more than 5,000 weapons today as this sullen city went discouragedly about its business.

COLOGNE, Germany, April 27 -- The Christian Democratic Union called on the West German people today to insure the country's prominent place in the world by returning the party to power in September's national elections.

THE call of the outdoors is luring local families into country lanes and highways left unexplored since last fall. These family trips provide an opportunity to share and discuss new experiences, be they nature trails or historic sites.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., April 26 -- The Rabbinical Assembly of America, a major wing of conservative Judaism, voiced opposition Wednesday to Federal aid grants or loans to non-public schools.
Trading in copper futures highlighted a generally higher but dull commodity market on New York exchanges yesterday.

After sixty-six years as a trustee of the Franklin Savings Bank, Howard Caswell Smith resigned yesterday, setting a possible record. He is believed to have been the oldest trustee in term of service in the savings bank industry.
PARIS, April 27 -- France moved fast today to punish those who had endangered national security by a four-day army mutiny in Algeria and to lock the door against those who might try it in the future.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The executive vice president of the General Electric Company denied under oath today that he had known about or had directed meetings between subordinate officials and competitors to fix prices.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 27 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, the Laotian neutralist who is recognized as Premier by the pro-Communist rebels, has indicated that there may not be a cease-fire in Laos until a political settlement has been worked out.

LONDON, April 27 -- Edward Heath, Deputy Foreign Secretary and Lord Privy Seal, has protested to the Soviet Union over the delay by the Communists in arranging a cease-fire in Laos. The protest was made yesterday to Aleksandr A. Soldatov, Soviet Ambassador to Britain.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 27 -- Nassau County Executive A. Holly Patterson named an eleven-member Mitchel Field Development Committee today. It will study the county's land needs at the 1,168-acre airbase near Hempstead, which is to be closed in June.
Printers at The New York Times returned to their jobs shortly before 3 P.M. yesterday after renewing a work stoppage that had begun the day before.
The Disabled American Veterans suspended three local chapters yesterday as a result of irregularities in bingo operations disclosed by the State Investigation Commission.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 27 -- Jacob Sher's Sherluck got off in front and stayed there to win the $34,300 Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland today. Sherluck, one of the outsiders among the ten Kentucky Derby candidates that competed in the mile-and-an-eighth race beat Flutterby of the Alberta Ranches by six lengths.

The appointment of Jack I. Straus as general chairman of the Police Athletic League's $830,000 fund campaign, which begins Monday, was announced yesterday. Mr. Straus is chairman of the board of R.H. Macy Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- President Kennedy discussed today with some of his principal advisers and with Congressional leaders counter-measures that might be taken if the Communist-backed rebels in Laos continued fighting.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $7,000,000 to $37,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements increased $21,000,000 to $709,000,000.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Following is text of President Kennedy's special message to Congress on conflicts of interest:

In an attempt to reduce lateness of its ticker tape, the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that starting on May 1 it would put into effect the following procedures at the opening each day and during each trading session when it appeared that the volume might cause the tape to run late.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Administration forces began a drive today for action this session on President Kennedy's program of medical care for the aged.
WARSAW, April 25 -- The climate of relations between the United States and Poland, fair and warm last winter, has turned abruptly frosty with the coming of spring.
Featherbedding by unions has prevented newspapers from making full use of technological progress, according to a report yesterday to the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

ZERALDA, Algeria, April 27 -- The First Paratroop Regiment of the French Foreign Legion, fully armed and carrying red roses, roared dramatically out of its camp here today to dissolution as a fighting unit.

Emphasis in the stock market shifted to low-price issues yesterday. Even so, volume declined on the New York Stock Exchange. Eight of the fifteen most active issues closed below $25 a share, ten below $25.25.
Newspaper publishers and executives reacted cautiously last night to President Kennedy's appeal for self-regulation by the press on stories affecting national security.

THWARTED for the last four months from getting on with their spring season of operettas because of an off-Broadway theatre shortage, the American Savoyards, Dorothy Raedler's stalwart verse-singers, finally found a haven.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) -- The Justice Department is investigating possible violations of antitrust laws in residual oil prices and supplies.
Chicago is planning to sell $40,000,000 of school construction bonds on May 15. The issue will come due serially from 1963 to 1981.

Aqueduct's second case of suspected horse stimulation in six weeks was disclosed at the track yesterday. A report of a state saliva test showed that Coramine, a stimulant, had been present in Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Chief of Chiefs, the winner of last Monday's $22,400 Toboggan Handicap.
Carmine G. De Sapio, Michael H. Prendergast and Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. combined last night in an attack on the Liberal party.
LONDON, April 27 -- Demand for blue-chip industrials continued strong on the stock market here today.

A record first-quarter loss of $21,900,000 was reported yesterday by the Chrysler Corporation. The loss reflected a sharp sales decline, with only 152,202 cars and trucks sold in the period, compared with 354,080 units shipped to dealers in the first three months of 1960.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 27 -- Adolf Eichmann transported 1,000 Czech Jews to a barren, wind-swept plateau in southern Poland at the onset of the winter of 1939, a witness charged today.

JEAN DE RIGAULT'S French-speaking troupe of Le Theatre du Vieux-Colombier de Paris has crossed the Atlantic again, and last night it put on Moliere's comedy "L'Ecole des Femmes" at the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre.
Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that Charter revision in 1961 was not "dead" as charged by Seymour Graubard, a member of the former Moore commission.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- President Kennedy personally expressed regret today to an African diplomat who was refused service in a Hagerstown, Md., restaurant.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 27 -- President Tito confirmed today that talks were under way looking toward a conference of the world's neutralist leaders to discuss international issues and world peace.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The makers of Anacin and Bufferin asked dismissal today of Federal Trade Commission charges that they had misrepresented the speed with which thees products relieved pain.

MIAMI, April 27 -- Premier Fidel Castro told 1,000 applauding prisoners today that he would urge the Cuban people to spare their lives. In a spectacular three-hour con frontation, televised throughout Cuba, Dr. Castro lectured, exhorted, questioned and argued with the captives taken after last week's landings on Zapata Peninsula.

The college basketball scandal spread yesterday to five more colleges and universities. District Attorney Frank S. Hogan reported that eight more players had taken or had agreed to take bribes in the last two seasons to keep scores down.
The Federal Maritime Board yesterday announced a step designed to bring some order into the field of containerization.

The United States experienced its first gold loss in nine weeks in the week ended last Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of the New York reported yesterday. The gold stock dropped by $1,000,000 to $17,390,000,000.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed by voice vote today President Kennedy's nomination of U. Alexis Johnson of California as Deputy Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced yesterday that its first-quarter earnings were the lowest for any three-month non-strike period since the third quarter of 1945.
LONDON, April 27 -- An unofficial strike among London's dock workers gained momentum today as nearly half the labor force refused to handle cargo.

KANSAS CITY, April 27 (UPI) -- Minnie Minoso drove in five runs tonight, enabling Early Wynn to coast to his 286th major-league victory as the Chicago White Sox defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 9 -- 1.
Earnings of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) in the first three months of 1961 were 13.5 per cent higher than in the 1960 period, M.J. Rathbone, president, reported yesterday.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 27 -- The formation of a Government with the cooperation of one of Kenya's two African nationalist parties was announced tonight. The Cabinet list issued by the Governor, Sir Patrick Renison, includes three leaders of the Kenya African Democratic Union.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) -- The Government moved today to prevent the Aluminum Company of America (Alcoa) and Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Company from expanding into the aluminum architectural field by acquiring small, independent fabricators.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Republicans began criticizing the Kennedy Administration today for its handling of the Cuban situation.

ONE HUNDRED years ago, as we all have been reminded more than once recently, a war was being waged in this country. Some citizens have at various times emphasized that it was a war about states rights, secession and the unity of the nation. Others have argued that it really was a war between rival economic blocs.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Both the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and its Subcommittee on Latin America are trying to set up a briefing for committee members on the failure or the attack on Cuba, it was reported tonight.
Gabe Paul relinquished his post yesterday as general manager of Houston's National League franchise and assumed a similar position with the Cleveland Indians.
FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, April 27 (Reuters) -- Sierra Leone celebrated its independence today after nearly 175 years as a British colony.

President Kennedy's message on conflicts of interest contains no novel views. The problems of maintaining ethical standards in the Federal Government have been thoroughly explored in recent years, notably by a committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. Nevertheless, the President makes a great contribution by presenting in a single brief document a thoughtful, complete outline of what the law should be.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- "A full, open, and complete investigation" of the Title I Housing program was urged today by Representative William Fitts Ryan, Democrat of Manhattan.

MILLVILLE, N.J., April 27 -- A white and silver Trans Caribbean airplane cut through gathering thunder clouds and touched down at the municipal airport here. A dozen Millville residents had gathered in the dusk to watch the transport arrive.

President Kennedy urged the press last night to cooperate voluntarily with the Government, as it does in wartime, to prevent the unauthorized disclosure of news helpful to enemies of the United States.

" Charter revision for 1961 is dead." Seymour Graubard, a member of the now-defunct Moore commission that wrote a proposed new Charter for New York City, made this unqualified statement before the committee at large of the Liberal party. He blamed obstructionism and delay by Mayor Wagner, who has been the founding father of Charter reform since Jan. 1, 1958.

First-quarter sales of the National Cash Register Company reached a record $112,055,533, topping the hundred million-mark for the first time in its seventy-seven-year history, Robert S. Oelman, president, reported yesterday.

Many Americans must have suffered in silence while watching Adlai Stevenson sadly attempt to defend United States policy toward Cuba before a world audience (the General Assembly debate April 17). Mr. Stevenson must know, as does every properly informed person, that the American Central Intelligence Agency, under Allen Dulles, has been planning and financing the training and equipping of Cuban and other counter-revolutionary forces in the United States and Latin America for many months.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 27 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk assured the foreign ministers of the Central Treaty Organization countries today that the Kennedy Administration would continue the United States policy of supporting mutual defense against Communist aggression in the Middle East's "northern tier."
The Hunter College Opera Association last night presented the New York premiere of "Esther," a Biblical opera in three acts with tousle by Jan Meyerowitz and libretto by Langston Hughes.
Bing Crosby was on his new yacht fishing off San Francisco when his younger sons, Phillip, Dennis and Lindsay, made their New York nightclub debut Wednesday night at the Latin Quarter.

SYRACUSE, April 27 (AP) -The P food chain rushed in fresh supplies to open its forty-six supermarkets tomorrow and four other chains prepared to open upstate stores Monday after settlement of a twenty-day strike.

The National Maritime Union yesterday took its first independent steps in organizing efforts aboard "runaway" shipping by picketing the Panamanian flag cargo ship Dragon at Pier 34, North River at Canal Street.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- President Kennedy sent to Congress today his first two reorganization plans for regulatory agencies. They covered the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Communications Commission. The object in each case was the same -- to bring greater flexibility into the workings of the agency and increase its efficiency.

MIAMI, Fla., April 27 -- The Peoples' Revolutionary Movement was reported today to have decided to abandon the Cuban Revolutionary Council and to carry on alone the struggle within Cuba against the Castro regime.
The eleventh annual Belmont Ball will be held in the Man O'War Room of the Aqueduct Race Track on June 2.

Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson will address the twelfth annual 1960 Albert Lasker medical journalism awards luncheon next Thursday at the Sheraton-East Hotel. Mr. Johnson, who recovered from a heart attack in 1955, will discuss "Medical Research and the Nation's Future."

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) -- Dick Hall, a right-hander pitched a two-hitter as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Washington Senators tonight, 5 -- 0. He allowed only one man to get on base in the first eight innings, Danny O'Connell, who singled in the fourth and was put out on a double play.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The saddest men in Washington these days are the intellectuals on the White House staff who helped deal with the Cuban issue: McGeorge Bundy, former dean of the faculty at Harvard; Walt Whitman Rostow of Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Arthur Schlesinger Jr., the Harvard historian.
TE figure 8 took over hannel 2 for a graceful smooth hour last night.
The Rockefeller Foundation issued grants totaling $3,593,995 in the first four months of 1961, J. George Harrar, acting president of the foundation, announced yesterday.
BUENOS AIRES, April 27 -- Adolfo Mugica, 64-year-old conservative lawyer and a former member of the Chamber of Deputies was named Foreign Minister of Argentina tonight.
CHICAGO, April 27 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

MONTREAL, April 27 (Canadian Press) -- Nathanael V. Davis, president of Aluminium, Ltd., reported to shareholders today that estimated net earnings in the first quarter of 1961 amounted to $7,500,000, or 24 cents a share, compared with $8,800,000, or 29 cents a share, for the 1960 quarter.

Intervention by the Justice Department in a Federal court suit to force the reopening of desegregated public schools in Prince Edward County, Va., raises two questions: first, will the subterfuge employed by Prince Edward County and the State of Virginia to defeat integration be successful; and, second, is the Kennedy Administration in earnest in its avowed efforts to enforce the Constitution as interpreted in the Supreme Court's 1954 decision?

JIMMIE DYKES, the Sitting Bull of the Indian tribe whose hunting preserves are along the shores of Lake Erie, was detected yesterday in the act of sending up smoke signals. But the chief of the noble redmen was not using a fire and a blanket. He was using a cigar. Clouds of smoke billowed up in strange and confusing patterns.
SAN JUAN, P.R., April 27 -- There are indications that some activities of Cuban exile forces have centered in this area.

WHEN the Sierra Leone constitutional conference ended successfully in London last May, Sir Milton Augustus Strieby Margai, Prime Minister and leader of the Sierra Leone delegation, remarked to a bystander that he was "restrained from dancing with joy" only by the presence of Iain Macleod, the British Colonial Secretary.

IN assembling the material for 'Parodies" (Random House), Dwight Macdonald has done mankind one particular favor. He has included Paul Jennings' immaculately satirical essay entitled "Report on Resistentialism."
BUENOS AIRES, April 27 (AP) -- An Argentine arbitrator today awarded the American and Foreign Power Company $53,632,000 for properties seized during the former regime of Dictator Juan D. Peron.

The fourth annual Lenox Hill dinner dance was held last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria, where tables were set with pink cloths and pink candles to match the color of the new pavilion of Lenox Hill Hospital, beneficiary of the event.

Mayor Wagner denounced a state investigation yesterday as a Republican effort to win the city election this year by "trying to destroy my personal reputation." He angrily declared that he held Governor Rockefeller "personally responsible."

A second flight-crew union, the Flight Engineers International Association, has questioned the use of only two crew members in the cockpits of Trans-Canada Air Lines' new Vanguard turboprop airliners.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Three Federal judges in Louisiana have asked the Attorneys General of the United States and of all fifty states to comment on a far-reaching legal question.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- Too strict adherence by city planners to zoning codes is causing friction between planners and architects working in the urban renewal movement, a specialist in urban design said today.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- An astronomical satellite carrying a telescope was sent into space today to help solve the mystery of the origin of cosmic rays.
CHICAGO, April 27 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs won their fourth straight home game of the season without a loss, setting back the Cincinnati Reds, 5 -- 2, in the National League's only game today.

FOR years, an editor of a leading women's magazine was complimented on the succession of beautiful, young secretaries to worked for him. The turnover on the job was fairly rapid, because one young woman after another left to marry.
The legality of professional basketball's player-contract option clause is about to be challenged in the courts.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended last Saturday were 1 per cent below the level of 1960.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy said today his brother and Franklin D. Roosevelt probably would never have become President if they had not suffered physical disabilities.
Mrs. Eleana Maria Bulova yesterday lost her bid for a one-half share of her husband's estate, estimated between $10,000,000 and $15,000,000.
EVANSTON, Ill., April 26 -Four-year Merit Scholarships worth $5,000,000 were announced here today for 950 high school seniors.
YONKERS, April 27 -- Su Mac Lad, permitted by the others to set his own pace, encountered no trouble at all while winning the National Championship Trot before 27,011 at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

CHICAGO, April 27 (AP) -- -- Wheat and new crop soybean futures worked into a steady to firm range on the Board of Trade today, but all other contracts continued their downward trend in rather slow dealings.
An improvement in the contractual relationship between local public agencies undertaking urban renewal programs and private builders has been set as the goal of the Urban Renewal Administration.
Greenwich Village residents opposing the redevelopment of a fourteen-block area in their neighborhood served a court order on Mayor Wagner yesterday at a Board of Estimate hearing.
The American Jewish Committee said yesterday that major banking institutions in this country were beginning to offer equal opportunity to Jews who sought executive careers in banking.
Last night with the American Ballet Theatre at the Broadway, Lupe Serrano gave such a performance of the "Black Swan" as Petipa himself would have gone into ecstasies over.
Competitors in the very competitive beer industry guard their new campaign approaches with the same zeal that a magician guards the rabbits he is about to pull from his shiny top hat.
The wholesale commodity price index eased to 87.3 Wednesday from 87.4 on Tuesday. Monday's figure was 87.3. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 85.9 on April 20, 1960.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Mercury "man-in-space" program has been delayed by several months because of labor difficulties at the Cape Canaveral, Fla., missile test center, it was charged today.
How many hits equal four runs in baseball? For the Yankeers the answer was eleven yesterday as they rallied to nip the Cleveland Indians, 4 -- 3, at the Stadium.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A major overhaul and modernization of conflict-of-interest laws affecting officials and employes of independent agencies was proposed to Congress today by President Kennedy.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 27 (AP) -- Don Whitt shot an eight-under-par 63 today and took the first-round lead in the $30,000 Texas open.

Many persons entertained at the twenty-sixth annual Spring Dance of the Boys Club of New York at the Plaza last night. Harry Winston, Inc., was sponsor of the dinner dance, part of the proceeds from which will provide trips for some 1,500 city boys to Camp Carey in Jamesport, L.I., and to Camp Tabor on Fishers Island, N.Y., this summer.

In reference to your April 17 editorial "The Forgotten People" I should like to point out the great forward strides taken by New York State in helping make life better for the migrant workers who help with our harvest and our food processing.

HENRYVILLE, Pa., April 27 -- It is not difficult to count up now after sixteen men have fished Paradise Creek most of the day: it is impossible. Everybody caught trout but nobody was under surveillance all day and nobody has been sworn.
LAST night's installment of "C.B.S. Reports" over Channel 2 was an admirable explanation of the reasons for space travel together with some of its manifold problems.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 27 -- Volunteers will take up brooms, shovels and paint brushes here Saturday to rejuvenate the old downtown area along North Avenue north of the New England Thruway.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 27 -- City policemen used tear gas bombs tonight to break up the second night of student rioting in Harvard Square. Eight youths were arrested.
DETROIT, April 27 (AP) -- Dave Hillman pitched six and two-thirds innings of brilliant relief ball to help Boston gain a 5-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers today.

DETROIT, April 27 -- Walter P. Reuther proposed today that the American labor movement open a drive for a flexible wage-and-hour law providing for a reduction in the forty-hour week with no loss in pay during periods of serious unemployment.

Last night's concert in Carnegie Hall was a family affair. Partiticipating were Tung Kwong-Kwong, pianist, and her brother, Tung Yuan, 'cellist, both born in Shanghai, and Miss Tung's husband Ma Si-Hono violinist, a native of Canton, China.
Residents of New York and the metropolitan area will take part in the eighth national civil defense test today.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 (AP) -- The National Football League today set up a plan for restocking a club in case of a disaster.

Two-thirds of the Negro and Puerto Rican children attending one predominantly white public school under the open-enrollment program are expected to be left back this June, Harold Siegel, executive director of the United Parents Associations, disclosed yesterday.
DALLAS, April 27 -- A Presbyterian denomination that began as a result of the dispute over slavery urged the end of enforced racial segregation today.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The intervention of the Department of Justice to force the reopening and racial desegregation of the public schools in Prince Edward County, Va., is a smashing blow at two fond Southern illusions. One was a dream of Southern lawyers; the other was a dream of Southern Democratic politicians.

TRENTON, April 27 -- Thorn Lord of Princeton, who was defeated for United States Senator last November, was elected unanimously today by the Democratic State Committee as the party chairman in New Jersey.

United States industry has "raised its sights" on capital outlays since last fall and now plans to spend $35,350,000,000 for new plant and equipment this year, or only 1 per cent less than the $35,690,000,000 spent last year.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 27 (Reuters) -- A new attempt to settle Denmark's biggest labor conflict was under way today as strikes involving 150,000 workers went into their third week.

PARIS, April 28 -- Philosophically speaking, Charles de Gaulle proved again this week that man can dominate events. By the nobility and resolution of his personal actions he showed the essential folly of such Marxist claptrap as "economic determinism" and "dialectical materialism," doctrines that purport to prove that there are political forces superior to human will.
WALLINGTON, N.J., April 28 -- Two firemen were injured today when a ladder collapsed during a fire.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 28 (AP) -- Echo I, the balloon satellite launched last August and the only man-made moon clearly visible to the unaided eye, will put on a show around the clock this week-end.

THE American Ballet Theatre last night presented the first "Giselle" of its season at the Broadway Theatre, with Lupe Serrano in the title role, Royes Fernandez as Albrecht and Toni Lander as Myrtha Except for the dancing, as such, by the three principals it was unfortunately not very good.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Shipments and new orders received by manufacturers last month each rose 2 per cent above the February level after allowing for the usual seasonal gain, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Back in early 1959 the New York Central Railroad called a halt to merger studies it then was conducting with the Pennsylvania Railroad. At the time, Central's president, Alfred E. Perlman, explained Central's reason this way:

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- An electronics engineer was granted a patent this week for a radio transmitter that is powered entirely by the human voice. As it needs no battery, the equipment can be very light.

TRENTON, April 28 -- The Bi-State Waterfront Commission insisted today that its powers must be increased if criminal elements that "still siphon $500,000 a year" from the docks of greater New York are to be eliminated.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 28 (UPI) -- Rod Laver, the top-seeded player, defeated a British Davis Cup team-member, Bobby Wilson, 9 -- 7, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, today in the semi-finals of the British hard-court lawn tennis championship.
WALLOPS ISLAND, Va., April 28 -- A Mercury space capsule of the type that may carry a man more than 100 miles above the earth next week survived an unexpectedly severe test flight today.

Justice Irving Saypol said yesterday he would render a decision on the constitutionality of the state law under which Mayor Wagner appointed an eleven-member Charter Revision Commission within "a matter of days."
James R. Hoffa and Arthur H. Motley, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, debated last night the question of whether labor unions had become too powerful.

The first volume in Doubleday's "Your Ancestor" series is planned for Aug. 25 publication and will be called "It's The Irish." Written by the columnist Bob Considine, it tells the story of "the sons of Erin" who came to America from the time of the famine in Ireland to the present.

In a ten-page brief filed by their lawyers with the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public yesterday, two members of the American Stock Exchange charged by the commission with a multimillion-dollar stock-market manipulation conceded that "the facts plainly justify sanctions" against them.
Peter C. Tripp, a former disk jockey for Station WMGM, testified in Special Sessions Court yesterday that he had never taken payola.

Los Angeles, April 28 (UPI) -- Western Air Lines filed a $1,000,000 damage suit yesterday against the Flight Engineers International association' and obtained a temporary restraining order against the organization's members.

The State of Ohio is planning to borrow $32,000,000 to finance the construction of major thoroughfares. May 24 has been decided on as the date for the sale of serial bonds to raise the money. The obligations will be secured by motor vehicle revenues. The issue will come due from 1962 to 1972.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 28 (AP) -- Unnumbered thousands of Africans and 1,000 whites have been killed in six weeks of terror in the Portuguese West African territory of Angola, press reports said today.

Earl G. Nisonger has been appointed president of the British Automobile Manufacturers Association, here. He is president of the Nisonger Corporation, New York and Los Angeles importer of automotive parts.

PARIS, April 28 -- Paris was faced with a threat of seizure by paratroopers from Algeria this week and many people were very brave about it. Others unloaded at the stock exchange and used the money to buy sugar and coffee.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 28 -- The "minor terror" in Poland during the opening months of World War II before the Nazi conquerors started a program to kill all European Jews was vividly recalled today at the trial of Adolf Eichmann.
The passing of H.I. Brock of The Times -- Irving to his friend -- bring up many thoughts of deep respect and great affection.

MILWAUKEE, April 28 (UPI) -- Warren Spahn, the amazingly durable 40-year-old southpaw of the Milwaukee Braves, pitched the second no-hitter and the 290th victory of his major league career tonight when he defeated the San Francisco Giants, 1 -- 0.
THE exhibition of Gordon Russell's fantastico-abstract paintings at Durlacher's, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street, is a puzzling affair.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 28 -- Ronald Ngala, president of the Kenya African Democratic Union, will be Education Minister in the government sworn in today. Mr. Ngala said later he would also be in charge of government business.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 28 (AP) -Mrs. Kathy Cornelius posted four birdies on the second nine today to tie Mickey Wright for the lead at the halfway point of the $6,500 Titleholders golf tournament.
MIAMI, April 28 -- Definite and widening splits among Cuban exiles opposed to Premier Fidel Castro have become evident since the defeat of their invasion attempt of April 17.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 28 -- Eleven persons living next to Freebody Park, where the Newport Jazz Festivals have been held for the last six years, took steps today to prevent the proposed 1961 concerts from being held in the city-owned park.

LONDON, April 28 -- Despite a plea by their union leaders for a return to work, London stevedores and dockers continued their unofficial strike today. More than 13,500 men, nearly half of the total labor force, again refused to handle cargoes.

WASHINGTON, April 28 change Commission ruled yesterday that Bruns, Nordeman Co., a Wall Street brokerage concern, and two of its partners manipulated the over-the-counter market in the stock of Gob Shops of America, Inc., four years ago.
DETROIT, April 28 -- The United Automobile Workers laid out today a broad but flexible collective bargaining program aimed particularly at overcoming unemployment and job insecurity.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 28 (UPI) -- Arnold Palmer took a three-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the $30,000 Texas open golf tournament today. He shot an eight-under-par 31, 32 -- 63 for a 36-hole total of 130.

LOS ANGELES, April 28 (AP) -- The Minnesota Twins, trying to widen their slim lead in the American League, sent Pedro Ramos to the mound tonight in the second game of their series with the Los Angeles Angels.
American-flag passenger ship operators are now optimistic about getting a larger slice of a $46,000,00 cruise-traffic revenue.
The New York County Council, Veterans of Foreign Wars, will hold its annual Loyalty Day parade down Fifth Avenue today.
KANSAS CITY, April 28 (UPI) -- Cal McLish, attempting a comeback, scattered six hits tonight in pitching the Chicago White Sox to a 4-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.
ALBANY, April 28 -- College students will have more than one opportunity to qualify for the scholar-incentive awards that New York state will begin bestowing next year.

THERE may be some cute colloquial meaning in the title of the British comedy, "Please Turn Over," which followed a string of Peter Sellers pictures into the Guild Theatre yesterday. But if there is, it escapes us, as does the effort at homey humor in this squashy little package of chestnuts got together by the same team that made the late unlamented "Carry On Nurse."

MARC BOHAN, the 35-year-old designer whose flared line restored confidence and commercial leadership to the House that Dior built, arrived in New York yesterday for a triumphal two-week visit, during which he will be lionized by buyers, store presidents, fashion editors and social leaders.

The threat of a strike by 15,000 elevator operators and service workers in 1,400 Manhattan and Queens apartment houses ended yesterday. An agreement was reached on a new three-year contract between Local 32-B of the International Union and the Building Service Employes Realty Advisory Board.
WARSAW, April 28 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka, Communist leader of Poland, lashed out at President Kennedy today as "pitiful," "deceitful" and unfit to lecture the Polish people on freedom.

PARIS, April 28 (AP) -- Gen. Marie-Michel Gouraud, the French commander at Constantine, who by his own admission wavered away from loyalty to President de Gaulle and joined the Algeria generals' rebellion, was taken to solitary confinement in Sante Prison tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The International Joint Commission was reported today to have rejected the proposed $687,000,000 Passamaquoddy tidal power project as economically unfeasible under present conditions and criteria.

Activity on the New York Stock Exchange fell away yesterday as market operators apparently decided to postpone commitments until after the week-end. Trading started at a slow pace and grew slower as the day progressed.
Allied Stores Corporation, which operates Stern's and Gertz branches here and in suburban areas, lifted its sales to $680,492,329 in its fiscal year ended Jan. 31 from $679,487,876 a year earlier.

It is shocking to read Prof. Frank Tannenbaum's suggestion in your correspondence columns of April 27 that the United Nations should tax every means of international communication in order to obtain the funds it needs and which it cannot now be sure of receiving from its member states.
Shyly, a 19-year-old boy watched the dancing couples, and a trumpeted blue note heightened his loneliness. Then a girl approached and asked, "May I have this dance?"
EAST WILLISTON, L.I., April 28 -- The women's Cross County Golf Association opened its season at Wheatley Hills today.
DES MOINES, April 28 (AP) -- A superb quartet of milers from Western Michigan smashed the American and National Collegiate records for the four-mile relay today in the fifty-second Drake Relays.
President Kennedy sought the counsel of two elders of the Republican party yesterday in his quest for national solidarity in what he has called a period of peril.

Leaders in the building industry in twelve Eastern states were urged here yesterday by Neal J. Hardy, Commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration, to assist the Kennedy Administration's efforts to expand the country's supply of rental housing.

ALGIERS, April 28 -- The determination of President de Gaulle's Government to put an end to coups in Algeria was demonstrated today by an announcement that 400 Europeans had been arrested and that 400 more were sought by the police.

The advertisement of the "Fair Play for Cuba Committee" published April 21, is an affront to the American people. This committee's concept of fair play is complete tolerance and even benevolence toward the present regime of Fidel Castro which suppresses basic human rights and sanctions terror and official murder as an instrument of government.

LUANG PRABANG, Laos, Saturday, April 29 (AP) -- King Savang Vathan of Laos and Cambodia's chief of state, Prince Sihanouk, are making backstage efforts to find a compromise that would bring a cease-fire in Laos' civil war.
CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The Franklin National Bank of Long Island, Mineola, is dropping its lawsuit against the State Superintendent of Banks and ten banks that have established branches in Nas sau County under the Omnibus Banking Law.
The third annual Embassy Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria last evening offered a program of feline fantasy for the amusement of local society and members of the international social set.
GENEVA, April 28 -- The nuclear test-ban conference recessed today for four days to allow the United States and British delegates to return to their capitals for consultations.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the owner of the Hudson River Day Line was one of a group that had paid the rent for his political headquarters at the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles last summer.
CHICAGO, April 28 -- President Kennedy declared tonight that the United States, committed to the defense of freedom, could help only those who were willing to help themselves.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Department of Defense will soon be asked to take over new responsibilities in the fields of subversive warfare and civil defense, responsible sources said tonight.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 27 (UPI) -- The New York Central Railroad charged today that the merger of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway and the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad would do "irreparable damage" to railroad service east of the Mississippi River.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 28 -- Six Belgian advisers of President Moise Tshombe of Katanga were arrested by the United Nations early today at Coquilhatville and flown here under guard.
A major program aimed at collecting the kind of traffic information needed to "alleviate New York City's traffic problem" will get under way here shortly.
The tenth annual Mother's Day luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the Talbot Perkins Adoption Service will be held next Friday in the Sheraton-East.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- A new and enlarged citizens' committee was named today to advise Postmaster General J. Edward Day on the selection and design of the nation's commemorative stamps.

HAVANA, April 28 -- Summoning the foreign diplomatic corps to the Presidential Palace at 11 o'clock last night, President Osvaldo Dorticos Torrado read a note signed by himself and Premier Fidel Castro.

AS its name implies, the Contemporary Baroque Ensemble mixes two kinds of music. Playing in MeMillin Theatre of Columbia University last night, the ensemble presented works by Locatelli, Bach and Purcell, composers of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, and by Roy Harris, Lou Harrison and the late Wallingford Riegger, all of this century.
Air raid sirens wailed a warning across the country at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon in a national drill aimed at dispelling public fatalism and apathy toward a possible nuclear attack.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Jerry Adair, a rookie second baseman, hit a two-run homer in the seventh inning in leading the Baltimore Orioles to a 4-2 victory over the Washington Senators before 4,112 fans tonight in Griffith Stadium.

Mikhail Tal of Latvia, the world chess champion, and Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia adjourned the seventeenth game of their return title match at the Variety Theatre in Moscow yesterday, according to Tass, the official Soviet news agency.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 28 (AP) -- Stockholders of Northern Pacific Railway yesterday approved a proposed unification of the N.P. with the Great Northern Railway, Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad, and Spokane, Portland Seattle Railway.

MOSCOW, April 28 -- Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr., United States Ambassador, called yesterday on Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to express concern at the continued advance of Left-wing forces in Laos despite the Soviet-British appeal for a cease-fire.

A loan for the equivalent of $22,000,000 was made yesterday by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) to the State Railways of Thailand to assist the carrier system in putting through a six-year modernization program.
PARIS, April 28 -- France did not lose a single dollar on the currency markets during the four-day Algerian crisis, Finance Minister Wilfrid Baumgartner reported today.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 28 -- The application of the Russian Orthodox Church for membership in the World Council of Churches was hailed by Protestant leaders today as a possible step toward world peace.
PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- Yale and Michigan were in possession of the chief honors today as the opening session of the sixty-seventh Penn Relays ended with a blinding rain lashing Franklin Field.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Five scientists received Ernest Orlando Lawrence Memorial Awards today for meritorious contributions to the development, use or control of atomic energy.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) -- The Federal Government filed a civil-rights suit today at Shreveport, La., charging that Negroes in East Carrol Parish (county) had been illegally denied their voting rights.

BONN, April 28 -- Alfred Frenzel, a former Social Democratic member of Parliament, was sentenced to fifteen years at hard labor by the Federal Supreme Court in Karlsruhe today for treasonable relations with the Czechoslovak intelligence service.

In a display of anti-Castro sentiment, about 100 longshoremen refused yesterday to handle the baggage of 129 Cuba-bound passengers who left here last night from Pier 15, East River, for Havana aboard the Spanish Line passenger ship Covadonga.
Sixty years ago this week automobile owners in New York were for the first time required to register their cars with the Secretary of State and secure a license plate to be carried on the vehicle.

ST. LOUIS, April 28 (AP) -- Subsidiaries of the American Investment Company of Illinois, a major personal finance concern, have purchased the assets of the M.A.C. Corporation, including twenty-eight consumer finance offices in three Southern states, it was announced today.

WHEN the Dalai Lama of Tibet escaped from the Chinese Communists early in 1959, an army of Indian and foreign newsmen gathered at Tezpur in Assam to meet him. News arrangements were dissatisfying; seventy correspondents telegraphed Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru for help.
Mieczyslaw Horszowski will give a piano recital Tuesday evening at Town Hall for the benefit of Polish Mutual Assistance, Inc.
TELEPHONE bells are ringing -- and chiming, jangling and humming -- in the lobby of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company building at 195 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- President Kennedy has scheduled a meeting of the National Security Council tomorrow morning to consider the Laotian crisis and other policy questions concerning Southeast Asia.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The General Electric Company announced the formation today of a new company as the basis for a joint industrial venture in developing and operating a communications satellite system.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Carl W. Strom, now Ambassador to Bolivia, was named today to head the State Department's Foreign Service Institute.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) -- Management and union spokesmen agreed today that too many companies set up unrealistic hiring standards that discriminated against physically handicapped workers.
Publishers and editors generally responded with circumspection yesterday to President Kennedy's plea to the press for "self-restraint."
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Census Bureau says more than 12 per cent of New Jersey homes are deteriorating or dilapidated.

YONKERS, April 28 -- Bye Bye Byrd, needing a victory in tonight's free-for-all to send his career earnings over the $500,000 mark, wound up second to Tar Boy in the $16,000 Siwanoy Pace.

Interest in stereophony -- wall-to-wall sound -- ranges from hot to cool among many of New York's FM radio stations.

Earnings of the Armco Steel Corporation for the first quarter of this year fell to $9,260,646, or 63 cents a share, from $23,957,994, or $1.62 a share, in the 1960 period, the company announced yesterday. Sales for the quarter declined to $187,571,507 from $274,308,574 last year, the nation's sixth-ranking steelmaker disclosed.
Mrs. Pamela Garroway, wife of Dave Garroway, the television performer, was found dead here yesterday, apparently as a result of an overdose of barbiturates.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Senators who control Pentagon purse strings asked today for a complete list of all retired military officers now serving the Government in civilian posts.
George Friedhof, who has been tending seedlings in the New York Botanical Garden for fifty-eight years, put in his last day's work yesterday.

LONDON, April 28 -- British officials maintained today their belief that fighting in Laos could be ended soon by the negotiation of a cease-fire between the pro-Western Government and Communist-led forces.
NEW DELHI, India, April 28 -- The International Control Commission for Laos reconvened here today, obviously aware that a difficult and delicate task lay ahead.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Justice Department has called another Federal grand jury in Philadelphia to hear new evidence of price-fixing and bid-rigging in the electrical equipment industry.

LONDON, April 28 -- The stock market here continued to advance today with widespread gains in most industrial sections, particularly real estate and store shares. For the third consecutive day the Financial Times industrial shares index set a record. It rose 1.2 points to 362.8, a rise of 6.1 points on the week.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- A group of Republicans in the Senate appeared today to have accepted the controversial Social Security principle for providing medical care to the aged.
Mary Judd is a soprano with a wonderful lyric gift, and it was on display late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall.
LANSING, Mich., April 28 (AP) -- The entire $100,000 state operating budget for Michigan's Office of Civil Defense was eliminated today by the State Senate Appropriations Committee.

AHRWEILER, West Germany, April 28 -- The last of the instructions in the will of Sgt. Anton Hafner was carried out today, sixteen years after the German World War II fighter pilot died in combat on the eastern front.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged on far October to 2 to 13 points up on the other futures yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

Juan D'Agostino's 5-year-old gray Argentine import Tudor Way was the overnight favorite at 8-5 among thirteen horses scheduled to compete in the $87,550 Grey Lag Handicap at Aqueduct today.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., April 28 -- The Valley Opera Company presented "Carmen" tonight at the Benjamin Franklin Junior High School here. The performance will be repeated tomorrow night, closing the company's third year of fall and spring presentations of English versions of famous operas.

WITH all the new buildings going up in Greenwich Village, it is a delight to come across Carol Creutzburg's note cards, on which charming scenes of the old "Village" are depicted in pen and ink sketches. One print shows tots sailing boats and splashing about in the Washington Square pool.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges announced today that he would set up Government-wide machinery to "pursue vigorously" the aid program for depressed areas now awaiting President Kennedy's signature.
An exhibition dramatizing "mankind's struggle toward a just and durable peace" will open tomorrow at the Interchurch Center, 475 Riverside Drive.

ROBERT LITTELL has a guntherian capacity for finding significant stories everywhere. He writes penetratingly or lightly as the occasion demands. He examines our time's horrors, curiosities and felicities. He calls his book "It Takes All Kinds"* -- which has always been a suitably enigmatic comment on our world.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) -- A contractors' spokesman said today that unions "acting like spoiled children" -- and the Government's refusal to spank them -- were responsible for exorbitant costs and delays at United States missile sites.

An active week is ahead in the market for new capital with nearly $300,000,000 of corporate and municipal fixed-interest securities scheduled for offering. Of this total, $166,500,000 of municipal and utility issues will be offered at competitive sealed bidding.

A May Day luncheon in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor on Monday will mark the opening of Day Care Week. It is being sponsored by forty-seven city-wide, welfare and civic agencies.

IN the April issue of Revue Francaise de Bridge, the official publication of the French Bridge Federation, Jose Le Dentu, a member of this year's French international team, discusses classic hand played by Sam Fry Jr. of New York and shown here.

Textron, Inc., is entering the meter business through the acquisition of the Sprague Meter Company of Bridgeport, Conn. Rupert C. Thompson Jr., Textron chairman, announced yesterday that the cash transaction was approved by Sprague shareholders.

The ailing New York, New and Hartford Railroad fell deeper into the red last month, bringing its first-quarter deficit to nearly double the amount for the 1960 period.
BUENOS AIRES, April 28 -- With the swearing in today of his new Foreign Minister, Adolfo Mugica, President Arturo Frondizi said he had completed the revision of the Cabinet.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 28 -- The foreign ministers of the Central Treaty Organization agreed today to add a military command post to its secretariat to improve regional defense planning and coordination.

French Line clerical personnel who went on strike yesterday morning will establish a picket line today at Pier 88, North River at West Forty-eighth Street.

PARIS, April 28 -- President de Gaulle will report to the French epople May 8 on the progress of the purge of the military and civilian administration and his plans for employment of his temporary dictatorial powers.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The most outspoken Democratic opponent of the Eisenhower Administration's efforts to get rid of the 4 1/4 per cent interest rate ceiling on Government bonds does not like it much better when the Kennedy Administration does it.

ST. LOUIS, April 28 (AP) -- Red Schoendienst delivered a two-run double in the eleventh inning tonight, lifting the St. Louis Cardinals to a 10-9 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies in a four-and-a-half-hour battle filled with thirty-four hits and seven unearned runs.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., said yesterday he was moving to curb racial discrimination that embarrasses diplomats assigned to or visiting in this country.
Commodities on New York exchanges wound-up the week yesterday on a quiet note. Trading was dull and featureless and prices generally rose.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 28 -- A dictum from the dean's office today was expected to return quiet to Harvard College following two nights of demonstrations against the substitution of English for Latin on diplomas for bachelors' degrees.

First-quarter sales of Mead Johnson Co. rose to $35,581,722 from $22,004,805 in the initial three months last year, D. Mead Johnson, president of the nutritional and pharmaceutical company, told shareholders in Evansville, Ind., yesterday.

Persistent precipitation prevented Mickey Mantle from getting another crack at Cleveland pitching at the Stadium last night. In the opinion of the Yankee slugger's admirers, this undoubtedly saved the visiting Indians from another setback.
TIFLIS, U.S.S.R., April 28 (AP) -- The touring United States men's and women's basketball teams scored decisive victories over Tiflis quintets today.

Bond prices edged upward in most parts of the gilt-edge market yesterday as the trading week came to a close. The volume of business was light.

MONTREAL April 28 (AP) -- Dave Keon, a 21-year-old center for the Toronto Maple Leafs, was awarded the Calder Trophy today as the National Hockey League's outstanding rookie of the 1960-61 season.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) -- Good Government Awards were presented tonight to Representative Charles A. Halleck of Indiana, House Republican leader, and Senator Spessard L. Holland, Democrat of Florida, at the annual George Washington dinner of the American Good Government Society.
SINGAPORE, April 28 -- A few thousands Chinese laborers, mostly illiterate, will influence the immediate political future of Britain's most important military base in the Far East tomorrow.
CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -- A moderate rally steadied the grain futures market today after a generally weak start in slow activity on the Board of Trade. Corn and soybeans rose in all positions.

A handful of Congolese soldiers arrested Katanga's President Moise Tshombe at the airport of Coquilhatville and told him he could not return to his province unless he ended his differences with the other leaders.

WE are in the midst of changes, at home and abroad, as far-reaching in their implications, and in their demands upon us, as any we have experienced in the past. PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 29 -- An atmosphere of calm bordering on apathy prevailed here today as the nation prepared for the election tomorrow in which the unicameral Legislature will be chosen.
The ability of nuclear-powered surface warships to stay at sea for long periods of time without having to refuel should outweigh their higher building costs, a shipbuilding expert said last week.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- This is a delicate and may even be a dangerous moment in world affairs, but the primary danger is not of war in Cuba or Laos. MIAMI, April 28 -- As May Day approaches, the regime of Fidel Castro speaks to Cuba and the world in the tones of a country completely identified with the Soviet Union.

SYRACUSE, April 29 -- A mine of historical material covering New York City from 1824 to 1935 is being explored at Syracuse University.

KANSAS CITY, April 29 (UPI) -- Mary Throneberry banged out the third grand-slam home run of his career and Haywood Sullivan socked a three-run double today as the Kansas City Athletics scored a 13-9 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

In the repeat showing of a two-year-old program over the Columbia Broadcasting System, several references to coffee were changed to tea out of respect for Thomas J. Lipton, Inc., which sells tea.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 26 -Two official statements have been made by the Bolivian Government on the Cuban situation: a joint statement by the Government and Central Bureau of the National Revolutionary Movement, the official party, condemned "countries from which the invaders went to Cuba" and a statement asserting the Government position of "no intervention."

ONCE the early spring burst of vegetable planting activity has passed, gardeners often overlook the possibility of prolonging the life of their vegetable plots. Those who missed out in early April mistakenly think they have to wait until next year to begin.
The fifth United States World Trade Fair opening Wednesday is expected to show, in addition to exotic pageantry and display, the harmony nations can attain through trade.

BUENOS AIRES, April 29 -- Dr. Alfredo L. Palacios, a colorful 80-year-old Socialist leader, has won a fight over his right to sit in the Argentine Senate. A Salvation Army version of the Trapp Family Singers turned up yesterday at the organization's "Youth Music Festival" here. FAIRFIELD, Conn., April 29 -- A cavalcade of station wagons filled with antiques will arrive at the Fairfield University Field early on May 27 for the second annual Flea Market and Antiques Show, sponsored by the Friends of the Museum of Art, Science and Industry in Bridgeport.

DURING the past six months cultural circles in Sweden and other Scandinavian countries have been debating how and to what extent the state should support artists. As the Danish author Jorgen Nash puts it, "The struggling artist is today the last proletarian in the welfare state."

Yale's varsity lightweight crew defeated Columbia and Penn in a blanket finish on the Harlem River yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The first 100 days of John F. Kennedy's Presidency ended shortly after noon today.

LAUREL, Md., April 29 (AP) -- The John S. Kroese entry of Civic Guard and Mozart finished one, two in the $25,000 Laurel Anniversary today. There were only four starters and no place or show bets were allowed.
LONDON, April 29 -- The struggle of one peer to remain a commoner resulted this week in a cautious start on a reform program for the whole House of Lords.
BATON ROUGE, La., April 29 (AP) -- Ian Stewart, an Englishman, set a meet record in the two-mile run and Louisiana State took the team honors at its invitation track and field meet today.

Young and Gerard Swope, two great statesmen of industry, the General Electric Company has sought to identify itself with an image of corporate citizenship based on regard for the welfare of the community. This architects and engineers display building for the swimming-pool industry has been designed as an information center for owners and prospective buyers of home and public pools.

The Westchester Committee of the Woman's Council of the Episcopal City Mission Society will give a gala spring dance called the "Crystal Ball" on May 26 for the benefit of the society's summer program at Elko Lake Camps.

OSTRAVA, Czechoslovakia, April 29 (UPI) -- Czechoslovakia beat Mexico, 2 -- 1, in a soccer match before 122,000 fans today.

Francois D'Albert, violinist and president of the Chicago Conservatory College, gave his second New York recital in Town Hall yesterday afternoon. He was accompanied by Herbert Ruff, pianist.

Progress in experiments to tame the nuclear reaction of the hydrogen bomb -- known as the thermonuclear, or fusion, reaction -- into a virtually limitless source of industrial power was reported last week at the annual Washington meeting of the American Physical Society by a group of physicists of the Lawrence Radiation Laboratory at Livermore, Calif., headed by Dr. Richard F. Post.
LUANG PRABANG, Laos, April 29 -- A King of Laos was cremated today in this ancient capital of his line while in the surrounding hills pro-Communist rebels were active.
A majority of the nation's pharmacy colleges are still clinging to the "trade school" concept of education, rather than seeking to develop well-rounded professionals, according to a recent study.
Summer dress business got well under way last week, according to reports from resident buying offices. Cottons were among the biggest sellers, followed by crepes.
Edward J. Barber, president of Barber Steamship Lines, Inc., was re-elected president of The Maritime Association of the Port of New York at the group's annual meeting last week.
One of the nerve centers of a growing revolution in biological science is housed on 305 rolling acres northwest of the nation's capital.

Moves during the past week to stop hostilities and negotiate a political settlement in Laos produced instead of peace an immediate aggravation of the situation. Although Russia joined Britain in appealing for a cease-fire the Communist-led rebel forces in Laos continued their attack against weak and demoralized Laotian Government troops.

HANOVER, N.H., April 29 -- Dartmouth College today announced plans for a new $1,500,000 field house designed by Pier Luigi Nervi of Italy. It will be the first complete structure in this country by Nervi, who has adapted his circular design for the Palazzetto dello Sport built in Rome for the 1960 Olympic Games to the rectangular requirements of Dartmouth's field house.
Eastern Air Lines' six-month experiment in operating a no-frills airline shuttle operation between New York and Washington and New York and Boston will begin today.

In laboratories across the nation, at rocket test stands in desert wastelands, on launching pads overlooking the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans and at tracking stations around the world, the United States is mounting a massive assault on space. By the end of this decade, at least $20 billion will have been invested -- far more than was spent in World War II to unlock the energy of the atom.

As John Fitzgerald Kennedy today completes his first 100 days in the Presidency, large problems cloud the world horizon. All last week the White House reverberated to the pressures of extraordinary events abroad.

A NUMBER of shrubs and small trees can be planted now that will be colorful during the sunny days of October. Red and golden yellow leaves against the crisp autumn sky provide a color "spectacular" that appeals to everyone.

LONDON, April 29 (Reuters) -- Jimmy Greaves, the English soccer star who is joining the Milan club in Italy, said farewell today to Chelsea supporters by scoring all four goals in his club's 4-3 victory over Nottingham Forest.

PINEVILLE, Ky. -- Redbud and redbird are vying for the visitor's attention in Pineville these spring days. Warm jackets are still in order and, on the northern slopes of the near-by mountains, white patches of snow can be seen.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- Penn's varsity crew rowed through the rain this afternoon to win the Childs Cup by beating Princeton and Columbia.

OBERLIN, Ohio, April 29 -- One hundred forty young people, most of them college students, gathered here this week-end to try to find a better way of preserving world peace than their elders have.

Merchants throughout the country are working hard to attract customers to their stores and keep them coming back. Probably no housewife has ever begun an attack on a disheveled attack with greater spring-cleaning fury than a nonprofit corporation and thirteen city departments have begun their attack on blight on Carnegie Hill.

Assets and share value of Investors Mutual, Inc., were at record highs on March 31, Harold K. Bradford, chairman and president of the mutual fund, announced in the semi-annual report.

Net profits after taxes of 692 nonfinancial corporations dropped by 15 per cent in the first quarter from those of the final quarter of last year, the First National City Bank reported in its Monthly Letter, issued today.

THE outstanding events of the dance week-end included the final performances of Martha Graham's season at the Fifty-fourth Street Theatre. For the closing program last night, an added work was presented by special request.

May 1, 1517, has come down in history as "Evil May Day" -- a reverse twist for a day we associate with all that is blithe and bright. On that date there was an insurrection of London apprentices, who fell upon the French residents of that city, attacking their victims and looting their homes.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- A House committee contended today that the National Institutes of Health was not fully meeting the vastly increased responsibilities posed by its research and training grant programs.

A COMPREHENSIVE report on preparations for sending the first American into space this week were shown last night over Channel 4.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- A bitterly divided House faces a second and probably final showdown this Wednesday on the Kennedy Administration's plan to increase the minimum wage and extend it to millions more workers.
NEW DELHI, India, April 30 -- India was reported today to be alarmed about a possibility of military intervention by the United States in Laos.

Democratic organization leaders are putting pressure on Mayor Wagner to say he will refuse Liberal party endorsement in the coming Mayoral election unless his city-wide running mates are also endorsed. The pressure is being applied although the Mayor has not yet indicated whether he will seek re-election.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 30 -- A significant connection between the tendency to gain weight after maturity and the development of coronary artery disease was reported at a scientific meeting here today.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI) -- George Meany said today he had urged President Kennedy to endorse a vast expansion of Federal spending on public works projects to reduce heavy unemployment.
A kind of angry silence settled over Madison Avenue at the end of last week. Some accounts parted company with their agencies and no one wanted to talk about any of them.

Dominican exiles here announced yesterday their intention to make a formal appeal to the United States Government for "effective help" in their fight against the dictatorship of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina.
Mayor Wagner accused Governor Rockefeller of financial irresponsibility and governmental immorality yesterday for having signed a bill increasing the city's expenses for teachers' pensions.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., April 30 -- The Hughes Cup Regatta, America's longest rowing race, gets another distinctive touch tomorrow. An attempt will be made to hold the four-and-a-quarter-mile pull across Long Island Sound from Travers Island at 7 A.M.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 30 -- One of the quietest and most sparsely attended elections here in recent years tok place in Haiti today.

THERE was a somewhat different type of "Report from Moscow" yesterday afternoon over Channel 4; it was a half-hour visit to a Baptist church in Moscow, where the Russian congregation foregoes the advantages of Communist party membership in order to worship God.

The Treasury's campaign against "expense account living" apparently has not offered convincing proof that taxpayers will voluntarily give up many of the "fringe benefits" that make their labors more attractive.
An application has been submitted to the Maritime Administration for mortgage insurance on the construction of two hydrofoil craft for commercial operation in the United States.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. said yesterday that he would propose a new plan to President Kennedy this week to break the log jam over Federal patronage to New York City Democrats.

" THE EDGE OF FREEDOM,"* by John B. Oakes, is the narrative of a journey of discovery. Sped by a Carnegie Corporation grant and this newspaper's blessing he went recently through Eastern Europe and emerging nationalist Africa, where every passport stamp is an introduction to peril.

Sales of the eight major New York department stores and their branches, which had exceeded the 1960 level by 19 per cent in March, suffered a sharp reversal last month. Volume for April was 13 per cent below that of the 1960 month.

RYE, N.Y., May 1 -- Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis scored 40, 42 -- 82 over the South Course at the Westchester Country Club today and headed the field in both the gross and the net divisions in the opening tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association season.
The four-day-old strike of French Line clerical personnel forced 271 passengers arriving aboard the Flandre to do their own stevedoring yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The solution to the unemployment situation is economic growth and measures to aid workers dislodged by automation, the President's Labor-Management Advisory Committee said today.
LONDON, May 1 -- Transport Minister Ernest Marples defended today the Government's decision to give the Cunard Line a subsidy for building a successor to the 81,237-ton Queen Mary.
PARIS, May 1 -- What happens to sports in a country living through an Army mutiny and threatened by civil war?
The city plans to resume its program of distributing Federal surplus food supplies to the poor, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.

Thirty years ago the anti-war movement began to spread in England and the United States. One of its high points were rallies at which tens of thousands of students, after Hitler had come to power, took the Oxford pledge never to bear arms in defense of their country, which at that time meant the defense of the free world.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) May 1 -- "Why did you not revolt?" Attorney General Gideon Hausner snapped to a death-camp survivor on the stand today at the resumption of the trial of Adolf Eichmann.

WASHINGTON, May l -- Samplings by this department of bipartisan Congressional opinion on any commitment of United States military forces in Laos have disclosed an almost unanimous belief that this should not be undertaken. The samplings have been random and casual, but nearly all the replies have run one way.
Gains in operating revenues and earnings for the first quarter of 1961 were reported yesterday by Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., of Nyack, N.Y., and its subsidiaries.
