LONDON, May 1 -- John Hare, Minister of Labor, appealed today to striking London dockworkers to return to their jobs.

LONDON, May 1 -- The point at which the West should decide that it can no longer await a cease-fire in Laos and must take military action is the focus of a dispute developing between the United States and Britain, qualified sources said today.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 1 (AP) -- Billy Gardner's line double with two out in the ninth inning drove in Jim Lemon and gave the Minnesota Twins a 6-5 victory over the Chicago White Sox today.
Barney G. Cameron, vice president and business manager of The New York Herald Tribune, has submitted his resignation to become effective at an early date.
Humberto Triana, a leading prosecution witness in the Molina murder trial here, was reported yesterday to have been captured by the Cuban government in the recent unsuccessful invasion of the island.

For the nature lover spring is the force that releases wild and beautiful things from winter's imprisonment. A city man takes what he can find, and if he happens to be fond of wildlife, he hies himself to Bear Mountain-Harriman State Park around this time to observe a variety of woodland creatures as they emerge from their native haunts.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Despite the Yankees' jarring loss to the Senators in the second game of yesterday's doubleheader, Manager Ralph Houk and his pitching coach, Johnny Sain, saw a lot to comfort them for the future.

Apparently undaunted by international crises, American corporations have continued to increase their investments abroad, according to a survey of intentions by Newsweek magazine in conjunction with the National Industrial Conference Board.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) -- Millions of Americans rededicated their nation's heritage of rule by law in Law Day ceremonies throughout the United States today.
Directors of Kerr-McGee Oil Industries, Inc., at a meeting held yesterday in Oklahoma City, Okla., initiated action to redeem on June 15 the prior convertible preferred stock.
KESHENA, Wis., May 1 (AP) -- The Menominee Indian Nation became independent of Federal control today.

The Times of April 21 carried a front-page story date-lined United Nations, "Ties With Mongolia Are Planned by United States." The story reported that the United States is considering establishing diplomatic relations with Outer Mongolia "to determine whether Outer Mongolia is in fact an independent state."
The annual luncheon of friends of the American Israeli Lighthouse will take place tomorrow in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
Parks Commissioner Newbold Morris announced yesterday the start of an educational campaign to curb vandalism in the parks. Such vandalism, he said, cost the city $295,930 last year.
NEW DELHI, India, May 1 -- The International Control Commission for Laos sent its initial report to Britain and the Soviet Union today.
PURCHASE, N.Y., May 1 -- Six homes featuring art collections are included in the Barnard-in-Westchester scholarship benefit tour, to be held next Saturday from 12.30 to 6 P.M.
An armed robber forced the superintendent of a Brooklyn apartment house to collect rent yesterday, then took the money. The robber also got $1,000 from the landlord.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A committee of economists proposed today that the Consumer Price Index be transformed into what many people think it already is -- a cost-of-living index.
The Series E United States Savings Bond celebrated its twentieth anniversary yesterday with holdings at a record high.
The upturn in steel production appears to be accelerating.
RESIDENTS of Brooklyn Heights are not convinced that progress in housing necessarily leads into the era of enlightenment.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) May 1 -- The trial of Adolf Eichmann, disrupted once by screams of "murderer" from the court gallery, turned today to the ghastly drama of Nazi-occupied Poland.

A DECADE ago today the doors closed on one of the most affectionately remembered hotels in America. It is the date on which the last meal, a farewell luncheon for members of the kitchen staff, was prepared by the noted chef, Louis Diat.

TO bare or not to bare one's midriff? That is the question that each woman who goes to buy a bathing suit must decide. Bikini adherents -- and their recruits among otherwise conservative members of the population are growing -- have found that Swedish manufacturers know how to treat the minimal swimsuit with the maximum of style.

OLEAN, N.Y., May 1 (UPI) -- Tom Stith, St. Bonaventure's all-America basketball player, has pulmonary tuberculosis and will be confined indefinitely to a sanitarium at Mount Morris, N.Y., it was learned today.
LONDON, May 1 -- Stock market prices moved irregularly here today, although gains continued to predominate in the industrial lists.

IN the notes for the Edgard Varese program at Town Hall last night there was a striking quotation by the composer: "Contrary to general belief, an artist is never ahead of his time but most people are far behind theirs."
BUFFALO, May 1 (AP) -- Federal and state mediators met with negotiators today in an effort to end a strike of truck drivers and dairy workers along a wide section of the Niagara frontier.

National Airlines, Inc. is offering to its common stockholders the right to subscribe for $10,288,000 of 6 per cent convertible subordinated debentures due in 1976. The debentures are offered in the ratio of $100 for each eighteen shares held on April 28, 1961.

One hundred and twenty housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration are planning the sale of issues of temporary loan notes totaling $164,349,000 on May 9 to finance low-rent projects. The notes will come due from Sept. 15, 1961 to June 15, 1962.
LONDON, May 1 -- News has reached the British Museum of Natural History of the capture of what is considered one of the rarest reptiles.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A United States-Canadian commission found today that the Passamaquoddy project to develop power from the tides of the Bay of Fundy was not economically feasible now.
NEWARK, May 1 -- Appeals for fiscal reforms to finance state services highlighted the opening today of a series of public hearings by the state Democratic party's platform committee.
KINGS POINT, L.I., May 1 -The United States Merchant Marine Memorial Chapel was dedicated here today to the memory of American merchant seamen who have given their lives for their country.

A documentary film about socialized medicine in Britain will be televised over Channel 13 (WNTA) on May 14 at 7:30 P.M. Five New York physicians will present a panel discussion immediately after the film.

The month just ended was abundant in signs that the economy is recovering from what will go down in economic history as the recession of 1960-61. This newspaper's Weekly Index of Business Activity, for example, closed the month at its highest level in almost a year. The appreciable increase in steel production during April finally brought steel output toward the end of the month above the level of 60 per cent of capacity.

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 1 -- King Savang Vathana has come out against an attempt by the great powers to settle the issue of peace in Laos at a conference in Geneva, Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia said today.
MAYPORT, Fla., May 1 -- A convoy left the naval station here today to deliver a floating drydock and several attending craft to Holy Loch, Scotland, 4,000 miles away.
President Kennedy welcomed Arthur Hays Sulzberger, chairman of the board of The New York Times, to the "rocking chair club" yesterday.

The Fire Department's stepped-up schedule of inspections in the city's schools resulted yesterday in the closing of parts of a public school in Harlem and a Roman Catholic parochial school in Brooklyn.
For the first time in the history of the office, the Borough President of Manhattan, Edward R. Dudley, appointed a career Civil Service employe as Commissioner of Borough Works yesterday.

FOR its final production of the season, "The Play of the Week," on Channel 13 is offering "All Summer Long," a perceptive study of an American family leading a pallid, sluggish existence that brings it to the edge of disaster.

General buying and heavy commission-house purchasing raised prices for wool futures yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Scattered selling supplied the contracts. The forward positions climbed to new highs for the lives of the contracts.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The House passed a bill today to leaglize the flag. It also gave the President sole authority for designing the star arrangement when more states join the union.

PARIS, May 1 -- The Government said today that two of the retired generals who led the army mutiny in Algeria last week had been able to go there through the complicity of a high-ranking general of the air force.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 1 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower cautioned today against a "witch-hunting" investigation of the Cuban invasion failure.
ACCRA, Ghana, May 1 -- President Kwame Nkrumah assumed absolute control tonight of Ghana's Government and the ruling party.
A hotel chain here has developed a buy-and-lease-out operation for its properties, reversing the widely used sale and lease-back.
Trans World Airlines said yesterday it had signed a $187,000,000 lease-purchase contract for they Boeing jets.

Striking employes of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company voted overwhelmingly last night to end their month-old walkout. Company and union spokesmen said that the 2,800 employes involved would begin returning to work tomorrow morning.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 1 -Medical reseachers had a field day against disease and infirmity at a packed scientific meeting here today.
Unless the Federal Communications Commission suffers a change of heart, advertisers and their agencies appear to have lost their fight against increased commercial television time.

The drab thoroughfares of New York were blossoming yesterday with flowering magnolia, hawthorn and cherry trees, as well as many of the 250,000 tulips, 2,000 azaleas and various other items planted for the fourth annual Salute to Spring.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., May 1 -William McGovern of Wheatley and Pat Cici of Lido combined for a 33, 33 -- 66, six strokes under par, to win the first Long Island Professional Golf Association amateur-pro tournament of the season at the Brookville Country Club today.

Financing plans involving $90,000,000 of fixed interest securities of two utilities, a steel company and a refrigeration concern were announced yesterday. In addition, a secondary offering of common shares of a crude-oil marketer also was announced.

MOSCOW, May 1 -- Defense Minister Rodion Y. Malinuovsky declared at a huge May Day rally today that the Soviet Union was taking all necessary steps to strengthen still further its armed forces and defense capacity.
Prices of United States Government securities and other prime-risk bonds held firm in a quiet trading session yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today set aside the manslaughter conviction of Lewis Lloyd Anderson, a Negro minister of Selma, Ala., who complained that members of his race were systematically excluded from trial and grand juries in Dallas County, Ala.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk assured a Senate group today that the United States had no plans now "to proceed in any way in armed intervention in Cuba."
ALBANY, May 1 (AP) -- A strike by 2,500 construction workers in the Albany-Troy area tied up work today on about $30,000,000 in projects. Seven thousand other workers refused to cross picket lines.
STERLING FOREST, N.Y., May 1 -- Governor Rockefeller commended 150 engineers, scientists and educators here today for advancing the cause of peace.
Guests at the Maternity Center Association's fashion show luncheon at the Sheraton-East on May 10 will arrive there with gifts of rummage.

GARDNER W. MOULTON of Hartford, Conn., throwing murderously courteous punches, has come forward as the champion of the canoeist in so far as the canoeist and the trout fisherman interfere with each other.
Federal and state support for child day-care centers is not only a social but also a patriotic responsibility, Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday.

The Southern Pacific Company, giant West Coast transportation system, reported yesterday that revenues and earnings fell in both March and the first three months of 1961 from the levels of the 1960 periods.
LINDEN, N.J., May 1 -About 2,600 employes at the General Motors assembly plant here stopped working today in a dispute over an alleged speed-up.

BALTIMORE, May 1 -- It will be another week, perhaps even two weeks, before Stockholders of the Alleghany Corporation know who has won control of their company. Its management of the last twenty-one years headed by Allan P. Kirby of Morristown, N.J., has been opposed in a fight for control by Mr. Kirby's one-time business "friends" but now "foes", John D. Murchison and his brother, Clint W. Murchison Jr. of Dallas, Tex.

MOSCOW, May 1 (UPI) -Francis Gary Powers, the United States U-2 pilot who was shot down over the Soviet Union a year ago, presumably spent the anniversary of his flight today making envelopes in a prison.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Tuesday, May 2 -- A United States astronaut is expected to be launched today on a flight such as no American has ever attempted.
Tension grips Bedford-Stuyvesant -- Brooklyn's Little Harlem -- in the aftermath of last week's street-gang warfare that took the lives of two teenagers.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Supreme Court decided today to hear further argument before tackling the touchy problem of unequal districts in Legislatures.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- President Kennedy signed today the $394,000,000 bill to aid areas economically depressed by chronic unemployment.

YONKERS, May 1 -- More than 5,000 persons have bowled a total of 11,000 games at Central Lanes since the establishment opened here last Friday night but not even 50 cents, the price of one game, has been recorded on the cash register.
The Board of Hospitals will recommend to Mayor Wagner that Fordham Hospital in the Bronx be closed, Hospitals Commissioner Ray E. Trussell said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Stewart L. Udall, the Kennedy Administration's director of lands, parks, oil, minerals and Indian affairs, appears to be creating two contradictory reputations.
Stocks drifted along yesterday in comparatively lethargic trading. The result on the New York Stock Exchange was a minor gain on average.
There was plenty of singing but no violence in Washington Square last evening at a May Day rally complete with a youth chorus and counterpoint from the crowd.
The New York Red Cross Blood Program collected 12,265 pints of blood in April, compared to 11,476 in March.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 1 -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga remained a prisoner in Coquilhatville today, despite the Central Government's announcement yesterday that he would be transferred to Leopoldville.
The family of a New York University freshman arrested during a demonstration by folk-music fans at Washington Square Park moved yesterday to bring assault charges against the police.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy announced last night the suspension of a patrolman for allegedly accepting "gratuities" from the owners of two coffeehouses in Greenwich Village.

PARIS, May 1 -- Now that the French "mutiny of the generals" may be a thing of the past, the question whether the United States helped save the day for President de Gaulle is perhaps less important than what is believed in France, in North Africa and elsewhere about the United States' role in the events.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Kennedy Administration is considering asking the United Nations to reinforce the call for a cease-fire in Laos and to send observers there to see that a cessation of hostilities is fully observed, diplomatic sources said today.
The Esso Standard division of the Humble Oil and Refining Company yesterday instituted off-season allowances on home heating oils, kerosene and Diesel fuel, from Maine to Louisiana.

The Greater New York Fund is the largest network of local charities in the world. It provides persons who either live or work in New York with the chance to contribute at one time -- at their place of business -- to 425 local medical health and welfare agencies.

EVERYONE knows that people like to peer into celebrities' homes. What the National Design Center did not know, but bargained for a year ago, is that people also like to view rooms created for well-known personalities even if they do not live in them.

REVIVED interest in the blocking of mink, a technique that reduces the cost of a coat -- sometimes by more than a half -- has caused something of a stir among New York furriers and confusion in the public mind.
A new tension point has developed in the strained relations between the merged labor federation and major Negro organizations.

The description of the Cuban revolution by Premier Fidel Castro and his associates as "Socialist" hardly comes as a surprise. The revolution had been evolving in this direction almost from the beginning, slowly in its first year, 1959, and rapidly last year. This is a form of socialism different from the democratic socialism of Europe.

A LITTLE more commercialism is the last thing television needs and the first thing it is going to get. In a marriage of viewpoints as intriguing as it was unexpected, the New Frontier down in Washington and Ollie Treyz, the whiz kid of commercial TV, have decided that the viewer is to be blessed by more advertising in network station breaks.
The compromise version of the minimum wage bill which emerged from conference late yesterday will, we hope and expect, be approved by both houses of Congress tomorrow.

TRENTON, May 1 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner named William Fillmore Wood of Plainfield today to the State Superior Court. If confirmed by the State Senate, Mr. Wood would become the first Negro to serve in such a high judicial post in New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy asked congress today to make clear through stiffer penalties that bomb scares at airports or aboard commercial airliners are no joking matter.

Sir John Gielgud had hardly settled down at a local hotel suite yesterday when he began speaking -- not in the classic style for which he is famous in the theatre, but rather in a torrent of words -- about what had impelled him to make a hurried trans-Atlantic trip to New York.
MIAMI, Fla., Tuesday, May 2 (AP) -- A machinists strike grounded all National Airlines planes at 1 A.M. (Eastern Daylight Time) today.
MIAMI, May 1 -- Rolando Masferrer, a former Cuban Senator who has been in the custody of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service here since April 8, was released today.
TRENTON, May 1 (AP) -The State Health Department today banned the taking of shellfish in the New Jersey portions of Raritan Bay and the Sandy Hook Bay and also the Navesink and Shrewsbury Rivers.

The election of six foreign writers and artists as honorary members of the American Academy and National Institute of Arts and Letters was announced yesterday by Allan Nevins, secretary of the academy.
Messages from American labor leaders were broadcast to Eastern Europe yesterday by Radio Free Europe.

A citizen suit filed here yesterday charged that the State Constitution illegally favored rural areas in the apportionment of legislators. It asked the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York to declare the system void.
CINCINNATI, May 1 (AP) -Jim O'Toole pitched a six-hitter tonight as the Reds beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 3 -- 2, and climbed from the National League cellar.
" All the Way Home," which yesterday became the first Pulitzer Prize play based on a Pulitzer Prize novel, is the Cinderella story of many Broadway seasons.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Officials of the National Farmers Union endorsed the Administration's omnimus farm bill today, calling it a useful "do-it-yourself" approach through which farmers could strengthen their bargaining power.

The state Investigation Commission disclosed a procedural change yesterday by which a Democrat will take over its chairmanship for the coming six-month period, in which inquiries into New York City affairs may be prominent.

The merger of the Universal Match Corporation and Universal Controls, Inc., was approved yesterday by the executive committee of Universal Match and all the directors of Universal Controls. It is now subject to the approval of stockholders of both companies at special meetings to be held on July 31.

Two major films have been booked for premieres at Broadway first-run theatres. "The Guns of Navarone," adapted and produced by Carl Foreman on location in Greece and released by Columbia, will open at the Criterion Theatre June 22.

MELBOURNE, April 30 -- The Minister for National Development, Senator William Henry Spooner, has announced the striking of oil in Cabawin Number One well at Tara, Queensland, that he describes as "encouraging."
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 1 -- The space agency sought today to stem a publicity build-up enveloping the forthcoming space flight of a Mercury astronaut.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The Defense Department is backing a policy of the services against the showing to civilian groups, under military sponsorship, of the film "Operation Abolition," a spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -With broad grin, a former Australian naval officer observed today that President Kennedy was "still the same man" he had helped rescue in World War II but "certainly better dressed."
ANOTHER Harvard man is going to Washington. He is William Loren Batt Jr., a tall, tweedy, slightly bald positive thinker who is almost a stereotype of what Harvard men are supposed to be these days.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A Senate-House conference committee produced today a "compromise" minimum-wage bill neatly designed to attract reluctant Southern Democratic votes in the House.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 -- Some 4,000,000 school children who hold accounts in the nation's 515 mutual savings banks could be required to file income tax returns to obtain refunds on interest withheld under a new Federal tax proposal.
WORCESTER, England, May 1 (Reuters) -- Australia was in danger today of losing the opening cricket match of its tour.
TODAY'S deal drew atten-chiefly because of the unusual contract at which it was played in one instance. However, when studied more closely it presents other interesting aspects.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 1 (UPI) -- Frank Oftring was named head basketball coach at Holy Cross today and said he planned to concentrate on two factors -- defense and Jack (The Shot) Foley.

Columbia combined two timely triples with the three-hit pitching of Murray Melton, a senior left-hander, to hand Rutgers its second defeat of the season, 4 -- 1, at Baker Field yesterday. The game was called after six and a half innings because of rain.
I belong to a group of people who are over sixty-five, have no Social Security and whose incomes are largely from dividends on stock.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 1 -- Dr. Albert L. Weiner, an osteopathic physician, was indicted today on fifteen counts of manslaughter in the serum hepatitis deaths of fifteen of his patients.

NEW CASTLE, Pa., May 1 (UPI) -- Three Belgian mare workhorses were sold at auction today by the Federal Government and brought $152 more than was owed in Social Security taxes by the Amish farmer from whom they were seized.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The United States Government is becoming concerned over the persistence of newspaper reports and rumors in France that someone from this country encouraged the April 22 mutiny of French generals in Algeria.
Aqueduct's investigation of two cases of race-horse stimulation resumed yesterday, with positive results still eluding the investigators.
DALLAS, May 1 (AP) -- The 1961 American Football League schedule, disclosed today by Commissioner Joe Foss, has the Boston Patriots and New York Titans opening the season Sept. 9 at Boston.
MIAMI, Fla., May. 1 -- A passenger drew a pistol and a knife in the cockpit of a National Airlines plane over the Florida Keys today and forced the pilot to fly to Havana.
An anonymous letter to Mayor Wagner's special post office complaint box has resulted in the smashing of a $1,000,000-a-year numbers racket, the Mayor reported yesterday.

DALLAS, Tex., May 1 -- The General Assembly of the Southern Presbyterian Church demanded unanimously today that groups, such as the John Birch Society, put a stop to "undocumented" charges of communism in the clergy.

LOUISVILLE, May 1 -- Four-and-Twenty, one of the colts rated in the most-likely-to-succeed bracket for the Kentucky Derby, heads a field of ten entered in tomorrow's thirty-seventh running of the Derby Trial.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) -- Two members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee accused the Administration today of giving too much advance publicity to the United States Mercury flight.
Council President Abe Stark gave his reluctant support yesterday to City Charter revision under the state revision law -- if that law is found constitutional by the courts.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) -- Commerce Secretary Luther H. Hodges disclosed today that the Kennedy Administration was considering offering American investors guarantees against government seizure in less-developed nations.
Once Billy Pickett learns to use the power at his command, the White Plains (N.Y.) boxer may make a place for himself in the middleweight division.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 1 -- These days, when it is fashionable for Hollywood's businessmen to sport the intellectual vocabulary of creative artists, one of the most energetic manipulators in guileful buying and selling shows no signs of guilt.
The sixty-three metropolitan outlets of the Vim Television and Appliance store chain were shut down yesterday by a strike of 200 sales, clerical and maintenance employes.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 1 -- Roger M. Blough, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation told stockholders here today that his company was experiencing "a gradual but noticeable improvement in orders."
President Kennedy has been urged by the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen Union to appoint a consumer counsel to look after consumer interests.
" All the Way Home," a play based on the Pulitzer Prize novel for 1958 won the 1961 Pulitzer Prize for drama yesterday.
CHICAGO, May 1 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

A long bill of particulars could be offered in support of Harris L. Present's position regarding relocation of tenants displaced by urban renewal and in opposition to the contentions of Chairman J. Clarence Davies Jr. of the Housing and Redevelopment Board on this subject.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 1 -- King Hussein of Jordan announced tonight his engagement to a girl whom he identified as a commoner and a non-Arab. He said she was a Moslem.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 1 -- Twenty-seven rowing enthusiasts, all collegians, awakened at dawn today to take part in the twice-postponed James H. Hughes Memorial Cup Regatta before the start of their morning classes.
A goal of $11,000,000 for the Greater New York Fund's 1961 appeal was announced yesterday by Hermann Place, president of the fund, who is director of the General Precision Equipment Corporation.

BERLIN, May 1 -- Berliners turned out today for contrasting May Day celebrations held almost within earshot in the two parts of this divided city. The combined attendance at the celebration was estimated at 1,000,000.
VALLEY FORGE, Pa., May 1 (AP) -- Ground was broken today for the American Freedom Center, a $1,500,000 project designed as a showcase of free enterprise.
Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner, has called on state residents to approve budgets "adequate for the growing needs of your schools."

The price of copper was raised by a cent a pound yesterday, reflecting an upturn in demand in the copper industry. The Anaconda Company, a major producer, and the American Smelting and Refining Company, a producer as well as a custom smelter, led the round of price increases.
KEY WEST, Fla., Tuesday, May 2 -- Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba asserted last flight that Cuba was a Socialist nation and declared there would be no more elections.

At the very moment when the Russians are trying to paralyze if not destroy the United Nations, an American Assistant Secretary of State, Harlan Cleveland, argues convincingly for pulling more strength into the United Nations and for making more positive use of it.
Mrs. Edna Plumb is "over 70" -- more she will not admit to, "because I don't want my friends to feel sorry for me."
TRENTON, May 1 -- The state owns all land flooded at mean high tide regardless of its proximity to navigable streams, bays or the ocean, the Appellate Division of Superior Court affirmed today.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 1 (UPI) Circuit Judge Walter B. Jones postponed today Parks Commissioner Frank W. Parks' $500,0O0 libel suit against The New York Times and four Alabama Negro ministers. It will not be heard until the next term of court, pending Federal action.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to review lower court rulings that states must produce voting records on demand of the United States Attorney General.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 5 to 16 points (25 to 80 cents a bale) yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The Supreme Court became slightly confused today in admitting 315 lawers from New York some ended up taking the oath twice. All are graduates of New York University Law School.
Auto output by three of the four major auto makers declined in April. They also reported yesterday production for the first four months of this year was below the 1960 level.
JERUSALEM, May 1 -- Dr. Leon W. Wells of 3051 Edwin Avenue, Fort Lee, N.J., testified that of his whole family, seventy-six members, he was the only one who had escaped with his life.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Supreme Court rejected today a union argument that all employes of railroads that merge must be kept at work after the merger.

The Pulitzer Prize Awards count for a great deal in this country, even though they may not predict what posterity will say. This year there is poetic justice in the drama award to a play that nearly failed: "All the Way Home," Tad Mosel's dramatization of the late James Agee's novel that won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction three years ago.

The textile industry appears to have reached the bottom of its downward cycle and now is beginning to move up again, G.S. Tompkins, president of the American Viscose Corporation, told shareholders at the annual meeting in Philadelphia yesterday.

When the Moiseyev dancers assembled for rehearsal yesterday on the cavernous stage of the Metropolitan Opera House, two United States ice-skating stars were waiting in the fifth row in the darkened house.
LONDON, May 1 -- A new era dawned today for Britain's multitudes of horse players as off-track betting shops, operated by licensed bookmakers, opened for business.
WHITE PLAINS, May 1 -- A four-year state college on a 215-acre site in North Yonkers was proposed today by supervisors of that city.

The Randolph Trading Corporation has acquired the five-story apartment building at 1295 Sheridan Avenue, the Bronx, from a client of Myron K. Wilson, lawyer. The transaction was negotiated by Carl Davis, broker.
A 48-year-old Hempstead business man sought yesterday to avoid pleading in the Federal Court, Brooklyn, to charges of conspiring to smuggle Chinese aliens into the United States.
CHICAGO, May 1 -- An American branch of the International Society for Labor Law and Social Legislation was established today with headquarters in Chicago.
HAVANA, Tuesday, May 2 -- About 500,000 Cubans demonstrated here yesterday against the "imperialistic United States" and shouted approval of the regime of Premier Fidel Castro.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Discount rates on short-term treasury bills bounded upward again on today's sale of the regular weekly issues, following the trend of trading in the market last week. They had been falling sharply for three weeks and hit new lows last Monday.

THEY really are not twins. They're not even related. But the Olympic Village in Rome was in a constant state of confusion last summer when Chris von Saltza and Lynn Burke, two statuesque, blue-eyed, platinum-blonde swimmers, put in an appearance. Being inseparable companions and strikingly similar in looks, coloring, architecture and tastes, they were almost indistinguishable.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) -- Two communications giants recommended today that the industry's space operations be organized through a jointly owned concern.

Operations of the Bristol-Myers Company for the first three months of this year resulted in substantially larger earnings than those cleared in the 1960 period, according to a report issued for publication yesterday.

On the evening of May 10 many socially prominent persons will assume the dress of members of the Brazilian royal family, the court, nobility and diplomatic corps to attend a grand ball and supper in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the National Society for Crippled Children and Adults.

Mayor Wagner has still to announce his decision on whether to run for a third term. But it is obvious already that if he does seek re-election he faces a substantial test of his principles and of his expressed independence of political bossism. At the same time the Liberal party, curiously enough, faces an almost identical test.
CHICAGO, May 1 (AP) -- The grain futures market today withstood a late moderate flurry of selling and finished with prices generally higher, although most of them were well their peaks of the day.

LOS ANGELES, May 1 (UPI) -- The heavyweight champion, Floyd Patterson, today was offered $350,000 to meet the winner of the Zora Folley-Alejandro Lavorante fight, but Folley conceded Sonny Liston rated a title shot more than any other contender.
SEATTLE, Wash., May 2 -- Symbolically, the Boeing Airplane Company stepped into the space age today, divesting its corporate title of the word airplane.
LONDON, May 2 -- Profit-taking more than matched demand in most industrial sections of the stock market here today and prices finished slightly lower on balance.

The Calumet Farm entry of Sun Glint and Prince's Gate was the overnight co-favorite with Capt. Harry F. Guggenheim's Make Sail for today's fifth running of the $28,400 Bed o' Roses Handicap at Aqueduct. The odds were 2 -- 1.

Morgan Stanley Co. and associates are offering for public subscription today $100,000,000 of thirty-year debentures of Continental Oil Company. The issue bears a 4 1/2 per cent coupon and is priced at 99 1/4 to yield 4.55 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) Howard V. Morgan of Oregon, nominated to the Federal Power Commission, told the Senate Commerce Committee today he had not listed a minor arrest in 1937 on Federal job forms because the arrest had always exasperated and mildly outraged him.
BOSTON, May 2 (UPI) -- Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., the skipper of Vim in the 1958 trials for the America's Cup races, was named skipper today of Easterner, which also participated in the trials.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 (UPI) -- The United States Government dropped remaining charges today in the Powell-Schuman treason-sedition case of the Korean War.
Governor Rockefeller declared last night that "the so-called rich" were paying a larger percentage of the state's taxes under his fiscal programs than they did two years ago.
LONDON, May 2 -- David K.E. Bruce, United States Ambassador to Britain, said tonight the West had submitted too patiently and too long to vicious and untruthful attacks on its civilization.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) -- Directors of the Chamber of Commerce reaffirmed today their thirty-seven-year-old code of business ethics and urged business men to obey the antitrust laws.

In her appearance in Carnegie Recital Hall last night, Katherine Seaman showed musical intelligence in her choice of program, which was restricted to works in German, a language in which the soprano seemed comfortable.
The New York City Housing Authority sold yesterday $7,870,000 of temporary loan notes for the financing of State-aided low-rent projects at an average interest cost of 1.51253 per cent.

Boris Koutzen, Russian-born violinist, composer, teacher and conductor, was honored with a program of his music last night at Judson Hall. The concert was arranged to celebrate his sixtieth birthday, which was on April 1.
DALLAS, Tex., May 2 -- The Southern Presbyterian Church upheld capital punishment today on the legal ground that it is specifically provided for by the church's constitution.
LOUISVILLE, May 3 -- Fred Hooper's Crozier ran straight and fast at Churchill Downs today, fast enough to break the track record in winning the Derby Trial.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., May 2 -- Indiana hopes to open its own "new frontier" in the Midwest with the construction of a deep-water port on Lake Michigan that would make the state an industrial power.
William H. Gray Jr., City Clerk of Yonkers, was accused yesterday of having accepted a $500 bribe in 1959 from William P. Buckner, convicted swindler, to help Buckner's bingo operations.

LONDON, May 2 (AP) -- Terry Downes, the British middleweight champion, stopped Tony Montano of Phoenix, Ariz., in five rounds of their ten-round bout tonight. Montano retired after the end of the fifth round because of a bad cut over his left eye.

LOS ANGELES, May 3 (AP) -- Jim Gentile's ninth-inning home run over the right-field wall was the deciding shot in a battle of home runs tonight as the Baltimore Orioles defeated Los Angeles, 7 -- 6, before a crowd of 6,664.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 2 -- Herbert G. Klein, former Vice President Nixon's campaign press secretary, accused the Justice Department today of threatening to blackmail American newspapers.

A 14-year-old boy sang the National Anthem here when President Benjamin Harrison laid the cornerstone for Grant's Tomb in 1892. Now almost 83 years old, he presented the first contribution yesterday for an equestrian statue of the general in front of the tomb, and offered to sing "The Star Spangled Banner" again at the dedication.

Nurserymen planted nineteen young London plane trees yesterday on West Ninety-six Street between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue. Resident of the block, who paid for the trees, watched with approval.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 4 to 16 points (20 to 80 cents a bale) yesterday.

Traffic safety in the city gained in the first four months of 1961 compared with the same period a year ago, the police reported yesterday. Fatalities declined 19 per cent and injuries and accidents also were lower.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, May 2 -- The Cabinet of secessionist Katanga Province promised today to discuss United Nations demands on the reorganization of the Katanga Army and the ousting of foreign advisers.

GREENVILLE, S.C., May 2 (AP) -- Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon said here today that he did not think Republicans should publicly criticize the Kennedy Administration for "mistakes which have hurt our world position."

MIAMI, Fla., May 2 -- The operations of National Airlines remained at a standstill tonight more than eighteen hours after a strike was called by the International Association of Machinists. There have been no negotiations since 11:30 o'clock last night, according to officials of the airline here.

MOTION pictures of fine American hunting and fishing, long either confined to showings in small clubs or so badly made that they were hardly worth showing at all, have only recently begun to force their way into television and before large audiences.

LONDON, May 2 -- British and French officials renewed today their talks on the problems Britain would face in joining or becoming associated with the six-nation European Economic Community or Common Market.
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 2 -- The Venezuelan Government has decided to seek "concerted action" on the Cuban question, reliable sources indicated today.
The election of J. Richardson Dilworth, Robert A. Magowan and Ernest L. Molloy as directors of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., was announced yesterday by Jack I. Straus, chairman.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- President Kennedy has selected Dr. James R. Killian Jr. to lead the permanent Presidential board that monitors the Government's foreign intelligence activities. Dr. Killian is chairman of the Corporation of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

LUXEMBOURG, May 2 -- Prince Jean of Luxembourg, whose mother, Grand Duchess Charlotte said today she would name him her lieutenant on Thursday, previously was designated heir to the title of Grand Duke.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation reported yesterday for the first quarter of 1961 a consolidated net income of $16,096,270, or $1.06 a share, on an average of 15,152,058 shares outstanding in the period. This represented an increase of 27.3 per cent from the net income of $12,647,289, or 81 cents a share, reported for the 1960 period.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- An old and valuable pencil and sepia drawing of Benjamin Franklin has been accepted informally by Mrs. John F. Kennedy as the first major acquisition of her newly created Fine Arts Committee for the White House.
RICHMONDVILLE, N.Y., May 2 (UPI) -- Chauncey Winters, a banker, believes in doing his own urban renewal, and the taxpayers of this upstate village love him for it.
The Port of New York led all other United States and Canadian ports in money spent on port construction in the last fifteen years, the Port of New York Authority disclosed here yesterday.

An apartment development for 568 families in Stamford, Conn., has bene sold by Jesse Hartman, New York and Connecticut builder. The property, which fronts on Bedford, Hoyt and Morgan Streets, was bought by a syndicate of investors headed by Gilbert Schlesinger and Bernard E. Alpren.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 2 -- The defense of Adolf Eichmann suffered two major blows today.
Branch Rickey received the 1961 annual distinguished achievement medal of the Grand Lodge of Masons of New York State last night.

The Coca-Cola Company announced yesterday that William E. Robinson, chairman since 1958, was retiring from that office. Lee Talley, president, was elected to the additional post of chairman. The action came at a meeting of directors of the big soft drink company, which also reported its first quarter earnings.

LUXEMBOURG, May 2 -- Grand Duchess Charlotte, 65-year-old monarch of Luxembourg, made the expected announcement to Parliament today that she was appointing her eldest son and heir, Prince Jean, as her lieutenant to exercise executive power on her behalf.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the principal goals of his administration for 1961 were Charter revision, a massive attack on slums and "a vigorous drive against unethical practices." In all, he listed twenty-eight major objectives to achieve this year.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 2 -- Human cells have for the first time been altered in the test tube by treating them with the hereditary material extracted from other human cells, a scientist reported here today.

The tragic events in Cuba in recent days provide a dramatic demonstration, if such is required, of the need for the United States Congress to take prompt action on President Kennedy's appropriation request of $500,000,000 for the Inter-American Fund for Social Progress.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Following is the text of a statement on Cuba issued today by Lincoln White, Department of State spokesman:
The city yesterday granted the financially hard-pressed New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad a nine-month deferment on $304,000 in real estate taxes that were due Monday.
WASHINGTON, May 2 --President Kennedy announced today a program of assistance to the textile industry. The program pointed strongly toward import quotas on competing nations.
With such standouts as Althea Gibson and Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Danzig available to lend a helping hand, New York City's boys and girls will again have the opportunity to learn the game of tennis.
KANSAS CITY, May 2 (AP) -- Bud Daley pitched the Kansas City Athletics to a 7-4 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight, aided by Marv Throneberry's two-run homer.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 2 -- Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Zionist Organization, accused Premier David Ben-Gurion today of worsening problems faced by American Jews by fixing his relations with them through what he termed an unrepresentative organization.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- An Administration bill to authorize $3,298,000,000 in Federal grants for public schools started moving through the Senate today under pressure from Democratic leaders for early passage.
LONDON, May 2 -- A Baptist missionary who recently returned from Angola charged today that the Portuguese had been exacting merciless reprisals against rebelling Africans in recent weeks.
CLEVELAND, May 2 (AP) -- A single by John Romano in@ the eleventh inning drove in the winning run as the Indians beat the Chicago White Sox, 3 -- 2, tonight in the opener of a two-game series.

LOUISVILLE, May 2 -- The sun was shining bright on the old Kentucky home today. But there was a nip in the air, like the frost on a mint julep glass, as the Kentucky Derby began to gain momentum in its relentless rush toward Saturday's showdown. The Derby Trial this afternoon concluded the competitive phase of the preparations and only speculative conversation remains.
ACCRA, Ghana, May 2 -- President Kwame Nkrumah curtailed the powers of two of his senior Cabinet colleagues today.

Stockholders of the Radio Corporation of America sat unmoved yesterday at their annual meeting during a report that first-quarter earnings dropped by 8 per cent from those of the 1960 period. The report was given by John L. Burns, president, who said that the decrease occurred despite record sales for the period.

Marion Harper Jr.'s dream of creating a new kind of advertising agency structure was subjected to a considerable disillusionment yesterday. McCann-Erickson, Inc., lost all of its Colgate Palmolive Company business.
Relatively little taxpayer resistance to higher school budgets appeared as suburban school districts began their annual voting last night.

Directors of Food Fair Stores, Inc., declared yesterday a five-for-four split on the common stock, payable on Aug. 14 to stockholders of record of July 14. One additional share will be issued for each four shares held.

The Geo. B. Peck Company of Kansas City, Mo., will become the first unit of the new Almart division of Allied Stores Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Theodore Schlesinger, president of Allied.

The City Planning Commission's recommendations for a 1961-62 middle-income housing and renewal program are encouraging both for what they propose and for the opportunity they afford the public to be heard.

A strong tone surged up in the bond market yesterday, encompassing all gilt-edge corporate obligations as well as securities of the United States Government and of state and municipal government bodies.
OTTAWA, May 2 -- The Canadian Government announced today that it had negotiated an agreement with Communist China for one of the biggest grain sales in Canada's history.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- Senator Prescott S. Bush, Republican of Connecticut, expressed fear today that budget deficits could prove habit-forming to the Kennedy Administration. This, he said, could reawaken "sleeping inflation."
CHICAGO, May 2 (AP) -- Guiding influences were absent from the grain futures trade today and prices shifted generally within a narrow range in mostly slack dealings.
Mayor Wagner's Charter Revision Commission, ignoring a court challenge to its legality, moved yesterday to speed its work on drafting a new Charter for submission to the voters Nov. 7.
Adlai E. Stevenson said last night that the United Nations "is and will continue to be managed predominantly by its non-Communist members."
ALGIERS, May 2 -- Under the pressure of mass arrests, house-to-house searches by the police and the fear of denunciation, Europeans in Algiers appear to be closing their ranks.
Archaeological remains of Indian cultures that flourished long before the Spanish conquest of Central Mexico have been added to the collection of the Museum of the American Indian.

The following table gives the amount of dealings in the stocks from which the averages are computed, the combined trading in both classes of issues, as well as the total daily transactions for week and month:
PHILADELPHIA, May 2 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit has established a new rule to determine legal insanity of a defendant.
WHITE PLAINS, May 2 -- This city needs fifty-two more acres of parks and playgrounds at once, Westchester County's Planning Department and Recreation Commission declared today.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- When President Kennedy came to Chicago last week-end, he tried to define the main problem before the nation. It did not lie, he said, in the Soviet Union, or in Cuba, or in Laos, but right here at home.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- The Secretary to the Cabinet acknowledged today that he once advised Government officials to mention President Kennedy in their speeches.

Stockholders of Kennecott Copper Corporation greeted their new president yesterday with a broadside of controversial questions. The new president, Frank R. Milliken, 47, stood his ground, however, and in the end won enthusiastic applause from the 850 shareholders assembled at the Statler Hilton Hotel for the annual meeting.
Following is the text of the conclusion of Mayor Wagner's annual message to the City Council yesterday, giving his administration's goals for 1961:
" Continental Classroom," a dispenser of higher education on television for three years in early morning hours, plans to leave the National Broadcasting Company with its last telecast on May 26.

The woman with the full figure will find a varied selection of summer styles at Lane Bryant, from bathing suits in popular maillot or dressmaker styles to brightly colored chiffon dresses for evening.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 2 (AP) -- Utilities in New York State are well under way with a program to provide the fastest and most efficient means of developing atomic power, the president of Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation told stockholders today.
Dan Denny and Bob Woodruff of Bristol, Conn., placed first over all in the tenth annual Yankee Monte Carlo Rally run over the week-end by the Connecticut Sports Car Club.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Senate and House conferees agreed today on legislation to create seventy-three Federal judgeships.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 2 -- Members of the Congressional space committees expressed a near-unanimous concern today over the publicity being given the nation's first attempt to send a man into space.

LONDON, May 2 -- The reserves of gold and convertible currencies held by Britain as central banker for the sterling area declined again last month, falling below the $3,000,000,000 mark for the first time since last July.
With or without a cease-fire the threat of Communist takeover in Laos remains -- through military means if there is not a cease-fire, through political action if there is.
TORONTO, May 2 (Canadian Press) -- The Royal Insurance Company, with headquarters in London, has offered to buy shares of two 100-year-old Canadian insurance companies.
The stock market snapped out of its brief lethargy yesterday. Prices advanced, on average, on the New York Stock Exchange in heavier trading.
Diplomats from South and Central America and their wives were guests of honor at last night's sixth annual Heart of America Ball, which has as its theme "A Salute to Latin America."
CHICAGO. May 2 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 2 -- The Reformed Church here will hold a fair on May 12 and 13. Proceeds will aid church-improvement projects, help to reduce the mortgage debt and aid Warwick Estates. The last fair held by the congregation was in 1957.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 2 -- The Central Government announced today that President Moise Tshombe of Katanga would "remain" in Coquilhatville until the end of the conference there of Congolese leaders.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 2 -- The Yankees paid their first visit today to the Twin Cities' gaudily refurbished Metropolitan Stadium and forthwith celebrated the occasion in the grand manner.

The head of a private investigating agency was indicted here yesterday on charges of placing an eavesdropping device in a private car hired by the Duchess of Argyll while she was in New York last December and January.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The State Department described Cuba today as a full-fledged member of the Communist bloc. It indicated that consultations with Latin-American Governments for a joint approach to this problem had begun.
MILWAUKEE, May 2 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers scored six runs in the seventh inning tonight on two hits, five walks, an error and a wild pitch and went on to defeat the Milwaukee Braves, 11 -- 9.
The Fire Department has given the Board of Education twenty-four hours to clear up two violations in the Martin Van Buren High School in Queens.

Despite relatively poor shoe sales and production during the first quarter of this year, attendance and buying at the Popular Price Shoe Show of America is close to record levels. Attendance on Sunday, the opening day of the five-day presentation of fall footwear, was a record.

SQUARE dancing, puppet shows, rhythm bands and quilting bees are all part of the "Daisy Days" to be presented this week-end by the Girl Scouts of Greater New York. The vernal celebration will be held on Saturday from 1 to 5 P.M. and 6 to 10 P.M., and on Sunday from 2 to 6 P.M., simultaneously in each of the five boroughs.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- President Kennedy told the nation's biggest defense companies today that they would buttress the free enterprise system if they carried out his recent order against job discrimination on Federal work.
With ballots by the thousand to count, the battle for control of the Alleghany Corporation is hanging in the balance. It may be a week, two weeks or three before the results are tallied.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Government rejected fifteen identical bids today on more than $1,250,000 of electrical equipment sought by the Interior Department.
Though the weather was not conducive to good golf, the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association opened its season with interclub team matches yesterday.

Net income of the Ralston Purina Company, its United States and Canadian subsidiaries, amounted to $9,773,093 for the six months ended on March 31. This was equal to $1.49 a share and compared with $9,348,468 or $1.44 a share a year earlier.

In a few days Peter Ustinov should have the cameras turning on "Billy Budd" on location off the coast of Spain. Mr. Ustinov left town over the week-end for a brief vacation with his family in Switzerland before activating the Allied Artists version of Herman Melville's allegorical tale, which was successfully dramatized on Broadway in 1951.
ROME, May 2 -- Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip were given an enthusiastic reception in Naples this morning and in Rome this afternoon on their official state visit to Italy.

NEAR KOTA BALUD, British North Borneo, May 2 -- Land, sea and air forces of the Southeast Asian alliance made a mock assault landing in this jungle area yesterday. The operation was practice for what they might have to do in earnest should the Allies decide to intervene militarily against Communist advances.
The Living Theatre has made it.
Plans were announced yesterday for Armed Forces Week in the New York and New England area at a luncheon meeting of the New York Chapter of the Military Order of the World Wars.
ST. LOUIS, May 2 (UPI) Harvey Haddix pitched a six-hit shutout tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates posted a 6 -- 0 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- President Kennedy asked legislation today to increase compensation rates for veterans with service-connected disabilities by $58,230,426 a year.
MONTREAL, May 2 (AP) -- Doug Harvey of the Montreal Canadiens today was named the outstanding defense man in the National Hockey League for the sixth time.

THE American Ballet Theatre opened its second and final week at the Broadway Theatre last night with a program containing its final novelty, the season's first presentation of Herbert Ross' "Caprichos."
BANGKOK, Thailand, May 2 -- Thailand's Premier, Field Marshal Sarit Thanarat, summoned Anatoli N. Nikolayev, the Soviet Ambassador, to Government House today for a discussion on Laos.
Mayor Wagner formally welcomed the fifth annual United States World Trade Fair to the city last night, on the eve of the fair's opening at the Coliseum.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Stewart L. Udall was accused today of requesting an oil executive to solicit $100 contributions to a Jefferson-Jackson Day Democratic dinner from other oil and gas men. Mr. Udall, the Secretary of Interior, categorically denied the charge. He admitted, however, that he had told the friend, J.K. Evans, that he hoped that "he and some of his friends would be at the dinner."

The Bronx Women's Bar Association last night elected as its president Anna T. Withey, assistant corporation counsel in the city's Law Department. Mrs. Withey is the first Negro to be elected to the position.

Prizes for the best Hebrew short stories will be awarded by the Hebrew monthly Bitzaron. The first prize will be for $1,000, and the second and third prizes will be for $500 and $250 respectively. They were made available by Israel Steifel, a Pennsylvania State Senator and national chairman of the publication.

Net income of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway in April was $1,007,000, compared with $3,344,000 in the 1960 month. But in issuing the month's results yesterday, management reported that the long-awaited traffic upturn "has at least started."

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 2 -- A cease-fire in a critical battle zone in the Laotian civil war went into effect today after a meeting between officers representing the royal army and the pro-Communist Pathet Lao movement.

ATLANTA, May 2 (AP) -- Two men who have been active in efforts to abolish the House Un-American Activities Committee have begun one-year prison sentences for refusing to answer questions of the committee.
An industrial designer pluged to his death last night, from the roof of the twenty-story apartment building in which he lived. He was Scott Wilson, 58 years old, of 300 East Forty-sixth Street.

Bond issues totaling $20,000,000 of Nippon Telegraph Telephone Public Corporation, representing the first. Japanese corporate securities to be sold here in twenty-five years, will be offered to United States investors today. Meanwhile, Norway is offering $18,000,000 of external loan bonds to the public here.

Your April 29 editorial "Omne Ignotum * * *" concerning the recent rioting of Harvard students demanding Latin on their as yet unearned diplomas seems to me to strike just the right note for passing off an adolescent spring-term prank, as does President Pusey's comment, "What is pat in the Latin and chic in the Greek I always distinguish more easily in English."

AMERICANS visiting Europe generally discover that their eyes are bigger than their baggage allowance. However, if the airline officials were not surprised at Robert Gumport's willingness to pay $100 in excess luggage charges, they probably were puzzled to learn that the weight came from such items as English preserves, French nougats, Belgian canned asparagus, Swiss canned cheese fondue and twelve well-filled notebooks.
WITH Mother's Day soon to be celebrated, Martin's in Brooklyn has prepared itself for gift-buying children by amassing a variety of gift merchandise in a single spot -- the Penny Bank Shop.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- President Kennedy met today with his leading political and military advisers to consider developments on two "cold war" fronts -- Southeast Asia and the stalemated talks in Geneva on a nuclear test ban.
Dire findings in a ten-month study of the theatre's financial condition sent fifteen leading Broadway delegates to City Hall yesterday to plead with Mayor Wagner for immediate tax relief.

An alleged ring of phonograph-record counterfeiters was broken up last night when policemen posing as members of the gang arrested the suspects as they plotted their next move at a dinner meeting in the Plaza Hotel.
Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon told business leaders here last night that one United States tax incentive to foreign subsidiaries of domestic companies should be ended.
CINCINNATI, May 2 (UPI) -- Ken Hunt, with help in the ninth inning from Jim Brosnan, pitched the Cincinnati Reds to a 3 -- 2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.
A PROBLEM that went the rounds of New York's bridge clubs recently was to pick the best opening lead from the West hand in this deal.

Sales of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company in the first quarter of 1961 fell by 14.3 per cent while earnings declined by 9.5 per cent from the levels of the 1960 period, E.J. Thomas, chairman, reported yesterday.

A spokesman for Championship Sports, Inc., said yesterday that his outfit knew nothing about a report that Floyd Patterson probably would defend his heavyweight boxing title against Tom McNeeley in Boston next fall.

A Brooklyn judge requested yesterday that Peter J. Reidy, the city Buildings Commissioner bring departmental charges against twenty-seven inspectors. He acted after a grand jury had reported that it lacked sufficient evidence to indict them on criminal charges.

MOSCOW, May 2 (AP) -- The Soviet press agency Tass said today that Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba had told its Havana correspondent he hoped to go to Moscow to receive the Lenin Peace Prize that has been awarded to him.

PARIS, May 2 -- Militarily speaking, the choice we offer our NATO allies at this week's Oslo meeting is between a bigger bang for a buck and a bigger buck for a bang. Planning for the next five years depends on how this is resolved.

LONDON, May 2 -- Viscount Hailsham, Lord President of the Council, lifted his glass tonight in a toast to "the new Ambassador of the United States, our ally, and our friend, and above all our dear companion in the most desperate and exciting adventure in human history."

A syndicate of investors headed by Manville H. and Junius P. Abramson of Abramson Brothers, lawyers and realty owners, has taken title to 1410 Broadway, a thirty-four-story store and office building at the southeast corner of Thirty-ninth Street.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 2 -- The United States' first man-in-space flight was postponed today because of bad weather. Another launching attempt probably will not be made before Friday at the earliest.

WHEN the emperor Claudius went back to Rome after the conquest of Britain in 43 A.D. he left behind him a capable military governor named Aulus Plautius, who began at once on a road-building program. One of his major roads ran due north from London and eventually was extended to Edinburgh, a distance of some 400 miles.
Mayor Wagner swore in a new Councilman yesterday -- Travis E. Devlin, 51 years old, a Brooklyn lawyer.
WARSAW, Ky., May. 2 (UPI) -- Millions of dollars worth of gold bars were stacked briefly beside U.S. Route 42 yesterday after a Brink's, Inc., semitrailer truck overturned on a curve.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Democrats on the Joint Economic Committee of Congress gave only qualified endorsement today to the Kennedy Administration's policies and programs for spurring the nation's economy.
LONDON, May 2 -- The wildcat strike at the London docks spread today as the Labor Ministry and Trade Union officials sought a formula to end the walkout which is now in its seventh day.
CHICAGO, May 2 (UPI) Don Cardwell held the San Francisco Giants to five hits today and Bill Williams, a rookie, belted a grand slam homer as the Chicago Cubs posted a 9-4 victory.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) -- President Kennedy established today a White House Committee on Small Business to develop new policies and programs on behalf of small concerns.

In the final year of his second term, confronted as he is by the immediate necessity to decide whether he will seek re-election, Mayor Wagner would hardly send an annual message to the City Council that minimized his administration's progress toward a better city. Yesterday he reported the city's economy to be in encouraging condition, its finances "sound."

Domestic sugar futures rose sharply in heavy trading yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Heavy and aggressive trade buying and short covering raised quotations 6 to 7 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 42,550 tons.
PROVIDENCE, May 2 -- In lieu of spring practice, the Ivy League football coaches are staging a conversational scrimmage here. It may end in an eight-way scoreless tie.

NO man is a prophet in his own country, particularly if he is an Italian ready-to-wear manufacturer. During the past decade, an increasing number of American women have come to look for a made-in-Italy label in the fashions they buy from specialty shops and department stores here.
The clerical workers', strike against the French Line enters its sixth day today with no prospects of an immediate settlement.
WASHINGTON, May. 2 (AP) -- Union leaders from Cape Canaveral deplored today the wave of strikes they said had occurred in defiance of their pleas at the big missile and space-fight base.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) -- Jim Bunning enabled the Detroit Tigers to retain their one-game lead in the American League tonight when he beat the Washington Senators, 6 -- 3, and posted his first victory of the season.
HURLEY, Wis., May 2 (AP) -- An Air Force B-47 crashed early today in Wisconsin's North Wooods. It was the second such crash in the area. Two men survived today; four died in the crash Feb. 24.

Irving Maidman, realty investor and builder, has bought the two and four-story connected buildings at 226-28 Sevent Avenue, near the northwest corner of Twenty-fourth Street. The First National City Bank, the seller, formerly occupied the buildings for a branch office.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) lent $80,000,000 yesterday to the Japanese National Railways to speed transportation in Japan's most industrialized area.
WARSAW, May 2 -- Poland launched into a traumatic two weeks today. The optimists' bloomed as the tulips do now. The pessimists' gloom hung like the black clouds over Warsaw Stadium this afternoon.
LONDON, May 3 -- Antoinette Avril Gardiner, the 20-year-old British girl who is to marry King Hussein of Jordan, is remembered here as a well-mannered girl with a talent for dancing.

While President de Gaulle mops up the last remnants of the military revolt that tried to torpedo peace in Algeria, President Kennedy receives today with all due honors an African statesman who has played a major role in the Algerian drama. He is President Bourguiba of Tunisia, who comes here to discuss the interests of North Africa as well as the interests of his own country.

The bewildering kaleidoscope of events in the Congo has now produced a new pattern that looks like an alliance between the United Nations and President Kasavubu for the unification of that strife-torn land in a federal state.

WORCESTER, England May 2 (Reuters) -- Rain halted play in the final hours of a cricket match between Australia and Worcestershire County today, washing out what was shaping up as a tight finish to the three-day match.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy announced today an antitrust indictment against Avdel, Inc., of Burbank, Calif., the nation's principal producer of a "quick-release" pin widely used in defense items, including missile.

Defense and prosecution rested yesterday in the trial of Peter C. Tripp, who is accused of receiving more than $30,000 from record companies in return for playing their tunes on his hits-of-the-week program on WMGM during 1958 and 1959.

Greater New York Fund banners flying from buildings in all main thoroughfares are New York City's symbols of hope to the sick, the old, the homeless, the troubled and the handicapped. Under the campaign leadership of George A. Murphy, chairman of the Irving Trust Company, the fund once again has undertaken to meet the great need faced by 425 of the city's medical, health and welfare agencies.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The number of Americans out of work declined by 533,000 between mid-March and mid-April, but the decline was only "seasonal," the Labor Department reported today.

Five charges out of sixty-five brought by the Police Department against nine owners and managers of Greenwich Village coffeehouses were disposed of yesterday in Upper Manhattan Arrest Court. They involved a black French poodle, mixing cement on the road and a late-hours waitress.
NEW DELHI, India, May 2 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today he thought there would be a cease-fire in Laos within a few days.

Competition for national prestige took one of its more peaceful forms yesterday as more than sixty nations vied in an unofficial race to complete exhibits for the fifth United States World Trade Fair. The fair opens today at the New York Coliseum and will continue through May 13.

ATLANTA, May 2 (AP) -- School officials were surprised by the number of Negro pupils who sought applications to transfer to white Atlanta public schools yesterday, the first day they were eligible to do so in this Deep South state.

The Broadway Theatre has been hooked for "Kean," due there Nov. 2. Alfred Drake will be starred in the George Forrest-Robert Wright-Peter Stone musical, the source of which is Jean-Paul Sartre's drama. The central character is the British tragedian, Edmund Kean, a role that will be interpreted by Mr. Drake.
Record sales of $114,300,000 were reported yesterday by the Interstate Department Stores for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31. This was 27 per cent above the volume in the previous fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- President Kennedy named Cyril E. King, an aide to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, as Government Secretary of the Virgin Islands today.

It is a sad and significant fact that Germany should concern itself solicitously with the well-being of former Nazi big-wigs when there are still many people who suffered from the Nazis and who still have not been given a modicum of restitution.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Touring version of "The Ev and Charlie Show" wowed the National Press Club today with a performance blending jokes, melodic oratory and patriotic declarations.
CINCINNATI, May 3 (AP) -- Jim Maloney, in his first start of the season, led the Cincinnati Reds to a 9-3 triumph over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.
MADISON, N.J., May 3 -- Seven college students have decided to under-take a do-it-yourself, 27,000-mile goodwill mission to Central and South America.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 3 -- The story of the Warsaw ghetto uprising stirred a thronged courtroom today at the trial of Adolf Eichmann.
We cannot quarrel with the ambitions of Indiana to have a deep-water port and to expand industrially with the growing commerce on the Great Lakes induced by the St. Lawrence Seaway.

William Michelman, realty operator, has purchased two six-story apartment buildings at 440-44 East 146th Street, the Bronx, through Robert P. Sheldon, Inc., broker. The houses occupy a plot 85 by 100 feet and contain fifty-nine apartments.

Reports that several Hawaiian sugar plantations had been closed because of strikes buoyed domestic sugar prices yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Only the distant March position, which was inactive, fell.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- Delegates of the Chamber of Commerce attacked major portions of President Kennedy's domestic program today. They also booed Senator Joseph S. Clark, Democrat of Pennsylvania, who advised them to "grow up."

CANNES, France, May 3 -- The last-minute arrival tonight of a chartered plane from Paris carrying sixty international personalities in the fields of motion pictures and other arts, diplomacy and politics, added appropriate glitter to the gala opening of the fourteenth Cannes Film Festival this evening.
CHICAGO, May 3 (AP) The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
President Kennedy has asked for more self-censorship and restraint on the part of the press for security reasons.

LISBON, Portugal, May 3 (Reuters) -- A second Cabinet shake-up, promised by Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar in the face of a continuing revolt in the West African territory of Angola, was announced officially today.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- President Kennedy received an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws today from George Washington University. In a brief talk he emphasized the need for intimate relations between political leaders and institutions of higher learning.
PHILADELPHIA, May 3 -- A leader of the American Council for Judaism charged tonight that the citizenship status of Moroccan Jews was being harmed by Zionist campaigns for mass immigration to Israel.
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the largest of the life insurance companies, with assets of $17,941,244,002, does not often make advertising news.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) The Air Force said today it had been warned that Texas Radar Tower 4 was in bad condition three days before the structure collapsed in a storm off the New Jersey coast last Jan. 15, killing all twenty-eight occupants.
BETHPAGE, L.I., May 3 -- The St. John's University golf team captured the Long Island intercollegiate golf crown over the black course at Bethpage State Park today with a total of 333.

CLEVELAND, May 3 (UPI) -- Bob Hale pinch-hit a single in the ninth inning to score Johnny Romano from second base and the Cleveland Indians gained a 4-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight. The Tribe stretched its winning streak to three games.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 3 -- A program of Latin-American chamber music under the direction of John Celentano tonight continued the annual festival of American Music at Kilbourn Hall of the Eastman School of Music.

The Secretary of the Interior exercises important functions affecting the oil and gas industry of this country and the economic fortunes of different groups in that industry. Any suspicion that he is, or might be, subjecting persons in the industry to personal or political pressure, or placing himself under any obligation to them, strikes directly at the heart of the great public trust to which he is committed.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 3 -- A diet rich in carbohydrates (sugars and starches) and low in fats tends to raise the level of fats in the blood, according to a report made at a scientific meeting that ended here today.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., May 3 -- Friday is now the scheduled day for the attempt to send Navy Comdr. Alan B. Shepard Jr. on the first American space flight.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) -- Dave Sisler turned in a brilliant relief effort against his former Detroit Tiger teammates tonight to help the Washington Senators register a 5-4 victory.

There is no major reading problem among school children of the Soviet Union, according to a group of Soviet educators on a visit here. The reason is quite simple, they said: If Ivan can't read, he is left back until he can.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 -- The leadership of the nation's school boards faced a fundamental split today. The split is between advocates of involvement in national issues and defenders of the traditional hands-off stand on such questions as Federal aid to education and national standards.

TORONTO, May 3 (Canadian Press) -- Ellis Burton and Tim Thompson hit home runs with the bases filled in the eighth inning today to help the Toronto Maple Leafs rout the Jersey City Jerseys, 15 -- 3, in their International League home opener.
HAVANA, May 3 -- Capt. Manuel Artime, a leader of the ill-fated force landed on that the south coast of Cuba April 17, was captured by Government troops yesterday.

Contradictory testimony about the relations between Deputy City License Commissioner Herbert A. Koehler and William P. Buckner, convicted swindler, was given yesterday to the State Investigation Commission.
CHICAGO, May 3 (AP) -- Moderate to heavy selling caused a fairly general decline in the grain futures market today. Near soybeans took the hardest blow.

BOSTON, May 3 -- The Massachusetts Senate defeated legislation today that would have permitted the state to exercise its option to buy the right-of-way of the Old Colony Division of the New Haven Railroad.

PHOENIX, Ariz., May 3 (AP) -- Morris K. Udall, the winner in one of Arizona's closest Congressional elections, said today that a recent unpopular announcement by his older brother, Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall, had almost cost him the victory.
Mikhail Tal of Latvia, the world chess champion, was outplayed by Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia in the eighteenth game of their world title match at the Variety Theatre in Moscow yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- President Kennedy is trying to learn how a decorated combat veteran of World War II was sent to prison on what Congress has held to be false testimony.

LONDON, May 3 -- British and French officials completed today another phase of their exploration of the problems involved in achieving an agreement between the European Economic Community and Britain and the other members of the European Free Trade Association.
It would be idle to deny that President Kennedy warmed the cockles of every working newspaper man's heart with one passage of his recent speech to the nation's publishers.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The White House confirmed today that Dr. James R. Killian Jr. would head the special Presidential board that monitors United States intelligence activities.

Textile industry leaders indicated yesterday that they were highly encouraged by President Kennedy's program for meeting international competion. There were undertones of disappointment, however, over Mr. Kennedy's failure to impose quotas immediately on textile imports.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 3 -- President Arturo Frondizi of Argentina, after the second in a round of conferences with leaders of neighboring countries, maintains that he is not proposing the formation of any bloc or third force in today's divided world.

The fifth graders of Public School 34 took direct action yesterday against potential litterers. They marched out of their school at East Eleventh Street and Avenue D and into Tompkins Square Park, singing to the park-bench sitters: "Let's keep it clean here, enjoy its beauty.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 3 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, remarked today that, after three months as the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, he sometimes yearned for "the simple brutalities of bipartisan politics."

CLEVELAND, May 3 (AP) -- The rubber industry's biggest company, Goodyear Tire and Rubber, agreed today with the United Rubber Workers on a two-year contract providing wage increases of 14 1/2 cents hourly for tire plant workers and 7 1/2 cents for nontire plant employes.
