The board of directors of the Magnavox Company proposed a three-for-one split of the capital stock yesterday. It also proposed an increase in the authorized stock to 10,000,000 shares from 3,500,000. Both actions are subject to the approval of stockholders at a special meeting to be held in July.
A multitude of viruses, real and imagined, haunt modern cancer research like tiny malignant ghosts.
Win or lose, Eddie Arcaro is booed by Aqueduct fans.
THERE is a maxim in German that says "What the peasant doesn't know, he doesn't eat." In other words, it must have been a fairly sophisticated man who swallowed the first oyster.
LONDON, May 3 -- Britain has urged the Soviet Union to follow the rebel order for a cease-fire in Laos with immediate instructions to the International Control Commission to verify the armistice.
The bond market registered yesterday its best show of strength in many weeks.

LOS ANGELES, May 3 (AP) -- Earl Averill's two-run homer in the ninth capped a rally as the Los Angeles Angels beat the Orioles, 7 -- 6, tonight. Jim Gentile hit two home runs and drove in five runs for Baltimore.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 3 -- Ron Conti doubled in the ninth inning to score John Lepik from first and give the New York University baseball team an 8-7 victory over Hofstra today in a Metropolitan Conference game.

MIAMI, Fla., May 3 -- A picturesque sailing ship used as a seagoing school for teen-agers sank in the Gulf of Mexico in a windstorm, the Coast Guard reported today. Six of the nineteen persons aboard were lost.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- President Kennedy's mininum wage bill received final Congressional approval today. It assures raises for 2,500,000 workers.
WESTPORT, Conn., May 3 -- Perry Githens of 4 Maplegrove Avenue, a public relations man and editor of Popular Science Magazine from 1945 to 1950, was found dead this afternoon in a car at his home.
Light voting and general acceptance of higher school budgets appeared to be the pattern in the annual suburban school district elections completed last night and early today.
April was colder, wetter and less sunny than usual and it looks as though May will be the same.

LOUISVILLE, May 3 -- Contrary to the general expectation, Crozier's record-breaking performance in the Derby Trial yesterday didn't appreciably reduce the field for the Kentucky Derby. Only four horses -- more or less long shots -- were withdrawn today.
A community safety program designed to reduce child traffic casualties was started in Harlem yesterday by Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., May 3 (AP) -- Doug Moe, a basketball star, was suspended indefinitely from the University of North Carolina today for failing to report bribe offers. Indefinite suspension is less severe than expulsion.

Sales and earnings of Marshall Field Co., Chicago department store, fell slightly in the quarter ended April 30 from the 1960 level, James L. Palmer, president, told the annual meeting in Chicago yesterday. A year ago the chain cleared $972,698, or 47 cents a common share, on sales of $50,146,670.
James Thrasher, a 52-year-old public relations man and former newspaper man, was found dead last night in his apartment at 82 West Twelfth Street.
A TEEN-AGE artist who believes that a happy home is not always a place of exuberant joy has walked off with first prize in an art contest sponsored by the Jewish Family Service.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 3 -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province, after a week of virtual captivity, was reported tonight to have asked to be readmitted to the conference of Congolese leaders in Coquilhatville.
Sanity and sobriety are what we have come to expect from The New York Times. We are again indebted to you for your calm and responsible editorial of April 27 on the Cuban situation.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) -- The Department of State is getting in touch with the main textile importing and exporting nations today to arrange a conference on President Kennedy's plan for controls on the textile trade.

MILWAUKEE, May 3 (AP) -Robert S. Stevenson, president of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, said today that despite the concern's involvement in recent antitrust cases the company "did not gouge our costumers.

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 3 -- Hugo Soto Socorro, a member of Congress, said today that extremists were preparing to attack Teodoro Moscoso, the new United States Ambassador, on his arrival here. Mr. Moscoso, the first Puerto Rican to be named a United States Ambassador, is scheduled to arrive this week.

Now that the machinery has been put in motion to formulate an International Cocoa Agreement as a method of bolstering prices, an accord among the world's cocoa producers undoubtedly will result, according to Julian Hemphill, director of cocoa-bean buying for the Hershey Chocolate Corporation.
Two lion whelps, born last week to be monarchs of the sawdust clearing in the asphalt jungle, made their first public appearance yesterday at Madison Square Garden.
The H.L. Green Company, a variety store chain that had 366 units in operation at the end of last January, is disposing of 219 of the units.

A preview next Monday of the Luciano Guarnieri exhibition of paintings at the Galerie Internationale, 1095 Madison Avenue, will raise funds for the Boys Towns of Italy. The show will continue through June 3.

NEW DELHI, India, May 3 -- The Kennedy Administration was reliably reported today to be prepared to lend India $1,000,000,000 in the next two years to help meet the foreign exchange requirements of India's third Five-Year Plan.
Cardinal Spellman, who is 72 years old today, heard himself described as "a great soldier and a great American" at a party yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- Dr. Warren Weaver, vice president of the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, warned here tonight that the demands of national service were threatening to distort the central function of American universities and upset their "internal balance."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 3 (AP) -- Dr. E. Vincent Askey of Los Angeles, president of the American Medical Association, delivered a stinging attack on Abraham A. Ribicoff tonight at the 150 the annual meeting of the Rhode Island Medical Society.

NEW DELHI, India, May 3 -- The International Control Commission for Laos will be ready to leave New Delhi on twenty-four hours' notice to police a cease-fire there, its chairman, Samarendranath Sen of India said today.
The Mary Richter League of the National Children's Cardiac Hospital will give its twenty-first annual luncheon and fashion show Saturday in the St. Regis Roof.
RABAT, Morocco, May 3 -- King Hassan has delegated his powers as Premier to the director of the royal Cabinet, Ahmed Reda Guedira, it was announced today.

While the Cuban question has not yet developed into a national calamity, every well-informed person is gripped by the fear that hasty, ill-advised unilateral action by the Administration must lead us promptly to just such a disaster.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy announced today the hanging of two Paul Cezanne paintings in the Green Room of the White House.
Central Park's Wollman Skating Rink will be the temporary home this year for the New York Shakespeare Festival until a $400,000 ampitheatre is completed.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The case for a first round of tax reform was put to the House Ways and Means Committee today by Douglas Dillon, the Secretary of the Treasury.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Vice President Johnson is expected to leave next week for the Far East on a diplomatic and fact-finding mission.
The port will receive two more sight-seeing craft in the next two year, Francis J. Barry, president of Circle Line Sightseeing Yachts, Inc., said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- Senators were told today that the Air Force had taken steps to prevent another tragedy like the one in which an accidentally discharged Sidewinder missile destroyed a B-52 bomber April 7.
The Police Department reassigned 234 commanders yesterday in its biggest reshuffle in years. The shifts followed the promotion of 105 high-ranking officers.
A plan for establishing the nation's most comprehensive center for the study of urban problems has been submitted to Mayor Wagner by officials of the City University.
For the first time since the passage of the Landrum-Griffin Act in the fall of 1959, the Federal Government has initiated court action under it against an employer.
KEY WEST, Fla., May 3 (AP) -- Capt. Manuel Artime was captured after he wandered for two weeks in the mosquito-infested swampland of Zapata peninsula, the Havana radio announced today.
The French Line slipped a 10,000-ton freighter into the harbor yesterday and managed to unload 101 French compact cars, avoiding picket lines at the company's terminals elsewhere in the harbor.

Those who want to be heard at public hearings before Mayor Wagner's Charter Revision Commission should submit their views in writing of the commission in advance of the hearings, John T. Cahill, chairman of the commission, suggested yesterday.
"Mother Goose in Outer Space" will be the theme for this year's Mother Goose Ball, to be held on May 13 at the 102d Regiment Armory, Fort Washington Avenue between 168th and 169th Streets.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 3 -- The Minnesota Twins concentrated on stopping Mickey Mantle today. They partly succeeded in this noble venture, but to the chagrin of a crowd of 18,158 it still gained them nothing.

ST. LOUIS, May 3 (AP) -- Bob Gibson -- with an assist from Lindy McDaniel -- pitched the St. Louis Cardinals to a 3-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight. The defeat dropped the Pirates from first to second place in the National League race.
THIS deal, an unusual example of making every small card count, occurred in a match of the College Clubs Bridge League of New York.

The William F. Mayer Company, importer and distributor of household furnishings with a plant at 45 West Twenty-fifth Street, has bought the one-story industrial building at 448-52 Nepperhan Avenue, Yonkers. The building, which contains 50,000 square feet of space, was originally a unit in the sprawling plant of the Alexander Smith Carpet Company, which moved to the South.

LOUISVILLE, May 3 -- In the pale, un-warmed glow of an early morning sun, Crozier stood in front of his barn today and contentedly munched on the grass. Watching him with just as much contentment were Fred Hooper, the big man who owns him, and Chuck Parke, the little guy who trains him.

RABAT, Morocco, May 3 -- The left-wing Moroccan Federation of Labor called a general strike today for at least forty- eight hours at four United States military bases in Morocco after negotiations for a wage increase had collapsed.

THE young man on the platform was a striking figure, with a generous thatch of slightly wavy hair sur-mounting a high forehead. His features were even, the nose long and thin, and he was, on the whole, smooth-faced.
President Kennedy's program for assistance to the textile industry implies that he is seriously thinking of imposing quotas on textile imports into this country.
WASHINGTON, May 3 --Two House committees disputed Administration judgments today by authorizing more money than had been requested for defense preparations and space planning.
BAY CITY, Mich., May 3 (AP) -- A visiting Arab official canceled all luncheon and dinner meetings on his schedule in Bay City yesterday after what he characterized as two "insults."
Negroes in New York State are escaping from their urban neighborhoods in increasing numbers, the State Commission Against Discrimination reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) -- President Kennedy asked labor leaders today to end union restrictions that discriminated against Negroes.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., May 3 -- The Air Force launched a ninety-seven-foot Titan I missile today from a hole 146 feet deep. It was the first launching of its kind in the United States.
MILWAUKEE, May 3 (UPI) -- Warren Spahn of the Milwaukee Braves, making his first start since throwing a no-hitter last Friday night, pitched a two-hitter tonight and beat Los Angeles, 4 -- 1.
A black French poodle that needed walking led to the arrest yesterday of its master, a textile salesman, who ultimately was pictured as the city's new scofflaw "king."

Mergers are very much in the news these days, and especially in Washington. Yesterday, Under Secretary of Commerce Edward Gudeman said legislation requiring companies to give the Government a two-month notice of proposed mergers would be good for business.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- Missile contractors testified today that strikes and other labor troubles had slowed the man-in-space program, along with other missile projects.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- In approximately one-half the cases, J.K. Evans, the Washington oil man, never made good on his promise to recall his letter soliciting funds from fifty-six fellow oil and gas men for the Democratic party.
East New York Vocational of Brooklyn won the Public Schools Athletic League track and field team novice championship wind-swept Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.

The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, financing arm of the General Motors Corporation, reported yesterday a net income for the first quarter of $15,741,671, compared with $12,187,924 for the first three months of 1960.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 -- The last of sixty-four defendants on trial for the City Hall riots last May were found not guilty today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 3 -- Premier Fidel Castro's dedication of Cuba as a "Socialist republic" and one without elections has swung Brazilian opinion strongly in favor of holding an American foreign ministers' conference to consider the Cuban problem.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 3 -- Five men allegedly involved in a phonograph-record counter-feiting ring were arraigned in county court here today on charges of grand larceny, conspiracy and violation of trademark laws.
Gardner Cowles, a director of United Air Lines, Inc., eliminated his holdings in the airline system by selling 10,282 common shares last February.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The House approved and sent to the Senate today Administration-sponsored legislation to expand Federal authorities and expenditures to combat water pollution.

Warm weather is late this year; but through the generous donations of private businesses and individuals thousands of tulips, azaleas and flowering trees are brightening the arrival of a tardy season. Among the donors, as in other years, Mrs. Albert D. Lasker is one of the most prominent.
At least two Broadway producers are going to do something about the high cost of theatre tickets.
Brooklyn Hospital, the borough's oldest voluntary institution, is considering an affiliation with the city's neighboring Cumberland Hospital.
Donald P. Horan finished poking into the oil-spotted boilers in the basement of the Belvedere Hotel at 319 West Forty-Eighth Street, off Eighth Avenue.

Three days after the attack on Pearl Harbor, the Japanese sank the Repulse and the Prince of Wales, the backbone of the British fleet in the Pacific. The story of the sinking of those ships is told by Bernard Ash in "Someone Had Blundered."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 3 -- A new chapter in American educational philanthropy in the Middle East began here today with the inauguration of Thomas C. Schuller as president of International College.
IF the motto, "Je m'en fiche," tattooed on the hand of the countess, could be translated freely into "Who cares?," it would sum up admirably one's reaction to "The Tattooed Countess."
LONDON, May 3 -- A former British vice consul was sentenced today to forty-two years in prison after he had pleaded guilty to charges of espionage for the Soviet Union.
ATLANTA, May 3 -- This city's movie censorship law was held unconstitutional today by Judge Luther Alverson in Fulton County Superior Court.

Stocks continued to march, along the upward road yesterday and with none of the hesitancy that marked several recent sessions. Prices were up sharply on the New York Stock Exchange in accelerated trading.

Sixteen former residents of a Greenwich Village apartment building charged in State Supreme Court yesterday that they had been evicted to make way for part of a housing development that never materialized.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 3 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has decided to swallow a little pride to increase its profits. It has joined other major studios in offering bargain rates to induce independent producers to make pictures at its studio.
The fifth United States World Trade Fair opened yesterday at the New York Coliseum with more than sixty nations making a hard-selling bid for trade and tourist business.
Gil McDougald, a key performer in eight New York Yankee pennant successes, yesterday signed to scout New Jersey for the new local entry in the National League, the Metropolitan Baseball Club, Inc.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 3 -- Full-time administration of a "Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge" will be started by the Department of the Interior when Federally owned land in the area near here is increased to 2,000 acres "in a consolidated and manageable unit."
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said tonight that foreign aid had "more solemn purposes" than merely meeting the threat of communism.

Sir Laurence Olivier will star in a ninety-minute television dramatization of Graham Greene's novel, "The Power and the Glory." The play, which is proposed for telecast next season, will be taped this month.
Two plans to desegregate the New Rochelle public school system were submitted yesterday to Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- President Kennedy has decided that the Peace Corps will not be merged with the nation's other foreign aid programs.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The retiring president of General Electric Company told Senate investigators today that he had kept silent on price-fixing collusion by associates on the way up the corporate ladder because it was not his immediate responsibility and because he was no "gossip."
The Port of New York Authority borrowed $35,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance capital improvements at La Guardia Field and New York International Airport.
SEOUL, Korea, May 3 (Reuters) -- Premier John M. Chang announced today a reshuffle of South Korea's Cabinet to bring about "stepped-up efficiency" in the Administration.

Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co. and associates are offering to the public today $15,000,000 of 4 7/8 per cent twenty-five-Year refunding mortgage bonds of the Washington Gas Light Company. The bonds are priced at 100.359 to yield 4.85 per cent.
PARIS, May 3 -- The diplomatic talents of James M. Gavin, the United States Ambassador, were put to a test today at a luncheon given in his honor by the Anglo-American Press Association of Paris.

The "wind of change" that is transforming the former British and French colonial empires into an association of independent nations is now also shaking to its foundation the last of the great Western colonial empires -- the Portuguese. It has produced terrorism, massacres and open rebellion in Angola, and it has brought governmental and military shake-ups and a military alert to Portugal itself to be able to cope with any uprising at home.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) -- The Airline Pilots Association said today that two psychiatrists who treated an airline captain before his plane crashed disagreed with the Civil Aeronautics Board's report that he was "unfit to fly."

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., is planning to expand its video tape facilities through the purchase of NTA Telestudios, Ltd., a subsidiary of National Telefilm Associates, Inc., it was learned yesterday. Terms of the transaction could not be ascertained, but a spokesman for M.G.M. said they would be announced when the deal was completed.
The United States Lines was deluged yesterday with awards for outstanding performance in safety compliance on its ships.

YONKERS, May 3 -- International pacing takes over the spotlight from the trotters tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway, where the first of a series of three rich races, the $50,000 International Pace, will be staged before some 30,000 harness racing enthusiasts.
CHICAGO, May 3 (AP) -- A weak Chicago defense and Orlando Cepeda's two-run homer in the sixth inning helped the San Francisco Giants gain an 8-4 victory over the Cubs today.

The election of seven new directors of the Beter Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York, Inc., was announced yesterday. The agency, which serves New York City and parts of Westchester County and northern New Jersey, seeks to promote business integrity.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The United States offer has two objectives -- to cover India's projected deficit in international payments and to schedule orders firmly now for future delivery.

A seasonal decline of 2,908,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 219,317,000 barrels, compared with 222,225,000 a week earlier and 219,524,000 a year ago.
The automobile industry had some good news to announce yesterday. Two car manufacturers reported improved sales and another producer did some rehiring.

DAKAR, Senegal, May 3 (AP) -- Quiet negotiations are in progress between Senegal and the British colony of Gambia for establishment of a federation or some other form of association after Gambia has gained independence.
Stuart Scheftel, one-time political associate of the late Rudolph Halley, notified Liberal party leaders yesterday that he intended to enter the Liberal primary as a candidate for Mayor.
Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., the largest private bus operator in the country, asked the city yesterday to raise the line's basic fare from 15 to 20 cents.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 3, -- A six-run sixth inning helped Yale gain a 13-3 victory over Columbia in an Eastern Inter-collegiate League baseball game today.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art and the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes signed an agreement yesterday.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 3 -- Nation-wide raids were made today by the South African police in an effort to forestall anti-Government demonstrations.

With disarming modesty and warmth, Prof. Arnold Toynbee submitted to a writer's nightmare yesterday. He sipped sherry at a cocktail reception where the guests included a dozen writers and historians who have publicly criticized his work, sometimes with goodwill, sometimes with outraged scorn.
Pressure will be kept on the city's Board of Education to correct fire hazards in schools despite disruptions and hardships, Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. said yesterday.

PARIS, May 3 -- The Government announced today that peace negotiations with the Algerian Moslem rebels would begin "soon" and that President de Gaulle would retain full emergency powers until a settlement was in sight.

Electric power production totaled 14,254,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended last Saturday, compared with 14,311,000,000 the week before and 13,656,000,000 a year ago, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

A COLLECTION of Israeli ready-to-wear fashions, representing the work of fifteen prominent manufacturers, is being show this week as part of the United States World Trade Fair at the New York Coliseum.

ABOARD U.S.S. PRAIRIE, off British North Borneo, May 3 -- Allied commanders on the scene believe that the current military exercise of the Southeast Asian Alliance in North Borneo has increased the non-Communist world's capacity to counter any further Communist expansion in this area.

TRENTON, May 3 -- A Democratic party pledge against the imposition of sales, income or other broad-based taxes is expected to be eliminated from the state platform this year for the first time since 1952.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- David M. Satz Jr. of West Orange has been recommended for appointment as United States Attorney for New Jersey. He is now a deputy attorney general for New Jersey. Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy recommended Mr. Satz to President Kennedy.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 1 point up to 10 down yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
The two choral works presented last night by Paul Boepple and the Dessoff Choirs in Carnegie Hall had little in common except rarity of performance.

Consolidated net income of the Anaconda Company for the first quarter was estimated at $11,700,000 or $1.09 a share, Clyde E. Weed, chairman of the nation's second largest copper producer, reported yesterday. In the first three months last year the company cleared $12,950,000 or $1.21 a share.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia was welcomed to the United States today by President Kennedy and thousands of Washingtonians who lined his flag-bedecked parade route.
GENEVA, May 3 -- East and West exchanged recriminations today over the stalemate reached after 300 sessions of their conference on a treaty to end nuclear weapons testing.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- President Kennedy today scheduled a conference next Tuesday morning with leading editors, publishers and press association representatives. He will discuss his proposal for a voluntary curb on "cold war" news that would be helpful to enemies of the United States.
LONDON, May 3 -- Small gains predominated among blue-chip equities of the stock market here today.
The Park Department's $16,000,000 program for acquiring ten new parks and major park additions in four boroughs was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 3 -- Pro-Communist Laotian rebels proclaimed a cease-fire effective at 8 A.M. today. A later attack by the rebels on a key town in the narrow southern waist of Laos failed to dim hopes here that all fighting would soon stop.
Raw materials for a winning soccer team arrived from Britain yesterday aboard a KLM Royal Dutch airliner.
HARTFORD, May 3 (AP) -- The State police today arrested six executives of New York chemical companies in the sale of explosive soot-remover chemicals in Connecticut.

CHICAGO, May 4 (UPI) -Sam Jones held the Chicago Cubs to two hits in the last eight innings today as the San Francisco Giants scored a 9-3 triumph. The Giants rallied with five runs in the sixth inning.
Soccer standouts of today and tomorrow verbally kicked their favorite topic around the Playbill Restaurant in the Hotel Manhattan yesterday during an International Soccer League luncheon.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- A week-to-week increase was reported today in freight loadings by both the rail and truck industries.

CINCINNATI, May 4 (UPI) -- Joey Jay yielded only a first-inning single to Johnny Callison tonight, pitching a one-hitter to give the Cincinnati Reds a 4-0 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies. The triumph was the fifth straight for the Reds.
BRISTOL, England, Friday, May 5 -- The voters of Southeast Bristol have chosen the second Viscount Stansgate to represent them in the House of Commons though he may not be able to do so.

The Affiliated Holding Corporation has sold two six-story apartment houses on a plot 50 by 75 feet at 7 and 9 Eldridge Street. The buyer was an investing client of the Harris Management Corporation, the broker in the deal.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 4 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion has come under strong attack from many quarters in Israel for having by-passed his Cabinet and the World Zionist Organization to define relations between Israel and the Jews of other countries.

An issue of $4,800,000 of equipment trust certificates of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad was awarded yesterday to Salomon Brothers Hutzler and associates on a bid of 99.667 for obligations with a 4 1/8 per cent dividend rate.

" THE MIKADO," probably the most popular and celebrated of the Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, which makes delicious fun of Japanese court life and of some oriental mores that have an occidental ring to them, was presented last night at the Greenwich Mews Theatre on West Thirteenth Street.
City school officials have ordered checks of several new schools as the result of suspicions of possible fraud in the construction of a high school.
THERE are few things left in this troubled age that are as carefree as the cookout. With a backdrop of clear blue sky and a spotlight of glowing coals, the stage seems set for light-hearted dining.

The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency said last night that the agency was planning to impose a speed limit on high-speed airplanes approaching congested terminal areas.

MILWAUKEE, May 4 (UPI) -- Joe Adcock hit the eighth grand-slam home run of his career today in the tenth inning, and the Milwaukee Braves scored a 10 -- 6 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) -- The head of a Senate investigating panel said today Texas Tower Radar Platform 4 should have been abandoned for repairs before it collapsed into stormy seas, killing twenty-eight men.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 4 -- Walter Charles Williams is a 41-year-old, hulking, crew-cut aeronautical engineer who, for several critical hours tomorrow, will perhaps be one of the most important men in the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The House of Representatives approved by voice vote this evening an Administration bill to authorize $11,000,000,000 to complete the 41,000-mile interstate highway system in 1972.
ALLAIRE, N.J., May 4 -- Wesley Ellis, head pro at Mountain Ridge, set a course record for the Spring Meadow Country Club with a five-under-par 32, 32 -- 64 today in a P.G.A. pro-lady tournament.
PENSACOLA, Fla., May 4 -- Reports relayed through the Pentagon and the Naval Air Station here said that the trip upward went as planned, but the two balloonists ran into trouble on the descent.

The Port of Seattle, Wash., sold $7,500,000 of harbor bonds secured by general taxation to a syndicate headed by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and Kuhn, Loeb Co. yesterday, at an interest cost of 2.634747 per cent.

The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) cleared $43,820,000, or $1.23 a share, in the first quarter of this year, John E. Swearingen, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday in Whiting, Ind.
Cotton futures were steady to 20 points off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, except the distant May contract which rose a point. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

Bill Linck, president of the Long Island Arena, which holds a franchise in the Eastern Hockey League, denied yesterday that his Commack group planned to drop the Rovers. He said the team would be kept but with a different name.
ALGIERS, May 4 -- Algiers was sealed up last night by 8,000 policemen and conscript soldiers. They blocked all approaches to the city during the curfew hours, 9 P.M. until 5 A.M.

A warning that a bill now before the Senate would stifle the research incentive of the pharmaceuticals industry and harm the American consumer was sounded yesterday at the annual member luncheon of the Brand Names Foundation at the Commodore Hotel.
The Kips Bay Boys Club will benefit from the spring edition of Operation Boutique, a sale of donated articles, to be held Monday in the club's auditorium, 301 East Fifty-second Street.

The eighteenth game of the world chess championship match between Mikhail Tal of Latvia and Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia, which had been adjourned after forty-one moves the day before, was won by Botvinnik yesterday when the champion resigned without resuming play, according to Tass, the official Soviet news agency.
CAIRO, May 4 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic and President Tito of Yugoslavia have opened a drive to attract Latin America to the neutralist bloc.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 4 -- The Israeli tribunal hearing the case of Adolf Eichmann tried today to stem a flood of vivid but seemingly irrelevant testimony on Nazi atrocities in Poland and Lithuania.

PATERSON, N.J., May 4 -- For members of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun (Nathan Barnert Memorial Temple) and their young organist tomorrow's Sabbath evening service will have special significance.

Cardinal Spellman, concerned over the impact of slum eradication projects on many parishes of the New York Archdiocese, has set up a Committee on Housing and Urban Renewal.

DETROIT, May 4 -- Consolidated net income of the Ford Motor Company for the first quarter of 1961 was $76,200,000, or 47 per cent less than the $143,100,000 cleared in the 1960 period.

Commodities on New York exchanges closed generally lower yesterday in quiet trading. Prices of copper, rubber, wool, coffee and cottonseed oil declined; hides and sugar were mixed, and lead, cocoa and potatoes advanced.
The market for high grade debt investments shifted further toward a sellers' market yesterday, as a new surge of bidding on a broad front tended to outstrip supply in all trading areas.

Harold G. Kern, general manager of the Hearst newspapers and publisher of The Boston Record-American and Sunday Advertiser, has been appointed chairman of the executive committee of the Hearst Corporation. He succeeds the late Martin F. Huberth.
Fiery chrysanthemums and roses arched above the Hudson River last night and the boom of rockets echoed through the tall apartment buildings of Riverside Drive and West End Avenue.

The strike of 106 clerical employes against the French Line enters its eighth day without prospects of a settlement.

The United Nations Mission of the Republic of China and the Office Equipment Manufacturers Institute, Inc., have taken space through two subleases in the new Pfizer Building at 235 East Forty-second Street, northwest corner of Second Avenue.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Kennedy re-established today a board of private citizens that is to make a continuing study of the Government's intelligence activities.

TAMPA, Fla., May 4 (AP) -"She went down like a rock," said the skipper of the Albatross, the sea-going school that Tuesday in the Gulf of Mexico, with the loss of six lives.
BONN, Germany, May 4 -- In another move calculated to stem the flow of foreign capital into West Germany, the Federal Bank today lowered the country's bank rate by one-half per cent to 3 per cent.
A new rowing association, designed to spur interest in crew among the smaller colleges, will come into official being tomorrow.

LOS ANGELES, May 4 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers obtained Dick Farrell, a relief pitcher, from the Philadelphia Phillies tonight for Don Demeter, an outfielder, and Charlie Smith, a rookie infielder.

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 4 -- President Romulo Betancourt presented today a six-month budget of 2,920,000,000 bolivars ($872,000,000 at the official rate). He proposed new taxes and reductions in expenses to cut the deficit to 350,000,000 bolivars.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Two Westinghouse Electric Corporation officials told Senate investigators today that they had only high motives when they conspired with competitors to fix prices in violation of the antitrust laws.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The Government proposed today that issues in the three-day National Airlines strike be submitted to arbitration.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- "If the Republicans stay unified," said General Eisenhower at Gettysburg this week, the word "stay" implying that they are, "they will win the House in 1962." But the fact is that the Administration's three major legislative victories thus far were accomplished only by a Republican split in the House.

MANY reasons have been given for the decline of realism in modern art. Some persons say that today's deep knowledge of the physical nature of the world has destroyed its appearance as an inspiration. ALBANY, May 4 -- Joseph F. Finnegan, former director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, will become the first full-time chairman of the State Mediation Board on June 1.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The United States sees the battle against poverty as the "real issue" in the Western Hemisphere, Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today. This issue, he added, is one "not to be confused with Sino-Soviet penetration" in Cuba.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright strongly indicated tonight that the Kennedy Administration was considering the possibility of direct military intervention to counteract Communist threats in South Vietnam and Thailand.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Treasury announced today that it had received almost $27,000,000,000 of subscriptions on Monday's offer to sell $7,750,000,000 of one-year certificates and two-year notes. It accepted $510,000,000 more than it went to the market for -- $5,510,000,000 on the certificates and $2,750,000,000 on the notes.

HARRIMAN, N.Y., May 4 -A United States official concerned with disarmament indicated tonight that Washington might suggest a different type of disarmament control if the Soviet Union refused to alter its demand for supervision of a nuclear test ban by a triumvirate.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- A debate over the role of Julius C. Holmes in some profitable ship deals blocked a Senate vote today on his nomination to be Ambassador to Iran.
LOUISVILLE, May 4 -- There were few expressions of disapproval when the trainers of the fifteen horses drew post positions this morning for Saturday's Kentucky Derby.

The George Washington Bridge appeared to be exposed to a theoretical threat of being blown up yesterday, but experts said any such risk was "remote" at worst.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the nation's third largest copper producer, had a consolidated net income of $8,853,084 in the quarter ended on March 31, Robert G. Page, president, reported yesterday. This was almost double the $4,666,498 cleared in the first quarter of 1960, when operations were curtailed by strikes at mines and refineries.

A program of new music was presented in Carnegie Recital Hall last night by the young men who make up the Composers Circle. Production of lumber in the week ended last Saturday totaled 237,832,000 board feet, compared with 233,426,000 the week before and 253,474,000 board feet a year ago.

PARIS, May 4 (Reuters) -Former Gen. Maurice Challe, leader of last month's abortive revolt in Algeria, was taken to the Paris law courts today to be interrogated by an examining magistrate.

Vice President Johnson warned last night that the Communist world offensive was likely to "reach a peak of intensity, frequency and diversity during the next twelve to eighteen months."

APPLETON, Wis., May 4 -- The bad news of the last month at home and abroad has clearly increased the strength of the Goldwater Republicans in the Middle West. Unemployment and a slack economy at home and the defeats in Cuba and Laos have all encouraged the belief that something is fundamentally wrong, and this, in turn, has provided a more sympathetic atmosphere for the attractive and energetic conservative Senator from Arizona.

MANILA, May 4 (UPI) -Robert Ezra McCann, an American business man who spent ten years in a Chinese Communist prison, died today of cancer at the United States hospital at Clark Air Force Base, north of Manila. He was 60 years old.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 4 -- Rutgers University has closed admissions for next fall at resident colleges in this city and has set up waiting lists of qualified applicants.

" Those 163 Days: A Southern Account of Sherman's March from Atlanta to Raleigh," by John M. Gibson, will be published by Coward-McCann on May 29. Mayor Wagner told a group of his advisers yesterday that it was "crucial" that the city improve its competitive position with private industry in obtaining and holding "the bet possible talent for our municipal services."
Paul O'Dwyer, younger brother of former Mayor William O'Dwyer, said yesterday that he was seriously considering entering the Democratic primary as a candidate for Controller.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 4 -- Danish farmers' organizations called on their members today to halt all supplies for the domestic and export markets Monday.
LOS ANGELES, May 4 (AP) Ron Hansen drove in four runs, two of them with a game-winning single in the thirteenth inning, as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Los Angeles Angels, 8 -- 7, tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- Business sales perked up in March and inventories fell sharply as auto makers geared production closer to sales, the Department of Commerce reported today.
MOSCOW, May 4 -- The Russian Republic decreed today that persons convicted of engaging in private enterprise or as idlers should be banished to forced labor in restricted localities.
Thomas P. Burke, a 30-year-old English teacher, was held in $5,000 bail yesterday in Felony Court on charges of burglary and attempted rape.

The Maritimes Trade Department of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations made public yesterday its "vigorous" opposition to a seven-member council appointed by the Administration to study the problems of the nation's merchant marine.

The Federal Reserve System added $495,100,000 to its holdings of Treasury bills in the week ended last Wednesday. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which reported the transaction, said it was the largest such addition since the week ended July 2, 1958, when $502,000,000 of bills was purchased.
A House committee in Washington yesterday rejected shipping industry objections to a strong maritime regulatory bill.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) -- A Convair cost analyst said today his company had invented jobs for union employes, at a cost of $692,000 to the Government, to prevent strikes during work on the Atlas missile.
ALBANY, May 4 -- Governor Rockefeller said today he would start an inquiry into the state's bingo laws and their administration as soon as he could find a qualified investigator to do the work.
Process Lithographers, Inc., New York, announced yesterday that it had agreed to buy a substantial amount of the authorized but unissued capital shares of the Bartell Broadcasting Corporation.

One who has is Marguerite Buck, who in 1944 set up Marguerite E. Buck Enterprises, reported to be the only Educational Hair Fashion Office in the world.
THE world has been in love with emeralds since Cleopatra first commanded her lapidaries to carve her image on the green crystals of Nubia.

Daily average borrowing by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $24,000,000 to $61,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements dropped $227,000,000 to $505,000,000.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today expelled two members of long standing from the securities business for alleged multi-million dollar stock manipulations.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The House Science and Astronautics Committee restored today part of the $182,000,000 cut by President Kennedy's budget aides from the coming year's space program.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon defended the Administration's tax proposals for three and a half hours today against criticism by legislators of both parties.
IN writing and performance, Jean Genet's "The Blacks" at the St. Marks Playhouse is a brilliantly sardonic and lyrical tone poem for the theatre.
CHICAGO, May 4 -- The University of Chicago today inaugurated with traditional ceremony its new chancellor, Dr. George Wells Beadle, a Nobel Prize winner in 1958.
C.L. Sulzberger urges in his column of April 22, dealing with the Cuban situation: "We must obscure our methods of cold warfare and get the C.I.A. right out of public life."
Roman Catholics in the country now number more than 42,000,000, or about 24 per cent of the population, the Official Catholic Directory reported yesterday.
TRENTON, May 4 -- Governor Rockefeller held out the promise here today that New York would cooperate further to empower the Port of New York Authority to deal with New Jersey rail commuter problems.
LONDON, May 4 -- Profit taking hit prices on the stock market here today although most losses were small.
President Lincoln's twenty-day ultimatum to Southern armies "to disperse and return peaceably to their respective abodes" expired 100 years ago today.
BOSTON, May 4 (AP) -Unionized shoe workers, confronted with dwindling job opportunities, called unanimously today for a thirty-five-hour work week and more restrictions on shoe imports.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia forecast from the White House today that peace talks between France and the Algerian Nationalists would begin at Evian-les-Bains, France, next Thursday.

A TROUT fisherman in this cranky season, already three weeks late and still full of rain, snow and wind, can't afford to bank much for the week-end on what fishing conditions are today. Storms have been fouling everything up too frequently.

WHO would ever have imagined that growing tobacco in Connecticut could be as socially involved and emotionally exhausting as it is made to appear in the Warner Brothers' film, "Parrish," which opened at the Music Hall yesterday!
TRENTON, May 4 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner signed a bill today postponing for one year the effective date of legislation designed to alleviate New Jersey's property assessment problem.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These rates do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.

Early this month some residents of the near-by Connecticut region of Ridgefield, Weston, Westport and Norwalk will bring north from winter storage at Oxford, Md., the well-known twin-screw sixty-five-foot motor yacht Helianthus.
St. John's, retaining its Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference lead, scored seven runs in the eighth inning and won, 9 -- 1, from Manhattan at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

YONKERS, May 4 -- Apmat of Australia, all 16 hands 3 inches of him, outfaced Bye Bye Byrd in the final thirty yards of the mile-and-a-half race tonight and won the $50,000 International Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Mrs. Esther Van Wagoner Tufty, president of the 1,600-member American Women in Radio and Television, which is celebrating its tenth anniversary in convention here, strode into the Statler Hilton hotel suite once occupied by President Eisenhower, settled herself in a comfortable chair and pulled out her familiar pince-nez.
Workers in private industry got the word yesterday from the Commerce and Industry Association not to count on four-day week-ends over Memorial Day and the Fourth of July.
DETROIT, May 4 -- Retail sales of new, domestically built passenger cars continued to rise in the final ten days of April, but remained far below the daily rate of a year before.
The city's ban against folk singing in Washington Square Park was upheld yesterday by the State Supreme Court.

ALBANY, May 4 -- Senator Walter J. Mahoney today appointed a personal adviser and a relative by marriage, John J. Sullivan of Buffalo, as Secretary of the State Senate, a job that pays $20,486 a year.
A record number of 2,460 entries has been received for the United States Golf Association's Open championship. This total exceeds the previous high of 2,153 established a year ago.

In these days of inflation, bondholders seldom reap more than they expect. But a foreign exchange windfall awaits holders of the Republic of Austria's 5 1/2 per cent issue of external bonds marketed here in December of 1958.

Earnings of American Metal Climax, Inc., for the first quarter fell to $7,557,000, or 53 'cents a share, from $9,568,000, or 67 cents a share, in the 1960 period, Walter Hochschild, chairman, announced yesterday at the annual meeting here.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., May 4 -- Julius LeVonne Chambers, a 24-year-old Negro student, has achieved the highest honor at the University of North Carolina Law School -- editor in chief of The North Carolina Law Review.

Only a few days ago President Kennedy appealed to the press with the hope that the press itself would censor news items in the interest of securing a more psychologically fit nation. The rebuttal to President Kennedy's appeal came most vehemently from those who could only be called purists of democracy.
The construction industry and its trade unions have worked out an arrangement to avoid strikes and other labor troubles in building the 1964 65 New York Worlds Fair at Flushing Meadow.

After reporting to President Kennedy and consulting with the National Security Council, Arthur H. Dean, chief American delegate to the Geneva nuclear test ban conference, returns to it for a last ditch effort to win Soviet agreement to a treaty banning such tests under adequate inspection and control.
BLUE POINT, L.I., May 4 -The Suffolk Republican party's executive committee recommended W. Royden Klein of Old Field today for an interim appointment as Suffolk County Judge.

LOUISVILLE, May 4 -- Johnny Longden leaned against the wire fence that borders the backstretch at Churchill Downs on this glorious spring morning. His hands were plunged into the pockets of his quilted zipper jacket and a pork-pie hat supplied a top frame for his wizened features.
CHICAGO, May 4 -- The first use of the Sabin oral poliomyelitis vaccine in a community-wide program was described today as "highly effective."
The Bankers Trust Company announced yesterday that three vice presidents had been elected. Those promoted were Ellsworth Donnell, Frank J. Jones and John B. Young.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -Congress sent to President Kennedy today legislation to create seventy-three new Federal judgeships.

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 4 -Talks to work out the machinery of an armistice in Laos are scheduled to begin at noon tomorrow between representatives of the pro-Western Vientiane Government and those of the pro-Communist and neutralist rebels.

The scholarship fund of the New York Federation of Music Clubs will receive the proceeds of a tour on May 21 of the homes of prominent music patrons. They include Mrs. Elinor Lewenthal of 30 East Seventy-first Street, Edward D. Stone of 7 East Sixty-seventh Street and Mrs. G. Hilmar Lundbeck of 1 Beekman Place.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 4 -- Burgess Schuster of Brooklyn i won his secondgame in two days as New York University defeated Princeton, 17-2, on Stadium Field today.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The United States Information Agency has stopped taking polls abroad on who is winning the "cold war," a spokesman said today. The decision was said to have been made with White House approval last February.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended last Saturday were 3 per cent below the level of a year earlier.
Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon sounded a note of "loyal opposition" yesterday to the Kennedy Administration.
NEW DELHI, India, May 4 -- The United States Peace Corps hopes to send up to 100 young Americans to India late this year, R. Sargent Shriver the corps' director, said here today.
Two plays by the late Bertolt Brecht, prolific German dramatist, currently represented in New York by "The Threepenny Opera" and "In the Jungle of Cities," have been earmarked for Broadway.

A five-man committee has been appointed by the United States Figure Skating Association to study what form a memorial to the members of the United States world team killed in an airplane crash in Belgium last February should take.
BETHPAGE, L.I., May 4 -- A forest of evergreen trees is being developed here by the children of the Plainedge Public Schools.
The wholesale commodity price index eased to 87.4 on Wednesday from 87.6 on Tuesday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 85.6 on April 27, 1960.

Three more schools were closed yesterday in the Fire Department's ninety-day inspection of every public, parochial and private school in the city. Seven schools have been closed entirely or in part since Monday.
The General Dynamics Corporation announced yesterday the creation of five new operating divisions, two major organizational groups and a realignment of corporate executive responsibility.

A convicted slayer, who had been paroled from prison last June and within weeks was alleged to have killed two elderly men in Queens, was confined yesterday to jail to stand trial in the double slaying.

PARIS, May 4 -- A message from former President Dwight D. Eisenhower congratulating President de Gaulle on his triumph over the recent mutiny in Algeria was made public today by the office of President de Gaulle.

William Ewart Gladstone, eminent Prime Minister of England, is reported to have said that when the security of the nation is at stake treaties theretofore made which if adhered to would endanger the national safety must be disregarded. Sir Winston Churchill has also said that there is virtue in being inconsistent when consistency jeopardizes the national interest.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 4 (AP) -- Samuel Goldwyn, the film producer, won a victory today in Federal Court in his antitrust suit against the Twentieth Centutry-Fox Film Corporation and three subsidiaries.

In its first calendar year following consolidation of other companies, the United Industrial Corporation showed a loss of $6,442,836 in 1960, the holding company reported yesterday. Its seven operating units had sales of $37,185,301 last year.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -Vice President Johnson has quietly shunted aside another Democrat, Senator Albert Gore of Tennessee, from his place as one of the Senate advisers to the nuclear test ban meetings at Geneva.

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub team matches that had been postponed on Tuesday because of rain were completed yesterday. Led by Mrs. Bernard Freeman, Inwood defeated Fresh Meadow, 15 to 0, over the victor's course.
The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday it was preparing to televise a college credit course in government next fall.
Licenses for real estate brokers and salesmen will be extended from one year to two years at an increase in fees under a new state law. The changes become effective Nov. 1.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was represented today as believing that inadequate military planning contributed to the failure of the Cuban invasion.

PITTSBURGH, May 5 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers exploded for fifteen hits and took advantage of five Pittsburgh errors tonight, overpowering the Pirates, 10 -- 0. It was Bob Friend's first loss of the season.

The nineteenth game of the world chess championship match between Mikhail Tal of Latvia and Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia was adjourned yesterday after forty-one moves, according to Tass, the official Soviet news agency.

HIN HEUP, Laos, May 5 -Military representatives of the pro-Western Laotian Government and the pro-Communist Pathet Lao rebels held a preliminary conference here today on machinery for continuing the cease-fire that became effective Wednesday.
Twenty-two airlines were still trying yesterday in Montreal to reach an agreement on trans-Atlantic air cargo rates to replace the pact that expires on June 30.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 5 -- Emperor Halle Selassie has donated his Genetta Leul Palace and its grounds as the nucleus for Ethiopia's first university, Premier Aklilou Abdewold announced today in a speech marking the twentieth anniversary of Ethiopia's liberation from Italian occupation.

BALTIMORE, May 5 (AP) -The outcome of the fight for control of the Alleghany Corporation will not be known for at least ten more days.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 5 -- Following is a partial transcript of the radio conversation between Comdr. Alan B. Shepard Jr. and the Mercury control center during the space flight today:
Prices of world sugar futures rose yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange in one of the heaviest trading sessions this year.
PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- In the ten years since he joined the Giants, Willie Howard Mays has made believers of even the most sophisticated baseball fans.

Although the United Nations at its last General Assembly did not debate the Hungarian question, its members heard in the dying hours of the session an eloquent statement from Adlai Stevenson regretting the omission; the matter has been deferred to the Sixteenth Assembly.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Kennedy Administration plans to lay before Congress next year a tax reform program that will include reduction of individual income taxes.
IN Bermuda, "at a cocktail party which had reached midnight and was still rolling," a lady asked James Thurber to stop arguing and to start singing.
Asia is seeing a marked awakening "to the need and desirability of fertility control," a nationwide conference of population experts was told here yesterday.
THAT all too rare element of current TV, an original ninety-minute drama, and a curiously intriguing one at that, was presented last night on Channel 4's "Hallmark Hall of Fame.'
CLEVELAND, May 5 (AP) -A rookie, Ed Hobaugh, held the Cleveland Indians to five hits in pitching the Washington Senators to a 5-2 victory tonight.

The Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation has completed arrangements to buy the Circle Weld Manufacturing Corporation and is negotiating to acquire Curtis Laboratories, Inc., John Carter, president of Fairchild, announced at the annual meeting here yesterday.
A settlement in the week-old strike of clerical workers against the French Line was reached late yesterday afternoon.

The New England Woodwind Quintet, which made a successful New York debut last year, returned to Carnegie Recital Hall late yesterday afternoon to play another program. The list of works this time contained Vivaldi's Concerto for Flute, Oboe and Bassoon, Elliott Carter's Woodwind Quintet, Oscar Lorenzo-Fernandez' Suite for Wind Quintet (heard in its first New York performance), Gunther Schuller's Suite, and Anton Reicha's Quintet in E flat.

It was seventy years ago yesterday that, amid addresses by clergymen and dignitaries, amid music conducted by Walter Damrosch and a nervous Russian named Peter Ilyich Tchaikovsky, the new Carnegie Hall was opened. Ever since then the auditorium has been symbolic of the best in music.
An unconscious 4-year-old boy was rescued from a fire in his home in Brooklyn yesterday after searches by an off-duty fireman had been thwarted by heavy smoke.
NO program in broadcasting's history ever evoked the drama, excitement and prayers that attended the trip into space of Comdr. Alan B. Shepard Jr. of the Navy.
SYRACUSE, May 5 (UPI) -Nearly 1,000 students at Syracuse University held a rally today to protest reports that the university was attempting to stop dating between students of different races.

ENSENADA, Mexico, May 5 (UPI) -- The sixty-seven-foot yawl Chubasco, her spinnaker flying in a light wind, sailed across the finish line first today in the fourteenth annual yacht race from Newport Beach, Calif., to Todos Santos Bay.
The Navy said yesterday it was changing some long-accepted practices in shipbuilding as a result of the fire aboard the carrier Constellation here last December.

HARRIMAN, N.Y., May 5 -Discussions in the American Assembly today disclosed deep pessimism about the prospects of an agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union on stopping nuclear tests or on any other phase of disarmament.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- A memorial to Abraham Lincoln in Spencer County, Ind., was recommended today by the National Park Service.
LONDON, May 5 (Reuters) -- An Archdeacon of the Church of England flatly denied the existence of the devil today and quoted his own experience in a thunderstorm as proof.

CHICAGO, May 5 (AP) -Trade in soybean futures split down the middle today with old crop contracts again under heavy selling pressure and the new crop months moving ahead on buying described as investment demand.
PARIS, May 5 -- France's Foreign Minister sought today to quell rumors that United States agents were involved in the recent Algerian mutiny but he stopped short of a flat denial.
Some 9,000 business organizations worked together for more than two years to help launch the first American astronaut into space yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- In a break with tradition, the National School Boards Association voted today to take action on national educational issues.

BRASILIA, May 5 -- Brazil will not oppose a meeting of American foreign ministers on the Cuban problem if other countries in the hemisphere want one, Foreign Minister Afonso Arinos de Melo Franco said tonight.

The Board of Education's efforts to improve the school program will reach down to the kindergarten level next fall.
The successful flight of America's first astronaut, Comdr. Alan B. Shepard Jr., roused the country yesterday to one of its highest peaks of exultation since the end of World War II.
Directors of the California Packing Corporation (Calpak) proposed yesterday a two-forone split of the common stock and a rise in the dividend.
CHICAGO, May 5 -- Following are excerpts from the speech delivered today by former Vice President Richard M. Nixon to the Executives Club of Chicago:

WILMINGTON, Del., May 5 (AP) -- Chancellor Collins J. Seltz dismissed yesterday a stockholder suit against Chemical Fund of New York, a mutual fund organization. The suit charged that the fund paid an excesssive management fee to F. Eberstadt Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent to 119.3 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 5 (AP) -- An object more fiery than the brightest star flashed across the skies north of Puerto Rico in the early morning darkness on Sept. 9, 1959.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -President Kennedy said today that the assignment of United States armed forces to South Vietnam would be one of several important matters Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson would discuss on his coming trip to Asia. [Opening statement and Question 4, Page 14.]
MIAMI, May 5 -- The Castro regime's strongest attack yet on Roman Catholic priests was broadcast tonight to the Cuban people.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 5 -- The new Government headed by Premier Theo Leferre of the Christian Social party and Vice Premier Paul Henri Spaak, Socialist, won its initial test of confidence in the lower house of parliament tonight.
TRENTON, May 5 (UPI) -- The fossil remains of a giant sea serpent 75,000,000 years old have been unearthed in Gloucester County mineral diggings, the State Museum announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- A State Department spokesman said today that apparently no United States secrets were given away by the British spy, George Blake, who was sentenced to forty-two years' imprisonment for having given the Soviet Union British secrets.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 5 (AP) -- Jack Kralick of the Minnesota Twins turned in another sterling pitching performance today, stopping Boston, 5 -- 1, on a six-hitter before 3,937 fans.
A fast track and a field of thirteen are expected for today's sixty-first running of the $60,200 Carter Handicap at Aqueduct.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Since Adam anxiously traded in a rib to create a mate, women have been talking and, despite male efforts to muzzle them, women's success in communications continues to become increasingly important.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 5 (UPI) -- Premier Jafar Sharif-Imami and his Cabinet resigned today under the pressure of anti-Government demonstrations in support of higher pay for teachers.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Kennedy and President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia expressed the "conviction" today that an orderly process of ending colonial rule was "essential to the promotion of human welfare, the consolidation of peace and the encouragement of the striving African peoples."
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 5 -- The Congolese Government closed river traffic today between here and Brazzaville, capital of the former French Congo.
Refrigerated containers for transport of chilled meat, fruit and vegetables are being developed by Canadair for the CL-44 swing-tail freighter prone.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -The Voice of America told the world in thirty-five languages today of the space flight by Comdr. Alan B. Shepard Jr.
Thousands of airline passengers were forced to use private cars and taxicabs yesterday when bus service between Manhattan and the three metropolitan airports was interrupted by a strike.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- President Kennedy signed the bill raising the minimum wage today.
The abolition of the Federal Office of Civil Defense and Mobilization was called for yesterday by the Civil Defense Protest Committee.
NEW DELHI, India, May 5 -W. Averell Harriman, United States Ambassador at Large, conferred with Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today on the Laos situation.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points off to 10 points up yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Kennedy declared today that the United States had no plans to train Cuban exiles as a separate force here or in any other country "at this time."
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- An Air Force surplus aluminum extrusion plan in Adrian, Mich., was sold to the Harvey Aluminum Company today for $3,626,100.

The shocking conditions that have grown up around the promotion and management of bingo games as revealed in a week's hearings by the State Commission of Investigation certainly demand the further exploration that Governor Rockefeller has promised.

Events today: National Music Week Orchestra, Julius Grossman, conductor, Town Hall, 2:40 P.M.; Sonya Monosoff, violinist, and Louise Rood, violist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 2:30; Charles Milgrim, pianist, Town Hall, 5:30; Music Education League's annual winners' concert, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30 and 8:15; the Weavers, folk singers, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.

BERLIN, May 4 -- The vast voluntary outpouring of West Berliners for the May Day celebration was an avowal of faith that was doubly impressive because of the city's relaxed, almost serene, spring mood.

YONKERS, May 5 -- The owner and the driver of False Step, the pride of New Zealand, who was ordered scratched from the $50,000 International Pace at Yonkers Raceway, do not intend to make an international incident out of what happened here Thursday night.
TOKYO, May 5 -- The New York Philharmonic was an outstanding attraction of a three-week festival of international music known as the "1961 Tokyo East-West Music Encounter" that began April 16.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today that imports of green coffee in March totaled 295,500,000 pounds valued at $97,200,000.

As millions of his countrymen watched and prayed, a slim rocket bearing Navy Commander Alan Shepard rose majestically to a height of 115 miles and traveled 300 miles down the Atlantic range, where, exactly nineteen minutes after take-off, the happy astronaut was hauled aboard a waiting helicopter in apparently perfect physical condition, "feeling fine."

Two concerns manufacturing furniture and a manufacturer of floor coverings have leased space in the Decorators Center Building at 307 to 321 East Sixty-second Street. The structure was opened recently by Joseph D. Rosenblatt as a headquarters for interior decorators and furniture concerns.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 5 -- Despite a pair of 7's, Tim Holland led the qualifiers in the William D. Richardson Memorial tourney with a 74 today. The competition at the Seawane Club marked the official opening of the Long Island Golf Association's season.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin said today that the deepening of the channels in the harbor of Superior, Wis., and Duluth, Minn., would contribute to the economic development of the entire Midwest.
Terminal Barber Shops, Inc., announced yesterday that sixteen barber shops and two beauty salons that were closed last Monday by a strike would reopen on Monday under a new union agreement.

" The French Army is always wrong." Brig. Gen. Charles de Gaulle is reported to have said this a few months ago when units of the French Army threatened a mutiny such as that in which part of the army last month engaged.

CROTON - ON - HUDSON, N.Y., May 5 -- On the 123d day after Christmas, a pair of cardinals, one nest and five pale blue, speckled eggs were found decorating a discarded Christmas tree in a garage here.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Kennedy sent Arthur H. Dean, his negotiator on a nuclear test ban treaty, back to Geneva today with an implied warning to Moscow that the United States might not continue the talks much longer without some prospect of a safeguarded treaty.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -An official of the American Council for Judaism today accused the United States Government of having left American Jews vulnerable to the "deliberate Zionist policy to alter the status of all who would be known as Jews."
LONDON, May 5 -- Britain and the Soviet Union have agreed on the instructions to be given the International Control Commission for supervising the truce in Laos.

FORT ERIE, Ont., May 5 (AP) -- Charlie Boland, who had a cast removed from a fractured ankle so he could ride at the Fort Erie meeting, died in a hospital today of head injuries suffered in a racing fall on Wednsday.
ART historians of the future will have no easy time finding the common denominator of art's many manifestations today, a sample of whose variety may be found in Manhattan galleries this week.

GAMES are taking on an international flavor at Georg Jensen, where a new collection from England, Spain, Italy and France has just arrived on the ground floor. These adult games, which range from $6 to $200, include chess and checkers sets, compendiums (multiple game sets), roulette wheels -- and new games of skill such as Space Tilt and Jugg-o-Lette.
The Pearl River Valley Water Supply District, Mass., borrowed yesterday $8,800,000 on serial bonds secured by service revenues and assigned taxes.

LISBON, Portugal, May 5 (Reuters) -- About 3,400 troops sailed today for the Portuguese territory of Angola. It was the largest group of soldiers sent to the West African territory since an outbreak of terrorist attacks began there seven weeks ago.

After several weeks of major activity in the market for new capital, next week will provide a respite. Major fixed-interest issues slated for marketing total $114,775,000, compared with nearly $300,000,000 a week earlier.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- An even greater effort in the exploration of space was promised today by President Kennedy.
CHICAGO, May 5 -- Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon urged President Kennedy today to rally the American people for a new start in American foreign policy.
" RETURN TO PEYTON PLACE," which opened at the Paramount and Normandie yesterday, is more a take-out of a mean and selfish mother than it is a sequel to the film, "Peyton Place."
NEW ORLEANS, May 5 -- A voter registrar appearing before the Federal Civil Rights Commission here today failed the test she uses to determine whether applicants are qualified to register.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 5 -Ceylon's House of Representatives passed a bill today setting up a state corporation for the import and distribution of petroleum products.

The head of the Fair Play for Cuba Committee, which favors the regime of Premier Fidel Castro, has been ordered by the Senate Internal Security subcommittee to produce his group's lists of members, chapters and student councils.

SELDOM on display, fresh green parsley can be bought at most greengroceries at any time of the year. In cold weather, when it is not available from near-by sources, it is shipped north from Texas in quantities to meet all the demand.
City school officials yesterday ordered Thomas P. Burke, a 30-year-old teacher accused of attempted rape, to report to the Board of Education Monday for questioning.
Thomas H. Quinn has been elected a director of the Park Electrochemical Corporation, Flushing, Queens. He is president of the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company of New York.

BONN, Germany, May 5 -The Common Market summit conference scheduled for May 19 here was postponed today when the six Foreign Ministers failed to agree on the extent of political consultation possible without Britain's participation.

HACKENSACK, N.J. May 5 -- Judge Arthur J. O'Dea today vacated an order he had signed April 12 giving Michael Kearney of Fort Lee, Independent Democratic candidate for Governor, the right to have his name on the ballot in November.

Jerry Finkelstein, chairman of the Struthers Wells Corporation, maker of industrial and marine equipment, has been elected chairman and a director of All-State Properties, Inc., a real estate operating and development company.

The National Maritime Union, the nation's largest union of unlicensed seamen disclosed yesterday that it was reactivating its long-dormant licensed officers division.

LONDON, May 5 -- Princess Margaret, married a year tomorrow, appears to have abdicated her position as Britain's Crown Princess of fashion. LONDON, May 5 -- The space flight by Comdr. Alan B. Shepard Jr. was saluted in Britain today as a great technical achievement and an act of supreme courage.
LOS ANGELES, May 5 -- Perhaps it was that playing under the critical eye of their former manager, Casey Stengel, had the Yankees feeling a trifle self-conscious. It may have been something else.
COLUMBIA, Mo., May 5 (AP) -- The Missouri honor award for distinguished service in journalism was presented today to seven journalists, an American newspaper and a foreign newspaper.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today a plan of National Airlines to offer 400,000 shares of Pan American World Airways capital stock for public sale.

The bond market lapsed into inactivity not uncommon to a Friday yesterday. Severe limitations were imposed yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg on procedures to be followed on Monday at the annual meeting of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc.

THE road to Miltown is paved with excess baggage, improperly stoppered perfume bottles, wrinkled dresses and wasted suitcase space. And all this could be avoided, according to Mrs. Jeanne Mertz, if people would only do a little more planning before they begin to pack.
LOUISVILLE, May 5 -- Not since Floyd Collins got stuck in a cave for seventeen days in 1925 has there been an event to cause so much hullabaloo in Kentucky as a Derby week-end.

PITTSBURGH, May 5 (AP) -- A schoolboy who used his car as a battering ram to save two soldiers from possible death on a train track was honored today by the Carnegie Hero Fund commission.

The highly praised children's musical, "Young Abe Lincoln," which made the big jump from Off Broadway to Broadway, will return to its original home grounds next week, a victim of higher economics.

History's longest war doubtless is the struggle of man against insect. Despite the length of the battle, however, there is considerable disagreement over which side is winning.
Former Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy said yesterday that his chances of running for Mayor in November were "remote."
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- President Kennedy today barred Government officials from outside employment or activity for private gain.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- As people move out of this world into space, they may also move out of provincial ways of thinking and see the whole world differently, an eminent psychiatrist said here today. He advocated a program of psychological "peacefare" toward this end.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman denied today Republican contentions that there were no guidelines or standards over powers he might exercise under the Administration's new long-range farm program.

MOSCOW, May 5 (Reuters) -- The Moscow radio tonight described Alan Shepard's manned space flight as commendable. It said the United States might eventually put a man into orbit around the earth as Russia had done.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- An international financial rescue package worth more than $2,000,000,000 is being prepared for Brazil. Negotiations, already well advanced, involve the United States, six Western European countries, Japan and the International Monetary Fund.

LONDON, May 5 -- The Labor party set the parliamentary machinery in motion today in an effort to return Viscount Stansgate to the House of Commons as Anthony Wedgwood Benn, Labor Member for Southeast Bristol.

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 5 -- Drilling of the first well for the Venezuelan Government's oil company will start tomorrow, Dr. Juan Pablo Perez Alfonso, Minister of Mines, announced today. The contract has been let to the Delta Company, and the well is expected to start producing by the end of next month.
St. Luke's Hospital Chapel, long regarded by architects as a work of art, has been restored to its original beauty after a destructive fire in 1959.

Rabindranath Tagore was born 100 years ago today in an India where a bloody revolt against the British power had just been sternly repressed. He died twenty years ago, too soon to see the British flag flutter down at the Red Fort of New Delhi and a new flag go up into the Indian breeze.

" I WANT to be first because I want to be first," Alan Bartlett Shepard Jr. once answered when asked why he wished to be the initial American in space. And it was as if this cool, aloof Naval commander was just hard-nosed enough to drive himself to be first.

TRENTON, May 5 -- New Jersey Republicans today accused Gov. Robert B. Meyner of "padding" Civil Service payrolls, of lacking financial responsibility and of "demoralizing" the state police.

To most motorosts and many experts "chrome" has become the generic word for any bright metal on automobiles. But all that glitters is not chrome. Sometimes it is stainless steel, plated zinc, plated steel or aluminum. The term even is being applied when the item is not metal at all, for some trim par are plastic.

The overthrow of the Tokugawa Shogunate in Japan is discussed in two books to be published this month. Princeton University Press will issue on May 22 "Sakamoto Ryoma and the Meiji Restoration," by Marius B. Jansen.

EAST DERRY, N.H., May 5 (AP) -- The whole town -- and more -- turned out today to help the overjoyed parents of America's first astronaut celebrate Comdr. Alan B. Shepard Jr.'s successful flight into space.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The reactor that will power the first nuclear merchant ship, Savannah, was patented this week while it was undergoing tests in a shipyard at Camden, N.J.
State Senator Daniel G. Albert, a Republican of Rockville Centre, L.I., yesterday was elected chairman of the committee that will draft bills to carry out the state court reorganization plan.
PENSACOLA, Fla., May 5 -An exhausted Navy physicist described last night his record-setting balloon trip into the stratosphere, which ended in the drowning of his medical observer.
Recently something happened that seems to me very newsworthy -- in contrast to the disturbing daily events that must be printed.
POTEAU, Okla., May 5 -- A vicious tornado tore through two tiny eastern Oklahoma communities near here tonight, killing at least fourteen persons and injuring fifty-seven.
