Mayor Wagner's right to appoint a Charter Revision Commission was upheld by Justice Irving Saypol yesterday in State Supreme Court.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 5 -- Indonesian authorities have temporarily banned the circulation of Time and Life magazine, it was announced today.
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., May 5 (AP) -- A beaming Louise Shepard said today her husband's journey to the fringe of space was "just a baby step" compared to new challenges ahead.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 5 -- United Nations authorities, both here and in Africa, are carefully watching the case of President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province.

St. John's University scored six times in the sixth inning yesterday and went on to a 9-6 Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference victory over Fordham at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- Regional branch banking, safeguarded against "excessive concentration," was advocated as superior to "unit" banking today in a report made by two professors at the University of Chicago graduate school of business.
A cocktail dance has been arranged for May 18 at the St. Regis Roof to raise funds for the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club.
CHICAGO, May 5 (UPI) -The Detroit Tigers blasted the Chicago White Sox' starter, Bob Shaw, for seven hits and six runs in one and two-third innings tonight and won, 8 -- 4.

Many prefatory parties were given in connection with the fifth annual Junior Republic Ball, held last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event benefited the George Junior Republic, a sixty-five-year-old co-educational youth community in Freeville, N.Y.
License Commissioner Bernard J. O'Connell cleared Deputy Commissioner Herbert A. Koehler yesterday of any wrongdoing or impropriety in connection with bingo operations.

GRAND BAHAMA ISLAND, May 5 (AP) -- Commander Alan B. Shepard's "perfect flight" was toasted in champagne when he arrived here today, but doctors waiting to check him over did not allow him to participate.

Before the opening of the market yesterday, the American Stock Exchange assigned Schweickart Co. as specialist in the nineteen issues of stocks of seventeen companies for which the concern of Re, Re Sagarese was specialist.
PARIS, May 5 -- The success of the United States' first attempt to launch a man into space was greeted here with an enthusiasm tempered by the knowledge of the Russians' earlier achievement.

MILWAUKEE, May 5 (AP) -- Chico Cardenas' sacrifice fly in the twelfth inning after a three-run pinch homer by Wally Post in the ninth propelled the Cincinnati Reds to a 6-5 victory over the Milwaukee Braves tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) -- The Food and Drug Administration moved today to break up what Commissioner George P. Larrick described as a "nation wide sea water swindle."
The space flight of Comdr. will be shown this morning on British television screens as a result of a dual video-taping operation in New York City.
KANSAS CITY, May 5 (AP) -- Heavy rains in southeastern Kansas and western Missouri increased the danger of floods and caused highways to be blocked in numerous places.
OXNARD, Calif., May 5 -- The latest and perhaps the most surprising entrant in the waterdesalting field is a maker of rocket engines.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 5 -- Comdr. Alan B. Shepard Jr. carried with him into space today an American flag donated by the students of the Cocoa Beach Elementary School.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 5 -- Almost every sensation of twist and turn, acceleration and weightlessness that Comdr. Alan B. Shepard Jr. went through today was something that he had been through in make-believe several times while in training.
Four rowing trophies will be at stake today in regattas involving Eastern colleges.

Hunter Moss of Miami, Fla., has joined James D. Landauer Associates, Inc., of New York, as a consultant. He will concentrate on projects outside the city. Mr. Moss, who will continue his own mortgage business in Miami, formerly was a member of the board of governors of the American Society of Real Estate Counselors.
HUNTSVILLE, Ala., May 5 (AP) -- "Go, Redstone, go!" they shouted at Redstone Arsenal today.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, May 5 -- Sir Roy Welensky, Prime Minister of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, declared today that the "racial doctrine" of African nationalism had in it the "seeds of bitter trouble for the Western nations in time to come."

WASHINGTON, May 5 -Federal financing of future Presidential elections was advocated by President Kennedy today. The idea was put forward as his solution to the difficulties and embarrassments of current political fund-raising activities.
LONDON, May 5 -- The stock market ended its bookkeeping account period today in an uncertain mood in the face of fairly heavy profit taking.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Department of Commerce made public today "suggested guidelines" for the Business Advisory Council in its study of the Maritime Commission.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 5 -- A slim, cool Navy test pilot was rocketed 115 miles into space today.

Net income of the Atlantic City Electric Company, Atlantic City, N.J., rose to $1,702,069 in the first quarter from $1,484,698 in the 1960 period. This was equal to 35 cents a share, compared with 32 cents a year earlier.

ABOARD U.S.S. LAKE CHAMPLAIN, May 5 (UPI) -The cherry red glow of a capsule appeared suddenly in the bright blue Bahamas sky today. Just as suddenly, a red and white parachute opened. Alan Shepard was right on target.

The Greater New York Fund has found that one of the best ways of familiariz ing people with the services provided by its 425 hospitals and health and welfare agencies is through the "Come-and See" tour.

NEWARK, May 5 -- The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and its affiliate, the Esso Research and Engineering Company, submitted today a general denial of charges made in a suit filed by two Italian oil companies that a breach of contract had been committed.

LAS VEGAS, May 5 (AP) -Jay Hebert shot another sub-par round of golf today -- a five-under-par 67 -- to keep the lead at the midway mark of the $52,000 Tournament of Champions.

One of the most significant and influential trends of the international movie scene is the so-called "poetical realism" of a burgeoning group of young film creators. The latest advocate of this technique to visit New York is Karel Reisz, director of the highly successful British-made drama, "Saturday Night and Sunday Morning."
LOUISVILLE, May 5 -- Rain, whose only friend till now has been the farmer, acquired another firm adherent today in Jack Price, who trains Carry Back.

CLEVELAND, May 5 (AP) -- Only 213,482 gross tons of iron ore were shipped from upper lake ports by May 1, the American Iron Ore Association reported today. This compared with 5,675,931 gross tons by May 1 in the shipping season of 1960.
Track 4 of the Grand Central-Times Square shuttle will be shut down tomorrow until June 5 for the installation of a tieless, spikeless, rubber and concrete roadbed.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower will discuss the Presidency in a long filmed interview for the Columbia Broadcasting System television network and for posterity.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -President Kennedy promised today that he would give advice on how the average citizen might contribute above his ordinary responsibilities to the advancement of the national interest.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) -- President Kennedy said today he had asked Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg to cooperate closely with Senators investigating labor slowdowns and work stoppages at missile launching sites.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) -- President Kennedy's proposal for a $900,000,000 college scholarship program received a setback in Congress today.

Earnings and sales of Berkshire Hathaway, Inc., fell sharply for the quarter and six months ended on April 1, reflecting a drop in demand for textile products, Malcolm G. Chase Jr., chairman, and Seabury Stanton, president, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Kennedy Administration expects to ask Congress for at least $75,000,000 to provide retraining for the long-term unemployed. Other new anti-recession measures also are being considered.

PARIS, May 5 -- Apart from relationships with the United States and Russia, there are two big questions in Western Europe today. The second is: What will be the relations between France and Germany after Chancellor Adenauer dies?

NEWARK, May 6 -- For almost forty years Newark people have been coming to Eddison Mosiman's shop in search of hard-to-find books. "If Mr. Mosiman doesn't know, no one does," they say.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- John F. Kennedy's first hundred days in the White House came to an end this week. As if the date had real significance, his Republican opponents solemnly weighed the results and found them wanting.

SILVERSTONE, England, May 6 -- In pouring rain, with great pools of water lying on the course, others skidded, spun and plowed into ditches. But Stirling Moss drove smoothly, impeccably and swiftly for 233 miles to win the international trophy race today for intercontinental cars in 2 hours 41 minutes 19 seconds.

MILWAUKEE, May 6 -- Representative Clement J. Zablocki said today that Premier Fidel Castro's May Day speech barring elections had effectively counteracted criticism of the United States for its role in the recent rebel invasion of Cuba.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A bill to promote coordinated rail-barge transportation was introduced this week by Senator E.L. Bartlett.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I. -- With the launching of a replica of a nineteenth-century double-ender fishing boat, Block Island will set sail June 10 on a summer-long celebration of its tercentenary. The christening ceremony at New Harbor, near the Narragansett Hotel, will evoke nostalgia for Block Island's good old days to many elderly islanders and sentimental thrills to summer visitors.

OSLO, Norway, May 6 -- The Foreign Ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization powers began arriving here today for their annual spring meeting and their first close personal appraisal of the Kennedy Administration's new diplomatic team.

HARRISBURG, Pa. -- In recent years, Pennsylvania has been enormously successful in attracting new and expanded industry. Now, the Keystone State, aware that tourism last year added $1,300,000,000 to its business revenue, is offering tourists an opportunity to visit more than fifty of its industrial plants.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., -- In a rare spirit of harmony, member governments have agreed that international tourism is fine and should be promoted by the United Nation. With this aim in mind, they have decided to call a world-wide conference on international travel and tourism to take place not later than 1963, but sooner if possible.

ST. PAUL, May 6 -- Gov. Elmer L. Andersen said this week that Minnesota stood ready to put the Federal depressed areas program to work as soon as the State Legislature voted a $3,000,000 appropriation as a development revolving fund.
